</lemepagenote>

<section type="title-page">

<heading>
GLOSSOGRAPHIA:
OR A
DICTIONARY,
Interpreting all such
Hard Words,
</heading>

Whether Hebrew, Greek, Latin,
Italian, Spanish, French, Teutonick,
Belgick, British or Saxon, as are now used in
our refined English Tongue. 

Also the Terms of Divinity, Law, Phy&shy;
sick, Mathematicks, Heraldry, Anatomy, War,
Musick, Architecture; and of several other Arts
and Sciences Explicated. 

With Etymologies, Definitions, and
Historical Observations on the same. 

Very useful for all such as desire to
understand what they read. 

By T. B. of the Inner-Temple, Barrester. 

LONDON: 

Printed by Tho. Newcomb, and are to be sold by Hum&shy;
phrey Moseley, at the Prince's Arms in St. Pauls
Church-yard, and George Sawbridge at the Bible
on Ludgate-hil. 1656. 

</section>


</page>

<page sig="A1v">


</page>

<page sig="A2r">
<section type="To the Reader">

<heading>
TO THE
READER. 
</heading> 

AFter I had bestowed the waste hours of
some years in reading our best English
Histories and Authors; I found, though
I had gained a reasonable knowledge in
the Latine and French Tongues, as I
thought, and had a smattering both of
Greek and other Languages, yet I was often gravelled
in English Books; that is, I encountred such words, as
I either not at all, or not throughly understood, more
then what the preceding sence did insinuate; For Ex&shy;
ample: 

In the Turkish History I met with Ianizaries, Muf&shy;
ties, Timariots, Basha's, Seraglio's, Shashes,
Turbants, &amp;c. 

In the French History, the Salique Law, <emend err="Appen">Appen&shy;</emend>
nages, Vidams, Daulphin, &amp;c. 


</page>

<page sig="A2v">
In the Spanish, the Escurial, Infanta, Sanbent&shy;
to, &amp;c. 

In the Roman Histories I found often mention of Con&shy;
suls, Tribunes, Dictators, Pretors, Cohorts, Le&shy;
gions, Theaters, Obelisks ; The Capitol, Vatican,
Pasquin &amp;c. 

And in many other Books, mention of several Reli&shy;
gious Orders: as Carmelites, Carthusians, Cister&shy;
sians Theatins, Bonhomes, &amp;c. So likewise both
of ancient and modern Sects; as Arrians, Eutychi&shy;
ans, Iacobites, &amp;c. Anabaptists, Arminians, Erasti&shy;
ans, Traskites, Socinians, Quakers, &amp;c. 

In Books of Divinity, I found Sanhedrim, Vrim
andThummin, Sanctum Sanctorum, Shibboleth,
Hypostatical, Circuminsession, &amp;c. 

In every Mercurius, Coranto, Gazet or Diurnal, I
met with Canizado's, Lantspezado's,
Brigades, Squadrons, Curassiers, Bonemines,
Halts, Juncta's, Paroles, &amp;c. 

In the mouths of Common people, I heard of Piazza,
Balcone, &amp;c. in London : And in the Country, of
Hocktide, Minnyng days, Lurdanes, Quintins, &amp;c. 

Nay, to that pass we are now arrived, that in London
many of the Tradesmen have new Dialects; The Cook
askes you what Dishes you will have in your Bill of
Fare; whether Olla's, Bisques, Hachies, Omelets,
Bouillon's, Grilliades, Ioncades, Fricasses ; with a
Hautgoust, Ragoust, &amp;c. 

The Vintner will furnish you with Montesiascone,
Alicant, Vernaccia, Ribolla, Tent &amp;c. Others with
Sherbet, Agro di Cedro, Coffa, Chocolate, &amp;c, 

The Taylor is ready to mode you into a Rochet, Man&shy;
dillion, Gippen, Iustacor, Capouch, Hoqueton, or a
Cloke of Drap de Bery, &amp;c. 

The Shoo-maker will make you Boots, Whole 


</page>

<page sig="A3r">
Chase, Demi-Chase, or Bottines, &amp;c. 

The Haberdasher is ready to furnish you with a Vi&shy;
gone, Codebec or Castor, &amp;c. The Semstress with a
Crabbat, Toylet, &amp;c. 

By this new world of Words, I found we were slipt into
that condition which Seneca complains of in his time;
When mens minds once begin to enure themselves to
dislike, whatever is usual is disdained : They affect no&shy;
velty in speech, they recal oreworn and uncouth words,
they forge new phrases, and that which is newest is best
liked; there is presumptuous, and far fetching of words:
And some there are that think it a grace, if their
speech hover, and thereby hold the hearer in sus&shy;
pence, &amp;c. 
I beleeved my self not singular in this ignorance; and
that few, without the help of a Dictionary, would be a&shy;
ble to understand our ordinary English Books; I found
nothing considerable in this kind extant, though now ma&shy;
ny make it their study to be learned in our own Language;
and I remembred Aristotles, <term lang="la">Verba valent in usu sicut
&amp; nummi</term>. For these Reasons, and to comply with my
own fancy, I began to compile this Work; which has
taken me up the vacancy of above Twenty years. 

Besides the Words of the nature before specified,
you have here such and so many of the most useful Law&shy;
Terms as I thought necessary for every Gentleman of E&shy;
state to understand, not intending any thing for the stu&shy;
died Professors of that noble Science, there being some
excellent Peeces of that nature already extant 

The several parts of mans body, as the Pia andDu&shy;
ra Mater, the Missentery, Muscles, several sorts of
Veins, and Arteries, &amp;c. with their proper Appellati&shy;
ons; As also the names and qualities of at least ordinary
Diseases, I thought fit for the knowledge of many, who
neither profess the study of Physick, Anatomy nor Chy&shy;
rurgery. 


</page>

<page sig="A3v">
I held it no less necessary for every Gentleman to be
so far seen in Heraldry, as to know (at least) the most
usual Terms; as when a Lyon or other Beast is said to
be Dormant, Passant, Couchant, Saliant, Ram&shy;
pant, Seisant, &amp;c. and what is meant by a Fesse, a
Canton, a Bend, &amp;c. that he may by consequence be able
at least to blazon his own Coat. 

Here are likewise explicated all Latin words, that
are used without alteration in English, as Encomium,
Peccavi, Verbatim, Virago, Bona fide, De bene
esse, &amp;c. And, with these, the terms of many Sciences un&shy;
folded; as of Logick, Astrology, Geometry, Musick,
Architecture, Navigation, &amp;c. with those of our most in&shy;
genious Arts, and Exercises, as Printing, Painting, Jewel&shy;
ling, Riding, Hunting, Hawking, &amp;c 

Yet I will not say I have met with all that might
require Explication, for that were an imployment for
Archymedes, <term lang="la">Pulveris Erythr&aelig;i subducere numerum</term>;
But I have inserted such as are of most use, and best
worth knowledge; that is, <term lang="la"> Qu&aelig; nunc sunt in honore
vocabula</term>. To some words I have added Etymologies,
to others, Historical Observations, as they occured, and
this but <term lang="la">ex obliquo</term>. 

I have avoided Poetical Stories, as much as I could
since they are not necessary to be understood by the Ge&shy;
nerality; And as for Schollars and Poets, there is a copi&shy;
ous Latine Dictionary of them and somewhat of late done
in English by Mr. Ross: Yet sometimes I am forced to touch
a little upon that string; as to tell the story of Pandora, to
make her Box understood; and that of Tantalus, to ren&shy;
der the word Tantalize intelligible. 

I have likewise in a great measure, shun' d the old
Saxon Words; as finding them growing every day more
obsolete then other. Besides there is an excellent Dictiona&shy;
ry thereof shortly expected from the learned Mr. Somner. 


</page>

<page sig="A4r">
Yet even such of those, as I found still in use, are not here
omitted. 

In this Design I met with two Objections; The
first, that my labor would find no end; since our English
Tongue daily changes habit; every fantastical Traveller, 
and homebred Sciolist being at liberty, as to antiquate, and
decry the old, so to coyn and innovate new Words: Which
Horace thus observed. 

<term lang="la">Ut Sylv&aelig; foliis pronos mutantur in annos:
Prima cadunt; ita verborum vetus interit &aelig;tas,
Et juvenum ritu florent modo nata vigentque.
Debemur morti nos, nostraque ----- 
De Arte Poet.</term> 

Signifying hereby that words in Common Tongues, like
leaves, must of necessity have their buddings, their blos&shy;
somings, their ripenings and their fallings: Which old
Chaucer also remarks. 

I know that in form of speech is change
Within a hundred year,and words tho
That hadden price,now wonder nice and strange
Think we them;and yet they spake them so,
And sped as well in love,as men now do . 

This we grant, and confess it impossible to keep Words
of unlearned Tongues from falling and change in tract of
time; which has even happened among the Latine Writers
themselves, when theirs was a spoken tongue as ours now
is; who though they first made their own words, and gave
them their allowance, yet divers of Cecilius Statius, Enni&shy;
us, and Plautus were by posterior Latinists rejected; and 


</page>

<page sig="A4v">
now again many of them, by the last Writers of all (though
before, as it were, by Proclamation put down for baseness) 
are, upon a new Touch, warranted for good, and pass abroad
as Sterling. Thus we see our Latin Dictionaries seldom
or never Reprinted, without some Additions, Corrections,
or Denotations of obsolete Words: So when any conside&shy;
rable supplement of new English Words have legally pass' d
the Mint and Test of our Vertuosi, the same liberty may
be allowed this Work; not derogating at all from the use of
it in the interim. 

The second Objection was, That the use of such words was
not commendable, according to that of C&aelig;sar, <term lang="la">Tanquam sco&shy;
pulum vitari debes verbum infrequens</term> ; and he that should
use them would be subject to the censure of a<term lang="gk">&lambda;&omicron;&rho;&omicron;&delta;&alpha;&#x1F77;&delta;&alpha;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03C2;</term>,
one that prefers the novelty or affected elegance of the phrase
to the nerves and importance of the sence; which is confu&shy;
ted by our best modern Authors, who have both infinitely
enriched and enobled our Language, by admitting and natu&shy;
ralizing thousands of foraign Words, providently brought
home from the Greek, Roman, and French Oratories;
which though, in the untravel' d ears of our Fathers, would
have sounded harsh, yet a few late years have rendred
them familiar even to vulgar capacities. Witness the
learned Works of the Lord Bacon, Mr. Montagu, Sir
Kenelm Digby, Sir Henry Wotton, Mr. Selden, Mr.
Sands, Dr. Brown, Dr Charlton, Dr. Heylnyn, Mr.
Howel &amp;c. Wherein such words are used more or less: To
many of which I have added the Authors names, that I
might not be thought to be the innovator of them. Nor is
it my purpose to become an Advocate for the use of such
Words; let every ones Genius and the quality of the
Subject they treat of be their own Dictator; But cer&shy;
tainly, at least to understand them, can be no unnecessa&shy;
ry burden to the Intellect; since Knowledge is<term lang="la"> Animi pa&shy;
bulum</term>. And ' tis Galens Axiom, Who ever is ignorant of 


</page>

<page sig="A5r">
words shall never judge well of things . Lib.I. de Me&shy;
thod. cap.5. 

My Lord Coke (that Oracle of our Law) 
has left us these words. In School Divinity, 
<note type="rm">
In Pres.
in Com up&shy;
on Littl.
</note>
and among the Glossographers and Inter&shy; 
 preters of the Civil and Canon Laws, in 
Logick, and other Liberal Sciences, you shall meet with
a whole Army of Words; which cannot defend them&shy;
selves in <term lang="la"> Bello Grammaticali</term>, yet are more significant,
compendious, and effectual to declare the true sence
of the matter, then if they were expressed in pure
Latin. 

And Mr. Denham in his quaint Preface to the De&shy;
struction of Troy; As Speech is the Apparel of our 
Thoughts, so are there certain Garbs and Modes of
speaking, which vary with the times; the fashion of
our Clothes not being more subject to Alteration, then
that of our Speech; And this I think Tacitus means,
by that which he calls<term lang="la"> Sermonem temporis istius auribus
accommodatum</term> ; The delight of change being as due to
the curiosity of the Ear, as of the Eye . 

Having thus solved these two main Objections, I may,
with an humble confidence, hope this Book will prove as
useful to our Nation, as that Congenerous Essay, <term lang="fr">Des
Merveilles de Nature</term>), done by Ren&eacute;, is to the French;
which has been Printed almost twenty several times with&shy;
in less then so many years. 

To compile and compleat a Work of this nature and im&shy;
portance, would necessarily require an Encyclopedie of
knowledge, and the concurrence of many learned Heads;
yet. that I may a little secure the Reader from a just ap&shy;
prehension of my disability for so great an Undertaking, I
profess to have done little with my own Pencil; but have
extracted the quintessence of Scapula, Minsheu, Cotgrave,
Rider, Florio, Thomasius, Dasipodius, and Hexams 


</page>

<page sig="A5v">
Dutch, Mr. Davies Welsh Dictionary, Cowels Interpre&shy;
ter, &amp;c. and other able Authors, for so much as tended
to my purpose; and hope I have taken nothing upon trust,
which is not authentick; yet should I not thus adventure
to make it publick, but that it also had the perusal and
approbation of some very Learned, and my Noble Friends. 

It is chiefly intended for the more-knowing Women, and
less-knowing Men; or indeed for all such of the unlearn&shy;
ed, who can but finde in an Alphabet, the word they un&shy;
derstand not; yet I think I may modestly say, the best of
Schollers may in some part or other be obliged by it. For
he that is a good Hebrician, Grecian, and Latinist, per&shy;
haps may be to seek in the Italian, French, or Spanish; or
if he be skil' d in all these, he may here finde some Words,
Terms of Art, or Notions, that have no dependence upon
any of those Languages. 

Such as neither understand Greek nor Latin, may, with
a little pains, and the help of this Book, know the mean&shy;
ing of the greatest part of such words as we now use in
English, and are derived from either of those Languages,
which are many. And to facilitate this, they may do well
to learn the numbers in those Languages, as En, dyo,
treis, &amp;c.<term lang="la"> unus, duo, tres, &amp;c.</term> and such words and par&shy;
ticles as are most used in Composition; as<term lang="gk"> Monos, Hemi,
Pseudos, Tetra, &amp;c.</term> <term lang="la">Circum, Subter, Pr&aelig;ter, Ultra, &amp;c.</term>
And then in simple words to understand but the nature and
difference between a Verb, Verbal, Noun, Participle, &amp;c.
that when they know one of them, they may also compre&shy;
hend all the Derivatives from the same Fountain; as
toillaqueate,illaqueator,illaqueation,illaqueated,
illaqueable,&amp;c. And by once throughly learning these, all
other words of this nature, which are not a few, would seem
easie. 

So likewise for Compound words, knowing Pseudos to
signifie false, they would understand Pseudo Prophet to 


</page>

<page sig="A6r">
be a False Prophet; circum, about or round about, cir&shy;
cumstation, a standing round about, &amp;c. with the like.
And this easiness of understanding all the words that
come from one Root, when one of them is known, made me
forbear to insert the whole number of such words; pre&shy;
suming, if the Reader know one or two of them, he will not
be ignorant of the rest; and I have selected the most diffi&shy;
cult. 

Sometimes the same word is used both Substantively and
Adjectively; asDatary,Expedient,&amp;c. And some&shy;
time both Substantively and Verbally; as Attaque,Re&shy;
prive,&amp;c which, being unrestrained in the use, were al&shy;
most impossible to observe in all words; besides, if it be in&shy;
terpreted in the one acception, it will easily be understood
in the other. 
So likewise there is a liberty in most Adjectives, whe&shy;
ther you will say Optique  (after the French) Optick,
Opticous or Optical ; which I thought unnecessary al&shy;
ways to remark. 

If I say a word is Greek, French, Italian, &amp;c. I
speak not always in rigor; for, commonly the words we bor&shy;
row from other Languages, are a little altered from their
Originals, to make them speak English. 

Something might also be said of the choice of Words, in
our refined English Tongue; which are to be liked and ap&shy;
proved according to their tone, and the sweetness of their
cadence, that is, as they run musically in the Ear. Latin
Verbs of the first Conjugation are more usually converted
into English; as<term lang="la"> contamino</term>, as, to contaminate;<term lang="la"> Recal&shy;
citro</term>, as, to Recalcitrate, &amp;c. then those of the second,
third, and fourth Conjugations. 

I have made use of several Authors of different per&shy;
swasions in Controversial points, both of Religion and
other Literature, which possibly will not please all Readers;
and therefore must crave pardon, in this particular, if 


</page>

<page sig="A6v">
some citations pass under a non-liquent, since the nature
of the Words inforced me to have recourse thereto. 

To conclude, though I may truly say I have taken
much pains in this investigation of Words, yet it is but too
probable, that<term lang="la"> in multiloquio non decrit peccatum</term>; that,
in so great a Circumference, some Lines may not be truly
drawn from the Centre; which yet I hope will not draw an
oblique censure from the Reader, but his pardon rather, and
animadversion; that I may, as St. Austin advises,<term lang="la"> Et scri&shy;
bendo proficere, &amp; proficiendo scribere, &amp; qu&aelig; nescio
discere</term> . De Trin lib.3. cap.I. in Prol. Retract. 

<term lang="la">Rode Caper vites, tamen hic, cum stabis ad Aras,
In tua quod fundi cornua possit erit</term>. 

T.B. 

</section>


</page>

<page sig="A7r">
<section type="poem to the author">

<heading>
TO HIS 

HONORED FRIEND 

Mr. T. B. 

Upon his 

Glossographia. </heading>

HAd Babel, th'old World's Rendevouz
(first mean't
To center Mankinde in one joynt con&shy;
sent
To undue Homage) by that Politick
tye
Setled her Universal Soveraignty,
The World in one vast Fam'ly had combin'd,
Nor labor'd thus to know each other's mind.
Language and Laws had firmly held together,
That Court and Tow'r had been the Mint for either:
But, when Dissension bred a Separation,
And each fixt Colony became a Nation, 


</page>

<page sig="A7v">
Chance and Design in time more licenc't grew,
And Dialects the Original ensue;
Which by degrees degenerate from their Mother,
Till they disown their birth, and seem another:
Besides, the various Climates tun'd their throats
And vocal Organs, apt for different Notes.
Then, Speech, which in this Analytick vein
Was first resolv'd, compounded grew again,
As Enemies in conquer'd Countries fixt
And ill-according Dialects intermixt;
Which Chance went on corrupting, till th'next so
Subdu'd that Nation, and that Language too. 

But most, in these our Modern times, this Ile
And Language oft became a double spoil
To Foreiners; Pictish with Danish clung
Into our Saxo-Belgick-Norman Tongue.
Not all theIargons, fanci'd to inspire
By miracle that disagreeing Quire
Of Babel' s Bricklayers, were so numerous
As those, which, by degrees, encroach't on us.
Nor was't all-jumbling War which wrought alone
This change, and shuffled many Tongues in one,
But even Peace (such is th'uncertain Fate
Of Speech) which settles all things, alters that.
This nourish't Peace, bred Commerce, which inclin'd
Men to impart th'Expressions of their mind.
Civiler Greek and Latin interlac't
Our rude Ground, with their rich Imbrod'ries grac't.
Smooth France, neat Italy, and manly Spain,
Lent it some tinctures of a quainter strain:
And, as with Merchandize, with terms it fares,
Nations do traffick Words, as well as Wares,
<term lang="fr">Bon-jour</term> usurps upon our plain Good-morrow,
'Tis Neighborhood's best praise to lend and borrow. 


</page>

<page sig="A8r">
Travellers, which about the world do roam
Had made us Englishmen, Strangers at home;
'Twas due unto their dearly earned praise
To dress strange Stories in exotick phrase.
Nay homebred heads unsocially did strive
T'estrange themselves andShibboleths contrive;
Tradesmen affected uncoth words to cant,
And blunder in terms non-significant;
Each Company would be thought a little Nation
And coyn a Dialect in their own fashion:
Artists grew Mock-Divines, and needs would teach
Their tricks in mystick words 'bove vulgar reach.

Thus were we at a loss, and none could tell
What Trav' llers, Grandsires, Books or Friends meant, wel.
Wee'd still been thral'd to th' School-boys stupid task,
Pos'd with hard English words, to stop and ask;
Gallants had paid their Crowns to see the Play,
And ne'r known first what meant anOpera;
Had not this thred been spun to lead them through
Our Tongue, grown Labyrinth, and Monster too.
Confusion, in this Book, in Order' s set,
An Heap is form'd into an Alphabet:
Old Babels Ruins this in part repairs
And in an handsom Work the Rubbish rears,
Scattered thence to our Isle; nor shall we now
Unto their Iars our disacquaintance ow.
Rankt i'th' first Class of Moderns this would be,
Had not Wits taken toy at industry,
And thought all profitable subjects dull,
'Cause they too solid are to pierce their Skul,
Pervious to nought but what to th'ear best chimes,
Sliding in low, or cap'ring in high Rymes.
But, since all Science first from Notions springs,
Notions are known by Words; there's nothing brings, 


</page>

<page sig="A8v">
Then treating these, to Knowledge more advance,
Held Pedantry by witty Ignorance.
In fine, what's due to industrious observation,
And re-acquainting our self-stranger Nation
With its disguised self; what's merited
By rendring our hard English Englished;
What, when our Tongue grew gibbrish, to be then
National Interpreter to Books and Men;
What ever praise does such deserts attend,
Know, Reader, 'tis thy debt unto my Friend. 

J.S. 

</section>


</page>

<page sig="B1r">
<section type="dictionary"> 

<heading>
GLOSSOGRAPHIA: 

OR THE 

INTERPRETATION 

OF 
Hard Words. 
</heading> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="a"><alpha>A</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="a(d)"> <f type="bkbl"/>A</form> <xpln lexeme="o(ex)">Alpha is a Greek
privative (which
being set before
any simple word
deprives it of its
proper signification) and <emend err="sig">sig&shy;</emend>
nifies as much as, without. 

Cicero calls A <term lang="la">literam saluta
rem</term>, a comfortable Letter, be&shy;
cause it was a note of <emend err="Abso">Abso&shy;</emend>
lution, but O, <term lang="la">literam tristem</term>. 
a sorrowful letter, because it
denoted condemnation. See
<term lang="la">Ignoramus</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abacted(a)"> Abacted, ( <etym lang="la">abactus</etym>)</form> <xpln lexeme="deposed(a)">driven
away by violence or stealth,
also deposed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abaddon(pn)">Abaddon (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class> <etym lang="he"> &#x05d0;&#x05d1;&#x05d3; Abadh</etym>)
</form> <xpln lexeme="Devil(pn)">the Devil, so called in the
New Testament, Apoc.9.11.
<term lang="la">quasi</term>, A bad one; it properly
signifies one that burns with
a desire of destroying men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abandon(v)"> Abandon (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">from the Span.</class> 


</page>

<page sig="B1v">
<etym lang="sp">Abandonar</etym>)</form> <xpln lexeme="banish(v)" lexeme="proscribe(v)" lexeme="leave(v)" lexeme="forsake(v)"> to banish or pro&shy;
scribe: to leave or forsake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abannition(n)"> <emend err="Abanuition">Abannition</emend>  (<etym lang="la">abannitio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
banishing for a year, properly
among the Greeks for man&shy;
slaughter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abba(n)"> Abba <class type="etymlang" lang="sy">(Syriack)</class></form> <xpln lexeme="father(n)"> Father,
So Christ expounds it, Mark
14.36 and St. Paul, Rom 3.15</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aboard(v)"> Abbord (from the Italian <etym lang="it">
abbordare)</etym> </form> <xpln lang="en">to go neer the
shore; also to bord or grap&shy;
ple with a ship. Florio.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abbot(n)"> Abbot (from <class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class> <etym lang="he">&#x05d0;&#x05d1; Abh</etym>,
or Syriack <etym lang="sy">Abba</etym> i. e. Father)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
spiritual Lord that has the
rule and preheminence over a
Religious House.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abbreviator(n)"> Abbreviator<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">one
that abridges or makes a brief
draught of a thing. In Rome
 there are Officers belonging
to the Pope called <term lang="la">Abbrevia&shy;
tors de parco majori</term> (whose
Office is to endite Letters at
request of suppliants, which
inditing is termed a rough
draught, or copy of the Re&shy;
quest) And Abbreviators, al&shy;
so <term lang="la">de parco minori</term>, whom the
Italians call <term lang="it">Giannizzeri</term>, who
also attend on the expedition
of Letters, I. Part Treasury
of Times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abbreviature(n)"> Abbreviature<etym lang="la">( abbreviatu&shy;
ra</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="abridgement(n)" lexeme="brief(n)"> a brief writing, an A&shy;
bridgment or brief of a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abdals(pn)"> Abdals,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Religi&shy;
ous people among the Persians
 who take their name from
 Abdala, Father of Mahomet;
they have no abode, vow po&shy;
verty, lodge in Churches, &amp;c.
 Herberts Travails, p.167.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abdera(pn)"> Abdera.</form> <xpln lang="en">A City in Thrace,
where Democritus the laugh&shy;
ing Philosopher lived. Hence
 Abderian laughteris used for
mad, foolish, or incessant
laughter; and Abderite, for
 Democritus, or any inhabitant
of that place.</xpln></wordentry>

ject, to renounce, to refuse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abjuration(n)">Abjuration <etym lang="la">(abjuratio
)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">forswearing or renouncing
Oath. In our common Law
it is an Oath taken to forsak
the Realm for ever. But there
is a later Oath so called, made
by the long Parliament, which
concerns matters of Belief
and may be seen at large in a 
Treatise called the Christian
Moderator, part. 3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="academy(n)">Academy<etym lang="la"> (Academia)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="academic(n)"> a
woody or shady place neer A&shy;
thens, where Plato taught;
now taken for any famous
School or University; hence
Philosophers of the Sect of
Plato are called Academicks .
In Alexandria (now called
Scanderia) in &AElig;gypt, Gautenus
(saith Heylyn) read Divinity 


</page>

<page sig="B3r">
and Philosophy in the year
180. from whom it is thought
the Orders of instituting Uni&shy;
versities first began in Chri&shy;
stendom.</xpln></wordentry>

</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accent(n)">Accent<etym lang="la"> (accentus)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="tune(n)" lexeme="tenor(n)"> tune,
tenor, the rising and falling
of the voice, the due sound
over any word or letter, or
the mark of any letter which
directs the pronunciation.
There are also Accents of sen&shy;
tences; As in the close of a
Period we let fall the voice,
in a demand raise it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accessory(n)" lexeme="accessary(n)">Accessory Accessary  <etym lang="la"> (accessarius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">guil&shy;
ty of a fault; in
our Common Law it signifies
a man guilty of a fellonious
offence, not principally, but
by participation, as by com&shy;
mandment, advise or conceal&shy;
ment. Whereof see more in
Cowels Interpreter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Actius Naevus(pn)">Actius N&aelig;vus</form> <xpln lang="en">a Roman
South-sayer of great fame, in
the presence of Tarquin did
cut a Whetstone in two with
a Razor; hence it is we use
to say proverbially, sharper then
Actius his Razor, as in Rel.
Med.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acre(n)" lexeme="aeker(n)">Acre<etym lang="la"> (acra)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="corn-field(n)" lexeme="corn-land(n)"> is a certain

in length 40 Roods, Poles or
Pearches, and four in breadth
or to that quantity, be the
length more or less. And, if
a man erect any new Cottage,
he must lay four Acres of
land to it after this measure,
ordained by Stat.31. Eliz.
Ca. 7. <term lang="sx">)Aeker</term> in the old Sax&shy;
on did signifie a Corn-field, or

any thing made of red

most excellent work made of

sian tongue, signifies a man. 
Herb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adamites(pn)">Adamites<etym lang="la"> (Adamiani)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
Sect of Hereticks instituted
in Bohemia about two hundred
yeers since, by Adamus Pastor
an ignorant fellow, who pre&shy;
tended forsooth to raise a
sort of sanctifyed people, but
indeed it was rather an herd
of shameless beasts; one pro&shy;
per mark of their profession
was, to meet stark naked in
their Synagogues, which
were sometimes hot Stoves,
and none were to be admitted
into their number, but such
as could stand stark naked
before the rest of their com&shy;
pany, men and women, for
the space of an hour, without
shame or blushing; they held
sundry heretical Doctrines, as
that in Christ there was but
one nature, &amp;c. There were 


</page>

<page sig="B4v">
in the third age after Christ,
some that gave beginning to
such a Sect, but failing of ac&shy;
ceptance, it dyed, or lay as
it were raked up in Embers,
till the forenamed Adamus
blew this cole in Bohemia, and
afterwards about the yeer
1535 in Holland, chiefly at 
Amsterdam, Utricht, and Em&shy;
den, in which and many
other places they are still
conceived to be lurk&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="addomestic(a)">Addomestique<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(French)</class></form> <xpln lexeme="tamed(a)">
tamed, made gentle, housal,
familiar. 
</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

</page>

<page sig="B5r">
Also an earnest charging or
commanding another to say
or do somewhat. As when
Caiphas said to Christ, I adjure
thee by the living God to tell us
if thou art Christ the Son of
God, Mat.26 63.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjutant(n)">Adjutant<etym lang="la"> (adjutans)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">help&shy;
ing or ayding, properly in
that which is good. One that
helps another in the discharge
of an Office, which is also
signifyed by Coadjutor.
Also an Officer in an Army so
called.</xpln></wordentry>

to place justly, set aptly,
couch evenly, joyn han&shy;
somly, match fitly, dispose
orderly, several things toge&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjuvate(v)">Adjuvate<etym lang="la"> (adjuvo)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="help(v)" lexeme="aid(v)" lexeme="further(v)" lexeme="favor(v)">to help

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjutory(a)">Adjutory<etym lang="la"> (adjutorius)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="bone, adjutory(n)">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="administrator(n)">Administrator<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">in
our Common Law is properly
taken for him that hath the
goods of a man dying inte&shy;
state committed to his charge
by the Ordinary, and is
accountable for the same,
when-ever it shall please the
Ordinary to call him there&shy;
unto. An Administrator is by
the Statute of 31 Edw. 3. cap.
11. authorized to dispose
of the goods of the de&shy;
ceased as fully, and to be 
accountable for the same,
as Executors. Of Admini&shy;
strators and Executors, see a
Treatise written by Master
Wentworth of Lincolns
Inn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="administratrix(n)">Administratrix<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">she
that hath that charge or
Office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="admiration(n)">Admiration<etym lang="la"> (admiratio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="point, admiration(n)" lexeme="admiration point(n)">
wondring at, mervailing.
An Admiration point is thus
[!] As when we say,<term lang="la"> O tempora! 
O Mores!</term></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ad octo(n)" lexeme="ut octo(n)">Ad Octo orUt Octo.</form> <xpln lexeme="degree, superlative(n)">A
term in Philosophy, which
signifies the superlative de&shy;
gree, because in Philosophy
the eighth degree is the high&shy;
est, in which they distinguish
qualities or accidents.</xpln></wordentry>

25.</xpln></wordentry>

in breadth, was so called of

Town on the mouth of Eri&shy;
danus or Poe. Heylyn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="advent(n)">Advent<etym lang="la"> (adventus)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="coming unto(n)" lexeme="approaching(n)">the
time from the Sunday that
falls either upon Saint An&shy;
drews day, or next to it, till
Christmas; which time was
wont to be spent in some ex&shy;
traordinary devotion by way
of preparation for the Feast
of the Nativity of our Saviour
then approaching. The words
bare signification is, a com&shy;
ing unto, or approaching.</xpln></wordentry>

sons; but if onely one of two
persons by whom this sin is

seems to have taken that
name, as it were <term lang="la">ad alterius

which the Adulterer always
ayms at. Minsheu.</xpln></wordentry>

matter, so called <term lang="la">ab advocando</term>,

led to his clyents assistance,

or Proctor in the Civil Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="advowson(n)">Advowzen<etym lang="la"> (advocatio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="advowson in gross(n)" lexeme="advowson dependant(n)">the
reversion of a spiritual pro&shy;
motion, and signifies in our
Common Law a right to pre&shy;
sent a Clergy-man to a Bene&shy;
fice, as much as <term lang="la">Ius Patrona&shy;
tus</term> in the Canon Law. Of
this there are two sorts, Ad&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="B6r">
vowzen in gross, which belongs 
or adheres to any Manor, as 
parcel of the right of it; and 
Avowzen dependant, which de&shy;
pends on a Manor as apperti&shy;
nant thereunto. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Africa(pn)">Africa<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Greek)</class></form> <xpln lexeme="a(d)">one of the
four parts of the world lying
Southward, herein is Barbary
Numidia, Lybia, the Land of
Negroes, &AElig;thiopia interior and
exterior, &AElig;gypt and the
Islands. It is called Africa of
the Greek word <term lang="gk">Phrice</term>, which
signifies cold, and the particle
A, which, in that language
being placed before a word,
deprives it of its proper sense:
so that Africa signifies a
Country hot, or without cold,
as indeed it is.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Afric(a)" lexeme="African(a)">Africk 
African  <etym lang="la"> (Africus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to Africa, or
to the Southwest wind; <term lang="en">A&shy;
frick-bird</term>, taken for a coward
or one in gay cloaths that has
little Spirit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aga(n)">Aga</form> <xpln lang="en">an Officer that com&shy;
mands the great Turks Jani&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="B6v">
zaries, and is the third in re&shy;
pute in his Empire. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agaric(n)">Agarick (<etym lang="la">agaricum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a white
and soft Mushrom, or excre&shy;
scence growing on the Larch
Tree; also a root in Sarmatia
that helps digestion. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="age(n)">Age<etym lang="la"> (&aelig;tas)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="age, full(n)" lexeme="age of discretion(n)" lexeme="infancy(n)" lexeme="childhood(n)" lexeme="youth-hood(n)" lexeme="man-hood, young(n)" lexeme="man-hood, ripe(n)" lexeme="age, old(n)" lexeme="age, deprepit(n)">that part of a
mans life which is from his
birth to his last day. A man
by our Common Law hath
two ages ; the age of 21 yeers
is termed his full age, and 14
the age of discretion. Lit. l.2.
c.4. In a woman there are
six. First at seven yeers of age
the Lord her Father may di&shy;
strain his Tenants for ayd to
marry her; for at those yeers
she may consent to Matrimo&shy;
ny. 2. At the age of nine
yeers she is Dowable. 3. At
twelve yeers she is able final&shy;
ly to confirm her former
consent given to Matrimony.
4. At fourteen yeers she is
enabled to receive her land
into her own hands, and shall
be out of Ward if she be of
this age at the death of her
Ancestor. 5. At sixteen
yeers she shall be out of Ward,
though at the death of her
Ancestor she was within the
age of fourteen yeers. 6. At
one and twenty yeers she is
able to alienate her Lands
and Tenements. See more
of this in Cowel. Proclus (a
Greek Author) divides the
life of man into seven ages.
1. Infancy, conteins four yeers. 
2. Childhood continues ten
yeers. 3. Youth-hood or A&shy;
dolescency consists of eight
yeers, that is, from fourteen to
two and twenty. 4. Young
man-hood continues fifteen
yeers, that is, from two and
twenty to forty one. 5. Ripe
man-hood hath fifteen yeers
of continuance, and there&shy;
fore makes his progress to 56
yeers. 6. Old age, which, in
adding 12 to 56, makes up 68.
7. Decrepit age is limited from
68 yeers to 88. See more
divisions of Age if you please,
in the first part of the Treasu&shy;
ry of Times, p. 337. and in 
 Vulg: Errors p. 216.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Agelastic(pn)">Agelastick from <etym lang="la">Agelastus</etym>,</form>
<xpln lang="en">Grandfather of Crassus, who
never laughed but once in all
his life, and that was to see a
Mare eat Thistles, hence) we
use it for one that seldom
laughs; sad or sullen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agemoglan(n)">Agemoglans or Agiam
Oglans, </form> <xpln lang="en">are those Christian child&shy;
dren, which are seized
by Turkish Officers, when
they are between the age of
ten, and eighteen or twenty,
to be made Janizaries, or for
other service of the great
Turk. The word signifies
unexpert, or untutored
youths.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agist(v)">Agist (from the French <etym lang="fr">
gist)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="agistor(n)" lexeme="guest-taker(n)" lexeme="agistment(n)" lexeme="gisting(n)" lexeme="joisting(n)">signifies in our Common
Law to take in and feed the
Cattle of strangers in the
Kings Forest, and to gather
the mony due for the same to
the Kings use: the Officers
that do this are called Agistors
 or  Guest-takers, of whom the
King had four in number in
every Forest where he had a&shy;
ny Pawnage ; their function is
termed Agistment, which is al&shy;
so used for the taking in of
cattel into the Parks or
grounds of subjects. Hence
comes the word gisting, or (as
the Country people corrupt
it) Ioysting of cattle. Man&shy;
wood forr. Laws.<xref lexeme="pannage"> See Pawnage.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agonath(n)" lexeme="agonothete(n)">Agonath or Agonothete<etym lang="la"> (A&shy;
gonotheta)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">judge or overseer
in feats of activity, a Master
of Revels.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agrarian laws(n)">Agrarian Laws,</form> <xpln lang="en">were
among the Romans, preferred
by the Tribunes of the Com&shy;
mons, as well for division of
Lands and fields (conquer&shy;
ed from the enemies) among
the Commons, as to restrain
the possessions of the Nobles
within a certain limit. Livy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agreat(adv)">Agreat<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">(Saxon)</class></form> <xpln lexeme="altogether(adv)" lexeme="lump, by the(pp)">altoge&shy;
ther. As to take a work a&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="B7v">
great, is to take the whole
work altogether, or, as some
say, by the lump.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alabaster(n)">Alabaster<etym lang="la"> (alabastrum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of Marble, white and ve&shy;
ry cleer, which by reason of
its natural coldness, preserves
things long from corruption;
and therefore they used to
make boxes of it to keep
sweet Oyntments, and Tombs
to bury Princes and great
Personages in. 
Dr. Bullocar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alabandical(a)">Alabandical<etym lang="la"> (alabandicus)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="barbarous(a)" lexeme="sottish(a)">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alay(n)">Alay</form> <xpln lang="en">A term in hunting,
when the Hart is in full chase,
and one lyes neer a covert,
and shakes off some fresh
Hounds into the Cry, to sup&shy;
ply and make it the stronger,
lest some overhaled dogs
should happen to sink in the
later end of the chase.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alacrity(n)">Alacrity <etym lang="la"> (alacritas)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="cheerfulness(n)" lexeme="liveliness(n)" lexeme="courage(n)">cheer&shy;
fulness, livelyness, courage,
joyfulness of heart.</xpln></wordentry>

ma)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a calling together to
Arms, as is usually done in a
Garrison, upon the approach
of an enemy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alazony(n)">Alazony<etym lang="la"> (alazonia)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="arrogancy(n)" lexeme="pride(n)">arro&shy;
gancy, or pride.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alb(n)">Albe<etym lang="la"> (alba)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a long white
linnen garment, wherewith
Priests are cloathed when
they say Mass, by which Albe
is represented the long white
robe, by derision put on our
Saviour in the presence of 
Herod. Treatise of Mass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Albion(pn)">Albion.</form> <xpln lexeme="Great Britain(pn)" lexeme="happy(a)">Great Britain, so
called, either from the Greek
word <etym lang="gk">Olbion</etym> that is happy, or
from <etym lang="la">Albis rupibus</etym>, its white
rocks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="albis(n)">Albis<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Latine)</class></form> <xpln lexeme="albis, in(n)" lexeme="unbound(a)" lexeme="quires, in(n)">as when
we say a book in Albis, that is
a book in quires or unbound.
A term more used beyond
Sea, then with us; we say
in Quires, the French, <term lang="fr">in
Blanc</term>.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alchaic verse(n)">Alchaick Verse (<etym lang="la">Alcaicum
Carmen</etym> from <etym lang="la">Alc&aelig;us</etym>, the in&shy;
ventor)</form> <xpln lang="en">has, after two Dactiles,
two Trochees, thus -uu-uu-u-u.
But, according to Fabricius, it
has five feet, he places the first
a Spondee or Iambick; the
second an Iambick, the third 


</page>

<page sig="B8r">
a long sillable, the fourth a
Dactyle, the fifth a Dactyle or
Amphimacre, and gives this
example. <term lang="la"> 

Vides ut alta stet nive candidum
Soracte, nec jam sustineant onus.</term> 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alchemy(n)">Alchymy<etym lang="la"> (alchymia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the art
of distilling or drawing quin&shy;
tessence out of metals by fire,
separating the pure from the
impure, setting at liberty such
bodies as are bound and im&shy;
prisoned, and bringing to
perfection such as are unripe.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alchemist(n)">Alchymist<etym lang="la"> (alchymista)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="chemick(n)">one
that useth or is skilled in that
Art, a Chymick. A melter
or extracter of Quintessences,
from the Greek <term lang="gk">&#x1f04;&lambda;&kappa;&iota;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</term>, and
that from the Hebrew <etym lang="he">Al
kum</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alcoran(pn)">Alchoran or Alcoran </form> <xpln lang="en">(<expan type="">id est</expan>
Scripture) the book of the
Turks Religion, first broach&shy;
ed by Mahomet, who was an
Arabian, and born in the yeer
572, his Father was a Pagan,
and his Mother a Jew. In
Arabia he was chosen Captain
of a Rebellious multitude, a&shy;
mong whom he inducted a
new Religion (which he pre&shy;
tended was revealed to him
by the Angel Gabriel) consist&shy;
ing partly of Jewish Ceremo&shy;
nies, which he learned of one
Abdalla, partly of Christian
Precepts taught him by Ser&shy;
gius a Nestorian Monk, and
partly of other phantastical
fopperies, which his own <emend err="in">in&shy;</emend> 
ventions suggested to him.
This Religion (if we may so
call it) Osmen the fourth Ca&shy;
liph of the Saracens (who
marryed Mahomets daughter
and by that means got a sight
of all his papers) reduced in&shy;
to four volumns, and divided
into several Chapters, the
whole Body of it is but an
Exposition and gloss of these
eight Commandments:
1 Every one ought to be&shy;
lieve, that God is a great
God and onely God, and Ma&shy;
homet is his Prophet.
2 Every one must marry
to encrease the Sectaries of
Mahomet.
3 Every one must give of
his wealth to the poor.
4 Every one must make
his Prayers five times a
day.
5 Every one must keep a
Lent one month in the yeer.
6 Be obedient to thy Pa&shy;
rents.
7 Thou shalt not kill.
8 Do to others as thou 
wouldst be done unto thy
self. 

And the Turk writes on
the outside of his Alcoran,
Let no man touch this Book but
he that is pure. M. S. in Arch.
Bod. you may read more at
large of this heathenish su&shy;
perstition in Doctor Helylyns 
description of Arabia, and
indeed in the Book it self,
not long since printed in En&shy;
glish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alembic(n)">Alembick<etym lang="la"> (alembicus)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="still(n)" lexeme="stillatory(n)">A 


</page>

<page sig="b8v">
Still or Stillatory to distil
waters.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="C1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allegory(n)">Allegory<etym lang="la"> (allegoria)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
dark speech or Sentence,
which must be understood
otherwise then the literal
interpretation shews. As
when St. I. Baptist, speaking
of our Saviour, Matt. 3. said,
Whose fan is in his hand, and he
shall make clean his floor, and
gather the wheat into his barn,
but the chaff he shall burn with
unquenchable fire. The mean&shy;
ing whereof is, that Christ,
being supreme Judge of all,
shall separate the good from
the evil, rewarding the one
in heaven, and punishing the
other in hell fire. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allegorical(a)">Allegorical</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to,
or spoken by an Allegory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allelujah(ex)" lexeme="alleluia(ex)">Alleluiah or Alleluia <class type="etymlang" lang="he">(Heb.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">
Praise ye our Lord, used as a
sign of exultation. Paulus
Diaconus writes, that when
the Britains were invaded by
the Saxons and Picts, and on
a time ready to fight a battel
with them, they were admo&shy;
nished by Germanus a French
Bishop (who was sent hither
with St Lupus, to confute the
Pelagian Heresie) that they
should say as he said, and
forthwith he cryed out aloud
Alleluiah, which when the
whole Army of Britains had
done, the sound thereof
strook such a terror into the
enemies, that they presently
fled, and the <emend err="Birains">Britains</emend> had the
victory, De gestis Rom l. 15.
and Bede Eccl. Hist. l I. cap. 20. 
This <term lang="he">Alleluia</term> (saith a lear&shy;
ned Author) is an Hebrew 
word, composed of <term lang="he">Allelu</term> and
<term lang="he">Jah</term>, whereof the Imperative
Mood <term lang="he">Allelu</term> (as neer as can
be uttered, for in it self it sig&shy;
nifies joy behond all utter&shy;
ance) is as much as praise ye ;
and the word Jah is one of the
ten names signifying our Lord,
which some think to be the
first word that children pro&shy;
nounce, when they are new&shy;
born. This word Alleluiah
the Jews do much esteem, and
pronounce it many times to&shy;
gether in their Synagogues.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allevate(v)" lexeme="alleviate(v)">Allevate or
Alleviate <etym lang="la"> (allevo)</etym> 
</form> <xpln lexeme="lift up(v)" lexeme="ease(v)" lexeme="comfort(v)" lexeme="assuage(v)" lexeme="diminish(v)">to lift up,
or ease or comfort,
to asswage or di&shy;
minish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alliciency(n)">Alliciency<etym lang="la"> (from allicio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="allurement(n)" lexeme="enticing(n)" lexeme="drawing unto(n)" lexeme="persuading unto(n)">
an allurement or enticing, a
drawing or perswading unto,
Vulg Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alligation(n)">Alligation (<etym lang="la">alligatio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="tying to(n)" lexeme="binding to(n)">a ty&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allision(n)">Allision<etym lang="la"> (allisio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="dashing againmt(n)" lexeme="dashing upon(v)" lexeme="rubbing against(n)">a dashing
against or upon, a rubbing a&shy;

and playing on the same let&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Allobroges(pn)">Allobroges.</form> <xpln lang="en">People of Sa&shy;
voy and Daulphine. It is said
by a pleasant Author, that
the etymology comes from
this, that Broges in some of
those Country languages sig&shy;
nifie Breeches, therefore Allo&shy;
broges, <term lang="la">quasi</term> all breeches, be&shy;
cause they wear great long
breeches.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allude(v)">Allude<etym lang="la"> (alludo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to speak
any thing which hath <emend err="resem">resem&shy;</emend>
blance, or is privily directed
to touch another matter, to
scoff covertly, to play to or
with another, to speak by re&shy;
lation to any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allusion(n)">Allusion<etym lang="la"> (allusio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a liken&shy;
ing or applying of one thing
to another, and it is as it were
a dalliance or playing with
words like in sound, unlike
in sense, by changing, adding,
or subtracting a letter or
two; so that words nicking
and resembling one the other,
are applyable to different sig&shy;
nifications. As the Almigh&shy;
ty (if we may herein use sa&shy;
cred Authority) in ratificati&shy;
on of his promise to the seed
of Isaac, changed Abram,
 high Father, into Abraham,
that is, Father of many; and
Sarai that is, My Dame, into 
Sara, that is, Lady or Dame.
The Greeks nicked Antiochus 
Epiphanes, that is, the famous,
with Epimanes, that is, the fu&shy;
rious. The Romans like&shy;
wise played with bibbing Ti&shy; 
berius Nero, calling him Bibe&shy;
rius Mero. So in Quintilian,
the sour fellow Placidus was 
called Acidus, and of late one 
called Scaliger Aliger: Cam&shy;
dens Rem. fol 158.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almanac(n)">Almanack (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr</class> <etym lang="he">Alma&shy;
nahh</etym>)</form> <xpln lexeme="prognostication(n)" lexeme="calendar(n)">a Prognostication or
Kalendar. But Verstegan de&shy;
rives it from the Germans;
they used (says he) to <emend err="en">en&shy;</emend>
grave upon certain squared
sticks about a foot in length,
the courses of the Moons of
the whole yeer, whereby they
could always certainly tell,
when the New and Full
Moons should happen, as also
their Festival days, and such
a carved stick they called an
Al-mon-aght, that is to say,
Al-mon-heed, to wit, the re&shy;
gard or observation of all the
Moons, and hence is derived
the name Almanack. Verstegan 
p.46 47.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almicantharat(n)" lexeme="almadatat(n)">Almicantharats andAlmadatats</form> <xpln lang="en">Arabian names of
Lines or Circles, which are
imagined to pass through eve&shy;
ry degree of the Meridian
Parallel to the Horizon up to
the Zenith . Du Bartas.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alody(n)">Alody<etym lang="la"> (alodium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">signifyed
anciently what in the more
strict sense Inheritance doth
in our Law, that is, Lands
descended from the Ancestor.
Selden.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almoner(n)">Almner, Almoner, or Am&shy;
ner<etym lang="la"> (eleemosynarius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is an Of&shy;
ficer of a King or Princes
house, whose function is care&shy;
fully to collect the fragments 


</page>

<page sig="C2r">
and to distribute them every
day to the poor: Charitably
to visit the sick and leprous,
those that are in prison, poor
widows, needy persons, and
those that have no constant
abode; likewise to receive
and faithfully distribute cast
horses, robes, mony and other
things given in Alms, he
ought also to stir up the King
with often Admonitions, e&shy;
specially on Festival days, to
be bountiful in giving Alms,
and to beseech that his rich
Robes may not be given to
Parasites, Masquers, Stage&shy;
players, or the like, but
may go towards the in&shy;
crease of his Almes. Fleta
lib. 2 cap. 22.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alnath(pn)">Alnath</form> <xpln lang="en">is a fixed star in the
horns of Aries, from whence
the first mansion of the
Moon taketh his name, and
is called Alnath. Chaucer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aloe(n)">Aloes</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Lignum Vit&aelig;</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aloe zocatrina(n)">Aloe Zocatrina. </form> <xpln lang="en">The juice
of an herb brought hither
dry out of Zocatara, an Affri&shy;
can Island, the best whereof
is cleer, clean and red like
the colour of a Liver; It is
very bitter, but an excellent
Medicine to purge cholerick
humors out of the Stomach,
yet not good to be taken in&shy;
wardly by such as are trou&shy;
bled with the Hemorrhoides .
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

sonable, inconsiderate.</xpln></wordentry>

and hony, and is much of the
taste of our Medea .</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alpha(n)">Alpha<etym lang="gk"> (&#x1f04;&lambda;&phi;&alpha;)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="chief(n)">the first let&shy;
ter of the Greeks called of us

used for the first or chief of a&shy;
ny thing; Almighty God is
called in the Apocalypse, Alpha
and Omega <expan type="">id est</expan> the beginning
and ending, first and last. Rev
23.13.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alphabet(n)">Alphabet<etym lang="la"> (alphabetum)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="cross-row(n)" lexeme="A. B. C.(n)">the

B, C. So called from Alpha 
and Beta the two first letters
of the Greek Alphabet or
Cross-row, and by conse&shy;
quence the word Alphabet
is onely peculiar to the
Greek tongue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amalekites(pn)" lexeme="Amalecite(n)">Amalekites or Amalecites,</form> <xpln lang="en">
were descendents of Esau by
his grand-child Amalec (which
word is Heb. and signifies <term lang="la">po&shy;
pulus lambens</term>, a licking people<emend err="">)</emend>:
these Amalekites inhabited
some of the lands betwixt
Ph&aelig;nicia and the red Sea, and
were the first that took Arms
against Moses and the children
of Israel, as they were travail&shy;
ing betwixt the said Red Sea,
and the land of Promise, o&shy;
ver whom Joshua (appointed
General of the Israelites by
 Moses) got a famous victory,
as you may read in Exod. 17.
Hence 'tis that enemies to the
children of God or good peo&shy;
ple, or enemies to good pro&shy;
ceedings are commonly called
Amalekites.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amalthean horn(n)">Amalthean Horn. </form> <xpln lang="en">Plenty
of all things. So used from
 Amalth&aelig;a, a she Goat, that
Iupiter sucked, whose horns
are faigned to have abounded
with plenty of all things.
Cicero' s Library was also
called Amalth&aelig;a, for being
abundantly stored with
books.</xpln></wordentry>

a sending away or remo&shy;
ving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amazons(pn)">Amazons<etym lang="la"> (amazones)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
warlike women of Scythia,
that had but one Teat
(their name in Greek
importing as much) they
were very manlike, and
did cut off their right
breast, that it might not
hinder their shooting,
for they were excellent
Archers; they lived by
themselves, and if at any
time they went to their
Husbands or neighbouring
men, and conceived: if
it were a Female childe
they kept it; if a Male,
they sent it to the Fa&shy;
ther: the Country where
they live is denominated
from them, and called A&shy;
mazonia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambage(n)">Ambage<etym lang="la"> (ambages)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an
idle circumstance of words,
a far fetched speech, or
a speech far from the pur&shy;
pose. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambagious(a)">Ambagious<etym lang="la"> (ambagi&shy;
osus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">full of idle cir&shy;
cumstances of speech or
words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amber(n)">Amber, (<etym lang="la">ambra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kinde of hard yellow
Gum, wherewith they
make Beads and Brace&shy;
lets.

Dioscorides saith, it
falls in manner of a
liquor from Poplar Trees
into the River Po in
Italy, where it congeals
and becomes hard. But
L. Guicciard affirms (and
more probably) that it
is the juice of a stone,
which grows like a Coral
in Poland in a Moun&shy;
tain of the North Sea, clean
covered with water, and in
the months especially of Sep&shy;
tember and December, this
liquor is by violence of
the Sea, rent from the
Rock, and cast into the
Havens of Poland and the
neighbouring Countries.
Besides its beauty, and
the quality it hath of
burning like pitch, and
attracting strawes and I&shy;
ron, like the Adamant,
it is good for stopping the
blood, Falling-sickness,
Dropsies and many other
Diseases. Heyl. But see
more of the quality and
nature of Amber, in Do&shy;
ctor Browns Vulgar Errors,
in the fourth Chapter of
the second Book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambergris(n)">Ambergreece, or Am&shy;
bergrise (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Ambergris)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">a sweet Aromatick juice or
perfume so called. &AElig;&shy;
tius and Simeon Sethius
(Greek Authors) af&shy;
firm it to be a kinde of Bi&shy;
tumen coming forth of the
Fountains or Springs in the 


</page>

<page sig="C3v">
bottom of the Sea, and that
by floating upon the water
it becomes hard, &amp;c. A
great quantity thereof is
found in Sofala and in the
Isles of Comaro, Demogra, Mo&shy;
zambique, and along this
Tract even to the Isles of
Maldina or Naledina, which
look into the East. There is
Amber of four several <emend err="co">co&shy;</emend>
lours: White, Gray, Red,
and Black, which comes ac&shy;
cording to the variety of
places or Regions where it is
found, the gray is preferred
before all the other, and if
known to be good, if when
pricking it with a pin, it de&shy;
livers forth a moisture like
oyle. The fume of it is
good against the falling-sick&shy;
ness, and comfortable to the
brain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambidexter(n)">Ambidexter (Lat. <etym lang="la">ex ambo <term lang="en">
and</term> dexter</etym>) </form> <xpln lang="en">he that useth his
left hand as well as his right,
that plays on both sides. In
our Common Law it signifies
that Juror or embraceor;
that takes of both parties, for
the giving his Verdict. He
forfeits ten times so much as
he takes, Anno 38. Edw.3. cap.
12. Cromptons Iustice of Peace,
fol 156. B.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambidextrous(a)">Ambidextrous.</form> <xpln lang="en">That can
use both hands, that plays
on both sides.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amebean verse(n)">Amebean Verse<etym lang="la"> (Carmen

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amen(ex)">Amen (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">ver&egrave;</term>)</form> <xpln lexeme="verily(adv)">in
the end of Prayer, a wishing
that it may be so, so be it.
But when it is found repeat&shy;
ed two several times, as Amen
Amen, then it implies verily,
verily, for confirmation of a
truth, Matt 18.3. Ich.6.26
Durantus saith, that Amen
imports, Be it to us which
we have prayed for. Amen
is used in most languages; in
Turky they use (<term lang="tu">Homin</term>) in&shy;
stead of it. S. H. B.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amenity(n)">Amenity<etym lang="la"> (am&aelig;nitas)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="pleasantness(n)" lexeme="mirth(n)" lexeme="delight(n)" lexeme="amity(n)">plea&shy;
santness, mirth, delight, ami&shy;
ty</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amerciament(n)">Amerciament (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the
Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Merci</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> Mercy)</form> <xpln lexeme="fine kitchin(n)">signifies
the pecuniary punishment of
an offender against the King
or other Lord in his Court
that is found to be (<term lang="la">in miseri&shy;
cordia</term>) <expan type="">id est</expan> to have offended
and to stand at the Mercy of
the King or Lord. There
seems to be a difference be&shy;
tween Amerciaments and Fines 
Kitchin fol.214. For Fines,
as taken for punishments, are
punishments certain, which
grow expresly from some Sta&shy;
tute, and Amerciaments are such
as are arbitrably imposed by
Affeerors. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="America(pn)">America.</form> <xpln lang="en">One of the four
parts of the world, so called
from Americus Vespasius a Flo&shy;
rentine, who with Columbus
a Genoese, first discover'd this
Country, about the yeer 1492
which is most aptly called the
New world; new, for the late
discovery; and world, for the
vast spaciousness of it. For
it being divided into two
parts; Mexicana and Peruana,
the compass of the first is
deemed 17000, of the other
13000 miles. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="American disease(n)">American Disease.</form> <xpln lexeme="pox, great(n)">The
great Pox, brought first from
the Indies by the Spanyards
into Christendom, and at the
Siege of Naples, they bestow&shy;
ed it on the French their e&shy;
nemies in the yeer 1528. <xref>See
Morbus Gallicus.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amfractuosity(n)">Amfractuosity<etym lang="la"> (amfractuo&shy;
sitas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a manifold winding,
turning, involution, intricacy,
compass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amfractuous(a)">Amfractuous<etym lang="la"> (amfractuosus)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="intricate(a)" lexeme="maze-like(a)" lexeme="perplexed(a)">
full of turnings or windings,
intricate, maze-like, per&shy;
plexed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amict(n)">Amict or Amice.<etym lang="la"> (amictus,
us)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="garment(n)" lexeme="attire(n)">a garment or attire; par&shy;
ticularly it is that linen at&shy;
tire, which Priests put on,
when they vest themselves,
by which is represented the
head-cloth, wherewith the
Jews covered the face and eys
of our Saviour, when buffet&shy;
ing they said Prophecy, who is
he that struck thee?</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ami(a)">Amie, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French</class>  
<etym lang="fr">Ami&egrave;</etym>,</form> <xpln lexeme="Amie(pn)">that is, beloved, and
that from <etym lang="la">Amatus</etym>, a name 
common both to men and
women. The Earls and Dukes
of Savoy, who are commonly
called <term lang="fr">Aim&egrave;</term>, were in Latine
called <term lang="la">Amadeus</term>, that is, loving
God, as Theophilus . We now
use Amias for this, in diffe&shy;
rence from Amie the womans
name. Camden.</xpln></wordentry>

of black spots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ammoniac(n)">Ammoniack.</form> <xpln lang="en">A kind of

so called, because it grows in
Lybia, neer the place where
the Temple of Jupiter Am&shy;
mon or Hammon was. There
is also a kinde of salt so called,
which is found in Africa un&shy;
der sand, and is like Allum.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

from Amon, or generally used

they were the worst and wic&shy;
kedest) which possessed the
land. Gen 15. 16. Ios. 2. 10. 
Amos 2.9.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amort(a)">Amort (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Amorti</etym>) </form> <xpln lexeme="extinguished(a)" lexeme="deaded(a)" lexeme="quenched(a)" lexeme="amortified(a)">

ched. Hence tis we use to say

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amphiction(n)">Amphictions<etym lang="la"> (Amphyctiones)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
were the most noble Coun&shy;
sellors of Greece, selected out
of the twelve privy Cities, and
instituted either by Acrisius 
(as Strabo) or (as Halicarnas&shy;
s&aelig;us thinks) by Amphictyon
the son of Helen, from whom
they seem to have derived
their name: They had power
to decide all controversies,
and to enact Laws for the
common good, their meetings
were at the beginning of the
Spring and Autumn. Heyl. and
Ryder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amphionize(v)"> To Amphionize, </form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> to play
the Amphion, who was the au&shy;
thor of harmony, and by his 


</page>

<page sig="C5r">
Eloquence brought men from
savageness to civility. Apol.
for Learning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amphyscians(pn)">Amphyscians<etym lang="la"> (amphiscii)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
such people as live under the
burning Zone, neer the Equi&shy;
noctial line, so called, because
their shadows at noon are
sometimes towards the North,
sometimes toward the South.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amphitheater(n)">Amphitheater<etym lang="la"> (amphithea&shy;
trum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of round Scaf&shy;
fold or Play-house full of
benches of divers heights, for
people to sit and behold pub&shy;
lique exercises; It differs
from a Theater as the Full
Moon from the half: this was
but half-circled, that round,
and composed as it were of
two Theaters, and is thereof
so called. Caius Julius C&aelig;sar,
(says Polydore Virgil) built the
first Amphitheatre in the field
and consecrated it to Mars.
Verona a City in Lombardy
boasts of an Amphitheatre, able
to contain 80000 people.
Heil. And Vespatians Amphi&shy;
theatre at Rome, said to be as
great. Theodorick King of
the Goths did utterly abolish
the pastimes then used to be
exhibited upon these Amphi&shy;
theatres.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amphitrite(pn)">Amphitrite <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class> </form> <xpln lexeme="sea(n)">the
wife of Neptune used for the
Sea. Ovid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amphoral(a)">Amphoral<etym lang="la"> (amphoralis)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="amphora(n)">
containing or pertaining to
Amphora, which is a vessel or
pot with two ears, by some ta&shy;
ken for a Rundler of nine 
gallons. Anciently the Ita&shy;
lick Amphora contained five
Gallons, the Attick Amphora 
seven Gallons and Dimid.
Godwin.143.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ampliation(n)">Ampliation<etym lang="la"> (ampliatio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="enlargement(n)" lexeme="reprieve(n)">a
deferring or prolonging of
Judgement or tryal, till
the cause be better certifyed:
an enlargement, a Reprive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amplification(n)">Amplification<etym lang="la"> (amplificatio)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="amplifying(n)" lexeme="enlarging(n)" lexeme="dilating(n)">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ampullous(a)">Ampullous<etym lang="la"> (ampullarius)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="proud(a)" lexeme="swelling(a)" lexeme="gorgeous(a)">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amulet(n)">Amulete<etym lang="la"> (amuletum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a ball
like a Pomander, good against
infection or bewitching; al&shy;
so any thing that is hanged a&shy;
bout the neck to preserve one
from bewitching and infe&shy;
ction.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ana(n)">Ana.</form> <xpln lang="en">A barbarous word used
by Physicians, and signifies of
every one a <emend err="little" source="errata">like</emend> quantity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anabaptists(pn)">Anabaptists,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of He&shy;
retiques, whose erroneous
Tenents or the greatest part
of them are,
1 That Christ took not
flesh from the Virgin Mary,
but that he past through her, 


</page>

<page sig="C5v">
as the Sun beams do through
glass, or rain through a spout.
2 That there is no original
sin.
3 That children ought not
to be baptized.
4 That such as have been
baptized in their infancy
ought to be re-baptized when
they come to yeers of discre&shy;
tion.
5 That lay-people may
preach and administer the Sa&shy;
craments.
6 That Absolution and the
Church-peace ought to be
denyed to such, who are fal&shy;
len into any grievous sin, yea
though they repent of it.
7 That Luther and the
Pope are false Prophets, but of
the two, Luther the worst.
In matters of State they hold,
1 That the people may de&shy;
pose their Magistrates and
chief Rulers.
2 That a Christian with a
good Conscience may not take
upon him or bear the office of
Magistrate, or keep any Court
of Justice.
3 That none may admini&shy;
ster an oath to another.
4 That no malefactor ought
to be put to death.
In family-government they
hold,
1 That no man hath a pro&shy;
perty in his goods, but that
all things ought to be held in
common.
2 That it is lawful to have
more wives then one at once.
3 That a man may put a&shy; 
way his wife, if she differ from
him in point of Religion,
and be not of their Sect. 

There are divers sorts of
Anabaptists, whereof some
hold but part of these opini&shy;
ons, some all of them, and
others more then these, wher&shy;
of you may see more at large
in Doctor Featley's description
of Anabaptists, Entituled the
Dippers dipt, and in Heresiogra&shy;
phy an English book so called.
Melancthon saith, that one
Nich. Stork first broached A&shy;
nabaptism in Germany, about
the yeer 1521. which doth
very much raign at this time
in many parts of Christen&shy;
dom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anabathrum(n)">Anabathrum<etym lang="la"> (anabathrum)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="pulpit(n)">
a Pulpit or any place where&shy;
unto we ascend by steps or
Stayrs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anachorite(n)" lexeme="anchoret(n)">Anachorite 
or 
Anchoret 
(<etym lang="la">Anchoreta</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">(so
called, because
they use to live 
<term lang="gk">&#x1F00;&nu;&epsilon;&upsilon;</term> <expan type="">id est</expan> retired from <emend err="com"> com&shy;</emend>
pany) a kinde of Religious
persons that live solitarily in
Cells, and dig their graves
with their nayls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anachronicism(n)" lexeme="anachronism(n)">Anachronicism Anachronism  <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class> </form> <xpln lang="en">an er&shy;
error in Chro&shy;
nology, or an undue conne&shy;
xion of time, a false Chro&shy;
nicling, a repeating of time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anachoretical(a)" lexeme="anachoretal(a)">Anachoretical 
Anachoretal 
<etym lang="la">(Anachoreta&shy;
lis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to solitariness or Her&shy;
mites.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anacreontic verse(n)">Anacreontick Verse (so
called from <etym lang="la">Anacreon</etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Lyrick 
Poet, who was the first in&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="c6r">
ventor of it) consists of seven
syllables, which syllables, as
I take it, are not tyed to any
certain Law of quantity. As 
<term lang="la"> 
Sat est quiete dulci,
Fessum fovere corpus.
</term> 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anadem(n)">Anadem<etym lang="la"> (anadema)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
ornament for womens heads,
as Garlands, Coronets or bor&shy;
ders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anaglyphic(a)">Anaglyphik or Anaglyp&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anagogical(a)">Anagogical<etym lang="la"> (anagogeticus)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="subtle(a)">

ing, or belonging unto high

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anagrammatism(n)">Anagrammatism. </form> <xpln lang="en">The
Art of making Anagrams,
which is a dissolution of a
name truly written into his
letters, as his Elements, and a
new connexion of it by Arti&shy;
ficial transposition (without
addition, subtraction or
change of any Letter) into
different words, making some
perfect sense applyable to the
person named; As

<term lang="la">Carolus Stuartus, Angli&aelig;, Scoti&aelig;
&amp; Hiberni&aelig; Rex.</term>
Anagr.
<term lang="la">Aula, Regno, Statu Exuerit, &amp;
hostili arte necaberis</term>.

The precise in this practise,
strictly observing all the parts
of the definition, are onely
bold with H, either in omit&shy;
ing or retaining it, for that it
cannot challenge the right of
a letter, but the Licentiates,
somewhat licentiously, lest
they should prejudice poeti&shy; 
cal liberty, will pardon them&shy;
selves for doubling or reject&shy;
ing a letter, if the sense fall
aptly, and think it no injury
to use E for &AElig;, V for W, S for
Z, and C for K, and contrari&shy;
wise. 

The Greeks (saith Camden)
refer this invention to Lyco&shy;
phron, who was one of those
Poets, whom the Greeks cal&shy;
led the seven stars or Pleiades,
and flourished about the yeer
380 before Christ, in the
time of Ptolom&aelig;us Philadel&shy;
phus King of &AElig;gypt, whose
name he thus Anagramma&shy;
tized, 

<term lang="gk">&Pi;&Tau;&Omicron;&Lambda;&Epsilon;&Mu;&Alpha;&Iota;&Omicron;&#x03A3;.</term>.

<term lang="gk">&Alpha;&pi;&#x1F78; &mu;&#x1F73;&lambda;&iota;&tau;&omicron;&#x03C2;</term>. Made of hony. 

And upon Arsinoe his wife,
thus.<term lang="gk">&Alpha;&Rho;&#x03A3;&Iota;&Nu;&Omicron;&#x1FCB;.</term> 
<term lang="gk">&#x1F9D;&rho;&omicron;&#x03C2; &#x1F34;&omicron;&nu;</term>. June's Violet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anagraph(n)">Anagraph<etym lang="la"> (anagraphe)</etym></form> <xpln lexeme="inventory(n)">a
registring or recording of
matters: an Inventory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analect(n)">Analects<etym lang="la"> (analecta)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">frag&shy;
ments, scraps of meat or
crums gathered together; and
metaphorically it is used for
collections or fragments of
learning, gathered out of any
Book or Author.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analem(n)">Analem<etym lang="la"> (analemma)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a Ma&shy;
thematical Instrument, wher&shy;
by is found out the elevation
of any Planet, or the height
of any other thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analogism(n)">Analogism<etym lang="la"> (analogismus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
forcible Argument, from the
Cause to the Effect, implying
an unanswerable necessity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analogy(n)">Analogy<etym lang="la"> (analogia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the just
proportion, correspondence 


</page>

<page sig="c6v">
and measure, which the ob&shy;
ject or subject holds, with the
true reason required therein:
An Agreement, harmony or
apt answering of the thing to
the considerations proper
thereunto. El. of Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analogous(a)" lexeme="analogical(a)">Analogous 
Analogical 
<etym lang="la"> (analogicus)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">proportional,
equal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analogist(n)">Analogists<etym lang="la"> (analogist&aelig;)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">tu&shy;
tors that are not bound to
give account of those whom
they have under tuition, as
guardians and protectors of
Wards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="analysis(n)">Analysis<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a resolution
or unfolding of an intricate
matter: or a resolving or di&shy;
stribution of the whole into
parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ananias(pn)">Ananias <class type="etymlang" lang="he">(Heb.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">the grace
