<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anapest(n)">Anapest (<etym lang="la">anap&aelig;stus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a foot
in a Latin verse, consisting of
two short syllables and one
long, as, <term lang="la">vacuas</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anapestic verse(n)">Anapestick Verse (<etym lang="la">anap&aelig;sti&shy;
cum</etym>) or Aristophanick,</form> <xpln lang="en">common&shy;
ly used in Tragedies, hath 3
feet, an Anap&aelig;st, a Dactyle and
a Spondee, which are used in
all parts of the verse indiffe&shy;
rently, as,

<term lang="la">Castos sequitur mala paupertas.
Vitioque potens regnat adulter.</term> 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anapolegetical(a)">Anapolegetical (from Gr.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anarchic(a)">Anarchique<etym lang="la"> (anarchicus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to Anarchy, with&shy;
out rule or government.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anarchy(n)">Anarchy<etym lang="la"> (anarchia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">when
people are without a Prince
or Ruler; lack of Govern&shy;
ment, confusion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anarchism(n)">Anarchism, </form> <xpln lang="en">the Doctrine,
Positions or Art of those that
teach Anarchy ; also the being
itself of the people without a
Prince or Ruler.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anathem(n)">Anathem ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">ana&shy;
thema</etym> with an era or &eacute; longum)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an offering or gift given to an
Idol, or to the Church, and
hanged up in the Temple in
testimony of devotion or
thanksgiving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anathem(n)">Anathem (from <etym lang="la">Anathema</etym> 
with an epsilon or ebreve)</form> <xpln lang="en">a man
that is accursed or given to the
divel by Excommunication;
also execration or excommu&shy;
nication it self. Anathema Ma&shy;
ranatha is one accursed for e&shy;
ver, or eternal execration, 1
Cor.6.21. Anathema belongs to
all obstinate scandalous offen&shy;
ders: Anathema Marantha be&shy;
longs onely to blasphemers of
the H. Ghost, Gal.1.9. Rom.9.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anathematize(v)">Anathematize<etym lang="la"> (anathematizo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
to excommunicate, to swear,
curse and give to the devil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anatiferous(a)">Anatiferous (from <etym lang="la">Anas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that brings the disease or age
of old women. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anatocism(n)">Anatocism<etym lang="la"> (anatocismus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anatomy(n)">Anatomy<etym lang="la"> (anatomia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the in&shy;

to discover the substance, acti&shy;
ons &amp; use of every part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ancile(n)">Ancil<etym lang="la"> (ancile)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">was a short
Buckler or Scutcheon which
was formed without corners,
being rebated on each side in
the fashion of a decressant or
Moon in the last quarter. This
Ancile (as they say) fell from
heaven into the hands of King
Numa in time of a Plague at
Rome, and he being adver&shy;
tised by Egeria, that it was
for the health of the City,
and ought to be kept safe,
caused eleven more to be
made so like, as they could
not be known from the pat&shy;
tern, which hereby was pre&shy;
served; the keeping hereof
was committed to the 12.
Salii . Livie and Fern.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Andrew(pn)">Andrew ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="la">Andreas</etym>)

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="angle(n)">Angle<etym lang="la"> (angulus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a corner,
nook, or secret place. It is al&shy;
so a Geometrical term for a
corner, included by two lines;
of which there are three sorts,
to wit, a right, an acute, and
obtuse angle . 

1 A Right Angle, is when
the two lines meeting do
frame a just square Angle of
90 degrees.
2 An Acute, is when the
two lines enclose less then a
square, thereby becoming
more sharp, and therefore A&shy;
cute .
3 An Obtuse Angle, Is when
the two lines include more
then the square, making it
thereby the more blunt and
dull, and is therefore called
Obtuse. Enchiridion of forti&shy;
fication.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="angor(n)">Angor<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">anguish or
grief either of body or mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annals(n)">Annals<etym lang="la"> (annales)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">brief histo&shy;
ries or Chronicles of things
done from yeer to yeer, pro&shy;
perly spoken of things done
in former ages, not in the pre&shy;
sent. Tacitus applies to Annals,
matters of state; To Diaries,
Acts and accidents of a mean&shy;
er nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annalist(n)">Annalist, </form> <xpln lang="en">he that makes or
writes such Annals or yeerly
Chronicles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annarian law(n)">Annarian Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">was a Law
among the Romans, first pro&shy;
posed by L. Julius, a Tribune
of the Commons, touching 
the yeer of the age requisite,
and meet to sue for any pub&shy;
lique office, or to exercise the 
same. Livy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annates(n)">Annats</form> <xpln lang="en">First fruits paid
of spiritual livings; so called
because the rate so paid, is al&shy;
so after one yeers profit. These
Annats (says Pol. Virgil) began
first at the Popes own Bene&shy;
fices, whereof he was Patron.
But Clement the fifth generally
decreed it in the yeer 1305.
Boniface the ninth, and John
 the 22, renewed that De&shy;
cree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anne(pn)">Anne (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class> <etym lang="he">Hannah</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gra&shy;
cious or merciful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anneal(v)">Anneale.</form> <xpln lang="en">To paint upon
glass, to annoint, or do any
thing with oyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anniferous(a)">Anniferous<etym lang="la"> (annifer)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that
bears fruit all the yeer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annihilate(v)">Annihilate<etym lang="la"> (annihilo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is the
opposite to creation, that as
to create, is to make some&shy;
thing of nothing, or to pro&shy;
duce an effect without the
help of precedent materials:
so to annihilate is utterly to
destroy or to reduce some&shy;
thing to its old nothing; and
as to create is an action pro&shy;
per onely to God himself, so
in like maner to annihilate is
onely proper to Him, whereas
other kinds of productions
and corruptions are the ordi&shy;
nary effects of sublunary and
second Causes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anniversary(n)">Anniversary<etym lang="la"> (anniversarius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that comes every yeer at a
certain time, yeerly, or from
yeer to yeer. 


</page>

<page sig="C8r">
Those were of old called An&shy;
niversary days, wheron the mar&shy;
tyrdoms or death-day of Sts.
were celebrated yeerly in the
Church; or the days where&shy;
on at the yeers end, men were
wont yeerly to pray for the
souls of their deceased friends
according to the continued
custom of Roman Catholiques</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annosity(n)">Annosity<etym lang="la"> (annositas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">old
age, agedness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annotation(n)">Annotation<etym lang="la"> (annotatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
noting or marking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annual(a)">Annual<etym lang="la"> annualis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to the yeer, yeerly or
every yeer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annuity(n)">Annuity (<etym lang="la">annuus reditus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
yeerly Rent to be paid for
term of life or yeers, or in
Fee. There are divers dif&shy;
ferences between a Rent and
an Annuity, whereof the first
is, that every Rent is going out
of Land, and an Annuity
goes out of no Land, but
charges onely the person of
the granter, or his heirs, that
have Assets by descent. The
second difference is, that for
the recovery of an Annuity,
no Action lies, but onely the
Writ of Annuity against the
Granter, his heirs or succes&shy;
sors: but of a Rent the same
Actions lye, as do of Land, as
the case requires. The third
difference is, that an Annuity
is never taken for Assets, be&shy;
cause it is no Free hold in
Law, nor shall be put in exe&shy;
cution upon a Statute-Mer&shy;
chant, Statute-Staple, or Ele&shy;
git, as a Rent may. Doctor 
and Student, Dial.1 cap3. And
Dyer fol. 345. num.2, speaks
also to this effect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annul(v)">Annul<etym lang="la"> (annihilo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to fru&shy;
strate, make void or bring to
nought.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annulated(a)">Annulated<etym lang="la"> (annulatus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antarctic circle(pn)">Antartick Circle<etym lang="la"> (antar&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antecedent(a)">Antecedent<etym lang="la"> (antecedens)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath a Relative, that
goes before or excels; In an
Argument or discourse con&shy;
sisting of two Propositions,
which by Logicians is called
an Enthymem: the first proposi&shy;
tion is called the Antecedent,
the other inferred out of the
first, is called the Conse&shy;
quent.</xpln></wordentry>

nation by the raising of dead
men. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anthropophagy(n)">Anthropophagy <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a
feeding on mans flesh; hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anthropophagize(v)">Anthropophagize, </form> <xpln lang="en">to play
the Canibal, to eat or feed on
mans flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anthropopathy(n)">Anthropopathy <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">hu&shy;
mane or mans passion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anthropomorphites(pn)">Anthropomorphites (<etym lang="la">an&shy;
thropomorphit&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sect of simple
Heretiques that began in &AElig;&shy;
gipt about the year of Christ
395 in time of Pope Siricius
and of the Emperour Theodo&shy;
sius the elder: their peculiar
Doctrine was, that God had a
body or corporeal shape, con&shy;
sisting of head, neck, arms,
&amp;c. like a man, having their 


</page>

<page sig="D1r">
appellation from the Greek
word <term lang="gk">&alpha;&nu;&delta;&rho;&omega;&pi;&omicron;&#x03C2;</term>, which sig&shy;
nifies Man, they are also com&shy;
monly called Vadiani or Au&shy;
diani, from their esteemed
Father or Author <emend err="Audams" source="errata">Auduus</emend>, a
Syrian, that lived about the
year 380. in time of Pope Da&shy;
<emend err="macius" source="errata">majus</emend>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antichrist(pn)">Antichrist<etym lang="la"> (antichristus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an
enemy or adversary to Christ.
It is compounded of the
Greek proposition<term lang="gk"> Anti</term> and
<term lang="la">Christus</term>, which signifies con&shy;
trary or against Christ.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antichambre(n)">Antichambre <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">any out&shy;
ward chamber, which is next
or near to the bed chamber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anticipate(v)">Anticipate<etym lang="la"> (anticipo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to

forestal.</xpln></wordentry>

the dating of a Letter or
other writing before the time
of the making or writing
thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antidicomarians(pn)">Antidicomarians.</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> Maries
adversaries, a sort of Here&shy;
ticks enemies to the blessed
Virgin. Sir. Tho. More.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antidote(n)">Antidote<etym lang="la"> (antidotum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a

gainst venome or poyson.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antique work(n)">Antike work (<etym lang="la">ab antes</etym> i. a
prop or buttress)</form> <xpln lang="en">a work in
painting or carving of divers
shapes of Men, Birds, Flowers,
Fishes, &amp;c. imperfectly, and
disorderly mixt and made
one out of another for delight
sake. Ball.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antigonize(v)"> To Antigonize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to play the
Antigonus, who was a boun&shy;
tiful King of Macedonia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antigraph(n)">Antigraph<etym lang="la"> (antigraphum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
an example, a copy, a coun&shy;
terpane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antigrapher(n)">Antigrapher<etym lang="la"> (antigraphus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a Controller, Treasurer, he
that keeps the accounts or
money received to the Princes
use, a maker or keeper of
counterpanes of Deeds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antilogy(n)" lexeme="antiloquy(n)">Antilogy 
Antiloquy 
<etym lang="la"> (antilogia)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">contradiction
gainsaying or overthwarting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antimetrical(a)">Antimetrical</form> <xpln lang="en">contrary, or
against the rule or order of
meeter, or verse. Recl. Pap.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antimony(n)">Antimony<etym lang="la"> (antimonium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
is a vein of the earth, like
lead, howbeit it hath this
difference from a metal; a
metal meltes, Antimony is bray&shy;
ed, and will be burnt rather
than molten; it is cold and dry
in the third degree, and is used
in Collyries for the eyes. Vig.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antimonial(a)">Antimonial, </form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
Antimony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antinomy(n)">Antinomy<etym lang="la"> (antinomia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
repugnance or contrariety be&shy;
tween two Laws, or the con&shy;
trarying of a Law. It was the
custom in Athens to delegate
five persons, to revise and ex&shy;
amine every year the contra&shy;
ry-Titles of Law, which they
called Antinomies . &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antinomians(pn)">Antinomians (<term lang="la">ab</term> <etym lang="gk">&alpha;&nu;&tau;&#x1f76;</etym> <etym lang="la">con&shy;
tr&agrave;, &amp;c.</etym> <etym lang="gk">&nu;&#x03cc;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">lex,  quasi, ad&shy;
versarii legis</term>, adversaries to
the Law)</form> <xpln lang="en">are a sort of
Reformists hatcht in Lu&shy;
thers days, about one hun&shy;
dred and thirty years since,
by a disciple once of Luther,
called John sir-named Islebius 


</page>

<page sig="d1v">
(from the Town Islebium,
where he and Luther were
both born in the County of
Mansfield in Germany) a hus&shy;
bandman. The Tenets of that
Sect are: That there be no de&shy;
vils; That the men of the
Gospel are not bound to do
the good works of Gods
Law, as being neither neces&shy;
sary, nor profitable; That
whatsoever sins a man falls in&shy;
to, be they Whoredoms, A&shy;
dulteries, thefts, Rebellions,
or what ever other, yet if he
do but believe the promises of
the Gospel, he is sure to be sa&shy;
ved; with such other dam&shy;
nable points. This Heresie is
still lurking in many corners
of Christendom; one John
Eaton is said to have been the
first professor of this Sect in
England.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antipast(n)">Antipast,</form> <xpln lang="en">The first dish of
a dinner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antipathy(n)">Antipathy<etym lang="la"> (antipathia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a con&shy;
trariety in nature, or natural
repugnance, a contrariety in
passions or inclinations, a dis&shy;
agreement of dispositions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antipathetical(a)">Antipathetical (<etym lang="la">anti <term lang="en">and</term> 
patheticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of a contrary pas&shy;
sion or nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antiperistasis(n)">Antiperistasis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term used
in Philosophy, when heat be&shy;
ing kept in by cold, waxes
the stronger in it self, or cold
kept in by heat grows more
vehement: an encounter of
contraries, or contrary cir&shy;
cumstance. Dub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antipelargy(n)">Antipelargy<etym lang="la"> (antipelargesis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the reciprocal love of chil&shy; 
dren to their Parents, or
(more generally) any requi&shy;
tal or mutual kindness. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antiphrasy(n)">Antiphrasie<etym lang="la"> (antiphrasis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
figure, where a word hath a
contrary meaning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antiphrastical(a)">Antiphrastical,</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath
or gives a contrary meaning to
words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antiphon(n)">Antiphone<etym lang="la"> (antiphona)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an
Anthemn, a kinde of Verse or
Sentence, which Church-men
sing by course, one singing one
verse, and another another.
<term lang="la">Vox reciproca duobus choris alter&shy;
natim psallentibus</term>. A respon&shy;
sory song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antipileptical(a)">Antipileptical <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">that
is good against the falling&shy;
sickness; or which is contra&shy;
ry to that disease. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antipodes(pn)">Antipodes <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">people
dwelling on the other side of
the earth with their feet di&shy;
rectly against ours, so as a
right line drawn from the one
to the other, passeth from
North to South, through the
Center of the world. These
are distant 180 degrees, which
is half the compass of the
earth. They differ in all
things, as seasons of the yeer,
length of days, rising and set&shy;
ting of the Sun, with the
like. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antipodal(a)">Antipodal,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
the Antipodes, or to those peo&shy;
ple that have their feet direct&shy;
ly against ours. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antiquary(n)">Antiquary<etym lang="la"> (antiquarius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
one that searches or is well
skild in Antiquities, as Coyns,
Histories, old words, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="d2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antiquate(v)">Antiquate<etym lang="la"> (antiquo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to bring
into the ancient manner or e&shy;
state, to abrogate or make
void.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antique(a)">Antique<etym lang="la"> (antiquus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">old,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antistrophe(n)">Antistrophe (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">inversio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a figure in Rhetorique, when
between two things that mu&shy;
tually hang one on the other,
there is an interchangeable
conversion, As <term lang="la"> Servus Domi&shy;
ni, Dominus servi</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antisabbatarians(pn)">Antisabbatarians.</form> <xpln lang="en">A sort
of Hereticks, who would
have no particular Sabboth at
all, but every day to be a Sab&shy;
both to a Christian man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antithesis(n)">Antithesis <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Rhero&shy;
tical figure, when contraries
are opposed to contraries, as
spokes in a wheele; a contra&shy;
ry Position, or opposition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antithet(n)">Antithets<etym lang="la"> (antitheta)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">op&shy;
posites, contraries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anti-Trinitarians(pn)">Anti-Trinitarians.</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> Ad&shy;
versaries to the Blessed Tri&shy;
nity, who are more spoken of
in writers under the name of
Trinitarians, which compre&shy;
hends those Heretiques that
reject the word Trinity, as not
being found in Holy Scripture,
and deny the number and
distinction of three persons
in the blessed Trinity. As the
Arians, who denyed him to
be truely God: whom true
believers call the son of the
Eternal Father, or the second
person of the Blessed Trinity.
Or as the Sabellians (having
their name from their Author
Sabellius an Egyptian, who 
lived <term lang="la"> Anno Christi</term> 260) who
denyed any difference or di&shy;
stinction betwixt the three
persons, confounding the
three into one. Or as the
Macedonians (so denominated
from Macedonius a Bishop of
Constantinople, living about the
year of Christ 359) who de&shy;
nyed the Holy Ghost to be
God, or as many other old
condemned Heretiques, to
whose opinions subscribed
those in the last age, who are
termed Deists, followers of
one Gregorius Pauli a Mini&shy;
ster of Cracovia in Poland a&shy;
bout the year of Christ 1564,
who vented many blasphe&shy;
mies against the Blessed Tri&shy;
nity, and many others, as Lu&shy;
dovicus Hetser, Michael Serve&shy;
tus, Campanus, with many di&shy;
sciples of theirs in Germany,
Hungary, Poland, and other
places, where there are of
them to this day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antetype(n)" lexeme="antitypy(n)">Antitype 
Antitypie 
<etym lang="la"> (antitypum)</etym> </form> <xpln lang="en">an 
example or
copy like or contrary to the
pattern. Bac. useth it:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antonians(pn)">Antonians, </form> <xpln lang="en">an order of
Religious persons, instituted
about the yeer 324, by the
&AElig;gyptian Monk St. Anthony,
who at the first sold his pos&shy;
sessions, and distributed their
worth among the poor, and
afterwards betook himself to
a most holy austere course of
life, perpetually addicted to
Prayer, Fasting, Watching,
and other corporeal mortifi&shy;
cations; teaching his Disci&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="d2v">
ples or followers to fight a&shy;
gainst the Devil, and his temp&shy;
tations with the sign of the
Holy Cross; His life was
written by Athanasius one
of the Greek Fathers, that
lived in his days.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antonomastically(adv)">Antonomastically, </form> <xpln lang="en">that is
said or spoken by the figure
Antonomasia, which is a put&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aonian(pn)">Aonian,</form> <xpln lang="en">An Epithete for

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apannage(n)">Apennage 
Appennage 
 <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">the
portion of
the Kings younger Sons in
France, a childs part. They
have in France a Fundamental
Law, which they call the
Law of Appennages, whereby
the Kings younger Sons can&shy;
not have partage with the el&shy;
der. This law was made by
Charlemayne, before whose
time France was dividable
into as many Kingdoms as the
King had Sons. By this Law
the younger (though some&shy;
times they are content with 
yearly Pensions) are to be<emend err="en"> en&shy;</emend>
tituled to some Dutchy, and
all the Profits, and Rights
thereto appertaining: all mat&shy;
ters of regality only excepted,
as Coynage, levying Taxes,
and the like. It is derived 
from the German word <term lang="gr">Avan&shy;
nage</term> which signifies a porti&shy;
on. View of France.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Apellean(a)">Apellean<etym lang="la"> (apelleus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to Apelles an <emend err="excel">excel&shy;</emend>
lent Painter.</xpln></wordentry>

Wot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Apocalypse(pn)">Apocalypse<etym lang="la"> (apocalypsis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a

Pathmos; So called because
it contains many profound

to him. The words bare
signification is, a revelation or
vision.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apocryphal(a)">Apocryphal<etym lang="la"> (apocryphus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is hidden, <emend err="un">un&shy;</emend>
known or doubtful; whose
original authority is not
known; Part of the Scrip&shy;
ture so called, because it is
doubted whether it be true
Scripture, or not certainly
known to be so.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apogean(n)" lexeme="apogee(n)">Apogeon

Shroud or Den
under the earth; also a tearm
in Astronomy, signifying the

any Planet is farthest from the

motest point of an Epicycle,
Ryder.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apology(n)" lexeme="apologism(n)">Apology

</form> <xpln lang="en">a defence or

cus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;

cuse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apologize(v)">Apologize<etym lang="la"> (apologizo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
make such a defence or ex&shy;
cuse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apologue(n)">Apologue<etym lang="la"> (apologus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a Fable
or Tale such as &AElig;sops were,
when bruite Beasts are feig&shy;
ned to speak, and which co&shy;
vertly teach lessons of good
life.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apophlegmatism(n)">Apophlegmatism<etym lang="la"> (apophleg&shy;
matismus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a medicine to
purge the Flegm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apophthegm(n)">Apophthegm<etym lang="la"> (apophtheg&shy;
ma)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a brief and pithy speech
or sentence of renowned per&shy;
sonages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apopheret(n)">Apopheret<etym lang="la"> (apopheretum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a New-years gift, a Pre&shy;
sent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apoplectical(a)">Apoplectical<etym lang="la"> (apoplecticus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to the Apo&shy;
plexy.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="d3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apoplexy(n)">Apoplexy<etym lang="la"> (apoplexia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a ve&shy;
ry dangerous disease, where&shy;
in a man lyes, without sense
or motion, as if he were dead,
with his eys closed, and great
difficulty in fetching his
breath; it comes for the most
part of cold and gross flegma&shy;
tick humors, oppressing the
brain in such sort, that the
Animal spirits cannot pass
from thence into the sinews,
as they were wont. A Pal&shy;
sey or dead Palsey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aporetic(a)">Aporetique<etym lang="la"> (from Aporia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
ever doubting, never certain
in any thing, wanting Coun&shy;
sel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apostata(n)">Apostata</form> <xpln lang="en">he that revolts or
falls from any thing he has
undertaken to defend, as from
true Religion. Iulianus the
Emperor was most infamous
for this crime, and therefore
called Iulian, the Apostata.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apostatize(v)">Apostatize<etym lang="la"> (apostato)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
make defection by revolt,
rebel or fall away from his Re&shy;
ligion, duty or purpose. 

Hence comes Apostacy the
Substantive, and Apostatical 
the Adjective.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aposteme(n)">Aposteme</form> <xpln lang="en">See <xref lexeme="impostume"> Impost&shy;
hume</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apostle(n)">Apostle<etym lang="la"> (Apostolus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">one
sent of a Message, a Messen&shy;
ger or Embassador. There&shy;
fore the twelve which Christ
sent to preach the word of
God, are properly called Apo&shy;
stles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Apostolics(pn)" lexeme="Apostolians(pn)">Apostolicks  
or
Apostolians <etym lang="la"> (Apostolici)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of
Heretiques 
that hold, 1 That many
Christians in these days have
more knowledge then the A&shy;
postles. 2 That there is a
salvation to be revealed un&shy;
known to the Apostles them&shy;
selves; 3 That God in a short
time will raise up Apostles,
men extraordinarily endued
with visible infallible gifts to
preach the Gospel, &amp;c. with
other such erroneous Tenets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apostrophe(n)">Apostroph<etym lang="la"> (apostrophus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
mark or comma, signifying
the cutting off some vowel, as
' tis for it is, th' end, for the end,
and the like; most used in
Poetry. It is also a figure,
when we convert our speech
from one matter or person to
another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apostume(n)">Apostume<etym lang="la"> (apostema)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an
Impostume, an unnatural swel&shy;
ling of any corrupt matter in
the body.<xref> See Impostume</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apophthegm(n)">Apothegme</form> <xpln lang="en"> See <xref target="apophthegm">Apo&shy;
phthegme</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apothec(n)">Apotheke<etym lang="la"> (apotheca)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a place
where any thing is laid to be
kept, as a shop, ware house, or
store house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apotomy(n)">Apotomy<etym lang="la"> (apotomia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a cut&shy;
ting off; a Mathematical
term.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apozem(n)">Apozeme<etym lang="la"> (apozema)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
coction, a boyling of water
with divers kinds of Spices
and herbs, used in stead of
of Syrrups; broth. Bac. in
his Nat. Hist. and Mr. Mon&shy;
tagu.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appareil(n)">Appareil <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">preparation,
provision, ready making; it
is an ancient word used in the 


</page>

<page sig="d4r">
Accompts of the Inner Temple,
and signifies that sum at the
foot of an account, which the
house remains in debt, or
which remains charged on the
house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apparitor(n)">Apparitor<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Serje&shy;
ant, Beadle, or Sumner; but
most commonly used for an
inferior Officer that summon'd
in Delinquents to a spiritual
Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appeal(n)">Appeale<etym lang="la"> (appellatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is of&shy;
ten used in our Common Law
as it is taken in the Civil:
which is a removing of a
Cause from an inferior Judge
to a superior, as Appeal to
Rome, Ann. 24. H.8. c.12. and
1 Eliz. c. I. So St. Paul ap&shy;
pealed from Festus to C&aelig;sar.
But it is more commonly u&shy;
sed for the private accusation
of a murtherer, by a person
who had interest in the party
murthered, or of any Fellon,
by one of his complices in the
Fact. See more of this in
Cowels Interpreter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appellation(n)">Appellation<etym lang="la"> (appellatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
calling or pronouncing an
Appeal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appellative(n)">Appellative<etym lang="la"> (appellativus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
naming, mentioning or cal&shy;
ling. Grammatically it is
taken for common, opposite
to proper, as this word homo,
a man, is by the Grammarians
called a Noun or name appel&shy;
lative, because common to all
men, and this word Petrus,
Peter, is a Noun or name pro&shy;
per to one individual per&shy;
son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appendant(n)">Appendant (<etym lang="la">appendens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
any thing belonging to ano&shy;
ther, As <term lang="la"> Accessorium principali</term>,
with the Civilians, or <term lang="la"> Adjun&shy;
ctum subjecto</term> with the Logici&shy;
ans. An Hospital may be ap&shy;
pendant to a Manor, Fitzher.
Nat. Br. fol.142. Common of
fishing appendant to a Free&shy;
hold. Westmin.2. cap.25. An.
13. Ed. I:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appennage(n)">Appennage</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Apen&shy;
nage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appenditious(a)">Appenditious<etym lang="la"> (appendicus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that depends on another, per&shy;
taining to an Appendix.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appendix(n)">Appendix <class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a hang-by,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appensor(n)">Appensor<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">he that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Appian way(pn)">Appian Way<etym lang="la"> (Appia via)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
notable street or high-way
which leads from Rome to Ca&shy;
pua in Campania, which Appius
Claudius in his Consulship pa&shy;
ved with stones and walled,
and therefore took denomina&shy;
tion from him; but was ex&shy;
tended to Brundusium in Cala&shy;
bria, by Iulius C&aelig;sar and Tra&shy;
jan. Of all other it seems to
be the principal, by the testi&shy;
mony of Papinius the Poet,
<term lang="la">Appia cunctarum fertur Regina
viarum</term>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appretiatively(adv)">Appretiatively<etym lang="la"> (appretiativ&egrave;)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
according to the price or va&shy;
lue; It is usually contradi&shy;
stinguished to intensively ; As
wee may be said to love a
Dog more then a Child in&shy;
tensively, but not appretia&shy;
tively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appropinquation(n)">Appropinquation<etym lang="la"> (appro&shy;
pinquatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an approaching or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appropriation(n)">Appropriation<etym lang="la"> (appropriatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
A term in the Law of Eng&shy;
land, when any body corpo&shy;
rate or private person hath
the right, and converts the
profit of an Ecclesiastical Li&shy;
ving to his or their own use,
onely maintaining a Vicar to
serve the Cure. 

To make an Appropriation,
licence must be obteyned of
the King i<emend err="">n</emend> Chancery, and
the consent of the Diocesan,
Patron and Incumbent are ne&shy;
cessary, if the Church be full;
But if the Church be void, the
Diocesan and the Patron upon
the Kings licence may con&shy;
clude it. Plowden in Grendons
case fo.496. b. &amp;. Seqq. To dis&shy;
solve an Appropriation, it
is enough to present a Clark
to the Bishop, for, that once
done, the Benefice returns to
the former nature, Fitzh. nat. 
br. fo.35 F.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="approver(n)">Approver<etym lang="la"> (approbator)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in our Common
Law, one that confessing Fe&shy;
lony of himself, appeals
or accuseth another, one
or more to be guilty of the
same: and he is called so, be&shy;
cause hee must prove that
which he hath alleadged in
his appeal, Stanf. Pl. Cor.
fo. 142. And that proof is
by battail, or by the Coun&shy;
try at his Election that ap&shy;
pealed. See more of this in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arbitrary(a)">Arbitrary<etym lang="la"> (arbitrarius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is voluntary or
left to our own will or cen&shy;
sure; belonging to arbitre&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arbitrator(n)">Arbitratour<etym lang="la"> (arbitrator)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is
an extraordinary Judge or
Commissioner in one or
more causes, between party 


</page>

<page sig="d5v">
and party, chosen by their mu&shy;
tual consents. This Arbitre&shy;
ment is either general, that is,
including all Actions, Quar&shy;
rels, Executions and De&shy;
mands, or special, which is of
one or more matters, facts, or
things specifyed. The Civi&shy;
lians (says Dr. Cowel) make a
difference between Arbiter 
and Arbitrator. For though
they both ground their pow&shy;
er upon the comprimize of
the parties, yet their liberty
is divers. For Arbiter is tyed
to proceed and judge accor&shy;
ding to Law, with equity
mingled: Arbitrator is per&shy;
mitted wholly to his own
discretion, without solemni&shy;
ty of process, or course of
judgement, to hear or deter&shy;
mine the controversie com&shy;
mitted unto him, so it be <term lang="la"> 
juxta arbitrium boni viri</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arborary(a)">Arborary<etym lang="la"> (arborarius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to the Trees or
Arbours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arborist(n)">Arborist (from <etym lang="en">Arbor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he

cret, privy, unknown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsenal(n)">Arcenal</form> <xpln lang="en"> See <xref>Arsenal</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arch(n)">Arche ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">Archos</etym>) </form> <xpln lang="en">the first
or chief, Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archetype(n)">Archetype<etym lang="la"> (archetypum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
first pattern or Original Copy,
the principal figure or exam&shy;
ple, whereby a thing is fra&shy;
med.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arch-Dapifer(pn)">Arch-Dapifer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a chief
Sewer, it is the Title that be&shy;
longs to the Count Palatine
of the Rhene, under the <emend err="Em">Em&shy;</emend>
perour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arch Duke(pn)">Arch Duke,</form> <xpln lang="en">as much as the
first or principal Duke. This
title belongs onely to the
house of Austria, devised by
the Emperor Frederick to
grace his nephew Philip,
when he was to marry Ioan
the daughter of Spain. Se&shy;
cond part, Treasury of Times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arch-flamen(n)">Arch-Flamins,</form> <xpln lang="en">were a&shy;
mong the Heathens, what
Arch Bishops or Arch-Priests
are among Christians; the
Heathenish Romans had three
Arch-Flamins in Britain in
King Lucius his time, whose
seats were at London, Caerlion 
upon Uske, and York, and 28
Flamins; to whose power
other Judges were subject.
These by Pope Eleutherius' s Le&shy;
gat, were converted from Ido&shy;
latry, and Bishops and Archbi&shy;
shops placed in their stead,
&amp;c. Hen. Hunting Hist. lib. a. 
and in Prolog. and Broughtons 
 Eccles. Hist. fol.273.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="d6r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archigrapher(n)">Archigrapher<etym lang="la"> (archigraphus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the chief Secretary or princi&shy;
pal Clerk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archiloquy(n)">Archiloquy<etym lang="la"> (archiloquium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the first part or beginning of
a speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archimandrite(n)">Archimandrite<etym lang="la"> (archiman&shy;
drita)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an Abbot, Prior, or
chief of a Hermitage. Dr.
Taylor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archimimic(n)">Archimimick<etym lang="la"> (archimimus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the principal Player or chief
Jester.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="architect(n)">Architect<etym lang="la"> (architectus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
Master builder, the chief
workman in Architecture, the
first inventer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="architectonical(a)">Architectonical <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a chief Master
or Architect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="architecture(n)">Architecture<etym lang="la"> (architecture)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the art of devising, framing,
or drawing plots in building.
It is written that this Science
did begin in Cain, because he
was the first that ever built
a City, which he called by his
sons name Enoch, as appears,
Gen.4. This Art contains the
condition of Carpentry, Ma&shy;
sonry, Imagery, Gold&shy;
smithry, and whatever is to
be wrought in either wood,
stone, or mettals. 1. part Treasury
of Times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="architrave(n)">Architrabs<etym lang="la"> (Architrabs)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
Crown or Chapter of a stone
Pillar: The reason-piece or
Master beam in buildings of
Timber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archive(n)">Archive<etym lang="la"> (archivum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
place where the Ancient Evi&shy;
dences, Charters and Records
are kept, the Chancery or Ex&shy; 
chequer. Lord Bacon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arch-triumphant(a)">Arch-triumphant.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref lexeme="triumphant arches">See Triumphant-Arch.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Archontics(pn)">Archonticks<etym lang="la"> (archontici)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
certain Heretiques, who af&shy;
firmed the world to be the
work of Princes, and denyed
the Resurrection. They took
their name from Archon the
first of that Sect, and began
about the yeer of Christ 334.
Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Archyea's wooden dove(n)">Archyeas wooden Dove</form> <xpln lang="en">
(famoused by Agullinus and o&shy;
ther Authors) which by rea&shy;
son of weights equally poysed
within the body, and a cer&shy;
tain proportion of ayr (as the
spirit of life) enclosed, flew
cheerfully forth, as if it had
been a living Dove. Compl.
Gent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arcitenent(a)">Arcitenent<etym lang="la"> (arcitenens, ab
arcum tenendo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">which bears or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arctation(n)">Arctation<etym lang="la"> (arctatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a strait&shy;
ning or making narrow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arctic Circle(pn)">Artick Circle (<etym lang="la">arcticus 
Circulus</etym>, so called for that it is
correspondent to the Circle
in Heaven called the Bear, in
Greek <term lang="gk">Arclos</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is distant from
the Tropick of Cancer 45 de&shy;
grees, it passeth through Nor&shy;
way, Muscovy, Tartary, &amp;c.
Heyl. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arctic Pole(pn)">Arctick Pole<etym lang="la"> (Polus arti&shy;

signifies northward or north&shy;
erne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arcubalist(n)" lexeme="arbalist(n)">Arcubalist 
 or Arbalist <etym lang="la"> (arcubalista)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">a warlike en&shy;
gine to cast
or shoot darts or stones. Our
Rich. I. first shewed the use
of this Engine to the
French, and was shortly af&shy;
ter slain by a shot there&shy;
of discharged by Bertram
De Gurdon at the siege
of Chaluz in France.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="areopagite(n)">Areopagite<etym lang="la"> (areopagita)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
Judges among the Atheni&shy;
ans instituted by Solon to
judge of life and death;
their custom was to use
such severity and integrity
in judgement, that they
heard all causes and mat&shy;
ters in the night, to the in&shy;
tent they should have no oc&shy;
casion to regard the parties,
but onely have their eye and 
respect earnestly to the thing
that was brought before
them. They were called
Areopagites from the Greek
<term lang="gk">Areopagos</term>, that is, Mars his
street, a street in Athens so
called, where they sate.
St. Dionysius, convert&shy;
ed to the Christian faith by
St. Paul, was one of those
Judges. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="areopagitical(a)">Areopagitical</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
the Areopagi.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Areopagy(pn)">Areopagy<etym lang="la"> (areopagus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
Town where the Judges cal&shy;
led. Areopagi sate in Judica&shy;
ture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aretaloger(n)" lexeme="aretalogon(n)">Aretaloger 
Aretalogon  
<etym lang="la"> (aretalogus)</etym> 
</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
braggs or boasts of vertue
in himself, a talking fellow,
a lyer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arescation(n)">Arescation from<etym lang="la"> Aresco)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">

Feltham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aretaphilia(pn)">Aretaphilia (Gr. <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">ama&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="argentanginy(n)">Argentanginy<etym lang="la"> (aregentan&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="argentry(n)" lexeme="argent(n)">Argentry 
Argent  
(Fr. from <etym lang="fr">Ar&shy;
gentum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">sil&shy;
ver, coyn, or mony; in He&shy;
raldry it signifies the silver
colour, or white, which the
Heralds hold to be the first
and most excellent colour. 


</page>

<page sig="d7r">
And white (Plato saith) is
the fittest colour for God; a&shy;
mong the Planets it is
compared to the Moon, and
among precious stones to the
Oriental Pearl . Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="argilous(a)">Argilous<etym lang="la"> (argillosus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">full
of white clay, fat, fertile,
clammy. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Argonauts(pn)">Argonauts<etym lang="la"> (argonaut&aelig;)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
worthies that went into
Colchos to fetch the Golden&shy;
Fleece: so called of the
ship Argo, in which they
sayled, the chief of them
were Jason, Typhis, Castor,
Pollux, Hercules and These&shy;
us. Also taken for idle and
lazy Marriners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="argonautic(n)">Argonauticks</form> <xpln lang="en">Books
treating of that Navigation
to Greece.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="argutious(a)">Argutious<etym lang="la"> (argutus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">subtile,
witty, of deep-reach, full of
words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arid(a)">Arid<etym lang="la"> (aridus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">dry, bar&shy;
ren, withered, unfruitful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aridate(v)">Aridate<etym lang="la"> (arido)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to make

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aridity(n)">Aridity<etym lang="la"> (ariditas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">dryness
or barrenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aries(pn)">Aries<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Ram, an
Engine heretofore used
in besieging Cities, so
called because it had horns of
Iron like a Rams-head, which
batter'd the walls; or other&shy;
wise, because they rushed a&shy;
gainst the walls with it, as a
Ram with his head, and back
again. The form of which
you may finde in Marcellinus,
lib.23 c 3. Also the first sign of
the Zodiack, so called, be&shy; 
cause when the Sun enters
into that sign about mid&shy;
March, he begins to beat
with his beams upon the
beginnings of the New&shy;
year, as a Ram doth butt,
or push with his horns.
Du Bartas.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arietine(a)">Arietine<etym lang="la"> (arietinus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">of or
like a Ram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arietation(n)">Arietation<etym lang="la"> (arietatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
butting like a Ram; or a bat&shy;
tering with the Engine called
the Ram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ariolation(n)">Ariolation<etym lang="la"> (ariolatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">fore&shy;
telling, sooth-saying, Vulg.
Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aristocracy(n)">Aristocracy<etym lang="la"> aristocratia()</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
kinde of Government in a
Commonwealth, wherein the
Nobles or better sort onely
rule. Such is the Republique
of Venice, which is governed
by a Senate of Noble men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aristocratical(a)">Aristocratical.</form> <xpln lang="en">Of or be&shy;
longing to that kind of Go&shy;
vernment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arithmetic(n)">Arithmetick<etym lang="la"> (arithmetica)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the Art of numbring: It is
written, that Abraham first
taught this Art to the Egyp&shy;
tians, and that afterwards Py&shy;
thagoras did much increase it.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arithmancy(n)">Arithmancy <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">Divi&shy;
nation made by number,
which hath consideration
and contemplation of Ange&shy;
lical vertues; of names,
signacles, Natures, and
Conditions, both of di&shy;
vels and other Creatures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aritude(n)">Aritude.</form> <xpln lang="en">The same with
 <xref>Aridity</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="d7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ark(n)">Arke<etym lang="la"> (arca)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">In Holy Scri&shy;
pture signifies two things
1. The Ark made by Noah at
the commandment of God,
which was 300 Cubits long,
(one foot and half to the <emend err="Cu&shy;">Cu&shy;</emend>
bit) 50 Cubits broad, and 30
high, Cen. 6. which sheweth
(according to But&aelig;o) the
whole concavity to have been
450000. The remnants of
which, Josephus saith, were in
his time to be seen. 

2. It signifies a most preci&shy;
ous and consecrated coffer, or
Chest called the Ark of Testa&shy;
ment or Testimony, made of
the wood Sethim, and plated
within and without all over
with gold: it had four cor&shy;
ners, and in each corner a
golden Ring, thorow which
were put bars of the same
wood, covered likewise with
gold, which served for the
carriage of it; This Arke
was two Cubits and a half
long, one Cubit and a half
broad, and one Cubit and a
half deep. Exod.25.30. In it
was kept part of the Manna 
in a pot of gold, also the
Two Tables of the Law, and
Aarons rod that had budded,
Heb.9.4.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Armada(pn)">Armada <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">(Sp.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a great Ar&shy;
my or Navy.</xpln></wordentry>

warlike.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armillate(a)">Armillate<etym lang="la"> (armillatus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
which hath or weareth brace&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arminians(pn)">Arminians</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called from
Iames Arminius a professor of
Divinity at Leyden, who lived
about the year 1605) a sort
of Hereticks, called also Re&shy;
monstrants ; that hold several
erroneous opinions concern&shy;
ing Predestination, the Re&shy;
demption of man by Christs
death, &amp;c. And in some
points agree with the Ancient
Pelagians . Heresiog.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armipotent(a)">Armipotent<etym lang="la"> (armipotens)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
powerful in arms, valiant, cou&shy;
ragious.</xpln></wordentry>

of beasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armoniac(n)">Armoniack<etym lang="la"> (armoniacum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a gum issuing from the Cyreni&shy;
an Ferula or Fennel-gyant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Armoric(pn)">Armorick<etym lang="la"> (Armonica)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en"> Brit&shy;
tain in France so called, and
the people of that Country
are called Armoricans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arroba(n)">Arobe, </form> <xpln lang="en">a measure of Sugar

zil, containing 25 of our En&shy;
glish Bushels. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harquebus(n)">Arquebuse <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr:)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Gun,

<page sig="d8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrearages(n)">Arrearages (comes of the
French<etym lang="fr">Arrierages</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">reliqua)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
it signifies the remain of an
account, or a sum of mony re&shy;
maining in the hands of an
accountant, it is also used
more generally for any mony
unpaid at the due time, as
arrearages of Rent. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arreptitious(a)">Arreptitious<etym lang="la"> (arreptitius)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
caught or tormented by a 
devil; also he that steals or
creeps in privily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrest(n)">Arrest <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">in the com&shy;
mon signification it is well
known for a seisure of, or Ex&shy;
ecution served upon a mans
person or goods; But we
sometimes use it (as the
French) for a Sentence, De&shy;
cree, Order or final Judge&shy;
ment of a Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arrianism(pn)">Arrianism.</form> <xpln lang="en">An Ancient
and pestilent Heresie (hatched
by one Arrius a Lybian born
(but a Priest of Alexandria)
which denyed the Son to be
consubstantial or of the same
substance with God the Fa&shy;
ther, &amp; asserted that he was a
creature made by God, capa&shy;
ble of vice, &amp;c. To beat
down which Heresie, the first
Council of Nice was called,
the Nicene Creed made, and
the Clause of one substance with
the Father, proved to be con&shy;
sentaneous to the Word. To
subscribe the Decrees of this
Council, Arius was sent for,
by the Emperor Constantine;
To whom he went, having
written his own heretical Te&shy;
nets, which he hid in his bo&shy;
som, and reading before the 
Emperor the Decrees of the
Council, he wrote a Recantati&shy;
on of his heresie, swearing
that he meant as he had
written; which words the
Emperor referred to the
Recantation, but he to the
paper of his own Tenets in
his bosom: when he had taken
this Oath, he went in tri&shy;
umph through the streets of
the City, till a necessity of
nature enforcing him, he
withdrew aside to a house of
ease, where he voided out his
guts, and sent his soul as a
harbenger to the Devil, to pro&shy;
vide room for his body. Heyl. 

This Heresie began about
the yeer of Christ 315. in
the time of Pope Silvester and
Constantine the great Emperor;
and notwithstanding, Arius
and his deceived complices,
were Excommunicated by
their own Bishop Alexander, up&shy;
on the first broaching of their
Tenets, and that the heresie
was condemned by the afore&shy;
said Council of Nice, and
thirdly, notwithstanding the
aforesaid suddain and infa&shy;
mous death of the Author,
the heresie dyed not with 
him, but did afterwards much
spread it self (by the help of
Constantine the Emperor)
through all Christen&shy;
dom, but more in the
East, then in the western
Church of God, nor is it to
this day quite extinct, divers
still adhering to it, especially
in Transilvania and the border&shy;
ing Countries.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="d8v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arride(v)">Arride<etym lang="la"> (arrideo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to smile or
look pleasantly upon, to shew
a liking and consent by ge&shy;
sture, to applaud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrision(n)">Arrision<etym lang="la"> (arrisio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a smi&shy;
ling upon, an applause.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrogate(v)">Arrogate<etym lang="la"> (arrogo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to attri&shy;
bute much to ones self, to
boast, to claim more then is
due, to presume.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrogancy(n)">Arrogancy<etym lang="la"> (arrogantia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
pride, presumption, haughti&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsenal(n)">Arsenal (Fr. <etym lang="la">Arcenal</etym>, Ital. <etym lang="it">
Arsenale)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">an Armory or store&shy;
house of Armor, Artillery or
ships. 

The Venetians (saith Heylin)
have an Arsenal, in which are
kept 200 Galleys, nigh to
which are houses stored with
Masts, Sayls, and other tack&shy;
lings: so that they can speedi&shy;
ly set out a great Navy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsenic(n)">Arsenick<etym lang="la"> (arsenicum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of gold colour called Orpine
or orpiment, others call it O&shy;
ker: the natural one is of two
sorts, the one red, the o&shy;
ther yellow. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsy-versy(n)">Arseverse<etym lang="la"> (<expan type="">id est</expan> averte ignem)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a pretended spell written up&shy;
on the door of an house, to
keep it from burning: 'tis
a Tuscan word, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <term lang="la">Arsurum
averte</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsy-versy(n)">Arseversie. </form> <xpln lang="en">Preposterous&shy;
ly, perversly, the cart before
the horse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Artemisean month(n)">Artemisean Month.</form> <xpln lang="en">The
month of May.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="artery(n)">Artery<etym lang="la"> (arteria)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a sinew
like to a vein, a hollow vessel,
in which the spirits of life 
mixed with blood do pass
through the body. All these
kind of veins proceed from
the heart, where the vital spi&shy;
rits are made, and are those
which pant or beat, called
commonly the pulses. Bull. 


<subform> Aorta (Gr.) </subform><subxpln> the great Arte&shy;
ry, the root whereof is fastned
to the little grisly bone, which
is in the heart; this is called
the mother of all other Arte&shy;
ries. </subxpln>

<subform> Axillar Artery<etym lang="la"> (arteria axil&shy;
laris)</etym> </subform><subxpln> the Arm-hole Artery,
or a left branch of the Aorta,
from which it <emend err="ascends" source="errata">descends</emend> ob&shy;
liquely towards the Armhole,
where after it hath sent its
branches to the higher ribs
and other adjacent parts, it
down to the bought of the
Cubit. </subxpln>

<subform> Carotick Artery<etym lang="la"> (arteria caro&shy;
tica)</etym> </subform><subxpln> issues from the Axillar,
and is divided into two bran&shy;
ches; the inward and great<emend err=".">&shy;</emend>
er, which goes unto the brain;
the outward which passes un&shy;
to the Larinx, tongue, nose,
eys and Muscles of the Tem&shy;
ples. </subxpln>

<subform> Cervical Artery<etym lang="la"> (arteria cer&shy;
vicalis)</etym> </subform><subxpln> an Artery in the Nape
or hinder part of the Neck,
issues from the Sous-claviere,
and goes thence from the
Neck-bone to the brain. </subxpln>

<subform> C&oelig;liaque Artery<etym lang="la"> (arteria coe&shy;
liaca)</etym> </subform><subxpln> is a main branch of the
great Artery, from which it
descends to the Midriff and in&shy;
trails. </subxpln>

<subform> Coronal Arteries, </subform><subxpln> are two 


</page>

<page sig="e1r">
little branches of the great
Artery, and led by it unto
the left ventricle and broad
end of the heart. </subxpln>

<subform> Crotaphique Artery<etym lang="la"> (arteria
crotaphica)</etym> </subform><subxpln> is a great sinew
neere to the Temples. </subxpln>
 
<subform> Crural Artery, </subform><subxpln>is the Artery
of the Thigh, among whose
Muscles it divides it self. </subxpln>

<subform> Cubical Artery </subform><subxpln> is a branch of
the Axillar . </subxpln>

<subform> Cystepatique Artery </subform><subxpln> is a
branch of the C&oelig;liaque, and
goes to the Liver and Gall. </subxpln>

<subform> Diaphragmatique Artery, </subform><subxpln><emend err="is">is&shy;</emend>
sues from the trunk of the
great Artery, and thence goes
to the Diaphragma . </subxpln>

<subform> Epigastrick Artery </subform><subxpln> is a branch
of the Iliack Artery ; distributes
it self among the Muscles of
the Epigastrum . </subxpln>

<subform> Gastrepiploique Artery </subform><subxpln>, is a
<emend err="brandch">branch</emend> of the c&oelig;liaque,
whence it goes to the Ven&shy;
tricle and Epiploon . </subxpln>

<subform> Geminous Arteries; </subform><subxpln> the
twin Arteries, two small ones
which descend to the joynt of
the knee, between the pro&shy;
cesses of the Thigh-bones. </subxpln>

<subform> Grand Artery. </subform><subxpln> As Aorta . </subxpln>

<subform> Hypogastrick Artery, </subform><subxpln> is a
branch of the Iliack, and di&shy;
stributes it self among the
parts of the Hypogastrium . </subxpln>

<subform> Iliack Artery, </subform><subxpln> is the descen&shy;
dent branch of the great one. </subxpln>

<subform> Intercostal Arteries, </subform><subxpln> are two;
an upper, which bestows it
self among the Muscles that
are between the four highest
ribs, and an under one, which
goes to every Muscle, that 
is between the rest of the ribs. </subxpln>

<subform> Lumbarie Arteries; </subform> <subxpln>the Loyn
arteries, issue from the Aorta
unto all the parts of the 
loyns, giving life to the mar&shy;
row of back-bone, and send&shy;
ing as many branches to its
joynts, as there be holes in it.</subxpln>

<subform> Mamillar Artery, </subform><subxpln> the Pap
Artery, issues from the trunk
of the Aorta : </subxpln>

<subform> Mesenterique Arteries, </subform><subxpln> are
two, an upper, which distri&shy;
butes it self among the small
guts, and an under one, which
goes to the lower part of the
Mesentery . </subxpln>

<subform> Plantar Arteries, </subform><subxpln> are two
branches of the Thigh Arte&shy;
rie (which they divide in the
middle of the Leg) an in&shy;
ward one, which descends to
the joynt or setting on of the
foot, and passing along the
sole, ends in five branches,
whereof two serve for the
great Toe, two for the second
Toe, and one for the middle
Toe; the outward (as the
inner) ends also in five
branches, two whereof it be&shy;
stows on the little Toe, two
on the next unto it, and one
on the middle one. </subxpln>

<subform> Privy Artery, </subform><subxpln> issues from the
great Arteries descendent
branch, and bestows it self
among the privities. </subxpln>

<subform> Radial Artery. </subform><subxpln>A second
branch of the arm-hole Arte&shy;
ry, whence it bestows it self
on the Radius or the upper
and greater bone of the Arm. </subxpln>

<subform> Renal Artery, </subform><subxpln>the Kidney&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="e1v">
Artery, issues out of the
Aorta, and enters into the
Kidney, bringing to it the fe&shy;
rosity of th'arterial blood. </subxpln>

<subform> Sacred Artery, </subform><subxpln> a branch of
the great Arteries descendent
branch, goes to the Marrow
which is in the Os Sacrum . </subxpln>

<subform> Sous claviere Artery, </subform><subxpln> the
ascendent branch of the great
Artery. </subxpln>

<subform> Spermatique Artery, </subform><subxpln> goes
from the body of the Aorta 
to the Testicles, and there
joyns with the vein that go&shy;
verns those parts. </subxpln>

<subform> Splenitique Artery, </subform><subxpln> is the
greatest branch of the C&oelig;liaque 
whence it goes to the Spleen,
and therein ends. </subxpln>

<subform> Thorachique Artery, </subform><subxpln> the
Breast-Artery, issues out of
the great Arteries ascendent
branch, and goes to the ante&shy;
rior Muscles of the Breast. </subxpln>

<subform> Venous or Veiny Artery, </subform><subxpln> is
one of the three principal
ones of the body, issues from
the left Ventricle of the heart
and carries blood from
thence to the Lungs for their
nourishment. </subxpln>

<subform> Trachean or Trachian Artery, </subform><subxpln>
called also the pipe of the
Lungs, is one of the three
principal Arteries in the bo&shy;
dy, and th'instrument of
breath and voice, it begins at
the Larinx, and ends at the
Lungs or Lights. </subxpln>

<subform> Arterial<etym lang="la"> (arterialis)</etym> </subform><subxpln> of
or belonging to the Arte&shy;
ries. </subxpln>
</xpln>
</wordentry>

full of Arteries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arthur(pn)">Arthur.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Latine name
in Juvenal drawn from the
goodly fixed Star Arcturus,
and that from Arctus, is the
Bear, as Ursicinus among the
Romans. The famous Ar&shy;
thur made this name first <emend err="fa">fa&shy;</emend>
mous among the Britains.
Cam. But why may not Ar&shy;
thure be rather a Brittish
word composed of Arth,
which signifies a Bear, and
gwr, which signifies a man
<term lang="la">Vir</term>? So Arthur, <term lang="la">quasi</term> a man
that for his strength and terror
may be called a Bear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="articular(a)">Articular<etym lang="la"> (articularis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the joynts.</xpln></wordentry>

point.</xpln></wordentry>

ning Artificer, a master of his

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arvisian wine(n)">Arvisian Wine. (so called

mountain in the Island Sio, for&shy;
merly called Chios, where it is
made) one of the best sorts of
Greek wine, thus praised by
Virg. Eclo.3. 


</page>

<page sig="e2r">
<term lang="la"> Ex multo in primis hilarans
convivia Baccho
Ante focum, si frigus erit; si
messis, in umbra:
Vina novum, effundam calathis
 Arvisia Nectar.</term> 

Pleasant with plenteous Bac&shy;
chus, when we feast,
By th'fire, if cold: in shades,
if heat molest:
I Bolls will with Arvisian
Nectar fill.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arval brothers(pn)"> TheArval Brothers or Fraternity (<etym lang="la">fratres arvales</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
were among the old Ro&shy;
mans, a sort of Priests, in
number twelve, who (be&shy;
sides the performance of
publique Sacrifices) were
appointed Arbitrators or
Judges to decide contro&shy;
versies concerning Land&shy;
marks, and bounds of the
field, whence they took
their Name. Godwin.</xpln></wordentry>

Divination, when men
(by opening and view&shy;
ing the Bowels of Beasts)
undertook to foretel things
to come, and such men
were called Aruspices <term lang="la">ab aras
inspiciendo</term>.</xpln></wordentry>
