<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ascendant(n)" lexeme="horoscope(n)">Ascendant (<etym lang="la">ascendens</etym>)
or Horoscope</form> <xpln lang="en">is the point
of the Ecliptick, arising
at some determinate mo&shy;
ment of the natural day;
in which the infant is con&shy;
ceived or born; so called
from two Greek Nouns
<term lang="gk">&#x1F65;&rho;&alpha;</term> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la"> Hora</term>, and <term lang="gk">&#x03C3;&kappa;&#x03CC;&pi;&omicron;&#x03C2;</term>, 
<term lang="la">scopus</term>, which is the scope
to be aymed at; for the
condition of the whole
life is believed to depend
on that moment; and
therefore that moment and
point of the Ecliptick, is
to be proposed and esta&shy;
blished as the principal
scope level'd at in <emend err="Astrolo&shy;">Astro&shy;</emend>
logical consideration. Ric&shy;
ciolus in his Almagesto No&shy;
vo.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ascentive(a)">Ascentive (from <etym lang="la">Ascen&shy;
do)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that ascends or climbs
up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ascetic(a)">Ascetike (from the Greek
<etym lang="gk">Ascetes</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Monachus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to a Monastery or
place, where people give
themselves to Meditation or
Prayer. Sir Kenelm Digby
in his Treatise of Bodies,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asclepiad(n)">Asclepiad<etym lang="la"> (asclepias, a&shy;
dis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of Verse con&shy;
sisting of a Spondee, a
Choriambique, and two Da&shy;
ctyles. 


</page>

<page sig="e2v">
<term lang="la"> Sublimi feriam sidera vertice</term>, 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Asia(pn)">Asia.</form> <xpln lang="en">One of the four
parts of the world bound&shy;
ing towards the East, so cal&shy;
led from Asia, daughter to
Oceanus and Thetis, wife to Ia&shy;
petus and mother to <emend err="Promethe"> Promethe&shy;</emend>
us; It stretches in length
about five thousand and two
hundred miles, and in
breadth four thousand five
hundred and sixty, wherein
are contained the several Re&shy;
gions of, 1 Anatolia, 2 Syria,
3 Palestina, 4 Armenia, 5 Ara&shy;
bia, 6 Media, 7 Assyria, 8 <emend err="Me"> Me&shy;</emend>
sopotamia, 9 Persia. 10 Chald&aelig;a,
11 Parthia, 12 Hircania, 13
Tartaria, 14 China, 15 India,
16 the Islands. This part of
the world hath worn the Gar&shy;
land of supereminency.
1 Because here man was
created, and put to Till the
Land.
2 Here our Saviour Christ
was born, wrought his Divine
Miracles, and suffered for our
salvation on the Cross.
3 Here were done the actions
memorized by the Holy Pen&shy;
men of the Old and New&shy;
Testament.
4 Here were the first
Monarchies of the Babylo&shy;
nians, Assyrians, Persians
and Medes.
5 This is the common
mother of us all, from
whence, as from the Tro&shy;
jan horse, innumerable 
Troops of men issued to
people the other parts
of the uninhabited world.
Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Asiatic(a)">Asiatick<etym lang="la"> (Asiaticus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to Asia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asinine(a)">Asinyne<etym lang="la">asininus ()</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to an
Ass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asmatographer(n)"><emend err="Asmotagraphers" source="errata">Asmatographers</emend><etym lang="la"> (<emend err="as">as&shy;</emend>
matographi)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">they who
tell or make Songs, or
Lessons for any Instru&shy;
ments.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Asmodeus(pn)">Asmodeus<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Greek)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">the
<emend err="friend" source="errata">Fiend</emend> of Lechery, or
spirit of Carnality; also
the name of the Devil,
that killed the seven Hus&shy;
bands of Sara the daughter
of Raguel, mentioned in
the third Chapter of Toby
Holy Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asotus(a)">Asotus.</form> <xpln lang="en">Intemperate, in&shy;
continent, prodigal. Hence
perhaps 'tis we call a drunk&shy;
ard a Sot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aspect(n)">Aspect<etym lang="la"> (aspectus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="behold"> behold&shy;</emend>
ing or viewing, sight, pre&shy;
sence or beauty. 

In Astronomy it signifies
the distance between the Pla&shy;
nets and heavenly signes:
and there are four such A&shy;
spects. The first, called a
Trine Aspect (because it di&shy;
vides the Heavens into three
even parts) is the distance
of four signs from each o&shy;
ther; As Aries beholds
Leo and Sagittarius with a
Trine Aspect, because these
are distant four signs, the 


</page>

<page sig="e3r">
one before, the other after
Aries . The second called a
Quartile, is the distance of
three signes, as Aries beholds
Cancer and Capricorn with a
Quartile Aspect, because they
are distant three signes from
him. The third called a
<emend err="Septile" source="errata">Sextile</emend> Aspect, is the distance
of two signes, As Aries be&shy;
holds Gemini and Aquarius 
with this Sextile aspect, being
but two signes distant from
them. The fourth, called
an Opposite aspect <emend err="in" source="errata">is</emend> the far&shy;
thest distance that can be,
namely a distance of sixe
signes asunder. As Aries 
beholds Libra, with this Op&shy;
posite aspect, and Libra be&shy;
holds Aries with the same.
The like is of all the other
Signes or Planets placed
in them. For example,
Taurus beholds Cancer and
Pisces, with a Sextile, Leo 
and Aquarius with a Quartile,
Virgo and Capricorn with
a Trine, and Scorpio with
an opposite Aspect. The
distance of one or five
Signes is not called an Aspect.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asper(n)">Asper.</form> <xpln lang="en">A sort of For&shy;
raign Coyn, and it is of
our mony one peny and a
quarter. Others say that
ten Aspers make but six pence
of our mony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asperate(v)">Asperate<etym lang="la"> (aspero)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to make
sharp, rough, eager, or
angry, to make more grie&shy;
vous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asperity(n)">Asperity<etym lang="la"> (asperitas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
sharpness, harshness, un&shy;
pleasantness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aspernate(v)">Aspernate<etym lang="la"> (asperno)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
contemn, reject, set light by,
or abhor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aspersion(n)">Aspersion<etym lang="la"> (aspersio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
besprinkling, wetting or
bedewing, and by meta&shy;
phor, infamy or slan&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Asphaltic(a)">Asphaltick.</form> <xpln lang="en">Of or be&shy;
longing to the dead Sea
or Lake called <emend err="Asphal"> Asphal&shy;</emend>
tites, nigh which once
stood the infamous Ci&shy;
ties of Sodom and Go&shy;
morrha. This Lake hath
such a bituminous or
sulphury strong smell,
that no living thing
can endure it. Rel.
Med.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aspirate(v)" lexeme="aspiration(n)"> An Aspirate orAspiration 
(<etym lang="la">aspiratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
breathing, aspiring or
influence. Also the pro&shy;
nouncing a syllable with
some more force of breath
then ordinary, as we
do those that have the
Letter H, as Have, her,
Homo, Hamus, &amp;c. con&shy;
trary to which <emend err="prou" source="errata">pronoun&shy;</emend>
ciation is that which
hath nothing of the
sound of H, as Are,
ear, amo, onus, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asportation(n)">Asportation<etym lang="la"> (asportatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a carrying or convey&shy;
ing away, a transpor&shy;
ting.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="e3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assart(v)">Assart (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Essarter)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
glade or make glades in a
wood; also to grub up or
cleer a ground of bushes,
shrubs, &amp;c. or to lop off the
boughs of a Tree. Assert is
taken for an offence commit&shy;
ted in the Forest, by plucking
up those woods by the roots,
that are Thickets or coverts
of the Forest, and by making
them plain, as arable Land.
Manwoods For. Law. But if
a man sue out a Licence to
assart his grounds in the Fo&shy;
rest and to make it several
for Tillage, then it is no of&shy;
fence. Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assassin(n)">Assassine (Ital. <etym lang="it">Assassino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Thief, cut-throat or Mur&shy;
derer, one that kills another
for gain or upon Hope or
Promise of reward; such a
one was he, who murdered
the Count of Tripolis in the
wars for the Holy Land; and
such a one was he who so de&shy;
sperately wounded our Ed. I.
at the Siege of Ptolemais or
Acon. Heyl. And such a one
was Felton that murdered the
Duke of Buck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assassinate(v)">Assassinate (from the Ital.
<etym lang="it"><emend err="Assassinate" source="errata">Assassinare</emend></etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to murther and
rob together.</xpln></wordentry>

ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assets(n)">Assets (from the French
<etym lang="fr">Assez</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">satis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our
Common Law, goods e&shy;
nough to discharge that bur&shy;
den, which is cast upon the
Executor or Heir, in satisfy&shy;
ing the Testators or Ancestors
Debts or Legacies. See 
Brook <term lang="la">titulo, Assets per dis&shy;
cent</term>: By whom you shall
learn, that whosoever pleads
Assets, saith nothing, but
that he against whom he
pleads, hath enough de&shy;
scended or come to his hands,
to discharge that which is in
demand. The Author of the
new terms of Law makes two 
sorts of Assets. Viz. Assets
par discent, and enter mains, the
former being to be alledged
against an heir, the other a&shy;
gainst an Executor or Admi&shy;
nistrator. Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asseveration(n)">Asseveration<etym lang="la"> (asseveratio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
an earnest affirming or a&shy;
vouching.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assiduity(n)">Assiduity<etym lang="la"> (assiduitas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">dili&shy;
gence without ceasing, conti&shy;
nual attendance, unintermit&shy;
ted sollicitation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assiduous(a)">Assiduous<etym lang="la"> (assiduus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">dayly,
continuall, diligent, appro&shy;
ved, always at hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assignation(n)" lexeme="assignment(n)">Assignation 
Assignment  <etym lang="la"> (assignatio)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">an appoint&shy;
ment or distribution, the pas&shy;
sing a thing over to another.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="e4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assignee(n)">Assignee<etym lang="la"> (assignatus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is he
that is appointed or deputed
by another to do any act, or
perform any business, or en&shy;
joy any commodity. And an
Assignee may be either in deed,
or in Law. Assignee in Deed,
is he that is appointed by a
person: an Assignee in Law, is
he whom the Law so makes,
without any appointment
of the person. Dyer fol.6.
num. 5. Perkins Tit. Grants
saith, that an Assignee is
he that useth or enjoys a
thing in his own right, and
Deput&egrave; he that doth it in the
right of another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assimilate(v)">Assimilate<etym lang="la"> (assimilo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
liken, resemble or com&shy;
pare.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assimulate(v)">Assimulate<etym lang="la"> (assimulo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
feign a thing, to counterfeit,
to represent, to set a good
face on the matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assize(n)">Assize (from the Norman
word <etym lang="no">Assise</etym>, and that derived
from the French <etym lang="fr">Asseoire</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan>
<term lang="la">collocare</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a word diversly
used in our Common Law.
Littleton, in the Chapter of
Rents, saith, it is &aelig;quivo&shy;
cal, and sets down three
significations of it; one
as it is taken for a Writ ;
another as it is used for a
Jury ; the third as for an
Ordinance . 

But in Cowel you may
read more significations. I
shall onely give you this ad&shy;
dition out of Sir Francis Ba&shy;
cons Use of the Law, concern&shy;
ing the General Assizes . All 
the Counties of this Realm
(saith he) are divided into
sixe Circuits, and two lear&shy;
ned men are assigned by
the Kings Commission to
every Circuit, and to ride
twice a yeer through those
Shires allotted to that Cir&shy;
cuit, these we call Justices
or Judges of Assize, who
have five several Commissi&shy;
ons by which they sit. The
first is a Commission of Oyer
 and  Terminer, directed to
them and many others of the
best account in their Cir&shy;
cuits, but in this Commissi&shy;
on the Judges of Assize are
of the Quorum, so as with&shy;
out them there can be no
proceeding. This Com&shy;
mission gives them power to
deal with Treasons, Murthers
and all manner of Felonies
and Misdemeanors whatsoe&shy;
ver, and this is the largest
Commission they have. The second is a Commission of
Gaole delivery . That is one&shy;
ly to the Judges themselves,
and the Clerk of the Assize
associate: and by this Com&shy;
mission they are to deal with
every prisoner in the Goale,
for what offence soever he be
there. The third Commissi&shy;
on is directed to themselves
onely, and the Clerk of
Assize to take Assizes, by
which they are called Iustices
of Assize, and the office of
these Justices is to do right
upon Writs called Assizes,
brought before them by such 


</page>

<page sig="e4v">
as are wrongfully thrust out
of their Lands. The fourth
Commission, is to take Nisi
Prius directed to none but to
the Judges themselves &amp; their
Clerks of Assizes, by which
they are called Justices of Nisi
prius . The fifth is a Commissi&shy;
on of Peace in every County
of their Circuit. And all the
Justices of the Peace having
no lawful impediment, are
bound to be present at the As&shy;
sizes to attend the Judges as
occasion shall fall out: if any
make default, the Judges may
set a Fine upon him at their
pleasure and discretions: the
Sheriff of every Shire is also
to attend in person, or by a
sufficient Deputy allowed by
the judges, who may Fine
him if he fail, &amp;c. See more
of this in Sir Francis Bacons 
Use of the Law, fol.13.<term lang="la">vsque
ad</term> 21.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="associate(v)">Associate<etym lang="la"> (associo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to ac&shy;
company, to joyn in Office,
to make fit; to make ones
self companion with ano&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assonate(v)">Assonate<etym lang="la"> (assono)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
sound together, to answer by
sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assuefaction(n)">Assuefaction<etym lang="la"> (assuefactio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">

use, enurement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assuete(a)">Assuete<etym lang="la"> (assuetus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">accustom&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assuetude(n)">Assuetude<etym lang="la"> (assuetudo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">cu&shy;
stom, use, continuance, u&shy;
sage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assumpsit(n)">Assumpsit (the third 
person of the Preterfect
Tense of the Verb <etym lang="la">assumo</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> to take to or upon ones
self)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a voluntary promise
made by Word, whereby
a man assumes or takes
upon him to perform or
pay any thing to another.
This Word contains any
Verbal Promise made upon
consideration, which the
Civilians express by divers
words, according to the
nature of the Promise,
calling it sometime pa&shy;
ctum, sometime sponsio&shy;
nem, sometime promissio&shy; 
nem, pollicitationem or Con&shy;
stitutum . Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assumption(n)">Assumption<etym lang="la"> (assumptio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a taking to, or upon, a
lifting up, an attributing:
Also the Minor Propo&shy;
sicion in a Syllogism . As

Whatsoever is due by the
Law of Nature, can&shy;
not be altered,
But Alleageance and O&shy;
bedience of the Sub&shy;
ject to the Supreme
power, is due by
the Law of Nature:
<term lang="la">Ergo</term>, it cannot be alter&shy;
ed. 

The first part of this
Syllogism is called the Ma&shy;
jor, the second part be&shy;
ginning with But is the
Assumption or Minor, and
Ergo makes the Conclu&shy;
sion.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="e5r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assumptive(a)">Assumptive<etym lang="la"> (assumptivus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that takes to himself or pro&shy;
mises, or that is lifted
up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astragal(n)">Astragal<etym lang="la"> (astragalus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a term
of Architecture, and is (ac&shy;
cording to Vitruvius, an an&shy;
cient and famous author
thereof) a ring or writhen&shy;
circle to deck or adorn the
neck of a column, &amp; is there&shy;
fore transferrd to the canon,
agreeing somewhat in shape
with the Column or Pillar.
Enchiridion of Fortication.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astragalize(v)">Astragalize<etym lang="la"> (astragalizo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
make or use Astragals : also to
play at Dice, Huckle-bones or
Tables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astriction(n)">Astriction<etym lang="la"> (astrictio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astriferous(a)">Astriferous<etym lang="la"> (astrifer)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that

most proper for the Heavens
or sky.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astringe(v)"> To Astringe<etym lang="la"> (astringo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astrolabe(n)">Astrolabe<etym lang="la"> (astrolabium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
flat-round instrument, where&shy;
by Astronomers gather the
motion, and distance of hea&shy;
venly bodies, and whereby
the length, height, and
breadth of any other thing
may be discerned and found
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astrology(n)">Astrology<etym lang="la"> (astrologia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is a
Science which tels the Reasons
of the Stars and Planets moti&shy;
ons. Astrology (sayes Doctor
Bullokar) doth promise by the
motion and influence of Stars
and Planets to foretel things
to come, or (as my Lo. Bac.
sayes) it professeth to disco&shy;
ver the influence and domi&shy;
nation of the superior Globe
over the inferior, and there&shy;
fore may be tearmed a kind of
natural divination, so long as
it keeps it self in due limits,
and arrogates not too much
to its certainty; into which
excess if it once break forth,
it can then be no longer cal&shy;
led natural Divination, but
superstitious and wicked; for
the Stars may incline, but
not impose a necessity in 


</page>

<page sig="e5v">
particular things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astrological(a)">Astrological</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
Astrology.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astrologer(n)">Astrologer<etym lang="la"> (astrologus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">he
that is well skilled in Astro&shy;
logy, or discourseth of the
variety of constellations, pla&shy;
netical aspects, disposing of
the houses; and by these and
their dispositions conjectures
of future occurrences.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astronomy(n)">Astronomy<etym lang="la"> (astronomia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
Science that teacheth the
knowledge of the course of
the Planets, Stars and other
celestial motions. This art
seems to be very ancient, for
Josephus lib. I. Antiq. writes
that the Sons of Seth, Grand&shy;
children to Adam, first found
it out; who hearing Adam
foretel the universal Flood,
which should shortly drown
the world, they thereupon
erected two great Pillars, en&shy;
graving in them the Princi&shy;
ples of Astronomy, the one
of which pillars was of brick,
the other of stone, that in case
the water should wash away
the brick, yet the stone might
preserve the knowledge here&shy;
of for posterity. Bull. These
Pillars were called Enoch, or
 Enos Pillars . Zoroastes the
first King of Bactria (who
raigned in the time of the As&shy;
syrian Monarch Ninus) is said
to have notably augmented
or perfected this Science.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astronomical(a)">Astronomical,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging
to Astronomy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astronomer(n)">Astronomer<etym lang="la"> (astronomus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is
he who (as Heyl. describes 
him) searcheth the reason of
the variety of heavenly moti&shy;
ons, the diversity of circles,
asterisms, risings and settings
<emend err="fo">of</emend> Stars and the like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astute(a)">Astute<etym lang="la"> (astutus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">crafty,
cunning, subtile, malici&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asyle(n)">Asyle<etym lang="la"> (Asylum)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a Sanctua&shy;
ry, a defence or place of re&shy;
fuge for offenders. Mont, See<xref>
Sanctuary</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asymbolic(a)">Asymbolike<etym lang="la"> (asymbolus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
that payes nothing of the
shot or reckoning, scot-free.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asymphony(n)">Asymphony<etym lang="la"> (asymphonia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a discord in discant, a disa&shy;
greeing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="achievement(n)">Achievment (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Acheve&shy;
ment)</etym> </form> <xpln lang="en">the performance or ac&shy;
complishment of any gallant
exploit, a bringing to per&shy;
fection; also a term of He&shy;

of any Gentleman, set out
fully, with all that belongs
to it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atheism(n)">Atheism <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">the dam&shy;
nable doctrine and opinion of
the Atheists, infidelity, the
denying of, or not beleeving
in God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atheist(n)">Atheist ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x1f04;&delta;&epsilon;&shy;
&omicron;&#x03c2;.</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la"> Sine Deo</term>, godless)</form> <xpln lang="en">he

that the soul dies with the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atom(n)">Atome<etym lang="la"> (atomus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a mote

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atrate(a)">Atrate<etym lang="la"> (atratus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">made black,
or cloathed in black.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atrocity(n)">Atrocity<etym lang="la"> (atrocitas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">cruelty,
fierceness, <emend err="outragi usness">outragiousness</emend>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atrophy(n)">Atrophy<etym lang="la"> (atrophia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a con&shy;
sumption that comes by a
fearful eating too little, or
greedy devouring too much.
Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attacted(a)">Attacted<etym lang="la"> (attactus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">touched,
or breifly handled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attainder(n)">Attainder, from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Attaindre</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> to attain unto, o&shy;
vertake, catch, or touch. from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Attingere</etym>, because
he that is attainted</form> <xpln lang="en">is, as it 
were, catched, overtaken
and plainly deprehended: for
Attainder is a conviction of
any person of a crime or fault,
whereof he was not convict
before: As if a man have
committed Felony or Trea&shy;
son, &amp;c. and is thereof in&shy;
dicted, arraigned, found
guilty, and hath judgement,
then he is said to have an
Attainder sued upon him, or
he is attainted . See more of this
in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attack(n)">Attaque <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">an assault, en&shy;
counter, skirmish, fight: a
violent meeting of two Ar&shy; 
mies or Enemies. Sir H. B.
in his voyage into the Le&shy;
vant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attemperate(v)">Attemperate<etym lang="la"> (attempero)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
to make fit or meet, to aim
right.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attenuate(v)">Attenuate<etym lang="la"> (attenuo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to make
thin or slender, to diminish or
make less.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attentate(v)">Attentate<etym lang="la"> (attento)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to at&shy;
tempt, assay or prove, also u&shy;
sed substantively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attestation(n)">Attestation<etym lang="la"> (attestatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
witnessing, affirming, or testi&shy;
mony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attic(a)">Attick<etym lang="la"> (atticus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">of Athens,
learned, eloquent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Atticism(n)">Atticisme<etym lang="la"> (atticismus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
phrase or manner of speech
of the Athenians : an elegancy
of speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attinge(v)">Attinge<etym lang="la"> (Attingo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to touch
lightly or softly; to menti&shy;
on or handle briefly, to reach
to, to arrive or come to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Attic(a)"><emend err="Atitque">Attique</emend><etym lang="la"> (atticus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to the Country of Athens,
Elegant. Attick Faith, is most
firm Faithfulness in keeping
promise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attired(a)">Attired (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">Ti&shy;
ara</etym>, which is an ornament for
the heads of the Persian Kings,
Priests, and women)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
used among Heraulds, when
they have occasion to speak
of the horns of a Buck or
Stag. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attornment(n)">Attournment (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">
tourn&eacute;r</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> to turn)</form> <xpln lang="en">is in our
common-Law a yeelding of
the Tenant to a new Lord,
or an acknowledgement of
him to be his Lord (which 


</page>

<page sig="e6v">
we usually call to turn Ten&shy;
nant) for otherwise he that
buyes or obtains any Lands or
Tenements of another which
are in the occupation of a
third, cannot get possession;
yet see the Stat.27. H.8. ca.16.
The words used in attournment
are set down in Littleton I a&shy;
gree me to the Grant made to you,
&amp;c. but the more common
attournment is to say, Sir, I at&shy;
town to you by force of the same
Grant: or I become your Ten&shy;
nant, &amp;c. or else deliver unto
the Grantee a penny, half&shy;
penny or farthing by way
of attournment. Litt. l.3. Ca.
attournment 10. whom you may
read more an large. 

Attournment may be made
to the Lord himself or to
his Steward in Court. Kitch.
fo.70.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attraction(n)">Attraction<etym lang="la"> (attractio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
drawing or pulling unto, a
bait or allurement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attrait(n)">Attrait (from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Attraict</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the same. Cres&shy;
sy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attrectation(n)">Attrectation<etym lang="la"> (attractatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a <emend err="scoff" source="errata">soft</emend> and often handling,
or touching, a feeling or med&shy;
ling with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attribute(n)" lexeme="attribution(n)">Attribute 
Attribution <etym lang="la"> (attributio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
an assign&shy;
ment, delivery or giving un&shy;
to: also a fit term or title ap&shy;
plyed to any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attrition(n)">Attrition<etym lang="la"> (attritio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a rub&shy;
bing, wearing, washing or
striking against: In divi&shy;
nity, it is metaphorically
used for that sorrow which a 
sinner hath for his sins, not
being founded principally
on the love of God above all
things, but in the fear of
the pains of Hell, or in the
consideration of the fowle&shy;
ness of sin, or in some other
the like thing. It is also
called imperfect Contrition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attrite(a)">Attrite<etym lang="la"> (attritus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">worn,
wasted, or fretted: or that
hath that kind of sorrow a&shy;
bove mentioned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avarice(n)">Avarice<etym lang="la"> (avaritia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">covetous&shy;
ness or greediness, inordinate
desire of money, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auctifical(a)">Auctifical<etym lang="la"> (auctificus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that
makes an increase or augmen&shy;
tation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auctor(n)">Auctor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that in&shy;
creaseth or augments, an au&shy;
thor or first inventor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aucupation(n)">Aucupation<etym lang="la"> (aucupatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">bir&shy;
ding or fowling: also gain, ad&shy;
vantage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="audacity(n)">Audacity<etym lang="la"> (audacitas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">rash&shy;
ness, boldness, fool-hardiness,
sauciness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="audible(a)">Audible<etym lang="la"> (audibilis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be heard, understood or
perceived.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="audience(n)">Audience<etym lang="la"> (audientia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the
sence of hearing, listning;
sometime it signifies an assem&shy;
bly of people hearkening to
something spoken: and when
an Embassador delivers his
Embassy to the King; wee
call it, Giving him audi&shy;
ence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auditor(n)">Auditor <class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">one that
hearkens; But in the com&shy;
mon acceptation it is an Of&shy;
ficer to some great personage 


</page>

<page sig="e7r">
who does yearly (by exa&shy;
mining the accounts of all
under-officers accountable)
make up a general book, that
shewes the difference between
their receipts and their al&shy;
lowances commonly called
( allocations) as namely, the
Auditors of the Exchequer
take the Accounts of those
Receivers, which receive the
revenues of the Augmentati&shy;
on, as also of the Sheriffs,
Escheators, Collectors, and
Customers, and set them
down and perfect them. See
Stat.33.8 H. ca.33.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avenage(n)">Avenage <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
quantity of Oates paid to a
Landlord in lieu of some o&shy;
ther duties. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avenue(n)">Avenue (Fr. <etym lang="fr">advenue)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is
the space that is left for pas&shy;
sage to and fro, in and out,
a Camp, Garison, or Quar&shy;
ter, when the place is either
fortified with a Line of Com&shy;
munication or Barricado's;
an access, passage, or entry in&shy;
to a place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="average(n)">Average<etym lang="la"> (averagium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">sig&shy;
nifies service which the Te&shy;
nant owes the Lord by
horse or carriage of horse.
It is also used for a cer&shy;
tain Contribution that
Merchants and others pro&shy;
portionably make towards
their losses, who have their
goods cast into the Sea,
for the safeguard of the
Ship or of the Goods and
Lives of those in the Ship
in time of tempest: And this 
contribution seems to be so
called, because it is pro&shy;
portioned after the rate of
every mans average or goods
carried. Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="averdupois(n)">Averdupois,</form> <xpln lang="en">See <xref lexeme="avoir-du-pois"><term lang="fr">Avoir
du pois</term></xref>, and see <xref> Weights</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avery(n)">Avery</form> <xpln lang="en">is the place where
Oates or Provender for
Horses is kept; From the
Saxon and Belgick Haver,
<expan type="">id est</expan> Oates, because Oates are
the common Provender for
horses. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aver(v)">Aver (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> ave&shy;
r&egrave;r)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to justifie, avouch or
maintain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="averment(n)">Averment, </form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Law, when a Defendant
offers to make good or ju&shy;
stifie an Exception plea&shy;
ded in abatement or Bar
of the Playntiffs act. New
termes of Law. But Cowel
rather thinks it should sig&shy;
nifie the act then the offer or
justifying the Exception,
whom <term lang="la">vide</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Avernian(a)" lexeme="Avernal(a)">Avernian 
Avernal <etym lang="la"> (avernalis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to the
lake Avernus, or to Hell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Avernus(pn)">Avernus, </form> <xpln lang="en">A Lake not
far from the City Cuma in
terra di lavoro, anciently
called Campania in Italy, the
stink whereof killed birds
as they flew over it: it was
dedicated to Pluto, and
is usually taken for Hell.
Of which, thus Virgil. &AElig;n.
l.6. 


</page>

<page sig="e7v">
<term lang="la">Quam super haud ull&aelig; poterant
impune volantes
Tendere itor pennis, talis sese ha&shy;
litus atris
Faucibus essundens supera ad
convexa ferebat:
Unde locum Graii dixerunt no&shy;
mine Avernum. </term>
Ore which no Foule unstruck
with hasty death,
Can stretch her strengthless
wings, so dire a breath
Mounts high heaven from
black jaws; the Greeks the same
Avernus call, expressed in the 
name. 



You may read more of
Avernus in Sands his Travels,
fol.280.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="averpenny(n)">Averpenny</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">quasi</term> average&shy;
penny) is money contributed
towards <emend err="th">the</emend> Kings Averages.
Rastal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="averruncation(n)">Averruncation<etym lang="la"> (averruncatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
a scraping or cutting off, as
men do Vines, a weeding or
taking away, an appeasing. Gr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aversion(n)">Aversion<etym lang="la"> (aversio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a tur&shy;
ning or driving away, a hating
or disliking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="augmentation(n)">Augmentation<etym lang="la"> (augmenta&shy;
tio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">increase. The Court of
Augmentation was erected 27.
Hen.8. as appears by the 27
Chapter of that years Parlia&shy;
ment. It was so called from
the increase of the Reve&shy;
nues of the Crown by the
suppression of Abbies and
Religious houses; And the
Court was ordained, that the
King might be justly dealt
with, touching the profits
of such religious houses. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="algorism(n)">Augrime<etym lang="la"> (algorithmus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
skil in accounting, or num&shy;
bring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="augury(n)">Augury<etym lang="la"> (augurium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a divi&shy;
nation, foretelling or Sooth&shy;
saying of things to come by
the chirping, flying, voyces
or fitting of Birds. The
Professors whereof (called
Augures) were of great ac&shy;
count among the heathen Ro&shy;
mans, insomuch that there
was a Colledge of them in the
City, neither would the Ro&shy;
mans undertake any publick
matter of importance with
out asking their assent; But
the vanity hereof was well
derided by a wife Jew, na&shy;
med Mossolamus, as Josephus
writes: For an Augur in the
Wars once requiring that the
Army which was then march&shy;
ing, might stand still a while,
till he took observation of a
Bird, thereby to fore-know
the success of that Expediti&shy;
on, this Jew (whilst the Au&shy;
ger was busie in his art) shot at
the bird with an arrow, and
by chance killed her, whereat
the Augur and others being
highly offended; Are you so
foolish (quoth the Jew) to
imagine this poor Bird can
tel what will happen to us,
that could not foresee her
own death so neer at hand?
They were called <term lang="la">Augures,
ab avium garritu</term>, from the
chirping and chattering of
birds. The &aelig;gyptians were
the first inventers of this Dia&shy;
bolical superstition.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="e8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="augurize(v)">Augurize<etym lang="la"> (auguro)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to di&shy;
vine, prophecy, foretel or
conjecture at things to come
by the aforesaid vain observa&shy;
tions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="augure's staff(n)">Augures-staff,</form> <xpln lang="en">was a croo&shy;
ked wand, which the Augures 
held in their hand, when they
made their divination, &amp;c.
The ceremonies whereof, and
the words of Augury, you
may read in the first part of
the Treasury of ancient and
modern times, p.184.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="august(a)">August<etym lang="la"> (augustus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">taken
adjectively signifies Royal,
Majestical, Imperial, Sacred;
It is a common name of the
Emperors among the Latins
(as Pharao was of the
Kings of &AElig;gypt) since Octa&shy;
vius Augustus his time, who
was the second Emperor of
the Romans, in the 41 or 42
year of his reign was born
our Saviour Jesus Christ. Au&shy;
gust also is the name of the
Sextile or sixth month from
March ; which took denomi&shy;
nation from the aforesaid Em&shy;
peror Augustus, because that
month he entred into his
Consulship, brought Tri&shy;
umphs into Rome, and con&shy;
quered &AElig;gypt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="augustal(n)">Augustals<etym lang="la"> (augustalia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
Playes in honor of August&shy;
us.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Augustan(n)">Augustan Confession<etym lang="la"> (Au&shy;
gustana Confessio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">the Prote&shy;
stant Confession of Faith, so
called from the City Augs&shy;
burgh in Germany, where at
a General Diet, appointed the 
eighth of April 1530. this
Confession was presented by
the Duke of Saxony and some
others to the Emperor Charls
the Fifth, &amp;c. Herb. H. 8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Augustine(pn)">Augustine, By the termi&shy;
nation of the word, is a dimi&shy;
nutive from <term lang="la">Augustus</term>, out of
which it may be properly
Englished little Augustus,</form> <xpln lang="en">It is
the proper name of divers
men, usually contracted in
English into Austin, whereof
the most renowned was St. 
Austin, Bishop of Hyppo in
Africk, one of the ancient Fa&shy;
thers of the Church, a man
of a most profound wit and
learning, and of a most holy
and religious life, after he was
converted by St. Ambrose to
Catholick Religion, from the
Manich&aelig;an Heresie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Augustine(pn)">Augustine,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Austin-Fry&shy;
ers or Monks, are those that
observe the aforesaid St. Au&shy;
stins institute of life; They
live in common, serving
God day and night, tyed by
the vows of poverty, chasti&shy;
ty and obedience; of which
holy Institute and Vows was
Dr. Martin Luther, before he be&shy;
came a Reformer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Augustinians(pn)">Augustinians</form> <xpln lang="en">(not taking
name from St. Austin, the Fa&shy;
ther and Doctor of the
Church, but from one Augustine
a late Bohemian) are a branch
of those Reformers, ordina&shy;
rily called in authors by the
name of Sacramentaries, who
had their origin from Andreas
Carolostadius about the year 


</page>

<page sig="e8v">
of Christ, 1524. These Au&shy;
gustinians (besides other blas&shy;
phemies) held, that Heaven
gates were not yet open, but
remained shut, till the ge&shy;
neral Resurrection, and last
Judgement. Lindanus Dia&shy;
log.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aviary(n)">Aviary<etym lang="la"> (avarium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a place
where birds are kept, or
where birds <emend err="hauntor">haunt or</emend> use; a
Cage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avid(a)">Avid<etym lang="la"> (avidus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">desirous,
greedy, covetous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avidity(n)">Avidity<etym lang="la"> (aviditas)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">desire,
earnest, or ardent affection,
greediness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alnage(n)">Aulnage <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">El mea&shy;
sure, the measuring with an El.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aviso(n)">Aviso <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">(Spa.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">an admonition
or advise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alneger(n)">Auinegeor 
or
Ainegeor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class>
<etym lang="fr">aulne</etym> i. an 
El)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
carries or measures with an
El: an Officer of the King,
who by himself or his Deputy
in places convenient, looks
to the assize of woollen cloth,
made through the Land, and
two seals for that purpose
ordained him. an.25. E.3 stat.
4. ca.1. Also an.3.<expan type="">read</expan>2. ca.2.
who is accomptable to the
King for every cloth so sealed.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aulic(a)">Aulick<etym lang="la"> (aulicus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;
ing to the Hall, or Court,
courtly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ancient demeasn(n)" lexeme="ancient domain(n)">Auncient Demeasn, De&shy;
main or Domain. (<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">publicum
vestigal</term>, or <term lang="la">Vetus patrimonium
Domini</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our com&shy;
mon Law, a certain Tenure 
whereby all the Mannors be&shy;
longing to the Crown in the
daies of St. Edward the Saxon
King, or William the Con&shy;
queror, were held. The
number and names of which
Mannors, as all other belong&shy;
ing to common persons, he
caused to be written into a
book (after a survey made of
them) now remaining in the
Exchequer, and called Domes&shy;
day Book, and those which by
that book appear to have be&shy;
longed to the Crown at that
time, and are conteined un&shy;
der the title (Terra Regis) 
are called Auncient Demeasne.
Kitch. fo98. See more of this
in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avocation(n)">Avocation<etym lang="la"> (avocatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
calling away or withdrawing,
a distraction.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avoir-du-pois(n)">Avoir-du-pois <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class> or
Avoir du poix . <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la"> habere pondus</term>,</form>
<xpln lang="en">full or due weight: it signifies
in our common Law two
things: first, a kind of weight,
divers from that called Troy
weight, which contains but
twelve ounces to the pound,
whereas this contains six&shy;
teen. And in this respect it
may probably be conjectured,
to be so called, because it is
of more weight than the o&shy;
ther. Also it signifies such
merchandize as are weighed
by this weight, and not by
Troy weight, as in the Statute
of York, an.9. E.3 in Pro&oelig;m. an.
27. Edw 3. Stat.2. ca.10.  &amp; an.
2 Rich.2. ca. I. See <xref> Weights</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="f1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avowry(n)" lexeme="advowry(n)">Avowry orAdvowry 
(comes from the French, <etym lang="fr">ad&shy;
vouer</etym>, <term lang="la">alias</term> avouer)</form> <xpln lang="en">and signi&shy;
fies as much as a justifying
or maintaining an act for&shy;
merly done. For example,
one takes a distress for rent,
or other thing, and he that
is distreyned sues a Replevin,
now he that took the distress,
or to whose use the distress
was taken by another, ju&shy;
stifying or maintaining the
act, is said to avow, and that
is called his avowry. Terms of
the Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auricle(n)">Auricle<etym lang="la"> (auricula)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a little
ear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auricular(a)">Auricular<etym lang="la"> (auricularis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to, or spoken in the
ear. As auricular Confession,
is that which is made in pri&shy;
vate to the Ghostly Father,
none hearing but himself, op&shy;
posite unto publick Confes&shy;
sion, which is made in the
hearing of many.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auricular vein(n)">Auricular vein,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
ear vein, which runs up by
the kernels which are under
the ear, Chyrurgeons open
it against deafness, pain and
ulcerations of the ears. See
in <xref>Vein</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aurum-potabile(n)">Aurum-potabile,</form> <xpln lang="en">is liquor

Chym. Dict.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auspical(a)">Auspical<etym lang="la"> (auspicalis)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">pertai&shy;

come. &amp;c. 

And they were called Aus&shy;
pices, that did foretel things
by beholding the flight of
birds, and were so denomina&shy;
ted <term lang="la"> ab aves aspiciendo</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

whence men, that are more

a presage of something to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="autotheism(n)">Autotheism (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr</class>:)</form> <xpln lang="en">the be&shy;

not from another, Calvins
autotheism signifies that point
of Doctrine which Calvin
held, which is, That God the
Son is not <term lang="la">Deus de Deo</term>, God
from God, whereas the Nicen
Creed saith, He is <term lang="la">Deus de
Deo</term></xpln></wordentry>

tumn, which is from the sixth
of August to the sixth of No&shy;
vember ; and is one of the four
Quarters of the year; Others
reckon Autume to begin at
the &AElig;quinoctium. <expan type="">id est</expan> about
the twelfth of September, and
to end at the Solstice or short&shy;
est day, about the eleventh of
December.</xpln></wordentry>

tence generally allowed to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baal(pn)">BAal<class type="etymlang" lang="he">(Hebr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Lord, a
Master, Husband, or Pa&shy;
tron: It was a common name
whereby the Heathens cal&shy;
led their God, 2 King.1.2. Judg.8.33.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baalzebub(pn)">Baal-zebub</form> <xpln lang="en"> See <xref lexeme="Belzebub">Bel-ze&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Babel(pn)">Babel (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">in Hebr.</class> it signi&shy;
fies confusion)</form> <xpln lang="en">was an ancient
City of Chaldea in Mesopota&shy;
mia, famous for the confusi&shy;
on of Languages, which
there happened: For immedi&shy;
ately after the universal De&shy;
luge, Nimrod the son of
Chus the son of Cham per&shy;
swaded the people (as some
Authors surmise) to secure
themselves from the like dan&shy;
ger by building some stupen&shy;
dious Edifice, which might
resist the fury of a second De&shy;
luge. This counsel was gene&shy;
rally imbraced, Heber onely
and his family, contradicting
such an unlawful attempt;
the major part prevailing,
the Tower began to rear a
head of majesty 5164 paces
from the ground (says Isidore)
having its basis and circumfe&shy;
rence equal to the height. But
God beholding from high this
fond attempt, sent amongst
them (who before were one
language) a confusion of 72
tongues, which hindred the
proceeding of this building,
one not being able to under&shy;
stand what his fellow called
or 


</page>

<page sig="f2v">
Bring me (quoth one) a Trowel quickly quick,
One brings him up a hammer; here this brick
(Another bids) and then they cleave a Tree.
Make fast this rope, and then they let it flee:
One calls for Planks, another Morter lacks;
They bring the first a stone, the last an Axe. Du Bartas.

Thus being compelled
to desist from so unlucky an
enterprize, they greedily
sought out such as they could
understand, with whom con&shy;
forting themselves, they for&shy;
get their former acquaintance,
and now are divided into 72
different nations, comprehen&shy;
ding about 24000 men, be&shy;
sides women and children,
Gen.10.10. 

The City Babel or Babylon
(howsoever the Tower was
hindred) went forward and
was finished an. mun. 1960.
the out-walls were built by
Q. Semiramis; it contained in
compass 60 miles, it had 100
gates, the walls were in height
200 (some Writers say 300)
foot, in breadth 75, and the ri&shy;
ver Euphrates passing through
the midst of it. 1. part. of the
Try. of Times p.142. 

Hence <expan type="">it is</expan> we use Babelish for
confused; And Babylonical for
magnificent or costly, and to
Bable or babble, to twattle, or
speak confusedly, which word
Bable Verstegan urges as a
proof that our old Saxon Lan&shy;
guage is as ancient as the
Tower of Babel. p.147.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bacchanalize(v)">Bacchanalize (from <etym lang="la">Bac&shy;
chus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to rage, play mad pranks,
fare like mad men, as the
Priests of Bacchus were wont 
to do, when they celebrated
his Feasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bacchanal(n)">Bacchanals<etym lang="la"> (Bacchanalia)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the places where the Feasts of
Bacchus or Bacchanalian feasts
were solemnized in riot and
drunkenness. Also the Feasts
themselves or time when they
were kept, <expan type="">id est</expan> at Shrovetide .
Sometimes also deboisht
drunkards men and women
are called Bacchanals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baccharach(pn)">Baccharach,</form> <xpln lang="en">A City stan&shy;
ding on the banks of the ri&shy;
ver Rhyne in Germany, so cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="gr"><emend err="Bacchiara" source="errata">Bacchi Ara</emend></etym> ; in ancient
time there was an Altar erect&shy;
ed to the honor of Bacchus, in
regard of the richness of the
wines which are made there,
and therefore called Bachrag 
or Bacharach ; vulgarly, Rhe&shy;
nish wines.</xpln></wordentry>

ot, drunkenness.</xpln></wordentry>

wine, drunken, sottish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="badger(n)">Badger (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">cometh of the Fr.</class>

<page sig="f3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balatron(n)">Balatron<etym lang="la"> (balatro)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a Bab&shy;
bler, or vain-talking fel&shy;
low, a Prater or vile
Knave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bail(n)">Baile (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">comes of the Fr.</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Bailler</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">attribuere, tradere, tri&shy;
buere</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it is used in our Com&shy;
mon Law properly for the
freeing or setting at liberty
one arrested or imprisoned
upon action either civil or
criminal, under surety taken
for his appearance at a day
and place certainly assigned.
Bract. lib.3. ca.8. num.8, &amp; 9. 

The reason why it is cal&shy;
led Bayl is, because by this
means the party restrained
is delivered into the hands of
those that bind themselves for
his forth-coming. There is
both common &amp; special Bail.
Common Bayl is in actions of
smal prejudice or slight proof,
in which case any Sureties are
taken; whereas upon cases
of greater weight Special Bayl 
or Surety must be given,
as Subsidy men at the least,
and they according to the
value. See the difference be&shy;
tween Bayl &amp; Mainprize in
 Manwoods Forrest Law. pag
267.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bain(n)">Bain <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Bath, Stew,
or hot-house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balcony(n)">Balcone (Ital. <etym lang="it">balcon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

fore needs no further expla&shy;
nation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balk(n)">Balk<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">(Sax.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a little peece

dize, as a bayl of Spicery, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballista(n)">Ballista<class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient

ropes of sinews and wo&shy;

together, &amp;c. The form
whereof you may read in

cap.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballon(n)">Ballon <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a great Ball,

called in Italy; also the round
Globe or top of a pillar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballotation(n)">Ballotation,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
casting lots, or a making
election by Balls, as in Venice
at the choyce of their Grand&shy;
Duke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balm(n)">Balme,</form> <xpln lang="en">A precious juyce or liquor, otherwise cal&shy;
led Balsamum, or Opobalsa&shy;
mum  (from the Hebr. Bag&shy; 
nal Shemen) It drops (by
cutting) out of a little low
plant (about a yard high)
having leaves like Rue, but
whiter, which growes in
&AElig;gypt, and some places
of the Holy Land. This 


</page>

<page sig="f3v">
juyce is somewhat like oyle,
but more clammy, and in&shy;
clining to a certain redness.
It has a strong smell, and
is not pleasant in taste. Be&shy;
ing put in a vessell of wa&shy;
ter it will sink down to the
bottom like a round pearl
without breaking, and may
be taken up again with the
point of a knife. It is an
excellent Medicine to take
any fear out of the body,
and for divers other purpo&shy;
ses, but very costly, and rarely
gotten. Saladinus writes that
there was but one Vineyard
of these in the whole world,
and that belonged to the
Great Turk. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balneary(n)">Balneary<etym lang="la"> (balnearium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
bathing place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balneation(n)">Balneation<etym lang="la"> (balneatio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
bathing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balneator(n)">Balneator: <emend err="Lat.)"><class type="etymlang" lang="la">(Lat.)</class></emend></form> <xpln lang="en">a Master
or Keeper of a Bath, or
Stew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Balthasar(pn)">Balthasar, <class type="etymlang" lang="he">in Hebrew</class> it
signifies, Searcher of trea&shy;
sure, or without treasure;</form> <xpln lang="en">
This was the name of one
of the Magi, or wisemen
vulgarly called the three
Kings of Collein, who came
out of the East to worship our
Saviour. The first of them,
called Melchior, an old man
with a long beard, offered
gold as to a King. The se&shy;
cond called Jasper, a beard&shy;
less young man, offered Fran&shy;
kincense, as unto God. The
third called Balthasar (a
Blackmoore with a spreading
beard) offered Myrrhe, as
to a man ready for his Sepul&shy;
chre. 

<term lang="la">Tres Reges Regi regum tria dona ferebant;
Myrrham homini, uncto aurum, thura dedere Deo:
Tu tria fac itidem dones pia munera Christo:
Muneribus gratus si cupis esse tuis.
Pro myrrha lachrymas, auro cor porrige purum,
Pro thure ac humili pectore funde preces.</term>
Thus in English.
Three Kings, the King of Kings, three gifts did bring;
Myrrh, Incense, Gold, as to God, Man, and King.
Let three pure gifts be likewise giv'n by thee
To Christ, even such as acceptable be.
For Myrrh, tears; for Frankinsence impart
Submissive prayers; for pure Gold, a pure heart.


See Vul. Errors fol 353. and Sands Travels.181.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="f4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baltic Sea(pn)">Baltick Sea</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called
from a great Peninsula for&shy;
lerly called Baltia now Scan&shy;
dia) is that which begins at
the narrow passage called the
Sound, interlaceth Denmark,
Swethland, Germany, and Po&shy;
land, and extends even to
Livona and Lituania. The
reasons why this Sea being so
large does not ebb and flow
are first, The narrowness of
the Straight, by which the
Ocean is let into it. And se&shy;
condly, The Northern scitu&shy;
ation of it, whereby the c&oelig;&shy;
lestial influences produce
therein the lesser operation.
Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandit(n)">Banditi <class type="etymlang" lang="it">(Ital.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">Out-laws,
Rebels, Fugitives condemned
by Proclamation; Bando in
Ital. signifying a Proclamati&shy;
on. These in the Low-Coun&shy;
tries are called Freebooters ; in
Germany, Nightingales ; in the
north of England, Moss-Troo&shy;
pers ; in Ireland Tories.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banner(n)">Banner,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Ensign, or
Standard from the Britt.
Ban, which signifies a high 
place, because Banners are
wont to be set on a high
place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banderol(n)">Banderol orBannerolle
(Fr. <etym lang="fr">Banderolle</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little flag or
streamer, or a Pennon worn
on the top of a Horsemans
Launce; A Cornet-De&shy;
vise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandle(n)">Bandle,</form> <xpln lang="en">A kind of drink&shy;
ing in the Oriental Countries, 
as Cambaia, Calicut, Narsingha,
which is rare and precious,
it is said (like the Poets Ne&shy;
penthe) to provoke pleasing
dreams. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bans(n)">Banes 
or
Bans  (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Ban)</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a publick
notice of any
thing. The word is ordina&shy;
ry among the Feudists, and
grown from them to other
uses; As to that, which we
here in England call a Procla&shy;
mation, whereby any thing
is publickly commanded or
forbidden. But it is used more
especially in the publishing
of matrimonial contracts in
the Church before marriage,
to the end, if any man can say
any thing against the <emend err="intenti">intenti&shy;</emend>
on of the parties, either in
respect of kindred, or other&shy;
wise, they may take their ex&shy;
ception in time. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baptism(n)">Baptism (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1f71;&pi;&zeta;&iota;&#x03c3;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a washing with
water, or diving over the
head)</form> <xpln lang="en">is one of the Sacra&shy;
ments instituted by our Savi&shy;
or Christ in remedy against
Original sin in the law of
Grace, as Circumcision was the
remedy against that sin in the
Law of Moses. Before Christs
institution of this Sacrament
John Baptist did baptize unto
penance, but his Baptism
was not a Sacrament. In Au&shy;
thors <emend err="yon">you</emend> may read of three
sorts of Baptism, which Di&shy;
vines call Baptismus fluminis,
of water, which is the already
mentioned; Baptismus flami&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="f4v">
nis, of the Spirit, which is
contrition of heart with de&shy;
sire of the sacrament of Bap&shy;
tism, And Baptismus sanguinis,
of blood, which is Martyrdom.
The custom of the Primitive
Church was to have God-Fa&shy;
thers and God-Mothers in the
administration of the Sacra&shy;
ment of Baptism; their Of&shy;
fice was not onely to be Wit&shy;
nesses of the Baptism, or to
speak or answer for the bap&shy;
tized, but also to under&shy;
take a charge of instructing
or seeing him instructed in
the true Religion in due
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baptist(pn)">Baptist<etym lang="la"> (baptista)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a name
of excellency given to Saint
John, that had the honor of
baptizing of our Saviour
Christ in Jordan, and who first
baptized.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baptistery(n)">Baptistery<etym lang="la"> (baptisterium)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
Font to baptize in, a Bath, a
vessel to wash the body in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barbarism(n)">Barbarism<etym lang="la"> (barbarismus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
fault in the pronouncing,
tone or accent of words; 
rudeness of speech or beha&shy;
vior.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barbican(pn)">Barbican 
or
Barbicane (French, <etym lang="fr"> Bar&shy;
bicane</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
out-work in
any building; also a Wall
or Bulwark before or over
a Wall, breast high to de&shy;
fend from the Enemies shot.
Some take it for a Senti&shy;
nels house, or Scout-house;
Chaucer useth the word Bar&shy;
bican, for a Watch-Tower,
hence Barbican by Red-cross-&shy;
street in London is thought
to take its denomination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barbitist(n)">Barbitist<etym lang="la"> (barbitista)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a
Lutinist, or one that plays on
the Lute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bard(n)">Bards (from the old Bri&shy;
tish <etym lang="br">Bardd</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the ancient
Poets of the Britans . <term lang="la">Bar&shy;
dus</term>, according to Pompei&shy;
us Festus, <term lang="la">Gallic&egrave; cantorem sig&shy;
nificat, qui virorum fortium
laudes canit</term>. Diod. Sicul. lib.5.
cals them Factores cantionum .
And Lucan (lib. I) <term lang="la">Poetas sive
vates</term>. 

<term lang="la">
Vos quoque qui fortes animas, belloque peremtos
Laudibus, in longum, vates, dimittitis &aelig;vum,
Plurima securi fudistis carmine  Bardi.
</term>

In Wales of old the Bards
did also keep the Ensigns,
Arms, and Genealogies of the
Nobility. See more in the
Laws of Howel Dha.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barnard(pn)">Barnard</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Bernard .</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bairn(n)">Barn orBearn <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">(Germ.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">
a child. Hence <expan type="">it is</expan> we say in
the north of England, how do
Wife and Barnes, <expan type="">id est</expan> how do 
Wife and Children. 

Or Barn may come from
the Hebr. Bar, and that from
Bara. <expan type="">id est</expan> Genuit. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barnabas(pn)" lexeme="Barnaby(pn)">Barnabas orBarnaby <class type="etymlang" lang="he">(Hebr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">Son
of the Master,
or Son of
comfort.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barocco(n)">Barocco,</form> <xpln lang="en">The name of a 


</page>

<page sig="f5r">
Syllogistical Mood in Logick
wherein the first Proposition
must be an universal Affirma&shy;
tive, and the other two Nega&shy;
tives.</xpln>

</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barricado(n)">Barricado (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa.</class> <etym lang="sp">Barricada</etym>,
<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Barricade</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a warlike de&shy;
fence of empty barrels and
such like vessels fill'd with
earth against an enemies shot
or assault. It is so called be&shy;
cause it was made of those
vessels, which the French call
Bariques, <expan type="">id est</expan> a vessel bigger then
our barrel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barattor(n)">Barettor 
 or
Barrator  (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Barateur</etym>, which
in that Lan&shy;
guage signifies a deceiver)</form> <xpln lang="en">
in our Common Law is a
common wrangler, that sets
men at odds, and is himself
never quiet, but at variance
with one or other: but Skene
(<term lang="la">de verb. signif. verbo Barratry</term>)
saith Barraters are Symonists,
and so called from the Italian
(<term lang="it">barrataria</term>) signifying corru&shy;
ption or bribery in a Judge
giving a false Sentence for
mony. Vid . Cowel upon this
word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barratry(n)">Barratrie or Barrataria,</form> <xpln lang="en">
any kinde of Simony, especi&shy;
ally in obtaining the right of
Benefices. Socinus Reg. 55.
Baldus in Consilio. 21. Part.5.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barriers(n)">Barriers (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French</class>
<etym lang="fr">Barres</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies with us that
which the <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">
Fr.</class> cal (<term lang="fr">jeu de Barres
</term> <expan type="">id est</expan><term lang="la">pal&aelig;stram</term>) a martial sport or
exercise of men armed and
fighting together with short
swords, within certain limits 
or Lists, whereby they are se&shy;
vered from the beholders.
Cow. This exercise was
formerly much in request
in England, but now is laid
aside.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barrister(n)">Barristers 
 or
Baristers</form> <xpln lang="en">at Law, may
be said to be
of two sorts,
I. The outward or Utter Bari&shy;
sters, are such, as (for their
long study and great industry
bestowed upon the know&shy;
ledge of the Common Law,
which must be for seven yeers
space at least) are called out
of their contemplation to
practice, and in the face of the
world to take upon them the
protection and defence of
Clients. These always plead
without the Bar, and are in o&shy;
ther Countries called Licenti&shy;
ati in Jure, howbeit in modesty
they at first continue them&shy;
selves hearers for some yeers,
like the Scholars of Pythago&shy;
ras, that for the first five yeers
never adventured to reason or
discourse openly upon any
point of their Masters Do&shy;
ctrine. 2. The Inner Bari&shy;
sters are those, who are admit&shy;
ted (as a mark of respect)
to plead within the Bar, such
are King, Queen, or Princes
Attorney, Sollicitor, or Ser&shy;
jeants, or any of the Kings
Council. But at the Rolls
and some inferior Judicatures,
all Lawyers of the degree of
the Bench are admitted with&shy;
in the Bar. See <xref> Mootmen</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bartholmew(n)">Bartholmew<class type="etymlang" lang="he">(Hebr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">the 


</page>

<page sig="f5v">
Son of him that makes the
waters to mount, that is, of
God, which lifts up the mind
of his Teachers, and drops
down water (Szegedinus.)
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bascuence(pn)">Bascuence (Spa. <etym lang="sp">Bascuenca)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
the Language of the Country
of Biscay in Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="basiate(v)">Basiate<etym lang="la"> (basio)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to kiss or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastardy(n)">Bastardy (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">comes of the

turn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastille(n)">Bastille
 or

tress or Forti&shy;
fortification termed

<term lang="fr">la Bastille</term> is as our Tower, the
chief prison of the kingdom,
and the chief Fortress of that
City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastion(n)">Bastion <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a Bulwark
or Fortress; the fortification
called a Cullion-head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baston(n)">Baston <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a staff, batt,
or cudgel. It signifies in the
Statutes of this Nation one 
of the Warden of the Fleet's
servants or Officers, that at&shy;
tends the Kings Court, with
a red staff, for the taking such
to Ward, as are committed
by the Court. So it is used
An.1 <expan type="">read</expan>2. Ca.12. &amp; 5. Eliz.
cap.23.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastonado(n)">Bastonado (Span. <etym lang="sp">Basto&shy;
nada</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a banging or cudgel&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

ple of Germany inhabiting

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="battalion(n)">Battalion (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Battaillon</etym>,
Span.<etym lang="sp"> Battallon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the main
battle, or a great Squadron of
foot-men appointed to fight,
so called by the Switzers and

man Legions) of between
six and eight thousand souldi&shy;
ers. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beatifical(a)">Beatifical<etym lang="la"> (beatificus)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beatify(v)">To Beatifie<etym lang="la"> (beatifico)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">to
make happy or blessed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beatitude(n)">Beatitude<etym lang="la"> (beatitudo)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">bles&shy;
sedness, happiness, prosperi&shy;
ty. The eight Beatitudes are
abstractedly thus; 1. To be
poor of spirit. 2. Meek. 3.
Mourn. 4. To hunger and
thirst after Justice. 5. To
be Merciful. 6. Clean of
heart. 7. Peace-Makers. 


</page>

<page sig="f6r">
8. To suffer persecution for
Justice. Which you may see
at large in St. Matt. cap.5.
They are called Beatitudes,
because the Scripture says,
<term lang="la"> Beati qui</term>, &amp;c. they are bles&shy;
sed, that are in any of those
States.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beatrice(pn)">Beatrice<etym lang="la"> (beatrix)</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">that
makes happy or blessed; a
womans name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bravish(a)">Bravis,</form> <xpln lang="en">may seem proba&shy;
bly to be corrupted from the
name of the famous Celtique
King Bellovesus. The French
having made in like sort Beau&shy;
vis of the old City Belloua&shy;
cum. In both these is a signi&shy;
cancy of beauty. In later
times Bogo hath been used in
Latin for Beavis . Camden.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beaconage(n)">Beconage.</form> <xpln lang="en">Signifying mo&shy;
ny paid for the maintenance
of Beacons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bemol(n)">Beemol <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">(Fr.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">the flat key
