<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bed-fere(n)">ABedpheere<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">(Sax.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a
Bed fellow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bead(n)">Bede
Beade   <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">(Sax.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">he that
prays, or a de&shy;
vout man, as Eucherius or Eu&shy;
sebius in Greek: we retain still
Bedeman or Bedesman in
the same sense; and to say our
Bedes, is to say our prayers.
Cam. 

Bede was also the name of a
most learned English Monk
commonly mentioned with
the Epithete Venerable, which
was a title given him even in
his life time, for his eminent
learning, gravity, and sancti&shy;
ty of life, he lived in a Mo&shy; 
nastery neer Newcastle upon
Tine in the seventh age, dying
about the yeer of Christ 734,
he wrote a multitude of books
the Catalogue whereof may
be seen in Doctor Pits, De il&shy;
lustribus Angli&aelig; Scriptoribus.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Sense not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bead-roll(n)">Bede-roll<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">(Sax.)</class></form> <xpln lang="en">is a roll
or list of such as Priests were
wont to pray for in Church&shy;
es.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beadle(n)">Bedle orBedel (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">from the
Heb.</class> <etym lang="he">Badhal</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">because they se&shy;
parate the good from the bad,
or beggars from rich men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bedlem(pn)">Bedlem</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Beth&shy;
lem</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beglerbeg(n)">Beglerbeg</form> <xpln lang="en">(<expan type="">id est</expan> Lord of
Lords) a Vice-Roy or su&shy;
preme Commander under the
great Turk, that commands
both the Sansiakes and Bassa' s ;
of these there be onely two,
the one of Greece, the other
of Natolia, and are by the
Turks called Rumely . In the
Persian tongue it signifies a
Marquess. Herb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beguines(pn)">Beguines.</form> <xpln lang="en">An order of
Nuns or Religious women,
who commonly be all old or
well in yeers. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bek(n)" lexeme="bec(n)">Bek orBec.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Phrygi&shy;
an word, signifying bread.
Herodorus declares in his se&shy;
cond book, that Psammeti&shy;
cus a King of the Egypti&shy;
ans, was desirous on a
time to make tryal what
language a child would na&shy;
turally speak, being brought
up among dumb people, or
where no speech should be
heard, to the end he might 


</page>

<page sig="f6v">
judge thereby, what was the
most ancient and natural<emend err="lan"> lan&shy;</emend>
guage; and did therefore
cause two children to be
nursed in a Forest, where
no voice of man could be
heard, after four yeers
were past, being brought
before the King they could
sometimes pronounce this
word Bec, whereupon
some gathered that<emend err="Phrygi"> Phrygi&shy;</emend>
an was the first Language
of man. But (as St. <emend err="Au">Au&shy;</emend>
gustine saith) these children
might have learned the word
Bec (and so retained it)
of Goats, among which they
were nourished. For, as he
shews in his work of the
quantity of the Soul, All
manner of speaking is by
hearing and imitation. Not&shy;
withstanding he believes that
(before the confusion of
Tongues at Babel) the He&shy;
brew language was natural
to all. Aug. in Civit. Dei lib.
16. cap.11.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beest(n)" lexeme="beestings(n)">Beest orBeestings,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">quasi</term> 
Breastings, the first milk that
comes from the Teat, after the
birth of any thing. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behiram(n)">Behiram.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Feast among
the Turks, wherein they
pardon all injuries. H. Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bel Videre(pn)">Bel videre. </form> <xpln lang="en">The Popes Pa&shy;
lace in Rome, so called, the
word signifies fair to see, or 
pleasant to behold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bell(pn)">Bell, </form> <xpln lang="en">in the Chaldean
tongue signifies the Sun; and
therefore Ninus and Semira&shy;
mis gave that name to their
Father Bel or Belus, that he
might be honored as the Sun,
which the Babylonians wor&shy;
shipped as a God. Rawl. Bel
also is a contract of Bebel,
which comes of Babal, a Lord:
it was not onely the particu&shy;
lar Idol of the Babylonians,
but a general name of the I&shy;
dols in the East, agreeing
to all the Idols of the Gen&shy;
tiles, as some write. Jer. 9 5.
1 King. 18 25.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bellacity(n)">Bellacity <etym lang="la"> (bellacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">war&shy;
likeness.</xpln></wordentry>

of flies, or the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Benedictines(pn)">Benedictines or Benedi&shy;
ctine Monks,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Religi&shy;
ous persons so called, from
St. Benedict, who was born at
Nursia in Umbria, Anno 482,
he gathered the Monks of I&shy;
taly together, and gave them a 
rule in writing. Their habit
is a loose Gown of black,
their under garment white
Woollen, their Crowns sha&shy;
ven. Of this ancient Order
have been above 50 Popes, and
at least 200 Cardinals.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bernard(pn)" lexeme="Barnard(pn)">Bernard or Barnard,  
(<class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">St. Bernards Cluni&shy;
ac Monks draw it from Bona
bardus by allusion; some turn
it hard child. If it be derived
(as the Germans will have
it) from Bearne, which sig&shy;
nifies a bear, it is answerable 
to Arthur, others yet more
judicially translate Bernard
into filialis indoles, child&shy;
like disposition towards Pa&shy;
rents, as Bernber, Lord
of many children, Cam. 

Verstegan says, the true
Orthography is Beornhart,
and by corruption Bearn&shy;
heart. i. Beares-heart.
</xpln></wordentry>

cians.</xpln></wordentry>

chief house of a Mannor,
or the Lords seat is so
called in some parts of En&shy;
gland to this day; espe&shy;
cially, in Herefordshire,
where there are the Ber&shy;
ries of Luston, Stockton,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bigamist(n)">Bigamist<etym lang="la"> (bigamus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that hath marryed two wives
of which sort La mech was the
first.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bigamy(n)">Bigamy<etym lang="la"> (bigamia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
marriage of two wives; not
both together, but severally
after the death of the first. It
is used in the Common Law
for an impediment to be a
Clerk, and so for a prisoner to
lose the benefit of his Clergy.
For the Canonists hold, that he
that has been twice marryed
may not be a Clerk; and they
ground it upon these words
of St Paul, I Tim.3.2. <term lang="la">Opor&shy;
tet ergo Episcopum irreprehensi&shy;
bilem esse, &amp; unius uxoris vi&shy;
rum</term> . And also him that hath
marryed a widow, they by in&shy;
terpretation take to have been
twice marryed, and both
these they not onely exclude
from Holy Orders, but deny
all priviledges of Clergy;
but this Law is abolished by
 Anno 1 Ed.6 cap.12. And to
that may be added the Statute
of 18. Eliz. cap.7. which al&shy;
lows to all men that can read
as Clerks, though not within 


</page>

<page sig="f8r"> 

Orders, the benefit of Clergy
in case of Felony, not espe&shy;
cially excepted by some other
Statute. Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bigate(n)">Bigat<etym lang="la"> (bigatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was a piece
of Roman silver Coyn, so cal&shy;
led of Bigia a Chariot, drawn
with two horses, stamped up&shy;
on the one side, and it was
the same with Denarius . Li&shy;
vie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bigot(n)">Bigot (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an hypocrite,
or one that seems much more
holy, then he is, also a scrupu&shy;
lous or Superstitious fellow
Sir K. Digby in his Treatise of
Bodies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bylaw(n)">Bilaws,</form> <xpln lang="en">are Orders made
in Court Leets, or Court-Ba&shy;
rons by common Assent for
the good of those that make
them, farther then the
publique Law binds. Cook
Vol.6. fol.63.a, Kitchin fol.45
&amp; 79.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bilinguis(a)">Bilinguis (<etym lang="la">ex bis &amp; lin&shy;
gua</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">double-tongued, de&shy;
ceitful. In our Common&shy;
Law it is used for that Jury
that passeth between an En&shy;
glish man and an Alien or
stranger, whereof part must
be English men, and part
strangers. Anno 28, Edw.3. 
cap.13,</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bissextile(n)">Bissextile<etym lang="la"> (bissextilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">leap
yeer, so called, because the
sixth Calends of March, are in 


</page>

<page sig="f8v">
that yeer twice reckoned
( viz,) on the four and
twentieth and five and twen&shy; 
tieth of February, so that
Leap yeer has one day more
then other yeers. 

Thirty days hath September,
April, June, and November:
February hath eight and twenty alone,
And all the rest have thirty and one:
But when of Leap-yeer cometh the time,
Then days hath February twenty and nine. 

This Leap-year is obser&shy;
ved every fourth year, and
was first devised by Julius
C&aelig;sar to accommodate the
yeer with the course of the
Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bitumen(n)">Bitume<etym lang="la"> (bitumen</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of clay or slime naturally
clammy, like pitch, growing
in some Countries of Asia;
It was of old used in Physick;
the best is heavy, bright and
cleer, of purple colour, and
<emend err="and"></emend> having a strong smell, the
black is accounted naught;
this Bitumen was used instead
of Mortar at building the
Tower of Babel, as appears in
Gen. cap.11. There is also a
kind of Bitumen, like a liquor,
flowing out of Mare Mortuum
and out of some fountains in
the Island Sicily, which is u&shy;
sed instead of oyle to burn in
Lamps. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bituminous(a)">Bituminous<etym lang="la"> (bitumineus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to Bitumen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bituminated(a)">Bituminated,</form> <xpln lang="en">soldered or
done with bitumen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bezant(n)">Bizantine or Besant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a ve&shy;
ry ancient coyn of Gold, so
called because it was coyned
at Constantinople, formerly
called Bizantium. This coyn 
is not now known, but Dun&shy;
stan Archbishop of Canterbury
(as it is in the Authentical
Deed) purchased Hendon in
Middlesex of King Edgar to
Westminster for 200 Bizantines:
of what value they were, was
utterly forgotten in the time
of King Edw.3. for whereas
the Bishop of Norwich was
condemned to pay a Bizantine
of Gold to the Abbot of St.
Edmondsbury, for encroaching
upon his liberty (as it was en&shy;
acted by Parliament in the
time of the Conquerour) no
man then living could tell
how much that was: so as it
was referred to the King to
rate how much he should pay:
which was the more strange,
considering, but 100 yeers be&shy;
fore 200000 Bezants were ex&shy;
acted of the Soldan, for re&shy;
deeming St. Lewis of France,
which were then valued at
100000 livres. The name con&shy;
tinues yet in the blazons of
Arms, where plates of gold
are called Bezants, and a great
piece of gold valued at 15.l.
(which the K. of En. formerly
offered on high festival days)
was called a Bizantine. 


</page>

<page sig="g1r">
but afterward there were
two purposely made for the
King and Queen with the re&shy;
semblance of the blessed Tri&shy;
nity inscribed, <term lang="la">In honorem
sanct&aelig; Trinitatis</term>, and on the
other side the picture of the
Virgin Mary, with <term lang="la">In honorem
sanct&aelig; Mari&aelig; Virginis</term>, and
this was used till the first year
of King James, who caused
two to be new cast, the one
for himself, having on the
one side the picture of a King
kneeling before an Altar with
four Crowns before him, im&shy;
plying his four Kingdoms,
and in the circumscription,
<term lang="la">Quid retribuam Domino pro om&shy;
nibus qu&aelig; tribuit mihi</term>: On
the other side a Lamb lying
by a Lyon, with <term lang="la">Cor contri&shy;
tum &amp; humiliatum non despici&shy;
et Deus</term> . And in another for
the Queen, a Crown pro&shy;
tected by a Cherubin, over
that an eye, and Deus in a
cloud, with <term lang="la">Teget ala Summus</term> ;
on the reverse, a Queen knee&shy;
ling before an altar with this
Circumscription. <term lang="la">Piis precibus
fervente fide, humili obsequio</term> .
Cam. Rem. 

The French Kings were also
accustomed to offer 13 Be&shy;
sants at the Mass of their
Coronation in Rheims, &amp;c.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="black rod(n)">Black rod,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is the Huissier
or Usher belonging to the or&shy;
der of the Garter; So cal&shy;
led of his black-rod which
he carries in his hand: he was
of the Kings Chamber and U&shy; 
sher of the Lords house in Par&shy;
liament. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

of Custard; a white meat
made of flower, milk, sugar,
and the brains of Pullets. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blood-wite(n)">Bloudwit (<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">from the Sax.</class> 
<etym lang="sx">blout</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> bloud) and
( <etym lang="sx">wit</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">for
which we have the word
( wite still in the west parts
of England, signifying a char&shy;
ging of one with a fault, or an
upbraiding. 

This Bloudwit is a word u&shy;
sed in Charters of Liberties
anciently granted, and signi&shy;
fies an amerciament; for
shedding of blood. So that
whosoever had it given him
in his Charter, had the pe&shy;
nalty due for shedding of
blood granted him. Cow.
Fleta saith, <term lang="la">Significat quietan&shy;
tiam misericordi&aelig; pro effusione
sanguinis</term>. lib. I. ca. 47.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bonhomes(pn)">Bonhomes (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> good
men)</form> <xpln lang="en">a religious order of
Fryers <emend err="entituled" source="errata">instituted</emend> by Saint
Francis de Paula, a Town of
Calabria in Italy: a person of
eminent sanctity and austeri&shy;
ty of life, and of that humi&shy;
lity, that he stiled himself 


</page>

<page sig="g2r">
the least or meanest of men,
and ordered the followers of
his institute or rule, to take
the appellation of Minimi 
(the least or unworthiest
among men) and thence they
are commonly known and
called by the name of Minims 
or Minorites ; One point of
mortification, whereunto the
Regulars of that Order tye
themselves by vow (besides
their three Vows, of Chasti&shy;
ty, Poverty and Obedience)
is a total abstinence from
flesh-meats. It is an Order
much reverenced in France,
where the Founder lived, and
died at Tours, an. 1507.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boras(n)">Boras or Borar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a white
or greenish substance like
Salt-petre, wherewith Gold&shy;
smiths use to soder gold and
silver: some write it is the gum
of a tree, which is very un&shy;
likely; others affirm it to be
made of old Lees of Oyl, by
art and drying in the Sun,
brought to be white; But
Doctor Bullokar rather con&shy;
ceives it to bee a Myne&shy;
ral.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="borough(n)">Borow
or 
Borough</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Corporate
Town that is
not a City, an.
2 Ed.3 ca.3. namely, all such
as send Burgesses to the Parli&shy;
ament, the number whereof
you may find in Mr. Cromp&shy;
tons Iurisd. fo.24. and more of
this in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="borough-English(n)">Borow-English,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is a cu&shy;
stomary descent of Lands or
Tenements, which (in all
places where this custom
holds) descend to the young&shy;
est son; or if the owner have
no issue, to his youngest Bro&shy;
ther, as in Edmunton. Kitchin.
fo.102. and the reason of this
custom (as Littleton saith) is,
for that the youngest is pre&shy;
sumed in Law to be least able
to shift for himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boscage(n)">Boscage (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Grove,

that's stored, or set thick with

Sir H. Wott.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boot(n)">Bote 
or 
Boote</form> <xpln lang="en">is an old Sax.
word, and signi&shy;
fies help, suc&shy;
cour, aide and advantage,
coming from the Low Dutch
Boete, Baete, which is a&shy;
mends, remedy, and help;
So we say what boots or avails
it? or what boot will you give
me? and is commonly joy&shy;
ned with other words, as
Bridg-boot, Burgh-boot, Fire&shy;
boot, Hedge-boot, and divers o&shy;
thers, Min.</xpln></wordentry>

at strife.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brachygraphy(n)">Brachygraphy<etym lang="la"> (brachygra&shy;
phia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the art of writing by
short characters. I cannot say,
either who was the author,
or whether the invention be
ancient or more modern, one&shy;
ly I find in Dion, that M&aelig;c&aelig;&shy;
nas (that great favorite of
Augustus C&aelig;sar, and Favorer of
learning) first found out cer&shy;
tain notes and figures <term lang="la">ad cele&shy;
ritatem Scribendi</term>, for the spee&shy;
dier dispatch of writing,
Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brace(n)">Brace,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the common ac&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="g3r">
acceptation is a known word
signifying two or a couple;
but with Printers a Brace is
that which couples two or
more words together, and is
made thus }</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brackmans(pn)">Brackmans,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect of Phi&shy;
losophers in India, that lived
onely by hearbs, roots, and
fruit. These Brackmans or
Bramines are now the Indian
Priests (perhaps following
the custom of the &AElig;gyptians
who were wont to chuse their
Priests out of their whole
number of Philosophers) and
are of like authority in their
Church, as the Muftees or
Mufties are among the Turks,
and as the Flamines and Arch&shy;
flamines were among the hea&shy;
then Romans, or as the Druides 
among the Britans and Gauls 
They hate Mahumed, and ac&shy;
knowledge one God and cre&shy;
ator of all things: the better
sort are called Mockadams, or
Masters. Herb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="braggodocio(n)">Bragodocia,</form> <xpln lang="en">a coynd word
with us, for a ranting coward,
or bragging fellow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bragget(n)">Bragget or Braggot (<class type="etymlang" lang="br">br.</class> 
<etym lang="br">Bragod</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a drink made of Malt,
water and hony, used in Wales,
having the name from the
Welch word Brag . <expan type="">id est</expan> malta
Gots, <expan type="">id est</expan> Hony-combs . This drink
is also called by us, and in Low
Dutch Mede, <term lang="la"> ex melle</term>, hony.
Min. Also a stay cut <emend err="o ut f">out of</emend> 
stone or timber, to bear up
the Summer, in Masonry cal&shy;
led a Corbel ; in timber-work 
a Bragget or shoulder peece.
Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brandish(v)">Brandish (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">brandir</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make to shine or glister with
gentle shaking or moving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bravado(n)">Bravado (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">bravade</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa.</class> 
<term lang="sp">brabada</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a shew of Challenge
or of daring, a boastful af&shy;
front.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breviary(n)">Breviary<etym lang="la"> (breviarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
abridgement, or compendi&shy;
ous draught, a short col&shy;
lection. Particularly, it is
the name of a book, to the
daily recital whereof the Ca&shy;
tholick Priests are tyed, from
the time they take the order of
Sub-Deaconship, in discharge
of part of their Function. I
have heard that the Lord
Treasurer Cecil after he had
diligently perused this book,
did greatly admire the order
and method of it, saying it
might well be termed a Bre&shy;
viary, for containing so much,
and such variety in so con&shy;
tracted a bulk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breviloquence(n)">Breviloquence<etym lang="la"> (brevilo&shy;
quentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a brief or short form
of speaking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brigand(n)">Brigand (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Footman
armed, or serving with a Bri&shy;
gandine; In old time when
those kind of Souldiers mar&shy;
ched, they held all to be
good prize, that they could
purloin from the people, and
thereupon this word now sig&shy;
nifies also a Theef, purse&shy;
taker, or High-way robber.
White.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brigandine(n)">Brigandine (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a jack or 


</page>

<page sig="g3v">
coat of Mail, but properly an&shy;
cient Armour of Skale-like
plates and many joynts. This
word is used ann. 4, &amp; 5. Ph.  &amp;
Ma. ca.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brigantine(n)">Brigantine (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of swift vessel for Sea, bigger
than the Frigot, and less then
the Foist, having some ten
or twelve oares on a side, and
commonly a theevish Vessel:
of these the Rhodians are
said to be the first Inven&shy;
tors. 

The Faloque is said to be
the least Sea-Vessel with Oars,
the Frigot next, then the Bri&shy;
gantin, the Foist, the Galiot,
the Galey, and the Galeasse the
biggest. Ren.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brigade(n)">Brigade 
Brigado  (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
of war, which
that you may the better un&shy;
derstand, six men make a Rot,
or Fife, three Rots of Pikes
make a Corporalship, but the
Musketiers have four Files
to a Corporalship, three
Corporalships of each arms
make a compleat Company,
<expan type="">id est</expan> nine Rots of Pikes and
twelve Rots of Musketiers
(one and twenty Rots toge&shy;
ther) which amount to the
number of 126 men, besides
all Officers, Muster-youngs,
and Pasnolants; four of these
Companies (being 504 men)
make a Squadron, and three
such Squadrons form a perfect
Brigade. Bar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bridge-bote(n)">Brig-bote or 
Brugbote</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a Tri&shy;
bute, contri&shy;
bution or aid 
towards the mending of
bridges, whereof many are
freed by the Kings Charter,
and hereupon the word is<emend err="u"> u&shy;</emend>
sed for the very liberty or ex&shy;
emption from this Tribute.
Cow. And Fleta l. I. ca. 47. saith, 
<term lang="la">Brigbote significat quietantiam
reparationis pontium</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brigid(pn)" lexeme="Brigit(pn)">Brigid
or 
Brigit</form> <xpln lang="en">contracted also
into Bride, an I&shy;
rish name, as it
seems, for that the ancient
St. Brigid was of that nation.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brigidians(pn)">Brigidians,</form> <xpln lang="en">An order of
religious persons instituted
by Brigidia a widow, who
was Princess of Suetia un&shy;
der P. Urbane the fifth, about
the year of our Lord 1372. it
was as well of men as wo&shy;
men, albeit they dwelt seve&shy;
rally by themselves. Pol. &amp;
Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brocado(n)">Brocado (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cloth of
gold or silver. Hence we call
that Brocado' d Silk or Satten,
which is wrought or mixed
with Gold or Silver, and
sometimes that is called Bro&shy;
cado' d Silk, which is wrought
with several colours of
silk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burghalpenny(n)">Brodehalfpeny (<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sig&shy;

</page>

<page sig="g4r">
ting up Tables or Boards in
a Fair or Market, from which
they that are freed by the
Kings Charter, had this word
mentioned in their Letters
Patents. In somuch as at this
day the freedom it self (for
shortness of speech) is called
Brodehalfpeny. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Buckeldians(pn)">Buckeldians,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of those

which are 1. Mumerians, 2. A&shy;

thorists . 5. Silents . 6. Enthu&shy;
siasts . 7. Libertines . 8. Ada&shy;

nians . 11. Bucheldians 12. Mel&shy;

and hollow within, made
like a heart, and used to be
hung about their necks; and
hance the Briefs or Mandats
of the Pope are called Buls,
from the lead Seal commonly
affixed thereto. 

Bulls of Basan, properly
fat Bulls; strong, powerful,
and cruel Enemies, Psa.22.12: 
Many young bulls have encom&shy;
passed me: Basan  was the
fruitful Country of Og, and
became the Jewes by con&shy;
quest. Deut.3.1.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="c"><alpha><f type="l"/>C</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cabbala(n)"> CAbala (Hebr.) <term lang="la">receptio</term></form> <xpln lang="en">
a receiving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cabbala(n)" lexeme="cabalistic art(n)">Cabala orCabalistick
Art,</form> <xpln lang="en">a hidden Science of
Divine Mysteries, which con&shy;
sists in drawing several senses
either out of the same letters
of a Hebrew word, as they
lye first written in the word,
or by different combinations
of them, or by changing
one letter for another ac&shy;
cording to art, or from the
different writing a letter in
one word, from the writing
of the same Letter in ano&shy;
ther word, or yet by some
other nice ways, known to the
Hebrew Rabbins, who are they
onely that use this art
for their Exposition of Scrip&shy;
ture; And as it is an Art
proper to the Jewes, so
is it judged by the better
learned to contain more of 


</page>

<page sig="g5r">
the imaginary, or phan&shy;
tastical, then of solid lear&shy;
ning, towards the true un&shy;
derstanding of holy Scrip&shy;
ture. 

Picus Mirandula describes
it shortly thus, <term lang="la">Est nam&shy;
que universa issa secretior Di&shy;
vin&aelig; legis expositio ex ore
Dei &agrave; Moyse accepta &amp; Pro&shy;
phetarum animis &agrave; Deo infu&shy;
sa</term> . It comprehends all
those secret waies of expo&shy;
sition of the Divine Law,
which were received by Mo&shy;
ses from the mouth of God,
and were afterward revea&shy;
led by God to his Pro&shy;
phets. 

And Camden saith thus of
it, "That (as the great
'Masters of the Jews testifie)
' Moses received of God a
'literal Law, written by
'the finger of God in the
'two Tables of the ten Com&shy;
'mandements to be impar&shy;
'ted to all, and another my&shy;
'stical, to be communicated
'onely to seventy men, which
'by tradition they should
'pass to their posterity,
'whereof it was called Ca&shy;
' bala which was divided into
' Mercana, or Merana, concer&shy;
'ning onely the sacred names
'of God, and Bresith, or
' Bereseith, of other names,
'consisting of Alphabetary
'revolution, which they will
'have to be Anagrammatism,
'by which they say Mary re&shy;
'solved, made our holy Mistris .
'But whether this Cabala is 
'more ancient then the Tal&shy;
'mudical learning, hatched
'by the curious Jews (as some
'will) about 200 years after
'Christ, let the learned consi&shy;
'der. Cam. 

Arithmancy, Theomancy and
Cosmology, are said to depend
on the aforesaid Cabala,
which (to give you also Reu&shy;
clins definition of it) is no&shy;
thing else but a kind of un&shy;
written Theology; and that
therein is a much greater part
of beleef and speculation, then
of discipline. 

We use to say, he is not
of our Cabal, that is, he is
not received into our Coun&shy;
cil, or is not privy to our se&shy;
crets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cabalist(n)">Cabalist<etym lang="la"> (Cabalista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
skilful in that secret Sci&shy;
ence.</xpln></wordentry>

measure in any action or
sound. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cadent(a)">Cadent<etym lang="la"> (cadens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">falling, fai&shy;
ling, dying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caducean(a)">Caducean<etym lang="la"> (caduceus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a&shy;
mong the Romans was the
name of a wand or rod, so
called &agrave; cadendo, because at
the sight thereof all quarrels
and discords presently cea&shy;
sed, and it was carried by
their Heraulds and Embassa&shy;
dors, as an Ensign of Peace.
Peach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caelibate(a)"><emend err="Celibate">C&aelig;libate</emend><etym lang="la"> (celibatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">single
life, the state of man or woman
unmarryed. Her. H.8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cajole(v)">Cageole (Fr. <etym lang="fr">cageoler</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caduciferous(a)">Caduciferous<etym lang="la"> (caducifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calamity(n)">Calamity<etym lang="la"> (calamitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">de&shy;
struction of corn or other
thing, misery, mischief, &amp;c. Ca&shy;
lamitas (says my Lord Bacon)
was first derived from calamus 
when the corn could not get
out of the stalk. Nat: Hist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calcedon(n)">Calcedon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term used by
Jewellers and Lapidaries, as
when in Rubie especially, or
Saphire, there is a certain
<emend err="Forbe" source="errata">foul</emend> vein of somewhat a
different and most commonly
whitish colour to the other
part of the stone, that they
call a Calcedon, and it makes
the stone of less value; 


</page>

<page sig="g6r">
there is also a pretious stone
called Calcedonius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calcined(a)">Calcined<etym lang="la"> (calcinatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">burn&shy;

powder by fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calcinize(v)">To Calcinize.</form> <xpln lang="en">To burn
to ashes, to reduce metals to
powder by the fire, to re&shy;
fine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calculate(v)">Calculate<etym lang="la"> (calculo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to cast

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calcule(n)">Calcule<etym lang="la"> (calculus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an ac&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calender linen(v)">To Calender Linencloth</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calends(n)">Calends<etym lang="la"> (calend&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">proper&shy;
ly the first day of every mo&shy;
neth being spoken by it self.
If Pridie be placed before it,
then it signifies the last day of
the foregoing month, as Pri&shy;
die Calend. Maii, is the last
day of April . If any num&shy; 
ber be placed with it, it signi&shy;
fies that day in the former
month, which comes so much
before the month named; as
the tenth Calends of October,
is the twentieth day of Sep&shy;
tember; because if one begin
at October, and reckon back&shy;
wards, that twentieth day of
September, is the tenth day
before October. In March,
May, July, and October, the
Calends begin at the 26 day,
in other months at the four&shy;
teenth; which Calends must e&shy;
ver bear the name of the
month following, and be num&shy;
bred backward from the first
day of the said following
months: See more in God&shy;
win p.64 and see <xref> Ides</xref>. 

At the Greek Calends (<term lang="la">ad
Gr&aelig;cas Calendas</term>) (<expan type="">id est</expan>) never:
for the Greks have no Ca&shy;
lends.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calent(a)">Calent<etym lang="la"> (calens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hot or warm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calenture(n)">Calenture (the Span. <etym lang="sp">Ca&shy;
lentura</etym>),</form> <xpln lang="en">a burning Feaver, or
an Ague.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calidity(n)">Calidity<etym lang="la"> (caliditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">heat,
warmth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calid(a)">Calid<etym lang="la"> (calidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hot, warm,
burning, fierce and hasty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caliduct(n)">Caliduct.</form> <xpln lang="en"> Palladio observes
that the Antients did warm
their rooms, with certain se&shy;
cret Pipes, that came through
the walls, transporting heat
to sundry parts of the house,
from one common Furnace,
which Sir Hen. Wotton proper&shy;
ly calls Caliducts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caligation(n)">Caligation<etym lang="la"> (caligatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
dimness of sight, blindness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caligate(v)">Caligate<etym lang="la"> (caligatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caligate soldier(n)">ACaligate souldier<etym lang="la"> (ca&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caliph(n)">Caliph.</form> <xpln lang="en">A name or title
of Dignity or estate in &AElig;&shy;
gypt, which people of the
Mahometan Religion used to
confer on such a man, whom
they thought to be of holy
life, a great and diligent ob&shy;
server of Mahomets Law, as al&shy;
so well learned therein, grant&shy;
ing him besides, to command
with Royal Authority; At
the beginning of this Religion
all Caliphs were Kings, wit&shy;
ness Mahomet himself inven&shy; 
ter thereof, who was King of
Arabia. These Caliphs were
also a kind of High-Priests, at
whose hands the Mahumetan
Princes were wont to receive
their Diadems and Regalities.
But their Office is now execu&shy;
ted in the Turks Dominions 
by the Mufti or chief Priest
of the Saracens. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="callent(a)">Callent<etym lang="la"> (callens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">crafty,
witty, cunning, or wise by ex&shy;
perience.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="callet(n)">Callot (<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lewd wo&shy;
man. Chauc. So perhaps Cal&shy;
low may be lewd or wicked,
which Mr. Cleveland uses in
his Poems, where he speaks of
a callow curse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caltrop(n)">Caltrop
 or
Calthrop (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Chausse&shy;
trope</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;
strument used
sometime in war, made with
four pricks of Iron, of such a
fashion, as which way soever
it is thrown, one point will
always stick up like a nayl, to
spoil the enemies horse feet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Calvary(pn)" lexeme="Mount Calvary(pn)">Calvary orMount Cal&shy;
vary<etym lang="la"> (calvarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hill a lit&shy;
tle out of Hierusalem, where
the malefactors were ordina&shy;
rily executed, and where our
Saviour Christ was Crucifyed
for the Redemption of man&shy;
kinde. The Mount had the
name Calvary from the Skulls
and dead mens bones that lay
there up and down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Calvinist(pn)">Calvinist.</form> <xpln lang="en">One that holds

in matters of Religion.<xref> See

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calumniate(v)">Calumniate<etym lang="la"> (calumnior</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to accuse or charge falsly, to
cavil or detract. He that in
his accusation, forges faults
never committed, is said to
Calumniate. He that under&shy;
takes ones sute, and either
will not urge reasons in the
behalf of his Clyent, or answer 


</page>

<page sig="g7r">
the Objections of his adver&shy;
sary, when he is able, is said
to Prevaricate . <expan type="">id est</expan> to play the
false Proctor. He that de&shy;
sists in his accusation and
lets his sute fall, is said Ter&shy;
giversari . Sylv. in Orat. pro
Mur.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calumnious(a)">Calumnious<etym lang="la"> (calumniosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of cavils or false accusa&shy;
tions, slanderous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cambio(n)">Cambio (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Burse or

change in London. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cambren(n)">Cambren (<class type="etymlang" lang="br">from the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="campaign(n)">Campain (Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Campaigne</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a plain field, or a wide and
level peece of ground. A
word much used among Soul&shy;
diers, by whom the next Cam&shy;
paine is usually taken for the
next Summers Expedition
of an Army, or its taking
the field.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Campus Martius(pn)">Campus Martius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a field
near Rome, where the anci&shy;
ent Romans made use of all
manly exercises, and the peo&shy;
ple often assembled to give
their suffrages towards the
election of Magistrates, &amp;c.
It was so called, because dedi&shy;
cated to Mars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Campus Sceleratus(pn)">Campus sceleratus (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">was the place, where the
vestal Nuns, if they were de&shy;
floured, suffered punishment;
the field of execution.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Canary wine(n)">Canary wine.</form> <xpln lang="en">So called,
because it is made in Canary
Islands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cancer(n)">Cancer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a crevice, or crab,
also one of the Twelve Ce&shy;
lestial Signs, so called for
that, as the Crab retrogrades
or goes backward; So the
Sun (being in that sign about
mid- June) ascends no higher,
but recedes by degrees, and
hastens towards Capricorn .
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canon(n)">Canon (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Properly a
Rule or line to make any
thing straight, or to try the
straightness of it. Hence
Laws or Decrees for Church&shy;
Government are called Ca&shy;
nons, and certain times of
Prayer used by Church-men
are called Canonical hours of
Prayer. Bull. And we call
those Canonical books, which
are Authentical Scrip&shy;
ture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canonical(a)">Canonical<etym lang="la"> (canonicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
according to Canonicall
Rule, or Order, received
into the Canon; Authen&shy;
tical.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canonize(v)">Canonize<etym lang="la"> (canonizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
examine by rule, to Register,
to put in the rank and num&shy;
ber: also to declare and
pronounce one for a Saint.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canor(n)">Canor (Lat.<etym lang="la"> Cano</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">melo&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cantabrians(pn)">Cantabrians<etym lang="la"> (Cantabri</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantation(n)">Cantation<etym lang="la"> (cantatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sing&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantharides(n)">Cantharides (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cer&shy;
tain flyes of a bright shining
green colour, breeding in the
tops of Ash, and Olive Trees
beyond the Sea. They are
sometimes used by Physitians,
to raise blisters in the body;
but their heads, wings, and
feet must be cast away. The
juice of them is poysonous.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canticle(n)">Canticle<etym lang="la"> (canticum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a plea&shy;
sant song, a ballad, a rime.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantion(n)">Cantion<etym lang="la"> (cantio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a song or

charm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantilene(n)">Cantilene<etym lang="la"> (cantilena</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a verse,
a common speech or tale, a
song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canto(n)">Canto (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Song or
Sonnet; also as Canton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canton(n)">Canton (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&kappa;&#x1f01;&nu;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">which is a corner pro&shy;
perly of the eye; also an hun&shy;
dred, Precinct, or Circuit of
Territory, wherein there are
divers good Towns and Vil&shy;
lages: this word is proper
to Helvetia or Switzerland, 


</page>

<page sig="g8r">
which was divided or Canton&shy;
ized about the yeer of Christ
1307 into 13 such Cantons. It
is also a term in Heraldry, and
signifies as much as an Angle
or corner in a coat of Arms,
contracted thus:
It possesseth for the most
part the dexter point of the
Scotcheon, and is the reward
of a Prince given to an Earl .
Peach.</xpln>
<lemenote>
There is an image of an escutcheon in the middle of this word-entry.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantonize(v)">Cantonize.</form> <xpln lang="en">To divide
into Cantons, quarters or cor&shy;
ners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantor(n)">Cantor (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a singer or
charmer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantred(n)" lexeme="cantref(n)">Cantred or ratherCantref</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies an hundred Villages,
being a British word com&shy;
pounded of the Adjective
Cant, which signifies an hun&shy;
dred, and Tref, which signi&shy;
fies a Town or Village. In
Wales the Counties are divi&shy;
ded into Cantreds, as in En&shy;
gland into hundreds. This
word is used An.28. H. 8. c. 3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canzonet(n)">Canzonet (from the It. <etym lang="it">Can&shy;
zonetta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a song or ditty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cap-&agrave;-pie(a)">Cap-a-pe (from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">caput</etym> and <etym lang="la">pes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">from head to
foot; as when a souldier is
compleatly armed, we say he
is armed Cap-a-pe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capacity(n)" lexeme="capability(n)">Capacity 
Capability  <etym lang="la"> (capacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
aptness to
contain or receive. 

Our Common Law allows
the King two Capacities, a na&shy;
tural, and a politique; in the
first he may purchase lands to
him and his heirs, in the later
to him and his successors.
And a Parson hath the like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cape(n)">Cape (Fr. <etym lang="fr">cap</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="">(</emend> that where&shy;
of Sea-men speak in their
voyages) is some remarkable
nook or elbow of Land. that
shoots farther into the Sea,
than any other neer part of
the continent. In Spanish it
is called <term lang="sp">Cabo</term>; <expan type="">id est</expan> an end, as
who should say, the end or last
of such a Land, as <term lang="sp">Cabo de Bue&shy;
na Esperansa</term> the Cape of good
hope, first found by Vasco de
Gama a Portugal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caparison(n)">Caparison (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Caparasson</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
trapping or furniture for a
horse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capo(n)">Capi.</form> <xpln lang="en">Three chief Offi&shy;
cers among the Venetians, to
whom and to the Senate the
Dukes authority is in all
things subject. Heyl.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Predates earliest OED reference (1952).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caper(n)">Capirs.(Fr. <etym lang="fr">Cappres</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">A
prickly plant almost like
Brambles, growing in Spain,
Italy, and other hot Countries:
the root hereof is much used
in Physick, against obstructi&shy;
ons of the Spleen or Milt. The
flowers and leaves are brought
hither from Spain, preserved
in brine, and are commonly
eaten with Mutton: they stir
up the appetite, warm the
Stomach, and open the stop&shy;
pings of the Liver and Milt.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Capharnatts(pn)">Capharnatts,</form> <xpln lang="en">those of Caphar&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="g8v">
<emend err="">naum</emend> in Palestine, who first doub&shy;
ted of the mystery of the
blessed Sacrament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capital(a)">Capital<etym lang="la"> (capitalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">worthy
of death, deadly, mortal, be&shy;
longing to the head. the se&shy;
ven Capital sins are Pride, Co&shy;
vetousness, Lechery, Anger,
Gluttony, Envy and Sloath,
and are called Capital, be&shy;
cause they are heads of many
others, which proceed from
them as Rivers from their
source.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capitation(n)">Capitation<etym lang="la"> (capitatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tri&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capite(n)">Capite,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is a tenure, when a
man holds Lands immediately
of the King, as of his Crown,
be it by Knights service, or
socage. Brook Tit. Tenures 46.
94. See more of this in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Capitol(pn)">Capitol<etym lang="la"> (capitolium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an an&shy;
cient Palace in Rome, so called
from the head of a man found
there when they digged to lay
the foundation; Arnobius saith
his name was Tolus, and from
Caput and Tolus came Capitoli&shy;
um . When Brennus and his
Gauls overcame the Romans
neer the River Allia in Italy,
Rome it self was forsaken of its 
chief strength, onely the Capi&shy;
tol was manned by Manlius and
saved from the fury of the
Gauls, by the cackling of Geese
which awaked the watch, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capitulate(v)">Capitulate<etym lang="la"> (capitulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

Articles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capnomancy(n)">Capnomancy<etym lang="la"> (capnoman&shy;

on Incense or Poppy-seed is

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capouch(n)">Capouche (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Capuchon</etym>, lat.
<etym lang="la">Capitium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a coul, hood, or co&shy;
ver for the head, which Monks
and Fryers use to wear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Capouchins(pn)" lexeme="Capucines(pn)">Capouchins orCapucines,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a religious Order of Fryers so
called of their Coule or Ca&shy;
pouch, ordayned by Matthew
Basci of Ancona. Fryer Lewis
his companion obtained
of the then Pope the habit
and rule of St. Francis in the
yeer 1526. In the space of 42
yeers they encreased to 2240
associates, had 222 Monasteries
and were divided into 15 Pro&shy;
vinces. Heyl. They wear nei&shy;
ther shirts nor breeches. Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caprichio(n)">Caprichio

<etym lang="sp">Capricho</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
humor, a fancy, a toy in ones
head, a giddy thought; hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caprichious(a)">Caprichious,</form> <xpln lang="en">humorsome,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Capricorn(pn)">Capricorn<etym lang="la"> (capricornus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Goat or one of the 12 signes of
the Zodiack, so named from
the custom and nature of that
beast, for as the Goat for the 


</page>

<page sig="h1r">
most part ascends and climbs
up to the top of the steepest
hills to seek his food. So the
Sun (when (in Mid- Decem&shy;
ber) he enters the Tropick of
Capricorn) ascends our Hemi&shy;
sphere. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carbuncle(n)">Carbuncle<etym lang="la"> (carbunculus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hath
two significations, the one a
precious stone, the other a
dangerous botch or sore. <expan type="">id est</expan>
 Carbuncle stone, is bright, of the
colour of fire, and hath many
vertues, but it chiefly prevails
against the danger of infecti&shy;
ous ayr. Some call a Ruby in
perfection, a Carbuncle; others
say a Diamond of a red or fie&shy;
ry colour, is a Carbuncle. 2.
Carbuncle disease is a botch, or
ulcer, called otherwise by a
Greek name Anthrax, caused of
gross hot blood, which raiseth
blisters and burns the skin;
This Ulcer is ever accompa&shy;
nyed with a Feaver. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carceral(a)">Carceral<etym lang="la"> (carceralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="card(n)">A SeaCard<etym lang="la"> (carta marina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a kinde of Map, wherin the
whole world is described,
which Seamen use, to instruct
them in Navigations.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cardiacal(a)">Cardiacal<etym lang="la"> (cardiacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
pertaining to the heart, <emend err="cordi">cordi&shy;</emend>
al, comforting the heart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cardinal(n)">Cardinal<etym lang="la"> (cardinalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
high dignity in the Church of
Rome, whereof there are about
70 in number, and were first 


</page>

<page sig="h1v">
instituted by P. Paschal the
first. Minsh. derives the word
from <term lang="la">Cardo, inis</term>, the hook or
hinge of a dore: for as the dore
hangs or depends on the hin&shy;
ges, so the Church on the Car&shy;
dinals. The word, taken Ad&shy;
jectively, is pertaining to a
hook or hinge; also chief or
principal, the four Cardinal
Vertues are, 1 Prudence . 2 Tem&shy;
perance . 3. Justice . 4. Fortitude . So
cal'd, because they are the prin&shy;
cipal foundations of a vertu&shy;
ous well-ordered life, and as it
were the hinges on which all
other moral vertues depend;
the four principal winds, East,
West, North, and South, are al&shy;
so called Cardinal winds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cardiognostic(a)">Cardiognostick (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
knows the heart, an attribute
peculiar to God alone; Mr.
How. useth the word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carfax(pn)">Carefox.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Market place
in Oxford so called, which
may well come of the French
<etym lang="fr">Quarrefour <term lang="en">or</term> carrefour</etym>, which
signifies any place or part of a
Town, where four streets meet
at a head, as at Carfox in Ox&shy;
ford, for there is the Quarre, the
square and quadrant. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carmelites(pn)">Carmelites</form> <xpln lang="en">(had beginning
and name at and from Mount
Carmelus in Syria, where Elias
the Prophet lived long solita&shy;
ry) a strict order of Fryers in&shy;

Antioch, An. 1122. They fol&shy;
lowed St Basil and were refor&shy;
med by the vertuous Spanish
virgin St Teresa, who made
them certain constitutions
confirmed by Pope Pius the
fourth, <term lang="la"> Anno</term> 1565 Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

ful to eat flesh; It is also a

that flesh which is given the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carnoggin(n)">Carnogan (<class type="etymlang" lang="br">Brit.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carol(n)">Caroll,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Christmas song,
or Hymn in honor of our Sa&shy;
viours birth, it comes from
<term lang="la"> Cantare</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to sing, and Rola
an interjection expressing
joy; for heretofore in the
burden of delightful songs,
and when men were jocund,
they were wont to sing Rola,
Rola, as sometimes they now
do,Hey down,derry derry.
It was an ancient custom a&shy;
mong the Christians in their
Feasts, to bring every one into
the midst, and incite him to sing
unto God, as well as he could,
either out of the Holy Scriptures,
or of his own wit and invention .
Tertul. lib. adversus gentes,
cap.39.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carouse(n)">Carous,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="gr">Gar</etym> <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">in the old
Teutonick</class> signified all, and
<etym lang="gr">ans</etym>, out; so that to drink
<emend err="Garans" source="errata">Garaus</emend>, is to drink all out,
hence by corruption, to drink
<emend err="Carans" source="errata">Garaus</emend> . and now we say to
Carous it, <expan type="">id est</expan> to drink all
out. Ver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carpatian Sea(pn)">Carpatian-Sea (so called
from an adjacent Island cal&shy;
led Carpathos now Scarpanto)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Sea lying between Rhodes,
and Crete.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carpocratians(pn)">Carpocratians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of
Hereticks so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carat(n)">Carrat (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Carat</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a&shy;
mong Goldsmiths and Myn&shy;
men is the third part of an
ounce; among Jewellers or
Stone-cutters, but the 192
part, for eight of them make 
but one sterlin, and a sterlin
is the four and twentieth
part of an ounce. Three grains
of Assize, or four grains of
Diamond, which make a
Carrat. A fool of twenty five
carrats, is an egregious fool,
a fool beyond all proportion;
the finest gold being but of
four and twenty carrats.
Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carrack(n)">Carrick 
Carrack</form> <xpln lang="en">a ship of a great
burthen, so cal&shy;
led of the Italian word <etym lang="it">Car&shy;
rico</etym>, <term lang="en">or</term> Carco, a burthen or
charge; you have this word,
An.2.<expan type="">read</expan>3 ca.4. and Jac.
ca.33.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="career(n)">Carriere (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the ring or
circle where they run with
great horses, also their course
or full speed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cartel(n)">Cartel (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Letter of de&shy;
fiance, or a chalenge for a
(single) Combate. <expan type="">Lord</expan> Her&shy;
bert uses it often in his
Hen. 8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carthusians(pn)">Carthusians,</form> <xpln lang="en">A religious
order of Monks, instituted
by St. Bruno, a native of Col&shy;
lein, who being a Parisian
Doctor of Divinity, and a
Canon of Rheims, abando&shy;
ned the world, and with six
associats began his austere
Heremitical course of life, on
the Carthusian Mountains, in
the Diocess of Gratianopolis,
with the licence of Hugh then
Bishop thereof; and from
thence his Order took the
name of Cathusians he flou&shy;
rished in the time of Pope
Urban the second, and dyed 


</page>

<page sig="h2v">
<term lang="la">Anno</term> 1101. Those of his rule
have at this day near 100
Monasteries; they eat no
flesh, never meet but on Sun&shy;
daies, labor with their hands,
watch, pray, &amp;c. their
robe is white, with a short
cape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cartilage(n)">Cartilage<etym lang="la"> (cartilago</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
gristle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cartilagineous(a)">Cartilagineous<etym lang="la"> (cartilagi&shy;
neus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of a gristle or full of
gristles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carrucata terrae(n)">Carrucata terr&aelig;,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a word
much used in the ancient
Charters, and <emend err="Land-eviden'">Land-eviden&shy;</emend>
ces of this Nation, and signi&shy;
fies as much land as may be til&shy;
led in a year by one Plough;
It is also called in the ancient
Laws Hildavel Hida terr&aelig;, now
a Plough-land. Carrucata is <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">a
corruption from the French
word</class> <etym lang="fr">Charru&euml;</etym>, a Plough.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cartouche(n)">Cartouche (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a charge
of powder and shot ready
made up in a paper; we cor&shy;
ruptly call it a cartage . Also a
roll in Architecture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carvel(n)">Carvel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caspian Sea(pn)">Caspian Sea<etym lang="la"> (mare Caspi&shy; 
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sea near Hyrcania, that
hath no passage into any other
Sea, but is a huge Lake,
and neither ebbs nor flows.
Therefore Sr. Philip Sidney
(to note, that he persisted
alwaies one) depainteth out
this Sea surrounded with
his Shoars, and over it this
motto <term lang="la">Sine refluxu</term>, for his De&shy;
vise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="case-mate(v)">Case-Mate (Fr. <etym lang="fr">chas&shy;
mate</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a loop-hole in a for&shy; 
tified wall to shoot out at,
or in fortification, a place in a
ditch, out of which to plague
the assailants. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cassation(n)">Cassation (from <etym lang="la">casso</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
quashing, annulling, or making
void.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Castalian well(pn)">Castalian-Wel;</form> <xpln lang="en">a foun&shy;
tain at the foot of Parnassus,
sacred to the Muses; taking
name of Castalia a Virgin, who 
(as Poets fain) flying from
the leacherous god Apollo, fell
down headlong, and was tur&shy;
ned into this fountain.
Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="castifical(a)">Castifical<etym lang="la"> (castificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mak&shy;

nent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="castrate(v)">Castrate<etym lang="la"> (castro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to geld,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="castleward(n)">Castleward.</form> <xpln lang="en">Is an imposi&shy;
tion laid upon such of the
Kings Subjects, as dwell with&shy;
in a certain compass of any
Castle, towards the main&shy;
tenance of such as watch and
ward the Castle, Magna Char.
ca.20. and an.32. H.8. ca.
48. 

It is used sometimes for
the very circuit it self,
which is inhabited by such
as are subject to this ser&shy;
vice, as in Stows annals, pag.
632.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casuist(n)">Casuist (from <etym lang="la">casus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that writes, or is well seen in
cases of conscience.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casule(n)">Casule, or Planet<etym lang="la"> casula</etym>)</form> 


</page>

<page sig="h3r">
<xpln lang="en">one of those attires where&shy;
with the Priest is vested, when
he says Mass, resembling the
purple robe of derision, which
the Souldiers put on our Sa&shy;
vior, saying Hail King of the
Jews. Tr. of Ma.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cata-baptist(pn)">Cata-baptist (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
abuseth or depraveth, or is an
adversary to the Sacrament
of Baptism, A Catabaptist
may sometimes be no Anabap&shy;
tist, such was Leo Capronymus,
who defiled the Font at his
Baptism, yet was not christe&shy;
ned again, but every Anabap&shy;
tist is necessarily a Catabaptist,
for the iteration of that
Sacrament is an abuse and
pollution of it. Dippers dipt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catachrestical(a)" lexeme="catachrestic(a)">Catachrestical 
Catachrestique (from <etym lang="la">ca&shy; 
tachresis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
abusive, as when one word is
improperly put for another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cataclysm(n)">Cataclysm<etym lang="la"> (cataclysmus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

great showre of rain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catadrome(n)">Catadrome<etym lang="la"> (catadromys</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

horses, for prize; a Tilt-yard.
An Engine which builders
use like a Crane, in lift&shy;
ing up or putting down any
great weight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chattels(n)">Catals 
Chatels</form> <xpln lang="en">In our Com&shy;
mon Law it 
comprehends all goods mo&shy;
vable and immoveable, <emend err="bu">but</emend>
such as are in the nature of
a Free-hold or parcel thereof.
Howbeit Kitchin chap. Cat.
fol.32. saith, That ready money
is not acconnted any goods,
or Chattels, nor Hawks, nor
Hounds. See more in Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catalepsy(n)">Catalepsie<etym lang="la"> (catalepsis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">oc&shy;
cupation, deprehension,
knowledge: Also a disease
in the head, occasioned
by distemper of the brain.</xpln></wordentry>

dio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to put one to open

some notorious offence, to
scorn, to defame. ka me, ka thee.</xpln></wordentry>

ry to nature, a Ganemede .

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catapult(n)">Catapult<etym lang="la"> (catapulta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
ancient warlike engine to
shoot Darts, or great Arrows
a far off, and by this name
was called not onely the in&shy;
strument it self, but the arrow
or whatsoever was shot out
of it, as Turneb. writes in his
15. Advers. cap. I. This En&shy;
gine was also called Balista.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cataphrygians(pn)">Cataphrygians,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Sect.
of damnable Hereticks that
lived in the time of Pope So&shy;
ter, and the Emperor Com&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="h3v">
modus about the year of
Christ 181. they bore that
name, because their Arch-lea&shy;
ders, Montanus and Apelles
were of the Country Phrygia;
they erred about Baptism,
rejecting the form that
Christ and his Apostles used,
they baptized their dead,
held two Marriages as bad
as fornications, with other
wicked Tenets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cataplasm(n)">Cataplasm<etym lang="la"> (cataplasma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pro&shy;
perly a medicine or poultis
made of divers hearbs either
bruised or boyled in water,
and so applyed outwardly to
the body: if theere be oyl ad&shy;
ded after the decotion it is
not then called a Cataplasm,
but an Emplaister . Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cataract(n)">Cataract<etym lang="la"> (cataracta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port&shy;
cullis, a great fall of water
from an high place, also a
distillation of humors out of
the eves, A Floodgate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catarrh(n)">Catarrhe<etym lang="la"> (catarrhus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Rhewm or distillation of
waterish humors out of the
head into the mouth, throat,
or eyes, caused by a cold, and
sometimes hot distemperature
of the brain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catastasis(n)">Catastasis (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the third
part of a Comedy, and signi&shy;
fies the state and full vigour
of it. Tragedies and Come&shy;
dies have four principal parts
in respect of the matter trea&shy;
ted of, 1. Protasis . 2 Epita&shy;
sis . 3. Catastasis .4. Catastro&shy;
phe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catastrophe(n)">Catastrophe (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sub&shy;
version, the ends, or last part 
of a Comedy or any other
thing: a sudden alteration,
the conclusion or shutting up
a matter, or the inclination
unto the end, as <term lang="la">Vit&aelig; human&aelig;
catastrophe</term>, the end of a mans
life.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catechetical(a)">Catechetical (from <etym lang="la">cate&shy;
chesis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to an In&shy;

book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="category(n)">Category<etym lang="la"> (categoria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pro&shy;
perly an accusation. It is also
a tearm used in Logick, and
is the same with predicament.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="categorical(a)">Categorical<etym lang="la"> (categoricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

solved on. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catenate(v)">Catenate<etym lang="la"> (cateno</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to link,
chain or tie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catharians(pn)">Catharians,</form> <xpln lang="en">were a branch
of the Novatian Hereticks
that lived in the third age
after Christ. They took the
name Cathari from the Greek
word <etym lang="gk">&kappa;&alpha;&delta;&alpha;&rho;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym> (which sig&shy;
nigies clean or pure) by rea&shy;
son of the cleanness and pu&shy;
rity they challenged to them&shy;
selves, saying, they were al&shy;
together pure from sin, and
therefore omitted that clause
in the Lords Prayer, Forgive
us our Trespasses, as we forgive,
&amp;c. they denied original sin, 


</page>

<page sig="h4r">
and the necessity of Bap&shy;
tism, with other Heretical
doctrines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catharists(pn)">Catharists (so called <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from
the Gr</class> <etym lang="gk">&kappa;&alpha;&delta;&alpha;&#x03af;&rho;&alpha;</etym>i. to purge, from
certain execrable cleansings
or purgings which they used)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a branch of the Manichean He&shy;
reticks, that appeared first to
the world in the time of Pope
Felix the first, and of Aureli&shy;
an the Emperor, about the
year of Christ 279. They re&shy;
jected the Sacraments of the
Church, held oathes to be un&shy;
lawful, and forbidden Chri&shy;
stians in all cases, &amp;c. with o&shy;
ther such mad positions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cathedral(a)">Cathedral (from <etym lang="la">cathedra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to a chair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cathedral church(n)">Cathedral Church,</form> <xpln lang="en">so cal&shy;
led from the Bishops chair
in every such Church; what&shy;
soever City gives title to a Bi&shy;
shop, there onely is a Cathe&shy;
dral Church, as at York, Wor&shy;
cester, Hereford, &amp;c. but none
at Shrewsbury, Northampton,
&amp;c. See <xref>Parish</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cathartic(n)">Catharticke<etym lang="la"> (catharticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
purgative, or evacuative, a
purging medicine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catholicism(n)">Catholicisme<etym lang="la"> (catholicis&shy; 
mus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">generality or universa&shy;
lity, or the Orthodox Faith
of the Catholick Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catholicon(n)">Catholicon (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
composition in Physick, so
termed, because it purgeth all
kind of humors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catholic king(n)">Catholick king,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Title
peculiar to the King of Spain,
as most Christian, to France;
and Defender of the Faith, to
England 
Alphonso the first of Oviedo
was so named for his sanctity;
with him this title dyed, and
was revived in Alphonso the
great, the twelfth of Leon,
and Oviedo, by the Grant
of Pope John the eighth:
after it lay dead till the days
of Ferdinand the great, who
re-obtained this Title from
Pope Alexander the sixth, be&shy;
cause he procured the Moors
to be baptized, banished the
Jews, and in part converted
the Americans to Christia&shy;
nity. Hist of Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catoptic(n)">Catopticks</form> <xpln lang="en">professors of
the Opticks, or art specula&shy;
tive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catoptiomancy(n)">Catoptiomancy<etym lang="la"> (catoptio&shy;
mantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">divination by vision
in a glass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cavalier(n)">Cavalier ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)

of Gen&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caviare(n)" lexeme="icary(n)">Caveary orIckary,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
strange meat like black Soap,
made upon the River Volgha
in Russia, out of a fish called
Bellongina, the Sturgeon, the
Severiga, and the Sterledey,
and thence transported to
England, and other Countries,
2. part of Treas. &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caveat(n)">Caveat (from <etym lang="la">caveo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">let
him take heed, but it is com&shy;
monly used for a substantive,
for a warning or admonition;
And so <expan type="">it is</expan> used among the 


</page>

<page sig="h4v">
Proctors, when a person is
dead, and a competition a&shy;
riseth for the Executorship,
or Administratorship, the
party concerned enters a
Caveat, to prevent or ad&shy;
monish others from intermed&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="causidic(a)">Causidick<etym lang="la"> (causidicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caustic(a)">Caustick<etym lang="la"> (causticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">apt to
burn or scald; also a medi&shy;
cine that burneth, and is u&shy;
sed when a disease cannot
otherwise bee mastered.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cautel(n)">Cautele<etym lang="la"> (cautela</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a provisi&shy;
on, or taking heed, an assu&shy;
rance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cautelous(a)">Cautelous (from <etym lang="la">cautela</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
circumspect, wary, advi&shy;
sed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cautery(n)">Cauterie<etym lang="la"> (cauterium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hot
iron, or searing iron, which
is by Physitians called an
actual Cauterie, and a po&shy;
tential Cauterie is that which
is without fire and iron, but
hath partly like strength, as
Unguentum Egyptiacum,  &amp;c<emend err=",">.</emend></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cauterism(n)">Cauterism<etym lang="la"> (cauterismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a cutting, burning, or searing
the body for an inflammation
or swelling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cauterize(v)">Cauterize<etym lang="la"> (cauterizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
burn, stop up, or sear with
hot irons, oyntments or me&shy;
dicines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cautional(a)" lexeme="cautionary(a)">Cautional 
Cautionary  (<etym lang="la">cautionalis</etym>) </form><xpln lang="en">
pertaining to
caution, pledge, or wari&shy;
ness.

<term lang="en">Cautionary</term>, or pledge Towns,
are such as are pawned or
given as an assurance for mo&shy;
ney, or fulfilling of Covenants
or Articles agreed on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cautor(n)">Cautor (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that fore&shy;
seeth, or bewareth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quire(n)">Cayer (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a quire of
written paper, a peece of a
written book, divided into
equal parts. M. How in his Lust.
Ludov.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="celestify(v)">To Celestify (from <etym lang="la">c&aelig;le&shy;

venly or excellent. Vul. Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Celestines(pn)">Celestines.</form> <xpln lang="en">An order of
Fryers, instituted by one Pe&shy;
ter a Samnite, born in the
yeer 1215. He always wore
a chain of Iron next his flesh,
and over that a shirt of hair.
Pope Gregory the eleventh
confirmed this Rule: they
follow St. Bennet, and took
name from the said Peter, who
for his Sanctity was chosen
Pope, and called Celestine the
fifth. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="celsity(n)" lexeme="celsitude(n)">Celsity 
Celsitude <etym lang="la"> (celsitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lofti&shy;
ness, excellen&shy; 
cy, haughtiness, nobleness,
highness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="celostomy(n)">Celostomy<etym lang="la"> (c&oelig;lostomia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">when
one speaks hollow in the
mouth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Celt(pn)">Celt<etym lang="la"> (celta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one born in
Gaul, a part of France.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Celtic(a)">Celtique<etym lang="la"> (celticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cement(n)">Cement orCiment<etym lang="la"> (c&aelig;men&shy;
tum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a strong and cleaving
Morter, made for the most
part of Tiles, Potsheards,
Glass, Flint, dross of Iron,
&amp;c. beaten all to dust, and
incorporated with Lyme,
Oyl, Grease, Rozen and Wa&shy;
ter. Min. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cemented(a)">Cemented,</form> <xpln lang="en">made or wrought
with such Morter, souldred or
pieced together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cemetery(n)">Cemetery (Lat. <etym lang="la">C&oelig;mete&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cenatical(a)" lexeme="cenatory(a)">Cenatical

</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cenotaph(n)">Cenotaph<etym lang="la"> (cenotaphium,

non est  Brisonius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a monument
or representation in the

do at the month or yeers end,	
called a Hearse, an empty
Tomb erected in memory of
the dead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cene(n)">Cene<etym lang="la"> (c&oelig;na</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Supper or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cenosity(n)">Cenosity<etym lang="la"> (c&aelig;nositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">foul&shy;
