physical term
signifying any medicine for
the eyes, most commonly ap&shy;
plied in a liquid form.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colobe(a)">Colobe (<etym lang="la">colobium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coat
with half sleeves, coming but
to the knees, used by the An&shy;
cients, and changed after&shy;
wards into the Dalmatica.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Coloieros(pn)">Coloieros,</form> <xpln lang="en">A sort of Gre&shy;
cian Monks and Nuns, so
called, whereof you may read
in Mr. Sand' s Travels, pag.
81,82.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colon(n)">Colon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mark com&shy;
monly used in the middle of
a sentence, and is made with
two pricks thus (:)</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colony(n)">Colonie (<etym lang="la">colonia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">The
Romans (when their City
was too full of inhabitants)
used to with-draw a certain
number to dwell in some
other place, which number
so withdrawn, as also the
place to which they were sent
was, and stil is called by this
name; Also a Grange or Farm,
where husbandry is kept.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coloquintida(n)">Coloquintida,</form> <xpln lang="en">A kind
of wild Gourd, which the
Persians name, Gal of the
earth, because it destroys all
hearbs near which it grows.
It is often used in Phy&shy;
sick, to purge slimy gross 


</page>

<page sig="k1v">
humors from the sinews and
joynts. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colosse(n)">Colosse (<etym lang="la">colossus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a great
Image or Statue made for the
honor of any person, as in
Rhodes there was one 70 Cu&shy;
bits high, made by Chares of
Lindum in twelve yeers space,
to the honor of the Sun. This
Colossus was made in the Image
of a man, the Thumb of
which few men can fathom.
The brass of this Statua was
so much, that when Mnani,
General of Caliph Osman, u&shy;
nited Rhodes to the Mahume&shy;
tan Empire, it loaded 900 Ca&shy;
mels. Heyl. We read also
of a Statue of Nero which was
a hundred foot high. But a&shy;
bove all, that of Mercury made
at Auvergne containing four
hundred foot in height, and
of inestimable value. 2 part
Treasury.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colostration(n)">Colostration (<etym lang="la">colostratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
disease or indisposition in the
stomack of young ones, cau&shy;
sed by sucking the <emend err="breastings">Beestings</emend>
or first Milk that comes from
the Teat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colubriferous(a)">Colubriferous (<etym lang="la">colubrifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears or brings forth
Snakes or Serpents.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="columbary(n)">AColumbary (<etym lang="la">columbari&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pigeon-house or Cul&shy;
ver hole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="columbine(a)">Columbine (<etym lang="la">columbinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Dove-like, pertaining to a
Dove or Pigeon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="columity(n)">Columity (<etym lang="la">columitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
safety, soundness, health.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="column(n)">Column (<etym lang="la">columna</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a round
Pillar or Post: Also when 
a page or side of a leaf writ&shy;
ten or Printed, is divided in&shy;
to two or more parts along
the Paper, as this page is di&shy;
vided into two, those parts or
divisions are called Columns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="columnary(n)">Columnary Tribute (<etym lang="la">co&shy;
lumnarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tribute that was
exacted for every Pillar that
held up the house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colure(n)">Colures (<etym lang="la">coluri</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">two great
moveable Circles, passing <emend err="tho">tho&shy;</emend>
row both the Poles of the
world, crossing one another
with right spherical Angles:
so that like an Apple cut in&shy;
to four quarters, they divide
the whole sphear into equal
parts: the one passeth through
the Equinoctial points and
Poles of the world, and is cal&shy;
led the Equinoctial Colure :
The other passeth through the
Solstitial points, and is called
the Solistitial Colure . Peacham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Comald(pn)">Comald</form> <xpln lang="en">A strict Order of
Fryers begun in Italy, Ann.
1012 by Romoald of Ravenna;
their first Monastery was
built neer Arezzo in the
Dutchy of Florence, by one
Comald, hence the name:
their Robe is white, they
follow the rule of St. Bene&shy;
dict. Grimston.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Comarch(n)">Comarck (<etym lang="la">comarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Earl, a Governor of a Town
or City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="combination(n)">Combination (<etym lang="la">combinatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a coupling together, a set&shy;
ing together in Order: but
it is most commonly taken
for a practise between two
or more for some evil end.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="k2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="combustion(n)"><emend err="Combnstion">Combustion</emend> (<etym lang="la">combustio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a burning, or consuming with
fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="combustible(a)">Combustible (<etym lang="la">combustibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
soon fired, easie to be burn&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comedy(n)">Comedy (<etym lang="la">com&oelig;dia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Play
or interlude. It is a kind of
fable representing, as in a
Mirror, the similitude of a
civil and private life, begin&shy;
ing for the most part with
some troubles, but ending
with Agreement or joy. These
Plays are called Com&oelig;di&aelig; from
<etym lang="gk"> &Kappa;&#x1ff6;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, which signifies Villa&shy;
ges, because Com&oelig;dians did go
up and down the Country,
acting these Com&oelig;dies in the
Villages, as they passed along.
Godwin.<xref lexeme="tragedy"> See Tragedy</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comediographer(n)">Comediographer (<etym lang="la">com&oelig;di&shy;
ographus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Comical Poet, or
writer of Comedies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comessation(n)">Comessation (<etym lang="la">comessatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
late supper, inordinate or rio&shy;
tous eating; Iohannes Tislinus
saith, it is a Bever taken af&shy;
ter supper, or a night drink&shy;
ing. Mr. How. in his second
Volumn of Letters, fol.48.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comestion(n)">Comestion (<etym lang="la">comestio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
eating or devouring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comestible(a)">Comestible (from <etym lang="la">comedo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
eatable, fit to be eaten. Sir
H. W.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comet(n)">Comet (<etym lang="la">cometa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a blazing
star. It is properly a great
quantity of exhalations hot
and dry, fat and clammy, hard
compact like a great lump of
pitch, which by the heat
and attractive vertue of the
Sun and Stars, is drawn 
up from the earth into the
highest Region of the Ayr,
where being neer the Ele&shy;
ment of fire, it is enflamed,
and appears like a Star with a
blazing tayl, and sometime
is moved after the motion of
the Ayr, which is Circular,
but it never goes down out
of the Compass of sight,
(though it be not seen in the
day time for the brightness
of the Sun) but still burns
till all the matter be consu&shy;
med. Goodly Gallery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comical(a)">Comical (<etym lang="la">comicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to, or which is hand&shy;
led in Comedies : also plea&shy;
sant or merry. The Anci&shy;
ent Grecians and Romans
had four sorts of Stage-Plays,
viz. Mimical, Satyrical,
Tragical, and Comical . Of
which see more in Mr. God&shy;
wins Anthologie, chap. de Lud&shy;
dis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cominus-pugnator(n)">ACominus-pugnator. 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that fights neer
at hand, or hand to hand.
Lo. Brook.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comity(n)">Comity (<etym lang="la">comitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gen&shy;
tleness, courtesie, mild&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comitial(a)">Comitial (<etym lang="la">comitialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to an Assembly of
people convened for the
chusing Officers or making
Laws. Among the Ancient
Romans, if any of the people
assembled were taken with
the falling sickness, the
whole Assembly or Comitium 
was dissolved; hence the
Falling sickness is at this 


</page>

<page sig="k2v">
day called Morbus Comitialis,
or the Comitial evil. God&shy;
win.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comma(n)">Comma ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the least
note of distinction, or a point
in the part of a Sentence
without perfect sense, and is
made thus <emend err="(.)" source="errata">(,)</emend></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commaculate(v)">Commaculate (<etym lang="la">commaculo </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

stain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commeator(n)">Commeator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one

ber</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commendaces(n)">Commendaces ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Fu&shy;
neral Orations, Prayers
made for the dead; Verses
made in praise of the dead.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commendam(n)">Commendam (<etym lang="la">commenda </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is, when a Benefice (being
void) is commended to the
charge and care of some suf&shy;
ficient Clerk, to be supply&shy;
ed, till it may be convenient&shy;
ly provided of a Pastor. In
which case we use to say,
such a one hath it in Commen&shy;
dam. And that this was
the true Original of this
practise, you may read at
large in <term lang="la"> Duarenus de Sacris
Ecclesie Ministeriis &amp; benefi&shy;
ciis l.5. c.7.</term></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commensal(a)">Commensal (<etym lang="la">commensalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Table-companion. Doctor
Kellison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commensurability(n)">Commensurability (<etym lang="la">com&shy;
mensurabilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an equal pro&shy;
portion or measure of one
thing with another. A joynt 
measuring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comment(n)" lexeme="commentary(n)">Comment 
Commentary (<etym lang="la">commen&shy;
mentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an abridgement, an Expositi&shy;
on, a Book of Notes and Re&shy;
membrances. The nature of
Commentaries is properly to
set down a naked continu&shy;
ance of the events and acti&shy;
ons, without the Motives and
Designs, the Councils, Speech&shy;
es, Occasions and Pretexts,
with other passages: so that
C&aelig;sar modestly rather then
truely, applyed the name Com&shy;
mentary to the best history in
the world. Heyl. Comment
sometimes signifies a fiction
or lye.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commigration(n)">Commigration (<etym lang="la">commigra&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a flitting or going from
one place to another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commilito(n)">Commilitone (<etym lang="la">commilito,
onis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fellow souldier, a
Camerade.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commination(n)">Commination (<etym lang="la">comminatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a vehement or extream threat&shy;
ning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comminuible(a)">Comminuible (from <etym lang="la">com&shy;
minuo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that may be broken in
pieces or bruised. Vul. Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commissary(n)">Commissary (<etym lang="la">commissarius</etym>)</form> 
<xpln lang="en"> a title of Ecclesiastical Juris&shy;
diction, ordained to this speci&shy;
al end, to supply the Bishops
jurisdiction and Office in the
out-places of the Diocess, or 


</page>

<page sig="k3r">
else in such Parishes as were
peculiar to the Bishop, and
exempted from the jurisdicti&shy;
on of the Arch-Deacon; for
where either by prescription
or composition, there are
Arch-Deacons, that have Ju&shy;
risdiction within their <emend err="Arch">Arch&shy;</emend>
Deaconries, as in most places
they have, there this Com&shy;
missary is but superfluous.
Cow. 

Commissary is also an Officer
in War, whose Function is
to look that the Provision
and Victuals provided for the
Army and Garrisons be just&shy;
ly distributed and disposed.
Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commissure(n)">Commissure (<etym lang="la">commissura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a joynt of any thing closed
and opened, a conjunction, a
joyning, joyning close or
couching things together.
Sir Hen. Wotton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="committee(n)">Committee,</form> <xpln lang="en">is he or they
to whom the consideration or
ordering of any matter is re&shy;
ferred, either by some Court
or consent of parties, to
whom it belongs. As in
Parliament, a Bill being read,
is either consented to and pas&shy;
sed, or denyed, or neither of
both, but referred to the con&shy;
sideration of some certain
men, appointed by the house,
farther to examine it, who
thereupon are called Com&shy;
mittees. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commorance(n)" lexeme="commoration(n)">Commorance 
Commoration (<etym lang="la">commora&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
abiding or dwelling in a place
together, a lingring: Also a 
figure, when one tarries long
upon a matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commotion(n)">Commotion (<etym lang="la">commotio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commot(n)">Commotes,</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in
Wales a part of a Shire, as a
Hundred An 28. H.8 c.3. It is
written Commoithes An.1. H.4. 
c.17. and is used for a gather&shy;
ing made upon the people (as
it seems) of this or that hun&shy;
dred, by the Welsh men. Min.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="k3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compartition(n)" lexeme="compartement(n)">Compartitionor<emend err="Compar">Compar&shy;</emend>
tement (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Compartiment</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a square Table or piece in
building, especially of stone;
also a Bed or Border in a
Garden; a partition, or e&shy;
qual division. By Comparti&shy;
tion, Architects understand a
graceful and useful distributi&shy;
on of the whole ground-plot,
both for rooms of Office, and
of Reception or entertain&shy;
ment, as far as the capacity
thereof and the nature of the
Country will comport. Sir
H. Wotton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compass(n)">SeaCompass (<etym lang="la">pyxis Nauti&shy;
ca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Instrument which
Marriners use for their directi&shy;
on in Navigation; the Needle
whereof (being in manner
of a Flower de Luce) always
points towards the North.
About the yeer 1300 one Fla&shy;
vio of Melphi in Naples,
found out the Sea-Compass,
consisting of eight winds
onely, the four principal, and
four collateral; and not long
after, the people of Bruges
and Antwerp perfected that
excellent invention, adding
24 other subordinate winds or
points. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compatible(a)">Compatible (from <etym lang="la"><emend err="compati">compati&shy;</emend>
or</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that can abide, agree, or
suffer together; concurrable,
that can indure or bear with
one another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compatriot(n)">Compatriot (<etym lang="la">compatriota</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that is of the same Country.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compter(n)">Compter  (from the Lat.
 <etym lang="la">Compar</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a fellow, an
equal, a consort, a fellow in 
Peerage. But taken from the
Latin <etym lang="la"> Compater</etym>, it is a word
by which the Father of a
child calls his Gossips, wit&shy;
nesses or Godfathers of his
child, and it may be read in
significations somewhat diffe&shy;
rent from these expressed.
In the Isle of Zacynthus or
Zant they have a custom at
Weddings to invite many
young men, whom they call
Compeers, of which every one
gives the Bride a Ring; which
done, it is there held an abuse
as detestable as Incest, to ac&shy;
company her in any carnal
kind: wherefore they choose
such for Compeers, as have for&shy;
merly been suspected of too
much familiarity. Sands.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compellation(n)">Compellation (<etym lang="la">compellatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a blaming or reproving; a
calling by names, or naming
with disgrace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compendious(a)">Compendious (<etym lang="la">compendio&shy;
sus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">very profitable, very

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comperage(n)">Comperage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Gos&shy;
siping; the affinity or friend&shy;
ship gotten by christen&shy;
ing of Children together.
Cotgr.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED except in cross-reference at "comp&egrave;re, n.".

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compromize(v)">Compromize (<etym lang="la">compromissum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a mutual promise of two
or more parties at difference,
to refer the ending their
controversies to the arbitre&shy;
ment and equity of one or
more Arbitrators. West in
the second part of his Symbo&shy;
lography under the title of
 Compromise Sect. I. defines it
thus, A Compromise is the 


</page>

<page sig="k4v">
faculty or power of pro&shy;
nouncing sentence between
persons at variance, given to
Arbitrators by the parties
mutuall private consent,
without publick Authori&shy;
ty.</xpln></wordentry>

very agreement between
parties that intend the levy&shy;

pass. See more of it in Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="concords(n)">Concords,</form> <xpln lang="en">In Musick,
which are Perfect or semi&shy;
perfect, between the unison
and the Diapason, are, the
fifth, which is most perfect,
the third next, and the
sixth which is more harsh,
and the fourth which is cal&shy;
led Diatessaron . Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

together: Also a term in
Logick, signifying a sub&shy;
ject and an accident joyned
together, as for example, Al&shy;
bum is a Concrete, signifying a
subject (be it a man or a horse)
and the accident Albedo or
whiteness joyned together,
And Albedo or whiteness 
by it self is termed the ab&shy;
stract of that Concrete.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="concubinage(n)">Concubinage (<etym lang="la">concubina&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the keeping a Whore
for his own filthy use, an
unlawful use of another wo&shy;
man instead of ones wife:
In our common Law, it
is an exception against her
that sues for her Dowry,
whereby it is alleadged, that
she was not a Wife lawful&shy;
ly married to the party, in
whose lands she seeks to be
endowed, but his Concubine.
Britton ca.107. Brac. l.4. Tract.
6. ca.8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conder(n)">Conders (may seem to
come <class type="etymlang" lang="la">of the Latin</class> <etym lang="la">condu&shy;
cere</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to conduct or lead)</form> <xpln lang="en">
are such as stand on high pla&shy;
ces near the Sea coast, at the
time of Herring fishing, to
make signs with Boughes, or
such like in their hands,
to the Fishers, which way
the Shole of Herrings passeth;
For that may better appear
to such as stand upon some
high Cliff on the shoar, by a
kind of blew colour, that the
said Shole makes in the wa&shy;
ter, then to those that are in
the ships : These are other&shy;
wise called Huers and Balkers,
as appears by the Stat. An. I.
Jac. ca.23.</xpln></wordentry>

course together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="confarreation(n)">Confarreation (<etym lang="la">confarrea&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a solemnizing of a Mar&shy;
riage, a ceremony used at the
solemnization of a marriage,
in token of most firm con&shy;
junction between man and
Wife, with a Cake of Wheat
or Barly: This ceremony is
still retained in part with us,
by that which we call the
Bride-Cake, used at many
Weddings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="confarreated(a)">Confarreated (<etym lang="la">confarrea&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="confiscate(v)">Confiscate, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Lat.</class>
<etym lang="la">confisco</etym>, and that (with the
<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">confisquer</etym>) from Fiscus,
which originally signifies, a
Hamper, Pannier, Basket,
or Freil:</form> <xpln lang="en">But metonymical&shy;
ly, the Emperors Treasure,
because it was anciently kept
in such Hampers: And
though our Kings kept not
their treasure in such things,
yet, as the Romans said, that
such goods as were forfeited
to the Emperors Treasury for
any offence, were bona con&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="k6v">
fiscata : so we say, those that
are forfeited to our Exche&shy;
quer, are confiscated. See more
of Goods confiscate in Stawnf.
Pl. Cor. l.3. ca.24.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conge d'&eacute;lire(n)">Conge d'eslire (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> leave
to choose)</form> <xpln lang="en">It is a meer
French word, and signifies
in our common Law the King;
permission royal to a Dean
and Chapter in time of vaca&shy;
tion to chuse a Bishop, or to
an Abbey or Priory to chuse
their Abbot or Prior. Fitz.
nat. br. fo.169. b, c, &amp;c.
See Cowel.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "congee".
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="congeniality(n)">Congeniality,</form> <xpln lang="en">A likeness

ther; As Sir Hen. Wotton
saies Poets and Painters have
alwaies had a kind of conge&shy;
niality. p.254.</xpln></wordentry>

Conjunction; a sentence

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conjuration(n)">Conjuration (<etym lang="la">conjuratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
as it is compounded of (<etym lang="la">Con</etym>
and <etym lang="la">juro</etym>) signifies a compact
or plot made by persons com&shy;
bining themselves together
by Oath or Promise to do
some publick harm. But in
our common Law it is used e&shy;
specially for such as have per&shy;
sonal conference with the Di&shy;
vel or evil spirit, to know
any secret, or to effect any
purpose. An.5. Eliz. ca.16.
And the difference between
Conjuration and Witchcraft is,
that the Conjurer seems by
prayers and invocation of
Gods powerful names, to
compel the Devil to say or
do what he commands him:
The Witch deals rather by a
friendly and voluntary con&shy;
ference or agreement between
him or her, &amp; the Devil or Fa&shy;
miliar, to have his or her turn
served for soul, blood, or other 
gift offered him: So that a
Conjurer compacts for curio&shy;
sity to know secrets, and
work marvels; and the
Witch of meer malice to do
mischief. And both these
differ from Inchanters, or Sor&shy;
cerers, because the former two
have personal conference
with the Devil, and the other
meddle but with Medicines,
&amp; ceremonial forms of words
called Charmes, without
apparition. Minshew, and
Daltons J. P.279.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cognizor(a)">Conizor orCognizor
(<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">cognitor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in Law it is u&shy;
sed in the passing of Fines for
him that acknowledges the
Fine; and the Conizee, is he to
whom it is acknowledged.
West. par. I. Symb. l.2. Sect.49. &amp;
part. 2. tit. Fines Sect.114.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conjure(v)">Conjure (<etym lang="la">conjuro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to swear
or conspire together, to ex&shy;
orcise a spirit. <expan type="">id est</expan> to swear him
or conjure him by the power
of another, by the names or
spels they use; whereas Ad&shy;
jure is to swear one to, as I
adjure, <expan type="">id est</expan> swear thee to it by
mine own power, and con&shy;
jure by the power of ano&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conuascency(n)">Conuascency (from <etym lang="la">con</etym>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conservator of the peace(n)">Conservators of the peace
(<etym lang="la">Conservator</etym>, or <etym lang="la">Custos Pacis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
was an Officer that had
charge to preserve the Kings
Peace, before the time of K:
Edw. the Third, who first e&shy;
rected Justices of the Peace
instead of those Conservators,
&amp;c. See Lamb. Eirenarcha
l.1. ca.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conservator of the truce(n)">Conservator of the Truce
and safe Conducts (<etym lang="la">Conserva&shy; 
tor induciarum &amp; salvorum
Regis conductuum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was an Of&shy;
ficer appointed in every Port
of the Sea, under the Kings
Letters Pattents, and had
forty pounds for his yearly
stipend at the least. His
charge was, to enquire of all
offences done against the
Kings Truce, and safe Con&shy;
ducts, upon the main Sea out
of the Countries and Fran&shy;
chises of the Kings Cinque
Ports, as the Admirals of
Custom were wont, and such
other things as are declared,
An.2. H.5. ca.6. Touching
this matter you may read a
nother Stat. An.4. H.5. ca.7.
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

suetudo, inis</etym>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">accustomed,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="consuete(a)">Consuete (<etym lang="la">consuetus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> <xref>i&shy;
dem.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="consul(n)">Consul (Lat. from <etym lang="la">con&shy;
sulendo</etym>, of giving counsel)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a chief Officer among the
Romans, of which two were
chosen yearly to govern the
City, and command their Ar&shy;
mies. 

In Paris, <term lang="fr"> Les Consuls</term>, are
five honest and substantial
Citizens, who determine
all cases of debt (not excee&shy;
ding 4000 li. Tournois) be&shy;
tween Merchant and Merch&shy;
ant: their authority continues
but a year, and the utmost
punishment they can inflict,
is but imprisonment. In most
Cities of Aquitain, the chief
Governors are termed Consuls,
the rest of the good Towns 


</page>

<page sig="k8v">
in France have such Consuls,
as Paris, by the names of <term lang="fr">Les
Judges &amp; Consuls des Merchands</term>.
Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="consummate(v)">Consummate (<etym lang="la">consummo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to make up or accomplish,
to sum up a reckoning.</xpln></wordentry>

stria to Hungary, &amp;c. It

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="continual claim(n)">Continual Claim,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Claim
made from time to time, with&shy;
in every year &amp; day to land or 


</page>

<page sig="l1r">
other thing, which in some re&shy;
spect we cannot attain with&shy;
out danger: For example, if I
be disseized of Land, into
which (though I have right)
I dare not enter for fear of
beating, it behoves me to
hold on my right of Entry to
the best opportunity of me
and my Heirs, by approach&shy;
ing as near it as I can once
every year, as long as I live,
and so I save the right of En&shy;
try to my Heirs. Terms of
Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contorsion(n)">Contorsion (<etym lang="la">contorsio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wri&shy;
thing, wresting, or pulling a&shy;
way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contrabanded goods(n)">Contrabanded Goods,</form> <xpln lang="en">pro&shy;
hibited goods, that are for&shy;
bidden to be imported, by
Proclamation, from the Ital.
<term lang="it"> Bando</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Proclamation.</xpln></wordentry>

an out-wall compassing the
walls of the City, and placed
before them for the more safe&shy;
guard. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contrition(n)">Contrition (<etym lang="la">contritio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">brui&shy;
sedness, or wearing with use.
In Divinity it is a perfect sor&shy;
row and horror that a man
hath for having committed
sin, and this, for that he lo&shy;
veth God with a soveraign
and singular love. 

Or Contrition (saith an Au&shy;
thor) is when the foulness
of sin is set off onely by con&shy;
ceiving the goodness of
God, without reflexion up&shy;
on reward or pain. 

Contrition (sayes another
Author) is the bruising of a
sinners heart (as it were) to
dust and powder, through
unfeigned and deep sorrow
conceived at Gods displeasure
for sin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contrite(a)">Contrite (<etym lang="la">contritus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">worn
or bruised; But is most com&shy;
monly used for penitent or
sorrowful for misdeeds, re&shy;
morseful,</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contrucidate(v)">Contrucidate (<etym lang="la">contrucido</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to wound, to murther, or
kill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="convexity(n)">Convexity (<etym lang="la">convexitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

ding down on every side,
Convexity is the out-side of an
hollow body, as Concavity 
the inside. In a painted Globe
of the world, the descripti&shy;
ons are upon the convexity
thereof, and that face is con&shy;
vex, the rest is belly, or con&shy;
cave. El. Armory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conviction(n)">Conviction (<etym lang="la">convictio</etym> from
 <etym lang="la">convinco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a proving guilty,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="convocation(n)">Convocation (<etym lang="la">convocatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
calling or assembling toge&shy;
ther. 

 Convocation house, is that
wherein the whole Clergy
assembled for consultati&shy;
on upon matters Ecclesi&shy;
astical in time of Parlia&shy;
ment; And as the house of
Parliament, so this consisted
of two distinct houses; One
called the higher Convocati&shy;
on-house, where the Arch&shy;
Bishops and Bps sate severally
by themselves; The other the
Lower Convocation-house,
where all the rest of the Cler&shy;
gy were bestowed. Cow.
See <xref lexeme="proloquutor">Prolucutor</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

ny of Souldiers or ships for the

news, as in the Cramp; or
when the Mouth, Nose, Eye,

ned awry out of its due

<page sig="l2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coparcener(n)">Coparceners (<etym lang="la">participes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
otherwise called Parceners, in
our Common Law are such
as have equal portion in the
Inheritance of their Ancest&shy;
or. Parceners are either by
Law or Custom; Parceners
by Law, are the issue female,
which (in case of no heir male)
come in equality to the lands
of their Ancestors, Bract. l.2.
ca.30 Parceners by custom
are those, that by custom of
the Country challenge equal
part in such Lands: As in
Kent by Gavel-kind . See Lit&shy;
tleton l.3. ca. 1, 2 and Britton
ca.27. Intituled, de Heritage
divisable. 

The Crown of England is
not subject to Co-parcenary.
An.25. H 8. ca.22. 

If Coparceners refuse to di&shy;
vide their common inheri&shy;
tance, and chuse rather to
hold it joyntly, they are said
to hold in Parcenary, or Copar&shy;
cenary . Litt. fol.56.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copal(n)">Copal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of white
and bright Rosin brought
from the West Indies, where&shy;
of the people there were wont
to make perfumes in their Sa&shy;
crifices: It is hot in the se&shy;
cond degree, and moist in the
first, and is used here to be
burnt against cold diseases of
the brain. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copy(n)">Copie (<etym lang="la">copia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">plenty, a&shy;
bundance, riches, eloquence,
provision of things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copiosity(n)">Copiosity (<etym lang="la">copiositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">plen&shy;
ty, store, abundance, copi&shy;
ousness.</xpln></wordentry>

which coupleth or joyneth,

joyn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornage(n)"><emend err="Coraage">Cornage</emend> (<etym lang="la">coragium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
kind of imposition extraor&shy;
dinary, and growing upon
some unusual occasion, and it
seems to be of certain mea&shy;
sures of Corn. For Corus tri&shy;
tict, is a certain measure of
Corn, Bracton. l 2. Ca.26.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coral(n)">Coral orCorral (<etym lang="la">Coralli&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">There are two principal
sorts hereof, the one white,
the other red, but the red is
best. It grows like a tree in
the bottom of the Sea, green
when under the water, and
bearing a white berry; and
when out, turns red. It is
cold and dry in operation,
good to be hanged about
Childrens necks, as well to
rub their Gums, as to pre&shy;
serve them from the Falling&shy;
sickness. Sands 235. There
is also a black and yellow
kind of Coral. See more in
Dr. Browns Vul. Err. fol. 91.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrosive(a)">Corarsive.</form> <xpln lang="en">See<xref>Corrosive</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corbel(n)" lexeme="corbet(n)">A Corbel,Corbet, or<emend err="Cor"> Cor&shy;</emend>
bil.</form> <xpln lang="en">In Masonry is a jutting
or shouldering peece cut out
in stone, as we may see in
wals, to bear up a post, Sum&shy;
mer or other weight, (which
in Timber-work, is called a 


</page>

<page sig="l2v">
 Bracket, or Braggat . This
and such like terms of art,
for the most part are taken
from the similitude of Beasts,
Birds or some living thing,
which they resemble, whence
this is called a Corbel (from
the French <etym lang="fr">Corbeau</etym>, a Crow
or Raven) because they were
wont to make such Jutties
out of a wall in form of a
Crow. Min.<xref> See Bragget</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corban(n)">Corban 
or
Corbon (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chest
or Coffer in the
Temple of Hie&shy;
rusalem, where the Trea&shy;
sure that served for the
Priests or Temples use was
kept. Also the treasure it
self. The word is used in
Eicon Basilica. Also a gift
or offering, Mark.7.11.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cordage(n)">Cordage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Ropes or
stuff to make ropes of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cordoban leather(n)">Cordovan Leather,</form> <xpln lang="en">so cal&shy;
led from Cordova or Corduba
a City in Spain. In the I&shy;
slands of Corsica, and Sardi&shy;
nia, there is a beast called
Musoli, not found elsewhere
in Europe, horned like a
Ram, and skinned like a
Stag, his skin carried to
Corduba, and there dressed
makes our true Cordovan Lea&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cordelier(pn)">Cordelier orCordilier 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a grey Frier of the
Order of St. Francis; So
called, because he wears a
rope or cord about his mid&shy;
dle for a Girdle, full of twisted
knots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cordwainer(n)">Cordiner orCordwainer 
(from the French <etym lang="fr">Cordvan
nier</etym>) or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">co&shy;
rium</etym>, a Skin or Hide)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Shoo-maker, a Tanner, or
Leather-dresser, a Curri&shy;
er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="correspond(v)">Corespond.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Corre&shy;
spond</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Corinthian work(n)">Corinthian-work,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort
of Pillars in Architecture.<xref> See
Tuscan</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornage(n)">Cornage (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Lat.</class>
 <etym lang="la">Cornu</etym>, a horn)</form> <xpln lang="en">in our Com&shy;
mon Law signifies a kind of
Grand Sergeancy, the service
of which tenure, is to blow
a horn, when any invasion
of the Northern enemy is
perceived, and by this ma&shy;
ny hold their Land North&shy;
ward, about the wal commen&shy;
ly called the Picts wall . Cam.
Britan, fo.609.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cornelian law(n)">Cornelian Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">L. Corne&shy;
lius Sylla, being Dictator,
made a Law (among others)
that all such as would fol&shy;
low him in the Civil War,
should be capable of any O&shy;
fice or Magistracy, before
they came to their ful years,
&amp;c. Those kind of Roman 
Laws always took denomina&shy;
tion from him that proffered
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corneous(a)">Corneous (<etym lang="la">corneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of, or
like a horn, hard, or white as
horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornicle(n)">Cornicle (<etym lang="la">corniculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lit&shy;
tle horn:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornigerous(a)">Cornigerous (<etym lang="la">corniger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
horned, having or wearing
horns: One of the Wine&shy;
god Bacchus his Epithets, 


</page>

<page sig="l3r">
because with drinking much
wine men grow fierce
and furious, as horned beasts,
whence that Satyrical. 

<term lang="la"> Sumit cornua pauper</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornice(n)">Cornice,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term of Archi&shy;
tecture.<xref> See Frize</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornucopia(n)">Cornucopie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">plenty
or abundance of all things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornuted(a)">Cornuted (<etym lang="la">cornttus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath horns; also Cuckhol&shy;
ded.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrody(n)">Corrody
Corody comes of the
Lat. <etym lang="la">corrodo</etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">
and signifies in our Common
Law a sum of money, or al&shy;
lowance of meat and drink,
due to the King from an
Abbey or other House of Re&shy;
ligion, whereof he is foun&shy;
der, towards the reasonable
sustenance of such a one of
his Servants, being put to
his Pension, as he thinks
good to bestow it on. And
the difference between a
Corody and a Pension seems
to be, that a Corody is allow&shy;
ed towards the maintenance
of any of the Kings ser&shy;
vants, that live in the Ab&shy;
bey; a Pension is given to
one of the Kings Chaplains,
for his better maintenance
in the Kings service, till he
may be provided a Benefice.
Cow. Of both these read
Fitz. Nat. br. fol. 230, 231
233.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corporal(a)">Corporal (<etym lang="la">corporalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath, or pertains to the body;
Also an inferior Officer in
war so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coronary(a)">Coronary (<etym lang="la">coronarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to a Crown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corollary(n)">Corollary (<etym lang="la">corallarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the addition or vantage above
measure, an over-plus, or sur&shy;
plusage; Also a smal gift or
largess bestowed on the peo&shy;
ple at publick Feasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coroner(n)">Coroner (<etym lang="la">coronator</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an
ancient Officer of this land,
so called because he deals
wholly for the King and
Crown. There be four of
them commonly in every
County, and they are cho&shy;
sen by the Free-holders of
the same upon Writ, and
not made by letters Patents.
Crompt. Jurisdict. fol.126. See
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corporeal(a)">Corporeal<etym lang="la">corporeus (</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath a body, or pertaining to
the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corporature(n)">Corporature (<etym lang="la">corporatura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the quantity, fashion, or con&shy;
stitution of the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrade(v)">Corrade (<etym lang="la">corrado</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to scrape
together, to take away or
spoil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrosive(a)">Corrasive (<etym lang="la">corrasivus</etym> from
 <etym lang="la">corrado</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which scrapes to&shy;
gether, shaves or spoils: This
word is many times mista&shy;
ken for Corrosive, from <etym lang="la">Cor&shy;
rodo</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="correlative(n)">Correlatives (<etym lang="la">correlativa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
 <term lang="la">Relatio</term> (according to the
Philosophers) is, <term lang="la">Cujus totam
esse est ad aliud esse</term>, whose whole
being is to be to another,
whence Correlatives are such
things as are mutually
one to another, and cannot
bee, nor bee explicated,
but in order to one another. 


</page>

<page sig="l3v">
As Father and Son, superior
and inferior, Husband and
Wife, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="correption(n)">Correption (<etym lang="la">correptio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
correcting in words, a rebu&shy;
king, a snatching away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="correspond(v)">Correspond (<etym lang="la">correspondeo
<expan type="">id est</expan> concorditer respondeo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to an&shy;
swer concordingly, agreeing&shy;
ly, or in the same proportion,
to accord or consent together,
to run one and the same
course together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="correspondent(a)">Correspondent,</form> <xpln lang="en">agreeable,
proportionable, or answer&shy;
able to another thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corridor(n)">Corridor,</form> <xpln lang="en">A curtain in
Fortification.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrigible(a)">Corrigible (<etym lang="la">corrigibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be corrected, or a&shy;
mended.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrival(n)">Corrivals (<etym lang="la">corrivales</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">they
who have water from, or use
the same River. And meta&shy;
phorically a Competitor
in love, or they that
love one and the same wo&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrivality(n)">Corrivality (<etym lang="la">corrivalitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the love of a Corrival, a cor&shy;
rivalship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corroborate(v)">Corroborate (<etym lang="la">corroboro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make strong, to harden or
confirm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrode(v)">Corrode (<etym lang="la">corrodo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to gnaw
about, to eat away: Also to
back-bite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrodible(a)">Corrodible (<etym lang="la">corrodibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be gnawn or eaten
away. Vul. Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrosive(a)">Corrosive (<etym lang="la">corrosivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
gnawing or eating about,
biting, as it were a nip&shy;
ping the very heart: Also a 
fretting plaister, or any thing,
which being laid to the body,
raiseth blisters, and makes it
sore. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corrugation(n)">Corrugation (<etym lang="la">corrugatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a wrinkling, or furrowing
of the skin, a frowning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corsair(n)">Corsary (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Corsaire</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Courier.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corslet(n)">Corslet (from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cor&shy;
salletto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">armor for the breast,
and back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corticated(a)">Corticated (<etym lang="la">corticatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath a rind or bark.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corvine(a)">Corvine (<etym lang="la">corvinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to, or like a Ra&shy;
ven or Crow; black as a
Crow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coruscant(a)">Coruscant (<etym lang="la">coruscans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gli&shy;
stering, shining, or light&shy;
ning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coruscation(n)">Coruscation (<etym lang="la">coruscatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
flash of lightning, or a kind of
seeming sparkling fire, which
appears in Mines by night.
Tis (saith an Author) a
glistering of fire, rather then
fire indeed, and a glimmer&shy;
ing of lightning rather then
lightning it self. Gal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curvet(n)">Corvetta (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital</class>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pran&shy;
cing, or continual dancing
of a Horse of Service. Hence
to corvet, is to leap or
prance, as a Horse of Service
doth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Corybants(pn)">Corybants (<etym lang="la">Corybantes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Cybeles, or Cybelles Priests,
so called from Corybantus,
one of her first Atten&shy;
dants. 

To play the Corybant, is
to run madly up and down,
playing on a Cymbal, and 


</page>

<page sig="l4r">
wagging the head, as those
Priests were wont to do;
Also to sleep with open
eyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coscinomancy(n)">Coscinomancy (<etym lang="la">conscinoman&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a divining by a Sieve.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="co-significative(a)">Co-significative (from <etym lang="la">con
</etym> and <etym lang="la">significo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of the same sig&shy;
nification with another
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmos(n)">Cosmos ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mundus the
world. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmarchy(n)">Cosmarchy (<etym lang="la">cosmarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the power of the Devil,
the government of the
World.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmical(a)">Cosmical (<etym lang="la">cosmicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
the world, worldly. 

In Astronomy we term
that the Cosmical ascension
of a Star, when it ariseth
together with the Sun, or
the same degree of the Eclip&shy;
tick, wherein the Sun abides.
Vul. Er 224.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmodelyte(n)">Cosmodelyte. May be de&shy;
rived from <etym lang="gk">&kappa;&#x1f79;&#x03c3;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> <etym lang="la">mundus</etym>,
and <etym lang="gk">&delta;&epsilon;&#x03af;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <etym lang="la">timidus</etym> or <etym lang="la">miser</etym>;</form> <xpln lang="en">
and so Englished, one fear&shy;
ful of the world, or a worldly
wretch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmography(n)">Cosmography (<etym lang="la">cosmogra&shy;
phia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the description of the
world in general. This art,
by the distance of the Cir&shy;
cles in Heaven, divides the
Earth under them into her
Zones and Climats, and by
the elevation of the Pole,
considers the length of the
day and night, with the
perfect demonstration of
the Suns rising and going
down, &amp;c. And is best 
handled by Pliny in his Natu&shy;
ral History.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmographer(n)">Cosmographer (<etym lang="la">cosmo&shy;
graphus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a describer of the
world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmographical(a)">Cosmographical</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to Cosmography.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmology(n)">Cosmology ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a speak&shy;
ing of the world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmopolite(n)">Cosmopolite (from <etym lang="la">Cos&shy;
mos</etym> and <etym lang="la">Polites</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la"> Cives</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Citizen of the world; or Cos&shy;
mopolitan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cosmometry(n)">Cosmometry ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
measuring of the world. It is
thus defined, Cosmometry shews
the reason of the world,
by measures of degrees and
minutes of the Heavens,
and the differences of Cli&shy;
mats days and nights, the
elevation of the Poles, di&shy;
versity of the noon Tides,
and shadows in Dyals, and
divides it self into Cosmo&shy;
graphy, and Geography, first part
Treasury.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="costrel(n)">Costrel orCastrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of bottle to carry wine
or such like in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="couchant(a)">Couchant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">couch&shy;
ing, or lying on the ground.
See <xref lexeme="levant and couchant">Levant, and Couch&shy;
ant</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="covent(n)" lexeme="convent(n)">Covent orConvent (<etym lang="la">con&shy;
ventus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a multitude of men
assembled together: The
whole <emend err="nnmber">number</emend> of religious
persons dwelling in one
house together, which ac&shy;
cording to Chaucer in the
Sompners Tale, is but thir&shy;
teen, viz. twelve and the
Confessor. 


</page>

<page sig="l4v">
A Cloister or Abby of
Monks or Nuns. Hence
Covent-Garden took denomi&shy;
nation, because it belon&shy;
ged to that Covent or reli&shy;
gious house, which is now
called White-hall, which (if
I mistake not) was a Pri&shy;
ory heretofore of Dominican
Friars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coverture(n)">Coverture,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a French
word, and signifies any thing
that covers, as Apparrel,
a Coverlet, &amp;c. In our
Common Law, it is particu&shy;
larly applied to the estate
and condition of a married
woman, who by the Laws
of the Realm is <term lang="la"> in potestare
viri</term>, under coverture or Co&shy;
vert baron, and therefore dis&shy;
abled to make any bargain or
contract, without her hus&shy;
bands consent or privity, or
confirmation. <term lang="la">Brook. hoc ti&shy;
tulo, per totum</term>. {}</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coulant(a)">Coulant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gliding,
slipping, flowing gently a&shy;
long.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="count(n)">Count (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Comte</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Earl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Couldray(pn)">Couldray,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the name
of a noble House belonging
to the Lord Viscount Moun&shy;
tague in Sussex; In French
it signifies a Hasel wood, or
Grove, whence perhaps it
took denomination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counter-compony(a)">Counter-compone,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
term in Herauldry, as if
you say, a Cross Counter&shy;
compone, this is as much as
to say, a Cross compoun&shy; 
ded of two sundry colours,
or three. See Accidence of Ar&shy;
mory, fol.54.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Counter(pn)">TheCounter orContor,</form> <xpln lang="en">
Is the name of two Prisons
in London, wherein Debtors
and others for misdemea&shy;
nors are Imprisoned; so cal&shy;
led from the French word
<etym lang="fr">Compt&eacute;r</etym>, which comes from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Comput&aacute;re</etym>, because
whoever slips in there, must
be sure to account and pay
well too, ere he get out,
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counter(n)">Contor,</form> <xpln lang="en">also in high Dutch,
is <term lang="la">locus seclusus</term>, a Prison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="countermure(n)" lexeme="counterscarf(n)">Countermure orCounter&shy;
scarf</form> <xpln lang="en">in a fortified Town,
is a bank of a Ditch or
mount opposite against the
wall. See <xref> Contramure</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counterround(a)">A Counterround (Fr.
<etym lang="fr">contreronde</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">when one round
goes one way, and another
another. Also a certain
number of Officers or Com&shy;
manders, going to visit
the Watch of the Corps de
guard, Sentinels, or the Rounds,
to see if they be diligent
in performing their duty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="countertail(n)" lexeme="countertally(n)">Countertaile
or 
Countertallie ((Fr.) 
<etym lang="fr">Contre&shy; 
taile</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Tally to confirme or con&shy;
fute another Tally. It is a
peece of wood which the one
party keeps, that is cut off
from another peece kept by
the other party; And so
when both meet with their
 Tallies, they score up the
number of what is delivered 


</page>

<page sig="l5r">
and received, by cutting a
notch with a knife. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coupant(a)">Coupant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cutting,
cleaving, lopping, mowing,
carving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="court-baron(n)">Court-Baron (<etym lang="la">Curia Ba&shy;
ronis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Court that every
Lord of a Mannor (which
in ancient times were called
Barons) hath within his own
Precincts; Of this, and Court
Leet, read Kitchin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courtesan(n)">Courtisan (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Courtisane</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Lady, Gentlewoman, or
waiting woman of the Court;
Also (but less properly) a pro&shy;
fessed Strumpet, famous (or
infamous) Whore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courtesy(n)">Courtesy of England (<etym lang="la">Lex
Angli&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is used with us for a
Tenure. For if a man mar&shy;
ry an Inheretrix seized of
Land in Fee-simple, or in
Fee-tail general, or as Heir
in Taile special, and gets a
child of her, that comes a&shy;
live into the world, though
both it and his Wife die forth&shy;
with, yet if she were in pos&shy;
session, he shall keep the
land during his life, and
is called Tennant by the
Courtesie of England. Glan&shy;
vil. l.7 ca.18. Littleton l. I. ca.4.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curtilage(n)">Courtilage <term lang="la">alias</term>Curti&shy;
lage (<etym lang="la">curtilegium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
a Garden, Yard, Field or
peece of void ground lying
near, and belonging to a
Messauge. West. par.2. Symbol.
<term lang="la">Titul. Fines Sect</term>.26.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="couthutlaughe(n)">Coutheutlaugh,</form> <xpln lang="en">is he that
wittingly receives a man out&shy; 
lawed, and cherishes or hides
him. In which case, he was
in ancient times subject to
the same punishment, that
the Out-law himself was.
Bracton. l.3. tract. 2. ca.13.
nu.2. It is compounded of
the old Saxon word (Cou&shy;
the) <expan type="">id est</expan> known, and (Ut&shy;
laugh) an out-law, as we now
call him. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cravat(n)">crabbat ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is properly
an Adjective, and signifies
comely, handsome, gracious;
But it is often used Substan&shy;
tively for a new fashion&shy;
ed Gorget which women
wear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cranage(n)">Cranage (<etym lang="la">cranagium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a liberty to use a Crane,
for the drawing up Wares
from Vessels at any Creek
of the Sea or Wharf un&shy;
to the land, and to make pro&shy;
fit of it. It signifies also the
money paid and taken for the
same. New book of Entries.
fol.3. col.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crany(n)">Crany (<etym lang="la">cranium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the bone
of the head, the skul or brain&shy;
pan.</xpln></wordentry>

surfeiting or oppressed with
surfeit.</xpln></wordentry>

of natural humors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="creek(n)">Creek (<etym lang="la">crepido</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">seems to
be part of a Haven, where any
thing is landed or disbur&shy;
thened from the Sea. So that
when you are out of the main
Sea, within the Haven, look
how many landing places you
have, so many Creeks may be
said to belong to that Haven.
See Cromp. Jurisdictions fol.
110.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crepitation(n)">Crepitation (<etym lang="la">crepitatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

noise.</xpln></wordentry>

ger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crescent(n)">Cressant (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Croissant</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in

of waxing or increasing,
sometimes taken for a half&shy;

beacon. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cretan(pn)">Cretan (<etym lang="la">cretensis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;
habitant of the Island of <emend err="Can"> Can&shy;</emend>
dy or Creet, also a lyer, because
those of that Island are espe&shy;
cially noted to be tainted
with that vice, as St. Paul ob&shy;
served of them out of Epi&shy;
menides: <term lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1FC6;&tau;&epsilon;&#x03C2; &#x1F00;&epsilon;&#x1F76; &psi;&#x03AD;&nu;&#x03C2;&alpha;&iota;, 
&kappa;&alpha;&kappa;&#x1F70; &delta;&#x03AE;&rho;&iota;&alpha;, &rho;&#x1F71;&#x03C2;&epsilon;&rho;&epsilon;&#x03C2; &#x1F00;&rho;&gamma;&alpha;&iota;</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crisis(n)">Crisis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>) judgement;</form> <xpln lang="en">
In Physick it signifies a sud&shy;
dain change in a disease, or
the conflict between nature
and sickness; that is, the time
when either the Patient be&shy;
comes suddainly well, or sud&shy;
dainly dyes, or waxeth bet&shy;
ter or worse, according to the 


</page>

<page sig="l6r">
strength of his body and vi&shy;
olence of the disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crism(n)">Crism</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Chrism</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

of a certain Saint, who is Pa&shy;
tron to Shoo-makers. Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crist(n)">Crist (<etym lang="la">crista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Creast,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crystal(n)">Cristal (<etym lang="la">crystallus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mine&shy;
ral substance like cleer glass
or ice. There are two kinds
hereof; one which grows
upon extream cold Moun&shy;
tains, being there congealed
like Ice, by the Mineral ver&shy;
tue of the place, As Alber&shy;
tus writes. Another that
grows in the earth in some
places of Germany. See more
of the nature and properties of
it in Dr. Browns Vulgar Errors
l.2. cap. I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cristalline(a)">Cristalline (<etym lang="la">crystallinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
white and transparent as cry&shy;
stal, or of or belonging to
crystal. The Crystalline hu&shy;
mor is seated in the midst of
the eye, and of a round fi&shy;
gure, somewhat flattened
both before and behinde; it
is the first instrument of sight,
and a glass wherein the spirit
imagines and judges of the
forms represented to it. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crithology(n)">Crithology (<etym lang="la">crithologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the office of gathering the first
fruits of Corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="critical(a)">Critical or Judicial days
(<etym lang="la">dies critici</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are when the
disease comes to the Crisis or
judgement of a amending or im&shy; 
pairing, and they are the
fourth and seventh days; be&shy;
cause in them the Physitians
use to judge of the danger of
a disease: But the seventh is
accounted the chief Critical
day, and the fourth a token
or sign, what the seventh day
will be, if the Patient live so
long. This account must be
made according to the num&shy;
ber of weeks thus; in the
first week the fourth day is
the token or Critical of the
seventh day. In the second
week the eleventh is the Cri&shy;
tical of the fourteenth. In
the third, the seventeenth is
the Critical of the twentyeth,
(for Hippocrates reckons the
twentyeth day for the last of
the third week) In the fourth,
the twentyfourth is the Criti&shy;
cal of the twenty seventh;
and so forth to an hundred.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="critic(n)" lexeme="critic(a)">Critick.</form> <xpln lang="en">Taken Adjective&shy;
ly is the same with Critical .
But Substantively it signifies
one that takes upon him to
censure or judge of other
mens acts or works written.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="criticism(n)">Criticism.</form> <xpln lang="en">The Art of
judging or censuring mens
words, writings, or actions:
also a quillet or nicity in
judgement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crosier(n)">Crosier.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Bishops staffe,
so called either from the
French <etym lang="fr">Croce</etym>, Crosse, of the
figure of the Cross which it
hath, or fromCroce, which
in our old English signifies a
shepherds Crook, because 


</page>

<page sig="l6v">
Bishops are spiritual Pastors
or shepherds.</xpln></wordentry>

kawing of Crows, Rooks, or
Ravens.</xpln></wordentry>

containing in quantity a quar&shy;
ter of a Sembrief, or two <emend err="quarters" source="errata">Qua&shy;
vers</emend>. It is sometimes used
for a whimsey or idle fancy of
the brain: as we say, his
head is full of Crotchets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crusade(n)">Croysado (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Croysade</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
expedition of Christians, as&shy;
sembled out of divers Coun&shy;
tries (by preachings and the
Popes Bulls) against the
Turks or other Infidels;
termed so, because every one
of them, when he undertakes
the journey, accepts of, and
wears on his Cassock or coat
Armor, the badge of the
Cross. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Culdeys(pn)">Culdeys (a corruption
from <etym lang="la">Cultores Dei</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> worship&shy;

gious people in Scotland, so

fies, that in Ireland there was

C&oelig;licolas, vel Colideos vocant,
devote deserviebant.</term></xpln></wordentry>

of building, by fastning boards
or timber with artificial
joynts, so firmly together, that
they cannot fall asunder.
Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cup-glass(n)" lexeme="cupping-glass(n)">Cupglass 
or 
Cuppingglass</form> <xpln lang="en">A hollow
round
glasse
with a hole in the bottom, u&shy;
sed by Physicians sometimes,
to draw blood or wind out of
the body, for it sucks with
great strength, by reason of a
little flame of fire made in it.
Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cupula(n)">Cupulo (It. <etym lang="it">cupula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a high
Arch or round vault of any
Church house or steeple;
some have abusively used it for
a spire or pinacle of a stee&shy;
ple. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curfew(n)">Curfew. <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Comes of the
French</class> <etym lang="fr">Couvrir</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to cover
and <etym lang="fr">feu</etym>, (the fire)</form> <xpln lang="en">we use it
for the eight o'th clock Bell,
or an evening Peal, by which
the Conquerour in the first
yeer of his reign, willed eve&shy;
ry man to take warning for
the raking up his fire, and
putting out his light. So
that in many places at this
day, where a Bell is customa&shy;
bly rung towards Bed-time,
it is said to ring Curfew.
Stows Annals. and Sir Rich.
Baker. fol.34.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coranto(n)">Curranto (<etym lang="la">ab huc &amp; illuc

ning dance, a French dance,
different from what we call a
Country dance.</xpln></wordentry>

</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Boat (almost like

dia's. Herb.</xpln></wordentry>

It is also used Substantively,
for a swift running stream of
water, and sometimes taken
for a strait of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cybele(pn)">Cybele,</form> <xpln lang="en">the mother of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cycle(n)">Cycle (<etym lang="la">cyclus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a round or
circle. In Astronomy it is
thus defined. The division
of the yeer into 52 weeks,<emend err="be"> be&shy;</emend>
cause it sets off one day super&shy;
numerary, makes an alterati&shy;
on in all the rest; so that the
days of the week (which
use to be assigned by the let&shy;
ters of the Alphabet) fall 


</page>

<page sig="l8r">
not alike in several yeers; but
Sunday this yeer, must fall out
on the next yeers Munday,
and so forward till seven yeers
and (because the Bissexille
superads another day every
fourth yeer) till four times
seven, that is, 28 yeers be
gone about. This revolution
is called the Cycle of the Sun,
taking name from Sunday, the
letter whereof (called there&shy;
fore Dominical) it appoints
for every yeer. It is found
by adding nine (for so far the
Circle was then gone about)
to the yeer of our Lord, and
dividing the whole by 28, so
to the yeer following 1639,
if nine be added, the numerus
factus will be 1648, which, di&shy;
vided by 28, leaves 24 for the
Cycle of the Sun. 

The Cycle of the Moon is
the revolution of 19 yeers, in
which space (though not
precisely) the Lunations re&shy;
cur. For because of the Sun
and Moons unequal motions,
the changes falling out in&shy;
constantly; the time of con&shy;
junction could not be still the
same. This variety the An&shy;
cients perceiving to be <emend err="peri">peri&shy;</emend>
odical, <emend err="eudeavoured">endeavoured</emend> to com&shy;
prehend what Circle it made
in going about. The learned
Meton, finding the Revolution
was not compleated in less
time, then the space of 19
yeers, set forth his Ennedeca&shy;
etris, within the Circle wher&shy;
of the Lunations (though
not exactly) do indeed recur, 
so that if the quadrature of
the Moon shall fall out as this
day of this yeer, the like
shall return again, the same
day of the 19 yeer succeeding.
This Cycle is therefore called
Cyclus decennovennalis, and
from the Author Annus Me&shy;
tonicus; from whose Athenians
the Egyptians may seem to
have received it, as the Romans
from them, in Letters of gold;
from whence (if not from the
more precious use of it) it
obtained to be called, as it still
is, the numerus aureus or Gol&shy;
den number . It was made
Christian by the Fathers of
the Nicene-Council, as being
altogether necessary to the
finding out the Neomenia Pas&shy;
chalis, upon which the Feast
of Easter, and all the move&shy;
able rest depended. It self is
found by adding an unite to
the yeer of our Lord, and di&shy;
viding the whole by 19, the
remainder shall be the Cycle
of the Moon; or if nothing
remain, the Cycle is out, that
is nineteen. Mr. Gregory, de
&AElig;ris &amp; Epochis p.133.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cyclometry(n)">Cyclometry (<etym lang="la">cyclometria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a measuring of Circles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cyclopedy(n)">Cyclopedy (<etym lang="la">cyclopedia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
universal knowledge of all
Sciences.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cyclops(pn)">Cyclops (<etym lang="la">cyclopes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an an&shy;
cient and big bon'd sort of
people, which had but one
eye, and that in the midst of
the forehead, inhabiting the
Island of Sicily: the Poets
called them gyants, because 


</page>

<page sig="l8v">
they were people of a mighty
stature, of which rank was the
so much famoused Polyphemus,
that with such humanity en&shy;
tertained Vlysses and his Com&shy;
panions. Rider. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cyclopic(a)" lexeme="Cyclopean(a)">Cyclopick 
Cyclopean</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
those Gyants
or Cyclops ; Monstrous, one&shy;
eyed, furious. Eicon Basil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cylinder(n)">Cylinder (<etym lang="la">cylindrus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Geometrical figure round and
long, consisting from top to
toe, of two equal parallel
Circles: also it is taken for
that part of the bore of a
Gun, which remains empty,
when the Gun is loaden, a ro&shy;
ler to beat Clods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cylindrical(a)">Cylindrical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
or like a Cylinder . Vul. Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cymaise(n)">Cymace (<etym lang="la">cymatium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of Pillar so graven, that the
carved work resembles the
waves; or a ledge or outward
member in Architecture, fa&shy;
shioned somewhat like a Ro&shy;
man S, and termed a Wave or
Ogee.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cymbal(n)">Cymbal (<etym lang="la">cymbalum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was
a kind of instrument, compo&shy;
sed of thin plates of brass,
with certain small bars of I&shy;
ron, fastened and cross billet&shy;
ed in the plates, wherewith
they made a great noise. O&shy;
thers think Cymbals are bells,
which according to the opi&shy;
nion of some, were consecra&shy;
ted to the service of the
Church by Pope Sabintan&shy;
Caussinus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cymraecan(a)">Cymraecan (from the Br.
<f type="br"/><etym lang="br">Cymraeg</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> Welsh)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="Cam"> Cam&shy;</emend> 
brian, Welsh or British: Mr.
How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cymbalist(n)">Cymbalist (<etym lang="la">cymbalistes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that plays on the Cymbals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cynanthropy(n)">Cynanthropie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fren&shy;
zy which makes a man haunt
unfrequented places, with a
conceit, that he is turned in&shy;
to a dog. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cynical(a)" lexeme="cynic(a)">Cynical 
Cynick (<etym lang="la">cynicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dogged,
currish or chur&shy;
lish like a dog. There was
in Greece an old Sect of Phi&shy;
losophers called Cynicks, first
instituted by Antisthenes; and
were so called, because they
did ever bark at, and rebuke
mens vices, and were not so
respective in their behavior as
civility required. Diogenes
was so famous in this kind of
Philosophy, that he was sur&shy;
named the Cynick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cynegetic(n)">Cynegetick (<etym lang="la">cynegetica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
books treating of hunting:
whereof Oppianus wrote four.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cynocephalist(n)">Cynocephalist (<etym lang="la">cynocepha&shy;
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a beast like an Ape, but
having the face of a dog: a
Babion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cynosure(n)">Cynosure (<etym lang="la">cynosura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure
of stars in Heaven. Mr. Brough&shy;
ton in his Eccles. history.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cynthus(pn)">Cynthus.</form> <xpln lang="en">A hill in Delos,
where Latona brought forth
Apollo and Diana, whence A&shy;
pollo and the Sun are called
Cynthius; Diana and the Moon
Cynthia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cyprine(a)">Cyprine (<etym lang="la">cyprinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to the Cypress-Tree,
which tree is destinated to
the dead; in that, being once
cut, it never re-flourisheth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dagon(pn)">Dagon.</form> <xpln lang="en">The Idol of the

Old-Testament. It had a
mans face and a fishes body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dalmatic(n)">Dalmatick (<etym lang="la">Dalmatica ve&shy;
stis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Vestment of a Dea&shy;
con or sub-Deacon, proper&shy;
ly belonging to his Order;
so called because they were
first made in Dalmatia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="damage-feasant(n)">Dammage-fesant</form> <xpln lang="en">(a term
in our Common Law) is
when a strangers beasts are in
another mans ground, with&shy;
out licence of the Tenant of
the ground, and there feed or
otherwise spoil the Corn,
grass, woods, &amp;c. In which
case the Tenant whom they
hurt, may therefore distrain
and impound them as well in
the night as in the day. But
in other cases, as for Rent, and
services and such like, none
may distrain in the night.
New Terms of the Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dandruff(n)">Dandruff 
or 
Dandraff (<etym lang="la">furfur</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">scurf
or kind of smal
scales that stick 
to the skin of the head, &amp; of&shy;
ten hang about the hairs.
They are caused by salt flegm
or some other corrupted hu&shy;
mors, piercing insensibly the
pores, and then sleightly con&shy;
gealed by the ayr, and may be
taken away by washing the
head with salt water, or
Vinegar warm. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Danegeld(n)">Danegelt,Daneguilt or
Danegold (compounded of
<etym lang="sx">Dane</etym> and<etym lang="sx">gelt</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">pecunia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was
a tribute laid upon our An&shy;
cestors of twelve pence for
every Hide of Land through
the Realm by the Danes .
Stow in his Annals, p.118.
saith, this Tribute came to
48000. l. <term lang="la"> per an.</term> and that it
was released by Edw. the Con&shy;
fessor, Heylin saith, by King
Steven.</xpln></wordentry>
