<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daphnomancy(n)">Daphnomancy (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&delta;&#x03ac;&phi;&nu;&eta;</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">laurus</term> and <etym lang="gk">&mu;&alpha;&nu;&tau;&epsilon;&#x03af;&alpha;</etym>
 <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Divinatio</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">divination by a
Lawrel Tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dapifer(n)">Dapifer ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that serves

<xref target="Arch-Dapifer">Arch Dapifer</xref>. The great Ma&shy;
ster or Steward of the Kings
house was so termed in old

gick; so called from Dar&shy;
danus, a wicked Magici&shy;
an.

 <term lang="la">At si nulla valet medicina repellere pestem,

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daric(n)">Darick (<etym lang="la">Daricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of ancient coyn bearing
the image of Darius King of
Persia, and valuing about two
shillings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="datary(a)">Datary (<etym lang="la">datarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is,
freely given: taken <emend err="Substan">Substan&shy;</emend>
tively, it is an Office in
Rome for collation of Church
Benefices. Also a dater of
Writings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="date(n)">Date (<etym lang="la">dactylus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
sweet fruit brought from
Numidia and other far Coun&shy;
tries. the Date Trees are
some male, some female: the
first brings forth onely flow&shy;
ers, the other fruit, yet
herein is the male beneficial
to the increase of the Dates;
for, unless a flowred bough
of the male be ingraffed into
the female, the Dates never
prove good. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dation(n)">Dation (<etym lang="la">datio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a giving, a
gift, a dole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="datism(n)">Datism (<etym lang="la">datismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
when by a heap of Synony&shy;
ma's, we rehearse the same
things. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dative(a)">Dative (<etym lang="la">dativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that gi&shy;
veth, or is of power to give.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Daulphin(pn)">Daulphin</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Dolphin</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="David's day(pn)">St.Davids-day.</form> <xpln lang="en">The
first of March kept solemnly
by the Brittains in honor of
their Patron St. David, whom
their Records and Tradition
testifie to have been a person
of eminent sanctity and au&shy; 
sterity of life, excellently
learned; a most eloquent
preacher of Gods word, and
Archbishop of <emend err="Men y">Menevy</emend> now
from him called St. Davids in
Pembrook shire. He flourish&shy;
ed in the fifth &amp; sixth age af&shy;
ter the coming of Christ, and
dyed in the 140 yeer of his
own, as Dr Pitts witnesseth in
his book de illustribus Britan&shy;
ni&aelig; Scriptoribus. The Brittains
always wear a Leek on that
day in memory of a famous
victory obtained by them a&shy;
gainst the Saxons; the said
Britains for the time of the
battail, wearing Leeks in their
hats for their military colours
by St. Davids perswasion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="day(n)">Days</form> <xpln lang="en">(according to the
division of Authors) are ei&shy;
ther Astronomical or Political :
of Astronomical, some be na&shy;
tural, and some again Artifi&shy;
cial. An Artificial day con&shy;
sists of twelve houres, Joh.
11:19. There be twelve hours
in the day, Gen.1.4,5. and
47.9. A natural day consists
of twenty four hours. The
beginning of politique days,
is divers: for the Atheni&shy;
ans began their day from Sun&shy;
set, but the Jews, Chaldeans,
and Babylonians from Sun-rise,
the Egyptians and the Ro&shy;
mans from midnight, of whom
we take our pattern to count
the hours from midnight, one, 


</page>

<page sig="m2r">
two, three, &amp;c. The Umbri&shy;
ans from noon. The parts
of Politique or Civil days
(according to Macrobius)
are these. The first time of
day is after midnight: The
second in Lat. <term lang="la"> Gallicinium</term>.
Cocks crow. The third <term lang="la"> Con&shy;
ticinium</term>, the space between
the first Cock and break of
day. The fourth <term lang="la">Diluculum</term>,
the break or dawn of the
day. The fifth <term lang="la">Mane</term> the
morning. the sixth <term lang="la">Meri&shy;
dies</term>, noon or mid-day. The
seventh <term lang="la">Pomeridies</term>, the after&shy;
noon. The eight <term lang="la">Sexum
diei</term>, Sun-set. The ninth,
<term lang="la">suprema tempestas</term>, twy-light.
The tenth <term lang="la"> Vesper</term>, the evening
or eventide. The eleventh
<term lang="la">prima fax</term>, Candle-time.
The twelfth <term lang="la">Nox Concubia</term>.
bed time. the thirteenth,
<term lang="la">Nox intempesta</term>, the dead time
of the night. <term lang="la">Vide</term> <emend err="Agelli">Agelli&shy;</emend>
um, Macrobium, &amp; <term lang="la">Funge&shy;
rum</term>. 

Maundy Thursday (the last
Thursday in Lent, and next
before Easter) so called as it
were, Mandati Thursday, from
a Ceremony used by the Bi&shy;
shops and Prelates in Cathe&shy;
dral Churches and Religious
houses, of washing their sub&shy;
jects feet; which Ceremony
is termed the fulfilling the <emend err="Man">Man&shy;</emend>
date, and is in imitation of
our Saviour Christ, who
on that day at night after
his last supper, and before
his institution of the Bles&shy;
sed Sacrament, washed his 
Disciples feet, telling them
afterwards that they must do
the like to one another: this
is the Mandate, whence the
day is denominated. At the
beginning of the aforesaid
Ceremony, these words of
Christ (uttered by him anon
after his washing their feet)
Joan.13,34. are sung for an
Antiphon. <term lang="la"> Mandatum novum
do vobis, ut diligatis invicem, fi&shy;
cut dilexi vos</term> . I give you a
new Mandate, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

ryot, disorder, unruli&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

nishing or perfecting.</xpln></wordentry>

white.</xpln></wordentry>

tain or Governor of ten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="debellation(n)">Debellation (<etym lang="la">debellatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

ing by war. Sir Tho. More
uses it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="de bene esse(n)">De bene esse</form> <xpln lang="en">are three<emend err="com"> com&shy;</emend>
mon Latine words, the mean&shy;
ing I conceive to be this; to
take or do a thing de bene esse,
is to accept or allow it for
present, but when it comes to 


</page>

<page sig="m2v">
be more fully examined or
tryed; it is to stand or fall, ac&shy;
cording to the merit or well&shy;
being of the thing in its own
nature; or as we say, <term lang="la"> valeat
quantum valere potest</term>. So in
Chancery, upon Motion to
have one of the Defendants in
a Cause, <emend err="" source="errata">examined</emend> as a witness, the
Court (not then precisely ex&shy;
amining the Justice of it, or
not hearing what may be ob&shy;
jected on the other side) of&shy;
ten orders that Defendant to
be examined De bene esse, <expan type="">id est</expan>
that his depositions are to be 
allowed or suppressed at the
hearing, as the Judge shall
see cause, upon the full de&shy;
bate of the matter.</xpln></wordentry>

milde, courteous, affable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Decameron(pn)">Decameron ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decemvirate(n)">Decemvirate (<etym lang="la">decemviratus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the Office or Authority of
those ten Noblemen or Go&shy;
vernors among the Romans,
who were called Decemviri,
they were appointed to go&shy;
vern the Commonwealth<emend err="in"> in&shy;</emend>
stead of the two Consuls, and
had the highest Authority,
from whom none could ap&shy;
peal. The Roman Laws
were divided into ten Tables
wherto these Decemviri added
other two, and called them
the Laws of the twelve
Tables, whereof you may
read Pomponius L&aelig;tus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decennial(a)">Decennial (<etym lang="la">decennalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to or conteining ten
yeers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decury(n)">Decury (<etym lang="la">decuria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a band
of ten souldiers. Also it sig&shy;
nified four or five bands of
souldiers, each consisting of
ten hundred horsemen, <emend err="ap">ap&shy;</emend>
pointed to be assistant to the
Judges sitting upon life and
death: also the Senators
and Judges were divided in&shy;
to Bands, called decuri&aelig;, and
the chief of them was called
Decurion . Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decurion(n)">Decurion (<etym lang="la">decurio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a <emend err="Cap"> Cap&shy;</emend>

sometimes it is used for an

drawn a cross by one Cen&shy;
ter star-wise, so it maketh

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dedalean(a)">Dedalean (<etym lang="la">d&aelig;daleus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">intri&shy;
cate or perplexed, also expert
or cunning. A derivative
from D&aelig;dalus an expert Arti&shy;
ficer, who first invented the
Saw, Axe, Sayle, and Sayle&shy;
yards for a ship, which gave
occasion for the Fable of D&aelig;&shy;
dalus his wings. &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

ling away, a revolting back,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defeizance(n)">Defeizance (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Des faire</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> to undo)</form> <xpln lang="en">and sig&shy;
nifies in our Common Law,
nothing but a condition an&shy;
nexed to an Act, as to an Ob&shy;
ligation, Recognizance or
Statute, which performed by
the Obligee or Recognizee, the
act is disabled and made void,
as if it never had been done,
Whereof you may see at large
West. part I. Sym. l.2. sect.156.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Defender of the Faith(n)">Defender of the Faith
 (<etym lang="la">Defensor Fidei</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a peculiar
title given to the Kings of En&shy;
gland by the Pope, as Catholi&shy;
cus to the King of Spain, and
Christianissimis to the French
King. It was first given by
Leo decimus to King Henry the
eight, for writing against
Martin Luther, in behalf of
the Church of Rome. The
Bull for this Title bears date
quinto Idus Octobr.1521. and
may be seen at length in the
Lord Herbert. Henry the eighth
fol.105. Stows Annals pag.
863.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defensative(n)">ADefensative</form> <xpln lang="en">is a medi&shy;
cine that keeps humors from
coming to a sore or place af&shy;
fected, or hinders the inflam&shy;
mation thereof. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deficient(a)">Deficient (<etym lang="la">deficiens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">faint&shy;
ing or failing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="definition(n)">Definition (<etym lang="la">definitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la"> est o&shy;
ratio explicans essentiam rei per
genus &amp; differentiam</term> ; a decla&shy;
ring what a thing is by a Gen&shy;
der or something that is com&shy;
mon to the thing declared, 
and to other things also, and
by a difference onely agreeing
to the thing explicated, and
distinguishing it from all
things else: Definition also is
a Decree or Determination,
as the definition of a Coun&shy;
cil.</xpln></wordentry>

which limits or determines.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="m4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="degrade(v)">Degrade (<etym lang="la">degrado</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to put
out of Office, to put from his
degree, estate, or dignity.
In Sleidans Comment you may
read the manner of degra&shy;
ding Priests to be thus. The
party to be degraded is atti&shy;
red in his Priestly Vestments,
and holds in the one hand a
Chalice filled with wine mi&shy;
xed with water, and in the
other a gilt patent with a
Wafer or bread. Then
kneeling down, the Bishops
Deputy first takes from him
all these things, commanding
him to say no more Masses.
Secondly, scraping his fingers
ends with a piece of glass, he
enjoyns him never to hallow
any thing: And thirdly,
stripping him of his Priestly
Vestments, he is cloathed
in a Lay habit, and so deli&shy;
vered into the Power of
the Secular Magistrate, if his
offence so require it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="degrandinate(v)">Degrandinate (<etym lang="la">degrandino</etym>)</form><xpln lang="en">
to hail much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="degree(n)">Degree,</form> <xpln lang="en">A term often u&shy;
sed in Astronomy and Phy&shy;
sick. In Astronomy it sig&shy;
nifies the thirtieth part of a
sign (viz.) of Aries, Taurus,
Gemini, &amp;c. for into so many
parts or degrees are all the
signs divided. In Physick it
signifies a proportion of heat,
or cold, moysture or dryness,
in the nature of simples; and
there are four such <emend err="proporti">proporti&shy;</emend>
ons or Degrees . The first
degree is so small, that it can
scarce be perceived. The 
second, that which may be
manifestly perceived without
hurting the sense. The third
that which somewhat offends
the sense. The fourth, which
so much offends, that it may
destroy the body. For ex&shy;
ample, sweet Almonds, Rice,
Bugloss, ripe Grapes, are hot in
the first degree: Parsley,
Saffron, Honey, in the se&shy;
cond degree: Cummin,
Galingal, Pepper, in the
third degree: And Garlick,
Spourge, Euphorbium in the
fourth degree. So Barley
is cold in the first degree,
Cucumbers in the second,
Sengreen in the third, and
Hemlock in the fourth de&shy;
gree. Where note, that in
heat, cold, and dryness,
there may be four degrees,
and in moisture but two. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demesne(n)">Demaine orDemeasne
(from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dominicum</etym>,
or Fr. <etym lang="fr">Demain</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Domain</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies as much as <term lang="la">Patri&shy;
monium Domini</term>. Hotoman <term lang="la">
in verbis feudalibus, verbo
Dominicum</term>, by divers Au&shy;
thorities, proves those lands
to be Dominicum, which a
man holds originally of
himself; and those to be
feodum, which he holds by
the benefit of a superior
Lord. But this word is
now most commonly used
for a distinction between
those Lands that the Lord
of a Mannor hath in his
own hands, or in the hands
of his Lessee; and such o&shy;
ther Lands appertaining to
the said Mannor, which be&shy;
long to free or Copy-hold&shy;
ers; howbeit the Copy&shy;
hold belonging to any
Mannor, is also in the o&shy;
pinion of many good Law&shy;
yers, accounted Demeasne.
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="denizen(n)">Denizen (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"><emend err="Do">Do&shy;</emend>
naison</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Donatio</term>, <term lang="la">aut quasi</term> 
Danes-son. <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">Dani filius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is in our Common-Law an
alien enfranchised here in
England by the Princes Char&shy;
ter, and inabled almost in all
respects, to do as native sub&shy;
jects do, namely to purchase
and possess Lands, to be ca&shy;
pable of any Office or dignity.
Yet it is short of Naturaliza&shy;
tion, because a stranger natu&shy;
rallized, may inherit Lands
by descent, which a man,
made onely a Denisen, can&shy;
not &amp;c. See more in Cow&shy;
el.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deodand(n)">Deodand (<etym lang="la">deodandum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
thing given or forfeited (as
it were) to God, for the pa&shy;
cification of his wrath in a
case of misadventure, where&shy;
by any Christian soul comes
to a violent end, without the
fault of any reasonable crea&shy;
ture. For example, If a horse
should strike his keeper, and
so kill him; if a man in dri&shy;
ving a Cart, and seeking to
redress any thing about it,
should so fall, as the Cart
wheel running over him,
should press him to death; If
one should be felling of a
tree, and giving warning to
company by, when the tree
were near falling, to look to
themselves, and any of them
should be slain nevertheless
by the fall of the Tree. In
the first of these cases, the 
Horse; In the second, the
Cart wheel, Cart and Horses;
and in the third, the Tree is to
be given to God, that is to
be sold and distributed to the
poor for an expiation of this
dreadful event, though ef&shy;
fected by unreasonable crea&shy;
tures. Stawnf. pl. Cor. l. I.
ca.2. And though this be
given to God, yet is it for&shy;
feited to the King by Law, as
susteining Gods person and an
Executioner in this case to see
the price of these distributed
to the poor, &amp;c. Fleta saith,
that this is sold, and the price
distributed to the poor, for
the soul of the King, his An&shy;
cestors, and all faithful peo&shy;
ple departed this life. l. I. ca
25. de submersis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="depauperate(v)">Depauperate (<etym lang="la">depaupero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to impoverish, to make or be&shy;
come poor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="depeculation(n)">Depeculation (<etym lang="la">depeculatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deponent(a)">Deponent (<etym lang="la">deponens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lay&shy;
ing down or aside: A Verb
Deponent in Grammar is so
called, because it deposeth 
or laies aside some of the
quality of a common verb
that is the passive significati&shy;
on, and the Participle in dus ;
all of which kind end in <expan type="">read</expan> as
loquor, &amp;c. 

In Chancery, and other
Courts of Justice we call
those Deponents that are sworn
to an Affidavit, or sworn
and examined upon Interro&shy;
gatories, and the Deponents
answers to such Interro&shy;
gatories are called Depositi&shy;
ons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="devise(n)">Devise ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an inven&shy;
tion or conceit in picture,
with his Motto, or Word,
born as well by Noble, and
Learned Personages, as by
Commanders in war, to no&shy;
tifie some particular conceipt,
or design of their own. And
is the same which the Italians 
(and we also from them) call
an Imprese, wherein there is
required a correspondency of
the Picture, which is as the
body, and the Motto, which
(as the soul) gives it life.
That is, the body must be of
fair representation, and the
Motto in some different lan&shy;
guage, witty, short, and an&shy;
swerable thereto, neither too
obscure, nor too plain, and
most commended, when it is
an Hemistich, or parcel of a
verse; for example, one,
who, as triumphing over the
force of Venus, depainted 


</page>

<page sig="m8r">
her Son, winged Cupid, in a
net, with this Motto, <term lang="la">Qui
capit, Capitur</term>. Likewise the
needle in the Sea compass still
moving, but to the North&shy;
point onely, with <term lang="la">Moveor im&shy;
motus</term>, notified the respective
constancy of the bearer to one
onely. 

Who desires further know&shy;
ledge in this ingenious Art,
may read The Art of making
Devises, lately translated
out of French, and Camd. Re&shy;
maines, tit. Impreses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deumo(pn)">Deumo,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Devil, or a
devillish Idol, most supersti&shy;
tiously adored by the Painims
of Calicut in the East India's.
Herb.188.</xpln></wordentry>

every one ought to do accor&shy;
ding to the rule of Law and
Reason.</xpln></wordentry>

disease, when one cannot
make water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diabolical(a)">Diabolical (<etym lang="la">diabolicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the Devil, Di&shy;
vellish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diacatholicon(n)">Diacatholicon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Electuary much used in Phy&shy;
sick, so called, because it
serves as a gentle purge for all
humors. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diaciminon(n)">Diaciminon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a compositi&shy;
on made of Simples fit to dis&shy;
solve windines in the stomack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diaconal(a)">Diaconal (<etym lang="la">diaconalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a Deacon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diadem(n)">Diadem (<etym lang="la">diadema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Kings
Crown, or Wreath for the
head; it properly signifies a
wreathed Head-band, with
which the ancient Kings were
consented, as thinking the
Crown belonged onely to the
Gods. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diagon(n)" lexeme="diagonal(n)">Diagon 
or 
Diagonal (<etym lang="la">diagonalis</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">a line which
passeth from
one corner, or one angle of a 


</page>

<page sig="m8v">
Geometrical body, to ano&shy;
ther corner or angle of the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diagram(n)">Diagram (<etym lang="la">diagramma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Title of a Book, a sentence,
or decree: Also a figure in
Geometry; And in Musick
it is called a proportion of
measures distinguished by
certain notes. Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diagraphic art(n)">Diagraphick-Art (<etym lang="la">diagra&shy;
phice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the art of painting or 
graving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dialectic art(n)">Dialectick-Art (<etym lang="la">
dialectica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the art of Logick, which
reacheth to reason or discourse
in an artificial form by En&shy;
thymems, and syllogisms in
mood and figure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dialect(n)">Dialect (<etym lang="la">dialectus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
manner of speech peculiar to
some part of a Country or
people, and differing from
the manner used by other
parts or people, yet all using
the same Radical Language,
for the main or substance of
it. In England, the Dialect,
or manner of speech in
the North, is different from
that in the South; and the
Western differs from both.
As in this example: At Lon&shy;
don we say, I would eat more
cheese if I had it, the North&shy;
ern man saith, Ay sud eat mare
cheese gin ay hader, and the
Western man saith Chud ee'at
more chiese on ich chad it:
Chud ee'at more cheese un ich
had it. 

The Grecians had five espe&shy;
cial Dialects. As 1. The
property of speech in Athens, 
called the Attick Dialect,
which was most copious and
fittest for eloquence. 2. The
Ionick, which the ancient
Writers most used. 3. The
Dorick . 4. The &AElig;olick, or
Bucolic, fittest for Poets. 5.
The common. Heyl. So e&shy;
very Country commonly
hath in divers parts of it some
difference of language, which
is called the Dialect or Sub&shy;
dialect of the place. 

In Italy, there are above
eight several Dialects or Sub&shy;
dialects, as the Roman, the
Toscan, the Venetian, the Mi&shy;
lanex, the Neopolitan, the Ca&shy;
labresse, the Genoevais, the
Piomontez, besides the Corsi&shy;
can, Sicilian, and other
neighboring Islands, &amp;c.
Mr. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dial(a)">Diale (<etym lang="la">dialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to the day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diallel(a)">Diallel,</form> <xpln lang="en">As parallels are
lines running one by the o&shy;
ther without meeting : So
Diallels are lines which run
one through the other, that
is, do cross, intersecate, or cut.
El. Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dialogue(n)">Dialogue (<etym lang="la">dialogus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a com&shy;
munication, reasoning or dis&shy;
putation between two parties
or more, or a written Dis&shy;
course, where such a Con&shy;
ference is set down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dialogical(a)">Dialogical (<etym lang="la">dialogicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or perttaining to a Dia&shy;
logue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dialogism(n)">Dialogism (<etym lang="la">dialogismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
figure or discourse, when
one discusseth a thing by him&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="n1r">
self, as it were talking with
another, does move the que&shy;
stion and make the answer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diameter(n)">Diameter ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
certain streight line drawn
through the center of a figure
and of both sides bounded in
the compass of it, which cuts
or divides the figure into two
equal parts. Euclid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diametrical(a)">Diametrical (<etym lang="la">diametricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to such a Dia&shy;
meter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Diana(pn)">Diana,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Moon; Al&shy;
so a goddess of hunting,
much honored for her cha&shy;
stity, having had many
Temples dedicated to her;
whereof the chief was that
at Ephesus, called the Tem&shy;
ple of Diana, which for the
spaciousness, furniture and
workmanship, was accoun&shy;
ted one of the worlds won&shy;
ders; It was 200 years in
building, contrived by Cte&shy;
siphon, being 425 foot
long, and 220 broad, sustained
with 127 pillars of marble
70 foot high, whereof 27
were most curiously graven,
and all the rest of marble po&shy;
lisht. It was fired seven
times, and lastly by Herostratus
(that night in which Alexan&shy;
der was born) to get himself a
name. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diapasm(n)">Diapasm (<etym lang="la">diapasma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a per&shy;
fume, a pomander, a medi&shy;
cine of dry powders, that
is either cast among Appar&shy;
rel to make them smel sweet,
or into a wound, or super&shy;
flously into drink. Rid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diapase(n)" lexeme="diapason(n)">Diapase orDiapason
( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a concord of all in mu&shy;
sick: An eighth. See a
further explanation of this
in Lord Bacons Natural Hist.
fo.30.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diapered(a)">Diaperd orDiapred (Fr:
<etym lang="fr">diapre</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">diversified with flou&shy;
rishes or sundry figures,
whence we call Cloth that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diaphanity(n)">Diaphanity (from <etym lang="la">diapha&shy;

half a year, had a Kings

under pain of Treason yeel&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Didymus(pn)">Didymus (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class>

or charity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dilemma(n)">Dilemma ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
Argument called by Logi&shy;
cians Cornutum Argumentum,
which convinceth ones ad&shy;
versary both wayes, as in say&shy;
ing; If he be a good man,
why do you speak evil of him?
if naught, why do you keep him
company? 

There is a Tradition of a
Dilemma, that Bishop Morton
(Chancellor to H.7.) used, to
raise up the Benevolence to
higher rates, and some called
it his Fork, &amp; some his Crotch ;
for he had concluded an Ar&shy;
ticle in the Instructions to the
Commissioners, who were to
levy the Benevolence ; That if
they met with any that were spa&shy;
ring, they should tell them, they
must needs have, because they laid
up; And if they were spenders,
they must needs have, because it
was seen in their port and man&shy;
ner of living. L. Bac. Hen :7.
p.101.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dilling(n)">Dilling (<etym lang="la">proculus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a child
born when the Father is old,
or the last child that Parents
have; in some places called a
Swil-pough.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dilogy(n)">Dilogy (<etym lang="la">dilogia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a <emend err="doubt">doubt&shy;</emend>
ful speech, which may signifie
or be construed two ways.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diloricate(v)">Diloricate (<etym lang="la">dilorico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to un&shy;
do, cut or rip a coat that is
sewed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dilucid(a)">Dilucid (<etym lang="la">dilucidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">clear,
light, manifest, easie to be dis&shy;
cerned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dilucidate(v)">Dilucidate (<etym lang="la">dilucido</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to de&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dilution(n)">Dilution (<etym lang="la">dilutio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wash&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diminution(n)">Diminution (<etym lang="la">diminutio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diminutive(n)">Diminutive (<etym lang="la">diminutivum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is diminished or
made lesse; or the lesser of
that whereof there is a big&shy;
ger. As Libellus, a little book,
and F&oelig;mella a little woman,
are the Diminutives of Liber 
and F&oelig;mina. So is Rivolet, of
a River.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dinarchy(n)">Dinarchy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the joynt
Rule or Government of two
Princes.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="n3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diocese(n)">Dioces (<etym lang="la">di&oelig;cesis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Greek
word compounded of <etym lang="gk">&delta;&iota;&#x1f70;</etym> and
<etym lang="gk">&#x1f42;&iota;&kappa;&eta;&#x03c3;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, and signifies with us
the Circuit of every Bishops
Jurisdiction. For this Na&shy;
tion hath two sorts of divisi&shy;
ons: one into Shires or Coun&shy;
ties, in respect of temporal
Policy; another into Dio&shy;
cesses, in respect of jurisdicti&shy;
on Ecclesiastical. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diocesan(a)">Diocesan (<etym lang="la">di&oelig;cesanus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that hath the Jurisdiction
of a Diocess; or hee that
Inhabites within a Dio&shy;
dess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Diogenes(pn)">Diogenes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Philoso&shy;
pher, who for his dogged
disposition, was Sir-na&shy;
med the Cynick . Hence it
is wee call this or that
man, who is of a churlish
or harsh disposition, a Dio&shy;
genes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dionymal(a)">Dionymal (<etym lang="la">dionymus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath two names.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dioptic art(n)">TheDioptick Art (<etym lang="la"><emend err="diop"> diop&shy;</emend>
tice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Perspective Art, or
that part of Astronomy,
which by Quadrants and hol&shy;
low instruments pierces the
Heavens, and measures the
distance, length, bigness, and
breadth of the C&oelig;lestial bo&shy;
dies. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dioptrical(a)">Dioptrical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
Dioptra, which is a measure to
weigh water; a Quadrat,
or Geometrical Instrument,
wherewith the distance and
height of a place is known a&shy;
far off, by looking through
certain little holes there&shy;
in; The looking-hole or 
sight of any instrument. Dr.
Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diple(n)">Diple,</form> <xpln lang="en">a note or mark
in the Margent to signifie
that there is somewhat to be
amended. Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dipondiary(a)">Dipondiary (<etym lang="la">dipondiari&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is of two pound

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dipsas(n)">Dipsades (<etym lang="la">dipsas, adis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kind of Snakes, whose
biting (consuming the hu&shy;
mors of mans body) causeth
a mortal thirst in the party
bitten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diphthong(n)">Diphthong (<etym lang="la">diphthongus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
two vowels contracted into
one body or form, whereof
in the Latin tongue there are
five, &aelig;, au, &oelig;, eu, ei.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diptic(a)">Diptyck (<etym lang="la">diptychus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">having

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dire(a)">Dire (<etym lang="la">dirus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cruel, terri&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dirge(n)">Dirge (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">a corruption from

nifies the office of the dead,

Catholicks for the souls in
Purgatory, and is so called
from the first word of the

which is Dirige.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="directory(n)">Directory (from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Dirigo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the name of a
book introduced by the late
long Parliament in the
stead of the Common Prayer
Book, which was voted down
on the 26 of November, 1644, 


</page>

<page sig="n3v">
and is called a Directory, be&shy;
cause it directs the Ministers 
and people in a different way
of praying, preaching and
administring the Sacraments.</xpln></wordentry>

um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a place wherein Souldi&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="direption(n)">Direption (<etym lang="la">direptio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a rob&shy;

king it away; properly in the

when all things lye open to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disme(n)">Dismes (<etym lang="la">decim&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Tythe,
or the tenth part of all the
fruits, either of the earth or
beasts, or our labor due to
God, and consequently to
him that is of the Lords lot, 
and hath his share, (viz.) our
Pastor. It signifies also the
tenths of all spiritual livings,
yearly given to the Prince,
called a perpetual Disme. A.2.
and 3. Edw.6. ca.35. which
in ancient times were paid to
the Pope, till Pope Urban
gave them to Richard the se&shy;
ond, to aid him against
Charls the French King, and
those other that upheld Cle&shy;
ment the seventh against him.
Pol. Virg. li.20. Lastly, it sig&shy;
nifieth a tribute levied of the
temporality. Holinshed fol.
111.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dispauper(n)">Dispauper,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a word most
used in the Court of Chance&shy;
ry, as when one is admitted
to sue in forma pauperis, if that
privilege be taken from him,
he is said to be Dispaupered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dissimilar(n)" lexeme="dissimilary(n)">Dissimilar

Dissimilary parts; (<etym lang="la">dissi&shy;
milares par&shy;
tes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are
those parts of a mans body,
which are unlike in nature
one to another, as the head,
Hands, Feet, Heart, Liver, &amp;c.
And the similary parts are
those which are of like nature,
as the skin, nerves, fat, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

or spread abroad, to disperse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discheveled(a)">Dissheviled, orDische&shy;
veled (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French</class> <etym lang="fr"> des&shy;
chevel&eacute;</etym> an old word used by
Chaucer, and yet still in use,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">and signifies as much as bare&shy;
headed, bare-haired, or the 
hair hanging down disorder&shy;
ly about the ears. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dischevel(v)">To Dischevel (Fr. <etym lang="fr">desche&shy;
veler</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to loose, disorder, scat&shy;
ter or pull the hair about the
ears. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dissology(n)">Dissology (<etym lang="la">dissologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
speech of two.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dissoluble(n)">Dissoluble (<etym lang="la">dissolubilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">easie
to be loosed or dissolved.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dissonance(n)">Dissonance (<etym lang="la">dissonantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dissyllable(n)">Dissyllable (<etym lang="la">dissyllabus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
word of two syllables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distantial(a)">Distantial (<etym lang="la">distans, antis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
differing or distant, far asun&shy;
der, divers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distend(v)">Distend (<etym lang="la">distendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to stretch
or reach out; to enlarge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distention(n)">Distention (<etym lang="la">distentio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distich(n)">Distick (<etym lang="la">distichon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a double

verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distil(v)">Distil (<etym lang="la">distillo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to drop

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distortion(n)">Distortion (<etym lang="la">distortio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wre&shy;
sting, writhing or crookedness.
Feltham uses the word Distor&shy;
quement in the same sence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distress(n)">Distress (<etym lang="la">districtio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
most commonly in the Com&shy;
mon Law, a compulsion in
certain real actions whereby to
bring a man to apparence in
Court, or to pay debt, or duty
denied. The effect whereof
most commonly is, to drive
the party distrained to Re&shy;
plieve the distress, and so to
take his action of trespass a&shy;
gainst the distreiner, or else to
compound neighborly with 


</page>

<page sig="n5r">
him for the debt or duty for
which he distrains; In what
cases a distress is lawful. See
The new terms of Law. Verbo
distresse. Sometimes it signi&shy;
fies great affliction or mise&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="districate(v)">Districate (from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">districare</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to rid out of trouble
or incumbrance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distringent(n)">Distringent (<etym lang="la">distringens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that rubs or wipes off, or that
troubleth greatly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disveloped(a)">Disveloped (from the Fr.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dithyrambic(n)">Dithyrambick (<etym lang="la">dithyram&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ditty(n)">Ditty (from the Ital. <etym lang="it">detto</etym>,

in words, and sung to a musi&shy;
cal tune. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divagation(n)">Divagation (<etym lang="la">divagatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

bout.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dival(a)">Dival (<etym lang="la">divalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">divine, be&shy;
longing to the Gods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divan(n)">Divan 
Divano</form> <xpln lang="en">a Judgment-hal,
a great Court of
Law or Justice among the
Turks and Persians, not much
unlike or inferior to our Par&shy;
liament, of which there is one
held in every Province; But
the chief Divan or Tribunal
of Justice is held in the
Great Turks Palace at Con&shy;
stantinople, the four first days
of every week. Hist. of Fran.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divaricate(v)">Divaricate (<etym lang="la">divarico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
stride or spread wide one
from another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divelied(a)">Divelled (from <etym lang="la">Divello</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pulled away, or asunder, un&shy;
done, ravished. Felth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diventilate(v)">Diventiliate (<etym lang="la">diventilo </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
fan or winnow Corn with a
Wind-fan, also to turn
out of one hand into ano&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diverberate(v)">Diverberate (<etym lang="la">
diverbero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
strike, beat or cut.</xpln></wordentry>

quens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that varieth or speaks
diversly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diverticle(n)">Diverticle (<etym lang="la">diverticulum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dividend(n)">Dividend,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Exche&shy;
quer seems to be one part of
an Indenture. An.19. Ed I.
ca.11. and 28. ejusdem, Stat.3.
ca.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divident(n)">Divident (from <etym lang="la">divido</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in
the University is that share
which every one of the Fel&shy;
lows does equally and justly
divide, either by an Arith&shy;
metical or Geometrical pro&shy;
portion of their annual sti&shy;
pend. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dividual(n)">Dividual (<etym lang="la">dividuus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be severed or divi&shy;
ded.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dividuity(n)">Dividuity (<etym lang="la">dividuitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
division, also an aptness to
divide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divination(n)">Divination (<etym lang="la">divinatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
presage or foretelling of
things to come; which may be
divided into three different
kinds (viz.) supernatural, na&shy;
tural and superstitious. Su&shy;
pernatural Divination (onely re&shy;
vealed to man by God) is not 


</page>

<page sig="n5v">
properly called Divination,
but Prophecy, with which
all the holy Prophets have
in former times been inspired.
Natural Divination, may be
divided into two branches;
whereof the first is that
which hath in former times
been practised by wicked spi&shy;
rits in Oracles and Answers
given by them in Idols, and
is at this day sometime seen
in possessed persons, who by
suggestion of the Devil may
foretel things to come, and
this is but a Natural Divinati&shy;
on : For though to us it seem
miraculous, because of our
ignorance in the causes and
courses of things, yet in
those spirits it is but natural,
who by their long experience
and great observation, besides
the knowledge of secrets in
nature, and their quick in&shy;
telligence from all places, are
able to fore-see much more,
then we by nature can. The
second Branch of Natural Di&shy;
vination is that, which a wise
man may foretel by probable
conjecture, being no way of&shy;
fensive, so long as it is onely
guided by reason, and over&shy;
ruled by submitting it self to
the Almighty power of God.
And to this second kind of
Divination, Astrology may
also be referred which (by the
motion and influence of Stars
and Planets) promises to
foretel many things, so long
as it keeps it self in due limits
and arrogates not too much 
to the certainty thereof; in&shy;
to which excess of vanity, if
it once break forth, it is then
no longer called natural Di&shy;
vination, but superstitious and
wicked. For the Stars may
incline, but not impose a ne&shy;
cessity in particular things.
The third and last manner of
Divination is that which we
call Superstitious, whereof
there has been among the
Gentiles divers different
kinds. As namely, Augury,
by the flying, feeding, and
chirping of Birds. Alphito&shy;
mancy, by Barly meal. A&shy; 
ruspicy, by opening and view&shy;
ing the bowels of Beasts.
Necromancy, by calling up De&shy;
vils, or dead mens Ghosts,
Geomancy, by making cer&shy; 
tain circles and lines in the
earth. Hydromancy, by some
apparition in water. Pyro&shy;
mancy, by the fire, or by spirits
appearing in the fire. Palmi&shy;
stry or Chiromancy, by look&shy;
ing on the lines of the fingers
and hands. Coscinomancy, by
a Sieve. Aeromancy, by the
Air. Capnomancy, by the fly&shy;
ing of smoak. Catoptromancy,
by visions in a glass. Sorcery 
or Cleromancy, by lots. Ar&shy;
momancy, by the shoulders of
beasts. Axiomancy, by Hatchets.
Daphnomancy, by a Lawrel or
Bay tree. Alectryomancy, by
a Cock. Alebromancy, by Bar&shy;
ly meal mixed with Wheat.
Batanomancy, by vertue of
hearbs. Cephaleonomancy, by
an Asses head broiled on 


</page>

<page sig="n6r">
coals. Ceromantie, by wax
put into water. Lithomancy,
by a stone. Belomancy, by ar&shy;
rows. Libanomancy, by In&shy;
cense or Frankincense. Me&shy;
topomancy, by the face. Ne&shy;
cyomancy, by conference with
dead bodies raised, &amp;c. 

All which being by the
Pagans themselves accounted
deceitful and vain, it remains
that of Christians they be
utterly rejected and abhor
red. 

Of the nature and definiti&shy;
on of Divination, see more in
my Lord Bacons advan. of
learning p.209.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divinize(v)">Divinize.</form> <xpln lang="en">To make divine
or heavenly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divinipotent(n)">Divinipotent (<etym lang="la">divinipotens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath power in divine
things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divitiate(v)">Divitiate (<etym lang="la">divito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to en&shy;
rich, or make rich. Felth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divitiosity(n)">Divitiosity (<etym lang="la">divitiositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
abundance of riches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divorce(n)">Divorce (<etym lang="la">divortium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
dissolution of marriage, a se&shy;
paration of man and Wife,
which was (as our Saviour
witnesseth, Matth.19.8.) first
permitted by Moses to the
Israelites, Deut.24.1. for the
hardness of their hearts, that
men might rather put their
Wives away, whom they
grew weary of, then use them
with too great extremity to
shorten their lives, as many
did; The woman so divor&shy;
ced was to have of her Hus&shy;
band a writing (asSt. Hierom
and Joseph, witness in l. de ant. 
4. c.8.) to this effect, I promise
that hereafter I will lay no claim
to thee, and this writing was
called a Bill of Divorce . But
with Christians this custom is
abrogated, saving onely in
case of Adultery. The anci&shy;
ent Romans also had a custom
of Divorce, among whom it
was as lawful for the Wife to
put away her Husband, as for
the Husband to dismiss his
Wife; But among the Israelites 
this prerogative was onely
permitted to the Husband.
Bull.<xref> See Repudiate</xref>. 

In our Common Law, Di&shy;
vorce is accounted that sepa&shy;
ration between two de facto 
married together, which is
&agrave; vinculo Matrimonii, non solum
&agrave; mensa &amp; thoro . And there&shy;
fore the woman, so divorced
received all again that she
brought with her. This is
not but onely upon a nullity
of the marriage through some
essential impediment, as con&shy;
sanguinity or affinity within
the degrees forbidden, pre&shy;
contract, impotency, or such
like. See the new terms of
Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diuretical(a)">Diuretical (<etym lang="la">diureticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
provokes one to piss, that
hath the power or property
to make one piss, or to pro&shy;
voke Urine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diurnal(a)">Diurnal (<etym lang="la">diurnalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;
ing to the day, or to a Pam&shy;
phlet so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diurnal(a)">Diurnal (<etym lang="la">diurnum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">taken
substantively is a Day-book,
or Register of every days 


</page>

<page sig="n6v">
business, news, or action.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diuturnity(n)">Diuturnity (<etym lang="la">diuturnitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
long space of time, long con&shy;
tinuance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divulgate(v)">Divulgate (<etym lang="la">divulgo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pub&shy;
lish or make common.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divulsion(n)">Divulsion (<etym lang="la">divulsio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
pulling in peeces, or asunder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dizain(n)">Dizain ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the num&shy;
ber of ten, the tenth : Al&shy;
so a ditty of ten Stanzaes,
or Stanza of ten verses:
Also a French penny. And
sometimes it is taken for a
pair of beads of ten courses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="docket(n)">Docket,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Brief in wri&shy;
ting. An.2. and 3. P.  &amp;
Ma. ca.6. West writes it Dog&shy;
get, by whom it seems to be
some smal peece of paper or
parchment containing the ef&shy;
fect of a larger writing. Sym.
part.2. tit. Fines. Sect.106.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="docible(a)">Docible (<etym lang="la">docibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">apt to
be taught.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="docibility(n)">Docibility (<etym lang="la">docibilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ea&shy;
siness to be taught, aptness
to learn, quickness of appre&shy;
hension.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="docilize(v)">Docilize (from <etym lang="la">doceo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
docible, tractable, teachable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doctiloquent(n)">Doctiloquent (<etym lang="la">doctiloquus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that speaks learnedly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dodecatemory(n)"><emend err="Dodecatamerie" source="errata">Dodecatemory</emend> ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
in Astrology, signifying a
twelfth part, and is most com&shy;
monly applied to the division
of the Zodiack into 12 signs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dodechedron(n)">Dodech&aelig;dron ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure
of 12 angles or corners, a
twelve-cornered proportion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dodona(pn)">Dodona,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City of Epirus 
near which stood a Grove of
Oaks onely dedicated to Ju&shy;
piter, called Dodona' s Grove,
the Oaks were said to speak,
and were wont to give oracu&shy;
lous answers to those that
came to consult them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dodrantal(a)">Dodrantal (<etym lang="la">dodrantalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
nine ounces or nine inches in
length or weight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dog days(n)">Dog-days, or Canicular days 
( <etym lang="la">dies caniculares</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">certain days
in July and August, so called
of the Star Canis, or the Dog&shy;
star, which then (rising with
the Sun) is predominant and
greatly increaseth the heat
thereof. During the time this
Dog-star reigns, the River Ni&shy;
lus in &AElig;gypt overflows his
banks, as though the waters
were led by that star. Min.
See Vul. Err. upon this subject,
fo.221. And the first part of
the Treasury of times. fo. 72.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doge(n)">Doge,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the title of dignity
belonging to the supream
Magistrate among Venetians,
who is also called a Duke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dog-draw(n)">Dogdraw,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a manifest
deprehension of an offendor
against Venison in the Forrest.
There be four of these noted
by Mr. Manw. part2. of his
Forrest Laws, c.18. viz Stable&shy;
stand, Dog-draw, Back-bear, and
Bloody-hand . Dog-draw is when
one is found drawing after a
Deer by the scent of a Hound
that he leads in his hand, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dogmatical(a)">Dogmatical (<etym lang="la">dogmaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
prudent, wise, learned, belong&shy;
ing to points of learning or
doctrine.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="n7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dogmatist(n)">Dogmatist (<etym lang="la">dogmatistes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that induceth any new Sect
or Opinion, one that makes or
would try conclusions, a
forger of new Sects.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dogmatize(v)">Dogmatize (<etym lang="la">dogmatizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
instruct or teach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dolation(n)">Dolation (<etym lang="la">dolatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a smoo&shy;
thing or making even.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dole(n)">Dole (<etym lang="la">dolus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">deceipt, trea&shy;
chery, guile. If from (<etym lang="la">dolor</etym>)
then grief or sorrow. We al&shy;
so call Alms distributed to the
poor at a Funeral, Dole, <term lang="la">quasi</term>
Deal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dollar(n)">Dollar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dutch coyn
worth about 4 s. or 4 s. 4 d.
of our money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dolorous(a)">Dolorous (<etym lang="la">dolorosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full of
grief, sorrow, or pain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dolphin(pn)">Dolphin (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Dauphin</etym>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the eldest Son of France, cal&shy;
led so of Daulphine, a Province
given, or (as some report) sold
in the year 1349 by Humbert
Earl thereof to Philip de Va&shy;
lois, partly on condition, that
for ever the French K. eldest
Son should hold it (during his
Fathers life) of the Empire. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domable(a)">Domable (<etym lang="la">domabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">easie
to be tamed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domestical(a)" lexeme="domestic(a)">Domestical 
Domestick  (<etym lang="la">domesticus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
the houshold, tame, fami&shy;
liar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dome(n)">ADome (from <etym lang="la">domus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Town-house, guild Hall,
State-house, Meeting-house
in a City, from that of Flo&shy;
rence, which is so called. Also
a flat round Loover, or open
roof to a Steeple, Banqueting&shy;
house, &amp;c. Somewhat re&shy; 
sembling the bell of a great
Watch. Merc. Ital.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dolman(n)">Dolyman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Turkish Gown,
long coat, or upper Garment,
closed with long buttons
down to the girdle-stead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domicile(n)">Domicil (<etym lang="la">domicilium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
mansion-house, or dwelling
place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domination(n)">Domination (<etym lang="la">dominatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Dominion, Rule, or Authori&shy;
ty over others.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Domination(pn)">Dominations,</form> <xpln lang="en">are one of
the nine Quiers of Angels
mentioned by St. Paul, Col.
1.16.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domini(n)" lexeme="anno domini(n)">Domini orAnno Domini,</form> <xpln lang="en">
is the computation of time
from the Incarnation of our
Saviour Jesus Christ. As
the Romans made their com&shy;
putation of time from the
building the City of Rome;
and the Grecians numbered
their years by the Olympiads 
or Games called Olympick.
So Christians, in remembrance
of the happy incarnation, and
blessed birth of our Savior,
reckon the time from his Na&shy;
tivity. Min.<xref> See Epoch</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dominical(a)">Dominical (<etym lang="la">dominicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to the Lord and
Master. The Dominical Letter 
in Calendars is so called
from a kind of preheminence
it hath above the rest of the
Letters, in token whereof it
is of red colour, represen&shy;
ting the purple, which is a
robe of dignity: or rather,
because it shews the Domini&shy;
cal or Lords day throughout
the year. Min.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="n7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dominicans(pn)">Dominicans,</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise
called preaching or Black
Fryers, a religious Order in&shy;
stituted by St. Dominick a
Spaniard, about the year
1206, he then sent his associ&shy;
ates to preach the Gospel
even to the furthest parts of
the world then known, which
they did with great success,
and their Successors since
have done, and do still even
in India and America: this
Order was confirmed by Pope
Honorius the third about the
year 1216.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domino(n)">Domino,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of hood
or habit for the head, worn
by Canons; and hence also
a fashion of vail used by some
women that mourn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dominicide(n)">Dominicide (<etym lang="la">dominicida</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
he that kils his Master.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="domition(n)" lexeme="domiture(n)">Domition 
or 
Domiture (<etym lang="la">domitura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
taming or
breaking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Donatists(pn)">Donatists,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect of Here&shy;
ticks, so called from Donatus
Bishop of Carthage, the first
broacher of that Heresie, who
lived about the year 358, in
the time of Pope Liberius, and
the Emperor Constantine.
Their prime tenet was, that
the true Church was onely in
Africk, and that out of A&shy;
frick there was no true Bap&shy;
tism; they held also that the
Son in the mystery of the
Blessed Trinity, was less
then the Father, and the
Holy Ghost less then the Son,
with other damnable points,
&amp;c.<xref target="circumcelians"> See Circumcellians</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="donative(n)">Donative (<etym lang="la">donativum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Princes benevolence or gift.
A Donative Benefice, is that
which is meerly given and
collated by the Patron to a
man, without either presen&shy;
tation to, or institution by
the Ordinary, or Induction by
his commandement. Fitzh.
nat. br. fo. 35. E. See the Sta&shy;
tute A.8. R.2. ca.4.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="donative(a)">Donative (<etym lang="la">donativus</etym> <class type="pos">ad&shy;
jectively</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is able or apt
to give.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doniferous(a)">Doniferous (<etym lang="la">donifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
carries a gift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="donor(n)">Donor</form> <xpln lang="en">(in our Common
Law) signifies the giver, and
Donee he or she to whom a
gift is given.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Doomsday Book(pn)">Doomssday-book,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old
Book made in the time of
Will. the Conqueror. and kept
in the Tower of London<emend err="" source="errata">in the Exchequer</emend>,
wherein all the ancient De&shy;
mean Lands of this Nation are
registred; It is so called, be&shy;
cause upon any difference,
the parties received their
doom <emend err="" source="errata">from ot</emend>. Others (less proba&shy;
bly) say tis called Dooms-day
Book, <term lang="la">Quasi</term> <term lang="la">domus Dei Book</term>;
But to confirm the former E&shy;
tymology, it is called in Latin,
<term lang="la">Liber Judiciarius</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dorado(n)">Dorado ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a thing
guilded or guilt. It is used
(in Religio medici fo.135.) for
a man that hath a fair out&shy;
side, but no qualities or good
parts within.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Doric dialect(n)">Dorick Dialect (<etym lang="la">dialectus
Dorica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the 5 Dialects
of the Gr. a tongue. <expan type="">videlicet</expan> <xref>Dialect</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="n8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Doric work(n)">Dorick-work,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a term in
Architecture, and signifies
one of the five orders of Pil&shy;
lars, mentioned by Vitruvius.
See <xref> Tuscan.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Doric music(n)">Dorick Musick (<etym lang="la">Dorica
musica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a king of grave and
solemn Musick, and therefore
assigned to great Persona&shy;
ges.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dormant(a)">Dormant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Heraldry, as a Lion dormant, <expan type="">id est</expan>
a Lyon sleeping, or lying
in a sleeping posture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dormitive(a)">Dormitive (from <etym lang="la">dormio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
causeth sleep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dorp(n)">Dorp (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg</class>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village or
Country Town.<xref> See Thorp</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dortor(n)" lexeme="dormitory(n)">ADorter,Dortoire or
Dormitory (<etym lang="la">dormitorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
place where many sleep toge&shy;
ther, so was the place anci&shy;
ently and still is called, where
religious persons are wont to
take their nights rest in their
Covents, many in the same
room.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dose(n)">Dose ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the quantity
of Potion or Medicine which
a Physitian appoints his pa&shy;
tient shall take at once.
Cotgr.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dodkin(n)"><emend err="Dothin" source="errata">Dotkin</emend>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a thing of smal
value, a kind of coyn (Stawmf.
pl. cor. fo.37.) it seems to come
of the Dutch word <term lang="du">Duytken</term>,
that is, the eighth part of a
Styfer or French shilling, of
which Styfers ten in the Low
Countries or ten Sols in
France, are of the same va&shy;
lue with an English shilling,
viz. twelve pence. Min.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dovetailed(a)">Dovetaild,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a term a&shy; 
mong Joyners, and signifies
that particular sort of joyning
bords together; so called,
when one peece of the one
goes into, or mingles with
the other, and is much bet&shy;
ter, and is more costly then
a common, plain, joyning
boards together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doublet(n)">Doublet ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a counter&shy;
feit Jewel or stone of two
peeces, joyned or glewed
together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dotal(a)">Dotal (<etym lang="la">dotalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to a Dowry or Joynture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dovane(pn)">Dovane ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr</class> <etym lang="fr">Do&uuml;ane</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
name of the Custom-house of
Lyons; hence also any Custom
or Impost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dowager(n)">Dowager (<etym lang="la">dotata</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wi&shy;
dow indowed, or that hath
a Joynture; a Title applied
to the Widows of Princes,
and great Personages onely.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="downs(n)">Downes,</form> <xpln lang="en">With us hath
two significations; the one,
certain hilly Plains in the
West <emend err="Counrry">Country</emend>, so called;
and this Down comes from the
old Sax.Dune <expan type="">id est</expan> a hill, com&shy;
monly that stretcheth it self
out in length: The other a
certain part of the Sea lying
near the Sands upon the coast
of Kent, where commonly
our English Navy rides; and
this we borrow from the
Hollanders, who call the
Sandbanks, which lye on the
sea-side, theDunes; And the
Town of Dunkirk, rightly
in English, Dun-Church, took
denomination from its being
scituate in theDunes or 


</page>

<page sig="n8v">
Sand-banks of the Sea.
Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dower(n)" lexeme="dowry(n)">Dower 
Dowry  (<etym lang="la">dos</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
in our Common
Law two things, First, That
which the Wife brings to her
Husband in marriage, other&shy;
wise called Maritagium, Mar&shy;
riage good. Next, and more
commonly, that which she
hath of her Husband, after
the Marriage determined, if
she out live him. Glanvile l.
7. ca.2. Bracton l.2. ca.38. See
more in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dowsets(n)">Dowsets,</form> <xpln lang="en">The stones of a
Stag or Buck, so called by
Hunts-men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doxology(n)">Doxology ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a song
of praise, a speaking or giving
glory; As when we say, Glory
be to the Father, &amp;c. that is
properly Doxology, and is said
to be composed by the first
Council of Nice, and St. Je&shy;
rome, to be the Author of
adding the other Versicle,
As it was in the beginning, &amp;c.
View of Directory, fo. 32.
33.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doxy(n)">Doxie,</form> <xpln lang="en">a she Rogue, a
woman Beggar, a lowzie
Quean.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Draco's laws(n)">Draco's Laws,</form> <xpln lang="en">Laws,
which for being extream se&shy;
vere and cruel, are therefore
said to be written rather with
blood then inke, such are
those that punish trivial of&shy;
fences with death, or some
other excessive torment. So
called from Draco an anci&shy;
ent and severe Law-maker
in Athens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dram(n)">Dram (<etym lang="la">drachma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
eighth part of an ounce, it
contains in it three Scruples,
every scruple being of the
weight of twenty wheat
corns: So that a Dram is the
just weight of 60 corns of
wheat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dramatic(a)">Dramatick (<etym lang="la">dramaticum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of Poetry, when the
persons are every one adorned
and brought upon the Thea&shy;
ter, to speak and act their
own parts. Hobbs.<xref lexeme="poesy"> See
Poesie</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Drap-de-Berry(n)">Drap-de-Berrie,</form> <xpln lang="en">a thick
kind of cloth so called, for
that it was first made in
the Country of Berrie in
France.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drapery(n)">Drapery (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">so called of the
French word</class> <etym lang="fr">Drap</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> cloth)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a term which Painters use,
consisting principally in the
true making and folding a
Garment in drawing or limn&shy;
ing, giving to every fold his
proper natural doubling and
shadow. Peacham. See <xref>Si&shy;
lerie</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drift(a)" lexeme="adrift(a)">Drift ora-Drift,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
among Water-men, and sig&shy;
nifies the floating of a Boat
alone without any person in
it, to row or steer it, but is
carried to and fro with the
Tyde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drill(n)">Dril,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Stone-cutters tool,
wherewith he bores little
holes in Marble, &amp;c. Also a
large over-grown Ape, or Ba&shy;
boon, so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dragoman(n)">Drogoman</form> <xpln lang="en">(or Draguman)
an Interpreter or Truch&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="o1r">
man, the word is used by the
Turks <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&delta;&rho;&alpha;&gamma;&#x03cc;&mu;&epsilon;&shy;
&nu;&omicron;&#x03c3;</etym>: The Fr. write it <term lang="fr">Drogue&shy;
man</term> . See <xref target="Truch man">Truchman.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dromedary(n)">Dromedary (<etym lang="la">dromas, adis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kind of Camel with two
bunches on his back, very
swift, being able to carry a
man 100 miles a day, and may
abide three days journey
without drink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="droll(n)">ADrole ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a good&shy;
fellow, boon companion,
merry grig; one that cares
not how the world goes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drollery(n)">Drolerie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is with
us taken for a kinde of face&shy;
tious way of speaking or wri&shy;
ating, full of merry knavish
wit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dropacist(n)">Dropacist (<etym lang="la">dropacista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that pulls off hair and makes
the body bare.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Druids(pn)">Druids (<etym lang="la">Druides</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">certain
Prophets or learned Pagan 
Priests that lived naked in
woods, giving themselves to
the study of Philosophy, and
avoiding al company as much
as they might : they were of
such estimation among the
people, that all controversies
were referred to their deter&shy;
mination, and a great penalty
laid on such as disobeyed
their sentence. They belie&shy;
ved the immortality of the
Soul, but supposed (with Py&shy;
thagoras) that they still passed
by death, from one body to
another. C&aelig;sar lib.6. de bello
Gal. They took their name
from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1f7a;&#x03c2;</etym>, an Oake, because
they held nothing more holy
then an Oak, which was also
sacred to Jupiter, or because
they were wont to exercise
their superstition in Oken
groves, when Lucan lib.
7: 
 <term lang="la"> ----- Nemora alta remotis
Incolitis lucis, ---- Antiqu. Hiber.</term> pag.27. 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dryad(n)">Dryads (<etym lang="la">dryades</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">nymphs
of the woods, or wood-fai&shy;
ries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dual(a)">Dual (<etym lang="la">dualis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to the number two.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duality(n)">Duality (<etym lang="la">dualitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
number two, duplicity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="divan(n)">Duana.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Divano</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duarchy(n)">Duarchy<etym lang="la"> (Duarchia </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
government wherein two go&shy;
vern joyntly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dubiosity(n)">Dubiosity (from <etym lang="la">dubiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ducal(a)">Ducal (<etym lang="la">ducalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath

like, of or belonging to a
Duke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ducket(n)">Ducket (<etym lang="la">ducalis aureus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
certain gold coyn, which was
first coyned in Rome, in the
yeer of the City 547. and
afterwards it began to be
used in other places. So
called, because it bore the
image of a Duke, and is
worth about six shillings
and eight pence.. Pol. Virg.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulcacid(a)">Dulcacid (<etym lang="la">dulcacidus</etym> <emend err=")"></emend> <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="la">
