<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulciloquent(a)">Dulciloquent (<etym lang="la">dulciloquus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that speaks sweetly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulcimer(n)">Dulcimer orDulcimel
 (<etym lang="la">sambuca</etym>) so called <term lang="la">quasi</term>, <etym lang="la">dulce
melos</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> sweet melody)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mu&shy;
sical instrument.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulcarnon(n)">Dulcarnon</form> <xpln lang="en">is a proporti&shy;
on in Euclid (lib. I. Theorem.33. 
Propos.47.) which was found
out by Pythagoras after a whole
yeers study, and much beat&shy;
ing of his brain; in thank&shy;
fulness whereof, he sacrificed
an Oxe to the Gods; which
Sacrifice he called Dulcarnon.
Alex. Neckam an ancient wri&shy;
ter in his book de naturis re&shy;
rum, compounds this word of
Dulia and caro, and will have
Dulcarnon to be <term lang="la">quasi</term> <term lang="la">Sacrifici&shy;
um carnis</term>. Chaucer aptly ap&shy;
plies it to Creseide; shewing,
that she was as much amazed
how to answer Troilus, as Py&shy; 
thagoras was wearied in bring&shy;
ing his desire to effect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulcisonant(a)">Dulcisonant (<etym lang="la">dulcisonus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that sounds sweetly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulcoration(n)">Dulcoration (from <etym lang="la">dulcor,
oris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a making sweet. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulocracy(n)">Dulocracy (<etym lang="la">dulocratia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of Government, when
slaves have so much Licence,
that they rule and domi&shy;
neer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulocratical(a)">Dulocratical.</form> <xpln lang="en">Pertaining
to that kinde of Govern&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dumal(a)">Dumal (<etym lang="la">dumalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to Bryers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dumosity(n)">Dumosity (<etym lang="la">dumositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath many, or is full of Bram&shy;
bles or Bryers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dun(v)">To Dun,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a word lately
taken up by fancy, and signi&shy;
fies to demand earnestly, or
press a man to pay for com&shy;
modities taken up on trust, or
other debt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duodecennial(a)">Duodecennial (<etym lang="la">duodecennis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of twelve yeers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duple(a)">Duple (<etym lang="la">duplex</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">double,
two, twice so much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duplicity(n)">Duplicity (<etym lang="la">duplicitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
doubleness, twice so much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duplicate(v)">Duplicate (<etym lang="la">duplico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
double, increase or make
twice so much. A Duplicat is
used by Crompton for a second
Letters Patent, granted by
the Lord Chancellor in a case
wherein he had formerly
done the same; and was
therefore thought void.
Crompt. Jurisd. fol.215. 

So a second letter written
and sent to the same purpose,
as the former, and to the same 


</page>

<page sig="o2r">
party for fear of miscarriage
of the first, or for other rea&shy;
son, is called a Duplicat: and
when such a second letter is
written, to be sent, the custom
is to write the word Duplicat
in the head of the letter, to
signifie that it is a second let&shy;
ter. A third letter may also
after the same manner be cal&shy;
led a Triplicate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="durable(a)">Durable (<etym lang="la">durabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
which will last or continue
long.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dura-mater(n)">Dura-mater ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
outward hard skin that en&shy;
wraps the brains, as Pia-ma&shy;
ter is the inner skin next the
brains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duress(n)">Dures (<etym lang="la">duritia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is in our
Common Law a Plea used in
way of exception, by him
that being cast in prison at a
mans suit, or otherwise by
beating or threats, hardly u&shy;
sed, seals any Bond to him
during his restraint. For
the Law holds this not good,
but rather supposeth it to be
constrained. Brook in his
Abridgement joyns Dures and
Manasse together, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Duritiam</term>
and <term lang="la">Minas</term>, hardness and
threatning. See the new
book of Entries, verbo Dures,
and the new Terms of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="durity(n)">Durity (<etym lang="la">duritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hardness,
rudeness, cruelty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duumvirate(n)">Duumvirate (<etym lang="la">duumvira&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Office of the Duum&shy;
vir in Rome, or of two in e&shy;
qual Authority, and may be
taken for the Sheriff ship of
the City of London, or of any 
other place, where two are in
joynt Authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dinar(n)">Dyna</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coyn among the
East-Indians valuing thirty
shillings of our mony. Herb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dynarchy(n)">Dynarchy</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See dinarchy</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dynasty(n)">Dynasty (<etym lang="la">dynastia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">govern&shy;
ment, rule or power.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dys(a)">Dys ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in compositi&shy;
on signifieth evil, difficil or
impossible.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dyscracy(n)">Dyscracy (<etym lang="la">dyscrasia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">when
some humour or quality a&shy;
bounds in the body. d. Taylor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dysentery(n)">Dysentery (<etym lang="la">dysenteria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
perillous flux with excoriati&shy;
on and painful wringing of
the bowels, and some blood
issuing: the bloody flux.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dysnomy(n)">Dysnomy (<etym lang="la">dysnomia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">evil
constitution or ordering of
the Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dyspathy(n)">Dyspathy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ill affecti&shy;
on, passion or vexation of
mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dyspepsy(n)">Dyspepsie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ill con&shy;
coction or digestion, rawness
of the stomach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dysopsy(n)">Dysopsie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dimness,
ill sight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="e"><alpha>E.</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alderman(n)"><f type="l"/> EAlderman</form> <xpln lang="en">among the
Saxons was as much as
Earl among the Danes Cam
Brit.107. And at this day
we call them Aldermen that
are associates to the chief
Officer of a Town. 24. H.8.
c.13.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="easement(n)">Easement (<etym lang="la">esamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
service that one neighbour
hath of another by Char&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="o2v">
ter or prescription without
profit, as a way through his
ground, a Sink, or such like.
Kitchin fo.105. which in the
Civil Law is called Servitus
pr&aelig;dii . Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Easter(pn)">Easter</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Pasche</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="easterling(n)">Easterling.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Ster&shy;
ling</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebon(n)">Ebene (<etym lang="la">ebenus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tree
that grows in &AElig;thiopia,
bearing neither leaves nor
fruit; it is black, and has
no grain like other wood,
and is sharp biting in taste,
being burnt it yeelds a plea&shy;
sant smel, neither is its smoak
offensive, but the green wood
is so full of sap, that it will
flame like a candle. It is
good against many diseases of
the eyes. That which grows
in India is spotted with white
and yellow, being of less e&shy;
stimation then that of &AElig;thi&shy;
opia. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ebionites(pn)">Ebionites (so called from
Ebion their first founder, who
lived in the time of Pope A&shy;
naclet, and the Emperor Titus
about the year of Christ 71.)</form> <xpln lang="en">
were certain Hereticks that
denied the Divinity of our
Saviour Christ, and held
he was onely man, concei&shy;
ved and born from man and
woman, as the rest of man&shy;
kind. Against which Heresie
St. John wrote his Gospel;
which they impugned and
rejected, as they did also the
Gospels of St. Mark and St.
Luke. and onely admitted
that of St. Matthew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebriety(n)">Ebriety (<etym lang="la">ebrietas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">drun&shy;
kenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebriosity(n)">Ebriosity (<etym lang="la">ebriositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">con&shy;
tinual drunkenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebrious(a)">Ebrious (<etym lang="la">ebrius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">drunken,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebullate(v)">Ebullate (<etym lang="la">ebullo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to bubble

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebullition(n)">Ebullition (<etym lang="la">ebullitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

a rising up in bubbles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eburnean(a)">Eburnean (<etym lang="la">eburneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of I&shy;

ry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eccentric(a)">Eccentrick (<etym lang="la">eccentricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath not all one centre,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="echo(n)">Eccho orEcho ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a re&shy;
sounding, or giving again of
any noyse, or voyce in a
Wood, Valley, or Hollow
place. Poets feign, that
this Eccho was a Nymph so
called, who being rejected
by one whom shee loved,
pined away for sorrow in
the Woods, where her
voyce still remains, answer&shy;
ing the outcries of all com&shy;
plaints.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ecclesiastical(a)">Ecclesiastical (<etym lang="la">ecclesiasti&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to the Church
or Church-men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ecclesiastic(n)">Ecclesiastick (<etym lang="la">ecclesi&shy;
astes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Preacher, a Church&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eclipse(n)">Eclipse (<etym lang="la">eclipsis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
fect or failing. Common&shy;
ly it signifies a want of
light: and there be two such
Eclipses, namely of the Moon,
and of the Sun. 

Eclipse of the Moon ne&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="o3r">
ver happens but at her full,
nor then always, but when
she is in such a point that
the interposition of the
earth deprives her of the Sun
beams, from whence she
taketh her light. Eclipse
of the Sun is not so u&shy;
sual, and happens onely at
the change of the Moon, as
when the Moon, being be&shy;
tween the Sun and us, doth,
with her dark body, hide
part of his light from us:
Which was the cause that
Dionysius Areopagita (seeing
the Sun so admirably eclip&shy;
sed at our Saviours Passion,
contrary to all reason,
when the Moon was not
in any nearness to hinder
his light) cried out in a&shy;
mazement <term lang="la">Aut Deus na&shy;
atur&aelig; patitur, aut machina mun&shy;
di dissolvetur</term>. Either the
God of Nature suffers, or
else the frame of the world
will be destroyed. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ecliptic(n)">Ecliptick line (<etym lang="la">linea Ec&shy;
liptica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an imagined line
running through the midst
of the twelve Signs, in
which the Sun alwayes
keeps his course, and is so
termed, because the Eclip&shy;
ses happen, when the Moon
is either in conjunction or
opposition under this line.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eclogue(n)">Eclogue orEglogue (<etym lang="la">ec&shy;
loga</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is commonly taken
for a Pastoral speech, or a
Poem containing a com&shy;
munication of Shepherds, 
such are Virgils Eclogues. But
the word in Greek signi&shy;
fies properly an election or
choyce gathering of things
together, or an abridgement
of Authors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ecstasy(n)">Ecstasy (<etym lang="la">ecstasis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
trance, swowning or astonish&shy;
ment, a ravishment or trans&shy;
portation of the spirit, by
passion, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ecstatic(a)" lexeme="ecstatical(a)">Ecstatick 
Ecstatical (<etym lang="la">ecstaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
taken with
an Ecstacy or trance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ectype(n)">Ectype (<etym lang="la">ectypum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
thing made according to the
example and copy; a coun&shy;
terfeit. Mr. Ross.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edacity(n)">Edacity (<etym lang="la">edacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">unsa&shy;
tiable eating, greediness,
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eddy(n)">Eddie,</form> <xpln lang="en">the whirling or

Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eden(pn)">Eden (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">delecta&shy;
tion, or a place of plea&shy;
sure and delight. The Gar&shy;
den of Eden stood near
the River Euphrates in Sy&shy;
ria, and abounded with all
manner of pleasures and de&shy;
lights, and therefore Eden is
used for Paradise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edentate(v)">Edentate (<etym lang="la">edento</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to strike
out, or draw out ones
teeth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edict(n)">Edict (<etym lang="la">edictum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Comman&shy;
dement, Ordinance or Pro&shy;
clamation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edification(n)">Edification (<etym lang="la">&aelig;dificatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
building; But most com&shy;
monly it is taken for
instruction, so plainly 


</page>

<page sig="o3v">
delivered, that the hearer pro&shy;
fiteth by it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edifice(n)">Edifice (<etym lang="la">&aelig;dificium</etym>) <class type="etymlang" lang="he">from
the Hebr.</class> <etym lang="he">&#x05d0;&#x05b6;&#x05d3;&#x05b6;&#x05df; Edhen</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">&aelig;des</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a building or frame of a buil&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&aelig;dile(n)">Edil orAedil (<etym lang="la">&aelig;dilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Officer among the ancient
Romans whose charge was to
oversee the building of Tem&shy;
ples, as also of private houses,
such as our Church-wardens,
or Surveyors are, &amp;c. And of
these &AElig;diles there were two
other sorts, as you may read
in Godwins Anthology, chap.
de &AElig;dilibus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edisserator(n)">Edisserator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edition(n)">Edition (<etym lang="la">editio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a setting
forth, a publishing, an impres&shy;
sion. As of books, we call it
a first, second, third, fourth,
&amp;c. Edition, when a book
has been so many several
times imprinted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edituate(v)">Edituate (<etym lang="la">&aelig;dituor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to de&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edmund(pn)">Edmund ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">forEad&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edward(pn)">Edward <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">in Sax.</class> Coines E&shy;

Christian humility of King
Edward the Confessor brought
such credit to this name, that 
since that time it hath been
most usual in all Estates. That
Ward signifies a keeper is ap&shy;
parent by Wood-ward, Mil&shy;
ward, &amp;c. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="efficacy(n)">Efficacy (<etym lang="la">efficacia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">force,
strength, vertue or abili&shy;
ty. 

Efficacy (saith Peacham) is
a power of speech, which
represents a thing after an ex&shy;
cellent manner, neither by
bare words onely, but by pre&shy;
senting to our minds the live&shy;
ly Id&aelig;a' s or forms of things so
truly, as if we saw them with
our eyes; As the places in
Hell, the fiery arrow of Acesta,
the description of Fame, the
flame about the Temples of
Ascanius, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="efficient(a)">Efficient (<etym lang="la">efficiens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

ton:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="effort(n)">Effort ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">endeavor,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="effracture(n)">Effracture (<etym lang="la">effractura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

dled rashness, unruly headi&shy;

lesness. Eicon Basil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egbert(pn)">Egbert, or rather Ecbert ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> alwaies bright, or
famous for ever. 

King Egbert, who was the
seventeenth King of the West
Saxons, having subdued the 
Principal Kingdoms of the
Saxon Heptarchy, stiled him&shy;
self the first English Monarch,
commanding South Brittain
to be called England, from the
English Saxons, from whose
blood he was extracted and
over whom he reigned. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egean Sea(pn)">Egean Sea (<etym lang="la">mare &AElig;g&aelig;um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
part of the Mediterranean Sea
neer Greece, dividing Europe
from Asia. A Sea dangerous
&amp; troublesom to sail through,
in regard of the multitude of
rocks and Islands every where
dispersed; Insomuch that a
man is proverbially said to
sail in the &AElig;gean Sea, that is
incumbred with difficulties,
or attempts a business of much
hazard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egestion(n)">Egestion (<etym lang="la">egestio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a distri&shy;
buting abroad, a carrying
or casting forth of ordure or
dung a voiding, or evacua&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egestuosity(n)">Egestuosity (<etym lang="la">egestuositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ex&shy;
tream poverty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egestuous(a)">Egestuous (<etym lang="la">egestosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">very

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eglantine(n)">Eglentine,</form> <xpln lang="en">Sweet-briar, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egilopical(a)">Egilopical (<etym lang="la">&aelig;gilopicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath or pertaineth to
the disease &AElig;gilopa, which
is a kind of Fistula or Im&shy;
posthume in the corner of
the eye, growing to be a
Canker, eating to the nose,
and is called the Lachrymale
Fistule . Rid</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="electuary(n)">Electuary (<etym lang="la">electuarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
medicine or confection to
be taken inwardly, and is
made two wayes, either li&shy;
quid, as in Forma opiat&aelig; ; or
whole, as in Tables or Lo&shy;
zenges, or in fashion four
square and long, which is cal&shy;
led Manus Christi . Min. 

Or it is a medicinable com&shy;
position, made of choyce
Drugs, and of substance be&shy;
tween a Syrup, and a Con&shy;
serve; but more inclinable to
this, then that. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="element(n)">Elements (<etym lang="la">elementa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are
the most simple bodies extant
in nature; from the several
participation of whose qua&shy;
lities all mixt bodies have
their several beings, and differ&shy;
ent constitutions, they are
four in number, to wit, Fire,
Air, Water &amp; Earth . Element in
the singular number stands for
one of those: sometimes also it 
signifies a Letter, as A, B, C,
sometimes the first foundati&shy;
on or principle of a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elizabeth(pn)">Elizabeth (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the God

Peace of God, or quiet rest
of the Lord. Mantuan play&shy; 
ing with it makes it
Eliza-bella . Min. ridicu&shy;
lously compounds it of the
Hebrew word <term lang="he">El</term>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Deus</term>,
and the Greek words <term lang="gr">Isa</term> and
<term lang="gk">Beta</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elocution(n)">Elocution (<etym lang="la">elocutio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fit
and proper order of words 
and sentences. 

Elocution (saith Judge
Doddridge) consists of three
things. 1 : Of the voyce,
as the instrument. 2. The
words, that are the subject.
3. The manner of doing,
which is the form of de&shy;
livery, &amp;c. English Lawyer,
fo.25.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elohim(pn)">Elohim (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> <term lang="la">Nomen
divinum, &agrave; Judicio, quasi De&shy;
us Judex</term>. In any process of
Justice and Judgement, God
always stiles himself Eloah or
Elohim. Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elopement(n)">Elopement</form> <xpln lang="en">(a Law term)
is when a married woman
leaves her Husband, and
dwels with the Adulterer,
by which, without volunta&shy;
ry submission, and recon&shy;
cilement to him, she shall
lose her Dower; Stat. Westm.
2; ca.34. 

 <term lang="la">Sponte virum malier fugiens, &amp; adultera facta,
Dote sua careat; nisi sponso sponte retracta</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eloquence(n)">Eloquence (<etym lang="la">eloquentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a gift or good grace of
speaking. That is proper&shy;
ly said to be Eloquence, (as
Tully saith) where there is a
judicious fitting of choyce
words, apt and grave sen&shy;
tences to matter well dispo&shy;
sed, the same being utter&shy; 
ed with a comely modera&shy;
tion of the voyce, counte&shy;
nance and gesture. Cic. in Prol.
Rhetor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emanation(n)">Emanation (<etym lang="la">emantio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a flowing or proceeding from.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emancipate(v)">Emancipate (<etym lang="la">emancipo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make free, or set at liber&shy;
ty, to affranchize, to sell his
title to another. By the Ro&shy;
man Law every Son was in
such subjection to his Fa&shy;
ther, that before he could be
released of his subjection,
and made free, he should by
an imaginary sale, be sold
three times by his natural
Father, to another man, who
was called by the Lawyers
Pater Fiduciarius, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Father
in trust; yea and be <emend err="brought" source="errata">bought</emend>
again by the natural Father,
and so manumised by him, and
then he became free. This i&shy; 
maginary sale was called Man&shy;
cipatio ; the children thus ali&shy;
enated from the Father, were
termed Emancipati ; this form
of setting free was termed E&shy;
mancipatio . Godw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Emanuel(pn)">Emanuel.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Emmanuel</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emarginate(v)">Emarginate (<etym lang="la">emargino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to take away the scurf a&shy;
bout the brims of wounds
and soars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emasculate(v)">Emasculate (<etym lang="la">emasculo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
geld, to take away that by
which one is male.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embargo(n)">Embargo ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span:</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stop
or stay. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ember Week(pn)">Ember week (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">so called
from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x1f21;&mu;&epsilon;&rho;&alpha;&iota;</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la"> dies</term><emend err="">)</emend>;</form> <xpln lang="en">of
which there are four in the
year set down in most Al&shy;
manacks. They are of great
antiquity in the Church, cal&shy;
led the <term lang="la">Quatuor tempora</term> in the
Latin Fathers; And beside
the first institution of them
for quarterly seasons of devo&shy;
tion, proportioned to each
part of the year, as the first
fruits of every season, that
the whole and each division
of it might be blest by it, and 


</page>

<page sig="o6v">
again beside their answerable&shy;
ness to those four times of so&shy;
lemn fast, mentioned among
the Jews, that we Christians
may not be inferior to them
in that duty) an admirable
use is assigned to them in the
Church in imitation of the A&shy;
postles, Act.13.3. View of
Directory, fol. 56. They are
called Ember-days, or days of
ashes (says another Author)
from the no less ancient <emend err="theu">then</emend>
Religious custom of using
haircloth and ashes in times of
publike piety and Penance,
or from the old custom of eat&shy;
ing nothing on those days
till night, and then onely a
Cake baked under the Em&shy;
bers or ashes, which was cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">panem subcineritium</term>, or
Ember-bread . Turb. Cat. But
Sir Hen. Spelman de Concil.
says the true word is Imber 
from the old Saxon<term lang="sx">Imbren</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embellish(v)">embellish (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Embellir</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to beautifie, garnish, adorn,
bedeck, trim up, or set out
unto the eye.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embezzle(v)">To Embezel (<etym lang="it">sort&egrave; ab Ital.
Invaligiare</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">in sacco ponere</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
steal or pilfer. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emblem(n)">Emblem (<etym lang="la">emblema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is pro&shy;
perly any fine work cunning&shy;
ly set in wood or other sub&shy;
stance, as we see in Chess&shy;
boards and Tables, notwith&shy;
standing it is commonly ta&shy;
ken for a sweet moral symbol,
consisting of picture and
words, by which some weigh&shy;
ty matter is declared. See
Art of making devises. p 7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emblematical(a)">Emblematical (<etym lang="la">emblemati&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to an Em&shy;
blem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emblematist(n)">Emblematist,</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
makes Emblems.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emblements(n)">Emblements</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Law&shy;
term, signifying strictly the
profits of Land which hath
been sowed; but the word is
sometimes used more largely,
for any profits that arise and
accrew naturally from the
ground, as grass, fruit of trees,
hemp, flax, &amp;c. Mr. Shep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embolism(n)">Embolism (<etym lang="la">embolismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the adding a day, or more, to
a year, Leap-yeer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embossment(n)">Embossement (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
bouchement</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mouthing or
putting into the mouth of; a
subornation or fore-In&shy;
struction; a lesson given or
conned before-hand. Mal&shy;
vezzies translater.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embost(a)">Embost.</form> <xpln lang="en">A term used by
hunters when a Deer is so hard
chased that he foams at the
mouth, and hangs out the
tongue, it comes <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">from the
Span.</class> <etym lang="sp">des-Embocar</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> to cast
out of the mouth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embracer(n)">Embracer.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Law-term,
and is he that, when a matter
is in tryal, comes for reward
to the Bar, being no Lawyer
nor witness, and speaks in fa&shy;
vor of one of the parties: or
who labours the Jury, or u&shy;
seth any unlawful practice, to
make them give their Verdict
as he would have them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embrocation(n)">Embrocation (Ital. <etym lang="it"> Em&shy;
brocatione</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fomenting, be&shy;
sprinkling or gentle bathing 


</page>

<page sig="o7r">
the head or any other part,
with a liquor falling from a&shy;
loft upon it, in the manner
of rain. Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embryo(n)">Embryon (<etym lang="la">embryo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
child in the mothers womb,
before it has perfect shape
And by a Metaphor, any
thing before it hath perfecti&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embryous(a)">Embryous.</form> <xpln lang="en">Pertaining to
an Embryon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emergent(a)">Emergent (<etym lang="la">emergens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is&shy;

word is often used when we
speak of an Emergent occasi&shy;
on, which is, when it ri&shy;
seth out of somewhat done
before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emerald(n)">Emerald (from the Span.
<etym lang="sp">Esmeralda</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Smaragdus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a pretious stone, the greenest
of all other, and is there&shy;
fore very comfortable to the
sight. The best of this sort
are brought out of Scythia,
and some affirm them to be
taken out of the Griffins
nest. It is found by experi&shy;
ence (as Albertus writes)
that if the Emerald be good, it
inclines the bearer to chastity 
and cannot endure the action
of lust. There is also a disease
sounding neer this word, for
which see Hemorroide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emigration(n)">Emigration (<etym lang="la">emigratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a departing, a going from one
place to live at another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emication(n)">Emication (<etym lang="la">emicatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eminence(n)">Eminence (<etym lang="la">eminentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ex&shy;
cellency passing or standing a&shy;
bove others. Also a particu&shy;
lar title of honor given to all
Cardinals, and is held to be
above Excellency.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emissary(n)">Emissary (<etym lang="la">emissarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sub&shy;
orned accuser, a spye, a tale&shy;

which he hath summoned to
appear for the performance of
such publike service as Ju&shy;
rors are imployed in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imparlance(n)">Emparlance (from the
French <etym lang="fr"> Parler</etym> to speak)</form> <xpln lang="en">sig&shy;
nifies in our Common Law a
desire or Petition in Court, of
a day to pawse what is best to
do, or of a day of respite.
The Civilians call it, Petitio&shy;
nem induciarum . See more of
this in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emphase(n)">Emphasse (<etym lang="la">emphasis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ear&shy;

ciation of a word, a signifi&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emphatical(a)">Emphatical (<etym lang="la">emphaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is uttered with
most express signification, in
such sort, that it sets forth
to the full the intent of the
Speaker, forcible, vigorous,
earnest, or done with an Em&shy;
phasie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="empiric(a)">Empirick (<etym lang="la">empiricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
young and unskilful Physiti&shy;
tian, who without regard
either of the cause of the <emend err="dis">dis&shy;</emend>
ease, or the constitution of
the Patient, applyes those
Medicines, whereof either
by observation of other mens
receipts, or by his own
practise, he has had experi&shy;
ence in some other, work they
how they will.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="empirically(adv)">Empirically (<etym lang="la">empiric&egrave;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

skilfully, done by practice
onely, without Theory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emulgent(a)">Emulgent (<etym lang="la">emulgens</etym>, from
 <etym lang="la">emulgeo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">milking or stroak&shy;

some call it the Pumping

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emulsion(n)">Emulsion (<etym lang="la">emulsio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any

mond milk; also any kind

mor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emunctory(n)">Emunctories (<etym lang="la">emunctoria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
certain kernelly places in the
body, by which principal
parts void their superfluities;
as under the Arm-pits for the
Heart, under the Ears for the
Brain, and the Groin for the 
Liver. Also a pair of Snuf&shy;
fers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enclitic(a)" lexeme="enclitical(a)">Enclitick 
Enclitical (<etym lang="la">encliticus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">that inclines
or gives back. Enclitical
Conjunctions in Grammar are
so called, because they incline
or cast back the accent to the
Syllable going before, of
which sort are these three,
 <term lang="la">qu&egrave;, n&egrave;, v&egrave;</term>, which are joyned
to the end of other words. As
in this verse of Horace. 
 <term lang="la">Indoct&ugrave;<expan type="">que</expan> pil&aelig;, discive, trochive, quiescit </term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="encomium(n)">Encomium ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a praise
or song in commendation of
any person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="encomiastic(a)">Encomiastick (<etym lang="la">encomiasti&shy; 
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to (or one
that writes) an Encomium;
praising, commending, extol&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="encroachment(n)">Encrochment,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Law term,
as when two mens grounds 
lye together, the one presseth
too far upon the other, or
when a Landlord takes more
rent or services of his Te&shy;
nant then of right is due;
they are called Encroach&shy;
ments, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="encyclop&aelig;dia(n)">Encyclopedy (<etym lang="la">encyclop&aelig;dia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that learning which compre&shy;
hends all Liberal Sciences; 


</page>

<page sig="o8v">
an Art that comprehends all
others, the perfection of all
knowledge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inditement(n)">Enditement: (<etym lang="la">indictamen&shy;
tum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">comes of the French
word <etym lang="fr"> Inditer</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to accuse, or
appeach, and is a Bill or De&shy;
claration made in form of Law
(for the benefit of the Com&shy;
monwealth) of an accusation
for some offence, either cri&shy;
minal or penal, exhibited un&shy;
to Jurors, and by their ver&shy;
dict sound and presented to
be true, before an Officer
having power to punish the
same offence, &amp;c. See more of
this in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="endorsed(a)">Endorsed,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in He&shy;
rauldry, when two beasts are
painted with their backs tur&shy;
ned to each other. Also we
call that endorsing, when
we write the title on the out&shy;
side of a Letter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="energy(n)">Energy (<etym lang="la">energia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">effica&shy;
cy, effectual operation or
strength.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="energetical(a)">Energetical,</form> <xpln lang="en">very forcible,
or effectual.</xpln></wordentry>

Riddles or hard questi&shy;
ons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Engonast(pn)" lexeme="Engonnast(pn)">Engonast orEngonnast,</form> <xpln lang="en">
(the name of one of the Con&shy;
stellations commonly taken
for Hercules, who in the Globe
is figured with his right knee
bent, in the manner of knee&shy;
ling, and with his left foot
treading part of the head of
the Dragon. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Enoch pillars(n)" lexeme="Enos pillars(n)">Enoch orEnos Pillars.</form>
<xpln lang="en">The story runs shortly thus,
Enos (the son of Seth, the son
of Adam, who is held to be
the first Author of Astrology)
having heard his Grandfa&shy;
ther Adam say, all things
should be destroyed by the u&shy;
niversal Flood) was desirous
that Science should not pe&shy;
rish, before it came to the
knowledge of men, did there&shy;
fore erect two Pillars, one of
stone, the other of brick, to
the intent, if the brick wasted
with water or storms, yet the
stone should preserve the Let&shy;
ters whole and perfect: and in
these Pillars were graved all
that concerned the observati&shy;
on of the stars, &amp;c. Pol. Virg.
one of which Josephus af&shy;
firms remained even in his
time.<xref> See Astronomy</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ennead(n)">Ennead (<etym lang="la">enneas, adis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">nine, 


</page>

<page sig="p1r">
the number of nine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enodate(v)">Enodate (<etym lang="la">enodo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to un&shy;
knit, to cut away the knot,
to declare or make manifest,
to untie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enormity(n)">Enormity (<etym lang="la">enormitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">want

ness, hugeness.</xpln></wordentry>

that bears or carryes a
Sword.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inquest(n)">Enquest (<etym lang="la">inquisitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
in our Common Law espe&shy;
cially taken for that Inqui&shy;
sition or Enquest of Jurors
or by Jury, which is the
most usual trial of all causes,
both criminal and civil in our
Land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entail(v)">Entaile (<term lang="la">feudum tallia&shy;
tum</term>) comes <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">of the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">en&shy;
taill&eacute;</etym>.</form> <xpln lang="en">And, in our Common
Law, is a substantive ab&shy;
stract, signifying Fee tayl, or
Fee entailed.<xref> See Fee</xref> and<xref> 
Tail</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

or motion within herself:
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entendment(n)">Entendment ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wit,
or understanding. It signi&shy;
fies in our Common Law
so much as the true mean&shy;
ing or signification of a word
or sentence. Of which see
Kitch. fo.224.</xpln></wordentry>

or dash one heele against the

blowes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Enthusiasts(pn)" lexeme="Enthusiasists(pn)">Enthusiasts orEnthusi&shy;
asists,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect of people that
thought themselves inspi&shy;
red, with a Divine spirit, and
to have a clear sight of
all things they beleeved,
&amp;c. 

Spondanus sayes, they
sprung from the Anabaptisti&shy;
call Sect of Nicholas Stork of
Silesia in the year 1522.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enthusiasm(n)">Enthusiasm 
or 
Enthysiasm (<etym lang="la">enthysias&shy;
mus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enthymeme(n)">Enthymeme (<etym lang="la">enthyme&shy;
ma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a term of Logick, and
signifies an imperfect Syllo&shy;
gism, which wants either the
Major or minor Proposition;
As for example, 

Every sin deserveth correcti&shy;
on.

Every theft is a sin.
Therefore every theft de&shy;
serves correction.

Now if we leave out the
first part (called the ma&shy;
jor) and say thus, Every
theft is a sin: Therefore e&shy;
very theft deserves correction.
Or omit the second part (cal&shy;
led the minor) and say Every
sin deserves correction; therefore
every theft deserves correction.
Then it is called an Enthy&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="p1v">
meme, to wit, a keeping in
the mind (for so the word
properly signifieth) because
one of these parts is concea&shy;
led in the mind, and not ut&shy;
tered: and in that regard it is
called truncatus syllogismus, a
lame or maimed Syllogism.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enthymematical(a)">Enthymematical,</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="pertain">pertain&shy;</emend>
ing to an Enthymeme . Dr.
Bramh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entity(n)">Entitie (<etym lang="la">entitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> a being or
subsistence.</xpln></wordentry>

take out the kernel, to de&shy;
clare or explicate a difficul&shy;
ty, to interpret or ex&shy;
pound</xpln></wordentry>

p&eacute;r</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to wrap, unfold, involve
or inclose; also to pester or
incumber.</xpln></wordentry>

or speech, which simply af&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eolian(a)">Eolian,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to &AElig;o&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epact(n)">Epact (<etym lang="la">epacta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is nothing
else but a number of eleven
days, which the common So&shy;
lar year, exceeds the com&shy;
mon Lunar year, the one
consisting of 365 dayes, the 
other of 354 days, and there&shy;
fore they add the excess unto
the Lunar year to coequal
them; For Epact&aelig; comes
from <etym lang="gk">&#x1f10;&pi;&#x03ac;&gamma;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, which signifies
 <term lang="la">intercalare</term> or <term lang="la">addere</term>; by the
addition of which excess in
every four years, there is got&shy;
ten a number more then 30,
which is greater then the E&shy;
pact can be, because from
Change to Change there can
be but Thirty daies; there&shy;
fore Thirty must be taken
from that excess, and the re&shy;
mainder is the Epact for the
next year, as 1656, the Epact
is Fourteen, to which <emend err="Eleven" source="errata">adde 11</emend>,
which makes Twenty five,
which is the Epact for the
next yeer. 

To get the Epact for ever.
do thus: Multiply the Prime
by Eleven, parting the Pro&shy;
duct by Thirty, and the Re&shy;
mainder is the Epact; Or see
the age of the Moon, the E&shy;
leven Kalends of April, for
that is the number of the E&shy;
pact. Hop. Concord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epatride(n)">Epatride,</form> <xpln lang="en">were Noble men
among the Athenians, and held
the like dignity with them as
the Patricii did at Rome.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

dent of a Province, or the
chief of all the Provincial
Presidents.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephemeran(n)" lexeme="ephemerides(n)">An Ephemeran 
or 
Ephemerides (<etym lang="la">epheme&shy; 
ris, idis</etym>)</form>


</page>

<page sig="p2r">
 <xpln lang="en">wherein daily Acts are re&shy;
gistred, a Journal or Diary:
commonly it is taken for a
book of Astronomy (in use a&shy;
mong such as erect figures to
cast mens nativities) by which
is shewn how all the Planets
are placed, every day and
hour of the year.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephemeridian(a)">Ephemeridian,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging
to such a Register or Day&shy;
book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephemerist(n)">Ephemerist,</form> <xpln lang="en">One that re&shy;
gistreth daily actions, or
one that casteth Nativities,
with the help of an Epheme&shy;
rides ; a maker of an Ephe&shy;
merides.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ephesian temple(n)">Ephesian Temple.</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> The

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ephesian moan(n)">Ephesian Moan,</form> <xpln lang="en">may be
taken for a sad and continu&shy;
al lamentation, and is dedu&shy;
ced from Heraclitus, a Phi&shy;
losopher of Ephesus, who
always wept at the mise&shy;
ries of the world, and mor&shy;
tal men. The phrase is used by
Du Bartas.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephah(n)">Ephi orEpha,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hebrew
measure, containing nine Ga&shy;
lons of ours</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephialtes(n)">Ephialtes ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the night
Mare, it is a kind of dis&shy;
ease commonly called the
Elfe, or Night-Mare, with
which whoever is affected,
he supposes himself to be
invaded by some spirit, which
leaning hard upon him, stops
the passage of breath. Min
See <xref> Incubus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephippiated(a)">Ephippiated (<etym lang="la">ephippiatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sadled, or that hath a saddle
on his back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ephod(n)">Ephod (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Priest&shy;
ly Garment, used ancient&shy;
ly to be worn by the Priests
among the Jewes, where&shy;
of there were two kinds.
The first was made of gold
and twisted silk of purple,
Scarlet, and violet colour,
and fine linnen with broi&shy;
dered work, and this one&shy;
ly belonged to the High
Priest, and was onely used
by him, when he executed
his function: it covered the
back, and the breast, and on
the shoulders there were set
two great precious Onyx
stones, and in them graven the
names of the twelve Sons of
Jacob, called the twelve Pa&shy;
triarchs, in the right shoulder
the six eldest, and in the left
the six youngest; that the
High Priest going into the
Sanctum Sanctorum, to offici&shy;
ate, might among other things
be put in mind he was to pray
to God for the posterity of
those twelve Patriarchs. 

The other was of white lin&shy;
nen, used by the other inferi&shy;
our Priests, Levites, and also
by Laicks. Bull. and Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epicedium(n)">Epicedium ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fu&shy;
neral Song, or verses in
praise of the dead, which
were wont to be sung be&shy;
fore the Corps were bury&shy;
ed :</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epicene(a)">Epicene (<etym lang="la">epic&aelig;nus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">com&shy;
mon, of both Sexes or kinds.
The Epicene Gender, is 


</page>

<page sig="p2v">
that which concludes both
Sexes under one Article, as
Aquila being declinable onely
with the feminine Article,
signifies both the male and fe&shy;
male of Eagles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epicurean(n)" lexeme="epicure(n)">Epicurean 
or 
Epicure (<etym lang="la">epicurus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that gives
himself whol&shy;
ly to pleasure, especially to
gluttony; Heretofore it sig&shy;
nified one that followed the
Sect of a Philosopher named
Epicurus, who taught, that
the greatest happiness was,
to be without pain, and to
enjoy pleasure of body, and
mind, and that death was
nothing, nor any thing after
death.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epicurean(a)">Epicurean (<etym lang="la">epicureus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
volumptuous, given to no&shy;
thing but pleasure and glut&shy;
tony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epicurism(n)">Epicurism (<etym lang="la">epicurismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the manner or custom of an
Epicure, a living wholly ac&shy;
cording to sense and plea&shy;
sure in eating, drinking,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epicycle(n)">Epicycle (<etym lang="la">epicyclus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
term used in Astronomy,
amd signifies a lesser circle,
whose center or middle
part is in the circumference
of a greater circle. In the
upper part of this Epicycle,
the five Planets, Saturn,
Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and
Mercury go forward accord&shy;
ing to the course of the
Signs, as Aries to Tau&shy;
rus,  &amp;c, in the lower part
they are retrogade, that is, 
go backward, as from Ge&shy;
mini to Taurus, from Tau&shy;
rus to Aries again. Be&shy;
tween these two Motions
are said to be two Stations,
viz. When a Planet cea&shy;
seth going foreward, and
begins to retrograde, or com&shy;
ing to the furthest point
of his retrogradation, goes
forward againe. So that
in the Epicycle these Pla&shy;
nets wheele about sometimes
according, sometimes con&shy;
trary to the order of the Signs.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epic(n)">Epick or 
Epique (<etym lang="la">epicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sort of Poesie
which is
made in Heroical and lofty
Verses, most commonly
spoken of Hexameters . <xref lexeme="poesy"> See
Poesie</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epidemy(n)">Epidemy (<etym lang="la">epidemia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
universal sickness, and ge&shy;
neral infection, a most
catching or contagious dis&shy;
ease.</xpln></wordentry>

publick, universal; infecti&shy;
ous, contagious.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epigram(n)">Epigram (<etym lang="la">epigramma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies properly, a super&shy;
scription or writing set up&shy;
on any thing; now it is
commonly taken for a short
witty Poem, which under a 


</page>

<page sig="p3r">
feigned name does covertly
praise or tax some particular
person or thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epilepsy(n)">Epilepsie (<etym lang="la">epilepsia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Falling-sickness, whereto
most commonly children and
young folks are most sub&shy;
ject. This disease is caused
by some humor or vapour,
suddenly stopping the pas&shy;
sage of spirits in the brain,
which the brain striving to,
expel, causeth the patient
to fall down and common&shy;
ly foam at the mouth.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epileptic(n)">Epileptick (<etym lang="la">epilepticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath the Falling-sick&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epilogism(n)">Epilogism ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a com&shy;
putation, or a numbring by
way of repetition. Mr.
Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epilogue(n)">Epilogue (<etym lang="la">epilogus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
conclusion or knitting up of
a matter; a Speech made
after an Interlude or Play en&shy;
ded.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epilogize(v)">Epilogize (<etym lang="la">epilogizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to con&shy;
clude or deliver an Epi&shy;
logue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epiphany(n)">Epiphany (<etym lang="la">epiphania</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
appearing of light, or a
manifestation. The feast of
Twelfth day after Christ&shy;
mas, is so called in memo&shy; 
ry and honor of Christs ma&shy;
nifestation or apparition
made to the Gentiles by a
miraculous Blazing Star,
by vertue whereof he drew
and conducted the three
Magi or Sages, commonly
called the three Kings, who
upon sight of that star came
out of the East into the
Country of Palestine or Jew&shy;
ry to adore Him in the Man&shy;
ger, where they presented
him, as on this day with
Mirrh, Gold, and Frankin&shy;
cense, in testimony of his
Regality, Humanity, and Di&shy;
vinity. The Vigil of this
Feast was of old called Vi&shy;
gilia Luminum ; And the
Ancients were then wont
to send lights one to another.
Greg. 

Arthur the Brittish King
is said to have begun the
custom of solemnizing the
Twelve daies in Christmas
with such Feasts, and Sports,
as are yet or lately were u&shy;
sed, by the Lords of mis&shy;
rule, in some Gentlemens
houses. Heyl.<xref lexeme="balthasar"> See Baltha&shy;
zar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="episcopal(a)">Episcopal (<etym lang="la">episcopalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or like a Bishop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="episcopate(v)">Episcopate (<etym lang="la">episcopo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to play
the Bishop, to oversee dili&shy;
gently.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epistyle(n)">Epistyle (<etym lang="la">epistylium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an ar&shy;
chitrave; also a little Pillar set
upon a greater.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epistolary(a)">Epistolary (<etym lang="la">epistolaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ser&shy;
ving for letters or Epistles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epitaph(n)">Epitaph (<etym lang="la">epitaphium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="p3v">
scription or writing, set up&shy;
on a Tomb, most common&shy;
ly in lamentation or praise
of the party there buried:
The invention whereof is
referred to the Scholars of
Linus, who first bewailed
their Master when hee was
slain, in doleful verses, then
called of him &AElig;lina, af&shy;
terwards Epitophia, for
that they were first sung at
burials, after engraved up&shy;
on the Sepulchers. Ac&shy;
cording to Plato' s Lawes
an Epitaph should be com&shy;
prised in four Verses. The
Lacedemonians reserved this
honor onely to Martial
men, and chaste women,
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epitasis(n)">Epitasis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the second
and busiest part of a Comedy,
which signifies the intention
or exaggeration of matters.
See <xref> Catastasis</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epithalamy(n)">Epithalamy (<etym lang="la">epithalamium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Bridal, Song, or Poem, or
a Song at a Wedding, in
commendation of the parties
married; Such was that of
Solomon, Psal.45 wherein
the praise of the Church
and her spiritual Marriage
and Union with Christ is
set down. Such also is that
of Stella in Statius, and
of Julia in Catullus, &amp;c.
It is so called from the Greek
word <etym lang="gr">epi</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">apud</etym>, and
 <term lang="gk">Thalamus</term>, which signifies a
Bed-Chamber, but more
properly a Bride-Chamber,
because this Song was used to 
be sung at the door of the
Bride-Chamber, when the
Bride bedded. There are
two kinds of Epithalamies,
the one used to be sung at
night, when the married cou&shy;
ple entred Bed; the other in
the morning, to raise them
up. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epithalamize(v)">Epithalamize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to make or
sing an Epithalamy or Bridal
song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epithem(n)">Epitheme (<etym lang="la">epithema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of liquid medicine applied
to an outward part of the
body, by a peece of thin
linen, or cotten dipped
in it; thereby to supple
the place, or cool and com&shy;
fort the inward (Heart,
Stomack, or Liver) that's
under it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epithemetical(a)">Epithemetical,</form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;
ing to such a kind of medi&shy;
cine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epithet(n)">Epithet (<etym lang="la">epitheton</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
word added to a Noun
Substantive to express some
quality of it. As to say, a
Noble Person, unbridled lust,
&amp;c. here Noble and Unbri&shy;
dled are the Epithets expres&shy;
sing the quality of a Person 
and Lust.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epitoge(n)">Epitoge (<etym lang="la">epitogium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Cassock, or long Garment
worn loose over other Ap&shy;
parel, the habit of a Gradu&shy;
ate in the University.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epitomator(n)">Epitomator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that abridgeth, or abbre&shy;
viates any matter in writing,
an Epitomist.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="p4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epitomy(n)">Epitomy (<etym lang="la">epitome</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an a&shy;
bridgement, abbreviation, or
short gathering of any mat&shy;
ter in writing. My Lord
Bacon says, Epitomes are the
corruptions and moathes of
Histories.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epitomize(v)">Epitomize (<etym lang="la">epitomizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to ab&shy;
breviate or make an abridge&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epoch(n)">Epoch (<etym lang="la">epocha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term of
time, or as it were a certain
retention or cohibition of
it in a Chronological Histo&shy;
ry, taken from the begin&shy;
ning of some Empire, King&shy;
dom, or notable event. The
Jewes had several Epochs pe&shy;
culiar to themselves alone,
and one in common with
their Neighbors; those which
they had among themselves
were, First, From the Crea&shy;
tion of the World, or the be&shy;
ginning of time. 2. From
the universal Deluge, which
happened An. Mun. 1656.
3. From the confusion of
Tongues, A. M. 1786 4. From
Abrahams Journey out of
Chaldea into Canaan, A. M.
2021. 5. From their deli&shy;
verance out of Egypt; A. M.
2453. 6. From the first
year of Jubilee, A. M. 2499.
7. From the building of Solo&shy;
mons Temple, An.2932. And
lastly, From the Captivity
of Babylon, A. 3357. 

That which they had com&shy;
mon with other Nations,
was the Epoch of the Victo&shy;
ry of the Greeks, which
took beginning on the first 
Victory which Seleucus had
against Antigonus, in An. Mun.
3637. an account much used
by the Jews, Chaldeans, Syri&shy; 
ans, and other Nations of
the East. But the Chaldeans 
also had their own Epoch, or
account apart, reckoning
their time from the first
year of Nabonassar (Salma&shy;
nassar he is called in Scrip&shy;
ture) which being 438
years before this of Seleu&shy;
cus, must fall in An. Mund.
3201. 

Next for the Grecians, they
reckoned a long while by
Olympiads, the first of which
is placed in the year of
the World 3174. But this
account perishing under the
Constantinopolitans, they reck&shy;
oned after by Indictions
(an account devised by Ju&shy;
stinian) every Indiction con&shy;
taining fifteen years, the
first beginning Ann. Christ.
513. Which among Chro&shy;
nologers is still used: The
Romans reckoning first from
the foundation of their Ci&shy;
ty, which was, An. Mund.
3213. And afterwards from
the Sixteenth year of Au&shy;
gustus his Empire (being
that which is properly called
the Roman &AElig;ra) An. Mun.
3936. An Account used by
the Spanyards (where it first
began) till the reign of
Pedro the Fourth of Ara&shy;
gon, who abrogated it in
his Dominions, An. Christ.
1350. followed therein by 


</page>

<page sig="p4v">
<emend err="St." source="errata"></emend>John the first of Castile,
An. Ch. 1383, and at last by
the King of Portugal also
1415. 

The Christians generally
reckon from the birth of
Christ, but this they did not
use till the year 600. follow&shy;
ing in the mean time the ac&shy;
count of the Empire. 

And finally, The Maho&shy; 
metans begin their Hegira 
(for so they call the time of
their computation) from
the flight of their Prophet
Mahomet from Mecha, when
he was driven thence by 
the Philarch&aelig; ; which happened
16 July, An. 617, (or as some
will have it) 622. As the
word Epoch is used by the
Grecians, so in the same
sense is &AElig;ra by the Latins;
It is called <term lang="la">Epoche</term> <term lang="gk">&delta;&pi;&#x1F78; &tau;&omicron;&upsilon; 
&#x1F10;&pi;&#x03AD;&chi;&omicron;&nu;</term>, <term lang="la"><emend err="ab intendo" source="errata">a sistendo</emend>, quod il&shy;
linc sistantur &amp; terminentur
mensur&aelig; temporum</term>. Scalig
de emend. Temp. lib.5.p 358.
Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epode(n)">Epod (<etym lang="la">epodus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
Lyrick Verse wherein the first
is alwayes longer then the
second. As those of Ho&shy;
race. 

 <term lang="la">Beatus ille qui procul negotiis,
Ut prisca gens mortalium</term>, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epulary(a)">Epulary (<etym lang="la">epularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to Feasts or Ban&shy;
quets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epulosity(n)">Epulosity (<etym lang="la">epulositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">great
banquetting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="epulous(a)">Epulous (<etym lang="la">epulosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">liberal
in Feasts, full of banquet&shy;
ting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equator(n)">Equator (<etym lang="la">&AElig;quator</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
great Circle going round
the terrestrial Globe from
East to West. It passeth
through Habassia, Sumatra,
and Guiana. The use of it
is to shew the latitude of
any Town, Promontory, &amp;c.
And is so called, either, be&shy;
cause it is equally distant from
the Poles, or because when
the Sun is in it, the day and
night are equal. Heyl. and
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equanimity(n)">Equanimity (<etym lang="la">(&aelig;quanimi&shy; 
tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">uprightness of heart or
mind, quietness, patience, in&shy;
differency.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equation(n)">Equation (<etym lang="la">&aelig;quatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">making
equal, even or plain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eques auratus(n)">Eques auratus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Knight
so called in Latin, because it
was lawful for Knights onely
to beautifie their Armor and
Caparisons for their horses
with gold. Fern. 102:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equestrian(a)">Equestrian (<etym lang="la">equestris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to a Horse-man,
Knight, or Gent. or to an
Horse. S. H. W.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equicrural(a)">Equicrural,</form> <xpln lang="en">even-legged,
that hath his legs even or
like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equidial(a)">Equidial (<etym lang="la">&aelig;quidialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">when
the daies and nights are both
of a length.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equinoctial(n)">Equinoctial (<etym lang="la">&aelig;quinoctium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is an imagined line passing
just in the midst between the
two Poles of Heaven, to
which line the Sun coming
twice a yeer (namely about
the eleventh of March, and
the eleventh of September)
makes the days and nights
of equal length in all the
world (unless with such as in&shy;
habit just under the Poles;)
for which cause it is called
&AElig;quinoctial: The Signes,
Aries and Libra both begin at
this time. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equipage(n)">Equipage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dight&shy;
ing or setting forth of man,
horse, or ship-furniture; good
Armor, fit attire, sufficient
array.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equiparate(v)">Equiparate (<etym lang="la">&aelig;quiparo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make equal, to be like, to
make comparison.</xpln></wordentry>

qualled unto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equivocal(a)">Equivocal (<etym lang="la">&aelig;quivocus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath a double or doubt&shy;
ful signification. An Equivo&shy;
cal word is that which con&shy;
tains more significations then
one, or that which in its sense
or meaning equally extends
it self, as well to one as to a&shy;
nother. As the word (Arms)
in our vulgar use, equally sig&shy;
nifies those parts of our body
so called, or weapons or tokens
of honor, and with an aspira&shy;
tion (which is an Elench or
deceit in the Accent) harmes .
El. Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equivocation(n)">Equivocation (<etym lang="la">equivocatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a double, divers and doubtful
signification of a word or
speech.</xpln></wordentry>

taining to the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

raldry, when any member of

 <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Lat.</class> (<etym lang="la">Ergo</etym>) a word

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Erimanthian(a)">Erimanthian.</form> <xpln lang="en">Belonging
to Erimanthus a Mountain in
Arcadia, where Hercules slew a
huge wilde-Bore, that wasted
the Country: hence this beast
is called the Erymanthian Mon&shy;
ster in Il Pastor Fido.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ermines(n)">Ermines ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
beast less then a Squirrel, the
fur whereof is very costly,
worn onely by Princes or
great persons. It hath a tail
of a thumb long. Ermine in
Heraldry sometime signifies
white powdered with black,
and sometimes black powder&shy;
ed with white. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eristical(a)">Eristical (from <etym lang="la">eris, idis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
contentious, full of strife.

for Tradition.</xpln></wordentry>

ces of Circuit. Plb. Cor. fol.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="errata(n)">Errata ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">plural

rance; they are most com&shy;
monly taken for those faults
or omissions, which escape

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="errhine(n)">Errhine (<etym lang="la">errhinum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a me&shy;

either liquid or in dry pow&shy;
der, is used to stop bleeding
at the nose, to provoke
sneezing, to cause child&shy;
birth, and to purge the brain.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eructate(v)">Eructate (<etym lang="la">eructo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to belch

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eructation(n)">Eructation (<etym lang="la">eructatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

on.</xpln></wordentry>
