<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Erythrean Sea(pn)">Erythrean Sea,</form> <xpln lang="en">(the Red&shy;
Sea, otherwise called the Ara&shy;
bian Gulfe or Gulfe of Mecha)
so called from King Erythr&aelig;us;
It is called the Red Sea, not
from any material redness
therein, but from the redness
of the earth and sands, and
from the great abundance of
Coral, which grows plentiful&shy;
ly in the bottom of this Sea.
See more in Vul. Er.320.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Esay(pn)">Esay (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">reward of
the Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escal(a)">Escal (<etym lang="la">escalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to meat, fit to be eaten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escambio(n)">Escambio</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Licence
granted to one for the making
over a Bill of Exchange to a
man beyond Sea. Register
Original. fol 199, a.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escheat(n)">Escheat (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class>
<etym lang="fr">Escheoir</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">cadere</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in
our Common Law any Lands
or other profits that fall to a
Lord within his Manor by
way of forfeiture, or the
death of his Tenant, dying
without heir general or spe&shy; 
cial, or leaving his heir with&shy;
in age unmarryed, Magna
Charta. Cap.31. Fitz. nat. br.
fol.143.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escheator(n)">Escheatour.</form> <xpln lang="en">An Officer
that observes the Escheats of
the King in the County
where he is Escheator, and
certifies them into the Ex&shy;
chequer. He continues in
his office but one yeer, nor
can he be Escheator above once
in three yeers. An.1.H.8.
Cap.8. &amp; An 3. <term lang="la">ejusdem</term> Cap.2.
See more of this in Cromptons
Justice of Peace</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escutcheon(n)">Escotchean (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Escusson</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
buckler or shield, whereof
in Europe we have onely two
kinds in use (the Lozenge ex&shy;
cepted) viz. that we use in
England, France, Germa&shy;
ny, &amp;c. and the Oval 
they bear in Italy, which
form they yet (from the
old Romans) hold in
use. The word Escut&shy;
cheon is derived from the
French <etym lang="fr">un Esc&ugrave;</etym>, that from
the Latine <etym lang="la">Scutum</etym>, and
that again from <etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&kappa;&upsilon;&tau;&#x1f72;&#x03c2;</etym>
in Greek, which is Lea&shy;
ther, because the Anci&shy;
ents had their Shields of
tanned Leather, the skins
laid thick one over ano&shy;
ther, as appears by that
of Ulysses, upbraiding A&shy;
jax. 


</page>

<page sig="p6v">
 <term lang="la">Qu&aelig; nisi fecissem, frustr&agrave; Telamone creatus
Gestasset l&aelig;v&acirc; taurorum tergora septem</term> . 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escuage(n)">Escuage (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Escu</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">clypeus</term>, a Buckler or
Shield)</form> <xpln lang="en">in our Common&shy;
Law signifies a kinde of
Knights service, called ser&shy;
vice of the Shield, whereby
the Tenant holding, is bound
to follow his Lord into the
Scottish or Welch wars at his
own charge, &amp;c. Fitz. nat.
br. fo.84.C.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="esculent(a)">Esculent (<etym lang="la">esculentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be eaten or pertaining to
eating.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Escurial(pn)">Escurial (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class> but <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">some
affirm it to be an Arabick
word</class>, and to signifie <term lang="la">Domus
lucis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the name of that in&shy;
comparable edifice built by
Philip the second King of
Spain in twenty four yeers
time, and at eight millions
charge, and is termed the
eighth wonder of the world.
It contains, first the King of
Spains Palace. Secondly, St.
Lawrence Church. Thirdly,
the Monastery of Hierony&shy;
mites. And fourthly, Free&shy;
Schooles; it hath eleven or
twelve several quadrangles,
every one with Cloysters.
Quade. 

By extension of the word,
or by metaphor it may be
taken for any other magnifi&shy;
cent Palace or Structure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="esnecy(n)">Esnecy (<etym lang="la">&aelig;snecia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Pre&shy;
rogative given to the eldest
Coparcener to chuse first, after 
the inheritance is divided.
Flet. l.5. cap.10. in divisionem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eson's bath(n)">Esons-bath.</form> <xpln lang="en"> &AElig;son in his
old age (as Poets feign) had
youth and vigor restored to
him by the Prayers of Medea
a notable Sorceress, &amp;c. <xref>See
Medea</xref>. Hence we may ima&shy;
gine Esons-bath to have had
the vertue of restoring youth
to aged persons, the phrase is
used in Rel. Medici.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;sopical(a)">Esopical (<etym lang="la">&aelig;sopicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fabulous
or pertaining to such tales
or Fables, as those of &AElig;&shy;
sop.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="esplees(n)">Esples (<etym lang="la">expletia</etym>, from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Expleo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">seem to be the
full profit that the ground or
land yields, as the hay of the
Meadows, the feed of the
pasture, the Corn of the a&shy;
rable, the Rents, Services and
such like issues. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="esquire(n)">Esquier (<etym lang="la">armiger</etym>) is in
letters little altered <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the
Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> Escuier</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">scutiger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it sig&shy;
nifies with us that degree of
Gentry, which is next to a
Knight. Sir Tho. Smith is of
opinion, that at the first these
were bearers of Arms to
Lords and Knights, and by that
had their name and dignity.
See Cam. Britan. fol.111. In
our old Saxon, an Esquire was
called Scyidknapa or (accor&shy;
ding to our modern Ortho&shy;
graphy)Sheildknabe, <expan type="">id est</expan> he
that in war did bear the Shield 


</page>

<page sig="p7r">
of Arms of his Chief or Supe&shy;
rior. Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Esquilinus(pn)">Esquilinus.</form> <xpln lang="en">One of the se&shy;
ven Hills in Rome. As 1 &AElig;s&shy;
quilinus . 2 Quirinalis 3 Vimi&shy; 
nalis, 4 C&oelig;lius 5 Tarpeius . 6
Palatinus . 7 Aventinus. which
may the better be remembred
by this contracted Verse. 
 <term lang="la">&AElig;squi. Quiri. Vimin. C&oelig;l. Tar. Palatinus. Aventin</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essay(n)">Essay ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a proof, a try&shy;
al, a flourish or preamble: A&shy;
mong Com&oelig;dians the tryal
or proof of their action,
which they make before they
come forth publiquely upon
the Stage, is their Essay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essence(n)">Essence (<etym lang="la">essentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the being
or natural substance of any
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Essenes(pn)" lexeme="Esseans(pn)">Essenes orEsseans. (<etym lang="la">&aelig;sseni
vel Ess&aelig;i</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called from their
skil in curing diseases) were
certain Sectaries or Philoso&shy;
phers, among the Hebrews,
who referred every thing to
destiny, that deemed the soul
to be immortal, that would
have men fight till death in
defence of Justice, that Sa&shy;
crificed not with the rest of
the people, nor scarce con&shy;
versed with them; much gi&shy;
ven to tillage and husbandry,
and highly prizing purity of
life and sanctity of conversa&shy;
tion, who lived in common
and never maryed, and kept
no servants, saying, servants
were wicked, and a wife cause
of discord. Their life was
Monastick, and themselves gi&shy;
ven much to contemplation
of the Nature of Herbs,
Plants, Stones, and
beasts in dyet, meat and 
drink, moderated by suffici&shy;
ency, much addicted to Mo&shy;
ral Philosophy, not caring
for wealth, or hoarding
up treasure. Josephus and
Philo.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essedary(n)">Essedary (<etym lang="la">essedarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of warrior, that was
wont to ride in a Waggon or
Chariot, but fought on foot,
formerly in use with the an&shy;
cient Gauls : also a Waggoner
or Chariot man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essed(n)">Essed (<etym lang="la">essedum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wain,
Chariot or Waggon. In anci&shy;
ent time it was a Chariot for
fight, of a peculiar form.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essential(a)">Essential (<etym lang="la">essentialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to the essence or be&shy;
ing of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essoin(n)">Essoine. <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">comes of the Fr.</class>
<etym lang="fr">Essoyn&eacute;</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Exoine</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Causarius
miles</term>, he that hath his pre&shy;
sence forborn or excused up&shy;
on any just cause, as sick&shy;
ness or other incumbrance.</form> <xpln lang="en">
It signifies in our Common&shy;
Law an alleadgement of an
Excuse for him that is sum&shy;
moned or sought for to ap&shy;
pear or answer to an Action
real, or to perform suit to
a Court Baron, upon just
cause of absence, &amp;c. See
more in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="estovers(n)">Estovers (from the
French <etym lang="fr">Estouv&eacute;r</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to foster)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in our Common&shy;
Law nourishment or main&shy;
tenance. For example,
Bracton. l.3. tract.2. cap.18.
Num.2. useth it for that su&shy;
stenance which a man, taken
for Felony, is to have out of
his lands or goods, for himself
&amp; his family during his impri&shy;
sonment: and the Stat. An.
6. E. I. cap.3. useth it for an
allowance in meat or cloth.
It is also used for certain al&shy;
lowances of wood, to be ta&shy;
ken out of another mans
wood. Mr. West part.2. Sym&shy;
bol. tit. Fines sect.26. saith,
that the name of Estovers con&shy;
tains house-boot, hey-boot, and
plow-boot, as if he gave in his
grant these general words, <term lang="la">de
rationabili estoveria in boscis</term>,
&amp;c. he may thereby claim
these three. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="estreat(n)">Estreat (from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ex&shy;
tractum</etym>, or from the French
<etym lang="fr">Extraict</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is used in our Com&shy;
mon Law for the Copy or true
note of an original writing.
For example, of americia&shy;
ments or penalties set down
in the Rolls of a Court, to be 
levyed by the Bayliff or other
Officer, of every man for his
offence. See Fitzh. nat. br.
fol.75. H. l. K: and 76.a. And
so it is used Westm.2. cap 8. &amp;
13. Ed. I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="estrepement(n)">Estrepement orEstripa&shy;
ment, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">cometh of the French
word</class> <etym lang="fr"> Estropier</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to maym or
lame,</form> <xpln lang="en">and signifies in our
Common Law, spoyl made by
a Tenant for life upon any
Lands or Woods to the pre&shy;
judice of him in the reversi&shy;
on, as namely in the Statute
A.6. Ed. I. cap.13.</xpln></wordentry>

parch with heat, to rage, as
the Sea doth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ethic(n)">Ethick (<etym lang="la">ethicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">moral,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ethics(n)">Ethicks.</form> <xpln lang="en">Books treating
of moral Philosophy and
manners. Also moral <emend err="Philo">Philo&shy;</emend>
sophers themselves are called
Ethicks. As Logick intreat&shy;
eth of the Understanding
and Reason; so Ethique of
the will, appetite and affecti&shy;
ons. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="p8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethiopians(pn)" lexeme="Moors(pn)">Ethiopians orMoores,</form> <xpln lang="en">
the people of &AElig;thiopia. The
particulars of their opinions,
wherewith they have infected
the true purity, I find thus
registred. 1. The use to
Circumcise both males and
females. 2. They baptize
the males forty, the females
eighty days after their Cir&shy;
cumcision. 3. After the re&shy;
ceit of the Sacrament, they
are not to spit till Sun-set.
4. They profess but one na&shy;
ture and one will in Christ.
5. They accept onely the
three first general Councils.
6. Their Priests live onely by
the labour of their hands, for
they allow them nothing, and
permit them not to beg. 7.
They re-baptize themselves
every Epiphany day in Lakes
and Ponds, because that day
they suppose Chr. to have been
baptized by John in Jordan.
Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ethnarchy(n)">Ethnarchy (<etym lang="la">ethnarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
principality or rule.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ethnic(a)">Ethnick (<etym lang="la">ethnicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hea&shy;
thenish, ungodly, irreligious:
And may be used Substantive&shy;
ly for a Heathen or Gen&shy;
tile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ethology(n)">Ethology (<etym lang="la">ethologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
feat of counterfeiting mens
manners, an interlude of a
moral subject, or wherein
mens manners are acted and
expressed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="etiology(n)">Etiology (<etym lang="la">&aelig;tiologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a ren&shy;
dring of a cause, a shewing
of reason.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Etna(pn)">Etna (<etym lang="la">&AElig;tna</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hill in 
the Island of Sicily, which
continually sends forth flames
of fire, occasioned by the a&shy;
bundance of sulphur and
Brimston therein contained,
which is blown by the wind
driving in at the chaps of
the earth, as by a pair of bel&shy;
lows, &amp;c. of this hill there are
many Poetical fictions which I
omit: it is now called Montgi&shy;
bal. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="etymology(n)">Etymology (<term lang="la">etymologia ab
</term> <etym lang="gk">&#x1f14;&tau;&upsilon;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">verus</term>, and <etym lang="gk">&lambda;&omicron;&rho;&#x1f79;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">sermo</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the true exposition or deriva&shy;
tion of a word, as <term lang="la">lepus</term> <term lang="la">quasi</term>
 <term lang="la">levipes</term>. 

 <term lang="la">Etymologia est resolutio vocis
in verum &amp; proprium effectum,
&amp; verbi veritatem notificat, &amp;
ob id, eam Cicero veriloquium
appellat. Clau. Cantiumcula de
loc. legal</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="etymological(a)">Etymological (<etym lang="la">etymologi&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to Etymolo&shy;
gy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="etymologize(v)">Etymologize (<etym lang="la">etymologizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to shew the true derivation
of a word, to interpret or
expound words truely.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evacuate(v)">To Evacuate (<etym lang="la">evacuo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make empty or void, to
purge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evade(v)">Evade (<etym lang="la">evado</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to escape,
to pass without danger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evagation(n)">Evagation (<etym lang="la">evagatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
wandring, roving or straying
abroad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evaginate(v)">Evaginate (<etym lang="la">evagino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Evangelics(pn)">Evangeliques,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of

<page sig="p8v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evangelistary(n)">An Evangelistary.</form> <xpln lang="en">The
Office of an Evangelist; also
a Pulpit, or the place where
the Gospel is delivered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evangelism(n)">Evangelism (<etym lang="la">evangelismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
joyful tydings; as the An&shy;
nunciation of the Virgin Ma&shy;
ry, the tydings of Christs na&shy;
tivity, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="euphorbium(n)">Euphorbium.</form> <xpln lang="en">A gum or
tear of a strange plant grow&shy;
ing on Mount Atlas in Lybia.
It is yellowish, cleer and brit&shy;
tle. It may be used in Oynt&shy;
ments against Palsies, Cramps,
and shrinking of sinewes:
but to be taken inwardly is
very dangerous, unless the 
malice of it be well corrected,
for it is exceeding hot neer the
fourth degree. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="euripe(n)">Euripe (<etym lang="la">Euripus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signi&shy;
fies generally any strait,
fret or Channel of the Sea,
running between two shoars,
as Julius Pollux hath defined
it. But Euripus Euboicus or
Chalcidicus, is a narrow passage
of Sea dividing Attica and
the Island of Eub&oelig;a now cal&shy;
led Golph de Negroponte,
which ebbs and flows seven
times every day: the rea&shy;
son of which when Aristotle
could not find, it is said he
threw himself into the Sea
with these words, <term lang="la"> Quia ego
non capio te, tu capias me</term> .
But see Dr. Browns Vul. Er.
fol. 364. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="euripize(v)">To Euripize,</form> <xpln lang="en">To ebb and
flow, as Euripus doth, to be
always in motion, to be in&shy;
constant, to be whirled hither
and thither.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eurythmy(n)">Eurythmie (<etym lang="la">eurythmia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is

tween the bredth, length, and
heigth of all the rooms of a
Fabrick. Vitruvius lib. I. cap.
2: Sir Hen. Wotton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Europe(pn)">Europe (<etym lang="la">Europa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one of
the four parts of the world,
lying towards the West, con&shy;
taining England, France, Spain,
Italy, Germany, all Greece,
Creet or Candy, with many o&shy;
ther Kingdoms, great Coun&shy;
tries and Islands. We have
many opinions concerning the
derivation of the word, but
the most received is, that it is 


</page>

<page sig="q1v">
called Europe of Europa, King
Agenors daughter, whom Ju&shy;
piter (as Poets feign) in like&shy;
ness of a Bull caryed over Sea
into the Island Candy. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eutychians(pn)">Eutychians</form> <xpln lang="en">followers of

who about the yeer of Christ
443 in time of Pope Leo the
first, and Theodosius the second
Emperour dogmatized, that
there was but one nature in
Christ, that Christ was not
truely born of the Virgin
Mary, with many other absurd
errors against Faith.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="excommunication(n)">Excommunication (<etym lang="la">ex&shy;
communicatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is thus defined
by Panormitan: <term lang="la">Excommunica&shy;
tio est nihil aliud qu&agrave;m censura &agrave;
Canone vel Judice Ecclesiastico
prolata &amp; inflicta, privans legi&shy;
tima communione sacramentorum,
&amp; quandoque hominum: </term> And it
is divided <term lang="la">in majorem &amp; mino&shy; 
rem: Minor est per quam quis &agrave;
sacramentorum participatione con&shy;
scientia vel sentenia arcetur. Major
qu&aelig; non solum &agrave; Sacramentorum,
verumettam fidelium communione
excludit, &amp; ab omni actu legiti&shy;
mo separat &amp; dividit . Ve&shy;
natorius de Sentent. Ex&shy;
com.</term>

Excommunication is a Cen&shy;
sure inflicted by the Canon
or Ecclesiastick Judge, de&shy;
priving the person offending
of the lawful Communion
of the Sacraments, and some&shy;
times of the liberty even of
conversing with the faith&shy;
ful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="excoriate(v)">Excoriate (<etym lang="la">excorio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pluck
off the skin or hide, to
flay or fret the skin off.
How.</xpln></wordentry>

in the body, the offal or re&shy;
fuse of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="excrementous(a)" lexeme="excrementitious(a)">Excrementous 
Excrementitious </form> <xpln lang="en">Pertain&shy;
ing to
the excrements or refuse of
nature or other thing, dreg&shy;
gy, <emend err="fifthy">filthy</emend>, full of excre&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="executor(n)">Executor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one

But more particularly 'tis

of all his substance according
to the contents of the said
Will. See more of this in

med, is the material cause
of divers fiery impressions
in the ayre, and being
thin and lighter then a
vapour, is carryed up even
to the highest Region. Good&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="expeditate(v)">Expeditate (from <etym lang="la">ex</etym>, and
 <etym lang="la">pes</etym>, to unfoot)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a word
usual in the Forrest Laws,
signifying, to cut out the balls
of dogs feet, or (as some well 
have it) to cut off by the
skin, the three claws of
the forefoot on the right side
for the preservation of the
Kings game. Every one that
kept any great dogs not ex&shy;
peditated, did forfeit to the
King three shillings and four
pence. Crompt. Jurisd. fol.
prima fol.205. and 212.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extend(v)">Extend (<etym lang="la">extendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to stretch
out, enlarge or prolong.
It signifies in our Common
Law, to seize and value the
Lands or Tenements of one
bound by Statute, &amp;c. that
hath forfeited his bond, to
such an indifferent rate, as by
the yearly rent the obligor
may in time be paid his debt.
The course and circumstance
of this see in Fitzhe. nat. br.
fo.131. Breif. d' execution sur.
Stat. Merch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extent(n)">Extent (from <etym lang="la">extendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hath
two significations, sometimes
signifying a Writ or Commis&shy;
sion to the Sheriff for the va&shy;
luing of Lands or Tenements.
Register. Iudicial, in the Table of
the book. Sometimes the act
of the Sheriff or other Com&shy;
missioner, upon this Writ.
Brook. titulo extent. fol.
313.</xpln></wordentry>

ry to intimate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extispicious(a)">Extispicious (from <etym lang="la">extispi&shy;
cium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to South&shy;
saying by the intrals of beasts.
Vul. Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extorsion(n)">Extorsion (<etym lang="la">extorsio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ex&shy;
action, a wreathing or wring&shy;
ing out or from. In our
Common Law it signifies an
unlawful or violent wringing
of money or moneys worth
from any man. For example,
if any Officer by terrifying
any Subject in his Office take
more then his ordinary duties,
he commits, and is inditable
of, Extorsion. To this may 
be referred the exaction of
unlawful Usury, winning by
unlawful Games, exces&shy;
sive Toll in Milners, &amp;c.
See more in Cowel, and in
Cromptons Justice of P. fo.48,
49, 50.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extort(v)">To Extort (<etym lang="la">extorqueo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
take away by force, to wrest
away by violence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extract(n)" lexeme="extraction(n)">Extract 
Extraction (<etym lang="la">extractio</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">a drawing
out, a breviate or abridge&shy;
ment, also a Draught or Co&shy;
py.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eyre(pn)">Eyre (<term lang="la">Iter</term>. Bracton, l.3.
ca.11. <term lang="la">in Rubrica</term>) <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">comes of
the old Fr. word</class> (<etym lang="fr">Erre</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Iter</term>)
as <etym lang="fr">grand erre</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan>. <term lang="la">magnum iter</term>.</form> <xpln lang="en">
It signifies in Briton. ca.2.
the Court of Justices Itine&shy;
rants. And Justices in Eyre,
are those onely, which
Bracton in many places calls
( <term lang="la">Justiciarios Itinerantes</term>) of the
Eyre, read Britton ubi Supra,
who expresses the whole
course of it. And Bracton
l.3. tractat.2. ca.1, and 2. The
Eyre also of the Forest is 
nothing but the Justice seat,
otherwise called; which is,
or should by ancient custom
be held every third year by
the Justices of the Forest jour&shy;
nying up and down to that
purpose. Cromptons Jurisd.
fo. 156. Manwood part. I. of
his Forrest Laws, pag.121,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

of the Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fabellator(n)">Fabellator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
feigns or invents tales. 

The difference betwixt fa&shy;
bellator and fabulator, can be
no other then that betwixt
 <term lang="la">fabella</term> and <term lang="la">fabula</term>; this signi&shy;
fying a fable or tale, that a
short or little tale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fabric(n)">Fabrick (<etym lang="la">fabrica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a shop
or work-house wherein any
thing is framed; the art of
framing or making, building,
or proportioning. It is most
commonly used for a building
or a thing artificially made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="factor(n)">Factor (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a doer or

for him that buys and sells for

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faculent(a)">Faculent (<etym lang="la">faculentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bright
or cleer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faculty(n)">Faculty (<etym lang="la">facultas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">power
to do or speak, promptness.
And of these there are three,
which govern man, and are
distributed into the whole
body, namely, Animal, Vital,
and Natural : The Animal fa&shy;
culty is that which sends feel&shy;
ing and motion to all the bo&shy;
dy, from the brain by sinews;
and nourisheth Understan&shy;
ding; The Vital faculty gives
life from the heart by Arte&shy;
ries to all the body; The Na&shy;
tural faculty gives nourishment
to all the parts of the body,
from the Liver by Veins, &amp;c. 
Vigon. In our Common Law
it is used for a priviledge or e&shy;
special power granted to a
man by favor, indulgence and
dispensation, to do that which
by the Common Law he
cannot: As to eat flesh upon
days prohibited, to marry
without Banes first asked, to
hold two or more Ecclesiasti&shy;
cal livings, the son to succeed
the Father in a Benefice, and
such like. And for granting
these, there was a particular
Officer under the Archbishop
of Cant. called the Master of
the Faculties . Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="facundity(n)">Facundity (<etym lang="la">facunditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">e&shy;
loquence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="facundious(a)">Facundious (<etym lang="la">facundosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full
of eloquence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="facundate(v)">Facundate (<etym lang="la">facundo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make eloquent or pleasant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faitour(n)">Faitours,</form> <xpln lang="en">seems to be a
French word antiquated or
something traduced. For
the modern French is (<term lang="fr">faiseur</term>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">factor</term>) It is used in the
Stat. A.7.<expan type="">read</expan>2. cap.5. And
in the evil part, signifying a
bad doer. Or it may not
improbably be interpreted
an idle liver, taken from (<etym lang="fr">fai&shy;
tardise</etym>) which signifies a kind
of numb or sleepy disease,
proceeding of too much slug&shy;
gishness, which the Latines
call (<term lang="la">Veternus</term>) for in the said
Stat. it seems to be a Synony&shy;
mon to Vagabond . Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

taining to a kinde of dart
thrown out of Towers be&shy;
sieged.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Falcidian law(n)">Falcidian Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Law a&shy;
mong the Romans so called,
because made in the time of
the Consulship of Falcidius:
which Law intreated of the
liberty, which every Citizen
of Rome ought to have in the
disposition of his own
goods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Family of Love(pn)" lexeme="Familism(pn)">Family of Love, orFa&shy;
milism,</form> <xpln lang="en">a blasphemous Heresie
broached by one Henry Nicho&shy;
lus of low Germany, a little a&shy;
bove one hundred yeers since.
He maintained, that Christ is
already come in his glory to judge,
&amp;c. And that the seat or Throne
of Judgement, whereon Christ
sits, is the Community of the Fa&shy;
mily of Love, whereof the said
H. N. is the eldest Father; and
that he and they are Godded
with God, and God manned with
them, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fane(n)">Fane (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&phi;&alpha;&#x03af;&nu;&omega;</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">ostendo</term>, <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Fanal</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wea&shy;
thercock, to shew the station
of the wind. First invented
by Andronicus Cirrestes at A&shy;
thens. Pol. Virgil. Also the
Lantern of a Ship or Galley.
 Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fannell(n)">Fannel (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Fanon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a scarf&shy;

the left Arm of a sacrificing

glish miles, or a League among
the Persians. Herb. tra. 135</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fealty(n)">Fealty, (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">comes of the
French</class> <etym lang="fr">Feaulte</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">fidelitas</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
and signifies in our Common
Law an Oath taken at the ad&shy;
mittance of every Tenant,
to be true to the Lord of
whom he holds his Land.
And he that holds land by
this only Oath of fealty, holds
in the freest manner that any
man in England under the
King may hold. Because all
with us that have Fee, hold
 <term lang="la">per fidem &amp; fiduciam</term>, that is,
by fealty at the least. Smith
de Repub. Anglor. l.3. cap.
8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feasible(a)">Feasible (Fr. <etym lang="fr">faisable</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ef&shy;

que.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fecial(a)">Fecial (<etym lang="la">f&aelig;eialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to the Herald that de&shy;
nounceth war or peace: The
manner was thus: The f&aelig;ci&shy;
alis carryed a Lance or Spear
headed with Iron, and half
burnt with fire, and strewed
herbs all the way in sign of
peace, even to the confines
of those against whom he was
to menace war; there in the
presence of three men of good 
yeers, declared, that he and
the people of Rome did denounce
war against them, &amp;c. And
then threw the Lance as far
as he could upon their
ground. When they pro&shy;
claimed Peace, the F&aelig;cialis 
took up a stone in his hand,
which (after certain so&shy;
lemn words pronounced,
and those to be read in God&shy;
wins Anthology. lib.4. cap. I.)
he cast out of his hand, &amp;c.
And of these F&oelig;ciales or
Heralds, there were in Rome
a Colledge of twenty; the
principal of them, was Pa&shy;
ter patratus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feud(n)">Feid,Feed, orFeud,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is that
ill custom which hath been
much used in Scotland, and the
North of England (viz. a
combination of kindred, 


</page>

<page sig="q7v">
to revenge the death of any
of their blood against the
killer, and all his race.
These deadly Feids, King
James in his Basilicon Doron,
adviseth his son to re&shy;
dress with all care possi&shy;
ble. The word signifies ha&shy;
tred. See <xref> Feud</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fee(n)">Fee (<etym lang="la">feodum, ali&agrave;s feu&shy;
dum</etym>) comes <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">of the French</class> 
 <etym lang="fr">fief</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">pr&aelig;dium beneficiari&shy;
um, vel res clientelaris</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
and is used in our Common
Law for all those Lands,
which we hold by perpetual
right, as Hotoman well ob&shy; 
serves, <term lang="la">verb. feodum. de verbis
feudalibus</term> . See more of this
in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fence-month(n)">Fencemonth,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a month
wherein it is unlawful to hunt
in the Forest, because the
female Deer do Fawn in this
month, which begins fifteen
days before Midsomer, and
ends fifteen days after. So
that to this moneth there are
31 days assign'd, See Man&shy;
wood part. I. of his Forest
Laws, p.80. but more at large 
part. secunda Cap 13. per totum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fenestral(a)">Fenestral (<etym lang="la">fenestralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to a window.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="felony(n)">Felony (<etym lang="la">Felonia</etym>) seems
to come of the French <etym lang="fr">Felon&shy;
nie</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">impetuositas, atrositas,
immisericordia</term>.</form> <xpln lang="en">We account
any offence Felony that is in
degree next to petty Trea&shy;
son, and compriseth divers
particulars under it, as
Murder, Theft, killing of a
mans self, Sodomy, Rape,
Wilful burning of houses, and
divers such like, which
are to be gathered, especial&shy;
ly out of Statutes, whereby
many offences are dayly
made Felony, that before
were not. Felony is discern&shy;
ed from lighter offences, by
this, that the punishment
thereof is death; Howbeit
Petit Larceny (which is the
stealing of any thing under
the value of twelve pence)
is Felony, as appears by Brook
tit. Coron. n.2. His reason is,
because the Indictment a&shy;
gainst such a one must run
with these words, <term lang="la">felonic&egrave; ce&shy;
pit</term>, and yet is this not punish&shy;
ed by death, though it be loss
of goods. A man may call
that Felony, which is under
petit Treason, and punished
by death. And of this there
be two sorts: one lighter, that
for the first time may be relie&shy;
ved by Clergy; another that
may not: and these are to be
known by the Statutes; for
Clergy is allowed where it
is not expressly taken away. 


</page>

<page sig="q8r">
<expan type="">videlicet</expan> Stanf. l. I. pl. Cor. &agrave; fine
cap.2. usque ad 39. Lambert
Inst. P. l.2. cap.7. and Cromptons
l. P. fol.32, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fen(n)">Fenne,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Marish ground.
Also Avicen divides his Ca&shy;
nons into partitions, which he
called Fennes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feminine(a)">Feminine (<etym lang="la">f&oelig;mininus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feneration(n)">Feneration (<etym lang="la">f&oelig;neratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">u&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feneratitious(a)">Feneratitious (<etym lang="la">f&oelig;neratitius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

pertaining thereto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feodary(n)" lexeme="feudary(a)" lexeme="feudatary(a)">Feodarie, alias Feudarie,
aliasFeudatarie (<etym lang="la">feudatarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
was an Officer authorized
and made by the Master of
the Court of Wards and Li&shy;
veries, by Letters Patents
under the Seale of that Of&shy;
fice; his Function was to be
present with the Escheator at
the finding any Office, and to
give Evidence for the King,
as well concerning the value,
as the tenure, and also to sur&shy;
vay the Land of the Ward,
after the Office found, and to
rate it; he is also to assign
the Kings widows their Dow&shy;
ers, and to receive all the
Rents of the Wards Lands,
within his Circuit, and to
answer them to the Receiver
of the Court of Wards and
Liveries. This Office is
mentioned, Ann.32. H.8. cap.
46.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feofment(n)">Feofment (<class type="etymlang" lang="go">from the Got&shy;
tish word</class> <etym lang="go">feudum</etym>, and signi&shy;
fies <term lang="la">Donationem feudi</term>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
in our Common Law any gift 
or grant of any Honors, Ca&shy;
stles, Manors, Mesnages,
Lands or other Corporal and
immoveable things of like
nature, unto another in Fee&shy;
simple, that is, to him and his
heirs for ever, by the delive&shy;
ry of seisin, and possession of
the thing given, whether the
gift be made by word or wri&shy;
ting; and when it is in wri&shy;
ting it is called a Deed of
Feofment, and in every Feof&shy;
ment the giver is called the
 Feoffer, and he that receives,
by vertue thereof, the Feoffee ;
And Littleton says, that the pro&shy;
per difference between a Fe&shy;
offer and Donor is, that the
Feoffer gives in Fee-simple,
and the Donor in Fee-tayl.
Lib I. Cap.6.</xpln></wordentry>

from the root upward. Vul. Er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fetiferous(a)">Fetiferous (<etym lang="la">f&aelig;tifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fruit&shy;
ful, that brings forth fruit or
young.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feud(n)" lexeme="deadly feud(n)">Feud orFeid, or deadly
Feud (<etym lang="la">feuda</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a profession of
an unquenchable hatred, till
we be revenged even by the
death of our enemy: and is
deduced from the German
word (<term lang="gr">Feed</term>) which (as Ho&shy;
toman saith) <term lang="la">in verbis feudalibus
modo bellum, modo capitales ini&shy;
micitias significat</term> . This word
is used 43. El. c.13.  See <xref>Feid</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

or Fee-simple; also held in
Fief or in Fee. Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fifteenth(n)">Fifteenth (<etym lang="la">decima quin&shy;
ta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Tribute or Impo&shy;
sition of money laid up&shy;
on every City, Burrough,
and other Town through
the Realm, not by the Poll,
or upon this or that man, but
in general upon the whole
City or Town; so called
because it amounts to one
fifteenth part of that which
the City or Town hath been
valued at of old. See more
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

fed Hawks; also nets to catch

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filazer(n)">Filazer (<etym lang="la">filazarius</etym>) comes
of the French [ <etym lang="fr">fillace</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
and is an Officer in the
Common Pleas, whereof
there be fourteen in num&shy;
ber. They make out all ori&shy;
ginal Processe, &amp;c. See
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="r1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="file(n)">File (<etym lang="la">filum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a thread
or wyer whereon Writs or o&shy;
ther exhibits in Courts are
fastned, for the more safe
keeping them. It is also a
term in War, where six Mus&shy;
keteers or Pike-men )or as
many as go a breast) make a
File or Rot <xref> See Brigade</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="film(n)">Filme (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">from the Belgick</class> 
velme, <etym lang="la">quod idem denotat</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fine thin skin within the
body, dividing the flesh or
any near member one from a&shy;
nother. Also a skin like a
cap wherein divers children
are born. Also the skins en&shy;
wrapping the brains are cal&shy;
led Filmes, the inmost, which
is next the brain, is also cal&shy;
led pia meninx, or pia mater,
the other dura meninx, or dura
mater . 

The Infant (saith Doctor
Brown) hath three Tegu&shy;
ments or membranous Filmes,
which cover it in the womb,
that is, the Corion, Amnios, and
Allantois ; whereof see more in
his Vul. Er. p.269.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filtration(n)">Filtration  
 ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a strain&shy;
ing, distilling, or passing of
simples, &amp;c. through a Felt,
wollen cloth, or the like.
Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

place, sometimes Departers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fire-boot(n)">Fire-boot (compounded

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fire-drake(n)">Fire-drake,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fire some&shy;
time seen flying in the night,
like a Dragon : common peo&shy;
ple think it a spirit, that keeps
some treasure hid: But Phi&shy;
losophers affirm it to be a
great unequal exhalation in&shy;
flamed between two clouds,
the one hot, the other cold
(which is the reason that it
also smoaks) the middle part
whereof, according to the 


</page>

<page sig="r2r">
proportion of the hot cloud,
being greater then the rest,
makes it seem like a belly, and
both ends like to a head and
tail. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="first fruits(n)">First-Fruits (<etym lang="la">primiti&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
were the profits of every spi&shy;
ritual living for one year, gi&shy;
ven in ancient time to the
Pope throughout all Chri&shy;
stendom, but by the Stat.
An 26. H.8. ca.3 transla&shy;
ted to the Prince; For or&shy;
dering whereof, there was a
Court erected An.32. H.8.
ca.45. but it was dissolved,
An.5. M. Sess.2. ca.10. and since
that time, though those pro&shy;
fits be reduced again to the
Crown by the Stat. A. I. Eliz,
ca.4. yet was the Court never
restored, but all matters for&shy;
merly therein handled, were
transferred to the Exchequer,
See <xref>Annats</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fiscal(a)">Fiscal (<etym lang="la">fiscalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flamine(n)">Flamines,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Priests a&shy;
mong the Romans and
Druides, so called: their Arch&shy;
Priests that presided over
chief Towns, or great Di&shy;
stricts, were called Arch&shy;
Flamins ; They took that
name of Filamen, a filet of
woolen yarn, which they used
to wear on their heads, or, as
others say, from the Mytre or
head Ornament, which those
Priests did wear, and was 


</page>

<page sig="r2v">
called in old time fiama .<xref lexeme="arch-flamen"> See
Arch flamin</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fledwite(n)">Fledwit, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">comes of the Sax&shy;
on word</class> <etym lang="sx">Fled</etym>, that is, a fu&shy;
fitive; andwit, which some
make but a termination, sig&shy;
nifying nothing of it self. O&shy;
thers say it signifies a repre&shy;
hension, censure, or correcti&shy;
on.</form> <xpln lang="en">

In our ancient Law it
signifies a discharge or free&shy;
dom from Amerciaments,
when one having been an
Out-lawed Fugitive comes
to the peace of his own ac&shy;
cord. Rastal. Expos. of words.
New Terms of Law. See
Bloodwit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fleet(pn)">Fleet (<etym lang="la">Fleta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a fa&shy;
mous Prison in London, so
called, as it seems from
the River, upon the side 
whereof it stands. Camb. Brit
fo: 137. 

To this Prison none are
usually committed, but
for contempt to the Lawes,
or upon absolute comman&shy;
dement of the King, or
the Superiour Courts of Ju&shy;
stice. or lastly upon debt,
when men are unable or un&shy;
willing to satifie their Cre&shy;
ditors.</xpln></wordentry>

matick</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="florin(n)">Florein,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coin where&shy;
of there be several sorts, one
about the value of three
shillings four pence, the o&shy;
ther about two shillings ten
pence farthing. In Lan&shy;
guedock, and the Coun&shy;
tries adjoyning, they have
a peece called a Florin worth
eighteen pence sterl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="florid(a)">Florid (<etym lang="la">floridus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gar&shy;
nished with flowers, fresh,
lively</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="floriferous(a)">Floriferous (<etym lang="la">flori&shy;
fer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that beareth flow&shy;
ers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flosculous(a)">Flosculous<etym lang="la"> (from <emend err="flos"> flos&shy;</emend>
culus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">flowery, or pertain&shy;
ing to a Flower, or Blos&shy;
som; full of flowers. Vul
Err.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flotsam(n)">Flotson, aliasFlotzam</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a word proper to the
Seas, signifying any goods
that by shipwrack are lost
and lye floting or swimming
upon the top of the wa&shy;
ter, which with Jetson, La&shy;
gon and Shares are given to
the Lord Admiral by his Let&shy;
ters Pattents. 

Jetson, is a thing cast out
of the ship, being in dan&shy;
ger of wreck, and beaten
to the shore by the waters,
or cast on the shore by
Marriners. Cook vol.6. fol.
106. a. It comes of the
French <etym lang="fr"> Jett&eacute;r</etym>, to cast out.
Lagon alias Lagam vel Li&shy;
gan is that which lieth in 
the bottom of the Sea. Cook
ibid. of the Dutch <term lang="du">Ligghen</term>
to lye. Shares are goods
due to more by proportion,
from the Sax. schyren, <expan type="">id est</expan> to
divide. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluctiferous(a)">Fluctiferous (<etym lang="la">fluctifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that raiseth or bringeth
waves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluctuate(v)">Fluctuate (<etym lang="la">fluctuo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
rise in waves and surges,
to be boisterous and rough;
to waver, doubt, or be un&shy;
certain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluctisonant(a)">Fluctisonant (<etym lang="la">fluctisonus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sounding or roaring with
waves or billows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluctivagant(a)">Fluctivagant (<etym lang="la">fluctiva&shy;
gus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wandring on the wa&shy;
ter or Sea, tossed by the
waves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluctuous(a)">Fluctuous (<etym lang="la">fluctuosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
troublous, unquiet, boyste&shy;
rous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluent(a)" lexeme="fluid(a)">Fluent

or gushing out,
waterish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluminous(a)">Fluminous (<etym lang="la">fluminosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of rivers.</xpln></wordentry>

ing much.</xpln></wordentry>

or issue.</xpln></wordentry>

fresh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fodder(n)" lexeme="fother(n)">Fodder, orFother,</form> <xpln lang="en">a cer&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="r3v">
tain weight of lead, about
2000 pound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fodient(a)">Fodient (<etym lang="la">fodiens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that digs
or thrusts into.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foin(v)">To Foine (<etym lang="la">pungo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to prick
or sting. Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foin(n)">Foines,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Fur
brought for the most part out
of France. The top of this
Fur is black, and the ground
whitish; the beast that bears
it, is about the bigness of a
Cat. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="folio(n)">Folio (<etym lang="la">folium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sheet or
large leaf of paper. We say
a book is in Folio, when two
leaves of it make a sheet; in
Quarto, when four leaves
make a sheet; in Octavo,
when eight leaves go to the
sheet; Duodecimo, or in
Twelves, when the sheet is
made into twelve leaves, &amp;c 
Every folio or leaf hath two
pages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Foliatanes(pn)">Foliatanes (from <etym lang="la">folia</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
leaves)</form> <xpln lang="en">an order of religious
persons, who lived onely
upon leaves, which the Pope
put down, as finding leaves
unable to nourish mans body.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="folkland(n)">Folkland,</form> <xpln lang="en">Copy-hold-&shy;
Lands were so called in the
time of the Saxons, and the
Charter-lands were called
Bock-land . Kitch.174.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="folkmoot(n)">Folkmoote is a <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Saxon
word</class> compounded of <etym lang="sx">Folk</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">populus</term>, and <etym lang="sx">Gemettan</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">convenire</term>.</form> <xpln lang="en">It signifies (ac&shy;
cording to Mr Lambert in his
exposition of Saxon words,
 <term lang="la">verbo, conventus</term>) two kinds of 
Courts, one now called the
County Court, the other cal&shy;
led the Sheriffs Turn . This
word is stil in use among the 
Londoners, and signifies <term lang="la">Cele&shy;
brem ex omni Civitate coven&shy;
tum.</term> Stowes Survey. But
Mr. Manwood in his first part 
of Forest Laws, pag.111. hath
these words, Folkmore is the
Court holden in London, where&shy;
in all the folk and people of the
city did complain of the Mayor
and the Aldermen, for mis&shy;
government within the City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foliage(n)">Foliage (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Fueillage</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
branched work in painting or
Tapestry; Also leafines.
Herricks Poems.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="follicle(n)">Follicle (<etym lang="la">folliculus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
bag, purse, or bladder. Vul.
Err.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foliate(v)">Foliate (<etym lang="la">foliatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">leaved or
having leaves; Gold foliate, is,
leaf gold. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foment(n)">Foment (<etym lang="la">fomento</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
warm, comfort, cherish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fomentation(n)">Fomentation (<etym lang="la">fomentatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a fomenting, a comforting, or
asswaging. 

In Physick it properly sig&shy;
nifies powdry or dry things in
bags, or any liquor in a
Spunge or Bladder applyed
warm to the body to miti&shy;
gate pain, or to make way by
opening the pores, for oint&shy;
ments or plaisters to be appli&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fons Solis(n)">Fons Solis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fountain
near the Temple of Jupiter
Hammon in Lybia, that at mid&shy;
night is as hot, as boyling
water, and at noon as cold 


</page>

<page sig="r4r">
as any ice, which may the
rather be credited, since our
Bathes in England are much
warmer in the night then in
the day. Sir Wa. Raw. in his
History of the World, l.4. fol.
184.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fontal(a)">Fontal (<etym lang="la">fontalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to a Fountain, or
Well.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forable(a)">Forable (<etym lang="la">forabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be boated, or peir&shy;
ced.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foraminous(a)">Foraminous (<etym lang="la">foraminosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of holes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foraneous(a)">Foraneous (<etym lang="la">foraneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to a Market or
Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forcipated(a)">Forcipated (<etym lang="la">forcipatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
bended like a hook. Vul.
Err.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forloin(n)">Foreloin,</form> <xpln lang="en">A term in hunt&shy;
ing, when a Hound meets a
chase, and goes away with it,
before the rest of the 
Cry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forestall(v)">Forestal (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">from the Belg.</class> 
<etym lang="bl">Veur</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">ante</term>, and<etym lang="bl">Stallen</etym>,
 <term lang="la">
Merces disponere</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is to buy
Corn, Cattle, or other Mer&shy;
chandize by the way as it
comes towards the Fair or
Market to be sold, to the in&shy;
tent to sell the same again, at
a more high and dear price.
New Terms of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forestaller(n)">Forestaller,</form> <xpln lang="en">is he that fore&shy;
stals, and buys things in such
sort.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forelorn hope(n)">Forelorn Hope,</form> <xpln lang="en">a party
of Souldiers sent before the
whole body of the Army to
skirmish with the Enemy, the
French call it <etym lang="fr">Enfans perdues</etym>; 
the Roman Velites, were in
a manner answerable here&shy;
unto. 

Forelorn, comes from the
Belg<etym lang="bl">Verloren</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">perditus</term>, lost.
The Forelorn-Hope is given for
lost, in respect it is most com&shy;
monly desperate Service.<xref> See
Perdu</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="formalist(n)">Formalist (from <etym lang="la">forma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
one that is very punctual or
precise in his actions or
words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="formator(n)">Formator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fornication(n)">Fornication (<etym lang="la">fornicatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Whoredom, Leachery, spo&shy;
ken of single persons, if ei&shy;
ther party be married then tis
Adultery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fortitude(n)">Fortitude (<etym lang="la">fortitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
strength, valour, courage. It
is one of the four Cardinal
Vertues, and is thus defined.
Fortitude is a vertue that mo&shy;
derates the irascible power,
according to reason, and so
it helps us to overcome those 


</page>

<page sig="rrv">
difficulties, which require
courage in chusing one harm
to avoid another. Fit. Cat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fortuitous(a)" lexeme="fortuit(a)">Fortuitous 
Fortuite (<etym lang="la">fortuitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err=" hat">that</emend>
hapneth by
chance, sudden, casual, ac&shy;
cidental.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fosse Way(pn)">Fosse way (from <etym lang="la">foffus</etym>, dig'd)</form> <xpln lang="en">
several High-ways in England
so called, because tis concei&shy;
ved they were digg'd or made
passable by the ancient Ro&shy;
mans, or because they were
ditched at least on one side
See <xref lexeme="Watling Street">Watling-street</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Foulk(pn)" lexeme="Fulke(pn)">Foulk orFulke,</form> <xpln lang="en">a mans
name; Some derive it from
the German <etym lang="gr">Volig</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> noble
and gallant; But I from
<etym lang="sx">Folc</etym>, the English Saxon
word for people, as though
it were the same with <term lang="la">Pub&shy;
lius</term> of the Romans, and
onely translated from <term lang="la">Publius</term>
as beloved of the people and
Commons. Cam</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fracid(a)">Fracid: (<etym lang="la">fracidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">more
then ripe, rotten-ripe, putri&shy;
fied.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fraction(n)">Fraction (<etym lang="la">fractio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a break&shy;
or bursting.</xpln></wordentry>

a peece or gobbet of a thing

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="franc(n)">Franc,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a French coyn
of twenty <etym lang="fr"> sols tournois</etym>, which
amounts unto 2 s. sterl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Francis(pn)">Francis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">from
<etym lang="gr">Franc</etym>, that is free, not ser&shy;
vile or bound. The same
with the Greek <term lang="gk">Eleutheri&shy;
us</term>, and the Lat. <term lang="la">Liberius</term>.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Franciscans(pn)" lexeme="Franciscan Friars(pn)">Franciscans orFrancis&shy;
can Friers,</form> <xpln lang="en">a religious or&shy;
der instituted by St. Francis
an Italian, about the year of
our Lord, 1198. and con&shy;
firmed by Pope Innocent
the third; His rule pre&shy;
scribed Chastity, Obedi&shy;
ence, Poverty, much fast&shy;
ing, and other austerities
to all that should be admit&shy;
ted of that Order; Of
which you may read more in
St. Bonaven. de vita St. Francis&shy;
ci. Out of this great Or&shy;
der have sprung divers others,
as Observantes, Conventuales,
Minimi, Capuciani, Collecta&shy;
nei, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frangible(a)">Frangible (<etym lang="la">frangibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be broken, break&shy;
able.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="franchise(n)">Franchise ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">liberty,
freedom, exemption; also good 


</page>

<page sig="r5r">
breeding, free-birth; it is ta&shy;
ken with us for a priviledge
or exemption from ordinary
Jurisdiction, and sometimes
an immunity from tribute, &amp;c.
See Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frank almoin(n)">Frank-Almoine (<etym lang="la">libera E&shy;
leemosynna</etym>) <class type="etymlang" lang="fr"> in French</class> <etym lang="fr"><emend err="Frank Ausmone">Frank&shy;
aumosne</emend></etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our
Common Law a tenure or
title of Lands. Britton,
( Cap.66. num.5.) saith
thus of it. Frank-almoine
is Lands or Tenements be&shy;
stowed upon God, that is gi&shy;
ven to such people, as bestow
themselves in the service of
God, for pure and perpetual
Almes: whence the Feof&shy;
fers or givers cannot demand
any terrestrial service, so
long as the Lands remain
in the hands of the Feof&shy;
fees.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "almoin," 2.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frank marriage(n)">Frank marriage (<etym lang="la">liberum
maritagium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a tenure in
tayle special, growing from
these words in the gift,
Sciant, &amp;c. Me T. B. de M.
dedisse, &amp;c. I. A. <term lang="la">filio meo &amp;
Marg. uxori ejus fili&aelig; ver&aelig;  T.
N. in liberum maritagium
unum Messagium</term>, &amp;c. West.
p. I. Symb.2. Sect.303.
The effect of which words
is, that they shall have
the Land to them and the
heirs of their bodies, and
shall do no fealty unto the
Donor until the fourth De&shy;
gree, &amp;c. Vide New Terms
of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frank-pledge(n)">Frank-pledge (<etym lang="la">franciple&shy; 
gium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is compounded of
franc <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">liber</term>, and pledge, <expan type="">id est</expan> fi&shy;
dejussor, a free-pledge or sure&shy; 
ty, and signifies in our Com&shy;
mon Law, a pledge or surety
for free-men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fraternize(v)">To Fraternize (from <etym lang="la">fra&shy;
ter</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to agree as brothers;
to concur with, or be neer
unto; also to admit into a
Fraternity, brotherhood or
society.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fraternal(a)">Fraternal (<etym lang="la">fraternalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to a bro&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fratricelli(pn)">Fratricelli,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect of He&shy;
reticks invented by one Her&shy;
mannus an Italian, about the
yeer of Christ 1304 in time
of Pope Benedict the eleventh,
and Albertus the first Empe&shy;
ror, they were otherwise cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">fratres de paupere vita</term>,
brothers of a poor life; they
taught promiscuous beddings,
that nothing was to be held
proper or ones own, that
Christians are not to be Go&shy;
vernours of a Common&shy;
wealth, with other foolish
errors condemned by Pope
Bonifacius the eighth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fratricide(n)">Fratricide (<etym lang="la">fratricidium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
brother-slaughter.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="r5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frederic(pn)">Frederic ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Rich
peace, or (as the Monk
which made this allusi&shy; 
on would have it) peaceable
reign. 

 <term lang="la">Est adhibenda fides rationi nominis hujus
Compositi Frederic, duo componentia cujus
Sunt Frederic Frith, quid nisi Pax? Ric, quid nisi regum?
Sic per Hendiadin, Fredericus, quid nisi vel Rex.
Pacificus? vel regia Pax? Pax, pacificusque</term> .
For Frederic the English
have commonly used Frery 
and Fery, which hath been
now a long time a Christian
name in the ancient Family
of Tilney, and lucky to their
house, as they report. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frement(a)">Frement (<etym lang="la">fremens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gnash&shy;

ments; as (in Summer time)
light garments, cool air, cool
places, cool drinks, Bowres
or shades over-spread with
green boughs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fresco(a)">Fresco ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fresh, cool,
coldish; also unsalt, new
laid, new made, sweet; green
or lusty. As we say, to walk
or drink in Fresco. <expan type="">id est</expan> to walk
in the cool or fresh air, or to
drink new or fresh wine or o&shy;
ther liquor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fretrots(pn)">Fretrots,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Secta&shy;

cestuous, as Adamites, by
night, and suppressed in the
year, 1310. Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frication(n)" lexeme="friation(n)">Frication 
or 
Friation (<etym lang="la">fricatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
rubbing or
fretting toge&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="friar(n)">Friar orFrier (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">Frater</etym>, or <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class>
 <etym lang="fr">fr&eacute;re</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> a brother)</form> <xpln lang="en">there be
four principal Orders reckon&shy;
ned of them A.4. H.4. ca.17.
( viz.) Minors, Grey Friers,
or Franciscans ; Augustins ; Do&shy;
minicans or Black-Friers; and
White-Friers, or Carmelites ;
from these four Orders the
rest descended. See in Zecchi&shy;
us de Repub. Eccl. p 380. And
Linwood, tit. de Relig. Domib
ca. I. verbo, St. Augustin.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Friar Observant(pn)">Frier Observant (<etym lang="la">frater
observans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an Order of
Franciscans for the better un&shy;
derstanding of whom it is to
be noted, that of those four
Orders mentioned in the
word above, The Fran&shy;
ciscans are, <term lang="la"> Minores tam obser&shy;
vantes quam conventuales, &amp; Ca&shy;
puchini . Zecchius de Repub.
Eccl. tract. de regular. ca.2.</term>
These Friers Observant (men&shy;
tioned An.25. H.8. ca.12.)
are so called, because they
are not combined together in 


</page>

<page sig="r6r">
any Cloister, Covent, or
Corporation, as the Conven&shy;
tuals are, but onely tye them&shy;
selves to observe the Rules of
their Order, and more strict&shy;
ly then the Conventuals do;
and upon a singularity of zeal
separate themselves from
them, living in certain places
and companies of their own
chusing, and of this you may
read Hospinian, de Orig. &amp; prog.
Monachatus, fo 878. ca.38.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fricasse(n)">AFricasse (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Fricassee</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
any meat fried in a pan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Friga(pn)">Friga,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hermaphroditi&shy;
cal Idol, adored by the old
Saxons on the day now cal&shy;
led Friday, which thence 
took its denomination, which
day was of old called Frige&shy;
deag . Verst. p 63.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fugalia(n)">Fugalia ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Feast
annually solemnized by the
old Romans in remembrance
of the expulsion of the
Kings out of Rome. Ac&shy;
cording to which pattern,
the joyful English having
cleared the Country of the
Danes, instituted the annu&shy;
al Sports ofHock-tide, the
word (in their old Saxon
tongue) importing the time
of scorning, or triumphing.
This Solemnity consisted 
in the merry meetings of the
neighbors on those daies,
during which the Festival
lasted, and was celebrated
by the younger sort of
both Sexes, with all manner
of Exercises, and Pastimes
in the streets, as Shrovetide
yet is. But now time hath
so corrupted it, that (the name
excepted) there remains no
sign of the first institution.
Heyl. 

Verstegan thinks this Hock&shy;
tide may come from the
Teutonick,Heugh-tide, <expan type="">id est</expan>
A time of gladness, or
joy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fugation(n)">Fugation (<etym lang="la">fugatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a put&shy;
ting to flight, or driving a&shy;
way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fugue(n)">Fugue ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a chase
or report of Musick; as
when two or more parts chase
one another in the same
point.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fugitive(a)">Fugitive (<etym lang="la">fugitivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
flitting, ready to run a&shy;
way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fugitive's goods(n)">Fugitives goods (<etym lang="la">bona
fugitivorum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are the pro&shy;
per goods of him that flies
upon felony, which after the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furcation(n)">Furcation (from <etym lang="la">furca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Furies(pn)">Furies (<etym lang="la">furi&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">three
imaginary Fiends or Spirits
in Hell, having Snakes
growing on them instead of
hairs. 

Poets feigned them to be
the Daughters of the River
Acheron and Night, and to
have the Office of tormen&shy;
ting the souls of murtherers
and wicked men, their names
were Alecto. <expan type="">id est</expan> uncessant&shy;
ly tormenting; Meg&aelig;ra, <expan type="">id est</expan>
enraged; And Tysiphone,
<expan type="">id est</expan> the Avenger of mur&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="r7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Furina(pn)">Furina</form>, <xpln lang="en">the goddess of
Theeves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furlong(n)">Furlong (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">of two Fr. words</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Fort-long</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> very long)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
quantity of ground, contain&shy;
ing twenty Lugs, Roods, or
Poles in length, and every
Pole sixteen foot, and a half,
eight of which Furlongs make
a mile. An.35. E. I. ca.6. It
is otherwise the eighth part
of an Acre. See <xref>Acre</xref>. In the
former signification the Ro&shy;
mans call it <term lang="la">[ Stadium</term>] in the
latter [<term lang="la">Jugerum</term>] This mea&shy;
sure which we call a Pole, is
also called a Perch, and dif&shy;
fers in length, according to
the custom of the Country.
See <xref>Perch</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furole(n)">Furole ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little blaze
of fire, appearing by night
on the tops of Souldiers
Launces, or at Sea on Sayl&shy;
yards, where it whirles and
leaps in a moment from one
place to another, some Ma&shy;
riners call it St. Herme's fire ;
if it come double, tis held a
sign of good luck; if single, o&shy;
therwise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furtive(a)">Furtive (<etym lang="la">furtivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is
done by stealth, filching,
theevish, felonious.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fuscation(n)">Fuscation (<etym lang="la">fuscatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
darkning or clouding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fusibility(n)">Fusibility,</form> <xpln lang="en">meltableness,
that may be molten. S. Hen.
Wotton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fusible(a)">Fusible (<etym lang="la">fusilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is or
may be molten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fusil(n)">AFusil (Lat. <etym lang="la">fusillus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
little Spindle: It is also a
term in Herauldry, and sig&shy; 
nifies that in a Coat of Arms,
which is in a manner like a
Spindle, as in that of Sire de
Montagu (a French name)
<term lang="fr"> il porte dargent, trois fusillees
en fasse de gueules</term>. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fusion(n)">Fusion (<etym lang="la">fusio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a melting
or pouring forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fustigate(v)">Fustigate (<etym lang="la">fustigo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

gel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="futility(n)">Futility (<etym lang="la">futilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">light&shy;

the being to come of any

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="galoshes(n)">Galoches ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wooden
shoos, or patens made all
of a peece, without any
latchet or tye of leather, and
worn in France by the poor
Clowns in Winter. What our
English Galoches are, and by 
whom worn, every one
knows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gamahe(n)">Gamahez ( <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab:</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">as Ta&shy;
lismans are Images or figures
made by art under certain
Constellations; So Gamahez
are such figures found so
wrought by nature, held to
be of greater vertue, being
therefore worn by some per&shy;
sons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gambado(n)">Gambado (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">from the Ital.</class> 
<etym lang="it">Gamba</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> a leg)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="with" source="errata"></emend> a kind
of leather instrument affixed
to the Saddle in the place of
Stirrops, wherein we put
our legs when we ride, to
preserve them from dirt and
cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gambol(n)">Gamboles (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">gambade</etym>,
Ital. <etym lang="it"> gamba</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan></form> <xpln lang="en">a leg, because
gamboles, or (as we call them)
Christmas gamboles are pro&shy;
perly games or tumbling
tricks plaid with the legs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gammot(n)">Gammot,</form> <xpln lang="en">an incision
knife.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gamut(n)">Gammut orGamut,</form> <xpln lang="en">the
first note in Musick, from
whence the whole number of
notes take denomination.
As the Greek Cross-row is
called Alphabet from the two
first letters, Alpha and <emend err="Be"> Be&shy;</emend>
ta.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ganching(n)">Ganching,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a form of
putting Offendors to death
in Turky, which is to let them
fall from on high, upon hooks,
and there to hang till they
die, by the anguish of their
wounds, or more miserable fa&shy;
mine. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gangic(a)">Gangick,</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertain&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="r8v">
ing to Ganges a great Ri&shy;
ver in India Oriental, the
breadth of it being in the
narrowest place eight, in the
broadest twenty miles, and
the depth never less then a
hundred foot. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gang-Week(pn)">Gang-week.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Rogation
week</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gangrene(n)">Gangreen (<etym lang="la">gangr&aelig;na</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
dead flesh in the body of
a botch, an eating Ulcer that
will quickly infect all the
body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gantlope(n)">Gantlope (<etym lang="la">Ghent Lope</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a punishment of Souldiers,
first invented at Ghent, or
Gant in Flanders, and there&shy;
fore so called. Lope in
Dutch signifies running ; for
the Offendor is to run
through the whole Regiment
with his upper part naked,
and every fellow-Souldi&shy;
er to have a whip at him,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ganymede(pn)">Ganymede (<etym lang="la">Ganymedes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the name of a Trojan boy,
whom Jupiter so loved (say
the Poets) as hee took
him up to Heaven, and
made him his Cup-bearer.
Hence any boy that is lo&shy;
ved for carnal abuse, or is
hired to be used contrary to
nature, to commit the de&shy;
testable sin of Sodomy is
called a Ganymede ; an
Ingle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garb(n)">Garbo ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a garbe,
comeliness, gracefulness or
good fashion; Also a
sharp or piquant taste; ap&shy;
plyed of late to Wine or 
Beer, that has a kind of plea&shy;
sing piquantness in its re&shy;
lish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gargarize(v)">Gargarize (<etym lang="la">gargarizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gargarism(n)">Gargarism (<etym lang="la">gargaris&shy;
mus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a liquid potion
to wash the mouth and
throat with, which is not
suffered to go down, but to
bubble up and down the
throat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gargantua(pn)">Gargantua,</form> <xpln lang="en">great throat.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garnish(v)" lexeme="garnishment(n)">Garnish orGarnishment
(from the <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> Garnir</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to
provide, furnish, fill with)</form> <xpln lang="en">
it is commonly taken for a
<emend err="ceratin">certain</emend> fee or quantity of
good liquor which prison&shy;
ers either give their fellow&shy;
Prisoners or else their Kee&shy;
pers at their first admittance
