perly signifies a furnishing,
storing, or supplying, and
sometimes a giving of assu&shy;
rance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gawdy days(n)" lexeme="grand days(n)">Gawdy orGrand days.</form> <xpln lang="en">In
the Inns of Court there are
four of these in the yeer, that
is, one in every term, viz. 
Ascension day in Easter Term,
Midsummer day in Trinity
Term, All Saints day in Mi&shy;
chaelmas Term, and Candlemas
day in Hillary term; these
four are or lately were no
days in Court, and on these
days double Commons are
allowed, and Musick former&shy;
ly on all Saints, and Candle&shy;
mas day, as the first and last
of Christmas. The Etymo&shy; 
logy of the word may be ta&shy;
ken from Judge Gawdy, who
(as some affirm) was the first
instituter of those days, or
rather from gaudium, because
(to say truth) they are days
of joy, as bringing good cheer
to the hungry Students. In
Colledges they are most com&shy;
monly called gawdy, in Inns
of Court Grand days, and in
some places they are called
Coffer days.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gavelkind(n)">Gavelkind,</form> <xpln lang="en">a custom
whereby every son or heir
male inherites a portion alike
in his Ancestors estate, and is
derived of three Saxon
words, <etym lang="sx">gife,eal,cyn,</etym> that is,
given to all the kin, <term lang="la">quasi</term>, <term lang="la">om&shy;
nibus Cognatione proximis data
h&aelig;reditas</term>. <emend err="Dodd evidg.">Dodderidge</emend>. Or
rather from<etym lang="sx">gafel</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">sensus,
tributum, pensio</term>, and<etym lang="sx">cynd</etym> 
 <term lang="la">natura, genus, conditio</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gauger(n)">Gawgeour.</form> <xpln lang="en">An Officer
having Authority to give a
mark of allowance to
all Tuns, Hogsheads, Pipes,
Barrels, &amp;c. of Wine, Oyl,
Honey and Butter, before
they ought to be sold, it
comes from the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Gawger</etym>,
i a Gager or Measurer of
Caske, &amp;c. Of this Of&shy;
fice see the Stat.27. Ed.
3. cap.8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gazet(n)">Gazet ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
Venetian Coyn scarce worth
our farthing, also a Bill of
news or a short relation of the
general occurrences of the
time, forged most commonly 


</page>

<page sig="s1v">
at Venice, and thence dis&shy;
persed every month into
most parts of Christendom.
Cotg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gazul(n)">Gazul.</form> <xpln lang="en">All &AElig;gypt, where
the Nile arrives not, is no&shy;
thing but a whitish Sand
bearing no grass, but two lit&shy;
tle weeds called Suhit and Ga&shy;
zul, which burnt to ashes,
and conveyed to Venice, make
the finest Christal glasses Sir
H. Blount in his Levantine
voyage.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gebaltark(pn)">Gebaltark or Gebaltare,</form> <xpln lang="en">(cor&shy;
ruptly called the Streights
of Gibralter) so called from
Gebal, which in Arabick signi&shy;
fies a Mountain, and Tarec the
son of Abdalla, who having
transported his Barbarians o&shy;
ver the Streight, secured his
Army with the natural forti&shy;
fication of the place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gehenna(pn)">Gehenna,</form> <xpln lang="en">Properly signi&shy;

Altars, there sacrificing their

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genealogy(n)">Genealogy (<etym lang="la">genealogia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a description of ones linage,
stock, or pedegree.</xpln></wordentry>

ingendring, of an ingendring,
faculty or breeding power.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="generosity(n)">Generosity (<etym lang="la">generositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
nobleness of minde, gentle&shy;
manlike courage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Genesis(pn)">Genesis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a genera&shy;
tion. The first Book of Mo&shy;
ses is so called in Greek and
Latine, because it declares
the Creation and Generation 


</page>

<page sig="s2r">
of all things. In Hebrew it
is <term lang="he">bereschith</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">in principio</term>, and
took its name from the first
words of the first Chapter of
the said book, as do many o&shy;
ther books of the Old-Testa&shy;
ment. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genethliacal(a)">Genethliacal (<etym lang="la">genethliacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to the casting of
Nativities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genethialogy(n)">Genethialogy  (<etym lang="la">genethlialo&shy;
gia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">telling or casting of Na&shy;
tivities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genethliac(n)">Genethliaques.</form> <xpln lang="en">Casters
of mens fortunes by the day
or hour of their birth; or
books treating of that sub&shy;
ject.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genial(a)">Genial (<etym lang="la">genialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full of
mirth: pertaining to marri&shy;
age; the marriage-bed was
of old called the Genial-bed,
 <term lang="la">quasi</term> Genital-bed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genital(a)">Genital (<etym lang="la">genitalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">serving
to engender, or for breed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genitals(n)">Genitals (<etym lang="la">genitale</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
privy members of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genitive(a)">Genitive (<etym lang="la">genitivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">natu&shy;
ral, engendring, of an ingen&shy;
dring faculty, that hath pow&shy;
er to ingender.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genitor(n)">Genitor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Father, a
beginner, a begetter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genius(n)">Genius ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a good or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentilitious(a)" lexeme="gentilitial(a)">Gentilitious 
Gentilitial  (<etym lang="la">gentilitius</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">that per&shy;
tains to a stock, an use or pro&shy;
perty taken from ancestors,
of the same kindred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gentile(pn)">Gentil (<etym lang="la">gentilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">among
the Jews all were Gentiles, 
that were not of one of the
twelve Tribes: Now com&shy;
monly we call them Gentiles,
that profess not the faith of
Christ.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentilesse(n)">Gentilesse ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Gentry,
Gentility, Nobility.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentilism(n)">Gentilism (<etym lang="la">gentilismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
opinion or belief of the Gen&shy;
tiles; paganism, heathenish&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentleman(n)">Gentleman (<etym lang="la">generosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
seems to be compounded of
two words, the one French
( <etym lang="fr">gentile</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">honestus, vel honestolo&shy;
co natus</term>;) the other Saxon
(<etym lang="sx">mon</etym>) as if you would say,
a man well born. The Italian
follows the very word, calling
those <etym lang="it">Gentil homini</etym>, whom we
call Gentlemen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genuflexion(n)">Genuflexion (<etym lang="la">genuflexio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the bowing of the knee.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genus(n)">Genus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the begin&shy;
ning of ones birth; a kindred,
stock, linage; a kind or fa&shy;
shion, &amp;c. also a Gender.
It is also a term in Logick;
and is the first of the five
Predicables ; When the Pre&shy;
dicate comprehends the full
Answer to a Question, 'tis
called a Species ; but if it
onely contains a part, so that
other common considerations
are comprehended under it,
'tis called a Genus. See Mr.
Whites Peripatetical Institutions
p.17.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geodesy(n)">Geodesie (<etym lang="la">geod&aelig;sia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the art
of measuring Land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geodesian(n)">Geodesian (<etym lang="la">geod&aelig;tes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
measurer of Land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geography(n)">Geography (<etym lang="la">geographia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is 


</page>

<page sig="s2v">
a description of the earth by
her parts and their limits.
Scituations, inhabitants, Ci&shy;
ties, Rivers, fertility, and ob&shy;
servable matters, with all o&shy;
ther things annexed there&shy;
unto. Heyl. <term lang="la"> Geographi&aelig;
proprium est unam &amp; continuam
terram cognitam offendere quem
admodum se habeat natur&acirc; &amp;
positione</term> .Ptolemie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geographer(n)">Geographer (<etym lang="la">geographus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a describer of the earth</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geomanty(n)">Geomantie (<etym lang="la">geomantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">di&shy;
vination by points and Cir&shy;
cles made on the earth, or by
opening of the earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geometry(n)">Geometry (<etym lang="la">geometria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Art of due proportion, con&shy;
sisting in Lineaments, Forms,
Distances, and Greatness.
There are four Principles
hereof, to wit, 1 A prick
or point. 2 A Line. 3 A
Superficies or outside. 4 A
body. 

It hath properly the name
from measuring the Earth,
being first found out in
&AElig;gypt, and was of great e&shy;
stimation among the Ancient
Grecians.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geometrician(n)">Geometrician (<etym lang="la">geometra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
one skilful in Geometry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geometrical(a)">Geometrical (<etym lang="la">geometricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to Geometry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geoponical(a)">Geoponical (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&pi;&#x03cc;&nu;&iota;&kappa;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging
to husbandry or Tillage. 
Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Georgians(pn)">Georgians,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Sect of per&shy;
nicious Heretiques, so called
from one David George, born
at Delft in Holland, he held 
that the Law and Gospel
were unprofitable for the at&shy;
taining heaven, &amp;c. That he
was the true Christ and Messi&shy;
as, &amp;c. with other such dam&shy;
nable Tenets, he dyed in the
yeer 1556. Heil 

Also a sort of Christians,
inhabiting a Country called
Georgia, lying between Col&shy;
chos, Caucasus, the Caspian
Sea and Armenia, heretofore
Iberia and Armenia, they are so
called not of St. George (as
some write) their selected
Patron, but of their said
Country, so named long be&shy;
fore the time wherein he is
supposed to have lived; yet
they bear much honor to this
St. George, the Cappadocian
Martyr (the same whom the
Knights of the Garter have
formerly so much honoured
in England) always carrying
his image in their Standards,
&amp;c. These in some points of
their Religion, agree with the
Roman Catholiques, but in o&shy;
thers they follow the Greci&shy;
ans; they have a Metropolitan 
of their own, for their spiri&shy;
tual guide, whom they o&shy;
bey most punctually, and who
hath his seat on Mount Sina, in
the Cloyster of St. Katherine
the Virgin Martyr. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="georgic(n)"><emend err="Georgicks" source="errata">Georgicka</emend> (<etym lang="la">georgica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">books
entreating of the tillage of
the earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gerah(n)">Gerah.</form> <xpln lang="en">An Hebrew weight
containing the twentieth part
of a Sheckle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gerent(a)">Gerent (<etym lang="la">gerens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bearing or
carrying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gertrude(pn)">Gertrude orGartrude</form> <xpln lang="en">(a
womans name) compounded
of the old SaxonGat <expan type="">id est</expan> All,
&amp;trude. <expan type="">id est</expan> Truth or Troth; for
d was sometimes by our An&shy;
cestors indifferently used in&shy;
stead of (th) So that Gertrude
is as much as All truth. Ver&shy;
stegan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gibraltar(pn)">Gibraltar orGebaltarck
</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called (as some Authors
affirm) from Gibal Tariff, one
of the principal Leaders of the
Moors into Spain) a Straight
in the Mediterranean Sea 
on the North-side of this
Straight, was Mount Calpe, on
The South Mount Abila, on
which Hercules placed his so
memorized Pillars, with the
inscription of <term lang="la"> Nil Ultra</term>. Heyl.
But see <xref lexeme="gebaltark">Gebaltarck</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gilbertines(pn)">Gilbertines</form> <xpln lang="en">A Religious
Order begun by one Gilbert at
Terington and Sempringham in
Lincolnshire in England, about
the yeer of Christ 1148. Pol.
Vir. This Gilbert built 13
Monasteries of his Order in
England; he was Canonized
by Pope Innocentius the third.
And commemoration is made
of him on the thirteenth of
October . Nova leg. S. S. Ang.
fol.167.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gild(n)" lexeme="geld(n)">Gild <term lang="la">alias</term>Geld (from the
Saxon word (<etym lang="sx">Gildan</etym>) <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">solve&shy;
re</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a Tribute, or
sometime an amercement :
or thirdly a fraternity or
company combined together
by Orders and Lawes made
among themselves by the
Princes Licence. And 


</page>

<page sig="s3v">
Gildhal is conceived to be so
called, there being a fraterni&shy;
ty or Commonalty of men
gathered into one combinati&shy;
on, supporting their common
charge by a mutual contribu&shy;
tion. See more in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gildable(a)">Gildable.</form> <xpln lang="en">Mr. Camden,
pag. 349, dividing Suffolk into
three parts, calls the first
Gildable, because tribute is
thence gathered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gisarme(n)">Gisarmes13. An. E. I. stat.

Fleta writes it Sisarmes l. I.
cap.24. I take it, it ought ra&shy; 
ther to be written Bisarmes, a
double weapon, or a weapon
with two pikes. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gist(n)">Giste ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a bed, couch,
lodging place to lye on or
rest in; hence came the Gifts 
of the Kings Progress, that is,
a writing containing the
names of the houses or Towns
where the King or Prince in&shy;
tended to lye or rest every
night through their Progress.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glister(n)">Glister (<etym lang="la">Clyster</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a liquor
made sometime with sodden
flesh, sometime with de&shy;
coction of herbs or other
things, which by a Pipe is
conveyed into the lower
parts of the body. It is
written, that the use hereof
was first learned from a
bird in &AElig;gypt called Ibis,
much like a Storke, which
bird doth often with her
bill, open her hinder parts,
when nature of her self doth
not expel what is needful.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

gluiness, clamminess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnarity(n)">Gnarity (<etym lang="la">gnaritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">expe&shy;
rience skilfulness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnathonical(a)">Gnathonical (<etym lang="la">Gnathonicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
flattering, deceitful in words;
soothing ones humor to get
by him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnathorize(v)">To Gnathorize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to play
the smell-feast, to flatter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnavity(n)">Gnavity (<etym lang="la">gnavitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">activi&shy;
ty, lustiness, quickness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnomical(a)">Gnomical (from <etym lang="la">Gnoma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to measure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gnostics(pn)">Gnosticks,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect of He&shy;
reticks (their first according
to the more common opini&shy;
on, was Carpocras) sprung a&shy;
bout the yeer of Christ one
hundred twenty and five, in
time of Pope Xistus the 
first, and the Emperour Adri&shy; 
an the first; they arrogated
to themselves a high degree of
skill and knowledge in all
things, and therefore were
called Gnostici, from the
Greek word <etym lang="gk">&gamma;&nu;&#x1ff6;&#x03c3;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">cognitio</term>;
they were also called <emend err="Borbori">Borbori&shy;</emend>
t&aelig; or Borboriani for abomina&shy;
ble foul practises, they had
among them: they held the
soul of man to be of Gods
substance; they held two
Gods, one good, the other
bad; they denyed the future
judgement, so to gain more
liberty to their vices, and
progress to their Doctrine,
with other absurd errors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnomonic(n)">Gnomonick, (<etym lang="la">gnomonice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the Art of Dyalling; con&shy;
sisting in the knowledge of
the scituation, lying or mea&shy;
sure of any place of Coun&shy;
try.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goety(n)">Goetie (<etym lang="la">goetia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the black
Art; divelish Magick or
Witchcraft.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gog and Magog(pn)">Gog and Magog.</form> <xpln lang="en"> Gog
by interpretation of the He&shy;
brew word is <term lang="la">tectus</term>, cover&shy;
ed; and Magog is uncovered.
In Scripture by Gog and Ma&shy;
gog are understood certain
Nations, (some Exposi&shy;
tors take them to be the A&shy;
quilonar Scythians, Iberians,
and Muscovites) or Princes
that with their Nations shall
more fiercely then others<emend err="con&shy;"> con&shy;</emend>
cur with Antichrist in perfe&shy;
cating the Church of Christ
Ezechiel 38,39. Revelation
20.8. 

To be a Gog or on Gog, is 


</page>

<page sig="s4v">
to be on top of the house;
to be proud or insolent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gogo &agrave; gogo(adv)">Gogo a Gogo ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">with
full contentment or his belly
full.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED but see "agog, adv.".
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="golden number(n)">Golden number,</form> <xpln lang="en">a number
which changeth every yeer,
by adding one to the Golden
number of the yeer going
before, until it grow as high
as nineteen, and then the
Golden number returns to
one again. For example,
this yeer 1656 the Golden
number is four, the next yeer
therfore it will be five, &amp;c.
This Golden number was de&shy;
vised to finde out the Feast
of Easter.<xref> See Cycle</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Golden Fleece(n)">Golden fleece.</form> <xpln lang="en">The Gold
in grains, which is found in
Rivers and purling Brooks,
they used in some parts to
gather with the help of
Sheep skins, that had the
Wooll on them, &amp;c. from
which manner of trying or
finding gold, the Fable of the
Golden Fleece was invented,
which Jason and his Argonautes 
sailed for to Pontus, which
was nothing else but a Rob&shy;
bery of the Colchians of that
gold which they had found
out and gathered, with such
Wooll-skins. First part of
the Treasury of Times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Golgotha(pn)">Golgotha</form> <xpln lang="en">a Syrian word,
signifying, a place of dead
mens skulls. It was a
place at Hierusalem on the
North side of Mount Sion, so 
called, because there lay the
skulls of offenders put to
death. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="golpe(n)">AGolpe ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">at a
blow; also a slash. Caba&shy;
la</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED but see "gulp, n.2."
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gomer(n)">Gomer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure among
the Hebrews, containing of
ours a Gallon and almost a
Pint. 

The Israelites when they
were fed from Heaven with
Manna in the Desart, re&shy; 
ceived every one this mea&shy;
sure full, for a days allow&shy;
ance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gomorrhean(pn)">Gomorrhean (from <etym lang="la">Go&shy;
morrha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sodomite, a <emend err="Bug"> Bug&shy;</emend>
gerer.</xpln></wordentry>

<xpln lang="en">A Venetian Wherry-boat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gonorrhea(n)">Gonorrhea ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
ease called the running of
the Reines; the flux of na&shy;
tural seed of man or woman
unwittingly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gordian knot(n)">Gordian knot.</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> a knot
which cannot be loosed:
The phrase ariseth from this
old story. Gordius (a King
of Phrygia Major) being rai&shy;
sed from the plow to the
Scepter, placed the furni&shy;
ture of his Wain and Ox&shy;
en in the Temple of Apollo
tyed in such a knot, that
the Monarchy of the world
was promised to him that
could untye it: which when
Alexander had long tryed,
and could not do, he cut it
with his sword. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="s5r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gorgon(pn)">Gorgon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a terrible
fighting woman. Poets feign
there were three such, daugh&shy;
ters to King Phorchus, their
names were Medusa, Schenio,
and Euryale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gourmand(n)">Gourmand ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Glot&shy;
ton, great-eater, a belly&shy;
God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gormandize(v)">Gormandize (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Gour&shy;
mander</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to ravine, devoure,
glut, or gluttonize it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gospel(n)">Gospel (<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">from the Saxon</class> 
<etym lang="sx"><f type="oe"/>godspel</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">is compounded
of <etym lang="sx">God</etym> and <etym lang="sx">Spel</etym>, the word
<etym lang="sx"><f type="oe"/>god</etym> among the Saxons sig&shy;
nifying good, as well as God,
and no difference being dis&shy;
cernable in the writing of
these two words among
them; unless, when tis ta&shy;
ken for God, it hath an e after 
it. (<term lang="sx">Spel</term>) seems to signifie
(word, or mystical speech) a&shy;
mong the Saxons, as when
<term lang="oe"><f type="oe"/>bigspel</term> (Deut.28.37.) sig&shy;
nifies a by-word or Proverb,
or (as it is used in the north)
by-spel . Some remains of the
use of this word are still a&shy;
mong us, as when a Charm, 
<term lang="la">carmen</term>, <term lang="gk">&#x1f14;&pi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</term>, indifferently
a verse or a word, one or more
lines of Scripture or other&shy;
wise, either spoken or writ&shy;
ten, and hung about ones
neck, on design to drive a&shy;
way a disease (according to
the superstitious beleef and
practise of our ancestors) is
still among us called a Spel,
from the ancient use of it, as
in Propertius. 
<term lang="la">Sunt verba &amp; voces, quibus hunc lenire dolorem
Possis</term> ----) 
So this wordGodspel and
by Euphony, Gospel, signifies
the word of God ; the mysti&shy;
cal speech, or good tidings,
delivered first by an Angel,
after by the Evangelists, &amp;c.
Dr. Hammond in his Annota&shy;
tions, p.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gossamer(n)">Gossymeare orGossomor
( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the white and cob&shy;
web-like exhalations, which
fly abroad in hot sunny wea&shy;
ther. Chau.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gracility(n)">Gracility (<etym lang="la">gracilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lean&shy;
ness, smalness, slenderness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gossip(n)">Gossip (from the old Sax.
<etym lang="sx">Godsip</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">our Christian an&shy;
cestors (understanding a spi&shy; 
ritual affinity to grow be&shy;
tween the Parents and such
as undertook for the child at
Baptism) called each other
by the name ofGodsib,
which is as much as to say, as
that they were sib together,
that is, of Kin together
through God: And the child
in like manner called such,
his God-Fathers or God&shy;
mothers, &amp;c. Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Graces(pn)">Graces (<etym lang="la">Charites</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">three
Sisters poetically supposed
the daughters of Jupiter and
Venus: they were called Ag&shy;
laia, Thalia, and Euphrosyne:
The moral was, to express 


</page>

<page sig="s5v">
the mutual love, and chear&shy;
ful conversation, which
ought to be among friends;
for they were painted naked,
to signifie friendship ought to
be plain without dissimulati&shy;
on, smiling and merry, to
shew, men should do good
willingly; young, and mai&shy;
den-like, to teach, freind&shy;
ship should consist in honest
things; and holding hands
together in a round ring, to
shew a benefit bestowed, re&shy;
turns again to the giver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gradual(n)">Gradual (<etym lang="la">graduale</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
part of the Mass which was
said or sung between the E&shy;
pistle and the Gospel, as a
grade or step from the first to
the later, signifying that the
profession of a Christian is to
be ascending from the Epistle 
to the Gospel, from the doctrin
of the Prophets and <emend err="Apostl s">Apostles</emend>
to Christs, from one degree
of vertue to another. 

Gradual Psalms, are fifteen
Psalms so called, that is, those
fifteen together from the 118.
to 133. or from the 120. to
135. they are so called from a
custom the Jews observed of
singing them, as they ascen&shy;
ded up fifteen steps or degrees 
(in Latine <term lang="la">gradus</term>) towards
Solomons Temple, where the
Levites did praise God with
a great voyce, 2 Chron.
20.19.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="graduality(n)">Graduality,</form> <xpln lang="en">that by which
a thing is constituted intrin&shy;
secally, in the being Gra&shy;
dual.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="graduate(v)">Graduate (<etym lang="la">graduatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that hath taken degree of
learning in a publick Uni&shy;
versity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gradation(n)">Gradation (<etym lang="la">gradatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
going by degrees, as up
stairs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="granate(n)">Granado ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span </class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pome&shy;
granat, an apple filled with
delicious grain; there is also
a warlike Engin that being
filled with Gunpowder and
other materials is wont to
be shot out of a wide mou&shy;
thed peece of Ordinance, and
is called a Granado, for the
likeness it hath with the o&shy;
ther Granado in fashion, and
being fully stuffed as the o&shy;
ther Granado is, though the
materials be very differ&shy;
ent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grand sergeanty(n)">Grand Sergeantie,</form> <xpln lang="en">is in
our Common Law, where
one holds Lands of the King
by service, which he ought
to do in his own person, as
to bear the Kings banner, or
his Spear, &amp;c. See Littleton
tit. Sergeanty, and Cow. tit.
Chivalrie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grange(n)">Grange (<etym lang="la">grangia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
house or building, not one&shy;
ly where corn is laid up, as
Barns are, but also where
there be Stables for Horses,
Stals for Oxen, and other
Cattle, Styes for Hogs and o&shy;
ther things necessary for Hus&shy;
bandry. Lindw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grecism(n)">Grecism (<etym lang="la">gr&aelig;cismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Greek church(n)">Greek Church</form> <xpln lang="en">differs
from the Roman Catholick.
1. Denying the Holy Ghost
to proceed from the Father
and the Son. 2. Denying
Purgatory, but praying for
the dead. 3. Beleeving that
holy men enjoy not the pre&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="s6v">
sence of God before the Re&shy;
surrection. 4. Communica&shy;
ting in both kinds; but using
leavened bread, and mingling
warm water with wine, which
both together they distribute
with a spoon. 5. Receiving <emend err="chil">chil&shy;</emend>
dren of seven years old to the
Sacrament, because then they
begin to sin. 6. Forbidding
extream Unction, Confirma&shy;
tion, and fourth Marriages.
7. Admitting none to Or&shy;
ders, but such as are marri&shy;
ed, and prohibiting marriage
to them that are actually in
Orders. 8. Rejecting carved
Images, but admitting the
painted. 9 Observing four
Lents in the year. 10. Re&shy;
puting it unlawful to fast on
Saturdays. So Heylin; But
others relate the Grecian dif&shy;
ferences from the Roman Ca&shy;
tholick otherwise, as may be
seen in Authors that write of
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grece(n)">Greese (<etym lang="la">gradus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stair, step
or degree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gregal(a)">Gregal (<etym lang="la">gregalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of the
same <emend err="ftock">stock</emend> or company, com&shy;
mon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gregorian(a)">Gregorian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cap of
hair. 

Gregorian Accompt so called
from Pope Gregory the thir&shy;
teenth.<xref lexeme="julian account"> See Julian Accompt</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gremious(a)">Gremious (<etym lang="la">gremiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the lap or bo&shy;
som.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="griff-graff(adv)">Griffe-Graffe ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">by

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grilliade(n)">Grilliade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a broyled

to please the eye. Cleavelands

be beaten with a lively and

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gryffon(n)">Gryffen orGryffon (<etym lang="la">Gryps</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a strange Bird (as some anci&shy;
ent Authors affirm) with four 


</page>

<page sig="s7r">
feet armed with cruel claws,
being from the breast up&shy;
ward fashioned like an Eagle,
but of purple colour, with
red fiery eyes, and whitish
wings, and in the hinder part
black, made much like a Ly&shy;
on. This bird nests in the
high mountains, and is<emend err="excee"> excee&shy;</emend>
ding hard to be taken, except 
very young, for he will ad&shy;
venture on any man, and is
so fierce, that he often kils
Elephants: he is most enemy
to horses; for which cause
Virgil in his eighth Eclog.
brings in the shepheard
Damon; who wondred at
a strange Marriage, speaking
thus. 

 <term lang="la">Junguntur jam Gryphes Equis -- </term>

The Gryffins fierce are joyn'd with horses now. Bul. 

But modern authors,
as Aldrovandus, Michovius,
and others say there is no
such animal extant. See Vul.
Er. fo.129.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guadiana(pn)">Guadiana,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in
Spain which runs under
ground the space of fifteen
miles: Hence the Spaniards
brag that they have a Bridge
whereon 10000 cattle daily
feed, Hist. of Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guastaliens(pn)">Guastaliens,</form> <xpln lang="en">an order of
religious people, consist&shy;
ing both of men and women,
and instituted the year 1537.
by the Countess of Guastala, a
Mantuan Lady. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

ler.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gules(n)">Gules.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Geules</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gule of August(pn)" lexeme="Yule of August(pn)">Gule, or Yule of August, <emend err=""> (</emend>
may come perhaps <class type="etymlang" lang="br">from the
Br.</class> <etym lang="br">Gwil</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">festum</term>, or <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from
the Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">jubilum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the first
day of August, called in
old Almanacks St. Peter ad&shy;
vincula, or in our latter Al&shy;
manacks, Lammas day . And
An.27. E.3. Stat.3. cap. vinco.
Fitzha. nat. br. fo.62.I. called
Gule of August, alias Goule de
August . Plowd. casu Mines,
fo.316. b. It is the very day
of St, Peter ad vincula, which
was wont and is still, within
the limits of the Roman Ca&shy;
tholick Church, celebrated
upon the very Calends of Au&shy;
gust . It is by some conjectured
the Gule <class type="etymlang" lang="la">comes of the Latin</class> 
(<etym lang="la">Gula</etym>) or <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">the Fr.</class> (<etym lang="fr">Gueule</etym>) the
throat. The reason of this
conjecture is in Durands ratio&shy;
nali divinor. l.7. ca. de festo 


</page>

<page sig="s7v">
S. Petri ad vincula, who saith,
That one Quirinus a Tribune,
having a daughter who had a
disease in her throat, went to
Alexander then Pope of Rome,
the sixth from St. Peter, and
desired of him to borrow or
see the chains that St. Peter
was chained with under Nero:
which request obtained, his
said daughter kissing the said
Chain, was cured of her dis&shy;
ease, and Quirinus, with his
family were baptized. <term lang="la">Tunc
dictus Alexander Papa</term> (saith
Durand) <term lang="la">hoc festum in Calen&shy;
dis Augusti celebrandum insti&shy;
tuit, &amp; in honorem beati Pe&shy;
tri Ecclesiam in urbe fabricavit,
ubi vincula ipsa reposuit, &amp; ad
vincula nominavit, &amp; Calendis
Augusti dedicavit. In qua festi&shy;
vitate, populus illic ipsa vincula
hodi&egrave; osculatur</term> . So that this
day being before called onely
the Calends of August, was up&shy;
on this occasion afterwards
tearmed indifferently, either
of the instrument that
wrought this miracle, St.
Peters day ad vincula, or of
that part of the Maiden,
whereon the miracle was
wrought, the Gule of August .
Cow. See <xref>Lammas day</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gulosity(n)">Gulosity (<etym lang="la">gulositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">glut&shy;
tony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gulp(n)">Gulph (<etym lang="la">finus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a part of
the Sea, insinuating &amp; embo&shy;
soming it self within the land,
or between two several lands;
As the Gulph of Venice, the
Persian Gulph, the Red Sea,
Sinus Mexicanus, Vermili&shy; 
us, Gangeticus. Compl. Gent</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gultwite(n)">Gultwit,</form> <xpln lang="en">seems to be com&shy;
pounded of<etym lang="br">Gult</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">noxa</term>, and
<etym lang="br">Wit</etym>, a termination of words
in the Saxon tongue, signi&shy;
fying nothing in it self, but
asdome orhood, Christendome,
childhood, manhood, &amp;c. Others
say, and it is true, that<term lang="br">Wit</term>
signifies blame or reprehension .
<term lang="br">Gultwit</term> (as Saxon in his de&shy;
scription of England, ca. II.
interprets it) is an amends for
trespass. Cow.</xpln>

duct through a strange terri&shy;
tory, Cassan&aelig;us de cousuetud.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gyges' ring(n)">Gyges Ring</form> <xpln lang="en">( Gyges was King
of Lydia) and his Ring said to
have this property, that being
on the finger and turned to
the inside of the hand, the
wearer went invisible; but
turning it to the outside, then 


</page>

<page sig="s8r">
he was visible again, as before
Plat. in lib. de Repub. will tell
you how Gyges came by this
Ring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gymnosophists(pn)">Gymnosophists (<etym lang="la">gymnoso&shy;
phist&aelig;</etym>) from <etym lang="la">gymnos</etym>, naked,
and <etym lang="la">sophist&aelig;</etym>, wise)</form> <xpln lang="en">certain
Philosophers in India that
went alwaies naked, and li&shy;
ved solitary in woods and de&shy;
sarts, feeding on hearbs, the
first beginner of which Sect
was (as St. Hierome reports,
Cont. Jovinian.) called Bud&shy;
das. These Gymnosophists were
to the Indians, as the Druides 
to the Brittans, and are called
by the Indians, Brachmans . See
<xref lexeme="brackmans">Brachmans</xref>. 

Strabo writes, that there
were two kinds of Gymnoso&shy;
phists, one dwelling in De&shy;
sarts, &amp;c. termed Hermanes ;
The other sort frequented
Kings <emend err="Cours"> Courts</emend>, Cities, &amp;c. and
were called Brachmans.</xpln></wordentry>

cratie,</form> <xpln lang="en">feminine Rule or Au&shy;
thority, the Government of a
woman.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="habeas corpus(n)"><f type="l"/>HAbeas Corpus,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
Writ, which a man, in&shy;
dicted of some trespass before
Justices of Peace, or in a
Court of any Franchize, and
upon his apprehension being
laid in prison for the same,
may have out of the Upper
Bench, thereby to remove
himself thither at his own
costs, and to answer the
Cause there, &amp;c. Fitz. nat. br.
fo.250. h. See more of this,
and of Habeas Corpora, in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="habit(n)">Habit (<etym lang="la">habitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the out&shy;
ward attire of the body,
whereby one person is di&shy;
stinguished from another;
as the Habit of a Gentle&shy;
man is different from that
of a Merchant, and the<emend err="ha"> ha&shy;</emend>
bit of a Handy-crafts man
from both. Sometime it<emend err="sig"> sig&shy;</emend>
nifies a quality in the body or
mind, not natural, but got&shy;
ten by long custom or infu&shy;
sed by God : As an Orator
still exercised in making O&shy;
rations, hath gotten a ha&shy;
bit of eloquent speaking.
And the holy Apostles had
a habit to understand and
speak languages without stu&shy;
dy. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

that may be inhabited or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hail to you(n)" lexeme="hail to you, all(n)">Haile to you, orall Hail
to you,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Saxon word, <term lang="la">ab</term>
all <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">omnis</term>, andheile <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">sani&shy;
tas vel salus</term>, and so is as
much as, all health to you. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halcyon(n)">Halcyon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of small bird called by some
a Kingsfisher, which breeds
on the Sea shoar about the
winter solstice, which time
being about fourteen daies,
there is no tempest or storms.
Hence tis we call peaceable
or quiet times, Halcyon or
Halcyonian daies . Two no&shy;
table properties are observed
in the nest of this bird, which
she makes with the foam of
the Sea; The first is, That
the Architecture of it is so
strong, so durable, that it can&shy;
not be broken, nor cut, even
with the violent stroak of
iron. 

The second, That it is so
proportioned to the bird,
as if it were sewed to her
body, in such manner as
no creature can there&shy;
in be received, but the Ar&shy;
chitect himself. Caussinus. See 


</page>

<page sig="t1r">
more in Vul. Err. p 128, and
129.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halieutics(n)">Halieuticks (<etym lang="la">halieutica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
books, treating of fishes or
fishing, whereof Oppianus
wrote five.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haliography(n)">Haliographie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
scription of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hallage(n)">Hallage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Toll that
is due to the Lord of a Fair
or Marker, for such com&shy;
modities as are vended in the
Common-Hall of the place.
Cotgr. 

A Fee due for cloathes
brought for sale to Blackwel&shy;
Hall in London. Coke. vol9 fol.
62. b.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halleluiah(ex)">Halleilliah.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Allelu&shy;
iah</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hallucination(n)">Hallucination (<etym lang="la">hallucinatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a being mistaken, or deciev&shy;
ed in judgement, an error
of opinion, a blindness of
mind. If vision (saith Dr.
Brown) be abolished, it is
called C&aelig;citas or blindness;
if depraved, and receive its
objects erroneously, Hallucina&shy;
tion, &amp;c. p.153.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hallmote(n)">Halymote <term lang="la">alias</term> Healge&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halo(n)">Halos orHalo ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

specially about the Moon.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halt(v)">Halt,</form> <xpln lang="en">or to make an halt, is
a term of War, and <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">comes
from the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> faire halte</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> to
stop, stay, or make a stand
or pause.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hamadryad(n)">Hamadryads (<etym lang="la">hamadryades</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Nymphs of the woods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hame(n)">Hames</form> <xpln lang="en">of a Horse-Col&shy;
lar, are two crooked peeces
of wood, made of purpose
to compass the Horse-Collar
to keep it close to the neck;
and may well come of the
Dutch <term lang="du">Hamme</term>, or <term lang="du">Hame</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">poples</term>, the Hamme of the
Leg; because those Hames
are crooked, and bow just
like the Hams of the Legs.
Min. or rather from the Latin
 <term lang="la">hamus</term> a hook.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hamble(n)">Hambles,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the plural of
the French (<etym lang="fr">hable</etym>) signify&shy;
ing as much as a Port or Ha&shy;
ven of the Sea. This word
is used, Anno 27. H.6.
cap.3.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hamkin(n)">Hamkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">A pudding made
upon the bones of a shoul&shy;
der of Mutton, all the
flesh being first taken off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hanse(pn)">Hanse ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Com&shy;
pany, Society, or Cor&shy;
poration of Merchants
(for so it signifies in the
Book of the Ordonnances of
Paris) combined together
for the good usage, and
safe passage of Merchan&shy;
dize from Kingdome to 


</page>

<page sig="t1v">
Kingdom. This society was,
and in part yet is indued with
many large Priviledges of
Princes, respectively within
their Territories. It had
four Principal seats or<emend err="Sta"> Sta&shy;</emend>
ples; where the Almain or
Dutch Merchants, being the
erectors of it, had an espe&shy;
cial house, one of which was
here in London, called <term lang="la">Gild&shy;
halda Teutonicorum</term>, or in our
common language the Steel&shy;
yard . But in Germany we
read of seventy two Hanse
Towns, as Lubeck, Ham&shy;
bourg, Magdenbourg, &amp;c. See
more of this in Ortelius in
the Index of his additament
to his Theater, <term lang="la">verbo Ancia&shy;
tici</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="handful(n)">Handful,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is four inches by
the Standard. An.33. H.8.
ca.5.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hansel(n)">Hansel (from the Brit&shy;
tish<etym lang="br">Honsel</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that bestows
the first money with a
Trades-man, in the morning
of a Fair or Market, it said
to give him handsel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hans-en-kelder(n)">Hans-en-kelder,</form> <xpln lang="en">is in
Dutch as much as Jack in
the Cellar ; And by meta&shy;
phor it is taken for the
childe in a womans bel&shy;
ly.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "Hans" b..
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hansiatic(a)">Hansiatick,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to,
or free of the Hanse Towns, or
Hanse Merchants. Lustra.
Lud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hap-harlot(n)">Haphartlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a course Co&shy;
verlet for a bed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hake(n)">Haque,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Hand-gun of
about three quarters of a yard 
long, An.33. H.8. ca.6. and
A.2. and 3. E 6. ca.14. there
is also the half Haque or Demi&shy;
Haque.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hackbut(n)">Haquebut ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the same
with Harquebuse, a Calee&shy;
ver . An.2, &amp; 3. E.6. ca.
14. &amp; An.4, &amp; 5. Ph. &amp; Ma&shy;
ca.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harange(n)">Harange (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Harangue</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Oration, Declaration, or set
Speech. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurricane(n)">Haracana
or 
Hero-cane (perhaps from 
the Spa. <etym lang="sp">Aran&shy;
car</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to weed
up or pull up by the roots, an
impetuous kind of tempest
or Whirlewind, happening
in the Indies, and those far
Countries, it comes with
such violence that it over&shy;
turns trees by the roots,
blows down houses, &amp;c. and
continues sometimes thirty
dayes; Marriners and Sea&shy;
men stand in great fear of
it at Sea; for it infallibly
wrecks their ships. Mr.
How: sayes, The Devil ap&shy;
pears often to the Pagans
in these Harancanes. Mr.
Herb. saies it happens in
some Countries but once in
nine years.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hariant(a)">Hariant,</form> <xpln lang="en">A term in Herauldry, when a fish
is painted standing up&shy;
right.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harass(v)">Harasse (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Harasser</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to tire or toyl out, to spend
or weaken, weary, or wear
out; also to vex, disquiet,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="t2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hariolation(n)">Hariolation (<etym lang="la">hariolatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fore-telling or South-say&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harmonical(a)">Harmonical (<etym lang="la">harmonicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
melodious, harmonious, musi&shy;
cal, proportionate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herald(n)">Harold 
Heralt 
or 
Herald (Ital. <etym lang="it">Heral&shy;
do</etym>, Fr. <etym lang="fr">He&shy; 
rault</etym>, <term lang="la">vel qua&shy;
si herus altus</term>, a high Matter)</form> <xpln lang="en">
with us it signifies an Of&shy;
ficer at Arms, whose functi&shy;
on is to denounce War,
to proclaim Peace, or to
be employed by the King
in Martial Messages or other
businesses. Their Office
with us is described by Po&shy;
lydore lib.19. thus, <term lang="la"> Habent
insuper apparitores ministros,
quos Heraldos dicunt; quorum
pr&aelig;fectus Armorum Rex vorita&shy;
tur. Hi belli &amp; pacis nuncii,
Ducibus, Comitibusque &agrave; Re&shy;
ge factis, insignia aptant, ac eo&shy;
rum funera curant</term> . They be
the Judges and Examiners
of Gentlemens armes, mar&shy;
shal all the solemnities at the
Coronations of Princes, ma&shy;
nage Combats, and such
like. There is also one and the
same use of them with us, and
with the French Nation. See
Lupanus cap. Heraldi. With us
the three chief, are called
Kings at Arms ; and of them
Garter is the principal, insti&shy;
tuted and created by Henry
the fifth. Stowes Annals, p
584. whose Office is to at&shy;
tend the Knights of the Gar&shy;
ter at their solemnities, and
to marshal the Funerals of 
all the Nobility. And in Plow.
cas. Reneger and Fogossa, is
found that Edw.4. granted the
Office of the King of Heralds
to one Garter, <term lang="la">cum feudis &amp;
proficuis ab antiq. &amp;c.</term> fo.12. b.
The next is Clarentius, or&shy;
dained by Ed.4. for he attain&shy;
ing the Dukedom of Clarence 
by the death of George his bro&shy;
ther, whom he put to death
for aspiring the Crown, made
the Herald, which properly
belonged to the Duke of Cla&shy;
rence, a King at Arms, and
called him Clarentius; His
Office is to marshal and dis&shy;
pose the Funerals of Knights,
Esquiers, &amp;c. through the
Realm on the South side of
Trent. The third is Norroy or
Northroy ; whose Office is the
same on the North side of
Trent, as that of Clarentius on
the South, as may well ap&shy;
pear by his name, signifying
the Northern King, or King of
the North parts. Besides these
there be six others, properly
called Heralds, according to
their original, as they were
created to attend Dukes, &amp;c.
in Marshal Executions; (viz.)
York, Lancaster, Somerset, Rich&shy;
mond, Chester, Windsor. Lastly,
There be four others called
Marshals or Pursuivants at
Arms reckoned after a sort in
the number of Heralds, and
commonly succeed in the
place of the Heralds, as they
die, or are preferred, and those
are Blew-mantle, Rouge-cross,
Rougedragon, &amp;  Percullis . Min. 


</page>

<page sig="t2v">
Fern in his Glory of <emend err="Genero">Genero&shy;</emend>
sity(p.151.) says Herald is com&shy;
posed of these two Dutch
words <term lang="du">Heer</term> and <term lang="du">auld</term>, which
is as much as to say, an old
Lord, or an ancient Sir. 

But Verstegan says that He&shy;
ralt comes from the ancient
TeutonickHere-healt, and
signifies the Champion of the
Army, or a most couragious
person. p. 251. Mr. Stow in
his Annals, p.12. derives it
from Hero.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harlot(n)">Harlot,</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="Metonymical">Metonymical&shy;</emend>
ly from Arletta or Harlo&shy;
tha, Concubine to Robert
Duke of Normandy, on whom
the Duke begat William the 
Bastard Conqueror, and King
of England; In spight to
whom, and disgrace to his
Mother, the English called
all Whores, Harlots, a word
yet in use among us.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harpies(n)">Harpyes (<etym lang="la">harpy&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mon&shy;
strous and ravenous birds,
which Poets faign to have
had womens faces, hands
armed with Talons, and Bel&shy;
lies full of ordure, where&shy;
with they infected all meat
they touched; They lived
in Stymphalis a lake of Ar&shy;
cadia, and were named Aello,
Ocypete, Celeno, and Thyella.
Thus the Poet. 

 <term lang="la">Tristius haud illis monstrum nec s&aelig;vior ulla
Pestis &amp; ira Deum, Stygiis sese extulit undis: 
Virginei volucrum vultus, f&oelig;dissima ventris
Ingluvies, unc&oelig;<expan type="">que</expan> manus, &amp; pallida semper
Ora fame</term> . --- Virg.3. &AElig;n. 

Hence tis we usually ap&shy;
ply the name of Harpyes to
avaricious, griping and usu&shy;
rious men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harpocrates(pn)">Harpocrates,</form> <xpln lang="en">the God of
silence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hart(n)">Hart</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Stag of five years
old compleat. Manwood part.
secunda of his Forrest Laws,
ca.4. num.5. which he hath
out of Budeus de Philologia
lib.2. And if the King or
Queen hunt him, and he
escape alive, then after&shy;
ward he is called a Hart
Royal . And if the beast by
the King or Queens hunt&shy;
ing be chased out of the 
Forest, and so escape;
Proclamation is commonly
made in the places therea&shy;
bout, That in regard of the
pastime the beast hath shew&shy;
ed the King or Queen, none
shall hurt him or hinder
him from returning to the
Forest, and then he is a
Hart Royal proclaimed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatch(n)" lexeme="scuttle(n)">Hatches orScutles</form> <xpln lang="en">of a
Ship, are the Overtures or
Trap-doors, whereat things
are let down into the hold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haubergeon(n)">Haubergeon (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class><emend err=")"></emend> the
diminutive of Haubert <expan type="">id est</expan> a
coat of Mail)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little coat of
Mail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hausible(a)">Hausible (<etym lang="la">hausibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be drawn or empti&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haw(n)">Haw (<etym lang="la">unguis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in
the eyes, so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hawker(n)">Hawkers,</form> <xpln lang="en">Are certain de&shy;
ceitful fellows, that go from
place to place buying and
selling Brass, Pewter, and
other Merchandize, that
ought to be uttered in o&shy;
pen Market. The Appel&shy;
lation seems to grow from
their uncertain wandring,
like those that with Hawks
seek their Game where
they can finde it. You
have the word, An 25. H.8.
ca.6. and Anno 33. ejusdem,
ca.4. 

Those people which go
up and down the streets
crying News-books, and sel&shy;
ling them by retail, are also
<emend err="ca ed">called</emend> Hawkers; And those
women that sell them by
whole-sale from the Press,
are called Mercury Wo&shy;
men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haybote(n)">Hayboot, seems to be com&shy;
pounded of<etym lang="fr">Hay</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <emend err="">(</emend><term lang="la">sepes</term>)
and<etym lang="sx">bote</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <emend err=""> (</emend><term lang="la">compensatio</term>) <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">the
former is French</class>, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">the second
Saxon</class>.</form> <xpln lang="en">It is used in our
Common Law for a permis&shy;
sion to take thorns and
frith, to make or repair hed&shy;
ges. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hayward(n)">Hayward <term lang="la">alias</term> Haward, 
seems to be compounded of
two French words, <etym lang="fr">hayt</etym>, i
 <term lang="la">sepes</term>, a hedge, and (<etym lang="fr">Garde</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">custodia</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies with us, 
one that keeps the common
Herd of the Town; And the
reason may be, because one
part of his Office, is to look
that they neither break nor
crop the hedges of inclosed
grounds. It may likewise
come from the German word
(<term lang="gr">Herd</term> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">armentum</term>) and
<term lang="gr">Bewarren</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="fr">cust dire</term>;) he
is a sworn Officer in the
Lords Court, and the form
of his oath you may see in
Kitchin, fol.46.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="headborough(n)">Headborow is compoun&shy;
ded of two words (<etym lang="sx">Heofed</etym> i.
<term lang="la">caput</term>) and <etym lang="sx">Borhe</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">pig&shy;
nus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies him that is
chief of the Frank pledge.
And him that had the prin&shy;
cipal Government of them
within his own pledge.
And as he was calledHead&shy;
borow, so was he also called,
Burowhead, Thirdborow,
Burshoulder, Tithingman,
Chief pledge or Burrow&shy;
Elder, according to the
diversity of speech in divers
places. Of this see Mr. Lam&shy;
bert in his explication of
Saxon words, Verbo Cen&shy;
turia, and in his Treatise
of Constables, and Smith
de Repub. Angl. l.2. ca.
22. It now signifies Con&shy;
stable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hebdomade(n)">Hebdomade (<etym lang="la">hebdoma&shy;
da</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the number of se&shy;
ven. A week, or seven years,
seven months or ages, Vul.
Err.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hebrews(pn)">Hebrews,</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies the peo&shy;
ple which came of Heber, the
fourth from Shem, in whose
Family the ancient language
of the world called Hebrew
from his name, continued;
And about the birth of his
Son happened that division
in the rest of the Languages of
the world, whereof he was
called Peleg or Phaleg, <expan type="">id est</expan> di&shy;
vision, See Gen. ii.18. Wil&shy;
sons Dict.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hecatomb(n)">Hecatomb (<etym lang="la">hecatombe</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Sacrifice wherein were killed
an hundred beasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heck(n)">Heck,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is the name of an
Engin to take fish in the Ri&shy;
ver Owse by York. A.23. H.8.
ca.18.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hectic(n)">Hectick (<etym lang="la">hectice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fea&shy;
ver inflaming the heart, and
soundest part of the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hederal(a)">Hederal (<etym lang="la">hederalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

deral Crown or Garland was
given to Poets, and excellent

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hegira(n)">Hegira,</form> <xpln lang="en">or year of deli&shy;
verance, the Epoch of the
Turks, their account of time,
which some call the Hagaren 
accompt. 

It fell out 16 July, An.622.
of the incarnation; from
whence they reckon their
years.<xref lexeme="epoch"> See Epoche</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Helchesaites(pn)">Helchesaites</form> <xpln lang="en">(so named of
a false Prophet called Helche&shy;
saus) divulged their heresie 
in the time of Pope Fabian
the first: these men did alto&shy;
gether reprove the Apostle
St. Paul, renewing the er&shy;
rors of Cerinthus, Ebion and
the Nazarians, saying it was
no sin to deny Jesus Christ in
the time of persecution, &amp;c.
Euseb. in histor. Eccles. l.6.
ca.28. Nicephorus in lib.5. ca.
24.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helcysm(n)">Helcysm (<etym lang="la">helcysma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
froth and filth of silver; the
dross and scum of that metal.
Pliny.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heliacal(a)">Heliacal (<etym lang="la">heliacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;
ing to the Sun. The
Heliacal emersion of a star
we term that, when a Star,
which before, for the vicini&shy;
ty of the Sun, was not visi&shy;
ble, being further remo&shy;
ved, begins to appear. Vul.
Err.224.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helical(a)">Helical (<etym lang="la">helicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to the sign, which is
called Ursa Major, or Charls
Wain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Helicon(pn)">Helicon</form> <xpln lang="en">a hill of Phocis

Muses. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hellebore(n)">Hellebore (<etym lang="la">helleborum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
hearb whereof there be two
kinds, the one called Bears&shy;
foot, the other called Nees&shy;
wort, medicinal for the Fren&shy;
sie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heliotrope(n)" lexeme="heliotropy(n)">Heliotrope 
Heliotropy (<etym lang="la">heliotropi&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
hearb Turnsole or Water&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="t4r">
wort, also a precious stone
mentioned in Pliny, and so
called from the Greek, be&shy;
cause being put into a vessel
of water, it will seem to turn
the rayes of the Sun into the
colour of blood. Rid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heliotropian(a)">Heliotropian,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to that hearb or stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helispherical(a)">Helispherical ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">round
as the Sun</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helioscopy(n)">Helioscopy, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Greek</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x1f25;&lambda;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">Sol</term>, and <etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&kappa;&#x03cc;&pi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">mesa</term>,</form> <xpln lang="en">and so may stand for the
furthest point of the Suns
course, in his ascension or
descension; also a kind of
Spurge tree or Plant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hellenism(n)">Hellenism.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Gre&shy;
cism</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hellenize(v)">Hellenize (from <etym lang="la">hellenes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
play the Grecian.</xpln></wordentry>

Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hellespont(pn)">Hellespont (<etym lang="la">Hellespontus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the narrow Sea by Constan&shy;
tinople, dividing Europe from
Asia, betwixt Propontis and
the &AElig;gean Sea. it is now
called Brachium Sancti Ge&shy;
orgii.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heluation(n)">Heluation (<etym lang="la">heluatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
vouring gluttony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helm(n)">Helme</form> <xpln lang="en">of the Rudder of
a ship, is a handle of wood,
put on the Rudder for a man
to govern the same, and
direct the ship; which may
be so called of Helm or Hel&shy;
met ; For as a Helmet saves
the head, so does that by
mans directing it, keep the
ship under sail from running 
on Rocks, and other like dan&shy;
gers; or rather as a Helmet is
the top peece for the head
of the Armor, so is the Helm
the top of the Stern or Rud&shy;
der. And in French <etym lang="fr"> Heaume</etym>
one word signifies both.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Helvetian(a)">Helvetian,</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertain&shy;
to Switzerland; other&shy;
wise called Helvetia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hemerobaptist(pn)">Hemerobaptist (<etym lang="la">hemero&shy;
baptista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that would
be baptized every day. Dip&shy;
pers dipt.</xpln></wordentry>

day, a Day-book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="henchman(n)">Henchman orHeinsman,</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a German word, signi&shy;
fying a Domestick or one
of a family; It is used with
us for one that runs on
foot, attending on a per&shy;
son of honor. An.3. Edw.4.
ca.5. An.24. H.8. ca.13 from
hence comes our word hine 
or hinde, a servant for husban&shy;
dry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heptarchy(n)">Heptarchy (<etym lang="la">heptarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kind of Government,
where seven rule; As in Eng&shy;
land when there were seven
Kings (viz.) First, The King
of Kent. 2. Of the South&shy;
Saxons . 3. Of the West
Saxons . 4. Of the East Sax&shy;
ons . 5. Of Northumberland.
6. Of Mercia. 7. Of the
East Angles . Of which you
may read more in Sir Rich&shy;
ard Bakers Chronicle, fol.
6, and 7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herbage(n)">Herbage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
in our Common Law the
fruit of the earth provided
by nature, for the bit or
mouth of the Cattle. But
it is most commonly used
for that liberty, a man hath
to feed his Cattle in ano&shy;
ther mans ground, as in the
Forest, &amp;c. Cromptons Jurisd.
fol.197.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hercules' Pillars(pn)">Hercules Pillars,</form> <xpln lang="en">On
the North side of the
Straight called of old
Fretum Herculeum, was
Mount Calpe, on the South,
Mount Abila, on which 


</page>

<page sig="t5r">
Hercules placed his so memo&shy;
rized pillars, with inscri&shy;
ption <term lang="la">Nil Ultra</term>, because that
was then conceived to be the
most Western bound of the
world. But Charles the fifth,
after the discovery of America,
coming that way, caused <term lang="la">Plus
Ultra</term> to be engraven, either
on the old Pillars, or else on
new erected in their places.
Heil. 

Hercules, is said to have
faln into the Falling-sickness,
by over much eating Quails,
which disease has ever since
been termed Hercules sickness .
Dr. Muffet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herculean(a)">Herculean 
Herculane (<etym lang="la">Herculeus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging
to Hercules, pertaining to a va&shy;
liant fellow, difficile, hard, in&shy;
vincible; So</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herculean labor(n)">Herculean labor,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pro&shy;
verb, signifying a work of
great difficulty, or almost im&shy;
possible to be atchieved,
which took beginning from
the twelve labors of Hercules,
of which see Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="here de Caesar(n)">Here de C&aelig;sar,</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> the Mo&shy;
narchy of C&aelig;sar. An ancient
account of time, used instead
of the yeer of our Lord, in
Spain especially, as also among
the Arabs and Sarrazines . It
took date 38 yeers before
Christs Nativity, and was used
in Spain till the yeer 1383.
which was of Here de C&aelig;sar.
1421.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

tical</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heresy(n)">Heresie (<etym lang="gk">&alpha;&#x1f35;&rho;&epsilon;&#x03c3;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym> <etym lang="la">h&aelig;resis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an opinion contrary to some
point of faith, whereof Eu&shy;
sebius, Platina, St. Austin, and
other learned Authors make
mention of very many since
our Saviours time, As, Sy&shy;
monians, Menandrians, Ebio&shy;
nites, Cerinthians, Nicholaitans,
Saturnians, Carpocratians, Gno&shy;
sticks, Valentinians, Marcionites 
Cleobians, Dorothians, Gorthe&shy;
nians, Masuberthians, Encra&shy;
tites, Basilides, Cataphrigians,
Arabes, Helchesaites, Novatians,
Catharians, Sabellians, Mani&shy; 
cheans, Arrians, Pelagians, He&shy;
lonitians, Hermogenians, Pepu&shy;
tians, Quintillians, Colliridians,
Priscillianists, Hemerobaptists,
Anthropomorphits, Chilliasts or
Millenarians, Masselians, Dimo&shy; 
crites, Garasians, Paterons, Poor
men of Lyons, Arnoldists, Spe&shy; 
ronists, Fraticelli, Adamites, O&shy;
rebites, Taborites, Noetians, Hy&shy;
droparastates, Artotyrites, Ptho&shy;
lemaites, Stacioicques, Phibio&shy;
nites, Helionites, Heracleonites,
Antitades, Perades, Phri&shy;
gians, Colarbasians, Docites,
Borborians, Zacheans, Naasa&shy;
nians, Phemionitains, Sethrani&shy;
ans, Phemionitains, Sethrani&shy;
ans Caynians, Codians, Ophites 
Severians, Paulianists, Cata&shy;
baptists, Arbigeois, Archontiques 
Hierarchites, Sileutians, Felici&shy;
ans, Nestorians, Jacobitans, Mo&shy;
nothelitanes . The Acephalick
Sects of Barcotabas, Cerdon,
Tatian, Redon, Apelles, Basili&shy;
cus, Sirenus, Montanus, Theo&shy;
dorus, Paulus Samosatenus, Og&shy; 
&agrave;oades, Artemon, Natalis, Gali&shy;
en, Berillus, Nepos, Liberius, 


</page>

<page sig="t5v">
Macedonius, Helvidius, Ethici&shy;
anus, Hermogenes, Epiphanes,
Pontinus, Sinerus, Prepon, Pi&shy;
thon, Cleobulus, Praxeas, Ascle&shy;
piodotus, Themison, Theodotus, Flori&shy;
nus, Blattus, Isidorus, Secundus,
Portitus, Bardesianus, Symma&shy;
chus, Theodocion, Lucius, Apoli&shy;
narius, Acatus, Donatus, Olym&shy;
pius, Adimantius, Alogios, <emend err="Ber">Ber&shy;</emend>
toldus, Paliardus the Philoso&shy;
pher, Almerick, Guillaume of
holy love, Hermand, Durcine;
Quintinists, Severists, Campanists 
&amp;c. with infinite more. See
Prateolus In this latter age
those that have most abound&shy;
ed, are, Anabaptists, Antinomi&shy;
ans, Brownists, Socinians, Armi&shy;
nians, Erastians, Quakers, Ada&shy;
mites, Anti-Trinitarians, Anti&shy;
Scripturians, &amp;c. with many
others, of which see Mr. Ross
his View of all Religions. 

Heresie (as the Fathers de&shy;
fine it) is a misbelief in some
points, of faith, contrary to
the Doctrine universally re&shy;
ceived in the Church. Cressy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heresiarh(n)">Heresiark (<etym lang="la">h&aelig;resiarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Arch-Heretick, a principal
Heretick, a Sect-Master.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heretic(n)">Heretick (<etym lang="la">h&aelig;reticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a per&shy;
son wilfully and stiffly main&shy;
taining false opinions against
the Scriptures and Doctrine of
the Church after due admo&shy;
nition. Titus 3.10 Wilsons
Dict.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heretoga(n)">Heretoga ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was our
ancient appellation for the
chief Conductor of an Army,
for which we have long since 
used our borrowed French
word Duke, from the Latine
 <term lang="la">Dux</term>. Here in the Ancient
Teutonick, is an Army, and
toga signifies to draw or
train forward. The Nether&shy;
landers for Duke do yet use
the nameHertogh, and the
Germans write itHertrog
Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herility(n)">Herility (<etym lang="la">herilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">master&shy;
ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heriot(n)">Heriot <term lang="la">alias</term>Hariot (<etym lang="la">herio&shy;
tum</etym><emend err=")"></emend> in the SaxonHeregeat
fromhere, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">exercitus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it sig&shy;
nified in our Saxon time a tri&shy;
bute given to the Lord, for
his better preparation toward
war. Lamb. The name is
still retained, but the use al&shy;
tered; for whereas by Mr.
Lamberts opinion, it signify'd
as much as Relief doth now
with us, it is taken now for
the best Chattel, that the Te&shy;
nant hath at the hour of his
death, due to the Lord by
custome, be it Horse, Oxe, or
any such like. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heroical(a)">Heroical (<etym lang="la">heroicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">noble, 


</page>

<page sig="t6r">
stately, excellent, the three
Heroical vertues are 1 Mo&shy;
deration of anger. 2 Tem&shy;
perance in Covetousness.
3. The despising of Plea&shy;
sures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heroic poem(n)">Heroick Poem,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called,
for that it treats of the man&shy;
ners of Heroes or heroick
persons, not natural Causes;
manners presented not dicta&shy;
ted, and manners fained (as
the name of Poesie imports)
not found in men. 

The part of an heroick
Poem is to exhibite a venera&shy;
ble and amiable Image of he&shy;
roick vertue, Mr. Hobbs. <xref lexeme="poesy"> See
Poesie</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hesperides(pn)">Hesperides,</form> <xpln lang="en">the daughters
of Hesperus, brother to Atlas,
called &AElig;gle, Arethusa, and <emend err="He"> He&shy;</emend>
sperethusa: They had Gardens
and Orchards, that bore gol&shy;
den fruit, kept by a vigilant
Dragon, which Hercules slew,
and robbed the Orchard.
From this story, we find of&shy;
ten mention of the Gardens
and Apples of Hesperides.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heteroclite(n)">Heteroclite (<etym lang="la">heterocliton</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is declined otherwise 
then common Nounes be.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Heteroscians(pn)">Heteroscians (<etym lang="la">heteroscii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
those people that dwell under
either of the temperate Zones:
so called, because their sha&shy;
dows at noon bend still but
one way, either North or
South.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hexagonal(a)">Hexagonal (<etym lang="la">hexagonus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath six corners or An&shy;
gles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hexameter(n)">Hexameter ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Verse
consisting of six feet in num&shy;
ber, all either Dactyls or Spon&shy;
dees, save that a Dactyl is
proper to the fifth place, and
a Spondee to the last: other
places are capable of either
foot. 

 <term lang="la">Otia damnantur qu&aelig; nulla negotia tractant</term> . 

These are also called He&shy;
roiques, and were used to re&shy;
present the memorable acti&shy;
ons of those the Ancients cal&shy;
led Demi-Gods. This Hex&shy;
ameter the Latines found most
grave and decent for their E&shy;
pique Poems; instead of
which we use the line of ten 
syllables, recompencing the
neglect of their quantity
with the diligence of Ryme.
Hobbs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hexastic(n)">Hexastick (<etym lang="la">hexasticum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
six Verses together, or a Sen&shy;
tence contained in six Verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hiation(n)">Hiation (<etym lang="la">hiatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a ga&shy;
ping.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatchel(n)">AHichel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
