<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hidage(n)">Hidage orHydage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an
extraordinary tax to be paid
for every Hide of Land.
See more of it in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hide(n)">Hide orHyde of Land,
 (<etym lang="la">hida terr&aelig;</etym>) Saxonic&eacute; Hide&shy;
landes</form> <xpln lang="en">, is a certain measure or
quantity of Land, by some
mens opinion, that may be
plowed with one Plow in a
yeer, Termes of Law. By
other men it is an hundred
Acres. By Beda (who
calls it <term lang="la">familiam</term>) it is as
much as will maintain a fa&shy;
mily. Crompton in his Juris&shy;
diction, fol.210. saith, it con&shy;
sists of an hundred Acres,
every Acre in length forty,
and in breadth four perches;
every perch sixteen foot and a
half. And again fol.212.
A Hide of Land contains a
hundred Acres, and eight
Hides, or eight hundred A&shy;
cres contain a Knights Fee.
Of this read more in Ma&shy;
ster Lamberts explication
of Saxon words. In Hida ter&shy;
ra.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hydromel(n)">Hidromel.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Hydro&shy;
mel</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hierarchy(n)">Hierarchy (<etym lang="la">hierarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an holy governance or prin&shy;
<emend err="cipalit">cipality</emend>. The Hierarchy or
Holy Order of Angels con&shy;
tains (as some affirm) nine
degrees, and is a mystical 
resemblance of the Blessed
Trinity, there being in nine,
thrice three, and in every
three, thrice one. So that
there are three superiour,
three inferiour, and three
middle degrees. The su&shy;
perior are Seraphins, Cheru&shy;
bins, and Thrones; the
middle, Dominations, Prin&shy;
cipalities, Powers ; the in&shy;
ferior, Vertues, Archangels, An&shy;
gels . Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hierarchical(a)">Hierarchical (<etym lang="la">hierarchicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to a holy Gover&shy;
nour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hieratical(a)">Hieratical (<etym lang="la">hieraticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sacred, holy, destined to
things sacred. As Hiera&shy;
tick Paper, fine Paper, De&shy;
dicated onely to Religious
Books.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hieroglyphics(n)">Hieroglyphicks (<etym lang="la">hiero&shy;
glyphica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mystical Letters or
Cyphers among the &AElig;gyp&shy;
tians by Images, signifying
holy Sentences, which were
to them instead of writing.
For Example; For a Mo&shy;
neth they painted a Palm-tree,
because at every New Moon
it sends forth a new branch.
For God, they painted a
Faulcon, as well for that he
soars so high, as that he go&shy;
verns the lesser birds. They
described Envy by the Eele,
because it never keeps com&shy;
pany with other Fishes.
The liberal man was figured
by a Right hand wide open:
As contrariwise, the avarici&shy;
ous niggard, by a left hand
close grip'd, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="t7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hierogram(n)">Hierograms (from the
 <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sacred Letters or wri&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hierography(n)">Hierographie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
description or pourtrayting of
divine things. <term lang="la">Rerum di&shy; 
vinarum edumbratio per qu&aelig;dam
signa</term> . Scap.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hierome(pn)">Hierome ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">holy
name. St. Hierome a Reve&shy;
rend Father of the Church,
much honoured for transla&shy;
ting the Bible, lived in the
yeer of Christ, 384.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hieronimians(pn)">Hieronimians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Religi&shy;
ous Order, that had their be&shy;
ginning of St. Hierome, who
leaving his Native Coun&shy;
try, went into Jury, and
there not far from Bethelem
lived in a Monastery very
devoutly, the later end of his
life, and dyed in the 91 yeer
of his age, and of Christ 421.
The Monks of this Order
wear their cloaths of a
brown colour, and a Cope
plaited over their Coat, girt
with a leather Girdle.
There were also certain
Hermites called Hieronimians
of the foundation of one
Charles Granel of Florence,
who (about the yeer of
Christ, 1365) became an
Hermite in the Mountains of
Fessulus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hierosolymitan(a)">Hierosolymitan (from
<etym lang="la">Hierosolyma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertain&shy;
ing to Jerusalem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hobbler(n)">Hoblers (<etym lang="la">hobellarii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">In
Ireland there were certain
Knights so called, because they
were wont to serve in the
wars upon Hobbies ; also with
us certain persons who were
by their tenure tyed to main&shy;
tain a little light Nag, (which
in Ireland they call a Hobby, 
and hence we say a Hobby&shy;
horse) for the certifying of a&shy;
ny invasion made by the ene&shy;
mies, or such like peril to&shy;
wards the Sea-side, as Ports&shy;
mouth, &amp;c. Of these you shall
read A.18. Ed.3. Stat.2. cap.
7. &amp; An.25. ejusdem Stat.5.
cap.8. Antiq. Hibern. p.35.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hocktide(pn)">Hocktyde orHockstyde,</form> <xpln lang="en">
of old thus. Hardiknute the
last King of the Danes in this
Nation dying suddainly at
Lambeth in the yeer 1042, his
death was so welcom to his
subjects, that the time was
annually celebrated for some
hundreds of yeers after, with
open pastimes in the streets,
and called Hockstide, (in some
parts of this Nation not yet
out of memory, but observed
the week after Easter) signi&shy;
fying scorning or contempt,
which fell upon the Danes by
his death. Sir Rich. Baker.
See <xref>Fugalia</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hocus pocus(n)">Hocus-pocus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Jugler, one
that shews tricks by sleight of
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="t8r">
taining the fourth part of a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="holographical(a)">Holographical (<etym lang="la">holographi&shy; 
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wholly written with his

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homage(n)">Homage (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Hommage</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">
fides clientularis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">service, fide&shy;
lity. In Court Barons, the
Jury, sworn to enquire of mat&shy;
ters, is so called. It signi&shy;
fies also a servile Ceremony of
duty by some Tenants to
their Lords, after this manner.
The Tenant that holds lands
by Homage, kneeling on both
knees before the Lord (who
sits and holds the Tenants
hands between his) saith as
follows. 

I become your man from this
day forth for life, for member
and for worldly honor, and shall
owe you my faith, for the Land I
hold of you; saving the faith I
owe to our soveraign Lord the
King, and to my other Lords . 

And then the Lord, sitting,
must kiss the Tenant. An.17
Ed.2. Stat.2. Glanvile, lib.9.
cap. I. See more of this in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homageable(a)">Homageable,</form> <xpln lang="en">that is sub&shy;
ject to, or ought to do ho&shy;
mage.</xpln></wordentry>

likeness of speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homerical(a)">Homerical</form> <xpln lang="en">after the man&shy;
ner of Homer, Homer-like. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homicide(n)">Homicide (<etym lang="la">homicida</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mur&shy;
therer, a man-slayer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homicide(n)">Homicide (<etym lang="la">homicidium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
the slaying of a man: and is
divided into voluntary and ca&shy;
sual : homicide voluntary is that
which is deliberated and
committed of a set mind and
purpose to kill: and this is
either with precedent malice
or without; the former is
murther, and is the felonious
killing, through malice pre&shy;
pensed, of any person living in
this Realm under the Kings 
protection. West. part.2. Sym.
tit. Inditements, sect.37. &amp;c.
usque ad 51: where you may
see divers subdivisions of
this matter. See also Glan&shy;
ville lib.14. cap.3. Bract. lib.3.
tract.2. cap.4.15, and 17. Brit.
cap.5,6,7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homily(n)">Homily (<etym lang="la">homilia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a famili&shy;
ar speech of men together:
a Sermon.</xpln></wordentry>

ing to the most Noble Order

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoplochrism(n)">Hoplochrism (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x1f41;&pi;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <term lang="la">arma</term>, and <etym lang="gk">&chi;&rho;&iota;&#x03c3;&mu;&#x03c2;</etym>,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horcentric(a)">Horcentrick ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">out of
the Center; clean without
the Compass of; Mathemati&shy;
cians apply this word to the
Sun, when the Center there&shy;
of, being at the full height of
his Epicycle, is farthest from
the Center of the earth.
Cotgr..</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horizon(n)">Horizon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Circle
immoveable, dividing the
half-sphear of the Firmament
which we see, from the other
half we see not: it hath the
name of <etym lang="gk">&#x1f41;&rho;&#x03af;&zeta;&omega;</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">termino</term>, to
bound or limit, because it li&shy;
mits our sight. For exam&shy;
ple, imagine you stood upon
Highgate or the Tower-hill at
Greenwich, so far as you may
see round about, as in a Cir&shy;
cle, where the Heaven seems
to touch the earth, that is
called the Horizon; The Poles
whereof are, the point just
over your head, called Zenith 
in Arabick; and the other un&shy;
der your feet, passing by the
Center of the world, called
Nadir . The Sun rising and
going down is ever in this
Line or Circle. Peach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horngeld(n)">Horngeld, is compounded of
Horn andGildan orGelder,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">solvere</term>;</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies a Tax
within the Forest to be paid
for horned beasts. Cromptons
Jurisd. fol.197. And to be
free of it, is a priviledge
granted by the King to such
as he thinks good. <term lang="la">Idem, 


</page>

<page sig="u1r">
ibidem</term>; and Rastal in his Ex&shy;
position of words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horologe(n)">Horologe (<etym lang="la">horologium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
hour-glass, clock, dyal, or like
instrument, to tell what hour
of the day it is.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horological(a)">Horological (<etym lang="la">horologicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to a Clock
or Dyal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horologiography(n)">Horologiography,</form> <xpln lang="en">a writing
of, or describing Clocks or
Dyals, there is a late Book
entituled Azimuthal horologio&shy;
graphy, treating of that sub&shy;
ject.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horometry(n)">Horometry ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">measure
of hours, or a measuring of
hours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horoscope(n)">Horoscope (<etym lang="la">horoscopus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any
thing wherein hours are
marked, as a Dyal; or the
calculation of ones nativity,
wherein the hour of birth is
chiefly observed. See <xref>Ascen&shy;
dant</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horridity(n)">Horridity (<etym lang="la">horriditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">trem&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horripilation(n)">Horripilation (<etym lang="la">horripilatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the standing up of the hair
for fear, a growing rough with
hair; a sudden quaking,
shuddering or shivering.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horrisonant(a)">Horrisonant (<etym lang="la">horrisonus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orchyard(n)">Hort-yards (from <etym lang="la">Hortus</etym>, a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hosanna(ex)">Hosanna (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> <term lang="la">vel</term> Osanna,
save now, or O Lord save me;
Also sometimes taken for the
Willow branches which the
Jews carryed in their hands at
the Feasts of Tabernacles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hospital(n)">Hospital (<etym lang="la">hospitalium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
house erected of Charity, for
entertainment and relief of
poor, sick and impotent peo&shy;
ple. The Emperour Constan&shy;
tine the great first began the
building of Hospitals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hospiticide(n)">Hospiticide (<etym lang="la">hospiticida</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
he that kills his guest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hotchpot(n)">Hotchpot (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Hochepot</etym>.
Belg.Hutspot <expan type="">id est</expan> flesh cut
into prity pieces and sodden
with hearbs or roots, not un&shy;
like that which the Romans
called <etym lang="la">Farraginem</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Littleton,
saith that litterally it signifies
a Pudding mixed of divers
ingredients: but metaphori&shy;
cally a commixtion or puting
together of Lands, for the e&shy;
qual division of them, being
so put together. Examples
you have divers in him. fol.55.
And see Britton. fol.119.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dihoti(n)" lexeme="dioti(n)">Hoti andDioti ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">two
terms used in Logick, the
one is the <term lang="la">quid</term>, and the o&shy;
ther the <term lang="la">propter quid</term>: the one
the thing it self, and the o&shy;
ther the cause or reason of it.
Arist.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Predates first OED phrase (1734).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="u1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="housebote(n)">Housebote, <emend err="">(</emend> is compounded
ofhouse andbote, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">compen&shy;
satio</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies Estovers 
out of the Lords wood to
repair and uphold a Tenement
or house. Or Housebote is ne&shy;
cessary Timber, that the <emend err="Les">Les&shy;</emend>
see for yeers or for life, of
common right, may take upon
the ground, to repair the
houses upon the same ground
to him Leased, although it be
not expressed in the Lease,
and although it be by a Lease
Parol; but if he take
more then is needful, he
may be punished by an Action
of Wast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="housel(v)">Howsel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to <emend err="mini">mini&shy;</emend>
ster Sacraments to a sick man
in danger of death. Bull.
The receiving the Sacraments.
Rider</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hugh(pn)">Hugh.</form> <xpln lang="en">Aventinus derives 
it <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">from the German word</class> 
<etym lang="gr">Hougen</etym>, that is, flasher or
cutter. But whereas the
name Hugh was first in use a&shy;
mong the French, and Otfrid
in the yeer 900 used Hugh for
comfort, I judge this name to
be borrowed thence, and so
is correspondent to the Greek
names <term lang="gk">Elpidius</term> and <etym lang="gk">Elpis</etym>.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huguenots(pn)">Huguenots ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Calvi&shy;
nists, Reformists, French Pro&shy;
testants. At first termed thus,
of a gate in Tours called Hu&shy;
gon, neer to which they as&shy;
sembled, when they stirred
first, or of the beginning of
their first Protestation, <term lang="la">Huc
nos venimus</term>, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huguenotism(pn)">Huguenotism (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Hugue&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Humiliates(pn)">Humiliates,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Religious
Order, instituted about the
yeer 1166. by certain persons
exiled by Fredericus Barbarossa,
who, when they were re&shy;
stored to their Country, ap&shy;
parelled themselves in white,
and lived by a kind of Vow,
in Prayers, penury and work&shy;
ing wool, and were admitted
by Innocentius the third, and
other his Successors. Pol.
Vir.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Humfrey(pn)" lexeme="Humphrey(pn)">Humfrey, orHumphrey

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hundred(n)">Hundred,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a part of a
Shire so called Originally, be&shy;
cause it contained ten Ty&shy;
things, each Tything consist&shy;
ing of ten housholds, called
in Latine <term lang="la">decennas</term>. These
were first ordained by King
Alfred the twenty ninth King
of the West Saxons . Stows 
Annals, pag.105. In Wales
it is called Cantred or Cantref. 
See more in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hustings(pn)">Hustings, may seem to
come <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the French</class> <etym lang="fr">Haul&shy;
ser</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to raise, elevate or sit a&shy;
loft)</form> <xpln lang="en">for it signifies the prin&shy;
cipal and highest Court in
London. An.11.H.7. cap.21.
and Fitzh. nat. br. fol.23. See
An.9. Ed. I. <emend err="Cap.unico" source="errata">cap. unico</emend>. Other
Cities and Towns also have
had a Court of the same name,
as Winchester, Lincoln, York,
Sheppey, and others; where
the Barons or Citizens have a 
Record of such things as are
determinable before them.
Fleta lib.2. Cap.55.</xpln></wordentry>

or a purple flower called
Crowtoes ; also a kind of preci&shy;
ous stone called a Hyacinth.

which is of colour like a Hya&shy;
cinth, to wit, blew and red.
Rev.9.11.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hyena(n)">Hyena,</form> <xpln lang="en">a beast like a woolf
having a main and long hairs
over all the body. It is the
subtillest (as some say) of all
beasts, and will counterfeit
the voice of a man, to draw
shepheards out of their hou&shy;
ses in the night, to the end
he may kill them. It is
written that he changeth
sex often, being sometimes
male, and sometimes female.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hymen(n)">Hymen ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the God of
marriages, or a song sung at
marriages. The Greeks at
their marriages were wont to
sing Hymen, Hymen&aelig;e, as
the Romans did Talassio, Ta&shy;
lassio.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypocondriac(a)" lexeme="hypocondriacal(a)">Hypocondriack

dricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to the fore&shy;
part of the belly and sides a&shy;
bout the short ribs, and a&shy;
bove the Navel, under which
lyeth the Liver or Spleen.
Also that is troubled with a
windy Melancholy in those
parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypocrisy(n)">Hypocrisy (<etym lang="la">hypocrisis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dis&shy;

</page>

<page sig="u3r">
sin, with a shew of faith and

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypocrite(n)">Hypocrite (<etym lang="la">hypocrita</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it
properly signifies one that as&shy;
sumeth or takes upon him the
gesture or person of another,
and covers or disguises his
judgement; but it is common&shy;
ly taken for a dissembler, that
<emend err="wish">with</emend> feigned holiness would
seem better then he is indeed;</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypocritical(a)">Hypocritical</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
an Hypocrite, dissembling,
counterfeit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypogee(n)">Hypoge (<etym lang="la">hypog&aelig;um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a vault

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypogram(n)">Hypogram ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a subscri&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hypospadians(pn)" lexeme="Hippospadians(pn)">Hypospadians orHippo&shy;
spadians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of monstrous
persons that abuse themselves
with a Horse or Mare. In
Febr. 1652. one of these (who
went by the name of Margaret
Raine) was convict before
the Judges at Edinborough in
Scotland for Buggery of a
Mare, or being buggered
by a Horse; and both shee
and the horse were burnt ac&shy;
cording to the Mosaical Law ;
this person by an inquest of
Chirurgians, was found to be
one of that sort (says the re&shy;
lation) whom the Philoso&shy;
phers call Hypospadians.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypostatical(a)">Hypostatical (from <etym lang="la">Hypo&shy; 
stasis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to supposi&shy;
tality, subsistence or person&shy;
ality. The Hypostatical Union 
is the union of humane nature
with Christs divine person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypothecary(a)">Hypothecary (<etym lang="la">hypothecari&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to a pledge or
gage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypothenusal(a)">Hypothenusal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">as the
Hypothenusal line is that side of
a Rectangle triangle, wich is
opposed to, or subtends the
right Angle. A term used in
Trigonometry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypothesis(n)">Hypothesis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a suppo&shy;
sition or condition; some&shy;
times it is taken for a Positi&shy;
on of something, as it were
demonstrated, and granted by
another. Scapula.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hypothetical(a)">Hypothetical <emend err=""> (</emend> <etym lang="la">hypotheticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
in Logick, those Propositions,
which have a Conjunction in
them, and so consist of two
parts, are called Hypothetical
Propositions, as in saying, If the
Sun be in our Hemisphear, it is
day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hysterology(n)">Hysterology (<etym lang="la">hysterologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an altering of the order of
speech, by placing that first
which should be last.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hysteron proteron(n)">Hysteron Proteron ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the same with Hysterology, it is
sometimes used in derision of
that which is spoken or done
preposterously or quite <emend err="contra">contra&shy;</emend>
ry. The common phrase is;
The Cart before the horse. 
</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="i"><alpha>I.</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jacent(a)"><f type="l"/> JAcent (<etym lang="la">jaceus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lying along,
slow, sluggish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jacinth(n)">Jacinth (<etym lang="la">hyacinthus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pre&shy;
cious stone found in &AElig;thiopia, 


</page>

<page sig="u3r">
whereof there are two kinds,
the one of a pale yellow co&shy;
lour, the other of a cleer
bright yellow, which is ac&shy;
counted the better. It is
cold of nature, comfortable
to the body, and provokes
sleep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jacob(pn)">Jacob (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> a tripper or
supplante)</form> <xpln lang="en">whose name (be&shy;
cause he had power with God,
that he might also prevail
with men) was changed in&shy;
to Israel by God. See Genesis
cap.32. <term lang="la">Philo de nominibus mu&shy;
tatis</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jacobins(pn)">Jacobins,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Fryers of St.
Dominicks Order are called
Jacobins in France, either be&shy;
cause their Monastery in Paris
is dedicated to St. James, or
because it is seated in the street
of St. James, called Rue St.
Jacque.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jacobites(pn)">Jacobites</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called from
Jacobus Syrus, who lived <term lang="la">Anno</term>
530.) a sort of Heretiques,
who (1) acknowledge but
one Will, Nature and Opera&shy;
tion in christ. 2 Use Cir&shy;
cumcision in both Sexes. 3
Signe their children with the
sign of the Cross, imprinted
with a burning iron. 4 Af&shy;
firm Angels to consist of two
substances, fire and light, &amp;c.
The Patriarch of this Sect is
always called Ignatius, and a
Monk of S. Anthonies Order, he
keeps his residence at Carami
in Mesopotamia, and is said to
have 160000 families under
his jurisdiction. Biddulph.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jacob's Staff(n)">Jacobs Staff,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pilgrims
staff, so called from those who
out of devotion go on pilgri&shy;
mage to the City of St. Jago,
or St. James Compostella in
Spain, where some of S. James
his Reliques are. It is some&shy;
times taken for a staff that
hath a dagger or little sword
in it. Also an Instrument
in Geometry so called. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jacob's Ladder(n)">Jacobs Ladder,</form> <xpln lang="en">the jour&shy;
ney of Jacob wherein God
would be present with him in
favour by his Angels, to lead
him forth well and happily;
also to bring him back again.
Gen.28.12. There stood a Lad&shy; 
der . See ver. 15, and 20.
Wilson.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jactator(n)">Jactator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cracker
or boaster</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jaculable(a)">Jaculable (<etym lang="la">jaculabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fit
to be thrown, that may be cast
or darted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jaculatory(a)">Jaculatory (<etym lang="la">jaculatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is suddainly cast
from one, like a dart; as Ja&shy;
culatory Prayers, sudden, ex&shy;
temporary Prayers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jamb(n)">Jambes ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">with us it is
used for the Posts sustaining
both sides of the door; the
side posts of a door.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jambic(a)">Jambick (<etym lang="la">Iambus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a foot
in meeter having the first syl&shy;
lable short, and the other long
as <term lang="la">salus</term>. Also a kind of Verse,
so called, consisting usually
either of four feet or of six,
which in rigor should be all
iambique feet, but in unequal
places (viz.) first, third, 


</page>

<page sig="u4r">
and fifth receives a Spondee ;
and in equal places, as se&shy;
cond, fourth, and sixth, 
retains peremptorily the Iam&shy;
bique feet. 

 <term lang="la">Suis &amp; ipsa Roma viribus ruit</term> . 

This kind of Verse is said
to be first invented by Archi&shy;
lochus a Greek Poet, and was
applyed by the Ancients to
Invectives. Doctor <emend err="Tatlors">Taylors</emend>
Gram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="James(pn)">James</form> <xpln lang="en">is wrested from
Iacob. <xref target="Jacob">See Iacob</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jampnorum(n)">Jampnorum,</form> <xpln lang="en">as so many A&shy;
cres lampnorum used in Fines,
is a made word from the Fr.
 <etym lang="fr">jaulne</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> yellow, because the
bloomings of Furze are yel&shy;
low, and Jampnum in our Law
books and Fines, signifies
Furze .</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="janizary(n)">Janizaries</form> <xpln lang="en">(<expan type="">id est</expan> the new
souldiery) are the Turks
principal foot souldiers, that
are of his Guard, who for the
most part by Original being
Christians, are chosen by the
Turkish Officers every five
yeers, out of his Europ&aelig;an
Dominions, or are taken
Captives in their child-hood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jannock(n)">Jannock (<etym lang="la">avenaceum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
loaf made onely of Oaten
meal, so called in the North of
England.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jansenism(pn)" lexeme="Jansenianism(pn)">Jansenism
or 
Jansenianism</form> <xpln lang="en">the Tenets
and Opini&shy;
on of Cor&shy; 
nelius Jansenius late Bishop of
Ypres, whose writings seemed
to hold forth these five Propo&shy;
sitions . 

1. Some precepts of God
are impossible to just men,
willing and endeavouring, ac&shy;
cording to the present power
they have; Grace also is want&shy;
ing to them, whereby they
might be possible. 

2. In the state of lapsed
nature, there is no resistance
made to interior Grace. 

3. To merit and demerit
in the state of lapsed nature,
there is not required in man
liberty from necessity, but li&shy;
berty from coaction is suffi&shy;
cient. 

4. The Semipelagians did
admit the necessity of interi&shy;
or preventing Grace to every
act, even to the beginning of
faith; and in this they were
hereticks, because they would
have that Grace to be such, as
the will of man might resist or
obey. 

5. It is Semi-Pelagianism
to say, that Christ dyed or
shed his blood for all men
without exception. 

These Propositions (though
much defended in France and
Flanders) were condemned
by Pope Innocent the tenth;
in the Calends of June,
1653.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Janus(pn)">Janus</form> <xpln lang="en">was the God to
whom the yeer was dedica&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="u4v">
ted, and therefore it began
with his festival, and the first
month was nominated from
him, for which cause he was
represented with two faces,
to shew he looked both back&shy; 
ward upon the time past, and
forward upon that to come,
and sometimes with four fa&shy;
ces, to signify perhaps (for I
know other reasons are given)
the four seasons of the year. 

 <term lang="la">Annorum nitidique sator pulcherrime Mundi,
Publica quem primum vota precesque canunt</term>. Mart. 

To this God, Numa built a
Temple, which in time of
peace was shut, and in war o&shy;
pen. Mr. Cowley.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jar(n)">Jar (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class> <etym lang="sp">Jarro</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> an
earthen pot)</form> <xpln lang="en">with us it is most
usually taken for a vessel of
twenty Gallons of Oyl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jargon(n)">Jargon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gibbrish, fu&shy;
stion language, Pedlers&shy;
French, a barbarous jangling.
Rel. Med.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jasper(n)">Jasper (<etym lang="la">jaspis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a precious
stone of divers colours, but
the best is green, transparent
with red veins, and shews
fairest being set in silver: it is
good to stop any issue of
blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jasponyx(n)">Jasponyx ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
Jasper white of colour with
red strakes, not much unlike
the nail of a mans hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jatraliptic(n)">Jatraliptick (<etym lang="la">jatraliptes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jatromathematic(n)">Jatromathematique (from
<etym lang="gk">&Iota;&alpha;&tau;&rho;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">medicus</term>, and <etym lang="la">mathemati&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ibis(n)">Ibis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tall strong
bird in &AElig;gypt with a long bill,
which doth much good there
in killing Serpents, and when
he is sick, he gives himself a
Glister of salt-water; some
write, that Hippocrates first
learned of this bird to give
Glisters. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Icarian Sea(pn)">Icarian Sea,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called
from Icarus, who (as the Poets
will have it) flying from Creet
with his waxen wings, and
not following his Father D&aelig;&shy;
dalus directly, was there
drowned. Thus Ovid. 

 <term lang="la">Dum petit infirmis nimium sublimia pennis
Icarus, Icarius, nomina fecit aquis</term> . 

Whilst Icaru' s weak wings too high did soar,
He fell, and Christned the Icarian shoar. 

</xpln>
<lemenote>
Blount's errata note that one should read "Icariis" here at some point.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="u5r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ich dien(n)">Ich dien, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">the true old Saxon</class>
was<etym lang="sx">Ih</etym> or<etym lang="sx">Ic thian</etym>, or<etym lang="sx">thi&shy;
ene</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> I serve ; some will have
it come from the British
<etym lang="br">Eich dyn</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> your man, in that
language;</form> <xpln lang="en">It is the Motto
belonging to the Devise of the
Princes of Wales, which we
commonly, though corruptly
call the Princes Armes; the
figure is three Ostrich feathers,
which (saith Camden) Edw. 
the black Prince won at the
battle of Cressy, from John K.
of Bohemia, whom he there
slew, whereto he adjoyned
this old English Motto, allu&shy;
ding to that of the Apostle,
The heir while he is a child dif&shy; 
fers nothing from a servant.
These feathers were an anci&shy;
ent ornament of military
men, and used for Crests, as
is evident by that of Virgil. 

 <term lang="la">Cujus olorin&aelig; surgunt de vertice penn&aelig;</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ichnography(n)">Ichnography (<etym lang="la">ichnogra&shy;
phia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a plot of a house to be
builded, drawn out in paper,
or the description of any work
according to its tract or trace&shy;
ry on the ground, as it were
the footsteppings of the work.
For <etym lang="la">ichnographia</etym> in Gr. is, <term lang="la">quasi</term>,
<term lang="la">vestigii descriptio</term>; or <term lang="la">Descriptio
operis futuri</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ichthyology(n)">Ichthyology (<etym lang="la">ichthyologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a discoursing or description of
fishes. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ichthyonomancy(n)">Ichthyonomancy (<etym lang="la">ichthy&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ichthyophagy(n)">Ichthyophagie. ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="iconical(a)">Iconical (<etym lang="la">iconismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="iconoclast(n)">Iconoclast ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a demo&shy;
lisher or breaker of Images;
also a Sect so called, sprung 
up about the yeer of Christ
719 in time of Pope Gregory
the second, and Leo the third
Emperour who, for casting
holy Images and Statues out
of the Churches, and causing
them to be burnt or broken,
was surnamed the Iconoclast or
Iconomachus . Against which
was gathered the seventh
Nicene Synod consisting of 350
Bishops, who decreed against,
and condemned it for Heresie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idea(n)">Idea ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the form or fi&shy;
gure of any thing conceived
in the mind or imagination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ideal(a)">Ideal (<etym lang="la">idealis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to an Idea, imaginary, concei&shy;
ved in the imagination, onely
in fancy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ides(n)">Ides (<etym lang="la">idus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">eight days in
every moneth so called. In
March, May, July, and October,
these 8 days begin at the eight
day of the month, and con&shy;
tinue to the fifteenth; in o&shy;
ther months they begin at the
sixth day, and continue to the
thirteenth; 


</page>

<page sig="u5v">
 <term lang="la">Sex Maius, Nonas, October, Julius &amp; Mars
Quatuor; &amp; reliqui tenet Idus quilibet Octo.
Inde dies reliquos omnes dic esse Kalendas</term> . 

Where note that the last
day onely is called Ides: and
the first of these days the
eighth Ides, the second the
seventh Ides: that is, the
eighth or seventh day before
the Ides, and so of the rest.
Therefore when we speak of
the Ides of such a month in 
general, it is to be understood
of the fifteenth or thirteenth
day of that month. 

They are so called of an
old word Iduo, to divide;
for that they commonly fall
out neer the midst of the
month as aforesaid, according
to Horace. 

 <term lang="la">----- Idus tibi sunt agend&aelig;,
Qui dies mensem Veneris marin&aelig;,
findit Aprilem</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="identification(n)">Identification,</form> <xpln lang="en">the making
two things to be the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="identity(n)">Identity (from <etym lang="la">idem</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">same&shy;
ness, or being the same of
things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiosyncrasy(n)">Idiosyncrasy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">natural
property, or peculiar tempe&shy;
rament of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiopathy(n)">Idiopathy (<etym lang="la">idiopathia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
proper passion of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiograph(n)">Idiograph (<etym lang="la">idiographum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
private writing; or of ones
own hand writing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiotical(a)">Idiotical (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&Iota;&delta;&iota;&omega;&tau;&iota;&kappa;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">private, or belong&shy;
ing to private men; also be&shy;
longing to an Idiot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiom(n)">Idiom (<etym lang="la">idioma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a proper
form of speech, a Dialect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiot(n)">Idiot (<etym lang="la">idiota</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that is
naturally born so weak of un&shy;
derstanding, that he cannot
govern or manage his inheri&shy;
tance. The King by his Pre&shy;
rogative hath the government 
of their Lands and substance,
that are naturally defective in
their own discretion, 17, Ed.
2. cap.8. An Ideot, and he
that afterward becomes of in&shy;
sane memory, differ in divers
cases. Coke fol.154. b. lib.4.
See more in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idiotism(n)">Idiotism (<etym lang="la">idiotismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">na&shy;
tural folly, simplicity, sottish&shy;
ness: also the same with Idi&shy;
om, a form of speech taken up
by the vulgar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idolatry(n)">Idolatry (<etym lang="la">idololatria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a giving
divine worship to that which
is not God; an Idol signifies
properly a shadow, or rather
a vain Vision or false repre&shy;
sentation of a thing that is
not. Eustachius upon Homer.
Pol. Virgil affirms Idolatry to
have begun in the time of Be&shy;
lus King of the Assyrians, who
raigned <term lang="la">Anno Mundi</term> 3180,
whom the Babylonians first 


</page>

<page sig="u6r">
worshipped for a God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idoneity(n)">Idoneity (<etym lang="la">idoneitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fitness,
propriety.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idoneous(a)">Idoneous (<etym lang="la">idoneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">proper,
fit, meet, convenient.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idyl(n)">Idyl (<etym lang="la">idyllium</etym> or <etym lang="la">idyllion</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Poem consisting of few Ver&shy;
ses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jehovah(pn)">Iehovah ( <class type="etymlang" lang="he">H.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is Gods proper
name of his own imposition,
and incommunicable to any
creature, of what rank or
quality soever: a name of
such immoderate reverence a&shy;
mong the eldest Jews, that
it was forbidden to be writ&shy;
ten right, or pronounced at
all in this world, but by the
High-Priest, and but in one
place, the Sanctum Sancto&shy;
rum, and but at one time of
the yeer, in the day of expia&shy;
tion. Gregory, p.5. 

An eternal self-being, one
that hath his Essence of him&shy;
self from everlasting, and is
the cause of existence or be&shy;
ing to all things and crea&shy;
tures, which are of him, by
him and for him. Exod.
6.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jehu-march(pn)">Jehu-march,</form> <xpln lang="en">a speedy quick
march, such as that was of
Jehu, King of Israel, who
marching with a troop of men
towards Jezrahel, stopt the
messengers that were sent to
him out of the Town, to
learn whether he came as a
man of peace, a friend, or a
foe? whereof you may read
more 4 King.9.10:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jeiune(a)">Jeiune (<etym lang="la">jejunus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">greedy,
hungry, bare, barren, emp&shy; 
ty, nothing copious.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jeiunity(n)">Jeiunity (<etym lang="la">jejunitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">slen&shy;
derness of stile, barrenness,
nakedness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="je ne sais quoi(n)">Je-ne-scay-quoy</form> <xpln lang="en">(four
French words, contracted as
it were into one, and signi&shy;
fies, I know not what, we use to
say they are troubled with the
Je-ne-scay-quoy, that faign
themselves sick out of nice&shy;
ness, but know not where
their own grief lies, or what
ayls them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jeofail(n)">Ieofaile,</form> <xpln lang="en">is compounded of
three French words, <etym lang="fr">J' ay fail&shy;
le</etym>, I have failed; and signi&shy;
fies in our Common Law an
oversight in pleading. See
the New Terms of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jeremy(pn)">Jeremy (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr,</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">high of the
Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jesuati(pn)">Jesuati,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Order of Monks
begun at Sen&aelig; by John Colum&shy;
banus and Francis Vincent, <term lang="la">Anno</term>
1365, and so called from their
often having the name of Je&shy;
sus in their mouths. Pope
Urban the fifth approved
them, and enjoyned them to
wear a white garment, a white
cover for their head, a lea&shy;
thern girdle, and to go bare&shy;
foot, using onely wooden
soles; these were afterwards
called Apostolici . Crantzius
and Surius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jesuit(pn)">Jesuite,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Socie&shy;
ty of Jesus, a Religious Order
first founded by Saint Ignati&shy;
us Loyola, born in Biscay 1492
Pope Paul the third did con&shy;
firm this Order, Sep. 15.1540.
To the three Vows of Pover&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="u6v">
ty, Obedience, and Chastity, com&shy;
mon to all other orders, St.
Ignatius at the institution
hereof, added the Vow of
Mission, which is this.--- And
further we judge it expedient for
our greater devotion to the Sea
Apostolique, and more full abne&shy;
gation of our own wills and plea&shy;
sures; that the professed of this
Society, besides the common bond
of the 3. Vows, be further tyed
by special Vow; so as that what&shy;
soever the Roman Bishop for the
time being shall command, per&shy;
taining to the salvation of souls,
and propagation of the Faith,
they shall be bound to execute,
without tergiversation or excuse;
whether they shall be sent unto
Turks or Infidels, yea even unto
those that are commonly called
the Indians, or unto any other He&shy;
retiques or Schismaticks what&shy;
soever.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jesuah(pn)">Jesuah (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>) <etym lang="la"> salvator</etym>;</form> <xpln lang="en">by
that name and by Jehoshuah,
which signifies <term lang="la">Deus salvabit</term>,
our Saviour Christ was fore&shy;
told, in the Old-Testament;
from the Hebrew <term lang="he">Jesuah</term> comes
the Greek <etym lang="gk">&Iota;&eta;&#x03c3;&omicron;&upsilon;</etym>, which the
Latins write <term lang="la">Jesus</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jesus(pn)">Jesus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">la.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the proper name
of our Savior Christ designed
him from heaven by the Angel
Gabriel, and the reason of its
imposition is given by those
words of the said Angel in the
first chapter of St. Matth. And
his name shall be JESUS, be&shy;
cause he shall save his people from
their sins ; the word Jesus sig&shy;
nifying a Saviour . In Greek 
 <etym lang="gk">&Iota;&eta;&#x03c3;&omicron;&upsilon;</etym> <term lang="la">per Anagramma est</term> <etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&#x1f7a; &#x1f21;
&#x1f40;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">tu es ovis illa</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">ovis illa
pro peccatis nostris immolata, Ag&shy;
nus mactatus ante jacta mundi
fundamenta</term>. In abbreviation
this sacred name is usually
written thus I. H. S. which
middle letter some believe to
be an h, when as it is in truth
the Greek H, Eta, or E lon&shy;
gum . 

Jesus in the China tongue
signifies the rising Sun. Gre&shy;
gory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jetson(n)">Jetson.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref lexeme="flotsam"> See Flotsam</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jew's ears(n)">Jews-eares.</form> <xpln lang="en">An Excres&shy;
cence about the root of El&shy;
der, and concerns not the Na&shy;
tion of the Jews, as some ima&shy;
gine. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ignaro(n)">Ignaro ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that is
ignorant. A fool or dunce,
an Ignoramus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ignify(v)">Ignify (<etym lang="la">ignafacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
burn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="igniferous(a)">Igniferous (<etym lang="la">ignifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
beareth fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ignipotent(a)">Ignipotent (<etym lang="la">ignipotens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
mighty by fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ignis fatuus(n)">Ignis fatuus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan>
foolish fire. It is a kinde of
light or exhalation seen in
the night, seeming to go be&shy;
fore, or to follow men, lead&shy;
ing them out of their way to
waters or other dangerous
places, yet it hurts not, and
is called Ignis fatuus, be&shy;
cause it onely feareth fools.
Goodly Gallery. Hence 'tis,
when men are led away with
some idle fancy or conceit, we
use to say an Ignis fatuus, hath
done it.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="u7r">

&AElig;tna and Vesuvius are said to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ignoramus(n)">Ignoramus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the first per&shy;
son plural of <etym lang="la">ignoro</etym>, signifies
properly we are ignorant;
but it is commonly used as a
Noun. As when we say such
a one is an Inoramus, <expan type="">id est</expan> a fool
or a dolt. In our Com&shy;
mon Law it is properly used
by the grand Enquest, empan&shy;
elled in the inquisition of cau&shy;
ses criminal and publick; and
written upon the Bill, where&shy;
by any crime is offered to
their consideration, when as
they mislike their evidence, as
defective or too weak to
make good the Presentment.
The effect of which word so
written is, that all farther in&shy;
quiry upon that party, for that
fault, is thereby stopped, and
he delivered without further
answer; It hath a resemblance
with that custom of the anci&shy;
ent Romanes ; where the
Judges, when they absolved a
person accused, did write A,
upon a little Table provided 
for that purpose, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Absolvi&shy;
mus</term>: If they judged him
guilty, they writ C. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Con&shy;
demnamus</term>: if they found the
cause difficult and doubtful,
they write N. L. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Non Liquet</term>:
Asconius Pedianus in orat. pro
Milone. Alexander ab Alexan&shy;
dro. Genial. dierum lib.3. C.14.,</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ignoscible(a)">Ignoscible (<etym lang="la">ignoscibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
tollerable, to be pardon&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ikenild Street(pn)">Ikenild street,</form> <xpln lang="en">is one of
the four famous ways that
the Romans made in England,
taking the beginning <etym lang="la">ab
Icenis</etym>, which were those
that inhabited Norfolke,
Suffolke, and Cambridge&shy;
shire. Cam. Britan. fol.
343. See <xref lexeme="Watling Street">Watling-street</xref>.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Icknield Street": not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iliad(pn)">Iliad (<etym lang="la">ilias, adis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> Homers
Poem of the destruction of
Troy, so called; so when
we say an Iliad of evils or
sorrow, is meant as ma&shy;
ny mischiefs or as much
grief, as befel the Tro&shy;
jans, at the Seidge and
destruction of their City;
Also a Poem of evils, or
sorrow.</xpln></wordentry>

first or mall guts, so term&shy;
ed by Anatomists.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ember Days(pn)" lexeme="Ember weeks(pn)">Imber days, orImber
weeks (<etym lang="la">quatuor tempora</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which
weeks are four in the yeer,
and anciently, Wednesday,
Friday and Saturday in each
fasted, according to these old
Verses, 

<term lang="la">Post cineres, Pentec, post crucem, postque Luciam,
Mercurii, Veneris, Sabatho, jejunia fient</term> . 

That is, the next Wednes&shy;
day after Cineres or Ash-wed&shy;
nesday, after Pentecost, <expan type="">id est</expan> Whit&shy;
sunday, after holy-Rood-day, or
the Exaltation of the Cross;
and the next Wednesday af&shy;
ter St. Lucies day in <emend err="Decem">Decem&shy;</emend> 
ber . See <xref>Ember</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

Term in Heraldry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imparlance(n)">Imparlance</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <xref>Empar&shy;
lance</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imp(n)">To Impe,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term most u&shy;
sual among Faulconers, and is
when a Feather in a Hawkes
wing is broken, and another
piece imped or graffed to the
stump of the old. But may
be handsomly used in a meta&shy;
phorical sence to other pur&shy;
poses. As to Impe the Feathers
of time with several recreati&shy;
ons. Sir P. S. <etym lang="br">Himp</etym> or <etym lang="br">imp</etym>
in the Brittish language is <term lang="la">sur&shy;
culus</term>, a young graffe or twig,
thenceimpio the Verb, to in&shy;
oculate or graff. Hence the
word to imp is borrowed by
the English, first surely to
graft trees, and thence trans&shy;
lated to imping feathers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imparity(n)">Imparity (<etym lang="la">imparitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="u8v">
inequality, unlikeness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impeachment of waste(n)">Impeachment of waste, 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Empeschement</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">impedimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies with
us a restraint from commit&shy;
ing of waste upon Lands or
Tenements.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impost(n)">Impost ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Imposition,
Tallage, Custome, Tribute;
and more particularly it sig&shy;
nifies the tax received by the
Prince for such Merchandises
as are brought into any haven 
from other Nations. Ann.31.
Eliz. cap.5. And I think it
may in some sort be distin&shy;
guished from Custom, because
Custome is rather that profit,
which the Prince makes of
wares shipped out of the Land
yet they may be confounded.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impositor(n)">Impositor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cousener

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impostume(n)">Impostume (<etym lang="la">apostema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
quantity of evil humors, ga&shy;
thered into one part of the
body, whereof there are two
kinds, one when inflamed
blood, being turned to cor&shy;
rupt matter, fills some place:
the other, when without any
inflammation, nature thrusts
those humors into some part
apt to receive them. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incentor(n)">Incentor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that

narrowly into. Scotch Pa&shy;
pers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incest(n)">Incest (<etym lang="la">incestus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">did signi&shy;
fie all kinde of pollution,
committed by undoing or un&shy;
tying the girdle called Cestus 
or Zona ; but now in a more
strict acceptation it signifies
onely that kinde of naughti&shy;
ness, which is committed be&shy;
tween two of neer kin. God&shy;
win.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incestuous(a)">Incestuous (<etym lang="la">incestus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
defiles one of neer kin, pol&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incident(n)">Incident (<etym lang="la">incidens, ab in 
&amp; cado</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a circumstance or
by-matter, a thing which
comes indirectly into a fact
or question, or (being not
properly of the substance
thereof) arises from it col&shy;
laterally or side-ways; also a 


</page>

<page sig="x2v">
chance, accident, casualty.
Cotgr. In Law it signifies a
thing necessarily depending
upon another, as more<emend err="prin"> prin&shy;</emend>
cipal. For example, a Court
Baron is so incident to a
Mannor, and a Court of Pie&shy;
powders, to a Fair, that they
cannot be severed by Grant:
Or if a Mannor or Fair be
<emend err="gran ed">granted</emend>, these Courts can&shy;
not be reserved. Kitchin fo.36</xpln></wordentry>

verting into Ashes, Imbers,
or Cinders. Mont. and Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incubus(n)">Incubus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">A Devil
that sometimes in mans shape
lies with women, as Succubus 
doth with men. Also a dis&shy;
ease called the Night-mare,
when a man in his sleep sup&shy;
poseth he hath a great weight
lying on him, and feels him&shy;
self almost strangled; in such
sort that he cannot turn him&shy;
self, nor sit up, nor call for
help. The vulgar think it
some spirit, but the Physiti&shy;
ans affirm it to be a natural
disease, caused by humors
undigested in the stomack,
which fuming up to the brain,
do there trouble the Animal
Spirits, stoping their passage
into the sinews, so that the
body cannot move. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inculcate(v)">Inculcate (<etym lang="la">inculco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pour 
or thrust in, to repeat of&shy;
ten, to beat into the me&shy;
mory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inculpable(a)">Inculpable (<etym lang="la">inculpabi&shy;
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">blameless, unreprove&shy;
able.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incumbent(a)">Incumbent (<etym lang="la">incumbens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
leaning, lying, falling or<emend err="rest"> rest&shy;</emend>
ing upon. 

An Incumbent in our Com&shy;
mon Law, is he that is pre&shy;
sented, admitted, and insti&shy;
tuted to any Church or Be&shy;
nefice with Cure, who is
therefore called the Incum&shy;
bent of that Church, because
he bends all his study to the
discharge of the cure there.
Terms of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indigo(n)">Indico,</form> <xpln lang="en">a stone brought

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indiction(n)">Indiction (<etym lang="la">indictio ab indi&shy; 
cendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the space of fifteen
years, by which account
Charters and publick wri&shy;
tings are dated at Rome; e&shy;
very year still increasing one,
till it come to fifteen, and
then returning to one a&shy;
gain. 

These Indictions (as Bede
notes) began the twenty
fourth day of September, and
were devised (as he thinks)
to avoid confusion in Chro&shy;
nology. Indiction is most
properly said <term lang="la">de Tributo in&shy;
dicto</term>, as appears by the title
in the Code (lib.10. Tit.16.)
And these Indictions began at
the very dismission of the
Nicen Council; succeeding
(saith Onuphrius) in place of
the Olympiads, which as un&shy;
christian, the Emperor had
forbidden. Greg.<xref lexeme="epoch"> See E&shy;
poche</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indictive(a)">Indictive (<etym lang="la">indictivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
which is declared, appoin&shy;
ted or solemnly uttered,
whereunto the people were
wont to be called by Procla&shy;
mation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indigenous(a)" lexeme="indigenital(a)">Indigenous

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="individuum(n)">Individuum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat:</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
singular thing; that which
cannot be divided, a body in&shy;
separable, a Moat: Also a
term in Logick, when we
directly express and seem to
point to that thing which we
speak of: As in saying, This
Horse, that man: for though
the words [ horse or man] may
be applied to any horse or
man, yet being so expresly
pointed at, they cannot then
be drawn to signifie other
then those two. 

Individuum Vagum, a sin&shy; 
gular thing not determined
to be this or that in particu&shy;
lar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indivisible(a)">Indivisible (<etym lang="la">indivisibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that cannot be divided.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indubitate(a)">Indubitate (<etym lang="la">indubitatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="induciary(n)">Induciary (<etym lang="la">induciarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to truce or league.
Sir Hen. Wotton (speaking of
the times of Q Eliz) calls
King James (then King of
Scotland) induciat heir of this
Imperial Crown.. Rel Wott.
p.13.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="induction(n)">Induction (<etym lang="la">inductio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
drawing, entry, or leading
into; an inducement, allu&shy;
ring or perswasion unto; al&shy;
so a form of argument from
particulars, proceeding to
universals. We take Inducti&shy;
on (says my <expan type="">Lord</expan> Bac.) to be
that form of demonstration,
which supports sence, presses
nature, and is instanced in
works, and in a sort mingled
therewith.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indulcate(v)" lexeme="indulciate(v)">Indulcate

Felth.</xpln></wordentry>

of Idulgences in the Roman

pardon. This word is used

not well be approved of in
regard the Latin Verb, from
whence it comes, is of the
second, and not of the first
Conjugation.</xpln></wordentry>

number or person, as other

love.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="engrosser(n)">Ingrosser (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Grasseur</etym>, or <etym lang="fr">Grossier</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
in our Common Law one
that buyes Corn growing, or
dead victuals to sell<emend err="aga n"> again</emend>,
except Barly for Malt, Oats
for Oatmeal, or victuals to
retaile, badging by licence,
and buying of Oyles, Spices,
and Victuals, other then fish
or salt. Anno 5. Ed.6. ca.14.
A.5. Eliz. ca.14. An.13. Eliz
ca.25. These are Mr. Wests
words, part.2. Symbol. titulo 


</page>

<page sig="x6r">
Indictments. Sect.64. How&shy;
beit this definition rather be&shy;
longs to unlawful ingrossing,
then to the word in general.
See <xref>Forestal</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inhibition(n)">Inhibition (<etym lang="la">inhibitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a for&shy;
bidding or stopping. It is al&shy;
so a Writ to inhibit or forbid
a Judge from further procee&shy;
ding in the cause depending
before him. See Fitzh. nat
br fol.39. where he puts pro&shy;
hibition and inhibition toge&shy;
ther. 

Inhibition is most common&shy;
ly a Writ issuing out of a
higher Court Christian to a
lower and inferior, upon an
Appeal An.24. H.8. ca.12.
And Prohibition out of the
Kings Court to a Court Chri&shy;
stian, or to an inferior tempo&shy;
ral Court. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

sick) a squirting or conveying
a liquid medicine, by Siringe
&amp;c. into some part of the bo&shy;
dy, or into a hollow or fistu&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="initiative(n)" lexeme="initiated(n)">Initiative

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="injunction(n)">Iniunction (<etym lang="la">injunctio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
Writ issuing out of the Chan&shy;
cery; sometimes to give posses&shy;
sion to the Plaintiff, for want
of the Defendants appear&shy;
ance; sometimes to stay pro&shy;
ceeding in a Cause at Com&shy;
mon Law upon suggestion
made, that the rigor of the
Law, if it take place, is a&shy;
gainst equity and conscience
in that case. See West. part 2.
Symb. tit. Proceeding in Chan&shy;
cery. Sect.25.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inlagary(n)">Inlagary (<etym lang="la">inlagatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
restitution of one outlawed,
to the Kings protection, and
to the benefit or estate of a
subject. Bract. l.3. tract.2. ca.
14. numb.6,7,8. Britton. ca.
13.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inlapidate(v)">Inlapidate (from <etym lang="la">in</etym> and
 <etym lang="la">lapis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make hard, stony, or
like a stone. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inlay(a)">Inlay ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among
Joyners, and signifies a lay&shy;
ing of coloured wood in
Wainscoat-works, Bedsteds,
Cupboards, &amp;c.<xref> See Mar&shy;
quetry</xref>. 

It is also used by Gold&shy;
smiths, Cutlers and others, 


</page>

<page sig="x6v">
as to Inlay with Gold or Sil&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="innatable(a)">Innatable (<etym lang="la">innatabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that cannot be swimmed
in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inmate(n)">Inmates,</form> <xpln lang="en">are those that
be admitted to dwel for
their money joyntly with a&shy;
nother man, though in se&shy;
veral rooms of his Man&shy;
sion house, passing in and
out by one door, and not
being able to maintain them&shy;
selves, which are inquitable
in a Leet. Kitchin. fol.45.
where you may read him at
large, who are properly In&shy;
mates in intendment of Law,
and who not.</xpln></wordentry>

lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that cannot be sailed in,
that will not bear a ship or
boat.</xpln></wordentry>

brated by the Roman Ca&shy;
tholicks on the 28 of Decemb. 
in memory and honor of those
innocent children Herod slew,
not long after our Saviours
Nativity, when he sought for
Christ himself, thinking to de&shy;
stroy him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="innuendo(n)">Innuendo,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Law term,
most used in Declarations and
other pleadings; and the of&shy;
fice of this word is onely to
declare and design the person
or thing which was named
incertain before; as to say, he
( innuendo the Plaintiff) is a
Theef; when as there was
mention before of another
person.</xpln></wordentry>

Thom.</xpln></wordentry>

and setting it on with clay :
or when an hole is bored in a
tree, and a kernel put in with

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inquistion(n)">Inquisition (<etym lang="la">inquisitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a diligent search or inquiry,
strict examination. 

Spanish Inquisition, was first
created and called the Sacred
Council of Inquisition, about or
not long after the year, 1492.
at which time the Empire of
the Moors ended in Spain by
the valour of Ferdinand the Ca&shy;
tholick. Such Moors, as after
the decay of their Kingdom,
staid in Spain, were by a Sta&shy;
tute in that case provided, to
be christned. And that they
might be known to be, as they
professed, this Inquisition
was ordained, consisting of
a President (and he always
an Ecclesiastical person, as
the Arch Bishop of Tolledo,
or the Arch Bishop of Se&shy;
vil) assisted by twelve other
Councellors, who deal all
together in matters ap&shy;
pertaining to Religion.
<emend err="H l.">Heyl</emend>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="insanity(n)">Insanity (<etym lang="la">insanitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mad&shy;
ness, disease of mind.</xpln></wordentry>

Such was that the Jews put
upon the Cross when they
crucified our Savior, <term lang="la">JESUS

DEORUM</term>, for which words
these letters are ordinarily u&shy;
sed over the head of a Cruci&shy;
fix, J. N. <expan type="">read</expan> J.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="insect(n)">Insect (<etym lang="la"><emend err="insecta" source="errata">insectas</emend></etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a small
fleshless and bloodless vermine
divided (in some sort) be&shy;
tween the head, body and
belly, as an Ant, Fly, Bee, &amp;c.
under which, the Earth-worm,
Caterpillar, &amp;c. are also com&shy;
prehended. Lord Bacon useth
Incesta' s for creatures bred
of putrifaction. Nat. Hist.
143.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="interdict(n)">Interdict (<etym lang="la">interdictum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
injunction, prohibition or for&shy;
bidding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="interdiction(n)">Interdiction (<etym lang="la">interdictio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="x8v">
the same. It is used in the
Common Law, as in the Ca&shy;
non, where it is thus defined,
 <term lang="la">Interdictio est censura Ecclesiasti&shy;
ca prohibens administrationem di&shy;
vinorum. c. quod in te: de p&aelig;nitens.
&amp; remis&aelig;</term>, in the Decretals.
And thus is it used, Ann 24.
H.8. ca.12. Interdicted of wa&shy;
ter and fire, were in old time
those who for some crime
were banished. Which Judge&shy;
ment, although it was not by
express sentence pronounced,
yet by giving order, that no
man should receive such an
one into his house, but deny
him fire and water (the two
necessary Elements of life)
he was condemned (as it
were) to a civil death; and
this was called <term lang="la">Legitimum ex&shy;
ilium</term> . Livie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="interduct(n)">Interduct (<etym lang="la">interductus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
space between full sentences
in printing or writing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inventory(n)">Inventory (<etym lang="la">inventorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
a description or repertory,
orderly made, of dead mens
Goods and Cattels prized by
four credible men or more,
which every Executor or Ad&shy;
ministrator ought to exhibite 


</page>

<page sig="y2r">
to the Ordinary, at such times
as he shall appoint the same.
West. part. I. Symb. lib.2. Sect.
696. Where likewise you
may see the form: This Inven&shy;
tory proceeds from the Civil
law: for when as by the ancient
Law of the Romans, the heir
was tyed to answer all the Te&shy;
stators debts, by which means
heritages were prejudicial to
many; Justinian, to encourage
men the better to take upon
them this charitable Office,
ordained, that if the heir
would first make and exhibite
a true Inventory of all the
Testators substance coming
to his hand, he should be no
further charged then to the va&shy;
lue of the Inventory. l. ult.
Co. de Jure deliberando.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inversion(n)">Inversion (<etym lang="la">inversio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a turn&shy;
ing inside out, or upside
down, a mis-placing of words
or matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="invest(v)">Invest (<etym lang="la">investire</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to give
or put into possession; <term lang="la">Inve&shy;
stitura proprie dicitur quando ha&shy;
sta vel aliquod corporeum tradi&shy;
tur &agrave; Domino; ut ait Feudista, 
lib.2. tit.2.</term> with us we use
likewise to admit the Tenant,
by delivering him a verge or
rod into his hand, and mini&shy;
string him an Oath, which is
called Investing : others de&shy;
fine it thus. <term lang="la">Investitura est alicu&shy;
jus in suum jus introductio</term> . Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inure(v)">Inure (from <etym lang="la">In</etym> and <etym lang="la">Ure</etym>,

used much in Conveyances,
and signifies to take place or
effect, to be available. Ex&shy;
ample, a Release shall inure by
way of extinguishment. Lit&shy;
tleton, cap. Release. And a re&shy;
lease made to a Tenant for
term of life, shall inure to him
in the Reversion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joculary(a)">Joculary (<etym lang="la">jocularius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

ter. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joculatory(a)">Joculatory (<etym lang="la">joculatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
merry, pleasant, sporting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jocund(a)">Jocund (<etym lang="la">jocundus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">merry,
pleasant, cheerful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="John(pn)">John (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gracious,
Thought to be an unfortu&shy;
nate name for Kings; For that
John King of England well
near lost his Kingdom, and 
John King of France was
long Captive in England,
and John Baliol was lifted
out of his Kingdom of Scot&shy;
land. That John Stewart,
when the Kingdom of Scot&shy;
land came to him, renoun&shy;
cing that name, would be
proclamed King Robert. Ju&shy;
on is used by the Welch 
and Sclavonians for John, and
in this Realm about the Con&shy;
querors time John was rarely
found, butJuon, as Camden
observes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jonathan(pn)">Jonathan (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Gods
gift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jonah(pn)" lexeme="Jonas(pn)">Jonah orJonas,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name
of that Prophet which was
sent to Ninive, Jon. I.2. It
signifies in Hebrew a Dove.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="juncade(n)">Joncade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cer&shy;
tain Spoon-meat, made of
Cream, Rose-water, and Su&shy;
gar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ionic-work(n)">Jonick-work,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a sort of

Tuscan</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ionic(n)">Jonick (<etym lang="la">Jonicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cer&shy;
tain foot in a verse consist&shy;
ing of two long syllables and
two short; also wanton; as
Jonica Saltatio, a wanton or
effeminate dance. Also per&shy;
taining to Jonia, a Region of
Greece.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="io paean(ex)">Jop&aelig;an ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a voyce or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jot(n)" lexeme="jod(n)">Jot orJod (<etym lang="la">I&ouml;ta, litera
Gr&aelig;ca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a thing of very
little or no value; so called
from the Hebrew letter Jod,
which is the least in that lan&shy;
guage. 

 <term lang="la">Unum de titulo tollere Iota potes</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="iotacism(n)">Jotacism (<etym lang="la">Iotacismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
when the letter (I or I&ouml;ta)
sounds much; as if we say,
 <term lang="la">Juno Jovi irascitur</term>. It is also
sometimes taken for an error
in pronouncing the letter I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="journal(n)">Journal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Diary or
Day-book. Also as much
land as a Team of Oxen can
plough up in one day. In our
time (sayes my Lo: Bacon)
Journals are in use only in Na&shy;
vigations and Expeditions
of War. Among the Anci&shy;
ents it was a point of honor
to Princes to have the Acts of
their Court referred to Jour&shy;
nals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="journ&eacute;e(n)">Journee ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a day or
whole day; a day of Battle;
also a days work or labor, a
days travel or journey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="irony(n)">Ironie (<etym lang="la">ironia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure in

contrary to the signification
of the word, or when a man

he thinks, to mock him, whom
he argues with; a mocking or
scoffing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="irregularity(n)">Irregularity (<etym lang="la">irregularitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
disorder, going out of rule.
in the old Canon Law it is
taken for an impediment,
which hinders a man from
taking holy Orders; as if he
be base born, notoriously de&shy;
famed of any notable crime,
maimed or much deformed, or
have consented to procure a
nothers death, with divers o&shy;
ther. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ismaelite(pn)">Ismaelite</form> <xpln lang="en">one descended
from Ismael, son to Abraham by
his wife Agar, of which Isma&shy;
el it was foretold before his
birth, <term lang="la">hic erit ferus homo, manus
ejus contra omnes; &amp; manus om&shy;
nium contra eum</term> . Gen.16. One
like to Ismael in conditions
and manners. Ismael by in&shy;
terpretation of the Hebrew
word is <term lang="la">exauditio Dei</term>, a mer&shy;
ciful hearing or granting of
God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="isthm(n)">Isthme (<etym lang="la">isthmus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a neck, a
narrow piece of Land betwixt
two Seas almost meeting;
also the neck of the wesand.
 <term lang="la">Est angustia illa intermedia inter
Peninsulam &amp; Continentem. &amp;
veluti qu&aelig;dam Cervix. qu&aelig; &agrave;
continente, velut &agrave; corpore graci&shy;
