nente tanquam Caput cum reliquo
corpore connectit</term>.<xref lexeme="peninsula"> See Pen-in&shy;
sula</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Isthmian games(n)">Isthmian games (<etym lang="la">isthmii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
one of the four solemn games 


</page>

<page sig="y4r">
which were celebrated every
fifth yeer in Greece, institu&shy;
ted by Theseus in honor of
Neptune; they had the name
 Isthmii from the narrow piece
of ground in Greece that Co&shy;
rinth stood in, where the
games were celebrated</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="itinerary(n)">Itinerary (<etym lang="la">Itinerarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Commentary concerning
things fallen out in Journeys,
also the Kalender of miles,
with the distances of places,
and the times of abode in eve&shy;
ry place; like the gifts of
Princes, a Directory for the
way. It is also used Adje&shy;
ctively, as pertaining to a jour&shy;
ney.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="itinerate(v)">Itinerate (<etym lang="la">itineror</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to tra&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jubilation(n)">Jubilation (<etym lang="la">jubilatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

joycing, much gladness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jubilee(n)">Jubile (<etym lang="la">jubil&aelig;us annus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
yeer of rejoycing or of remis&shy;
sion. among the Hebrews e&shy;
very fiftieth yeer, was called
the yeer of Jubile, for then
were bond-men of their own
Country made free, possessi&shy;
ons returned again to the first
owners, neither was it lawful 
to plant or sow any thing that
yeer. Among Christians this
solemnity of keeping a yeer
of Jubile, was first instituted
by Bonifacius the eighth, in
the yeer of our Lord 1300,
who ordain'd, that it should
be observed every hundreth
yeer. After this, Clement the
sixth, instituted it to be kept
every fiftieth yeer; and lastly
Sixtas the fourth brought it
to be celebrated every twenty
fifth yeer, beginning it first in
the yeer of our Lord God
1475, and so it continues.
Some derive the word from
the Heb. Jubbel, others from
Jobel, which signifies any mu&shy;
sical sound, so called (as Masi&shy;
us helps it out) from Jubal, the
Father of those, who play
upon the Harp and Organ;
and when the Jubile came
a great sound of Trumpet
was to be made through all
Israel in sign of the Remissi&shy;
ons. Greg. in part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jucundity(n)">Jucundity (<etym lang="la">jucunditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
mirth, pleasure, rejoycing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Judaic(a)">Judaick (<etym lang="la">judaicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Jewish,
pertaining to the Jews.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Judaism(pn)">Judaism (<etym lang="la">judaismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Custom, Religion or Rites of
the Jews.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="judicable(a)">Judicable (<etym lang="la">judicabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may<emend err="de"> be</emend> judged or discussed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="judicatory(n)">Judicatory (<etym lang="la">judicatorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a place of judgement, a judg&shy;
ment seat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="judiciary(n)">Judiciary (<etym lang="la">judiciarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to a Judge or Judge&shy;
ment; also that is to be

<page sig="y4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jugal(a)">Jugal (<etym lang="la">jugalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is yoak&shy;
ed, or pertaining to yoaks,
Matrimony or Wedlock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jugament(n)">Jugament (<etym lang="la">jugamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a thing that fastens or couples
like a yoak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jugular(n)">Jugulars (<etym lang="la">ven&aelig; jugulares</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
See <xref>Veines</xref>:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jujube(n)">Jujubes,</form> <xpln lang="en">certain plumbs of
Italy sold here by Apotheca&shy;
ries. This fruit is in colour
white or red, in fashion round
or like an Olive, in taste
sweet, having a hard long
stone, like an Olive stone, but
much less. If these plumbs
be kept long, they wax dry
and full of wrinkles. They
are temperate in heat and
cold, and are good against
the Cough, roughness of the
throat, and against all exul&shy;
cerations and inflammations
of the Kidneys and Bladder : 
but being eaten for meat,
are of hard digestion. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="julep(n)">Julep ( <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Physical
drink, made either of distilled
waters or Syrups mixed toge&shy;
ther, or of a decoction sweet&shy;
ned with hony or sugar, or
else mingled with Syrrops,
and ministred commonly as a
preparative to open the pas&shy;
sage of the inward parts, and
fit the humors for a purgation.
The word properly signifies a
pleasant potion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="julio(n)">Julio,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Italian Coyn, of
value with us about six pence,
so called, because it was first
made by Pope Julius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Julius(pn)">Julius ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">soft-haired or
mossie-bearded, so it signifies
in Greek. It was the name
of &AElig;nea' s son, who was first
called Ilus. 

<term lang="la">Ilus erat dum res stetit Ilia regno</term> . 

The old English-men in the
North parts turned Julius into
Joly, and the unlearned
Scribes of that time may seem
to have turned Julianus into
Jolanus, for that name often
occurs in old Evidences.
Cam</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="July(pn)">July (<etym lang="la">Julius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">this moneth
was called July in honor of
Julius C&aelig;sar, the Dictator, be&shy;
ing before called Quintilis or
the fifth month from March ;
which according to Romulus,
was the beginning of the yeer.
It was so called, either be&shy;
cause Julius C&aelig;sar was 
born in that month, or because
he triumphed in that month,
after his Naval victory over
Cleopatra Queen of &AElig;gypt, and
her husband Antony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Julian account(pn)">Julian Account,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called
from Julius C&aelig;sar, who, 44
yeers before the birth of
Christ, observing the falseness
of the account then in use, or&shy;
dained the yeer to consist of
365 days and six hours, which
six hours in four yeers made
24 hours or a day civil, and
were added to the end of Fe&shy;
bruary ; by reason whereof e&shy;
very fourth yeer contained 


</page>

<page sig="y5r">
366 days, and was called An&shy;
nus Bissextilis, the Bissextile or
leap-year, because the sixth of
the Calends of March was
twice written, and the thing
it self was called Intercalation .
This Account for many yeers
seemed to have no sensible er&shy;
ror, yet in progress of time it
was discovered to be not so
exactly agreeable with the na&shy;
tural motion of the Sun; For
the Julian yeer exceeding the
true Solar yeer 10 min. and
48 seconds, caused the Equi&shy;
noxes and Solstices yeerly to
change their places and flye
back so many minutes and se&shy;
conds. Whereupon Pope
Gregory the thirteenth by the
advice and direction of Anto&shy;
nius Lilius and other excellent
Mathematicians, in the yeer of
Christ 1582 corrected the Ca&shy;
lender, making the yeer to
consist of 365 days, 5 hours,
49 m.12 s. And that the vernal
Equinox, which then was on
the 11 of March, might be re&shy;
duced to the 21 of March, as
it was at the time of the first
Nicene Council ; he commanded
10 days in the month October,
viz. from the 4 to the 14, to be
left out, so as the fourth day of
the month was accounted for
the 14 day. Hence it comes to
pass, that the new, forraign
Lilian or Gregorian account is
always 10 days before the old,
the English or Julian account.
Bucholzerus Ind. Chron. &amp; al.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jument(n)">Jument (<etym lang="la">jumentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a labor&shy;
ing beast, a horse. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jumentarious(a)">Jumentarious (<etym lang="la">jumentarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that belongs to such cattel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="juncture(n)">Juncture (<etym lang="la">junctura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a joyn&shy;
ing or coupling together, a
yoaking, a joynt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jungible(a)">Jungible (<etym lang="la">jungibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be joyned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="junonic(a)" lexeme="junonian(a)">Junonick

meeting together of people,
it is most commonly taken for
a joyning or meeting of men
to sit in Council.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jupiter(n)">Jupiter ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a faigned

the Paynims, c. Also a Pla&shy;
net. See <xref>Planet,</xref> and <xref>Saturn</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ivory(n)">Ivory (<etym lang="la">ebur</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Elephants teeth
It is of a binding nature, and
the scraping thereof is good a&shy;
gainst sores, growing under
the roots of the nayls. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="juration(n)">Juration (<etym lang="la">juratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Oath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jurat(n)">Jurats ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Jurats de Bour&shy;
deaux, are as the Eschevins or
Sheriffs in other Cities; we
have Officers of that name at
the Town of Maidston in Kent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jordan(n)">Jurden orJordan (<etym lang="la">matel&shy;
la</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a double Urinal or Cham&shy;
berpot. In some places it is
taken for that Chamberpot,
which did serve both the hus&shy;
band and his wife. In T. VVal&shy;
singhams hist. p.308. we read of
 <term lang="la">Du&aelig; oll&aelig; quas Jordanes vulgo
vocamus</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

or belonging
to the Law; also actionable,
or which may be put in suit,

</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jury(n)">Jury (<etym lang="la">jurati</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in

ny of men, as twenty four, or
twelve, sworn to deliver a
truth upon such evidence as
shall be delivered them,
touching the matter in que&shy;
stion. Of which see more
in Fitzh. nat. br. fol.165. D. &amp;c.
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="justicium(n)">Justicium (Lat. <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="la">juris

ministration of Justice in 
matters judicial. (Dr. Br. useth

not unfitly be called a Law&shy;
steed, as Solstitium, the Sun&shy;
steed .</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Justicians(pn)">Justicians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a religious or&shy;
der instituted by Lewis Bar&shy;
bus a religious man of Venice,
in the Abbey of St. Justine
(whence they took name) at
Padua, about the year 1412
in the time of Pope John the
three and twentieth. There
were also Nuns of the like or&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Justinianists(pn)">Justinianists,</form> <xpln lang="en">Students of
the Civil Law, Civilians, so
called from Justinianus, a Ro&shy;
man Emperor, that gathered
the sum of the Civil Law.
See <xref>Code</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Juventas(pn)">Juventas,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Goddess of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ixion(pn)">Ixion,</form> <xpln lang="en">begat the Centaures
on a Cloud (as the fable goes)
and was afterwards cast into
Hell by Jupiter, for boasting
that he had layn with Juno,
where he was bound to a
wheel, and the wheel turned
without ceasing. Hence the
Fable of Ixons wheel . 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="king's evil(n)">Kings Evil,</form> <xpln lang="en">A disease or
swelling so called. Edward
the Confessor King of Eng&shy; 
land was of that holiness of
life that he received power
from above to cure many dis&shy;
eases, among others, this of
the Kings Evil. A Prerogative
that continues (as som think)
hereditary to his Successors
of England Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keel(n)">Keel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> <etym lang="bl">Kiel</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the bot&shy;

still used in the north of Eng&shy; 
land and in Scotland ; So
Kele-wurt signifies Pottage&shy;
hearb, which we to this day
corruptly call Cole-wurts . Ver&shy;
stegan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kichel(n)">Kichel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cake,
which Horace calls Libum : 

 <term lang="la">Vique sacerdotis fugitibus liba recuso</term> . 

It was of old with us cal&shy;
led aGods Kichel, because
Godfathers and Godmothers
used commonly to give one
of them to their Godchildren,
when they aske blessing.
Chaucer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kilderkin(n)">Kilderkin (from the Belg

Quart: Agricola and Juni&shy;

chandize to the value of

der or over according to

Case of Reniger and Fagossa.
Cow</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knave(n)">Knave (anciently<etym lang="sx">Cnapa</etym>,
and<etym lang="sx">Knabe</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was not of old
used <emend err="us">as</emend> a name of disgrace, or
contempt (as now it is) but
as the name of some kind of
Servant or Lacquey; <emend err="As" source="errata">A</emend> 
<term lang="sx">Scyld-Knapa</term> was he that
carried a noble persons Shield,
&amp;c. Verst.<xref lexeme="esquire"> See Esquire</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kit-keys(n)">Kit-Kaies,</form> <xpln lang="en">The fruit of the
Ashen tree; they are little
narrow huskes hanging to&shy;
gether in clusters, where&shy;
in is contained the seed of
the Ashe, which is bitter:
This provokes Urine, and is
sought by some for other pur&shy;
poses. Bull.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knight(n)">Knight,</form> <xpln lang="en">a title of dignity,
was heretofore by our Ancest&shy;
ors writtenCnight, and in
the modern Teutonic it signi&shy;
fies Rider, and answers to the
French word <etym lang="fr"> Chevalier</etym>, which
may be englished a Horseman,
and so agrees with <term lang="la">Eques</term> in
Latin Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knight's fee(n)">Knights Fee (<etym lang="la">feudum mi&shy;
litare</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is so much inheritance,
as is sufficient yearly to main&shy;
tain a Knight, with conveni&shy;
ent Revenue, which in Hen. the
thirds days was but 15 l. Cam. 
Brit. p.111. or 680 acres of
Land, or 800 acres, <term lang="la">eodem</term>.
But Sir Thomas Smith in his
Repub. Angl. l. I. ca.18. rates
it at 40 l. And I find in the
Statute for Knights, An.1.
Ed.2. cap. I. that such as
had twenty pound in Fee, or
for term of life <term lang="la">per an</term>. might
be compelled to be Knights;
Stow. in his Annals, p.285.
saith, There were found in
England at the time of the
Conqueror 60211 Knights
Fees: Others say 60215,
whereof the religious houses
before their suppression were
possessed of 28015. 

Knights Fee, is sometime
used for the Rent that a
Knight payes for his Fee to
the Lord of whom he holds;
And this an uncertain sum,
some holding by forty shillings
the Shield, some by twenty
shillings, as appears by
Bracton lib.5. Tract. prim.
ca.2. 

My Lo. Coke in his nineth
Book of Reports saith, a
Knights Fee is estimated by
the value of the land (viz.)
20 l. annual : An hide of land
is as much as one Plough can
break up in a year: Releef
the fourth part of the annual
value of the land (viz.) of a
Knight 5 l. of a Baron 100
Marks, an Earl a 100 l. a Marq.
200 Marks, a Duke 200 l.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knighten guild(n)">Knighten gyld,</form> <xpln lang="en">was a
Gyld in London, consisting of
nineteen Knights, which King
Edgar, founded, giving them 


</page>

<page sig="y7r">
a portion of void ground ly&shy;
ing without the wall of the
City, now called Portsoken
ward. Stows Annals, pag.
151.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knight's service(n)">Knights service,</form> <xpln lang="en">an anci&shy;
ent tenure of lands, by which
a man was bound to bear
arms in War for defence
of the Realm.<xref> See Chi&shy;
valry</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knipperdollings(pn)">Knipperdollings,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of
Heretiques who took name
from one Knipperdolling, who
lived in Germany about the
year 1535, was contempo&shy;
rary with John of Leyden, a
follower of Muncer in matters
of doctrine, &amp;c. Lo. Herb. 
H.8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kyrie eleison(n)"><emend err="Kyre" source="errata">Kyrie</emend> eleison (<term lang="la">omnibus
linguis</term>, <term lang="la">a</term> <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&kappa;&upsilon;&rho;&iota;&epsilon;</etym>. <term lang="la"><expan type="">id est</expan> domine</term>,
and <etym lang="gk">&#x1f10;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x03ad;&epsilon;</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">miserere, ab</term> <etym lang="gk">&#x1f14;&lambda;&epsilon;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
i. <term lang="la">misericordia. q. miserere Do&shy;
mine</term>, Lord have mercy on
us. So <term lang="la">Christe eleison</term>. <expan type="">id est</expan>
Christ have mercy on us.<emend err="">)</emend></form> <xpln lang="en">In
the Greek Church these
words are of great esteem, and
often repeated by their
Priests; and are also used in
the latin Church. 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="l"><alpha>L</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labarum(n)"><f type="l"/> LAbarum (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&lambda;&alpha;&beta;&alpha;&rho;&#x1f78;&nu;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
A Church Banner, a
Flag or Streamer for the
War. 

Eusebius Pamphilius (lib.
I <term lang="la">de vita Constantini</term>) de&shy;
scribes this peculiar Stan&shy;
dard very curiously. The 
common form you may see
in the 163 page of the Ele&shy;
ments  of Armories. In the
Labarum these things are
more. First, The Banner
was of purple, where the
pictures of the Emperor
and his Children were
wrought in gold, and stones
of wonderful value and beau&shy;
ty; above the cross Beam,
or traverse Staff of the Ban&shy;
ner stood the two first Greek
Capitals of Christs name,
and on the point or top of
the Launce or Staff Imperi&shy;
al was advanced a Crown of
gold set with precious stones.
All in honor of his miraculous
conversion upon the appariti&shy;
on of the Cross.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labdacism(n)">Labdacisme (<etym lang="la">labdacismus</etym>) 
or rather <etym lang="la">lambdacismus</etym>, from
the Greek Letter <etym lang="gk">&lambda;&#x03ac;&mu;&delta;&alpha;</etym> or
<etym lang="gk">&lambda;&#x03ac;&mu;&beta;&delta;&alpha;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is when the let&shy;
ter L is pronounced with
too much force, as when
one saies, <term lang="la">ellucet</term>, for <term lang="la">elucet</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labefaction(n)">Labefaction (<etym lang="la">labefactio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
weakening or enfeebling, a
loosening or destroying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labial(a)">Labial (from <etym lang="la">labium</etym>, a
lip)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to the lips
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labile(a)">Labile (<etym lang="la">labilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">unstable,
unconstant, that will soon or
easily fall.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laboriferous(a)">Laboriferous (<etym lang="la">laborifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that takes pains, that en&shy;
dures labour, painfull, diffi&shy;
cult.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laboriosity(n)">Laboriosity (<etym lang="la">laboriositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
painfulness, laboriousness,
or laborosity:</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="y7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Labrador(pn)">Labrador ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a labou&shy;
rer, A Ploughman, a Country
Swain. Epist. Howel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labrous(a)">Labrous (<etym lang="la">labrosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath a brim, bank, or border;
Also that hath great lips.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="labyrinth(n)">Labyrinth (<etym lang="la">labyrinthus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Maze or intricate building, or
place made with so many
turnings, and windings, en&shy;
tries and doors, that whoever
went into it, could never
get out, without a perfect
guide, or a thread to direct
him, the end of which thread
must be tyed at the door
where he enters. Some hea&shy;
then Princes bestowed infi&shy;
nite charge in building such
Labyrinths, whereof there
were four principal ones in
the world. The first in
&AElig;gypt, near the Pool Mirios,
made for a Sepulchre for
their Kings, or (as some
write) in honor of the Sun.
The second in the Island of
Candy, built by D&aelig;dalus at the
command of King Minos.
The third, in the Isle Lemnos.
The fourth in Italy, built by
Porsenna King of the Hetruri&shy;
ans, of free stone, and vault&shy;
ed, for his own Sepul&shy;
chre. 

Labyrinth, also signifies me&shy;
taphorically an intricate O&shy;
ration or difficult matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lac(n)">Lacca ( <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
red gum coming forth of cer&shy;
tain trees in Arabia, and sold
here by Apothecaries, good
against diseases of the breast,
and comfortable to the Li&shy; 
ver. Painters also and Diers
use it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lacerable(a)">Lacerable (<etym lang="la">lacerabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be torn or rent in pee&shy;
ces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lacerate(v)">Lacerate (<etym lang="la">lacero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to rent,
tear or dismember.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lacert(n)">Lacert (<etym lang="la">lacerta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Lizard,
or an Ewt, Evet, or Est.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lacession(n)">Lacession (<etym lang="la">lacessio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pro&shy;
voking or stirring to an&shy;
ger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lachanopolist(n)">Lachanopolist (<etym lang="la">lachanopo&shy;
les</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a seller of hearbs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laches(n)">Laches (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Las&shy;
che</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> remiss, slack, or slow)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies, in our Common
Law, negligence: As no
Laches shall be adjudged in
the heir within age, Littl. fol.
136. and old nat. brev. fol.
110.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lachesis(pn)">Lachesis,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the three
destinies; Atropos and Clotho
are the other two.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lachrymable(a)">Lachrymable (<etym lang="la">lachrymabi&shy; 
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lamentable, to be bewai&shy;
led, or wept for.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lachrymate(v)">Lachrymate (<etym lang="la">lachrymo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
weep, to drop with moi&shy;
sture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laconical(a)">Laconical (<etym lang="la">laconicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
speaks briefly or pithily. So
used, because the Laced&aelig;mo&shy;
nians or people of Laconia
were wont to speak briefly
and wittily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laconism(n)">Laconism (<etym lang="la">laconismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
short speech, containing much
matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lactary(n)">Lactary (<etym lang="la">lactarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dairy&shy;
house, and may be used for
a Dayry-man, Milk man, or
Chees-monger. Br.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="y8r">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lagophthalmy(n)">Lagophthalmy (<etym lang="la">lagoph&shy;
thalmia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in the eyes,
when one sleeps like a Hare
with his eye-lids open, and
cannot well shut them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lake(n)">Lake,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fair red colour u&shy;
sed by painters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laical(a)">Laical (<etym lang="la">laicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging
to the Laity, not of the
Clergy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lair(n)">Laire,</form> <xpln lang="en">the place where
any Deer harbors by day; a
term of hunting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lais(pn)">Lais,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Harlot of
Corinth, who took so great a
price for the prostitution of
her body, as made Demostenes
cry, <term lang="la">Tanti non emam Lais p&aelig;&shy;
nitere</term>, (I will not buy repen&shy;
tance so dear) and occasioned
the old verse. 

 <term lang="la">Non cuivis homini contingit adire Corinthum</term> . 

'Tis not for every mans avail
Unto Corinth for to fail. 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lambitive(a)">Lambitive (from <etym lang="la">lambo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that licketh with the tongue,
or lappeth, that toucheth a
thing softly. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lamiae(pn)">Lami&aelig; ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">were spirits
and specters of the female
kind, called by some, Ladies
of the Fairies. 

Howbeit Dion Chrysostome
saith, that there are certain
living creatures, or wilde
beasts inhabiting the utmost
and desert places of Africk,
which from the face to the
navel, were excellently beau&shy;
tiful, and their fashion was to
lay open their Alabaster necks
and breasts to the view of
men, that so they might al&shy;
lure and draw them near, and
often would they forth&shy;
with devoure them. And
to this purpose the Prophet
Jeremy saith, The Lami&aelig; have 
discovered and drawn forth their
brests, and shewn their dugs,
Lam.4. The Hebrew Doctors
interpret them Devils of the
Desert, in expounding that
word of Isay, Tsijim (Isa.13.)
that it should signifie Lami&aelig;.
Tr. of Specters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lammas Day(pn)">Lammas day,</form> <xpln lang="en">the first of
August, otherwise called the
Gule orYule of August, which
may be a corruption of the
Brittish word <etym lang="br">Gwyl Awst</etym>,
signifying the Feast of August ;
or may come from <etym lang="la">Vincula</etym>,
that day being called in La&shy;
tin <term lang="la">Festum St. Petri ad vincu&shy;
la</term>. It is called Lammas day,
because on that day after
Mass, the Priests in former
times were wont to begin to
gather their Tithe Lambs.
But Doctor Hammond, in his
Resolution to six Queries, 


</page>

<page sig="y8v">
pag.465. derives it from the
Saxon <emend err="Hlapm&oelig;p," source="errata"></emend><etym lang="sx">lafmess</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> e&shy;
loaf-mass, or bread-mass; so
named, as a Feast of thanks&shy;
giving to God for the first
fruits of the Corn, and seems
to have been observed with
bread of new wheat; and ac&shy;
<emend err="cordinly">cordingly</emend> it is a usage in some
places for Tenants to be
bound to bring in wheat of
that year to their Lord, on or
before the first of August . O&shy;
thers say, It is a corruption
<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">of the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Lien-Mess</etym>, which
relates to Vincula.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lamina(n)">Lamina ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a thin
plate of any mettal, most com&shy;
monly such as Sculpters use
to engrave upon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lampas(n)">Lampasse orLampreyes,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a disease in the mouth of a
horse or beast ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Lampas</etym>)
so called, because it is cured
by burning and cutting away
with a hot iron, as it were sea&shy;
red away with a Lamp or
light. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lanarious(a)">Lanarious (<etym lang="la">lanarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to wool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lanciferous(a)">Lanciferous (<etym lang="la">lancifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
beares a lance, a demilan&shy;
cer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lancepesade(n)">Lancepesado orLancepre&shy;
sado (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Lance-pessade</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that commands over ten
Souldiers, the lowest Of&shy;
ficer in a foot Company.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="land-cape(n)">Landcape,</form> <xpln lang="en">an end of land
that stretcheth further in&shy;
to the Sea then other parts
of the Continent therea&shy;
bouts.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "land," n., 10.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Landgrave(n)">Landgrave orLands&shy; 
grave (Belg. <etym lang="bl">Landtgrave,
Landegraef; landt</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">terra</term>,
and <etym lang="bl">grave</etym> or <etym lang="bl">graef</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">comes</term> q.
<term lang="la">Comes terr&aelig; vel regionis ab Im&shy;
peratore dono dat&aelig;</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Earl or
Count of a Province, where&shy;
of in Germany there are
four.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Langraviate(pn)">Langraviate,</form> <xpln lang="en">that Region
or Country, which belongs
to the Landgrave, such is that
of Hessia in Germany.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="landloper(n)">Landloper (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> <etym lang="bl">Lands&shy;
looper</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Vagabond, or a
Rogue that runs up and down
the Country. Bac. Hen.7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="landskip(n)">Landskip ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Pater&shy;
gon, Paisage or By-work,
which is an expressing of the
Land, by Hills, Woods,
Castles, Valleys, Rivers, Ci&shy;
ties, &amp;c. as far as may be
shewed in our Horizon. All
that which in a Picture is not
of the body or argument
thereof is Landskip, Parergon,
or by-work. As in the Ta&shy;
ble of our Saviors passion, the 
picture of Christ upon the
Rood (which is the proper
English word for Cross) the
two theeves, the blessed Vir&shy;
gin Mary, and St. John, are
the Argument: But the City
Jerusalem, the Country about,
the clouds, and the like, are
Landskip. El. Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="langued(a)">Langued,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heral&shy;
dry, as Langued Gules, whose
tongue is red, from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">langue</etym>, a tongue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="languid(a)">Languid (<etym lang="la">languidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">faint,
weak, feeble, sick, of little e&shy;
stimation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Laodicean(a)">Laodicean,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to

under Pope Silvester, and not
about the year 364 under Li&shy;
berius; as by some affirmed,
and is called the Laodicean
Council.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lapise(v)">Lappise,</form> <xpln lang="en">a tearm of hunt&shy;

mouthes in the Liam or
string, or a Greyhound in his
course.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lapse(n)">Lapse (<etym lang="la">lapsus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fall, sli&shy;
ding, or a slip. In our Laws
it is a slip or departure of a
right of presenting to a void
Benefice, from the original
Patron, neglecting to pre&shy;
sent within six moneths to
the Ordinary; For we say
that Benefice is in lapse or
lapsed, whereunto he that
ought to present, hath omit&shy;
ted or flipped his opportu&shy;
nity, An.13. Eliz. ca.12, &amp;c.
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laqueary(n)">Laqueary (<etym lang="la">laquear</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the roof
of a Chamber vaulted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="larceny(n)">Larceny (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Larcin</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> theft)</form> <xpln lang="en">is defined
by West. part.2. Symb. tit.
Inditements, to be theft of
personal Goods or Chattels in
the owners absence; and in
respect of the things stoln,
it is either great or smal.
Great Larceny is, when 


</page>

<page sig="z1v">
the things stolne, though
severally exceed the value of
twelve pence, and Petit Lar&shy;
ceny is, when the goods stoln
exceed not the value of
twelve pence. Hitherto Mr
West but he differs from
Bracton lib.3. Tract.2. ca.32.
numb.1. Of this see more in
Stawnf. Pl. Cor. l. I. ca.15, 16,
17, 18, 19.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lare(n)">Lare (<etym lang="la">Lar</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Idols that
the Heathen worshipped,
sometimes they were taken
for Gods of the fields or ways,
sometimes for home-Gods or
domestical; A familiar spirit.
Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="largesse(n)">Largesse ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bounty, li&shy;
berality; handfuls of money
cast among people, or a Do&shy;
native bestowed on Soul&shy;
diers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="largisical(a)">Largisical (<etym lang="la">largisicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
bestows bountifully, that
gives frankly, liberal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="largiloquent(a)">Largiloquent (<etym lang="la">largiloquus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of words, that is liberal of
his tongue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="largitional(a)">Largitional (<etym lang="la">largitionalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an Officer that looks to the
bestowing of gifts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="larval(a)">Larval (<etym lang="la">larvalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;
ing to a night-spirit, goblin
or masker, haggish, ghastly,
dreadful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lasciviate(v)">Lasciviate (from <etym lang="la">lascivia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to play the wanton, to give
ones self to lust and leche&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lask(n)">Laske (<etym lang="la">laxitas intestino&shy; 
rum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the looseness of the in&shy;
ward guts, the wherry-go&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lassitude(n)">Lassitude (<etym lang="la">lassitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">weari&shy;

Green-sickness. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="last(n)">Last ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a bur&shy;
den in general, as also parti&shy;
cularly a certain weight; for
as we say a Last of Herrings,
so they sayEin last Corns,
Last Wines, &amp;c. thence
comes Lastage, which see in
 <xref>Lestage</xref>. A Last of Herring
contains ten thousand. An.
31. Ed.3. Stat.2. ca.2. A Last
of Pitch and Tar, or of Ashes,
contains fourteen Barrels,
An.32. H.8 ca.4. A Last of
Hides An. I. Jac. ca.33 con&shy;
tains twelve dozen of Hides
or Skins. Cowel. A Last of
Corn is ten Quarters. Dal&shy;
ton</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latebrous(a)">Latebrous (<etym lang="la">latebrosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is full of holes, and dens to
hide in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latent(a)">Latent (<etym lang="la">latens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lurking,
hiding, or lying hid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lateran(pn)">Lateran,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Popes
Pallaces in Rome, so called
from Lateranus, a Patrician of
Rome, whose house was gi&shy;
ven by Constantine to the Pope
and his Successors, and so con&shy;
tinues.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lateral(a)">Lateral (<etym lang="la">lateralis, &agrave; latus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to the side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laterality(n)">Laterality,</form> <xpln lang="en">the side&shy;
being, or being side-ways of
a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lateritious(a)">Lateritious (<etym lang="la">lateritius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
made of brick, or like
brick.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="z2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latifolious(a)">Latifolious (<etym lang="la">latifolius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath broad leaves, or
folio's.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lation(n)">Lation (<etym lang="la">latio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a carrying,
bearing, ordaining; giving.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latirostrous(a)">Latirostrous (from <etym lang="la">latus</etym>
and <etym lang="la">rostrum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath a
broad or flat bill; Latrostrous
birds are Ducks, Geese, and
such like. Dr. Brown, useth it
in that sence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latitancy(n)">Latitancy (from <etym lang="la">latito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
lying hid, a lurking. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latitat(n)">Latitat (the third person
of <etym lang="la">latito</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> he lies hid)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
name of a Writ, whereby all
men in personal actions are
called originally to the Up&shy;
per Bench. Fitzh. nat. br. fol.
78. M. And it hath the name
from this, because in respect
of their better Expedition, a
man is supposed to lurk, and
therefore being served with
this Writ, he must put in se&shy;
curity for his appearance at
the day, for Latitare, <term lang="la">est se
malitiose occultare animo frau&shy;
dandi creditores suos agere volen&shy;
tes</term>. L. Fulcinius See more
in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latitude(n)">Latitude (<etym lang="la">latitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">breadth,
largeness, wideness, prolong&shy;
ing in speech. 

In Geography the latitude
of a place is the Arch of a
Meridian contained between
the Equinoxial, and the Ze&shy;
nith of the place that was
given. The latitude of a Star
is the Arch of a great circle,
drawn by the Poles of the
Ecliptic, contained between 
the Star, and the Ecliptic.
Wrights Use of the Sphear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latomy(n)">Latomy (<etym lang="la">latomia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Quar&shy;
ry of stones.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Latonian(a)">Latonian (<etym lang="la">latonius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to Latona, on whom
Jupiter (say the Poets) be&shy;
got Apollo and Diana hence
we use Latonian lights, for
the Sun and Moon (Latona' s
children.)</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lator(n)">Lator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a bearer, a
Porter a Messenger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latrocination(n)">Latrocination (<etym lang="la">latrocinatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
theft, robbery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lavatory(n)">Lavatory (<etym lang="la">lavatorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
place or vessel to wash in, a
Font or Conduit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lauds(n)">Lauds (<etym lang="la">laudes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">praises.
But more particularly, they
are a part of those prayers u&shy;
sed by Roman Catholicks,
and called our Ladies Office,
or the Priests Office, which is
between the Nocturns and the
houres . They are called Lauds
from the Psalms, <term lang="la">Laudate Do&shy;
minum de c&oelig;lis, &amp;c.</term> and <term lang="la">Lau&shy;
date Dominum in sanctis ejus, &amp;c.</term>
therein contained, &amp;c. Vide 
<xref>Primer</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laudanum(n)" lexeme="ladanum(n)" lexeme="labdanum(n)">Laudanum,Ladanum, or
Labdanum (Lat. <etym lang="la">ladanum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sweet smelling transparent
Gum, gathered from the
leaves of Cistus Ledon a shrub,
the sweetest is best (Dioscor)
of which they make Roman&shy;
ders, it smels like wine min&shy;
gled with Spices. It is hot
and dry, and being annoin&shy;
ted on the head with oyl
of Myrtles, it strengthens
the skin, and keeps hair 


</page>

<page sig="z2v">
from falling off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laudative(a)">Laudative (<etym lang="la">laudativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to commendati&shy;
on, wherein praise is contai&shy;
ned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lave(v)">Lave (<etym lang="la">lavo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to wash, to
rinse, to purge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Laverna(pn)">Laverna,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Goddess to
whom Theeves were wont to
supplicate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lancelot(pn)">Launcelot orLancelot
 (from <etym lang="la">lancea</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fleam or Chy&shy;
rurgeons Instrument which is
used in letting blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lancepesade(n)">Launcepesado.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Lan&shy;
cepesado</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lavolta(n)">Lavolta ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dance so
called; also a course held in
sayling or wandring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laureate(a)" lexeme="laureated(a)">Laureate orLaureated
 (<etym lang="la">laureatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">crowned with Lau&shy;
rel, wearing a Garland of
Bayes. Laureated letters, were
Letters bound up in Bay
leaves, which the Roman
Generals sent to the Senate,
when their contents were
Victory and Conquest newly
by them obtained.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laurel(n)">Laurel (<etym lang="la">laurus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bay tree,
In ancient Rome the Trium&shy;
phers used to be crowned
with Laurel, and the Captain
that triumphed carried a
branch of it in his hand. So
is the Triumph of Scipio Af&shy;
ricanus described by Appianus
Alexandrinus, Plin. lib.6. The
Laurel was consecrated to A&shy;
pollo, because that on mount
Parnassus there grew great
store of them. It is said to have
the property not to be hurt by
lightning, and therefore the 
Cock resorts thereto in
Tempests, as Natural Histo&shy;
rians testifie; conform to
which, is the Imprese of
him, who caused to be pain&shy;
ted a Cock under a Laurel
with this Motto, <term lang="la">SIC EVITA&shy;
BILE FULMEN</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lauriferous(a)">Lauriferous (<etym lang="la">laurifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that beareth Bays or Law&shy;
rel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="law of arms(n)">Law of Arms (<etym lang="la">jus mi&shy;
litare</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Law that gives pre&shy;
cepts and rules how rightly
to proclaim War, to make
and observe Leagues and
Truce, to set upon the enemy,
to retire, to punish offenders
in the Camp, to appoint
Souldiers their pay, to give
every one dignity to his
desert, to divide spoils in
proportion, and such like:
for further knowledge where&shy;
of read those that write de Ju&shy;
re Belli.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laws of the twelve tables(n)">Laws of the Twelve Ta&shy;
bles.</form> <xpln lang="en">See in <xref>Tables</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lawless man(n)">Lawlessman,</form> <xpln lang="en">is he <term lang="la">qui est
extra legem</term>, an Out-law. Bract.
l.3. tract.2. ca.11. num. I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="law of Marque or Mart(n)">Law of Marque or Mart:</form> <xpln lang="en">
This word is used 27 Ed.3.
Stat.2 . ca. 17. and grows
from the German word
<etym lang="gr">March</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">limes</term>, a bound or
limit. And the reason of
this appellation is, because
they that are driven to this
Law of Reprizal, take the
Goods of that people (of
whom they have received
wrong and can get no or&shy;
dinary Justice) when they 


</page>

<page sig="z3r">
can catch them within their
own Territories or Precincts.
See <xref lexeme="reprisal">Reprizal</xref> and <xref>Marque</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="law merchant(n)">Law Merchant,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Pri&shy;
viledge or specal Law, differ&shy;
ing from the Common Law
of England, and proper to
Merchants, and summary in
proceeding, An.27. Ed.3.
Stat.8. 9. 19. and 20. An.13.
Ed. I. Stat.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lawing of dogs(n)">Lawing of Dogs.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See
Expeditate</xref>. Mastiffs must be
lawed every three years. Crom.
Jurisd fo.163.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laxation(n)">Laxation (<etym lang="la">laxatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an easing,
releasing or freeing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laxity(n)">Laxity (<etym lang="la">laxitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">looseness,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lazer(n)">Lazer (so called of Laza&shy;
rus, spoken of in the Gospel)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a poor man full of soars and
scabs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lazule(n)">Lazule (<etym lang="la">lazulus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a blewish
stone, a kind of marble, of
which they make the colour
Azure, it is sometimes also
used in Physick, and is in ope&shy;
ration hot and dry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lazzareto(n)">Lazzareto ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hos&shy;
pital for sick folks, a Pest&shy;
house, Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="league(n)">League (Ital. and Span.
<etym lang="it">legua</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">leuca</etym> from the
Gr. <etym lang="gr">leucos</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> white, because
they did in old time, pitch
white stones at every leagues
end from the City.)</form> <xpln lang="en">The
difference of miles in several
Countries is great, but it
will be enough to know, that
the Italian and English are
reckoned all for one (though
some hold the Italian to be 
the lesser) and four of these
make a German mile, two a
French league, three and
somewhat more a Spanish
league; the Swedish or Da&shy;
nish mile consists of five
English miles, and some&shy;
what more; A league at Sea
is usually held to be three
English miles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leander(n)">Leander,</form> <xpln lang="en">a young man of
Abidos who was in love with
Hero.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="licanomancy(n)">Licanomancy (<etym lang="la">licanoman&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of divination by
water in a Bason.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lectisternium(n)">Lectistern (<etym lang="la">lectisternium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
was the solemn Ceremony of
trimming and setting out
a bed, not for repose, but
repast, according to the
ancient manner; wherein
they laid the Images of their
Gods, reared upon Bol&shy;
sters and Pillowes; The
principal whereof was that in
the honour of Jupiter at the
Epulum Jovis, <emend err="wherepon">whereupon</emend> Jupiter
was laid; Juno and Minerva
sitting on either side by him.
Livie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lector(n)">Lector ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Reader.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leero(n)">Leero,</form> <xpln lang="en">corruptly from
Lyra, is a way of tuning,
or playing on the Viol,
different from that of Al&shy;
phonso .</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "lyra," 5.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leet(n)">Leet,</form> <xpln lang="en">Is otherwise cal&shy;
led a Law day, Smith de Re&shy;
pub. Angl. lib.2. ca.18. This
Court in whose Mannor soe&shy;
ver it is kept, is accounted the
Kings Court, and is common&shy;
ly held every half year, &amp;c. 


</page>

See more in Cowel, and Kitchin
fol.6.</xpln></wordentry>

The Popes Embassador hath
most usually this title.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legatary(n)">Legatary (<etym lang="la">legatatius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legend(n)">Legend (from <etym lang="la">lego</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wri&shy;
ting; also the words that are
about the edge of a peece of
coyn. The golden Legend, so&shy;
called, is a book of the lives of
Saints.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legerdemain(n)">Legerdemain (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Legier

Pocus tricks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legible(a)">Legible (<etym lang="la">legibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legiferous(a)">Legiferous (<etym lang="la">legifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legion(n)">Legion (<etym lang="la">legio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Army or
Band of men. At first Ro&shy;
mulus his Legion consisted of
3000 footmen, and 300 horse.
after of 4200 foot, and 300
horse, and after that 5000
foot, and 300 horse. Liv6
38. 7.31. Veget.2.6. Isid.9.3.
saith, a Legion consisted of
6000 armed men, which
number it seldom or never <emend err="ex">ex&shy;</emend>
ceeded, as it appears by <emend err="Si"> Si&shy;</emend>
gonius, de jure Rom. l. I. cap15.
The Romans did very seldom
inroll into their universal Ar&shy; 
my, above four Legions, and
in an ordinary Legion, ten Co&shy;
horts, every Cohort contain&shy;
ing three Maniples, every <emend err="Ma">Ma&shy;</emend>
niple two Centuries, every
Century 100 Souldiers Godw.
pag.175.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legionary(a)">Legionary (<etym lang="la">legionarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or pertaining to a Legion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentiginous(a)">Lentiginous (<etym lang="la">lentiginosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is full of freckles, or pim&shy;
ples like Lentils.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentil(n)">Lentil (<etym lang="la">lens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
smal pulse, growing in hot
Countries, round and flat, of
colour sometimes black, some&shy;
times white, and sometimes 


</page>

<page sig="z4r">
brown; being boyled but
once, they loose the belly, but
at the second boyling in ano&shy;
ther water, they are of a bin&shy;
ding nature, being then good
to stop the bloody Flux, or
any looseness of the body.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentiscine(a)">Lentiscine (<etym lang="la">lentiscinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to the Mastick
tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lent(pn)">Lent,</form> <xpln lang="en">A time of fasting
for forty four daies next be&shy;
fore Easter; so called from
Lenct monat, or length
moneth, by which name the
old Saxons called March,
because then the dayes began
first to exceed the nights in
length, and they call this
fast, Lent, from the name of
the said moneth, because the
most part of it falls with&shy;
in the compass of this moneth.
Verst. 

This Fast of Lent was first
commanded to be observed in
England by Ercombert, the
seventh King of Kent before
the year of our Lord, 800. Sir
Rich. Bakers Chron. fol.7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentisk(n)">Lentisk (<etym lang="la">lentiscus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tree
growing in divers hot Coun&shy;
tries, which bears the no&shy;
table Gum called Mastick;
The Leaves and Bark of this
Tree stop all looseness and
issues of blood whatsoe&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentor(n)">Lentour (<etym lang="la">lentor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a clammy
or glewish humour. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentous(a)">Lentous (<etym lang="la">lentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">soft, ten&shy;
der, pliant, or limber, idle,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lenvoy(n)">Lenvoy (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
voy</etym> or <etym lang="fr">L' envoy</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a message or
sending; Also the conclusion
of a Sonnet or Ballade, in
a short Stanza, by it self, and
serving often times, as a de&shy;
dication or repetition of the
whole. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leonine(a)">Leonine (<etym lang="la">leoninus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
pertaining to a Lion, Lion&shy;
like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lepid(a)">Lepid (<etym lang="la">lepidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">neat,
pleasant, jocund, of a good
grace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lepidity(n)">Lepidity (<etym lang="la">lepiditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">delecta&shy;
bleness, or good grace in
speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leporean(a)" lexeme="leporine(a)">Leporean 
Leporine (<etym lang="la">leporinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or pertaining
to an Hare; delicate, delici&shy;
ous</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leprosity(n)">Leprosity,</form> <xpln lang="en">full of the Le&shy;
prosie or leprous disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lernean(n)">Lernean (<etym lang="la">lerneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

Not found in OED but cf. "lern&aelig;an," a..
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lesion(n)">Lesion (<etym lang="la">l&aelig;sio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hurting or
annoying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lesbian rule(n)">Lesbian Rule or Square;</form>
<xpln lang="en">The Lesbians were such per&shy;
fect work-men, that they
made Rules and Squares by
their work, and not their work
by the rule, and hence the
phrase. Dub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lastage(n)">Lestage or Lastage (from
the Saxon word<etym lang="sx">Last</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">o&shy;
nus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a custom chal&shy;
lenged in Fairs and Mar&shy;
kets for carrying of things.
Rastals Exposition of words:
Or a custom challenged in
Cheapings or Fairs. Saxon
in the description of England 


</page>

<page sig="z4v">
ca. I. Lastage. An.27. R.2.
ca.18. seems to be the bal&shy;
lance, or ballast of a Ship,
and so the French use it.
Fleta terms it Lesting, say&shy;
ing, <term lang="la">Quid significat acquie&shy;
tantiam <emend err="Lestagis" source="errata">lestagii</emend></term> . lib. I. ca.47.
Lesting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lessee(n)" lexeme="lessor(n)">Lessee,Lessor,</form> <xpln lang="en">terms in
our Law; Lessee is he to
whom the Lease is made
for term of years, for life or
at will, and the Lessor, he
that Leaseth, or makes a
Lease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lesses(n)">Lesses ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the dung
of a ravenous beast, as Bear
Bore, or Wolf.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lessian(a)">Lessian,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
Lessius, a modern Writer,
who wrote a Rule of se&shy;
vere temperance, where&shy;
in hee prescribed Fourteen
Ounces every day, whence
that is called a Lessian Di&shy;
et.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lestrigon(n)">Lestrigons (<etym lang="la">lestrigones</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kind of Giants or fierce
people of Sicily, often men&shy;
tioned in the Odysses of Ho&shy;
mer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lethal(a)">Lethal (<etym lang="la">lethalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mor&shy;

lent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lethality(n)">Lethality (<etym lang="la">lethalitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mor&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lethargy(n)">Lethargy (<etym lang="la">lethargus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
disease contrary to Frensy;
for, as Frensy is caused by
hot Humours inflaming the
Brain; Lethargy is by cold
flegmatick Humours op&shy;
pressing it in such sort, that 
the Patient can do nothing
but sleep, whereby he be&shy;
comes forgetful, with loss
(in a manner) of Reason,
and all the Senses. This dis&shy;
ease is by some called the
Drowsy evil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lethargic(a)">Lethargick (<etym lang="la">lethargicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to, or sick of that
disease; also dull, sleepy, for&shy;
getful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lethe(pn)">Lethe ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a feigned
river of Hell, the water
whereof being drunk, cau&shy;
seth forgetfulness of all that
is past; Hence it is used
for Oblivion or forgetful&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lethean(a)">Lethean (<etym lang="la">letheus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">for&shy;
getful: Also Lethean (from
<etym lang="la">L&aelig;theus</etym>) deadly, mortal, pesti&shy;
ferous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lethiferous(a)">Lethiferous (<etym lang="la">lethifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bringeth death, dead&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="letifical(a)">Letifical (<etym lang="la">l&aelig;tificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="levant and couchant(a)">Levant, andCouchant,</form> <xpln lang="en">

gers Cattle have been fee&shy;
ding and lying down in ano&shy;
ther mans ground, or have
remained there a good space

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="level-coil(n)">Level-Coile (from the

or remove the Buttock)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
when three play at Tables,
or other Game, where onely
two can play at a time, and
the loser removes his But&shy;
tock and sits out, and there&shy;
fore called also Hitch-But&shy;
tock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leviathan(pn)">Leviathan (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a great

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Levites(pn)">Levites (<etym lang="la">levit&aelig;, ex filiis
Levi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">those of the Tribe
of Levi in the old Law,
which Tribe was particular&shy;
ly allotted for the Church,
and whose maintenance was
from the Tenths or Tithes,
the First fruits, Offerings,
and Sacrifices of the people;
Josh. 18.17. The Priest&shy;
hood of the Lord was their
inheritance . There were of
them four kinds. First, Pu&shy;
nies or Tirones, who from
their child-hood to the five
&amp; twentieth year of their age,
learned the duties of their Of&shy;
fices. Secondly, Graduates,
who having spent four years
in the study of the Law,
were able to answer and op&shy; 
pose in it. Thirdly, Licen&shy;
tiates, who did actually ex&shy;
ercise the Priestly function.
And Fourthly, Doctors (Rab&shy;
bins they used to call them)
who were the highest in de&shy;
gree. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lexicon(n)">Lexicon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dictio&shy;
nary of words; a vocabula&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="libel(n)">Libel (<etym lang="la">libellus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">literally
signifies a little book, but by
use it is the original Decla&shy;
ration of any Action in the
Civil Law. An.2. H.5. ca.3.
and An.2. Ed.6. ca.13. It
signifies also a defamatory
Scroll, or slanderous wri&shy;
ting or invective of any
man cast abroad, or other&shy;
wise unlawfully published,
but then for distinction sake
it is called an infamous Libel,
 <term lang="la">famosus libellus</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="libertinage(n)">Libertinage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Epicu&shy;
rism, sensuality, licentious&shy;
ness, dissoluteness. Mr.
Mount.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="libertine(n)">Libertine (<etym lang="la">libertinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
free-man, one first-born or
made free. Also one of
loose life, or careless of Reli&shy;
gion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="libertivism(n)">Libertiuism,</form> <xpln lang="en">Libertinage,
or Libertinity (<etym lang="la">libertinitas</etym>)
the state of him that of Bond 


</page>

<page sig="z5v">
is made free; licenciousness,
Epicurism. In Divinity it is
thus defined; Libertinism is
nothing else, but a false liber&shy;
ty of belief and manners,
which will have no other de&shy;
pendence but on peculiar fan&shy;
cy and passion. It is a strange
monster, whereof it seems Iob
made description under the
figure of Behemoth ; as much to
say, as a creature, composed of
all sorts of beasts, of which
it bears the name. Iob.40.
Causs. in his Conclusion of Max&shy;
ims.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Libethrides(pn)">Libethrides ( <term lang="la">Dict. &agrave; Libe&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Libitina(pr)">Libitina,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Goddess of

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Libra(pn)">Libra ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the ballance,
or one of the twelve Signs of
the Zodiack . This Sign is so
called, because when the Sun
enters it, the day is in equal
ballance with the night, not
one longer or shorter than a&shy;
nother. Virg. Geor. I. 

 <term lang="la">Libra die, somnique pares ubi fecerit horas</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lycanthropy(n)">Licanthropy (<etym lang="la">licanthropia</etym>,
or <etym lang="la">lycanthropia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a frenzy, or
melancholly, wherewith some
being haunted, think them&shy;
selves turned into Wolves,
fly the company of men, and
hide <emend err="themseves">themselves</emend> in caves and
holes, howling like Wolves.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="licentiate(a)">Licentiate (<etym lang="la">licentiatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that hath licence in any Fa&shy; 
culty; most used in divinity.
In the Common Law, an Utter
Barrister. Before he comes to
be a Licentiate in the Civil
Law he must have studied five
years: Also the third degree
among the Levites . See <xref>Le&shy;
vites</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="licentious(a)">Licentious (<etym lang="la">licentiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rash,
unruly, dissolute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lich-fowl(n)">Lich-fowls,</form> <xpln lang="en">the reputed
unlucky night Raven, so cal&shy;
led, from the Sax.Lic orLich,
<expan type="">id est</expan> a dead corps; Country
people by corruption call
these Scritch-Owles, or Lich&shy;
Owls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lictor(n)">Lictor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sergeant,
The Lictors or Sergeants a&shy;
mong the ancient Romans
were twelve in number, who
with bundles of Rods and
Axes, always went before
the Magistrates; so called (as
Fastus thinks) <term lang="la">quod fasces vir&shy;
garum ligatos ferant</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liege(n)">Liege (from the Ital.<etym lang="it"> liga</etym>.
<expan type="">id est</expan> a Band, League or Obliga&shy;
tion)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a word borrowed
from the Feudists, and hath
two several significations in
our Common Law; some&shy;
times being used for Leige
Lord, An 34 and 35. H.8. ca 1. 
sometime for Leigeman, An 
10. R.2 ca. I. and An II. ejus&shy;
dem, ca.1. Leige-Lord, is he
that acknowledges no Supe&shy;
rior. <term lang="la">Duarenus in commentar.
de consuetud. Feudorum.</term> ca 4.
nu.3. Liege-man, is he that
owes ligeancy to his Liege
Lord . See more of this in
Skene<term lang="la"> de verborum significatione
verbo Legiantia</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ligeancy(n)">Ligeancy (<etym lang="la">ligeantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is such
a duty or fealty as no man
may owe or bear to more then 
one Lord. See Skene num.4.
This word is used in the sta&shy;
tutes of our Realme as the
Kings Liege people, An.14. H.8.
ca.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ligation(n)" lexeme="ligature(n)">Ligation

ing, also the
tongue-tying in children e&shy;
<emend err="pecially">specially</emend>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ligament(n)">Ligament (<etym lang="la">ligamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
ty-band or string: especially
the insensible string that is
seated either within or near
a joynt, and is termed by our
Anatomists, a Ligament, and
is between a Cartilage and a
Membrane . Reads Anat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ligneous(a)" lexeme="lignean(a)">Ligneous

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lignum vitae(n)">Lignum vit&aelig; ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
wood called Aloes, by the
Arabians Calambuco, which for
its sweet savor is valued at its
weight in pure Silver, as be&shy;
ing not onely serviceable for
the pompous Funerals of
Princes, but also for Bathes.
And with the Indians (among
whom it grows) is held an
unparalleld medicine for ma&shy;
ny grievous and dangerous
maladies. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="league(n)">Ligue ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a League or

ties which have been divided,
an Agreement made, or Alli&shy;
ance contracted.</xpln></wordentry>
