linnen thread, lint, a lent for
a wound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lincoln's Inn(pn)">Lincolns-Inn,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the
four Inns of Court, and in
antiquity next the Temples;
it was for the most part pur&shy;
chased of Sir Edw. Suliard of
Essex, by the Benchers and
Gentlemen of that House;
But it took denomination from
Sir H. Lacy Earl of Lincoln; to
whom part of this House was
given by Edw. the first. See
more in Stow. Chron. p.1072.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lineament(n)">Lineament (<etym lang="la">lineamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
feature or proportion of the
face or of any other part, a
line drawn in painting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linear(a)">Linear (<etym lang="la">linearis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to a line, lineal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linguacity(n)">Linguacity (<etym lang="la">linguacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
talkativeness, verbosity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linigerous(a)">Linigerous (<etym lang="la">liniger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
beareth flex or linnen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liniment(n)">Liniment (<etym lang="la">linimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
thin ointment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linosity(n)">Linosity (<etym lang="la">linositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">abun&shy;
dance of flax.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lintearious(a)"><emend err="Lintearions">Lintearious</emend> (<etym lang="la">lintearius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to linnen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lintel(n)">Lintel (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Lin&shy;
teau</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the head-peece of a
door, the upper posts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lippitude(n)">Lippitude (<etym lang="la">lippitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
propping, waterishness or
bloodshot of the eyes, bleared&shy;
ness of the eyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lipothymy(n)">Lipothymie (<etym lang="la">lipothymia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fainting or sounding, when the
vital spirits being suddenly op&shy;
pressed, a man sinks down as if
he were dead. Hist. of K. Cha.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquable(a)">Liquable (<etym lang="la">liquabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which
may melt, or become soft, or
liquid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquation(n)">Liquation (<etym lang="la">liquatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a melting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquefaction(n)">Liquefaction (<etym lang="la">liquefactio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a melting, or making soft,
or liquid, a dissolving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquescency(n)">Liquescency,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquid(a)">Liquid (<etym lang="la">liquidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">soft,
moist, wet, pure, clear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquid(n)">Liquids (<etym lang="la">liquid&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are
four in number (viz.) L, M,
N, R, and are called liquids,
 <term lang="la">Quia pronunciatione liquescunt
ore</term>, &amp;c. because in the pronun&shy;
ciation they melt as it were, or
become liquid in the mouth,
and are more softly uttered,
then other Consonants. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liquidate(v)">Liquidate (<etym lang="la">liquido</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
moist, or clear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litany(n)">Litany (<etym lang="la">litania</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a supplica&shy;
tion or prayer, the Gr. from 


</page>

<page sig="z7r">
whence the word is derived,
importing as much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="literality(n)">Literality (from <etym lang="la">litera</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lear&shy;
ning, knowledge of letters. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="literature(n)">Literature (<etym lang="la">literatura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">learn&shy;
ing, cunning, grammer, know&shy;
ledge of letters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litargy(n)" lexeme="lithargy(n)">Litargy orLithargy (<etym lang="la">li&shy;
thargyros</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">white lead, or the
foam that <emend err="risieth">riseth</emend> from lead
when it is tried. It is cold of
operation, and used by Chy&shy;
rurgeons in oyntments, and
Plaisters, being of a gentle,
drying, cleansing, and binding
nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lithomancy(n)">Lithomancy (<etym lang="la">lithomantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
divination by casting Pibble
stones, or by the Load-stone,
whereby as Tretzes in his Chi&shy;
liads, delivers, Helenus the
Prophet foretold the de&shy;
struction of Troy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lithotomy(n)">Lithotomy (<etym lang="la">lithotomia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ma&shy;
sons Work-house, or quarry;
also a Prison. D. Br. useth it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lithontriptic(a)">Lithontriptick (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&lambda;&#x03af;&delta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">lapis</term>, &amp; <etym lang="gk">&tau;&rho;&iota;&pi;&tau;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym> <term lang="la">, tri&shy;
tus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that wears, breaks, or cuts
a stone. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litigation(n)">Litigation (<etym lang="la">litigatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a strife,
a suit or pleading.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litigious(a)">Litigious (<etym lang="la">litigiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">conten&shy;
tious, ful of strife, wrangling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litispendence(n)">Litispendence (<etym lang="la">litispenden&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the hanging of a suit, till
it be tried or decided.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litoral(a)" lexeme="litorean(a)">Litoral 
Litorean 
 (<etym lang="la">litoralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or 
belonging to
the Sea-side or shore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liturate(v)">Liturate  (<etym lang="la">lituro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to blot
with the pen, to dash out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liturgy(n)">Liturgy (<etym lang="la">liturgia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">publick
service, or a form of publick
prayers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liturgic(a)">Liturgick (<etym lang="la">liturgicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to such a Liturgy;
ministerial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="livery(n)">Livery (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Liur&eacute;e</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hath
three significations. 1. It is u&shy;
sed for a Nobleman or Gen&shy;
tlemans Cloth, or colors worn
by his Servants or Followers,
with Cognizance or without.
A.1.R.2. c.7. &amp; A.20. ejus. c. I, 2.
A.8. H.6. c.4. A.8.Ed.4. c.3, &amp;c.
2. It signifies a delivery of pos&shy;
session. 3 It is the Writ which
lies for the heir to obtain the
possession or seizin of his lands
at the Kings hands, which see
in Fitzh nat. br. fol.155.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Livery of Seisin(n)">Livery of Seisin (<etym lang="la">delibera&shy;
tio seisin&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a delivery of pos&shy;
session of a Land or Tenement,
or other things. West, par. I.
Symbol. lib.2. Sect.169. cals
this a Ceremony in the Com&shy;
mon Law, used in the convey&shy;
ance of Lands or Tenements,
&amp;c. where you may see the
usual form of it set down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="livid(a)">Livid (<etym lang="la">
lividitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">black and 
blew, wan, of the colour of
lead; also malitious, envious,
backbiting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lividity(n)">Lividity (<etym lang="la">lividitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">blew&shy;
ness, the colour appearing up&shy;
on a stroak, a dead earthly
leaden colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="livor(n)">Livor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a black and
blew mark in a body, coming
of a stroke or blow; also black&shy;
ness of the eyes coming of hu&shy;
mors; also spite, envy, malice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lixiviated(a)">Lixiviated (from <etym lang="la">lixivia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or like to, or washed with
Lee or Lye made of ashes.
Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="z7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lixor(n)">Lixor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Water&shy;
bearer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lizard(n)">Lizard (<etym lang="la">lacertus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
beast much like our Euet, but
without poyson, breeding in
Italy and other hot Coun&shy;
trys; whose dung is good to
take away spots in the eie, and
clear the sight; And its head,
being bruised and laid to,
draws out thorns or any thing
sticking within the flesh, Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lob(n)">Lobbe,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a great kind of
North-Sea-fish. An.31. Ed.3.
Stat.3. ca.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="local(a)">Local (<etym lang="la">localis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to a place. It signifies in
our Common Law, as much
as tyed or annexed to a place
certain. Example, the thing
is local and annexed to the
freehold. Kitchin fol.180.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="located(a)">Located (<etym lang="la">locatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">placed,
set in a place, built.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lohoch(n)" lexeme="loch(n)">Loche,</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Lohoch.</xref></xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "loch".
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lococession(n)">Lococession (from <etym lang="la">locus</etym> and mo&shy;
 <etym lang="la">cedo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a giving place. Dr. Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="locomotion(n)">Locomotion (<etym lang="la">locus</etym> and
 <etym lang="la">tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a moving or stirring from
one place to another. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loculament(n)">Loculament (<etym lang="la">loculamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a place of bords made with
holes for Pigeons or Conies;
a Coffin for a Book; also the
several places wherein the
seeds lye, as may be seen in
Poppy heads. Dr. Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="locuplecity(n)">Locuplecity (<etym lang="la">locuplecitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
abundance of wealth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="locuplete(a)">Locuplete (<etym lang="la">locuples</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rich,
wealthy, well stored.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="locust(n)">Locust (<etym lang="la">locusta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
flying insect or Fly (which
the French term <etym lang="fr">Cigale</etym>) of 
which we have none in Eng&shy;
land. Read Dr. Brown in his
Vul. Err. lib.5. ca.3. There
were divers kinds of these;
some hurtful and venemous,
others comodious for meat.
Matth.3.4. His meat was lo&shy;
custs, which some conceive
to be the tops of hearbs and
plants.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodemanage(n)">Lodemanage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the hire
of a Pilot for conducting
a Ship from one place to ano&shy;
ther, and comes from the
Dutch <term lang="du">Loot</term> <expan type="">id est</expan> lead, and in
the same Dutch, the Pilot is
called<term lang="du">Lootsman</term> or <term lang="du">Piiloot</term>,
the man of lead, or casting
out his lead to save the Ship
from danger. Min. 


Chaucer makes this word to
signifie the skill or art of Na&shy;
vigation.<xref> See Pilot.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodestar(n)">Lodestar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Star that guides
Marriners, the north star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodestone(n)">Lodestone (<etym lang="la">magnes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stone
of the colour of rusty iron,
which hath an admirable ver&shy;
tue not only to draw iron to
it self, but to make any iron
on which it is rubbed, to draw
iron also. This stone is found
in the Indian Sea, and in the
Country Trachonitis; and
is of greatest use in Navigati&shy;
on; for by it Saylors find
out the certain course of their
Voyage, the needle in the
compass, tempered herewith,
still standing directly towards
the North and South. Bull.
Read more of the nature and
properties of this stone in
Dr. Br. Vul. Err. l.2. c.2. &amp; 3.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="z8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="locution(n)">Locution (<etym lang="la">locutio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a saying,
speaking, or word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodeworks(n)">Lodeworks,</form> <xpln lang="en">is one of the
works belonging to the Sta&shy;
naries in Cornwal, for which
see Cam. Br. in the title Cornw.
See <xref>Stremeworks</xref>.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "lode" 6.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="log(n)">Log,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name of an He&shy;
brew measure, as the Sextarius
Atticus was among the
Greeks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logarithm(n)">Logarithmes (<etym lang="la">logarithmi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a term in Mathematicks sig&shy;
nifying numbers, which be&shy;
ing fitted to proportional
numbers retain always equal
differences. Wing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logic(n)">Logick (<etym lang="la">logica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Art of
Logick, the Art of reasoning
or disputing. Logick (as my
Lord Bacon says) professes the
preparation and contrivance
of Aids and Forces for the un&shy;
derstanding. Arts Logical,
or Intellectual are four in
number. Art of Enquiry or
Invention; Art of Examina&shy;
tion or Judgement; Art of
Custody or Memory; and
Art of Elocution or Traditi&shy;
on, &amp;c. See more in his Ad&shy;
vancement of Learning. fol.218.
and 219.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logician(n)">Logician (<etym lang="la">logicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
skil'd or learned in the Art of
Logick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logism(n)">Logism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the due and judici&shy;
ous<emend err="nnderstanding"> understanding</emend> of a thing,
formerly considered and e&shy;
steemed of, according to rea&shy;
son. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logist(n)">Logist (<etym lang="la">logista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
causeth presidents or notable
sayings to be registred, a caster 
of accounts. The Logists a&shy;
mong the Athenians (saith
Harpocration) were ten men,
elected out of the Tribes, to
whom all such as had ended
their Office of Magistracy
(within 30 days of their Au&shy;
thorities expiration) were to
render an account of all such
occasions, as they had then
administration of in their
charge; They not onely kept
account of the moneys, but
likewise of all other matters
that appertained to the Kings
revenue, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logistic(n)">Logistick (<etym lang="la">logistice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Art of counting or reckon&shy;
ing, the practice of Arithme&shy;
tick, or that part thereof
which contains Addition,
Substraction, Multiplication,
and Division.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logographer(n)">Logographers (<etym lang="la">logographi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Lawyers Clerks, they that
write Pleas and Causes in the
Law, or Books of Accompt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="logomachy(n)">Logomachy (<etym lang="la">logomachia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a contention in words, strife
about words, a verbal alterca&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lohoch(n)">Lohoch, orLoch</form> <xpln lang="en">a Phisi&shy;
cal word, and is a thick Syr&shy;
rup, or other soft substance,
or confection, which must
not be swallowed, but suffer&shy;
ed to melt of it self in the
mouth, that so it may gently
slide down, and thereby have
the more vertue against dis&shy;
eases of the Brest, Lungs and
throat. Culpepper says, it is an
Arabick word, &amp; simply sig&shy;
nifies a thing to be licked up.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="z8v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lollards(pn)">Lollards (<etym lang="la">Lollardi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect
that abounded here in Eng&shy;
land in the dayes of Edw. the
Third, and Henry the Fifth.
An.2. H.5. ca.7. of these read
Stows Annals pag.425. Trite&shy;
mius in his Chronicle deduces
the name from one Gualter
Lolhard, a German, as the
first author of that Sect, living
about the year 1315. And
Chilian says, <term lang="la">Lollardus fuit A&shy;
lexianus Monachus &amp; Lollardus
quoque dicitur H&aelig;reticus Valden&shy;
sis</term>, Cow. 

These Lolhards were off&shy;
springs of the Wiclephists, they
began in time of P. Innocent
the sixth, and Charls the
fourth Emperor of that name,
(says another Author.) See
their Tenets in B. Spotiswoods
hist. of Scot. fol.61.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lombardeer(pn)">Lombardeer,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Usurer or
Broaker, so called from the
Lombards, a people of the hi&shy;
thermost part of Italy, who
were great Usurers, they were
called Lombards alias Longo&shy;
bards, from their long Beards
which they were wont to
wear. Hence our word Lum&shy;
bar, which signifies refuse
Housholdstuff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lombard(pn)">Lombard,</form> <xpln lang="en">is also for the
same reason, used for a bank
for Usury or Pawns; Hence
Lumbardstreet, which is still
full of Goldsmiths, and Mo&shy;
nyers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loam(n)">Lome (<etym lang="la">lutum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">durt, mud,
or morter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="longevity(n)">Longevity (<etym lang="la">long&aelig;vitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
long or old age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="longanimity(n)">Longanimity (<etym lang="la">longanimi&shy;
tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">long suffering, patience,
forbearance. In divinity it
is thus defined; Longanimity
is an untired confidence of
mind, in expecting the good
things of the life to come.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="longiniquity(n)">Longinquity (<etym lang="la">longinquitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
long distance of place, length
of time, continuance, long
lasting, or long life.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="longitude(n)">Longitude (<etym lang="la">longitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
length of place, time or any
other thing. The Longitude
of a Star is nothing else but
the arch of the Ecliptick,
contained between the begin&shy;
ing of Aries, and the circle of
the stars latitude. In Geogra&shy;
phy the longitude of a place is
the arch of the Equinoctial
Circle contained between
two Meridians, whereof one
goeth by the Canary Islands,
and the other by the place
that is given. Wrights Use of
the Sphear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodesman(n)">Lootsman,</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Pilot</xref> and <xref lexeme="lodemanage">
Lodomenage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loquacity(n)">Loquacity (<etym lang="la">loquacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
much talking, babling, or
prating.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Loray law(n)">Loray-Law.</form> <xpln lang="en">In the Me&shy;
morials of the Chamber of
Accounts in France, is found
an Article to this effect, <term lang="la">Si
homines de Loraico vadia du&shy;
elli temere dederint</term>, &amp;c. If a
combate were once accepted,
and after by consent of the
Lord of the Fee, were taken
up, each of the parties should
pay 2s.6d. But if it were per&shy;
formed, then the party van&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="aa1r">
quished should forfeit 112 s.
And upon this custom grew
the French proverb which
they use, when any man has
had a hard and unjust Judge&shy;
ment, saying, he was tried by
the Law of Loray or Bern, <term lang="fr">ou
le batu paye l'amende</term>, where
he that is beaten gives the re&shy;
compence. Sir. W. Ral.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurdan(n)">Lordane.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref>Lourdain</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lore(n)">Lore ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">skil or learn&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loricated(a)">Loricated  
 (<etym lang="la">loricatus </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ar&shy;
med with a coat of mail or
brigandine. Dr. Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lorimer(n)">Lorimers  
 (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Lormier</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
An. I. <expan type="">read</expan> 2. ca. 12. is one of
the Companies of London,
that makes bits for horse
bridles, spurs, and such like
smal iron-work; The name
seems to be taken <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">Lorum</etym>, and is elsewhere
written Loriners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="losenger(n)">Losenger ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a flatterer
or lyar. Chaucer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lotion(n)">Lotion (<etym lang="la">lotio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a washing or
rinsing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="louvre(n)">Loover orLovert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a tun&shy;
nel on the top of a roof or
house (from the Fr. (<etym lang="fr">l'overt</etym>)
<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">apertus</etym>) a place made open
to let out the smoak on the
top of the house; so we say
pound overt, a pound open at
the top, that men may see
the Cattle impounded and
cast in sustenance to them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurdan(n)">Lourdain orLordane (Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Lourdin</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sottish, dunce-like,
heavy, dull, blockish. But
Sir Rich. Baker in his Chro&shy;
nicle fo. 18. gives this etimo&shy; 
logy of it; when the Danes 
Lorded it here in England, the
English were fain to till and
ear the ground, whilst the
Danes sate idle, and eat the
fruit of their labours, and yet
in every place, for very fear,
were called Lord-Danes,
which afterwards became a
word of derision, when one
would signifie, a Lazy Lub&shy;
ber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Louvre(pn)">Louvre ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the royal
seat of the Kings of France
in Paris, famous throughout
all Europe. The front (which
is of masonry, enriched with
pillars, frizes, architraves,
and all sort of architecture
with excellent symmetry and
beauty) was began by Francis
the first; finished by Hen. his
son, and afterwards increased
by Francis the second, Charls
the ninth; Last of all made
the wonder of all other
works, by that long and
beautiful Gallery, the work
of Hen. the fourth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lozenge(n)">Lozenge ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little square
Cake of preserved flowers,
hearbs, &amp;c. also a quarry of a
glass window, or any thing of
that form.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lubrefaction(n)">Lubrefaction</form> <xpln lang="en">a making slip&shy;
pery, stirring or quick. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lubrical(a)" lexeme="lubricious(a)">Lubrical 
Lubricious  (<etym lang="la">lubricus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">slippery de&shy;
ceitful, incertain; stirring,
wanton, lascivious.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lubricity(n)">Lubricity (from <etym lang="la">lubri&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">slipperiness, incertain&shy;
ty, wantonness, incontinen&shy;
cy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lucerus(n)">Lucerus</form> <xpln lang="en">a beast almost as

lour between red and brown,
mingled with black spots, its
skin is a very rich Fur. An.24.
H.8. ca.14.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luciferian(a)">Luciferians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of He&shy;

Author, Lucifer, Bishop of
Calaris in Sardinia in time of
Pope Liberius, and the Em&shy;
peror Constantius, about the
year of Christ 365. they held
the soul of man was propa&shy;
gated out of the substance
of his flesh, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lucina(pn)" lexeme="Juno(pn)" lexeme="Diana(pn)">Lucina, Juno and Diana</form> <xpln lang="en">so
called, because they ruled the
travel of women, and helped
them in that business.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lucrative(a)">Lucrative (<etym lang="la">lucrativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lucrece(pn)">Lucrece,</form> <xpln lang="en">a chaste woman;

Tarquinius Collatinus, who slew
her self, because Sextus Tar&shy;
quitus had ravished her.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luminaria(pn)">Luminaria ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Feast of light; The Feast of
Christs Nativity or <emend err="Chirstmas">Christmas</emend>,
was so called in the Western
or Latin Church: because
they used many lights and
candles at this Feast; or ra&shy;
ther, because Christ the light
of all lights, that true light,
then came into the world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luminous(a)">Luminous (<etym lang="la">luminosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ful

tain time of the moon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lunacy(n)">Lunacy,</form> <xpln lang="en">that disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lupercal(a)">Lupercal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a place de&shy;
dicated to the God Pan, from
Lupa; because there a she
Wolf did nourish Romulus
and Remus. So the Sacrifices
and Playes dedicated to Pan
were called Lupercalia or lu&shy;
percal Sacrifices, and the
Priests of Pan (<term lang="la">luperci</term>) who
on the day of their Sacrifices,
ran up and down the City
naked, and stroak the hands
and bellies of women great
with child, with a Goats skin,
thereby to signifie both fruit&shy;
fulness and easie deliverance.
Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lupines(n)">Lupines (<etym lang="la">lupinum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little 
flat pulse, almost like a smal
bean, but much less and bit&shy;
ter in taste; They are not
very good meat, but are some&shy;
time used in Physick against
worms in children, and the
decoction of them takes a&shy;
way spots, and freckles of the
face. Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurdan(n)">Lurdane.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Lourdain</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurid(a)">Lurid (<etym lang="la">luridus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pale, wan,
black, and blew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luscition(n)">Luscition (<etym lang="la">luscitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dim&shy;
ness, pore-blindness of the
eyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lushburg(n)">Lushbrough,</form> <xpln lang="en">a base coyn,
in the dayes of Edward the
third.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lusion(n)">Lusion (<etym lang="la">lusio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a playing,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lustration(n)">Lustration (<etym lang="la">lustratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">com&shy;
passing, viewing or going a&shy;
bout on every side; a purg&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lustrifical(a)">Lustrifical (<etym lang="la">lustrificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath power to purge or make
holy, pertaining to purg&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lustrum(n)">Lustrum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Den or
Cave for wild beasts; a purg&shy;
ing by sacrifice; also the space
of fifty months, or five years.
The Romans sometimes kept
their account of time by these
Lustrums, which were so called
because they did once in every
five years revolution, <term lang="la">Lustra&shy;
re exercitum Romanum</term>, by sa&shy;
crifice purge the Roman Ar&shy;
my. Hence we use some&shy;
times, two Lustrums, for ten
years, three Lustrums fifteen
years, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="aa2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lutheranism(pn)">Lutheranism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the doct&shy;
rine or tenets of Martin Lu&shy;
ther, who (being an Augustin
Monk) forsook his Monasti&shy;
cal course of life, about the
year 1515. and from him
Lutherans took denominati&shy;
on : These differ from the
Calvinists, chiefly in main&shy;
taining consubstantiation in
the blessed Eucharist, with
omnipresence and eternal pre&shy;
destination, to be out of a
foreseen faith, and good
works, and not absolute;
which tenents are impugned
by the Calvinists . Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luteous(a)">Luteous (<etym lang="la">luteus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is
made of clay, loam, mud,
morter, earth; filth, mud&shy;
dy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lutulent(a)">Lutulent (<etym lang="la">lutulentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">miry,
durty, filthy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luxate(v)">Luxate (<etym lang="la">luxo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to put out
of joynt to loosen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luxation(n)">Luxation (<etym lang="la">luxatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a loo&shy;
sening or putting out of joynt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luxuriate(v)">Luxuriate (<etym lang="la">luxurio </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to ex&shy;
ceed, to be riotous or wan&shy;
ton, to grow rank.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luxurious(a)">Luxurious (<etym lang="la">luxuriosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
riotous, given too much to
pleasure, excessive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lycanthropy(n)">Lycanthropy (<etym lang="la">lycanthropia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a frenzy or melancholly,
which causeth the patient
(who thinks he is turned
Wolf) to fly all company, and
hide himself in dens and cor&shy;
ners.<xref> See Were-wolf</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lyceum(pn)">Lyceum,</form> <xpln lang="en"> Aristotles School
by Athens; Also Cicero' s
School, in his Mannor at Tus&shy;
culum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lymphatic(a)">Lymphatick (<etym lang="la">lymphaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
allayed or mixed with wa&shy;
ter; Also mad, furious, be&shy;
straught.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lydford law(n)">Lydford Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">is to hang
men first, and indite them
afterwards</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lyncean(a)" lexeme="lynceous(a)">Lyncean 
Lynceous  (<etym lang="la">lynceus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the
beast Lynx ; also quick-sighted,
from Lynceus one of the Argo&shy;
nauts, who was admired for
his quickness of sight. He
could see the new Moon, the
first day when it was in the
sign Aries, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lynx(n)">Lynx ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a spotted
beast like a Wolf, having a
<emend err="a"></emend> very perfect sight. This
beast breeds chiefly in the
Eastern Countries, and is of&shy;
ten found in the woods of Al&shy;
main and Sclavenia. Hence the
phrase of a Lynx-like-eye, for
one that's good and perfect
sighted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lypothamy(n)">Lypothamy.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref target="lipothymie"> See Lipo&shy;
thomy.</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lyric(n)">Lyrick (<etym lang="la">lyricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Poet
that makes verses to be sung
to the Harp. The best of these
among the Grecians was Pin&shy;
darus; and among the Latins,
Horace. Lyrick, taken adjective&shy;
ly, is pertaining to a Harp,
that playes on a Harp, or to
Lyrick verses, which the anti&shy;
ents applied to Songs and
Hymms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lyrist(n)">Lyrist (<etym lang="la">lyristes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Harper,
or one that sings to the
Harp. 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mac(pn)">MAc</form> <xpln lang="en">in Irish is as much
as Fitz in French, or as
Son, in English; as Mac-Willi&shy;
am, or Mac-Adam. <expan type="">id est</expan> the
Son of William, or the son of
 Adam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mahaleb(n)">Macaleb,</form> <xpln lang="en">the bastard Co&shy;
ral or Pomander; of whose
sweet and shining black ber&shy;
ries, chains, and bracelets are
made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macaronic(n)">Macaronique ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a con&shy;
fused heap, or huddle of ma&shy;
ny several things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macaroon(n)">Macarons ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">little Fri&shy;
ter-like buns, or thick Lo&shy;
zenges compounded of Sugar,
Almonds, Rose-water, and
Musk, pounded together and
baked with a gentle fire.
Also the Italian Mararoni,
lumps or gobbets of boiled
paste, served up in butter,
and strewed over with spice,
and grated cheese; a com&shy;
mon dish in Italy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Macedonians(pn)">Macedonians (<etym lang="la">Macedones</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
people of Macedonia, a large
Country of Europe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macellarious(a)">Macellarious (<etym lang="la">macella
rius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to the But&shy;
chers Row or Shambles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macellator(n)">Macellator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a But&shy;
cher.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macerate(v)">Macerate (<etym lang="la">macero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
lean; to mortifie, weaken,
bring down; also to allay, soak
or steep in liquor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Machiavelian(n)">Machiavelian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a subtil
Statesman, or cunning Poli&shy;
tician; So taken from Ni&shy; 
cholas Machiavel, Recorder of
Florence in Italy, whose Poli&shy;
ticks have poisoned almost all
Europe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="machevalize(v)">Machevalize orMachia&shy;
velianize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to practise Machia&shy;
velianism, or cunning subtil
policy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="machine(n)">Machine (<etym lang="la">machina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;
strument, an engine of War,
a frame, tool or device; a sub&shy;
til shift to deceive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="machinate(v)">Machinate (<etym lang="la">machinor</etym>, from
the Hebrew <etym lang="he">machane</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to de&shy;
vise or plot, to imagine or
contrive, to invent crafti&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macilent(a)">Macilent (<etym lang="la">macilentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lean,
thin, barren.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macritude(n)">Macritude (<etym lang="la">macritudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
leanness, barrenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macrocosmus(n)">Macrocosmus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
great world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="macrology(n)">Macrology (<etym lang="la">macrologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
prolixity in speaking; long
and tedious talk or speech, to
little or no purpose. It is a
figure among Rhetoricians;
As, <term lang="la">Vivat Carolus Augustus, &amp;
non moriatur</term>, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mactator(n)">Mactator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a killer or
murderer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maculature(n)">Maculatures (from <etym lang="la">macula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
blotting or waste papers.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maculate(v)">Maculate (<etym lang="la">maculo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to stain,
spot, or defile; to defame.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madidate(v)" lexeme="madify(n)">Madidate (<etym lang="la">madido</etym>) 
Madifie (<etym lang="la">madifacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to 
wet
or moisten, to make wet, to
wash or bath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madid(a)">Madid (<etym lang="la">madidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wet or
washed, moist, imbrued; also
drunken.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="aa3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madidity(n)">Madidity (<etym lang="la">madiditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">moi&shy;
sture, or being full of moist&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mador(n)">Mador ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">moisture; al&shy;
so sweat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madrigal(n)">Madrigal (Ital. <etym lang="it"> madrigali</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kind of song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magazine(n)">Magazine (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Magazin</etym> <term lang="la">quasi</term>
<term lang="la">mansio gaz&aelig;</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">lucus ubi gaz&aelig; &amp;
thesauri reponuntur</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a publick
Store-house or Ware-house,
most commonly appropriated
to appurtenances of War.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magdaleon(n)">Magdaleon (<etym lang="la">magdaleo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Langate, or long plaister like
a Rowler. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Magelianic Sea(pn)">Magelianick Sea,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called
from Ferdinando Magellanus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magi(n)">Magi,</form> <xpln lang="en">or the wise men of
the East.<xref lexeme="Balthasar"> See Balthazar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magician(n)">Magician (<etym lang="la">magus</etym>, a Persian
word primitively)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Persi&shy;
sians cal those Magos or Magi&shy;
cians, whom the Grecians call
 <etym lang="gr">Philosophos</etym>; the Latins, <term lang="la">Sapi&shy;
entes</term>; the Gauls, Druyds ; the
Egyptians, Prophets or Priests;
the Indians, Gymnosophists ;
the Germans, <term lang="gr">Die Pfaffen</term>;
we English, Wisemen, Wi&shy; 
sards, Cunning-men, South&shy;
sayers or Enchanters. Cham,,
otherwise called Zoraster,, King
of the Bactrians (who reigned
800 years after the siege of
Troy is said to be the first
inventor of Art Magick.
Pol. Vir Magia, among the
Persians, was taken for a
sublime sapience, and a Sci&shy;
ence of the harmony and
contents of universals in na&shy;
ture. Bac. And see Sir Wat.
Ral l. 1. f.171.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magic art(n)">Magick Art (<etym lang="la">magia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in
general, is wisdom, or con&shy;
templation of heavenly Sci&shy;
ences, and is two fold; Na&shy;
tural, which is lawful, and is
the ground of all true Phy&shy;
sick, and the occult wisdom
of nature, without which all
mans Reason and Knowledge
is Ignorance; The other is
Diabolical, superstitious and
unlawful, and is called Ne&shy;
cromancy : whereby men attain
to the knowledge of things by
the assistance of evil spirits.
Chym. Dict.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magistery(n)">Magistery (<etym lang="la">magisterium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
mastership, the rule or office
of a Master. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magistral(a)" lexeme="magisterial(a)">Magistral 
Magisterial  (<etym lang="la">magistralis</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to, or done by a Master or
Magistrate; masterlike, ar&shy;
tificial. In physick it relates
to a Plaister, Salve, or any
other thing invented for
cure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Magna Charta(pn)">Magna Charta,</form> <xpln lang="en">the great
Charter, contains a number
of Laws ordained the ninth
year of Hen. 3. and con&shy;
firmed by Edw. I. We have no
ancienter written Law then
this, which though it consist
of not above Thirty seven
Charters or Laws, yet is it of
such extent, as all the Law
we have is thought in some
sort to depend of it. Ho&shy;
linshed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnalia(n)">Magnalia ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">great
things to be wondred at. As
Magnalia Dei (mentioned Act.
2.11.) the great works of God.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnet(n)">Magnete (<etym lang="la">magnes, etis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
loadstone.<xref> See Lodestone</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnetic(a)">Magnetick (<etym lang="la">magneticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to the Lodestone,
or that which draws unto, or
attracts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnify(v)">Magnify (<etym lang="la">magnifacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make great account of, to ho&shy;
nor much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnificence(n)">Magnificence (<etym lang="la">magnificen&shy; 
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">stateliness, sumptuous&shy;
ness, high atchievement, great
performance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Magnificat(pn)">Magnificat,</form> <xpln lang="en">part of the
Even-song among the Ro&shy;
manists, or the song of the
Blessed Virgin Mary Luk 1.46.
beginning thus <term lang="la">Magnificat <emend err="a">a&shy;</emend>
nima mea</term>, &amp;c. My soul doth
magnifie our Lord, &amp;c. At say&shy;
ing of which, they use to stand
up, as being a Canticle or
Song of joy, for the delivery
whereof, the posture of stan&shy;
ding is most proper. 

To correct magnificat (an
English Proverb) signifies to
attempt to amend Scripture,
or that which is beyond cor&shy;
rection.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnifico(n)">Magnifico ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a great
or honorable Personage : The
chief Noblemen of Venice are
by a peculiar title, called Mag&shy; 
nifici, or Magnifico' s. And the
Rectors of the Academies in
Germany are honored with
the same Title.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnificent(a)" lexeme="magnifical(a)">Magnificent 
Magnifical  (<etym lang="la">magnificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that atchiev&shy;
eth worthy acts; noble, sump&shy;
tuous, acting great matters,
magestical.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magniloquy(n)" lexeme="magniloquence(n)">Magniloquy 
Magniloquence  (<etym lang="la">magni&shy;
loquen&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lofty manner of speak&shy;
ing, or a discourse of great
matters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magniloquent(a)">Magniloquent (<etym lang="la">magnilo&shy;
quus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that useth a stately
manner of speaking or write&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magnitude(n)">Magnitude (<etym lang="la">magnitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
greatness, largeness, noble&shy;
ness, valiantness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Magog(pn)">Magog</form> <xpln lang="en">(mentioned in
 Ezek.38.) Gog in the Hebrew
signifies (saith St. Hierom)
<term lang="la">tectum</term>, or a covering of a
house. And Pintus upon E&shy;
zekiel affirms, that by Gog is
meant Antichrist; For
(saith he) <term lang="la">Antichristus erit
Diaboli tegumentum sub specie
humana</term> ; that Antichrist shall
be the covering of the Devil
under humane form. He adds
that Magog, is as much to say
as Gog, the letter [M] being
an Hebrew Proposition and
imports as much as of or
from, so he takes Magog for
those people that follow An&shy;
tichrist. See more in exposi&shy;
tion of these two words in
Sir Wa. Ral Hist. of the World
lib. I. fo.136.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mayhem(n)" lexeme="maim(n)">Mahin orMaim (from 


</page>

<page sig="aa4v">
the Lat. <etym lang="la">mancus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a
corporal hurt, whereby a
man loseth the use of any
member, that is or might be
any defence to him in bat&shy;
tle. The Canonists call it
<term lang="la">Membri mutilationem</term>, as the
Eye, the Hand, the Foot,
the scalp of the head, the fore
tooth, or (as some say) any
finger of the hand. Glan&shy;
vile. lib.14. ca.7. And Ugo&shy;
linus de irregularitatibus, ca.4.
sect.3 4,5.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magonel(n)">Magonel,</form> <xpln lang="en">an instrument to
cast stones. Chauc.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mahumetism(pn)" lexeme="Mahumetanism(pn)">Mahumetism orMahu&shy;
metanism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Religion and
profession of Mahumet and
the great Turk; which see
in Alcoran, Mahumets Law&shy;
book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mahumetan(pn)">Mahumetan,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that pro&shy;
fesseth the Religion of Ma&shy;
humet</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maid Morian(pn)">Maid-Morian.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Mo&shy;
risco</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="majestative(a)">Maiestative (<etym lang="la">majestativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is full of majesty or ma&shy;
jestical.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mainour(n)">Mainour.Manour.Mei&shy;
nour orManer (from the
Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Manie&egrave;re</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> the Manner)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in our Common Law,
when a Theef, hath stoln
and is followed with Hue
and Cry, and taken with the
Manner, that is, having the
thing stoln about him, which
is called the Mainour ; And so
we say when we find one do&shy;
ing an unlawful act, that we
took him in the mainour or
manner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mainpernable(a)">Mainpernable</form> <xpln lang="en">(a Law
word, and) signifies bailable,
or that may be bailed, and
Mainpernors, are the Sureties
for one that is mainprized
to appear at a certain day,
&amp;c. yet Mr Manwood, I. part
For. Laws, pag.167. Makes a
difference between Bail and
Mainprize (viz.) that he
that is mainprised hath a grea&shy;
ter liberty, then he that is
bailed, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="major(a)">Major ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the grea&shy;
ter. The major proposition
of a Syllogism, See in <xref>Syllo&shy;
gism</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="majorate(v)">Maiorate (<etym lang="la">majoro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
greater.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="majoration(n)">Maioration,</form> <xpln lang="en">a making

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malachite(n)">Malachite (<etym lang="la">malachites</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malacissation(n)">Malacissation (<etym lang="la">malacissa&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malacia(n)">Malacy (<etym lang="la">malacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a calm,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Malaga(n)" lexeme="Malaga sack(n)">Malaga orMalaca Sack,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">so called from a City of that

where that kind of wine is
made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malady(n)">Maladie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sickness or
disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mallender(n)">Malanders,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in
horses, <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">from the Span.</class> (<etym lang="sp">mal
andar</etym>) <expan type="">id est</expan> to go ill, for so the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malediction(n)">Malediction (<etym lang="la">maledictio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">e&shy;
vil speaking, a curse, ban&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="aa5r">
ning, imprecation, execrati&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malefactor(n)">Malefactor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an evil
doer, an offender.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malefice(n)">Malefice (<etym lang="la">maleficium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
evil deed, an ill act, a shrewd
turn, hurt, displeasure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maleficiate(v)">Maleficiate (<etym lang="la">malefacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
do wrong, to offer abuse, to
do evil. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maletent(n)">Maletent,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Statute
called the Confirmation of the
Liberties of, &amp;c. An.29. Ed. I.
ca.7. is interpreted to be a
Toll of forty shillings for e&shy;
very sack of wooll. 

 Stow in his Annals p.461.
calls it a Maletot (from the
French <etym lang="fr"> maletoste</etym> or <etym lang="fr"> Maletote</etym>)
See also the Stat. <term lang="la">de Tallagio non
concedendo.</term></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malevolence(n)">Malevolence (<etym lang="la">malevolen&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ill-will, heart-burning,
spite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malignity(n)">Malignity (<etym lang="la">malignitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
