<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malleable(a)">Malleable (from <etym lang="la">malleus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
tractable, hammerable, which
may be wrought or beaten
with the hammer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malleated(a)">Malleated (<etym lang="la">malleatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
wrought or beaten with the
hammer or beetle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malkin(n)" lexeme="scovel(n)">Malkin, Maukin, or Sco&shy;
vel</form> <xpln lang="en">to make clean an oven (the
Italians call it <term lang="it">Scovola di forno</term>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> the broom or besome of the
oven) the Lat. is <term lang="la">Peniculus</term>,
or <term lang="la">Penicillus</term>, dim. a <term lang="la">pene</term>. <expan type="">id est</expan>
a tail; because they were in
times past, made of the tails 
of beasts, as now they are of
old clouts. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malmsey(n)">Malmesy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of wine
so called from Arvisium, a
promontory, in the Island
Chio, vulgarly called Marvi&shy;
sia or Malvisia, whence comes
the best of this sort of
Wine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maltesian(pn)">Maltesian,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Inhabitant
of the Island Malta, called in
Scripture Melita.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mamaluke(n)">Mamaluke,</form> <xpln lang="en">a light horse&shy;
man (in the Syrian and
Arabian tongues) The Ma&shy;
malukes were an order of
valiant horse-men in the last
Empire of Egypt. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mammeated(a)">Mammeated (<etym lang="la">mameatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath Paps and Teats,
or that hath great ones.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mammon(pn)">Mammon,</form> <xpln lang="en">according to
the opinion of St. Hierome
is a Syriac word, of the
singular number and mas&shy;
culine gender, signifying
riches, or the God of
Riches. Hierom. sup. Math. ca.
17. The Mammon of ini&shy;
quity, is expounded to be
riches unjustly detained from
them to whom it is due.
Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mammonist(n)">Mammonist (from <etym lang="la">mam&shy;
mon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">may be taken for a
worldling, or one that seeks
after riches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mahmudi(n)">Mammooda,</form> <xpln lang="en">a coyn a&shy;
mong the East Indians of
equal value with our shil&shy;
ling. Herb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manation(n)">Manation (<etym lang="la">manatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
flowing, or running, a trick&shy;
ling down.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="aa5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="man-bote(n)">Manbote,</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies a pe&shy;
cuniary compensation for
killing a man. Lambert in
his exposition of Saxon words
verbo, &AElig;stimatio. Of which
read Roger Hoveden also in the
latter part of his Annals, fol.
344. a b.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mancipate(v)">Mancipate (<etym lang="la">mancipo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
deliver possession, to give the
right to another, to sell for
money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mancipation(n)">Mancipation (<etym lang="la">mancipatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a manner of selling before
witnesses, with sundry cere&shy;
monies, &amp;c. so called &agrave; manu
captione, from taking that
which is sold into ones hands
or possession.<xref> See Emanci&shy;
pate</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manciple(n)">Manciple (<etym lang="la">manceps</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ca&shy;
ter or one that in Colledges
or Hospitals buyes victuals
and common provision into
the house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mancus(n)">Mancuse (<etym lang="la">mancus&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of the
ancient pence (which weigh&shy;
ed about three pennies of our
money) thirty (as Alfric
Arch Bishop of Canterbury, in
his Saxon Grammer, notes)
made a Mancus, which some
think to be all one with a
Mark ; for that Manca, or
Mancusa is translated in anci&shy;
ent Books, by Marca ; and
Manca (as appears by an old
fragment) was <term lang="la">quinta pars un&shy;
ci&aelig;</term>. These Mancuse or Man&shy;
cus were reckoned both in
gold and silver. For about
the year of our Lord 680 Ina
King of the West Saxons, as
we read in Malmsbury, enfor&shy; 
ced the Kentish men to re&shy;
deem their peace at thirty
thousand Manca' s of gold. In
the notes upon Canutus Laws.
I find this difference, that
Mancusa was as much as a
Mark of silver, and Manca 
was a square peece of gold
commonly valued at thirty
pence. Cam Rem. fo.181.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mandate(n)">Mandate (<etym lang="la">mandatum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
commandement, a message,
commission, or any thing
that one is commanded to
speak or do. In our Com&shy;
mon Law it is a commande&shy;
ment judicial of the King or
his Justices to have any thing
done for the dispatch of Ju&shy;
stice, whereof you shall see
diversity in the table of the
Register judicial. Verbo, Manda&shy;
tum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mandatary(n)">Mandatary (<etym lang="la">madatarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
he to whom a commandement
or charge is given; or he
that comes to a Benefice by a
Mandamus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mandible(a)">Mandible (<etym lang="la">mandibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">eat&shy;
able, or that may be eaten;
and</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mandible(n)">Mandible (<etym lang="la">mandibula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Jaw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mandilian(n)" lexeme="mandrage(n)">Mandilian 
Mandilion
from the Fr. (<etym lang="fr">Mandil</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Man&shy;
dille</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a loose Cassock, such
as Souldiers use to wear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mandrake(n)" lexeme="mandrage(n)">Mandrake  orMandrage
(<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&mu;&#x1f71;&nu;&delta;&rho;&alpha;</etym> . <expan type="">id est</expan> a
Den or Hole, because it useth
to grow about Dens or
Caves)</form> <xpln lang="en">a strange plant bear&shy;
ing yellow round apples, the
root of it is great and white 


</page>

<page sig="aa6r">
like a Radish root, and is de&shy;
vided into two or more parts,
growing sometimes like the
legs of a man. This root, e&shy;
specially the bark of it, is
extreamly cold and dry, even
to the fourth degree. It is
therefore very dangerous to
receive inwardly, for that the
least quantity too much, will
quickly kill a man. Chyrur&shy;
geons use to steep this root
in wine, and give it to be
drunk by such as they must
cut, saw, or burn in any part,
for its cold operation causeth
sleep, and maketh the body
insensible for a time. See
the confutation of many false
conceptions concerning this
plant Mandrake, in Dr. Br. Vul.
Er. l.2. ca.6. 

Mandrakes, lovely or ami&shy;
able, so in the Hebrew;
The Greek translates them
Apples of Mandragoras or Man&shy;
drake Apples ; they were such
things as gave a smel, Gen.30.
14. Cant.7.13. Wilson</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manducable(a)">Manducable (from <etym lang="la">Man&shy;
duco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">eatable, that may be
chewed or eaten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manducation(n)">Manducation (<etym lang="la">manduca&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a chewing or eating.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maundy Thursday(pn)">Mandy <emend err="Tursday">Thursday</emend>.</form> <xpln lang="en"> See in
<xref lexeme="day">Day</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mangonize(v)">Mangonize (<etym lang="la">mangonizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
polish, paint, or trim up a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mangonism(n)">Mangonism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the craft of
pampering, trimming or set&shy;
ting out saleable things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maniable(a)">Maniable (from <etym lang="la">manus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be managed by the 
hand, tractable. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maniac(a)">Maniack (<etym lang="la">maniacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mad,
frantick, brain-sick, wild&shy;
headed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Manichees(pn)">Manichees,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of He&shy;
reticks so called from one
Manes a Persian the first broa&shy;
cher of that Heresie. They
held a fatal necessity of sin&shy;
ning, &amp;c. with other dam&shy;
nable Tenents. This Manes,
affirmed himself to be both
Christ and the Paraclet too,
and sent out his twelve Dis&shy;
ciples about the world, to
spread abroad his heretical
Dogms, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manicle(n)">Manicles (<etym lang="la">manic&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hand&shy;
Fetters, or Gives wherewith
Prisoners are bound by the
hands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manifesto(n)">Manifesto ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an open
or publick declaration, most
commonly of some Prince or
Commonwealth, concerning
publik matters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maniple(n)">Maniple (<etym lang="la">manipulus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
gripe, a handful, a bundle;
But more particularly, it is a
Fannel or Scarf-like orna&shy;
ment worn about the left
Wrist of a sacrificing Priest.
Also a file of ten Souldiers
under one Captain and Tent;
so called because their hand&shy;
strokes in fighting went to&shy;
gether. Thom. or because
they fought <term lang="la">sub eodem mani.
pulo f&oelig;ni</term> (an handful of hay
being used at that time instead
of a flag.) Ovid. 


</page>

<page sig="aa6v">
 <term lang="la">Pertica suspensos pendebat longa maniplos,
Unde maniplatis nomina miles habet</term> . 

But I find in some Authors,
that the ancient Roman Ma&shy;
niple, consisted of 200 Soul&shy;
diers. See <xref>Legion</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manipular(a)">Manipular (<etym lang="la">manipularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to a band of men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manna(n)">Manna ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">man, or the
dew of heaven; a delicate
food, wherewith God fed
the children of Israel, it fal&shy;
ling from heaven in manner
of a dew, white, and some&shy;
what like Coriander seed;
with which the Israelites liv&shy;
ed forty years in the Wil&shy;
derness, till they came to
the Borders of the Land
of Canaan. At first sending
hereof the people were in
such admiration that they
said to each other, manhu? <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">quid est hoc?</term> what is this?
which seems to be the cause
why it was afterward called
Manna. In physick it is ta&shy;
ken for a kind of dew, or
grained Manna, which, falling
in hot Countries upon trees
and hearbs before break of
day, doth there congeal, al&shy;
most like crums of white
bread, and is gathered, and
choycely kept, as a gentle
purger of choler; it is sweet
of taste, the best whereof
comes from Calabria, where
they gather it from the leaf
of the Mulberry tree. Nat.
Hist.165. It is also taken for
any sweet matter extract&shy; 
ed out of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mansion(n)">Mansion (<etym lang="la">mansio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tar&shy;
rying, a baiting, an abiding.
Also (as Bracton defines it.
lib. 5, cap.28. num.1.) it is
a dwelling consisting of one
or more houses without any
neighbor; And yet he grants
forthwith, that <term lang="la">Mansio Man&shy;
sioni possit esse vicinata</term>. I find
it most commonly used for
the Lords chief dwelling
house within his Fee, whe&shy;
ther it have neighbors ad&shy;
joyning or not, otherwise
called the capital Mesuage.
Bracton lib. 2. ca.26. or the
chief Mannor place. Mansio 
among the ancient Romans
was a place appointed for
the lodging of the Prince or
Souldiers in their journey
or march, furnished with
convenient entertainment by
the neighbors adjoyning, &amp;c.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manslaughter(n)">Manslaughter (<etym lang="la">homici&shy;
dium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the unlawful kil&shy;
ling a man without pre&shy;
pensed malice; As when
two, that formerly meant no
harm to one another, meet
together, and, upon some sud&shy;
den occasion falling out, the
one kills the other. West par.
2. Symb. titulo Inditements. Sect.
44. 

It differs from Murther,
because it is not done with
propensed or foregoing ma&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="aa8r">
lice; And from Chancemedly,
because it hath a present in&shy;
tent to kill; and this is Fe&shy;
lony, but admits Clergy for
the first time. Stawnf. pl. Cor.
lib. I. ca.9. and Britton ca.9.
It is confounded with mur&shy;
ther in the Stat.28. Ed.3.
ca.11.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mansuete(a)">Mansuete (<etym lang="la">mansuetus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gen&shy;
tle, courteous, meek, mild,
humble, tractable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mansuetude(n)">Mansuetude (<etym lang="la">mansuetu&shy;
do</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">gentleness, meek&shy;
ness, tractableness, humi&shy;
lity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manticulate(v)">Manticulate (<etym lang="la">manticulor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to do a thing closly, as to pick
a purse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manticore(n)">Manticore orManticorn, 
(Ital. <etym lang="it">Manticora</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a ravenous
and mankind Indian beast,
that hath three ranks, and
very sharp teeth, he hath a
face like a man, and body like
a Lyon. Plin. l.8 ca.21.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mantle(n)">Mantile orMantle (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>
<etym lang="la">Mantile</etym> <class type="etymlang" lang="br">Br.</class> <etym lang="br">Mantel</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of cloak which Souldiers in
times past used in winter,
a long hanging Cloak; It
is taken for a long robe, An.
24. H.8. ca 14. Now it is cal&shy;
led a Leaguer Cloak ; and
the Ladies have appro&shy;
priated the name to a kind
of Cloak which they do
wear.

Also a term in Herauldry,
and was anciently a kind of
Cloak or Mantle, encompas&shy;
sing the Coat armor, but
now is that flourish which 
proceeds from the Wreath 
and Helm, and descends ex&shy;
ternally on each side the Es&shy;
cotcheon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manual(a)">Manual (<etym lang="la">manualis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
fils the hand, that one may
fold, cast or carry in the hand.
it is also used substantively;
as</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manual(n)">aManual (<etym lang="la">manuale</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
snall portable volume, a book
which may bee carried in
ones hand. Manuel in the
Common Law is a thing
whereof present profit may
be made. Stawnf. Pr&aelig;rog.
fol.54.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manuary(a)">Manuary (<etym lang="la">manuarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">got&shy;
ten by handy labor, or that
fits the hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manucaption(n)">Manucaption (<etym lang="la">manucap&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a taking by, or with the
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manuduction(n)">Manuduction (<etym lang="la">manuductio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a leading or guiding by the
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manumission(n)">Manumission (<etym lang="la">manumissio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a deliverance out of Bondage,
an enfranchisement, a making
free.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manumit(v)" lexeme="manumise(v)">Manumit orManumisse
 (<etym lang="la">manumitto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to enfranchize,
to make a Slave or Bond&shy;
man free, which was in old
time thus. the Lord of
the Slave holding him by
the head, arm, or other
part, said before witness, I
will that this man go free,
and in so saying, shoved him
forward out of his hand. See
more of this in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="aa7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manutention(n)">Manutention (from <etym lang="la">manu
tenere</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a holding with the
hand. Lo Herb. H.8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maranatha(n)"><emend err="Maran atha">Maranatha</emend></form> <xpln lang="en">(<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">adventus
Dei, Deus venit, vel usque ad&shy;
ventum Domini</term>) a curse men&shy;
tioned in I Cor.16. Anathema
Maranatha, the third and
highest degree of Excommu&shy;
nication. Dr. Ham. Annat. fo.
600.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maravedi(n)">Maravedis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little Spa&shy;
nish coyn, whereof thirty four
make but the Royal, or six
pence sterling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marcasite(n)">Marcasite orMarquesite
 (<etym lang="la">marcasita</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stone participa&shy;
ting with the nature of some
mettal, yet in so smal quanti&shy;
ty, that the mettal cannot be
melted from it, but will vapor
away in smoak, the stone
turning to ashes; those Mar&shy;
chasites are commonly in co&shy;
lour like the mettal mixed
with them, whether it be
Gold, Silver, Brass, or any
other. Some affirm a Mar&shy;
chasite to be any stone out of
which fire may be strucken.
Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marcessible(a)">Marcessible (<etym lang="la">marcessibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
apt or easie to rot or putri&shy;
fie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Margrave(n)">Marcgrave orMartgrave
 ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a County or Earl
of the Borders, Frontiers
or Marches : with us a Mar&shy;
quess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marches(n)">Marches (from the Germ.
<etym lang="gr">March</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> a border, or from
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Marqu&eacute;</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> a Mark)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
borders, bounds or limits of
any place, Region, or Coun&shy; 
try, as between us and Wales,
or between us and Scotland .
An.24. H 8. ca 9.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marcheta(pn)">Marcheta,</form> <xpln lang="en"> Eugenins the
third King of Scotland did
wickedly ordain, that the
Lord or Master of the ground
or land, should have the first
nights lodging with every
married woman within the
same; which Ordinance was
afterwards abrogated by King
Malcome the third, who or&shy;
dained, that the Bridegroom
should have the sole use of
his own Wife, and therefore
should pay to the Lord, a
peece of money called Marca .
Hector Boetius lib.3. ca. 12.
Spotswoods Hist. fol 29. Mr.
Skene says, that Marcheta mu&shy;
lieris is the raid of the wo&shy;
man, or the first carnal co&shy;
pulation with her. p.93.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marchioness(n)">Marchionesse.</form> <xpln lang="en">the wife of
a Marquesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marcid(a)">Marcid (<etym lang="la">marcidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wi&shy;
thered, rotten, feeble, li&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marcidious(a)">Marcidious  (<etym lang="la">marcidiosus </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
very rotten, feeble, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marcionist(n)">Marcionists,</form> <xpln lang="en">old condem&shy;
ned Heretichs, so called of
their first Master Marcion, a
Stoick Philosopher, who
held a detestable opinion, that
Christ was not the Son of
God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marcor(n)">Marcor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rotten&shy;
ness, withering, pining a&shy;
way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mermaid(n)">Mare-maid,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Syren or
Sea-fish, having the upper
part to the Girdle like a wo&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="aa8r">
man, and the neather like a
fish.<xref lexeme="neread"> See Neriad</xref>,<xref lexeme="siren"> Syrens</xref>, and
<xref target="mermaid">Mer-maid</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nightmare(n)">Night Mare,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in
the night, that troubles one
so in his sleep, that he can
scarce fetch his breath. See <xref>
Incubus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marshal(n)">Mareshal.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Marshal</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="margaritiferous(a)">Margaritiferous (<etym lang="la">marga&shy;
ritifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that brings forth, or
hath plenty of pearls or Mar&shy;
garites, which are found in
the shel-fish, especially in
Oysters, the best are brought
out of India, yet they are al&shy;
so found in our English and
Flemish Seas, but not in such
perfection.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marginal(a)" lexeme="marginean(a)">Marginal (<etym lang="la">marginalis</etym>)
Marginean (<etym lang="la">margineus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to the brim or mar&shy;
gin, written in the mar&shy;
gin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marine(a)" lexeme="maritime(a)">Marine 
Maritan (<etym lang="la">marinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to, or
near the Sea; also strange, as
from beyond Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marital(a)">Marital (<etym lang="la">maritalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to marriage or Wed&shy;
lock, on the Husbands part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maritime(a)">Maritime (<etym lang="la">maritimus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to, or near the Sea;
wavering and changeable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mark(n)">Mark,</form> <xpln lang="en">is with us 13 s.
4 d. In Scotland but 13 d. ob.
<xref>See Marcheta</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marmorean(a)">Marmorean (<etym lang="la">marmorens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of marble, or that is like it in
colour, hardness, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maronean wine(n)">Maronean Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">wine
of such vertue and strength,
that if twenty times so much
water be put to it, it will still 
keep his vertue. And is so
called from Maronea or Marog&shy;
na a City of Ciconia where it is
made. Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maronites(pn)">Maronites</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called
from one Maron, who is men&shy;
tioned in the fifth Act of the
Constantinopolitan Council) a
sort of Christians who are
onely found in Mount Liba&shy;
nus in Syria, they have a Pa&shy;
triark, whose name is al&shy;
ways Peter, they were a limb
of the Jacobites ; but received
the Roman Catholick Religi&shy;
on in the Papacy of Clement
the <emend err="Eigth">Eighth</emend>, who sent them a
Catechism printed at Rome in
the Arabian language. Sands
p.172.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marque(n)">Marque (seems to be a
French word, signifying <term lang="la">no&shy;
tam, vel signum</term>, or else to come
from the Ger. <etym lang="gr">March</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">limes</term>,
or from <etym lang="br">Marc</etym>, a Britan word
(used not onely by the now
Welch, but also by the Armori&shy;
cans) signifying as much as
note or character)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in
the antient Statutes of our
Land, as much as Reprisals;
as An.4.H.5. c.7. Marques and
Reprizals are used as Synoni&shy;
ma ; and Letters of Marque
are found in the same signifi&shy;
<emend err="fication">cation</emend> in the same Chap&shy;
ter, &amp;c. Cow. See Law of
Marque.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marquetry(n)">Marquetry,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a most cu&shy;
rious work wrought of wood
of divers colours, and divers
sorts, into the shape of knots,
flowers and other devices
with that excellency of cun&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="aa8v">
ning, as they seem all to be
one peece, and rather the
work of nature then Art;
Chequer work, inlaid work.
Marquetrie, properly belongs
to Joyners, as Mosaique to
Masons and Stone-cutters,
though some Authors con&shy;
found them.<xref> See Mosaique</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marquis(n)">Marquess orMarquis
 (<etym lang="la">marchio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">by the opinion of
Hotom. comes of the Germ.
<etym lang="gr">March</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">limes</term>, signifying o&shy;
riginally as much as <term lang="la">custos li&shy;
mitis</term>, or <term lang="la">comes &amp; pr&aelig;fectus li&shy;
mitis</term>, &amp;c. These are with us
in honor and place next
Dukes. See Cassan&aelig;us de con&shy;
suetud. Burg. p.15. See <xref>Marc&shy;
grave</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marquisate(n)">Marquisate (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Marqui&shy;
sat</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Marquiship or Marquis&shy;
dome, the Territories of a
Marquess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marrow(n)">Marrow (Fr. <etym lang="fr">marauld</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fellow, a Knave, or Ras&shy;
cal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mars(pn)">Mars,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Heathen god
of war; taken for War or
Battle it self. Also one of
the seven Planets. See <xref>Sa&shy;
turn</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marshal(pn)">Marshal (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mareschal</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
with us there are divers Of&shy;
ficers of this name; but one
most noble of all the rest,
who is called Lord or Earl
Marshal of England, of whom
mention is made in divers Sta&shy;
tutes, as An. I. H.4. ca.7. and
14. and An.13. Ric.2. ca.2.
His Office consists especially
in matters of War and Arms,
as well with us, as in other 
Countries, whereof you may
read in de Lupanus Magistrati&shy;
bus Franci&aelig; lib. I. ca. Marschal&shy;
lus, &amp; Tilius lib.2. c. de Con&shy;
estabili, Mariscallo, &amp;c. The
next to this is the Marshal of
the Kings house, then the Mar&shy;
shal of the Justices in Eyre,
Marshal of the Upper Bench
Prison in Southwark, Mar&shy;
shal of the Kings hall, Mar&shy;
shal of the Exchequer, &amp;c.
whereof see Cowel. 

In every Regiment of Soul&shy;
diers there is a Marshal, whose
Office is to look to Prisoners
of War, and to put in exe&shy;
cution all sentences or orders
of the Council of War upon
offenders, &amp;c. In Francis the
firsts time there were but two
Lord Marshals of France, now
there are ten, who having
their several Provinces as&shy;
signed them by the King, ride
circuits, are present at all ge&shy;
neral musters, to see how mi&shy;
litary discipline is observed
in Garrisons, view the forti&shy;
fications and reparations of
Frontier Towns, the muni&shy;
tion and victual of Arsenals
and Store-houses, and lastly,
provide for the punishment
and suppression of all vagrant
and idle Rogues; And as
they (under the Constable)
command all Dukes, Earls,
Barons, Captains and Gens&shy;
darms; so may they neither
give battle, make Proclama&shy;
tion, nor muster any men,
without his commandement.
Cot. 


</page>

<page sig="bb1r">
In the old Saxon it was
Marscale; Mare being the
general name for a Horse, Male
and Female: andScale sig&shy;
nified a kind of servant, as
Scalco still does in Italian :
So thatMarscale (now
Marshal) was with our An&shy;
cestors <term lang="la">Curator equorum</term>, one
that had the charge of horses;
and in France a Farrier is still
called Mareschal. Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Margrave(pn)">Martgrave</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Marc&shy;
grave</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="martial(a)">Martial (<etym lang="la">martialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">born
under the Planets of Mars ;
warlike.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="martial law(n)">Martial Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the Law
that depends on the voyce of
the King, or the Kings Lieute&shy;
nant, or of the General or
his Officers in Wars. Smith
de Repub. Angl. l.2. c.3.<xref> See Law
of Arms</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manticore(n)">Martichore,</form> <xpln lang="en">a beast found
in the Indies, which hath
the face of a Man, and the
body of a Lyon, who coun&shy;
terfeits the sound of Flutes to
charm passengers, and then
entraps and kils them. Ctesias.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="martingale(n)">Martingale ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Thong
of leather, the one end where&shy;
of is fastened under the
chops of a horse, and the o&shy;
ther to the fore Girth be&shy;
twixt his fore legs to make
him rein well, and hinder him
from casting up his head, as
many young horses do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="martyrology(n)">Martyrologe (<etym lang="la">martyro&shy;
logium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a book that treats of
the Acts, names, and sufferings
of Martyrs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mascle in blazon(n)">Mascle in blazon (Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Macle</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a short Lozenge,
having a square hole in the
midst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="masculine(a)">Masculine (<etym lang="la">masculinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of the male kind, manly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mass(n)">Masse,</form> <xpln lang="en">comes <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">missa</etym>, but whether <term lang="la">missa</term>
be derived from the Hebrew,
or be a Latin word corrupt&shy;
ed, is no smal controversie;
They that derive it from the
Hebrew, conceive it comes
from <etym lang="he">&#x05d4;&#x05dd;&#x05e1; Missah</etym>, which
signifies an Oblation or Offer&shy;
ing; They that account it to
be a Latin word corrupted,
conceive the Fathers used it
instead of <term lang="la">missio</term> a sending away:
For in ancient times when
the Mass or publick service
was ended; and the commu&shy;
nicants addressed themselves
to be partakers of the holy
Eucharist, it was a custom to
send away the younger sort,
such as were not yet fully in&shy;
structed and catechized;
Hence <term lang="la">Missa</term> was taken for,
and signified a Sacrifice, an
Oblation or Offering. 

The old Saxons called all
holy days, Mass days ; because
they were obliged to hear
Mass on those days. <term lang="la">Christ. 
caveat</term> in part. See <xref>Lam&shy;
mas</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="massicot(n)">Massicot ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Oaker
made of Ceruse, or white
lead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mastication(n)">Mastication (<etym lang="la">masticatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
eating or chewing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mastic(n)">Mastick (<etym lang="la">mastiche</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a white
and clear gum, of a sweet sa&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="bb1v">
vor, and grows on the Len&shy;
tisk tree in the Island Chios.
It is temperate in heat, and of
a dry binding nature, where&shy;
fore it strengthens the Sto&shy;
mack, staies vomiting, and
stops any issue of blood. Some
use to rub their teeth with it,
as well to whiten them, as
to fasten such as are loose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="masticine(a)">Masticine (<etym lang="la">masticinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of,
or pertaining to, or of the
colour of mastick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mastigophorer(n)">Mastigophorer (<etym lang="la">mostigo&shy;
phorus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fellow worthy to
be whipped; also an usher,
who with whips removed the
people, where there was
much press.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mastruke(n)">Mastruke (<etym lang="la">mastruca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
garment that men of Sardinia
used, a Robe made of Wolves
or Deers skins, which the No&shy;
bles in old time were wont
to wear in Winter.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mateology(n)">Mateologie (<etym lang="la">mat&aelig;ologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
vain inquiry or over curious
search into high matters and
mysteries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mateeotechny(n)">Mateotechnie (<etym lang="la">mat&aelig;otech&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="materia prima(n)">Materia prima ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
first matter or subject of all
substantial forms, whereof all
natural bodies consist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="materiation(n)">Materiation (<etym lang="la">materiatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the selling of timber for build&shy;
ing, preparing of timber wood
for service in War. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maternal(a)">Maternal (<etym lang="la">maternus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a mother, on
the mothers side, motherly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maternity(n)">Maternity (<etym lang="la">maternitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
motherhood, the being a mo&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mathematical(a)">Mathematical (<etym lang="la">mathema&shy;
ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertaining to the
Mathematicks, or to a Mathe&shy;
matician.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mathematics(n)">Mathematicks (<etym lang="la">mathemati&shy;
ca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Sciences or Arts, taught
by demonstration, and com&shy;
prehend four of the libe&shy;
ral Sciences (vix.) Arithme&shy;
tick (wherein Alg&aelig;bra is com&shy;
prehended) Geometry, Musick,
Astronomy ; wherein the &AElig;&shy;
gyptians and Caldeans first
excelled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mathematician(n)">Mathematician (<etym lang="la">mathema&shy;
ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one skilful in the Ma&shy;
thematicks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mathurins(pn)">Mathurins,</form> <xpln lang="en">Friers so cal&shy;
led, being of the order of the
Holy Trinity, whose princi&shy;
pal institute is to redeem
poor Christian Captives from
the slavery of the Turk; to
which purpose they beg alms,
and depute a person of their
own to go to Argier &amp;c. to
carry the price of their re&shy;
demption.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matricide(n)">Matricide (<etym lang="la">matricidium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
killing of ones mother; if
from <etym lang="la">Matricida</etym>, then tis a
matricide, or one that kills
his own mother, as that cru&shy;
el Tirant and monster of men
Nero did.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matrice(n)">Matrice (<etym lang="la">matrix</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
place in the womb, where the
child is conceived. 

Matrices of Letters or Cha&shy;
racters, are those moulds or
forms, in which the Letters 


</page>

<page sig="bb2r">
and Characters which Prin&shy;
ters use are formed and fashi&shy;
oned by the Letter-Founder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matriculate(v)">Matriculate (Ital. <etym lang="it"> matri&shy; 
culare</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to register names. It
comes of <etym lang="la">mater</etym>, a mother;
For them are young Scollars
in an University said to bee
Matriculated, when they are
sworn and registred into the
Society of their Foster-mo&shy;
ther of Learning, the Uni&shy;
versity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matrimonial(a)">Matrimonial (<etym lang="la">matrimoni&shy;
alis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to ma&shy;
trimony, Marriage or Wed&shy;
lock.</xpln></wordentry>

morning prayers.</xpln></wordentry>

hastened, soon finished, made
ripe. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maturative(a)">Maturative (<etym lang="la">maturativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
apt to ripen, or helping to
ripeness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maturity(n)">Maturity (<etym lang="la">maturitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ripe&shy;

time, perfection.</xpln></wordentry>

belonging to the morning, or 
morning prayer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maugre(pp)">Maugre (Fr. <etym lang="fr">maulgr&eacute;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <etym lang="la">animo iniquo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in spight of
ones heart or teeth, against
ones will; As the wife, maugre
the husband. Littlet. fol.124.
that is, whether the husband
will or not.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maund(n)">Maund ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr:</class> <etym lang="fr">Mande</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Flasket, open Basket, or Pan&shy;
nier having handles; a Hand&shy;
basket.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maundy Thursday(pn)">Maundy Thursday (<etym lang="la">dies
mandati</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">This was the Eve
or day next before our Savi&shy;
ours crucifixion; and usually
called Holy Thursday. See more
in <xref lexeme="day">Day</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mausoleum(n)">Mausoleum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fa&shy;
mous Sepulchre, built by
Queen Artemisia in honor of
her Husband Mausolus King of
Caria, and accounted one of
the Worlds wonders, it be&shy;
ing twenty five Cubits high,
supported with thirty six cu&shy;
rious Pillars, and consisting
of 411 foot in circuit, all
of Marble, and of famous
sculpture, of which Mar&shy;
tial. 

 <term lang="la">A&euml;re nam vacuo pendentia Mausol&aelig;a,
Laudibus immodicis Cares ad astra ferunt</term> . 

The Mausol&aelig;a hanging in the Skie
The men of Caria' s praises deifie. 

Hence any sumptuous Mo&shy;
nument, Tomb, or Sepul&shy;
chre, is called a Mausole&shy;
um.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maxillary(a)" lexeme="maxillar(a)">Maxillary 
Maxillar  (<etym lang="la">maxillaris</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to 
the jaw-bone. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maxim(n)">Maxime (<etym lang="la">maxima</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
principle, a rule that may not
be denied, a proposition, an
Aphorism or principle in any
art. 


</page>

<page sig="bb2v">
Maxims in Law are the
foundations of the Law, and
the conclusions of reason,
which ought not at any time
to be impeached or impug&shy;
ned; As for example it is a
Maxim, that if a man have
issue two sons, by divers wo&shy;
men, and the one of them
purchase lands in Fee, and
die without issue, the other
brother shall never be his
Heir, &amp;c. with divers like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maximity(n)">Maximity (<etym lang="la">maximitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ex&shy;
ceeding greatness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mazar(n)">Mazar orMazer (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> 
Maeser orMaser, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Ma&shy;
ple, or the knob in the Ma&shy;
ple)</form> <xpln lang="en">a broad, flat, standing
cup to drink in; so called
because such cups are often
made of Maple or of the knots
of it: There is also a kind
of smal Cherries so called,
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maze(n)">Maze,</form> <xpln lang="en">an astonishment;
sometimes a device, like a La&shy;
byrinth, made in some Gar&shy;
dens in manner of a knot, with
so many intricate turnings,
that if one be once entred
into it, it is hard getting
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mead(n)">Mead (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class><etym lang="bl">Mede</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>
<etym lang="sx">Meed</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Hydromel</xref> and
 <xref>Bragget</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meander(n)">Meander (<etym lang="la">M&aelig;ander</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a ri&shy;
ver in Phrygia, now called
Madre or Palazzia, having
many turnings, &amp;c. Hence
any oblique turning or
crooked winding is called
Meander, and Meandrous is
used for crooked, or full of
turnings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mean(n)">Mean,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Tenor in Song
or Musick, it is an inner part
between the Treble and Base,
so called, because <term lang="la">medium lo&shy;
cum obtineat</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mease(n)">Mease,</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure of her&shy;
ring : Also taken by some for
A Mesuage or House, Kitch. fo.
239.<xref> See Mese</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="measure of length(n)">Measure of length,</form> <xpln lang="en">three
barly corns measured from
end to end make an inch,
twelve inches a foot, three
foot a yard, five yards and
a half a Rood, Pole, or Pearch,
forty Roods in length and
four in breadeth make an
Acre of land according to the
Statute, forty Roods in length
onely make a Furlong, eight
Furlongs an English mile;
which is 1760 yards, 5280
foot, 63360 inches, or
190080 barly corns. 

A step is two foot and an
half, the fadom seven foot,
an English Ell three foot, and
nine inches, which measures
differ from other Countries
that have a Geometrical mea&shy;
sure; As four barly corns in
thickness make a Finger or
measure, four Fingers a Hand,
four of those Hands in breadth
a Foot, five of those Feet
a Geometrical Pace, and 125
Paces a Furlong; eight Fur&shy;
longs, or 1000 Paces five
foot to a Pace, make an Ita&shy;
lian mile; 3000 Paces make
a league, 4000 a common
Dutch mile, and 5000 Paces
make a German or great 
Dutch mile.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="bb3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mecaenas(pn)">Mec&aelig;nas<etym lang="la"> M( ec&aelig;nas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Patron or Benefactor to lear&shy;
ned men: so called of Mec&aelig;&shy;
nas) a noble Roman, who
being in great favour with Au&shy;
gustus the Emperor, was a
special friend to the Poets
Virgil and Horace, and gene&shy;
rally a supporter of all lear&shy;
ned men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mechanic(n)">Mechanick (<etym lang="la">mechanicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Handicrafts man, a man of
Occupation, a Trades-man.
The seven Mechanical Arts
are first, <emend err="Ariculture">Agriculture</emend>, or
Husbandry. Secondly, Clo&shy;
thing. Thirdly, Navigation.
Fourthly, Hunting. Fifthly,
Architecture. Six, Medicine.
And seventhly, Military dis&shy;
cipline.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mechation(n)">Mechation (<etym lang="la">m&aelig;chatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">for&shy;
nication, Whoredom, strum&shy;
peting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="medalia(n)" lexeme="medal(n)">Medalia 
Medal  (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Medaille</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient and
flat Jewel, or a peece of an&shy;
cient coyn or plate, where&shy;
in the figure of some notable
person, or some ingenious
devise is cast or cut, exam&shy;
ples of the first are common
and usual; of the later, we
read, that when some dis&shy;
likes grew between the Eng&shy;
lish and States of the united
Provinces, they fearing it
might tend to the hurt of both,
caused to be imprinted two
pitchers floating on the water
upon a Medalia, with this Mot&shy;
to, <term lang="la"> Si collidimur, frangimur</term> . Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mede(n)">Mede ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> or <etym lang="la">medea</etym>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">See 
<xref lexeme="bragget">Bragget</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Medea(pn)">Medea,</form> <xpln lang="en">a notable Sorce&shy;
ress, whom Poets feign to
have had the power or skill
to renew youth, and make
old men young, &amp;c. and
this was nothing else but that
from the knowledge of Sim&shy;
ples, she had a Receipt to
make white hair black,
and reduce old heads into
the tincture of youth again.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="median(a)">Median (<etym lang="la">medius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the middle,
halt, mean; not deserving
praise or dispraise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mediastine(n)">Mediastine (<etym lang="la">mediastinum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a partition made in the bo&shy;
dy by certain thin skins,
which divide the whole
breast, from the Throat to the
Midriff into two hollow bo&shy;
soms. Cotgr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mediation(n)">Mediation (<etym lang="la">mediatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
deviding in the middle, an in&shy;
treating or beseeching, an in&shy;
tercession, an arbitrating a
controversie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="medicable(a)">Medicable (<etym lang="la">medicabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that can heal or be healed,
curable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="medical month(n)">Medical month,</form> <xpln lang="en">consists

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mediety(n)">Mediety (<etym lang="la">medietas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mediterranean Sea(pn)">Mediterranean Sea</form> <xpln lang="en">(so
called because it hath its
course in the midst of the
earth) is that which stretch&shy;
eth it self from West to East,
dividing Europe, Asia, and A&shy;
fica.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="medullar(a)">Medullar (<etym lang="la">medullaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;

ward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Meducean(a)">Meducean (pertaining to

snakes, because she lay with
Neptune in Minerva' s Tem&shy;
ple, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meen(n)">Meen (Fr. <etym lang="fr">mine</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the coun&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="megrim(n)">Megrime orMigrame
 (<etym lang="la">Hemicrania</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pain com&shy;
ing by fits in the temples of
the head, from <etym lang="gk">&#x03ae;&mu;&iota;</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">semi</term> 
half, and <etym lang="gk">&kappa;&rho;&omicron;&nu;&#x03af;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> the skul,
or brain-pan. It is a disease
that pains onely the one half
of the brain at once, and
therefore called Megrime, or
Hemicrain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="melancholy(n)">Melancholy (<etym lang="la">melancholia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
black choler caused by adu&shy;
stion of the blood; also sad&shy;
ness, pensiveness, solitariness
Melancholy is by Phisitians
reckoned for one of the four
humors of mans body, and
resembles the Earth, as Choler 
doth the fire; Blood the air;
Phleme the water. It is said
to be the grossest of all four,
which, if it abound too much,
causeth heaviness and sadness
of mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="melampode(n)">Melamped (<etym lang="la">melampodium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the hearb called Hellebore.</xpln></wordentry>

lein. See <xref>Balthasar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Melchiorists(pn)">Melchiorists,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of

der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Melchites(pn)">Melchites,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect in Syria
so called, who are subject to
the Patriark of Antioch, and
are of the same Tenets with
the Grecians, except onely,
that they celebrate divine ser&shy;
vice, as solemnly on the Sa&shy;
turday, as Sunday; They 


</page>

<page sig="bb4r">
take their denomination from
Melchi, which in the Syriac 
signifies a King, because in
matters of Religion, the
people followed the Empe&shy;
rors Injunctions, and were
of the Kings Religion, as the
saying is. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meliorate(v)">Meliorate (<etym lang="la">melioro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
wax better, then before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="membrane(n)">Membrane (<etym lang="la">membrana</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
upmost thin skin in any part
of the body, whereof there
be many and of several appel&shy;
lations. As the Pleuretique
membrane, which is large and
two fold, through whose
doubles pass all the Sinews,
Veins, and Arteries, which
are between the ribs; the
inside whereof (as also the
breast or bulk) it wholly co&shy;
vers. Aslo a skin of parch&shy;
ment, or the pill or <emend err="pilling&shy;">pilling</emend>
between the bark and tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="membranatic(a)">Membranatick (<etym lang="la">membrana&shy;
ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertaining to a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="menial servant(n)">Menial servant (from
 <etym lang="la">m&aelig;nia</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> walls)</form> <xpln lang="en">a servant
that lives within the walls of

haps rather from the old
English wordMeny, which
signifies family, and so tis one
of the family.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meninx(n)">Menings (<etym lang="la">meninx</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">two
thin skins, that compass or
enwrap the brain, the one
called <term lang="la">dura mater</term>, which is
the stronger of the two, and
next the scul; the <term lang="la">pia
mater</term>, which is within the
first, being more tender and
fine, and close, wrapping the
brain it self; if either of these
skins be wounded, it causeth
speedy death.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="menologe(n)">Menologe (<etym lang="la">menologium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a speaking of Months, or

the reason of the Monthes is
given.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mercedary(n)">Mercedary (<etym lang="la">mercedarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is

wages for labor, or for him
that receives it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merchene law(n)">Merchenlage,</form> <xpln lang="en">was one of
the three sorts of Laws out
of which the Conqueror fra&shy;
med ours, mingled with those
of Normandy. Cam: Britan.
pag. 94. who also pag. 103.
shews, that in Anno 1016,
this land was divided into
three parts, whereof the
West Saxons had one, govern&shy;
ing it by the Laws called
West Saxon Laws, or West
Saxonlage, and that contained
these nine Shires, Kent, South&shy;
sex, Southrey, Barkeshire, Hamp&shy;
shire, Wiltshire, Sommerset,
Dorset, and Devonshire. 


</page>

<page sig="bb5r">
The second by the Danes,
which was governed by the
Law called Danelage, and that
contained these fifteen Shires,
York, Darby, Nottingham,
Leicester, Lincoln, Northamp&shy;
ton, Bedford, Bucks, Hartford,
Essex. Middlesex, Northfolk,
Southfulk, Cambridge, and
Huntington. 

The third was possessed and
governed by the Mercians,
whose Law was called Mer&shy;
chenlage, which were these
eight, Glocester, Worcester, He&shy;
reford, Warwick, Oxford, Che&shy;
ster, Salop, and Stafford.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mercury(pn)">Mercury (<etym lang="la">mercurius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
son of Jupiter and Maia; he
was the messenger of the gods,
the god of Eloquence, Mer&shy;
chandize, Chivalry, and
Thievery; also author of the
Harp, and guider of the way,
he was said to have wings on
his arms, and feet. It is com&shy;
monly used for a swift messen&shy;
ger, or for a book of news, be&shy;
cause such books are (as it
were) the messengers of the
newes. 

Mercury, with the Alchy&shy;
mists is Quicksilver. Also one
of the seven Planets.<xref> See
Saturn</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mercurial(a)">Mercurial (<etym lang="la">mercurialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
Mercury, born under the Pla&shy;
net Mercury ; hence humorous
or fantastical; Also prating,
talkative; subtil, or deceit&shy;
ful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mercurialize(v)">Mercurialize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to be humo&shy;
rous or phantastical, to be
light footed, to prattle or 
babble; Also to be eloquent,
as Mercury was.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merdiferous(a)">Merdiferous (<etym lang="la">merdifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that farmeth dung, a Gold&shy;
finder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meretricious(a)">Meretricious (<etym lang="la">meretricius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
whorish, pertaining to whore&shy;
dom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meridian(n)">Meridian (<etym lang="la">circulus meri&shy;
dianus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an immovable, and
one of the greater circles pas&shy;
sing through the Poles of the
world; It <emend err="it">is</emend> called the Meri&shy;
dian of Meridies, noontide,
because when the Sun rising
from the East toucheth this
line with the center of his
body, then it is noon to those
over whose Zenith that circle
passeth, and midnight to their
Antipodes . The number of
Meridians, are 180 (allow&shy;
ing two to every degree in
the Equinoctial) which all
concentre in either Pole, and
are the utmost bounds of lon&shy;
gitude. Peacham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meridian(a)">Meridian (<etym lang="la">meridianus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">or
Meridianal, of, or belong&shy;
ing to midday, or to the
South.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meritot(n)">Meritot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sport used by
children by swinging them&shy;
selves in Bel-ropes, or such
like, till they be giddy; In
Latin it is called <term lang="la">Oscillum</term>, and
is thus described by an old
Writer, <term lang="la">Oscillum est genus ludi,
scilicet cum funis dependitur de
trabe, in quo pueri &amp; puell&aelig; se&shy; 
dentes impelluntur huc &amp; illuc</term> . 
Chauc.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mermaid(n)">Mermaid,</form> <xpln lang="en">Seamaid, or
Siren, whereof the Poets 


</page>

<page sig="bb5v">
had three, Parthenope, <emend err="Leuco">Leuco&shy;</emend>
sia and Ligea; the first used
her voyce, the second a Ci&shy;
tern, the third a Pipe; and
so are said to entice Marriners
and Sea men to them, by the
sweetness of their musick,
and then to destroy them.
The upper part of their bo&shy;
dies, was like a beautiful Vir&shy;
gin, the neather was fishy.
By these Syrens, pleasures
are emblematically under&shy;
stood, from which unless a
man abstain, or at least use
moderately, he shall be de&shy;
voured in their waves. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mersion(n)">Mersion (<etym lang="la">mersio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a drown&shy;
ing or overwhelming.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mease(n)">Mese (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&mu;&epsilon;&#x03c3;&omicron;&nu;</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">medium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mese of Herrings
is Five hundred, or the half
of a thousand, used in the
North of England.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mesentery(n)">Mesentery (<etym lang="la">mesenterium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the middle of the bowels and
entrals, a certain thick and
fat skin, or the double skin
that fastens the bowels to the
back, and each to other, and
also wraps and incloses a num&shy;
ber of veins (called Meseraick 
or Mesenterick Veins) being
branches of the great carry&shy;
ing vein, by which both the
guts are nourished, and the
joyce of the meat concocted,
is conveyed to the Liver to be
made blood. Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mesenteric artery(n)">Mesenterick Arteries or
Veins.</form> <xpln lang="en">See in <xref lexeme="artery">Artery</xref> and
 <xref>Vein</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mesne(n)">Mesn (<etym lang="la">medius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">seems to
come from the <emend err="Frence">French</emend> <etym lang="fr">Maisn&eacute;</etym>, 
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">minor natu</term>, younger by birth.
It signifies in our Common
Law, him that is Lord of a
Mannor, and thereby hath
Tenants holding of him, yet
holding himself of a superior
Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mesnagery(n)">Mesnagerie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hus&shy;
bandry, or Huswifery, and
the use or practise thereof.
Bp. Brambal in his Answer to 
Down-derry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mesnalty(n)">Mesnalty (<etym lang="la">medietas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">comes
of Mesn, and signifies no&shy;
thing but the right of the
Mesn ; As the Mesnalty is ex&shy;
tinct. Old nat. br. fol.44. if
the Mesnalty descend. Kitch.
fo.147.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Messalians(pn)">Messalians (<etym lang="la">Messalini</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort
of Hereticks, who (among
other gross absurdities) held
the B. Sacrament of the Eu&shy;
charist and Baptism did nei&shy;
ther good nor harm to the
Receivers, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Messias(pn)">Messias (Hebr. <etym lang="he">Mashiahh</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies as much as Christ in
Greek, <expan type="">id est</expan> Anointed . Our Lord
and Savior is often so called;
because he was annointed
with the oyle of gladness
for those that beleeve in
him. 

St. Augustin says, That
Messias signifies in the Pu&shy;
nick language, as much as An&shy;
nointed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mesle(n)">Messile orMissil (from
 <etym lang="la">misseo</etym>, to mingle)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
bearing, so called in Blazon,
because of the intermixture
of one colour with another.
Leigh.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meta(su)">Meta,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Greek Preposi&shy;
tion, which being set before
several Cases, has several signi&shy;
fications. Scapula.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metacism(n)">Metacism (<etym lang="la">metacismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metachronism(n)">Metachronism ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
error in the connexion of
things or times, by reckoning
or accounting short or beyond
the truth. Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaleptic(n)">Metaleptick (<etym lang="la">metalepticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath the power of parti&shy;
cipating, or pertains to the
figure Metalepsis ; whereby a
word is put from his pro&shy;
per or comon signification.
Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metalliferous(a)">Metalliferous (<etym lang="la">metallifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that brings forth metals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metamorphosis(n)">Metamorphosis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
transformation, a changing
of one likeness into another,
or of one shape and figure in&shy;
to another. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metamorphize(v)">To Metamorphize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to trans&shy;
form, or change shape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaphor(n)">Metaphor (<etym lang="la">metaphora</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">translatio</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the friendly and
neighborly borrowing one
word to express another,
with more light and better 
note; or, when a word is
changed from his own signi&shy;
fication into some other near
unto it; as <term lang="la">l&aelig;tas segetes, lux&shy;
<emend err="urianti" source="errata">uriantia</emend> prata</term>, &amp;c. Swords hun&shy;
gry of blood: Heads disinhe&shy;
rited of their natural Seignio&shy;
ries, &amp;c. This, of all other
figures, is the most used and
useful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaphorical(a)">Metaphorical (<etym lang="la">metaphori&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">spoken by Metaphor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaphysics(n)">Metaphysicks (<etym lang="la">metaphy&shy;
sica</etym>, <etym lang="gk">&#x1f70; &mu;&epsilon;&tau;&alpha;</etym>, <term lang="la">post vel trans</term>, &amp;
<etym lang="gk">&phi;&upsilon;&#x03c3;&iota;&kappa;&alpha;</etym>: <term lang="la">quasi</term> <term lang="la">trans physica, quod
rerum physicarum cognitionem
transcendunt</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Science which
listing it self above the
changeable nature of things,
considers of such as subsist in
their own essence, not sub&shy;
ject to any alteration, deal&shy;
ing onely with universals, ab&shy;
stracting from Individuals;
School Divinity is the highest
part of it, consisting chiefly
in contemplative knowledge
of God, Angels, souls of men,
&amp;c. Physick  (says my Lord
Bacon) is that which enquires
of the efficient cause, and of the
matter; Metaphysique, that
which enquires of the form
and end . Advan. of learning. fo.
143.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaplasm(n)">Metaplasm (<etym lang="la">metaplasmus</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">transformatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure in
Rhetorique, when by reason
of the verse, &amp;c. some thing is
necessarily changed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metathesis(n)">Metathesis <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">(Gr.)</class> 
(<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">transpo&shy;
sitio</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">when one letter is put
for another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metempsychosis(n)">Metempsychosis (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>) 
</form> <xpln lang="en">a 


</page>

<page sig="bb6v">
passing of the soul from one
body to another; Pithagoras
his error. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metempsychosed(a)">Metempsychosed,</form> <xpln lang="en">that so
passeth, or is passed. Peach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metator(n)">Metator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a planter
or setter in order, a measurer
out of the place for a Camp
to pitch in, a measurer of
land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meteor(n)">Meteor (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&mu;&epsilon;&tau;&#x03ad;&omega;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la"><expan type="">id est</expan></term> 
<term lang="la">sublimis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an apparition, or
any imperfect mixt substance
ingendred on high, in the
air; as Rain, Snow, Thunder,
Hail, Lightning, blazing
Stars, Clouds and Wind; All
which are made of vapors or
exhalations drawn up from
the Earth and Sea, by the at&shy;
tractive vertues of the Sun.
Vide Aristot. Meteorolog.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meteorology(n)">Meteorology ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
coursing of Meteors, or sub&shy;
lime things.</xpln></wordentry>

gus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that studies or
speaks of high matters, as of
Meteors, Stars, and other
celestial things.</xpln></wordentry>

made of Wort, Hearbs, Spice,
and honey sodden together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="methodist(n)">aMethodist,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that puts

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Methuselah(pn)">Methuselah (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
name of the oldest man before
the flood, who lived 969 years.
Hence 'tis used proverbially, to
live the years of Methuselah,
for a very old age.</xpln></wordentry>

gure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metope(n)">Metopes (<etym lang="la">metop&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
of Architecture, and signifies
the distance or space between
Denticles and <emend err="Triglyphses" source="errata">Triglyphs</emend>, which
is either left plain, or garnish&shy;
ed with Lances, Bones, Bul&shy;
heads, binding bands and la&shy;
bels. Vitruvius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metopomanty(n)">Metopomantie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a di&shy;
vination by the face, or fore&shy;
head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metoposcopy(n)">Metoposcopy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mitch(v)">To Miche (from the Fr.

 <etym lang="he">Michiol</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&mu;&epsilon;&gamma;&#x03ac;&lambda;&eta;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="microcosmus(n)">Microcosmus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pro&shy;
perly signifies a little world.
This term is sometimes appli&shy;
ed to man, who is therefore
called a Microcosmus, or little
world, as being a Compendi&shy;
um of all other creatures, his
body being compared to the
baser part of the world, and
his soul to the blessed Angels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="microcosmical(a)">Microcosmical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to a little world, or to man.
Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Midas(pn)">Midas,</form> <xpln lang="en">a rich King of Phry&shy;
gia who desired of Bacchus that
what ever he touched might
be turned into gold, &amp;c.
Hence Midas is used proverbi&shy;
ally for a rich, covetous man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="midriff(n)">Midriff (<etym lang="la">diaphragma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a si&shy;
newy skin passing overthwart
in mans body, which divides
the Heart and Lungs from the
Stomack, Guts and Liver, lest
the vital parts should be offen&shy; 
ded with any ill vapor coming
from them. See <xref>Diaphragm</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="migrem(n)">Migrame</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Megrime</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="migration(n)">Migration (<etym lang="la">migratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a flit&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mile(n)">Mile (<etym lang="la">milliare</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is with us
a quantity of 1760 yards, o&shy;
therwise described to contain
eight Furlongs, and every
Furlong to contain forty
Lugs or Poles, and every
Lug or Pole to contain six&shy;
teen foot and a half. An.35.
Eliz. ca.6.<xref> See League</xref> and<xref> Furlong</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="militant(a)">Militant (<etym lang="la">militans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">going to
war, fighting. 

Church Militant, is the Church
here on earth, subject to trials,
combats and temptations.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="militia(n)">Militia ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Warfare, or

apish.</xpln></wordentry>
