<page sig="bb7v">
wisdom, and of all the Arts,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miniature(n)">Miniature (from <etym lang="la">minium</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> red lead)</form> <xpln lang="en">the art of draw&shy;
ing pictures in little, being
commonly done with red
lead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minims(pn)">Minims,</form> <xpln lang="en">an order of re&shy;
ligious persons.<xref> See Bon&shy;
homes</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miniographer(n)">Miniographer (<etym lang="la">miniogra&shy;
phus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that paints or writes
with Vermilion, or any red
colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minious(a)">Minious (<etym lang="la">minius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">red,
of the colour of Vermili&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ministry(n)">Ministery (<etym lang="la">ministerium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
service, labor, the charge of a
work, commonly taken for
that of the Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miniver(n)">Miniver orMeniver,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fine white fur made of the
bellies of Squirrils: Some
say it is the skin of a little
white Vermine, breeding in
Muscovia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minor(n)">Minor( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the lesser,
younger or smaller. The <emend err="mi&shy;">mi&shy;</emend>
nor or assumption of a Syllo&shy;
gism.<xref> See Syllogism</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minoration(n)">Minoration (<etym lang="la">minoratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a making lesse or <emend err="diminish">diminish&shy;</emend>
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minorative(a)">Minorative (<etym lang="la">minorativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which diminisheth, or
makes less, or is apt to make
less.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minority(n)">Minority (<etym lang="la">minoritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">non&shy;
age, underage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Minors(pn)">Minors.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Friar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Minos(pn)">Minos,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Creet,
who for his great justice is
feigned to have been made a 
Judge in hell, &amp;c. Hence, As
just, as Minos, proverbial&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minotaur(n)">Minotaur (<etym lang="la">minotaurus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Poetical monster, half like a
man, half like a Bull; was
kept in the Labyrinth of
Candy, and fed with mans
flesh, where at last he was slain
by Theseus, through the help
of Ariadne. This fable was
built upon this foundation;
that one Taurus a servant of
Minos got his Mis. Pasiphae
with child, from whence the
Infant was named Minotau&shy;
rus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minute(a)">Minute (<etym lang="la">minutus</etym> adj.)</form> <xpln lang="en">di&shy;
minished, small or little, mean,
or simple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minution(n)">Minution (<etym lang="la">minutio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a di&shy;
minishing or making less.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mirabilary(n)">Mirabilary (from <etym lang="la">mirum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
may be taken for a book of
wonders; as vocabulary, a
book of words. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miradical(a)">Miradical (<etym lang="la">miradicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
speaks strange things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mirifical(a)">Mirifical (<etym lang="la">mirificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mar&shy;
vellous, wonderfully done,
strangely wrought.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mirmillon(n)">Mirmillon (<etym lang="la">mirmillo, onis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a challenger at fighting with
swords; one sort of Gladia&shy;
tores, called also Galli, upon
whose crests was portraited a
fish. Perottus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mis(su)">Mis,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Particle in
composition, which for the
most part signifies to err, or
do ill: As to mis-interpret, to
err in interpreting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misantropy(n)">Misantropie (<etym lang="la">misantropia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an hating of men.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="bb8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misantropist(n)">Misantropist (<etym lang="la">misantro&shy;
pos</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that hates the com&shy;
pany of men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miscellany(n)">Miscellanies (<etym lang="la">mescellanea</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a hotch pot of sundry collecti&shy;
ons without any form or me&shy;
thod; a mixture of things
together, without any or&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miscellaneous(a)">Miscellaneous (<etym lang="la">miscellane&shy; 
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mixed together without
order.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miscreant(n)">Miscreant (<etym lang="la">q. mis-croyant</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a mis-beleever, an Infidel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misaraic vein(n)">Miseraick Vein.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See 
Vein</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Miserere(n)">Miserere,</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> have mercy;
It is the name and begining of
one of the penitential Psalms;
and it is commonly that Psalm,
which the Judge gives to such
guilty persons, as have the
benefit of Clergy allowed
by the Law, and is called
the Psalm of Mercy . There
is also a disease called Miserere
mei, which is a voiding of the
Excrements upwards, coming
of the obstruction of the smal
guts, and is very painful, the
patient imagining that his
guts are pulled out, and bro&shy;
ken.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miskenning(n)">Miskenning,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a chang&shy;
ing of speech in Court; Sax&shy;
on in the description of Eng&shy;
land, cap.11. But Stow defines
it thus, <term lang="la">Est queitum esse de a&shy;
merciamento pro querela, coram
quibuscunque, in transumptione
prolata</term> . Survey fol.919.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misogamy(n)">Misogamie (<etym lang="la">misogamia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ha&shy;
ting of marriage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misogyny(n)">Misogynie (<etym lang="la">misoginia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the 
hate or contempt of wo&shy;
men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misprision(n)">Misprision (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Mespris</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> contempt, despising)</form> <xpln lang="en">
it signifies in our Common
Law, negligence or over&shy;
sight. As for example Mispri&shy;
sion of Treason or Felony, is
a neglect or light account
shewed of Treason or Felony
committed, by not revealing
it, when we know it to be
committed. Stawnf. Pl. Cor.
lib. I. ca. 19. Misprision of
Treason incurs imprisonment
during the Kings pleasure,
loss of goods and profits of
lands during life. Misprision
of Felony, seems onely fina&shy;
ble by the Justices, before
whom the party is attainted.
See more of this in Cowel.
Misprision signifies also a mista&shy;
king. An.14. E. 3. Stat. I.
ca.6.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mistletoe(n)">Messelto,Meseldine, or
Mistelden (from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Mistel</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a plant having slen&shy;
<emend err="per">der</emend> branches and green thick
leaves, and never grows upon
the ground, but upon other
trees; The best is that which
grows <emend err="npon">upon</emend> the Oake, its
leaves and fruit are good
to soften and ripen any cold
hard swellings. Of the ber&shy;
ry of this vegetable, Birdlime
is made. But that the Thrush
eating these berries, and not
able to digest them, and so
from her inconverted muring
this plant should arise (as the
Antients affirmed) is doubted
by Dr. Brown fo.98. From 


</page>

<page sig="bb8v">
this conceit, that the Thrush
did cack Misselto, which
made birdlime, the bane of
the bird, arose that old pro&shy;
verb,

 <term lang="la">Turdus sibi malum cacat</term> . 

Applliable to such as are
authors of their own misfor&shy;
tune.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="missile(n)">Missil (<etym lang="la">missile</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dart, stone,
arrow, or other thing thrown
or shot; a term of Heraldry.
Guill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="missionary(n)">Missionaries,</form> <xpln lang="en">persons sent;
commonly spoken of Priests
sent to unbeleeving Coun&shy;
tries to convert the people to
Christian Faith. Also a parti&shy;
cular institute in France, cal&shy;
led the Fathers of the Mission ;
who go by pairs, in imitation
of the Apostles, preach and
catechize, and perform o&shy;
ther pastoral Offices, in as&shy;
sistance of the Clergy, and
with obedience to the Bi&shy;
shop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mission(n)">Mission (<etym lang="la">missio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sending
away, licence or leave to
depart. 

Mission (says a Roman Ca&shy;
tholick Author) is a giving of
Orders, Jurisdiction and power
to preach that Doctrine, which
is taught by the Catholick
Church, and to administer
the Sacraments.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="missive(n)">Missive (<etym lang="la">missus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cast
or hurle, a sending, or that
which witnesseth ones be&shy;
ing sent; It is also used ad&shy;
jectively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mithridate(n)">Mithridate orMethridate
 (<etym lang="la">mithridatum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a strong Treacle 
or preservative against poi&shy;
son, devised at first by the
Pontian King Mithridates, from
whom it took name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mitify(v)">Mitifie (<etym lang="la">mitifico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pa&shy;
cifie, or make quiet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mittimus(n)">Mittimus (<expan type="">id est</expan> we send)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
a Warrant made to convey
an offender to Prison. Also a
precept sent by the King out
of his Bench, to those that
have the custody of Fines le&shy;
vied, that they send them by
a day assigned by his Bench.
West. par. 2. Symb. tit. Fines
sect. 138. F. and 154. B. See
also the Regist. Orig. Ta&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mizmore(n)">Mizmor (Span. <etym lang="sp"> mazmorra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Dungeon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mnemosyne(pn)"><emend err="Muemosyne">Mnemosyne</emend> (Gr. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">memo&shy;
ria</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the mother of the Mu&shy;
ses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mobbie(n)">Mobbi,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain drink u&shy;
sed among the English in the
Barbado Island, and is made
of Potato roots. Mr. How.
Letters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mobility(n)">Mobility (<etym lang="la">mobilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">move&shy;
ableness, changeableness, in&shy;
constancy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="modality(n)">Modality,</form> <xpln lang="en">a School term,
and signifies the manner or
qualification of a thing in ab&shy;
stract.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="modder(n)">Modder (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">from the Belg.</class>
<etym lang="bl">Modde</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">puella</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wench or
young Girle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moderator(n)">Moderator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
creet Governor or Ruler; he
that keeps both parties from
running into extreams.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="modicum(n)">Modicum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
thing, a smal pittance.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="cc1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="modify(v)">Modify (<etym lang="la">modifico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to mea&shy;

mit.</xpln></wordentry>

limitation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="modulation(n)">Modulation (<etym lang="la">modulatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
pleasant tuning, a singing or
playing by number or mea&shy;
sure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Moguntine(a)">Moguntine,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
Moguntia or Mentz a City in
Germany, where Printing
was first invented by John
Gutenburg. An. 1440.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mule(n)">Moiles (<etym lang="la">mullei</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
Shooes with a high soal, used
in ancient times by Kings and
great persons. 

Moile is also used by Chaucer,
for a dish made of Marrow
and grated bread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moity(n)">Moitie (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Moiti&eacute;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the half of any
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="molar teeth(n)">Molar teeth (<etym lang="la">dentes mola&shy;
res</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the back teeth, cheek
teeth, or grinders, which are
five of each side the mouth,
both above and beneath. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="molendatious(a)" lexeme="molendinarious(a)">Molendarious 
or Molendinarious  (<etym lang="la">molen&shy;
darius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to a Mill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moliminous(a)">Moliminous (from <etym lang="la">moli&shy;
men, inis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath force, or
useth endeavor to do any
thing; difficult.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="molition(n)">Molition (<etym lang="la">molitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an en&shy;
deavor, practise, attempt, or
undertaking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mollificative(a)">Mollificative (<etym lang="la">mollificati&shy;
vus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that mollifies or makes
soft, that makes tender or
supple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mollitude(n)">Mollitude (<etym lang="la">mollitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">soft&shy;
ness, niceness, tenderness, ef&shy;
feminateness, wantonness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Moloch(pn)">Moloch,</form> <xpln lang="en">The name of an
Idol, in the Valley of Gehin&shy;
nom or Tophet, to which the
Israelites abominably offered
their children in sacrifice of
fire. This Idol was represen&shy;
ted by a man-like brazen bo&shy;
dy, bearing the head of a Calf.
See more in Sir Wal. Ral. l.2.
fol.294.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="molochite(n)">Molochite (<etym lang="la">molochites</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of precious stone, ha&shy;
ving a thick greenishness in
colour, like Mallows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moly(n)">Moly,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of hearb,
whose root to dig up, the an&shy;
cients supposed to be hazar&shy;
dous to the life of the digger;
Hence that of Homer.
<term lang="gk">
&Mu;&#x1FF7;&lambda;&omega; &delta;&epsilon; &mu;&#x03AF;&nu; &kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&#x03AD;&omicron;&upsilon;&#x03C3;&iota;, &Theta;&epsilon;&omicron;&#x1F76; &kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&epsilon;&pi;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&delta;&epsilon; &#x03A4;&#x1F40;&rho;&#x03CD;&omega;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;
&Alpha;&nu;&delta;&rho;&alpha;&#x03C3;&#x1F30; &gamma;&epsilon;&delta;&nu;&eta;&tau;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&#x03C3;&iota; &Theta;&epsilon;&omicron;&#x1F30; &delta;&epsilon;&tau;&epsilon; &pi;&alpha;&nu;&tau;&alpha; &delta;&#x03CD;&nu;&alpha;&nu;&tau;&alpha;&iota;,
</term>, 

The Gods it Moly call, whose root to dig away,
Is dangerous to man, but Gods they all things may.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Momus(pn)">Momus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the carping god,
or god of reprehension; And is
taken for any one that back&shy; 
bites others. Hence the pro&shy;
verb, <term lang="la">Momo satisfacere</term>; to con&shy;
tent one whom no man can
please.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="cc1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monas(n)">Monas ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the number
one, unity. And Monos ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)
alone; or one that lives a&shy;
lone; a word much used in
composition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monial(a)" lexeme="monachal(a)">Monial or Monachal (<etym lang="la">monachalis</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to a
Monk, or one
that lives alone, solitarily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monachism(n)">Monachism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the state or
condition of a Monk, or of a
lonely man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monarchy(n)">Monarchy (<etym lang="la">monarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
where a Prince Rules alone
without a Peer; or it is the
government of one man over
many.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monasterial(a)">Monasterial (<etym lang="la">monasterialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to a Monastery or
Monk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mound(n)">a Mond,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Ball of gold,
is one of the Ensigns belong&shy;
ing to an Emperor, because
he challenges the title of Ma&shy;
jesty over the whole world.
Herne. p.147.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monk(n)">Monks (from the Gr.
<etym lang="gr">monos</etym>, because they live a&shy;
lone or solitary)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of re&shy;
ligious people, whereof there
are divers sorts, as those of St.
Benedict, St. Bazil, St. Hie&shy;
rome, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="month(n)">Moneths ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax</class> <etym lang="sx">monads</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
however taken are not exactly
divisible into Septuaries or
weeks, which fully contain
seven daies, whereof four
times make compleatly twen&shy;
ty eight; For besides the u&shy;
sual or Calendary moneth,
there are but four considera&shy;
ble, that is, the moneth of
Peragration, of Apparition, of 
Consecution, and the medical 
or Decretorial moneth; where&shy;
of some come short, others
exceed this account. A month
of Peragration, is the time of
the Moons revolution from
any part of the Zodiack, unto
the same again, and this con&shy;
tains but twenty seven days,
and about eight hours. The
month of Consecution or (as some
term it) of Progression, is the
space between one conjuncti&shy;
on of the Moon with the
Sun, unto another; and this
contains twenty nine dayes
and a half. A month of Ap&shy;
parition is the space wherein
the Moon appears (deducting
three daies, wherein it com&shy;
monly disappears; and being
in combustion with the Sun,
is presumed of less activity)
and this contains but twenty
six days, and twelve hours.
The medical moneth, not
much exceeds this, consisting
of twenty six days, and twen&shy;
ty two hours, &amp;c. of this
see more in Dr. Br. vul. Err.
fol 212.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monger(n)">Monger orManger ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
was our ancient name for a
Merchant; it is now onely u&shy;
sed as an addition to divers
Merchantable Trades, as Iron&shy;
monger, Fish-monger, Wood&shy;
monger, and the like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monition(n)">Monition (<etym lang="la">monitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a war&shy;

lor.</xpln></wordentry>

 <term lang="la">Pauper videre Cinna vult, &amp; est pauper</term>. Mart.

in such fashion that none can

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monops(n)">Monops ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of

Bull, being narrowly pursu&shy;
ed, it voideth a kind of sharp
Ordure, deadly to such as it
lights upon. This beast is by
some called a Bonasus.</xpln></wordentry>

held the Holy Ghost was<emend err="no"> not</emend>

onely to them, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

licious wine, so called from

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="montera(n)">Montera ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hun&shy;
ters or Sea-mans Cap, which
kind of Caps were (not
long since) much in request
with us.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monticulous(a)">Monticulous (<etym lang="la">monticulosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moor(v)">To Moore a ship,</form> <xpln lang="en">is to fa&shy;
sten her so, that she stick in
the mud; to tye or bind her
in some Creek or Harbor with
Cables or great Ropes. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moot(n)">Moot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term used in the
Inns of Court, and signifies
the handling or arguing a
Case for exercise; As in the
Universities there are disputa&shy;
tions, Problems, Sophisms,
and such like Acts; It seems
to bee derived from the
French word (<etym lang="fr">Mot</etym>) <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la"> ver&shy;
bum Quasi, verba facere, aut
Sermonem de aliqua rehabere</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mootman(n)">Mootmen,</form> <xpln lang="en">are those Stu&shy;
dents that argue Readers
cases in houses of Chancery,
both in Terms and grand
Vacations; Of Mootmen after
some years study are chosen
Outward Baristers ; of which
degree after they have been
Twelve years, they are com&shy;
monly chosen Benchers, or
Antients, of which one of
the younger sort, reads yearly
in Summer Vacation, and
is called a single Reader ; And
one of the Ancients that 
have formerly read, reads
in Lent Vacation, and is cal&shy;
led a double Reader, and it
is usually between his first
and second Reading nine or
ten years; some of these
Readers are afterwards cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">ad statum &amp; gradum
Servientis ad legem</term>, and of
Sergeants are constituted the
honorable Judges and Sages
of the Law. 

For the entrance of the
young Student (who com&shy;
monly comes from one of
the Universities) were first
instituted and erected eight
Houses of Chancery, to
learn there the Elements of
the Law; (viz.) Cliffords
Inn, Lions Inn, Clements
Inn, Bernards Inn, Staple Inn,
Furnivals Inn, Davies Inn,
and New Inn ; And each of
these Houses consist of forty
or more. For the Readers, Ut&shy;
ter-Baristers, Mootmen, and
inferior Students, there are
four famous and renowned
Colledges or Inns of Court;
called. 1. The Inner Temple, to
which the first three Houses of
Chancery appertain; Grayes
Inn, to which the next two be&shy;
long; Lincolns Inn, which en&shy;
joys the last two saving one;
and the Middle Temple, which
hath onely the last. Each of
the Houses of Court consist
of Benchers above twenty, of
Utter Baristers above thrice so
many, of young Gentlemen about
the number of 160 to 180,
who there spend their time in 


</page>

<page sig="cc3r">
study of Law, and commenda&shy;
ble Exercises. The Judges of
the Law and Sergeants, being
commonly above the number
of twenty, are equally distri&shy;
buted into two higher and
more eminent Houses called
Sergeants Inns . All these are
not far distant one from ano&shy;
ther, and altogether make the
most famous University for
profession of Law onely, or of
any one human Science in the
world, and advanceth itself
above all others, <term lang="la">Quantum inter
viburna cupressus</term>. Lo. Coke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mopsical(a)">Mopsical (<etym lang="la">mopsicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that can&shy;
not see well; Hence perhaps
comes our phrase mop-ey'd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moral(a)">Moral (<etym lang="la">moralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to manners or civili&shy;
ty. The four moral or Cardi&shy;
nal vertues are, 1. Prudence,
2. Justice . 3. Temperance, 4. For&shy;
titude ; and are so called, be&shy;
cause they concern the man&shy;
ners or behaviour belonging
properly to the actions of
man, onely as he is man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moralize(v)">Moralize (<etym lang="la">moralizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to ex&shy;
pound morally, to give a mo&shy;
ral sence unto. As in the Fa&shy;
bles of &AElig;sop, the parties na&shy;
med are Foxes, Asses, and such
like Beasts, with Birds and
Fishes, yet there is a latent
moral sence therin, appliable
to the persons of men and wo&shy;
men, and which may serve for
rules of good manners, and
this is called the moral or mo&shy;
rality of the Fable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moration(n)">Moration (<etym lang="la">moratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stay&shy;
ing or tarrying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morbidezza(n)">Morbidezza ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">tender&shy;
ness, softness. s. H. Wotton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morbifical(a)">Morbifical (<etym lang="la">morbificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morbulent(a)">Morbulent (<etym lang="la">morbulentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morbus gallicus(n)">Morbus Gallicus,</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise
called Morbus Indicus, Neopoli&shy;
tanus, Hispanicus (in Lat. <etym lang="la">Lues
Venerea</etym>) the French Pox or
great Pox. In the City of
Naples about the year <emend err="14094" source="errata">1494</emend>.
this disease was first known
in Christendom, and is said
to be brought thither out of
America. See <xref>American disease</xref>.
The French report, that at the
siege of Naples, there were
certain wicked Merchants
that barrelled up mans flesh
(of some that had been lately
slain in Barbary) and sold it
for Mummy, and upon that
foul and high nourishment,
was the original of this dis&shy;
ease. Lo. Bac. nat. Hist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mordacity(n)" lexeme="mordancy(n)">Mordacity 
Mordancie  (<etym lang="la">mordacitas</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">biting; sharp&shy;
ness of speech, detraction, bit&shy;
ter tearms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mordicate(v)">Mordicate (<etym lang="la">mordico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
hurt with biting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moresque work(n)">Moresk work (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mores&shy;
que</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a rude or Antick paint&shy;
ing or carving, wherein the

to resemble a kind of wilde
leaves, &amp;c. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morglay(n)">Morglay (<etym lang="la">mort-glaive</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kil&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morling(n)">Morling <term lang="la">alias</term> Mortling</form> 


</page>

<page sig="cc3v">
<xpln lang="en">seems to be that wool which
is taken from the skin of dead
sheep, whether dying of the
rot or being killed. An 27.
H.6. ca.2. This is written
Morkein . An.3. Jac. cap 8. See
Morkein.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morion(n)">Morion (from the Ital.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Morisco(n)">Morisco ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Moor;
also a Dance so called, where&shy;
in there were usually five
men, and a Boy dressed in a
Girles habit, whom they call
the Maid Marrian or perhaps
Morian, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Morione</etym>
a Head-peece, because her
head was wont to be gaily
trimmed up. The common
people call it a Morris
Dance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morkin(n)">Morkein orMorkin (from
 <etym lang="la">mors</etym>, death)</form> <xpln lang="en">among huntsmen
is a Deer that dies by some
disease or mischance.<xref> See
Morling</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morology(n)">Morology (<etym lang="la">morologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morphew(n)">Morphew (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortgage(n)">Mortgage (Fr. <etym lang="fr">mort</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <etym lang="la">mors</etym>, and <etym lang="la">gage</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">pignus, mer&shy;
ces</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our Common
Law, a pawn of Land or Te&shy;
nement, or any thing movable
laid or bound for money bor&shy;
rowed, peremptorily to be
the Creditors for ever, if the
mony be not repaid at the day
agreed upon; And the Cre&shy;
ditor holding such Land or
Tenement is called Tennant in
Mortgage . See more of this
in the New Terms of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortiferous(a)">Mortiferous (<etym lang="la">mortifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
deadly, that brings death.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortification(n)">Mortification (<etym lang="la">mortifica&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mortifying, a quel&shy;
ling, taming or punishing the
flesh, a deading the appetite,
a killing of lust.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortmain(n)">Mortmain (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> a dead
hand)</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies in the Com&shy;
mon Law, an alienation of
Lands or Tenements to any
Corporation, Guild, or Frater&shy;
nity and their Successors; As
Bishops, Parsons, Vicars,
&amp;c. which may not be done
without license of the King,
and the Lord of the Man&shy;
nor, &amp;c. See more of this in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortress(n)">Mortress,</form> <xpln lang="en">a meat made
of boyled Hens, crums of
bread, yolkes of eggs, and
Saffron, all boyled together.
Chauc.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortual(a)">Mortual (<etym lang="la">mortualis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to death.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="cc4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortuary(n)">a Mortuary (<etym lang="la">mortuarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
a gift left by a man at his
death to his Parish Church,
in recompense of his personal
Tithes and Offerings not due&shy;
ly paid in his life time.
Heretofore, if a man had
three or more Cattle of any
kind, the best being kept for
the Lord of the Fee, as a
Herriot: The second was
wont to be given to the Par&shy;
son in Right of the Church.
But by the Statute of 21 H.8.
ca.6. a rate in money is set
down for Mortuaries, viz. three
shillings four pence, where
the goods of the deceased are
above the value of twenty
Nobles, and under thirty
pound; six shillings eight
pence, where the goods ex&shy;
ceed thirty pound, and under
forty pound; and ten shil&shy;
lings, where the goods a&shy;
mount above the value of
forty pound, &amp;c. These Mor&shy;
tuaries are due but in some
particular places. Cow. in
part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mosaic(n)" lexeme="musaical work(n)">Mosaique orMusaical 
work (<etym lang="la">Mosaicum, mus&aelig;acum, 
vel Musivum opus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a most
curious work wrought of
stones of divers colours, and
divers mettles, into the shape
of knots, flowers, and other
devices, with that excellency
of cunning, that they seem
all to be one stone, and ra&shy;
ther the work of Nature then
Art. 
Sir Hen. Wotton describes it
thus, Mosaique is a kind of 
painting in smal Pebbles,
Cockles, and shels of sundry
colours; and of late dayes,
likewise with peeces of glass,
figured at pleasure; An orna&shy;
ment, in truth, of much
beauty, and long life, but of
most use in Pavements and
floarings. El. of Archit. p.
268. 
St. Marks Church in Venice,
abounds with curiosity of
this Work, of which the Ve&shy;
netians vaunt themselves to be
the Authors.<xref> See Marque&shy;
try</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mosaical(a)">Mosaical,</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertain&shy;
ing to Moses, or to Mosaick 
work.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mosque(n)">Mosche orMosque,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Temple or Church among
the Turks and Saracens, the
Persians call it a Moschea .
Herb. tr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="motable(a)">Motable (<etym lang="la">motabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">al&shy;
wayes moving, still in mo&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="motacism(n)">Motacism (<etym lang="la">motacismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the dashing out of a let&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mother(n)">Mother,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in wo&shy;
men, when the womb riseth
with pain, for which the
smelling to all sweet savors is
harmful; as contrarily, to
all strong and loathsom,
good.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mot(n)">Mot ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>) <etym lang="it"> Motto</etym> (Ital)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a word; But in a restrained
sence it is properly taken for
the Word or short sentence
applied to an Imprese or De&shy;
vise .<xref> See Devise</xref>. There are
also Motto' s belonging to the 


</page>

<page sig="cc4v">
Coats of Arms of most of
the Nobility and Gentry of
England, which are seldom
or never in the English
tongue. 

Mot, is also a Note, which
a Huntsman winds on his
horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="motet(n)">Motet ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a verse in
Musick, or of a Song, a Posie,
a short-play.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mountain of piety(n)">Mountain of Piety (<etym lang="la">mons
pietatis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a stock of money
raised by the charity of good
people, who, observing the
poor ruined by the usury of
Jews, voluntarily contributed
good store of treasure to be
preserved and lent to them,
whereby they, upon securi&shy;
ty, might have money at a low
rate to relieve their wants;
which, because the mass is
great, and the thing pious and
charitable in it self, is called 
a Mountain of Piety, But in
respect the Officers and inci&shy;
dent charges cannot be had
without some emolument,
therefore the borrower payes
somewhat by the moneth for
the loan of that he receives,
Cajet. opusc. de monte Pietat. c. I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mountebank(n)">Mountebank <class type="etymlang" lang="it"> (Ital.</class> <etym lang="it">Mon&shy;
timbanco</etym>. <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span</class>. <etym lang="sp">Saltaenbanco</etym>,
<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> Charlatan</etym>. TeutonickLand&shy;
streicher. <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg</class>Quacksalver)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a cousening Drug-seller, a
base deceitful Merchant (e&shy;
specially of Apothecaries
Drugs) that, with impudent
lying, does, for the most part
sell counterfeit stuff to the
common people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muccilaginous(a)">Muccilaginous, comes <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from
the Latin</class> <etym lang="la">muccago</etym>, or <etym lang="la">muccus</etym>,
or <etym lang="la">mucus</etym> snot or snivil)</form> <xpln lang="en">snivil&shy;
ish, snotty, filthy, and thence
flegmy, and the like. Dr Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mucculent(a)" lexeme="muculent(a)">Mucculent orMuculent, (<etym lang="la">
muculentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full of snot or
snivel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mucid(a)">Mucid (<etym lang="la">mucidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sinued,
hoary, mouldy, filthy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mucor(n)">Mucor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hoariness,
filthiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mufti(n)">Mufti</form> <xpln lang="en">(<expan type="">id est</expan> an Oracle, or
answerer of doubts) a chief 
Priest among the Turks (who
is created by the Emperor)
and hath four several orders
or Sects subordinate to him
( viz.) first the Calenderim .
Secondly, the Haggiemlar .
Thirdly, the Torlacchi . Fourth&shy;
ly, the Dervislar, &amp;c. See more
of this in Sir Hen. Blounts Voy&shy;
age into the Levant. p.79.<xref lexeme="Brackmans"> See
Brachman</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mugient(a)">Mugient (<etym lang="la">mugiens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lowing,
bellowing, crying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulato(n)">Mulato ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the son of
a woman Blackmore, and a
man of another Nation, or <term lang="la">&egrave;
contra</term>; one that is of a mon&shy;
gril complexion. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulcible(a)">Mulcible (<etym lang="la">mulcibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which
may be appeased.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulct(n)">Mulct (<etym lang="la">mulcta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fine, an
amerciament, a punishing by
the purse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muleto(n)">Muleto</form> <xpln lang="en">a Moil or great
Mule, a beast much used in
France for carrying Sumpters,
&amp;c. It may also be taken for
a diminutive of (Mule) and so
signifies a little Mule.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muliebrity(n)">Muliebrity (<etym lang="la">muliebritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="cc5r">
tenderness, delicateness, wo&shy;
manliness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulierosity(n)">Mulierosity (<etym lang="la">mulierositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
unlawful lust after women,
properly married or defiled
women; for <term lang="la">Mulier</term>, signifies
a woman that hath had the
company of a man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muller(n)">Mullar (from the Latin <etym lang="la">mo&shy;
lo</etym>, to grind)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the upper stone
which Painters and Limners
use to grind their colours
with; the neather stone is
called the grinding stone.
The French call it a <term lang="fr">Moul&shy;
leur</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mullet(n)">Mullet (<etym lang="la">mullus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
dainty fish; Also a term in
Heraldry signifying a spot de&shy;
scending from high, and di&shy;
vided into five corners or
ends out of one drop, and is
the distinction for a third bro&shy;
ther:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulse(n)">Mulse (<etym lang="la">mulsum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">water
and honey sod together, also
sweet wine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mussulmans(pn)">Mulsulmans ( <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

led; The word signifies as
much as a people faithful
in their Law or Religion

</page>

<page sig="cc5v">
<etym lang="fr">Mouleure</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Grist or Corn&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mummial(a)">Mumial,</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertaining
to Mumie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mummy(n)">Mumie 
 or Mummie (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">Mumia</etym>. 
<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class> <etym lang="it">Mummia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a thing like pitch sold by A&shy;
pothecaries; It is hot in the
second degree, and good a&shy;
gainst all brusings, spitting of
blood, and divers other dis&shy;
eases: 

There are two kinds of it,
the one is digged out of the
Graves, in Arabia and Syria,
of those bodies that were em&shy;
balmed, and is called Arabian
Mummie . The second kind
is onely an equal mixture of
the Jews Lime and Bitumen,
in Greek <term lang="gr">Pissasphaltum</term>, in La&shy;
atin <term lang="la">Pici bitumen</term>, and of the
simplicists, <term lang="la">Cera montana, Cera
terrestris, Pissalsphaltum nati&shy;
vum, &amp; mumia nativa</term>. Gen.
Practise of Physick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Muncerians(pn)">Muncerians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Ana&shy;
baptists, so called from Tho.
Muncer, who was their Pro&shy;
phet, Senator and General,
when they rose in Rebelli&shy;
on in Suevia, and Franco&shy;
nia, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muniment(n)">Muniment (<etym lang="la">munimen</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Fortress or Fence, a Fort or
Hold: A Muniment house (in
Cathedral, or Collegiate
Churches, Castles, Colledges
or such like) is a house or
little room of strength, pur&shy;
posely made for keeping the
Seal, Plate, Evidences, Char&shy;
ters, &amp;c. of such Church, Col&shy;
ledge, &amp;c. such Evidences be&shy;
ing called in Law Muniments,
(or corruptly miniments) from
 <term lang="la">Munio</term>, to defend; because a
mans inheritance or possessi&shy;
on is defended by them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="munite(v)">Munite (<etym lang="la">munio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to for&shy;
tifie, strengthen, defend or
save.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="munited(a)">Munited (<etym lang="la">munitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">armed,
fenced, made strong, prepa&shy;
red.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murage(n)">Murage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Toll or Tri&shy;
bute to be levied for the buil&shy;
ding or repairing publick E&shy;
difices or Walls. Fitz. nat. br. 


</page>

<page sig="cc6r">
fo.227. d. It seems also to be
a liberty granted by the King
to a Town for Fathering mo&shy;
ney towards walling it. An.3.
Ed. I. ca.30.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mural(n)">Mural (<etym lang="la">muralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belong&shy;
ing to a wall. The Mural
Crown was one of the rewards
given by the old Romans to
their Souldiers, with which he
onely was honored, who did
first scale the walls, and enter
the Enemies City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murcid(a)">Murcid (<etym lang="la">murcidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">co&shy;

ful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murenger(n)">Murengers,</form> <xpln lang="en">are Officers
yearly elected in the City of
Westchester, who have a care
of the City Walls, and see
them repaired.</xpln></wordentry>

sloathful fellow, fitter to kill
Mice then men.</xpln></wordentry>

Kings were wont to cast their

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muscadel(n)">Muscadel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>) or Mus&shy;
cadine (<etym lang="la">Vinum Muscatum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
kind of wine so called, be&shy;
cause for sweetness and smel
it resembles musk. This wine
comes for the most part from
the Isle Creta or Candy; for this
Island (as Ortelius reports)
yearly transports 12000 Buts
of it. Others say it takes
name from Monte Alcino in
Italy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mosquito(n)">Muscheto,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Gnat.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muscle(n)">Muscle (<etym lang="la">musculus</etym>, dimin.
 <etym lang="la">&agrave; mus</etym>, because a Muscle is
like a flead Mouse)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;
strumental part of the bo&shy;
dy, serving for voluntary
moving the fleshy part of
it, compassed in with the
Strings and Sinews to move
withall, interlaced with
Veins and Arteries, the first
for distribution or nou&shy;
rishment, the other for
preserving natural heat. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muses(n)">Muses (<etym lang="la">Mus&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the feig&shy;

number, and Daughters to
Jupiter and Mnemosyne.

<page sig="cc6v">
 <term lang="la">Musarum nomina &amp; inventa ita tractat Virgili&shy;
us in Epigrammatis. 

1 Clio gesta canens transactis tempora reddit.
2 Melpomene tragico proclamat m&aelig;sta boatu.
Comica lascivo gaudet sermone 3 Thalia.
Dulciloquis calamos 4 Euterpe flatibus instat.
5 Terpsichore affectus cyntharis movet, imperat, auget.
Plectra gerens 6 Erato saleat, pede, carmine, vultu.
Carmine 7 Calliope libris Heroica mandat.
8 Urania c&oelig;li motus scrutatur &amp; astra.
Signa cuncta manu, loquitur 9 Polyhymnia gestu.
Mentis Apolline&aelig; vis has movet undique Musas.
In medio refidens complectitur omnia Ph&oelig;bus. 
</term>

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="musk(n)">Musk (<etym lang="la">moschus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Bar&shy;
barians call it Pat) is brought
out of India, and other hot
Countries, the best of all is
yellowish or of a gold colour.
It comes from a beast like a
Roe or wild Goat, in which
beast the Musk grows in a lit&shy;
tle bag, or bladder. 

Some say it comes from
a little beast like a Mouse.
It is comfortable to the heart
and brain and hot and dry in
operation.</xpln></wordentry>
