<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mute(n)">Mutes (<etym lang="la">mut&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">these let&shy;
ters b. c. d. g. h. k. p. q. t are so
called, because they have
no sound, without the as&shy;
sistance of a vowel, as s hath,
which makes a little his&shy;
sing, before it is joyned in
speech with a Vowel. Dr.
Taylors Gram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mutilate(v)">Mutilate (<etym lang="la">mutilo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
maim, cut off, diminish,
take away or make imper&shy;
fect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myrobalan(n)">Myrobalane (<etym lang="la">myrobalanus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an East-Indian plumb, or the
nut of Egypt, so called,
(whereof there are divers
kinds.)</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="cc7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myriad(n)">Myriad (<etym lang="la">myrias, adis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the number of ten thou&shy;
sand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myriarch(n)">Myriarck (<etym lang="la">myriarches</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Captain of ten thousand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Myrmidons(n)">Myrmidons (<etym lang="la">myrmidones</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
certain people of Thessaly,
that accompanied Achilles go&shy;
ing to Troy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myropolist(n)">Myropolist (<etym lang="la">myropola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
seller of swet Oyls, Ointments
or Perfumes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myrrh(n)">Myrrhe (<etym lang="la">myrrha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a gum
brought out of Arabia and As&shy;
syria, of colour between
white and red; It is hot and
dry in the second degree,
or (as some write) in the
third, and is often used in
Physick, being of an open&shy;
ing, cleansing, and dissolving
nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myrrhine(a)" lexeme="myrrhean(a)">Myrrhine 
Myrrhean  (<etym lang="la">myrrhinus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">of myrrhe,
made of myrrhe, seasoned
with myrrhe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myrtle(n)">Myrtle (<etym lang="la">myrtus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
low Tree, growing in hot
Countries, having smal dark
leaves, and bearing berries,
which are of a binding na&shy;
ture, good to stop any issue
of blood. 

It is a tender plant, not
able to endure cold, and was
wont to be worn by the Ro&shy;
man Captains, Garlandwise in
triumph, when they had ob&shy;
tained any victory, without
slaughter of men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mystagogical(a)">Mystagogical (<etym lang="la">mystagogi&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that interprets mysteries,
or ceremonies, that hath the
keeping and shewing of 
Church-Relicks to strangers.
Sr. Ken. Dig. in his Treatise of
Bodies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mystagogue(n)">Mystagogue (<etym lang="la">mystagogus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
he that hath that office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mysteriarch(n)">Mysteriarck (<etym lang="la">mysteriar&shy;
ches</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the master of holy my&shy;
steries, a chief Prelate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mystical(a)">Mystical (<etym lang="la">mysticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">secret,
hidden, sacred. 

Mystical Theology, is nothing
else in general but certain
Rules, by the practise where&shy;
of, a vertuous Christian
may attain to a nearer, a more
familiar, and beyond all ex&shy;
pression comfortable conver&shy;
sation with God, by arriving
unto, not onely a beleef, but
also an experimental know&shy;
ledge, and preception of his
divine presence, after an ex&shy;
pressible manner in the soul,
&amp;c. Cressy fol.437.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mythology(n)">Mythologie (<etym lang="la">mythologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a declaration of fables, an ex&shy;
pounding or moralizing up&shy;
on a tale. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mythologize(v)">Mythologize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to expound
or moralize a fable, or Poeti&shy;
cal History. 
</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="n"><alpha>N</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nadir(n)"><f type="l"/> NAdir ( <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the point
directly opposite to the
Zenith, which is just under our
feet, as the Zenith over our
heads. The same word is used
in the Lat. Ital. and Span. 
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Naiades(n)">Naiades,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nymphs or Fai&shy;
ries of the Rivers and Foun&shy;
tains. They have their names 


</page>

<page sig="cc7v">
from <etym lang="gk">&nu;&alpha;&#x1f7c;</etym>, to flow or bubble,
as the water doth from a foun&shy;
tain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naiant(a)">Naiant (Fr. <etym lang="fr">nageant</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
term of Heraldry, and sig&shy;
nifies swimming or float&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naif(a)">Naif ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lively, quick,
natural, kindly, proper, no
ways counterfeit. Jewellers
use this word, when they
speak of a Diamond that is
perfect in all its properties,
as in the water, shape, clean&shy;
ness, &amp;c. they say tis a Naif
stone ; others account a Naif
stone to be one that is found
growing naturally in such per&shy;
fection, as if it had been ar&shy;
<emend err="tifically">tificially</emend> cut, and therefore
most esteemed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Napaeae(n)">Nap&aelig;&aelig;,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nymphs or God&shy;
desses of the Woods and
Mountains, so called of <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&alpha;&shy;
&pi;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym>, which signifies the top
of a Hill or woody Val&shy;
ley.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="napthe(n)">Napthe (<etym lang="la">naptha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
marly or chalky clay, where&shy;
unto if fire be put, it kindleth
in such wise, that if a little
water be cast thereon, it
burns more vehemently; li&shy;
quid or soft bitumen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Narcissus(n)">Narcissus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an hearb
called white <term lang="la">Laus tibi</term>, or
white Daffodil. Poets feign
that Narcissus, a fair Boy, be&shy;
ing in love with himself, was
turned into a Lilly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="narcissine(a)">Narcissine (<etym lang="la">narcissinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or <emend err="pertainining">pertaining</emend> to a white
Daffodil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="narcotic(a)">Narcotique (<etym lang="la">narcoticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that makes a member sence&shy;
less, stupefactive, benumming,
depriving of sence. As Nar&shy;
cotic Medecines, which make
the Patient stupefactive, or
some of his members sence&shy;
less.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="narration(n)">Narration (<etym lang="la">narratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a re&shy;
port of a thing, a discourse,
declaration, or relation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="narrative(a)">Narrative (<etym lang="la">narratus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">de&shy;
clarative, reporting, relating,
expressing. It is also used
substantively, as Narration.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nasicornous(a)">Nasicornous (from <etym lang="la">nasus</etym>,
a nose, and <etym lang="la">cornu</etym> a horn)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath a horn on his nose, or a
horned, or horny nose. Dr.
Brown in his Vulgar Errors,
p. 166. speaks of these four
kinds of Nasicornous Insects, or
Beetles described by Muffetus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="natal(a)">Natal (<etym lang="la">natalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">native,
natural, of or belonging to a
nativity or birth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="natalitious(a)">Natalitious (<etym lang="la">natalitius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="natation(n)">Natation (<etym lang="la">natatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a swim&shy;
ming.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nated(a)">Nated (<etym lang="la">natus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">born, bred,
brought forth, framed of na&shy;
ture. Felth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nathaniel(pn)">Nathaniel (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr:</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
gift of God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naturalist(n)">Naturalist ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a natu&shy;
ral Philosopher, one skilled
in the Reason, and causes of
natural things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naturalize(v)">Naturalize (Fr. <etym lang="la">naturali&shy;
zer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make a natural Sub&shy;
ject; to admit into the num&shy;
ber of natural Subjects. At
Rome there were two sorts of
Citizens; some <term lang="la">Cives nati</term> 


</page>

<page sig="cc8r">
Citizens by birth; others <term lang="la">Ci&shy;
vitate donati</term>, Citizens by do&shy;
nation or gift, who because
they were added unto and
registred with the first sort of
Citizens, were thence called
 <term lang="la">Adscriptitii Cives</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naval(a)">Naval (<etym lang="la">navalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to ships, or a Navy of
ships. The Naval Crown was
given to him, who first entred
the enemies ship in a Battle at
Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naucify(v)">Naucifie (<etym lang="la">naucifacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
set nought by, to dis-esteem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nave(n)">Nave ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that part
of a Cart or spinning Wheel,
wherein the Spokes are set,
and in which the Axletree
runs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naufrage(n)">Naufrage (<etym lang="la">naufragium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
wrack on the Sea, loss, detri&shy;
ment, shipwrack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navicular(a)">Navicular (<etym lang="la">navicularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to ships.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navigable(a)">Navigable (<etym lang="la">navigabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
where ships may pass, sail&shy;
able, that will bear a
ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navigerous(a)">Navigerous (<etym lang="la">naviger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that will bear a Vessel or
Ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navigator(n)">Navigator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Say&shy;
ler. We use to say, Sir Fran&shy;
cis Drake was the first that
sailed round about the world,
which may be true in a miti&shy;
gated sence; (viz.) that he
was the first Captain or per&shy;
son of note that atchieved
this enterprize (Magellanus
perishing in the midst of it)
and therefore is reported to
have given for his Devise, 
Globe with this Motto . <term lang="la">Tu pri&shy;
mus circumdedisti me</term>. This
Navigation was begun Ann.
1577, and in two years and
a half with great vicissitude of
fortune, finished. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navity(n)">Navitie (<etym lang="la">navitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dili&shy;
gence, stirring, quickness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naumachy(n)">Naumachie (<etym lang="la">naumachia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a war, or battle at Sea; also
the place where such battle is
fought.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nauseate(v)">Nauseate (<etym lang="la">nauseo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to have
an appetite to vomit; also to
loath or abhor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nauseative(a)" lexeme="nauseous(a)">Nauseative Nauseous  (<etym lang="la">nauseosus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">loathsom, a&shy;
gainst the stomack, that makes
one ready to cast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nautical(a)" lexeme="nautic(a)">Nautical 
Nautick  (<etym lang="la">nauticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to ships
or Marriners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nazal(n)">Nazal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the nose-peece
of a Helmet; the part there&shy;
of that covers the nose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nazarite(pn)">Nazarite (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
a man separated or divided.
The Jews so called those that
had vowed themselves for
some time to God: And
these Nazarites, while their
vow lasted, were to abstain
from Wine and Grapes ei&shy;
ther green or dry, and gene&shy;
rally, from what ever came
from the Vine Tree, or might
make a man drunk. They
also cut not their hair, but
suffered it still to grow, and
observed divers other cere&shy;
monies. The date of their
vow being expired, they pre&shy;
sented themselves to the
Priest, who offered a Sacri&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="cc8v">
fice for them, and then was
the Nazarites hair cut, and
burnt with the Sacrifice; af&shy;
ter which, it was lawful for
them to drink wine as before.
See Numb.6.2.21. The Dis&shy;
ciples were first called Naza&shy;
rites (as the Mahumetans
still call them) from Jesus of
Nazareth, as now Christians 
from Christ; which name
was first given them at An&shy;
tioch by Evodus, Patriark
thereof, who immediately
succeeded St. Peter. Johannes
Antiochanes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neades(n)">Neades,</form> <xpln lang="en">beasts in Samos,
whose bones are so big, they
are kept for a marvel, and
their voyce so strong, it
shakes the earth. Rider.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neap-tide(n)">Neap-Tides,</form> <xpln lang="en">In the Wa&shy;
termens Dialect are, the eb&shy;
bing or smal Tydes.<xref> See
Spring-Tides</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nebulon(n)">Nebulon (<etym lang="la">nebulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Knave,
Rascal, Villain, Scoundrel, one
of no estimation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nebulosous(a)">Nebulosous (<etym lang="la">nebulosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
cloudy, misty, foggy; full
of clouds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="necromancy(n)">Necromancy (<etym lang="la">necroman&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a divination practized
by conjuration and calling
up Devils or dead mens
ghosts; which we read practi&shy;
zed by King Saul (I Reg.
cap.28.) when he required a
Sorceress to call the spirit of
Samuel to him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="necromancer(n)">Necromancer (<etym lang="la">necroman&shy;
tes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that practises that
wicked Art, a Master of the
Black Art, one that seeks to 
the dead. The Hebrews de&shy;
scribe him thus, He made
himself hungry, and then
lodged among the Graves,
that the dead might come to
him in a dream, and make
known unto him that which
he asked, &amp;c. Others there
were that clad themselves
with cloaths for that purpose,
and speak certain words, bur&shy;
ned Incense, and slept by
themselves, that such a dead
person might come and talk
with them in a dream. The
difference between Necroman&shy;
cers and Witches K. James (in
his demonologie) hath taught
in a word; the one (in a sort)
command, the other obey the
Devil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="necromantic(a)">Necromantick (<etym lang="la">necroman&shy;
ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to Necro&shy;
mancy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nectar(n)">Nectar ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pleasant
liquor or drink, that was feig&shy;
ned to be the drink of the
Gods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nectarine(a)" lexeme="nectarean(a)">Nectarine 
Nectarean  (<etym lang="la">nectareus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
immortal, di&shy;
vine, pleasant, like Nectar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="necyomancy(n)">Necyomancie,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same
with Necromancy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nefandous(a)">Nefandous (<etym lang="la">nefandus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hor&shy;
rible, hainous, mischevious,
not to be spoken or na&shy;
med.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nefarious(a)">Nefarious (<etym lang="la">nefarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cur&shy;
sed, unworthy to live, wicked,
detestable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="negative(n)">Negative (<etym lang="la">negativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
denies or gain-sayeth. Two
Negatives make an Affirma&shy;
tive; As he did not give 


</page>

<page sig="dd1r">
nothing, for, he gave some&shy;
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="negative pregnant(n)">Negative pregnant,</form> <xpln lang="en">in our
Common Law, implies also
an Affirmative. As if a man,
being impleaded to have done
a thing upon such a day, or in
such a place, denies he did it,
 <term lang="la">Modo &amp; forma declarata</term>, which
implies nevertheless, That in
some sort he did it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="negatory(a)">Negatory (<etym lang="la">negatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to denial, infi&shy;
ciatory, Negative.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="negotiation(n)">Negotiation (<etym lang="la">negatiatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
buying and selling, traffick,
merchandizing, managing of
business.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="negotious(a)">Negotious (<etym lang="la">negotiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full
of business, ever in action,
much employed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="negro(n)">Negro (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Italian</class> and <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spa&shy;
nish</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Neger or Blackmoor,
whom the Dutch call a
<term lang="du">Swart</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naif(n)">Neif orNief (from the
French <etym lang="fr"> naif</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">naturalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signi&shy;
fies in our Common Law a
Bond-woman, An. I Edw.6.
cap.3. The reason is, because
Women become bound rather
Nativitate, then by any other
means. See <xref>Naif</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nemaean Games(n)">Nem&aelig;an Games (<etym lang="la">nem&aelig;a</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
so called from Nem&aelig;a, a Town
in Greece, where Hercules slew
the Lions, and in honor of
this memorable exploit, were
instituted these Nem&aelig;an games.
which continued famous in
Greece for many ages. The
exercises were, running with
swift Horses, Whorlebats, run&shy;
ing on foot, quoiting, dart&shy; 
ing, wrestling, shooting. Sir
Walter Raleigh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nemesis(pn)">Nemesis,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Goddess of
Revenge, called also Adra&shy;
stia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nemoral(a)">Nemoral (<etym lang="la">nemoralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to a Wood or Grove,
inclosed or beset about with
Woods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nemorivagant(a)">Nemorivagant (<etym lang="la">nemoriva&shy;
gus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wandring in the Wood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nemorous(a)">Nemorous (<etym lang="la">nemorosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full
of Woods, Groves or Trees,
shadowed and dark with
Trees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neogamist(n)">Neogamist (<etym lang="la">neogamus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
newly married, a Bridegroom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neophite(n)">Neophite (<etym lang="la">neophitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any
thing lately planted or set;
one newly entred into any
profession, a man lately con&shy;
verted to the Faith. The Neo&shy;
phite or new Convert (says
Mr. Gregory, p.111.) received a
Taper lighted, and delivered
by the Mystagogus ; which, for
the space of seven days after,
he was to hold in his hand at
Divine Service, sitting in the
Baptistery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neopolitan disease(n)">Neopolitan disease.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See 
Morbus Gallicus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neoterical(a)">Neoterical (<etym lang="la">neotericus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is of late time, newly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nepenthe(n)">Nepenthe (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk"> Nepenthes</etym>)</form> 
<xpln lang="en">a kinde of Herb, which, being
put into Wine, drives away
sadness: Some take it for
Bugloss . Pliny, l.2. c.21.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nephritic(a)">Nephritick (<etym lang="la">nephriticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is troubled with a pain in
the Reins of the back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nepotation(n)">Nepotation (<etym lang="la">nepotatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
wasting or riotousness.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="dd1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neptune(pn)">Neptune (<etym lang="la">Neptunus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
God of the Sea, son to Saturn
and Ops. Hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neptunian(a)">Neptunian (<etym lang="la">Neptunius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to that Sea-God, or
to the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nequient(a)">Nequient (<etym lang="la">nequiens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">not
being able, disable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neread(n)">Neread (<etym lang="la">Nereides</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mare&shy;
maid, or Fish, like a beautiful
Woman down to the Girdle,
and the rest like a Fish: The
Male of these are called Tri&shy;
tons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nereides(pn)">Nereides</form> <xpln lang="en">are also taken
for Nymphs, or Fairies of the
Water, and comes from the
Hebrew <etym lang="he"> Nahar</etym>, i. a Flood or a
River.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nereus(pn)">Nereus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the
Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nero Domitius(pn)">Nero Domitius,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Em&shy;
peror of Rome, infamous for
his cruelty and tyranny; he
murdered his Mother Agrippi&shy;
na, his Brethren, and his Wife
Octavia, his Master Seneca, and
the Poet. Lucane, &amp;c. Hence
Tyrants are called Neroes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nerve(n)">Nerve (<etym lang="la">nervus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sinew,
strength, force, power, stout&shy;
ness, and constancy of minde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nerve(n)">Nerve</form> <xpln lang="en">is that by which
the Brain addes Sence and
Motion to the Body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nervy(a)">Nervy (<etym lang="la">nervosuis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">having
great or many Sinews, strong&shy;
ly made in Body, pithy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nervosity(n)">Nervosity (<etym lang="la">nervositus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
having of Sinews or strength,
fulness of Sinews.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nescience(n)">Nescience (<etym lang="la">nescientia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ig&shy;
norance, want of knowledge.
Mont.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nescious(a)">Nescious (<etym lang="la">nescius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
knoweth not, ignorant of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nestor(pn)">Nestor,</form> <xpln lang="en">a man of great
wisdom and eloquence, that
lived almost three hundred
years. Hence we take it pro&shy;
verbially, when we use Nestor
for a man of great age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nestorians(pn)">Nestorians (so called from
Nestorius, by birth a German,
their first Founder)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of
Hereticks, that hold (among
other enormities) that in
Christ were two Persons, as
well as two Natures, &amp;c.
This Heresie was condemned
by the General Council at E&shy;
phesus. And Nestorius his
Tongue rotted in his mouth,
for having been the Author of
such Blasphemy. He lived in
the days of Theodosius, and
was by him made Bishop of
Constantinople. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nevosity(n)">Nevosity (<etym lang="la">n&aelig;vositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">speck&shy;
edness, fulness of moles or 
freckles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neutral(a)">Neutral (<etym lang="la">neutralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">neuter,
belonging to neither.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neutrality(n)">Neutrality,</form> <xpln lang="en">the not siding
with either part, indifferency.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="New Year's gift(n)">Newyears Gift,</form> <xpln lang="en">or a gift
given the first day of the new
year; The usage came first
from the ancient Romans : For
the Knights used every year,
on the first day of January, to
offer Newyears Gifts in the
Capitol to Augustus C&aelig;sar,
though he were then absent:
Which custom hath descend&shy;
ed to us, albeit in sundry
kindes; for in Italy the great&shy;
est persons give to the mean&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="dd2r">
est; and in England the mean&shy;
est to the greatest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nexible(a)">Nexible (<etym lang="la">nexibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be knit or tied.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nexility(n)">Nexility (<etym lang="la">nexilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fast&shy;
ness, pithiness, compactness of
speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nyas hawk(n)">Nias Hawk (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Nias</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Nestling, or yong Hawk, late&shy;
ly taken out of the Nest; or
any Hawk that was taken out
of the Nest, before she preyed
for her self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nicean(a)">Nicean,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
Nice, a City in Bithinia, where
the first General Council was
held, Anno 314. to which,
there assembled three hundred
and eighteen Bishops, to beat
down the Arrian Heresie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="niche(n)">Nices orNiches (from
the Italian <etym lang="it">Nichi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the hollow
places in a wall, wherein Stat&shy;
tues or Images are set. Sir
H. W.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nicety(n)">Nicete ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sloth, idle&shy;
ness, slackness, simplicity;
hence our word nicety, which
we commonly use for coyness,
daintiness, curiosity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nicholaitans(pn)">Nicholaitans (so called
from Nicholas the Proselyte of
Antioch, one of the seven Dea&shy;
<emend err="ons">cons</emend>ons, which were instituted
with Saint Stephen by the A&shy;
postles)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Hereticks
that held it lawful to have
their wives common, &amp;c. St.
John makes mention of them
in his Apocalipse, where (speak&shy;
ing of the Church of Perga&shy;
mus) he saith. Thou hast them
that hold the doctrine of the Ni&shy;
cholaitans, I part Tr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nicholas(pn)">Nicholas ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Conqueror
of the people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nicodemites(pn)">Nicodemites,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of late
Reformists in Switzerland, so
called, because they make pro&shy;
fession of their Faith in pri&shy;
vate, as Nicodemus did to
Christ. M. Pol. p 5728.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nicotine(n)">Nicotian (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Nicotiane</etym>,
Spa. <etym lang="sp">Nicoctana</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Tobacco, so
called from John Nicot, who
first sent that weed into France
from Portugal, where he was
Ambassador Leiger for the
French King, about the year
1560. About which time,
and at which place he made
that great French and Latin,
(called Nicots) Dictionary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nictation(n)">Nictation (<etym lang="la">nictatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
winking or twinkling with
the eyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nidgery(n)">Nidgeries (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Nigeries</etym>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Fopperies, Fooleries, trifles,
Frivolous bables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nidifice(n)">Nidifice (<etym lang="la">nidificium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Nest, such as Birds make.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nidify(n)">Nidifie (<etym lang="la">nidificio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to build
or make a Nest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="niding(n)">Niding,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old English
word, and signifies an abject,
base minded, fals-hearted co&shy;
ward. In former time this
word was of great force in
England: For when there was
a dangerous Rebellion against
King William Rufus, &amp;c. after
he had but proclaimed, that
his Subjects should repair to
his Camp, upon no other pe&shy;
nalty, but that whoever re&shy;
fused to come, should be re&shy;
puted aNiding; they
swarmed to him immediately 


</page>

<page sig="dd2v">
from all sides in such numbers,
as he had in few days a great
Army, and the Rebels were so
terrified therewith, that they
forthwith yielded. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nidor(n)">Nidor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the savor of
any thing burned or rosted;
sometimes brightness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nidulation(n)">Nidulation (<etym lang="la">nidulatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
building or making a Nest.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nightmare(n)">Night-Mare</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Incubus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nigrefy(v)">Nigrefie (<etym lang="la">nigrefacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make black.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nihilify(v)">Nihilifie (<etym lang="la">nihil facio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to set
nothing by, to disesteem, to
make no account of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nigromancy(n)">Nigromancy.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Necro&shy;
mancy</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nihil dicit(n)">Nihil dicit,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a failing to
put in answer to the Plea of
the Plaintiff, by the day as&shy;
signed; upon which failure,
Judgment passeth against him,
as saying nothing, why it
should not. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nill(n)">Nil ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> <etym lang="bl">niet</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">nihil</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the sparkles or ashes that
come of Brass, tried in the
Furnace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nilus(pn)">Nilus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a great River run&shy;
ing through Ethiope and Egypt
famous for the vertue of its
water, which overflowing
this Country, makes it won&shy;
derful fertile many years af&shy;
ter. This River is in length
almost three thousand miles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nimbiferous(a)">Nimbiferous (<etym lang="la">nimbifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that brings storms or showres.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nimbot(n)">Nimbot ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dwarf,
Dandiprat, or little Skipjack.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nimiety(n)">Nimietie (<etym lang="la">nimietas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">too
great abundance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nimious(a)">Nimious (<etym lang="la">nimius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">too

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ningid(a)" lexeme="ninguid(a)">Ningid orNinguid (<etym lang="la">nin&shy;
guidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">where much Snow is.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nisi prius(n)">Nisi prius,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Writ Judi&shy;
cial, which lies in case where
the Enquest is panelled and
returned before the Justices
of the Bank; the one party
or the other making Petition,
to have his Writ for the ease
of the Country, &amp;c. It is cal&shy;
led Nisi prius, of these words
contained in the same <term lang="la">Nisi die
Lun&aelig; apud talem locum prius
venerint, &amp;c.</term> See <xref>Assize</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nitid(a)">Nitid (<etym lang="la">nitidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Clean, neat,
gay, trim, fair, bright.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nitidity(n)">Nitidity (<etym lang="la">nitiditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Clean&shy;
ness, brightness, trimness,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nitor(n)">Nitor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nitre(n)">Nitre (<etym lang="la">nitrum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Salt-re&shy;
sembling substance, of colour
light, ruddy or white, and
full of holes like a Spunge;
divers late Writers ignorantly
mistake it for Salt-Peter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nitrous(a)">Nitrous (<etym lang="la">nitrosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">having
the savor of Nitre, having
stuff in it, whereof Nitre is
made, full of Nitre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nival(a)" lexeme="niveous(a)">Nival (<etym lang="la">nivalis</etym>)
Niveous (<etym lang="la">niveus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to Snow, white or
cold like Snow, snowy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nixus(pn)">Nixus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the God of Child&shy;
bearing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noblesse(n)">Nobless ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Nobility,
Gentry, Generousness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nobilitate(v)">Nobilitate (<etym lang="la">nobilito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make Noble, to promote to
Dignity.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="dd3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nocent(n)">Nocent (<etym lang="la">nocens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath
done a trespass or injury; that
hurteth or endamageth; a
person guilty, or that hath
offended.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nocive(a)">Nocive (<etym lang="la">nocivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that doth
harm, hurtful, noyous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noctiferous(a)">Noctiferous (<etym lang="la">noctifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
betokens or brings night, the
evening Star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noctivagant(a)">Noctivagant (<etym lang="la">noctivagus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that wandreth by night.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nocturnal(a)">Nocturnal (<etym lang="la">nocturnus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to the night, nightly,
or in the night time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nocturn(n)">Nocturnes (<etym lang="la">nocturni</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a part
of the Office, or certain
Psalms and Prayers so called,
because they are used Nocturno
tempore, in the night.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nocument(n)">Nocument (<etym lang="la">nocumentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
hurt or damage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nocuous(a)">Nocuous (<etym lang="la">nocuus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
doth harm, hurtful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nodosity(n)">Nodosity (<etym lang="la">nodositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="knot"> knot&shy;</emend>
tiness, knobbiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nodous(a)">Nodous (<etym lang="la">nodosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">knotty,
full of knots, knurs, joynts
or difficulties; curious or
scrupulous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noli me tangere(n)">Noli-me-tangere,</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> Do
not touch me. An Herb so
called, because its Seed being
ripe, spurts away so soon as it
is touched: Also a disease so
called, being a peece of flesh
growing in the Nostrils, in
such sort, as it often stops the
Wind, and the more it is
touched, the worse it grows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomarch(n)">Nomark (<etym lang="la">Nomarcha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">He
that hath the preheminence in
the ministration of Laws, as a
Major, or other like Officer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomarchy(n)">Nomarchie (<etym lang="la">nomarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
jurisdiction or Majoralty, a
Law, a County or Shire, a
Territory about some City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nombril(n)">Nombreil (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Nombril</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Navel)</form> <xpln lang="en">in Heraul&shy; 
dry it signifies the lower part
of a Scutcheon, which is di&shy;
vided by the breadth into
three even parts. The Fesse be&shy;
ing the middle, and the Honor
Point, the uppermost part.
Guillim.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomenclator(n)">Nomenclator (Lat. <etym lang="la">Quais
nominis calator</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that knows
the names of things, and calls
them thereby; a common Crier
in a Court of Justice; a Bedel
or like Officer, to whom it be&shy;
longs to know by heart, the
names, offices, and crafts of all
the Citizens, thereby to in&shy;
struct such, as among the Ro&shy;
mans did stand and labor for
any office, that they might
speak to them more gently.
Thomasius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomenclature(n)">Nomenclature (<etym lang="la">nomenclatu&shy; 
ra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the numbring of names or
Surnames of sundry things;
the office of the Nomenclator.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nominal(a)">Nominal (<etym lang="la">nominalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to a name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nominalia(n)">Nominalia.</form> <xpln lang="en">A Feast among
the Romans : To Females they
gave the name on the eighth
day, to Males on the nineth,
which they called <term lang="la">Dies lustri&shy;
cus</term>, as it were the cleansing
day, on which they solemni&shy;
sed this Feast; and (as Tertullian
notes) <term lang="la">Fata adscribenda advoca&shy;
bantur</term>, that is (as I conceive)
their Nativities were set.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="dd3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomination(n)">Nomination (<etym lang="la">nominatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a naming or appointing; It
is used both by the Common
Lawyers and Canonists for a
power that a man, by ver&shy;
tue of a Mannor or other&shy;
wise, hath to appoint a Clerk
to a Patron of a Benefice, by
him to be presented to the Or&shy;
dinary. New Terms of the
Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomographer(n)">Nomographer (<etym lang="gk">&nu;&omicron;&mu;&omicron;&gamma;&rho;&#x03ac;&shy;
&phi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a writer of the Law; a
Legislator.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nomothesy(n)">Nomothesie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
making, publishing, or pro&shy;
claiming a Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nonage(n)">Nonage (Fr. <etym lang="fr">non aage</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <etym lang="la">non &aelig;tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">not yet of age, mi&shy;
nority; that is all the time
of a mans age <emend err="unper">under</emend> One and
twenty years in some cases,
and fourteen in some, as mar&shy;
riage. See Brook. Tit. Age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="non compos mentis(n)">Non compos mentis</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> not
in his right wits, is of four
sorts; 1 He that is an Ideot 
born; Next he that by acci&shy;
dent wholly loseth his wits.
Thirdly, a Lunatick, that has
sometime his understanding,
and sometimes not; Lastly,
he that by his own act de&shy;
prives himself of his right
mind for a time, as a Drunk&shy;
ard Vide Coke lib.4. fo.124. b.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nona(pn)" lexeme="Decima(pn)" lexeme="Morta(pn)">Nona, Decima and Morta</form>
<xpln lang="en">the three fatal Ladies, whom
the Greeks call Clotho, Lache&shy;
sis and Atropos.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="non liquet(n)">Non liquet. <expan type="">id est</expan></form> <xpln lang="en">It appears
not, it is not clear, it likes
not. Also a verdict given by
the Jury signifying, that the 
matter was to be deferred to
another day of trial; Igno&shy;
ramus with us, or a Repri&eacute; .it was wont to be put down
in a Scrowle or Tablet by
these letters (N. L.) like as
guilty, or <term lang="la">condemnatio</term> by (C)
quitting by A. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">absolutus</term>. 
Carol. Sigon de Judiciis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="non-residency(n)">Non-residency,</form> <xpln lang="en">unlawful
absence from the place of his
charge, most commonly spo&shy;
ken of Ministers and their
Cures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="non suit(n)">Non suit,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Renuncia&shy;
tion of the Suit by the Plain&shy;
tiff or Defendant, when the
matter is so far proceeded in,
as the Jury is ready at the
Bar to deliver their Verdict.
An.2 H4. ca.7., See the new
book of Entries, verbo, nonsuit.
The Civilians term it Litis re&shy;
nunciationem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nones(n)">Nones (<etym lang="la">non&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in March,
May, July and October, are the
six daies next following the
first day, or the Calends; In
other moneths they are the
four daies next after the first;
But the last of these days is
properly called Nones, and
the other reckoned back&shy;
ward, according to the num&shy;
ber distant from the Nones, as
the third, fourth, or fifth
Nones. Hoptons Concordance,
p.70.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="none of the day(n)">None of the day,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
third quarter of the day be&shy;
gining at Noon and lasting till
the Sun be gon half way to&shy;
wards setting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="non obstante(n)">Non obstante ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">not&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="dd4r">
withstanding, nevertheless, a
word much used in our Sta&shy;
tutes, Patents, and other
writings, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="non plus(n)">Non plus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">no more;
a term often used, when a
man can say no more, nor
answer an objection; then he
is said to be at a Nonplus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nonupla(n)">Nonupla,</form> <xpln lang="en">a quick time in
Musick peculiar to Gigs and
such like; having nine
Crotchets between Bar and
Bar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="normal(a)">Normal (<etym lang="la">normalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">right
by rule, made by the square
or Rule.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="norrel ware(n)">Norrel ware,</form> <xpln lang="en">corruptly so
called in some part of Eng&shy;
land for Lorimers .<xref> See Lori&shy;
mer</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Norrey(pn)" lexeme="Norroy(pn)">Norrey orNorroy,</form> <xpln lang="en">King
at Arms.<xref> See Harold</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nostoch(n)">Nostoch</form> <xpln lang="en">(says Dr Charlton
in his Paradoxes p.100 is the
nocturnal pollution of some
plethorical and wanton star,
or rather excrement blown
from the nostrils of som rheu&shy;
matick Planet, falling upon
spacious fields, plains and
sheep pastures, of an obscure
red or brown tawny, in con&shy;
sistence like a gelly, and to
trembling if touched; which
the Philosophy of the clouted
shoo affirms to bee the ruins
of a star fallen. Some there
are (saith Dorn&aelig;us) who by
Nostoch intend wax, but by
the favor of a metaphor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="notary(n)">Notarie (<etym lang="la">notarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Scribe
or Scrivener, that onely takes
notes, or makes a short 
draught of contracts, obliga&shy;
tions or other instruments;
these notes he may deliver to
the parties that gave him in&shy;
structions, if they desire no
more; but if they do, he
must deliver them to a Tabel&shy;
lion, who draws them at large,
ingrosses them in parchment,
&amp;c. and keeps a Register of
them, but this is not generally
observed; for in many Towns
of France the Notaries are al&shy;
so Tabessions . Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="notification(n)">Notification (<etym lang="la">notificatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
information, signification, ad&shy;
vertisement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="notion(n)">Notion (<etym lang="la">notio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">knowledge,
understanding; acquain&shy;
tance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Novatians(pn)">Novatians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of He&shy;
reticks whereof one Novatus 
was first Author about the
year 215, he condemned se&shy;
cond Marriages, and held that
such as had once faln or were
in Apostacy ought no more to
be received into the Church,
although they were repentant
<emend err="the efore">therefore</emend>, &amp;c. This Heresie was
condemned by a Council at
Rome.<xref> See Catharians</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novator(n)">Novator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
makes a thing new, a renew&shy;
er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novels(n)">Novels</form> <xpln lang="en">of the Civil Law
are in number 168. into
which the 91 Collations of the
Authenticks (which were set
out after the Codex by Justi&shy;
nian, then Emperor, and
brought into the body of the
Civil Law) were divided.
They were called Novelles 


</page>

<page sig="dd4v">
(says Cujatius) <term lang="la">quod novissime
promulgat&aelig; sint post Cod</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novenary(a)">Novenary (<etym lang="la">novenarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
nine, that consists of nine</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novendial(a)">Novendial (<etym lang="la">novendialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of nine days space or conti&shy;
nuance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novennial(a)">Novennial (<etym lang="la">novennis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
nine years.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novae tabulae(n)">Nov&aelig; tabul&aelig; ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was an
easement proposed in favour
of debtors at Rome, whereby
the old debt books, and obli&shy;
gations were cancelled; or
the nomina dashed out; A&shy;
mong the Athenians this
practise was called Sisacthia <expan type="">id est</expan>
an easing of burthen or Chre&shy;
copia, a cutting off, or striking
out of debts. Livie</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novercal(a)">Novercal (<etym lang="la">novercalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

or mother in Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novice(n)">Novice (from the Lat. <etym lang="la">no&shy;
viss</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a young Monk or Nun;

into the Order; also a young&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nowed(a)">Nowed,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heral&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="numerical(a)">Numerical,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to

<emend err="" source="errata">say</emend>the last difference, by

is distinguished from ano&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nuncupative(a)">Nuncupative (<etym lang="la">nuncupati&shy;
vus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">called, named, pronoun&shy;
ced, expresly declared by
word of mouth. 

A Will Nuncapative, is when
the Testator makes his will
by word of mouth (not by
writing) before sufficient
witnesses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nundinal(a)" lexeme="nundinary(a)">Nundinal 
Nundinarie (<etym lang="la">nundinari&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to Fairs or Markets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nundination(n)">Nundination (<etym lang="la">nundina&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a trafficking in Fairs or
Markets buying and selling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nun(n)">Nun (<etym lang="la">nona <expan type="">que</expan> non nupta</etym> 
Teut.<etym lang="gr">Nunn</etym>. Belg.<etym lang="bl">Nonne</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a holy or consecrated Vir&shy;
gin, or a woman that by vow
has bound her self to a single
and chaste life, in some place
and company of other wo&shy;
men, separated from the world,
and addicted to an especial
service of God, by prayer, fast&shy;
ing and such like holy exerci&shy;
ses. Cow. 

St. Hierom makes (<term lang="la">nonna</term>) ori&shy;
ginally an &AElig;gyptian word,
as Hospinian records of him, in
his book <term lang="la">de origine &amp; progressu
monachatus</term>, fo.3. Of these
there are several Orders;
Scholastica (the Sister of
St. Benedict) was the first
that collected them into
companies and prescribed
them orders : Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nuncio(n)">Nuntio (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital</class> and <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class> 
<class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">Nuncius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Le&shy;
gate or Ambassador from the
Pope.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nuptial(a)">Nuptial (<etym lang="la">nuptialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to a wedding, marri&shy;
age or Bridal. 

Nuptial gifts were certain
tokens, which the Husband
sent his Mistress before the
betrothing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nuptialist(n)">Nuptialist (from <etym lang="la">nupti&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Bride or Wife; or a Bride&shy;
groom or Husband; Also
one that makes Marriages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nuisance(n)">Nusance (Fr. <etym lang="fr">nusance</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hurt,
offence, annoyance, da&shy;
mage, Trespass. In Law
it is, where any man erects
any wall, stops any wa&shy;
ter, or doth any thing up&shy;
on his own ground to the
unlawful hurt or annoyance
of his neighbors; he that is
grieved may have thereof an
Assize of Nusance. New
Terms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nutation(n)">Nutation (<etym lang="la">nutatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">nod&shy;
ding, as one doth when he
sits sleeping.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nutriment(n)">Nutriment (<etym lang="la">nutrimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
nourishment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nutritive(a)" lexeme="nutritious(a)">Nutritive

</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to nourishment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nymph(n)">Nymph (<etym lang="la">Nympho</etym>. <class type="etymlang" lang="br">Brit.</class> 
<etym lang="br">Nymph</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bride or new
married wife. 

Hence those Virgin-God&shy;
desses of the Woods, moun&shy;
tains and waters had this
name, as the Nap&aelig;&aelig;, O&shy;
reades, Dryades, Hamadryades,
Naiades, Nereides, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

not tell out his tale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obbuction(n)">Obbuction (<etym lang="la">obuctio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cover&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obdurate(a)">Obdurate (<etym lang="la">obduratus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hard&shy;
ned, also unrelenting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obelize(v)">Obelise (from <etym lang="la">obelus</etym>
and <etym lang="la">obeliscus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make a long
stroke in writing, to signifie
somewhat to be put out; to
raze out. Mr. White.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obelisk(n)">Obelisk (<etym lang="la">obeliscus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
great square stone broad
beneath, and waxing smal&shy;
ler towards the top. There
were divers of these in
&AElig;gypt consecrated in honor
of the Sun; whereof four
were principally erected by
King Sochis, of wonderful
height; Many Obeliskes were
likewise at Rome in time of
the Roman Emperors. The
difference between an Obe&shy;
liske and a Pyramid was this,
the Obelisk was all of one
entire stone or peece, and
therefore of no such height
as the Pyramids, which were
of divers stones; and again
the Obelisk is four square, 
whereas the Pyramis may be
of other figure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obequitate(v)">Obequitate (<etym lang="la">obequito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
ride about.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obesity(n)">Obesity (<etym lang="la">obesitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fatness,
grosness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="objectator(n)">Objectator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
reproacheth or lays to ones
charge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obit(n)">Obit (<etym lang="la">obitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the death,
dying or decay of one; the
setting or going down of the
Sun. 

It is also sometimes taken
for an Elegy or Funeral
song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="objuration(n)">Objuration (<etym lang="la">objuratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
binding by oath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="objurgation(n)">Objurgation (<etym lang="la">objurgatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
chiding, rebuking, repro&shy;
ving or blaming.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="objurgatory(a)">Objurgatory (<etym lang="la">objurgatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to chiding, check&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oblat(n)">Oblat ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Souldier,
who, grown impotent or
maimed in Service, hath
maintenance or the bene&shy;

ed him in an Abbey; Also
the means or place of a
Monk, or such Souldier,
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oblation(n)">Oblation (<etym lang="la">oblatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an offer&shy;
ing; an aid or Subsidy mo&shy;
ney. Oblations are thus de&shy;
fined in the Cannon Law.
 <term lang="la">Oblationes dicuntur qu&aelig;cunque
&agrave; piis fidelibusque Christianis
offeruntur Deo &amp; Ecclesi&aelig;,
sive res soli, sive mobiles
sint. Nec refert an legentur
Testamento, an aliter donen&shy;
tur</term> . Cap. Clerici 13. qu&aelig;st. 2. 


</page>

<page sig="dd6r">
See Duarenuus de Sacr. Ec&shy;
cles. Minister. ac Benef. cap.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oblocutor(n)">Oblocutor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an evill

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oblong(n)">Oblong,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Geometri&shy;
cal term for a Quadrangu&shy;
lar figure, whose <emend err="lentgh">length</emend> ex&shy;
ceeds its breadth, of which the
most proper (distinguished by
their several terms) are these
six. 1. Sesquialter, which is
when half the height is added
to its length. 2. Sesquiter&shy;
tia, when a third part is ad&shy; 
ded to its length. 3. Sesqui&shy;
quarta, when a fourth part is
added. 4. Diagonea, when
the Oblong is increased to the
length of the Diagonal of the
single square. 5. <term lang="la">Superbitiens
tertias</term>, so called (<term lang="la">quasi</term> <term lang="la">super
bis tertias</term>) because the length
thereof is increased by two
thirds. 6. and lastly, <term lang="la">Dupla</term>,
which is a double square.
Enchyr. of Fortif.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obloquy(n)">Obloquy (<etym lang="la">obloquium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
speaking against, an evil re&shy;
port.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obmutescence(n)">Obmutescence (from <etym lang="la">ob&shy;

Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obnunciation(n)">Obnunciation (<etym lang="la">obnuncia&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a forbidding a thing up&shy;
on foreknowledge, conjecture
or likelihood of its ill suc&shy;
cess. As the ancient Romans
were wont to dissolve their 


</page>

<page sig="dd6v">
Assemblies (which dissolution
they called <etym lang="la">obnunciation</etym>) when
soever any evil token was seen
or heard, either by the Magi&shy;
strate or Augur . Godwin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obol(n)">Obole (<etym lang="la">obolus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coyn,
variable according to the
Country, with us it is an half&shy;
penny: Junius takes it for a
penny farthing of our money;
others, for a small Coyn worth
seven pence. Also a half&shy;
penny weight, twelve grains
among Apothecaries, and
fourteen among Mintmen and
Goldsmiths. <term lang="la">Obolus terr&aelig;</term>, five
foot in breadth, and ten in
length.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obreption(n)">Obreption (<etym lang="la">obreptio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
creeping or stealing to a thing
by crafty means, the getting
or obtaining it by dissimulati&shy;
on or private cousenage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obrogate(v)">Obrogate (<etym lang="la">obrogo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
check or interrupt one in his
tale, to gainsay. To abrogate
a Law, is to proclaim a contra&shy;
ry Law, for taking away the
former.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obrumpent(a)">Obrumpent (<etym lang="la">obrumpens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
breaking or bursting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obscene(a)">Obscene (<etym lang="la">obsc&oelig;nus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">all

ed. filthy, unclean, unchast,
dishonest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obscenity(n)">Obscenity (<etym lang="la">obsc&oelig;nitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">vil&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obsecrate(v)">Obsecrate (<etym lang="la">obsecro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to be&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Observants(pn)" lexeme="Observantins(pn)">Observants orObservan&shy;
tins,</form> <xpln lang="en">a branch of the Order

led Franciscans, instituted by
St. Francis of Assisium, distinct
from the Minims or Bonhomes,
instituted by St. Francis de
Paula.<xref lexeme="friar"> See Friars</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obsession(n)">Obsession (<etym lang="la">obsessio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lay&shy;
ing of siege, a beleaguring or
compassing about: A man is
said to be obsest, when an evil
spirit hants him, troubling
him divers times, and seeking
opportunity to enter into
him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obsibilate(v)">Obsibilate (<etym lang="la">obsibilo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obsidian stone(n)">Obsidian stone (<etym lang="la">obsidianus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obsidional(a)">Obsidional (<etym lang="la">obsidionalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or pertaining to a siege. 

The Obsidional Crown (<etym lang="la">Coro&shy;
na obsidionalis</etym>) was given one&shy;
ly to him that relieved a City
or Town besieged: This
Crown was made of Green
Leaves, or of the Grass and
Herbs of the same Field, where
the enemy had been over&shy;
thrown, or forced to flight.
The great Quintus Fabius re&shy;
ceived this Crown, for de&shy;
fending and delivering Rome
from the siege of Hannibal.
&AElig;millius Scipio was crowned
therewith in Affrica, for ha&shy;
ving delivered the Consul
Manlius with certain Bands.
Calphurnius also obtained it in
Sicily, with others. 2 part. Tr.
Oftimes.</xpln></wordentry>

or swelling, which being

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="offertory(n)">Offertory (<etym lang="la">offertorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
offering, or place where offer&shy;
ings are offered or kept;
also a part of the Mass so
called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="official(a)">Official (<etym lang="la">officialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to offices or duties.
It is a word diversly us'd; some
apply it to such as have the
sway of Temporal Justice, o&shy;
thers to the Minister or Appa&shy;
ritor of a Magistrate or Judge.
In the Cannon Law it is espe&shy;
cially taken for him, to whom
any Bishop generally commits
the charge of his Spiritual
Jurisdiction: And in this
sence, one in every Diocess is
( <term lang="la">Officialis Principalis</term>) whom
the Statues and Laws of this
Nation call Chancelors . Anno
32 Hen.8. cap.15. And are 
sometimes termed Commissa&shy;
ries; the difference of the
two powers, you may read in
Linwood, tit. De sequest possess.
cap. I. <term lang="la">Verbo, Officialis</term>. But
this word Official in our Sta&shy;
tues and Common Law, sig&shy;
nifies him whom the Arch&shy;
deacon substitutes in the
executing his Jurisdiction.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="officinator(n)">Officinator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Ar&shy;
tificer or Craftsman. Vitruvius
( lib.6. cap. 11.) distinguishes
the Officinator from the Archi&shy;
tect ; This designs the Idea of
the whole work; that is but a
second superintendent over all
the under Artisans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="officine(n)">Officine (<etym lang="la">officina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Shop
or Work-house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="offuscate(v)">Offuscate (<etym lang="la">offusco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
black or dark, to shadow or
make dim or duskish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ogdoastich(n)">Ogdastick (<etym lang="la">ogdastichon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

prised in eight verses, or a
Stanza of eight verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ogive(n)" lexeme="ogee(n)">Ogive orOgee (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Au&shy;

to make oyl of; also oyli&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oleron Laws(pn)">Oleron Laws, orLaws
of Oleron;</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, for that
they were made by K. Richard
the First, when he was there.
Cokes Inst. pars I. pag.206. b 
This Oleron is an Island near
Rochel, belonging to the
French.</xpln></wordentry>

smell. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

from the peace bringing Olive,
as Daphnis and Laurence, from
the triumphant Laurel . Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="olivaster(n)">Olivaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a wilde Olive&shy;

sence the Lord Bacon uses it, in
his Nat. Hist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oliviferous(a)">Oliviferous (<etym lang="la">olivifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="olla(n)">Olla ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pot to boil
meat in; and by figure is
taken for the meat it self boil&shy;
ed in it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="olla podrida(n)">Olla podrida,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Hotchpot
of several ingredients; Mr.
Howel, in one of his Letters,
describes it thus. The Olla po&shy; 
drida hath Intellectuals and
Sences: Mutton, Beef, and Ba&shy;
con, are to her as the Will, Un&shy;
derstanding and Memory are to
the Soul; Cabbage, Turnips,
Artichocks, Potatoes, and Dates,
are her five Sences, and Pepper 
the common Sence: She must
have Marrow to keep life in
her, and some Birds to make
her light, and by all means
she must be adorned with
some chains of Sausages, &amp;c.
This dish hath been, and still
is much in request with us,
and is commonly pronounced
Ollia ; the second l in Span&shy;
ish being melted in the pro&shy;
nounciation like an i . This
dish hath some Analogy
with that the French call a
Bisque.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Olympiad(n)">Olympiad (<etym lang="la">olympias, adis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the space of five years, or of
eighty moneths, thirty days
to a moneth, which was the
Epoch of the Grecians, and so
used from the time of cele&shy;
brating their Olympick Games,
which was every fifth year,
and the interval was called an
Olympiad . See more of this in
Mr. Gregorie, De &AElig;ris &amp; E&shy;
pochis, cap.7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Olympic Games(pn)">Olympick Games (<etym lang="la">olym&shy;
pia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Games instituted by Her&shy;
cules in honor of Jupiter, they
were celebrated every fifth
year in the Plains of Elis, a
City of Peloponnesus, and the
Exercises were five, Running,
Wrastling, Leaping, Quoiting,
and Whorle-bats . The reward
to those that overcame in these 


</page>

<page sig="ee1r">
feats of activity was nothing
but a Garland of Olive bran&shy;
ches, lest coveteousness, ra&shy;
ther then vertue, should
make them strive for victory;
They took name from the
City Olympia, otherwise Pisa.
Sir Wal. Ral. lib.2. fol.
490.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Olympias(pn)">Olympias ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">heaven&shy;
ly; a womans name, but some
use Olympha.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="onomancy(n)">Onomancie (<etym lang="la">onomantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
divination by names; also
the skill of repeating many
names by the art of memory.
Cot. 

The Pythagoreans judged
the even number of vowels in 


</page>

<page sig="ee1v">
names to signifie imperfecti&shy;
ons in the left sides of men,
and the odd number, in the
right.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="onomantical(a)">Onomantical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
unto, or skilful in that kind

oyl and wax.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="onyx(n)">Onyx (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a precious
stone found in the mountains
of Arabia of the colour of a
mans nail. Some write, that
it is congealed of a juyce
dropping from a tree called
Onycha, which is the cause it
smels sweet being <emend err=" ast">cast</emend> into
the fire, as also that it is of&shy;
ten found with divers pictures
in it, being easily therein fa&shy;
shioned, before the stone be
thoroughly hardned. This
stone is called by some the
Chalcidonie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opal(n)">Opal (<etym lang="la">opalum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a precious
stone of divers colours, where&shy;
in appears the fiery shining of
the Carbuncle, the purple co&shy;
lour of the Amethyst, and the
greeness of the Emerald very
strangely mixed together.
Plin. lib,37. ca.6.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opacity(n)">Opacitie (<etym lang="la">opacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">shad&shy;
ow of trees, Umbrage. Dr.
Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opaque(a)" lexeme="opacous(a)">Opaque 
Opacous (<etym lang="la">opacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sha&shy;
dowed, in the
shade, dark, obscure, black.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opera(n)">Opera ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a work, la&shy;
bor, <emend err="indust y">industry</emend>, diligence, stu&shy;
dy, &amp;c. In Italy it signifies
a tragedy, Tragi-Comedy,
Comedy or Pastoral, which
(being the studied work of a 
Poet) is not acted after the
vulgar manner, but performed
by Voyces in that way, which
the Italians term Recitative,
being likewise adorned with
Scenes by Perspective, and ex&shy;
traordinary advantages by
Musick. The common Plays
(which are not Opera' s) are
performed <term lang="la">ex tempore</term> by the
Actors, and are but in the na&shy;
ture of Farces or Gigs, want&shy;
ing the above mentioned a&shy;
<emend err="doruments">dornments</emend>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="operarious(a)">Operarious (<etym lang="la">operarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to the workman,
done with labor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="operator(n)">Operator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
worketh; a workman.</xpln></wordentry>

a covering.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opertaneous(a)">Opertaneous (<etym lang="la">opertaneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
done within doors, in secret
or in covert.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ophthalmy(n)">Ophthalmie (<etym lang="la">ophthalmia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an inflammation of the ut&shy;
termost skin of the eye called
Aduata, proceeding either
of fulness of the body, or of
the sharp biting cholerick
humor, or of gross humors, and
windiness puffing up the
place. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opiferous(a)">Opiferous (<etym lang="la">opifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which
aids or helps, succoring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opinable(a)">Opinable (<etym lang="la">opinabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

ny thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opinative(a)" lexeme="opiniative(a)">Opinative

Dr. Bram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opisthograph(n)">Opisthograph (<etym lang="la">opisthogra&shy;
