<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opitulate(v)">Opitulate (<etym lang="la">opitulor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to help,
succour, or aid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opobalsamum(n)">Opobalsamum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Gum of the Balm tree.<xref> See
Balm</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppication(n)">Oppication (<etym lang="la">oppicatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
covering with pitch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opium(n)">Opium ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">or Opiate,
the juyce of black Poppy,
sold dry by Apothecaries. It
is sometimes used in Physick
or cause sleep, or to asswage
excessive pain, but then it must
be mixed with other things,
and given with great discreti&shy;
on; for taken alone, it will
cast one into a deadly sleep;
being cold and dry in the
fourth degree. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppignorate(v)">Oppignorate (<etym lang="la">oppignoro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to lay in pledge, to gage or
pawn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppilation(n)">Oppilation (<etym lang="la">oppilatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an 
obstruction or stopping of
the Liver, or other chief en&shy;
trals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppilative(a)">Oppilative (<etym lang="la">oppilatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ob&shy;
structive, stopping, shut up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppletion(n)">Oppletion (<etym lang="la">oppletio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fil&shy;
ling up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opportune(a)">Opportune (<etym lang="la">opportunus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
meet, for the purpose, fit, con&shy;
venient, in due time, and as it
ought to be.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opposite(n)">Opposite (<etym lang="la">oppositum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a con&shy;
trary. 

Aristotle makes four kinds
of Opposites, first, those that
are relativ&egrave; opposita, as the
<emend err="Husbaad">Husband</emend> and the Wife, the
Master and the Servant, &amp;c.
which have reference each to
other. Secondly, those
which are Contraria ; as Right 
and Wrong ; Ignorance and
Science, &amp;c. Thirdly, Those
that are privativ&egrave; opposita, as
Light and Darkness ; Sight 
and Blindness, which things
succeed and deprive one a&shy;
nother. <emend err="Fourthly," source="errata"></emend> The <emend err="fourh">fourth</emend>
and last kind of Opposites are
those, which in Propositions
and Clauses are Contradicen&shy;
tia, the one affirming, and the
other negative, &amp;c. J. Dode&shy;
ridge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opprobrious(a)">Opprobrious (<etym lang="la">opprobrio&shy;
sus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">reproachful in words,
upbraiding, reviling, taunt&shy;
ing</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppugn(v)">Oppugn (<etym lang="la">oppugno</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to as&shy;
salt, to batter, to lay seige un&shy;
to, to fight against; Also
to reason against a thing ear&shy;
nestly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opsimathy(n)">Opsimathie (<etym lang="la">opsimathia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a 


</page>

<page sig="ee2v">
learning when one is old.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opsonator(n)">Opsonator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a buyer
or purveyer of meats; a Ca&shy;
ter, a Manciple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optable(a)">Optable (<etym lang="la">optabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is
to be desired, wished, or look&shy;
ed for.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optation(n)">Optation (<etym lang="la">optatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">choyce,
opinion, wishing, desiring.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optative(n)">Optative (<etym lang="la">optatum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wish
or desire. It is also used ad&shy;
jectively, as wishing for, or
that desireth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optic(a)" lexeme="optical(a)">Optick 
Optical (<etym lang="la">opticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to the sight.
Optick sinews are those which
bring the vertue of seeing to
the eyes. So the Optick Sci&shy;
ence is that by which the rea&shy;
son of sight is known; Art
speculative.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optimacy(n)">Optimacy (from <etym lang="la">optima&shy;
tes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Government in a Com&shy;
monwealth, by noble or other
chief persons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optimity(n)">Optimitie (<etym lang="la">optimitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">u&shy;
tility, great profit, excellen&shy;
cy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="option(n)">Option (<etym lang="la">optio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">choyce, or
election.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="optive(a)">Optive (<etym lang="la">optivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Adop&shy;
tive</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opulency(n)">Opulencie (<etym lang="la">opulentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
riches, abundance, plenty,
wealth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opulent(a)">Opulent (<etym lang="la">opulentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rich,
plentiful, wealthy, abun&shy;
dant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="opuscule(n)">Opuscule (<etym lang="la">opusculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
little work, a little labor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="or(n)">Or ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Gold; In He&shy;
raldry, it signifies gold co&shy;
lour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oracle(n)">Oracle (<etym lang="la">oraculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sen&shy;
tence, Council or Answer gi&shy;
ven by God; also a worthy
or notable saying or judge&shy;
ment; a Prophesie or Pre&shy;
diction. 

Among the Gentiles these
Oracles were but illusions of
the Devil, who answered for
the most part doubtfully in
Idols, to questions made to
him. As a great Prince, go&shy;
ing to the Wars, and deman&shy;
ding of the Oracle what suc&shy;
cess he should have, had
this ambiguous answer given
him. 
<term lang="la">Ibis redibis nunquam per bella peribis</term>. 
Which he thus <emend err="commaing">commanding</emend>,
<term lang="la">Ibis, redibis, nunquam per &amp;c.</term>
ventured on the War, and
was slain. 

There were two principal
places of Oracles, one of Am&shy;
mon in Lybia, the other at
Delphi in Bo&oelig;tia; at the first
Jupiter, in this Apollo were said 
to give answers. These Ora&shy;
cles ceased at the comming of
our Savior, at which time
August C&aelig;sar (then reigning)
consulting with an Oracle a&shy;
bout his Successor, recieved
this not satisfying answer in
Greek, 


</page>

<page sig="ee3r">
<term lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&#x1FD6;&#x03C2; &#x1F10;&beta;&rho;&alpha;,&#x1FD6;&omicron;&#x03C2; &kappa;&#x03AD;&lambda;&epsilon;&tau;&alpha;&iota; &mu;&omicron; '&delta;&epsilon;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&#x03C2; &mu;&alpha;&kappa;&alpha;&rho;&epsilon;&omicron;&#x03C3;&iota;&nu; &alpha;&nu;&#x03AC;&omicron;&#x03C3;&alpha;&nu;,
&Tau;&#x03CC;&nu; &delta;&epsilon; &delta;&omicron;&mu;&omega;&nu; &pi;&rho;&omicron;&lambda;&iota;&pi;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;, &kappa;&alpha;&iota; &#x1F04;&delta;&eta;&nu; &alpha;&epsilon;&delta;&iota;&epsilon; &#x1F10;&kappa;&#x03AD;&delta;&alpha;&iota;; 
&Lambda;&omicron;&iota;&pi;&#x1F78;&nu;, &alpha;&pi;&iota;&delta;&iota;&#x03C3;&iota;&gamma;&#x1FF6;&nu; &epsilon;&kappa; &beta;&omega;&mu;&#x1F7C;&nu; &#x1F25;&mu;&epsilon;&tau;&epsilon;&rho;&omega;&nu; ---- </term> 

An Hebrew Child whom the blest Gods adore,
Hath bid me leave these Shrines and pack to Hell,
So that of Oracles I can no more: 
In silence leave our Altar, and farewell.
Heyl.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oracular(a)">Oracular,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
an Oracle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oral(a)">Oral (from <etym lang="la">Os, oris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the mouth, visage,
face, look, favor or voyce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oratory(n)">Oratory (<etym lang="la">oratorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a place
wholly dedicated to prayer;
a Closet, a private Chappel to
pray in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oratorians(pn)">Oratorians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Religious
Fraternity or Order Institu&shy;
ted the last age by St. Phil&shy;
lip Nerius, a Florentine
Priest; They took name
from the place first frequen&shy;
ted by them for their exer&shy;
cises of Preaching, and Ca&shy;
techising, which was the
Oratory of St. Hierom in Rome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orbation(n)">Orbation (<etym lang="la">orbatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a depri&shy;
ving or bereaving one of his
goods, or of any other thing;
poverty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orbical(a)" lexeme="orbicular(a)">Orbical 
Orbicular  (<etym lang="la">orbicus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">round like a
circle, circular, globie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orbiculated(a)">Orbiculated (<etym lang="la">orbiculatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
made round in the form of a
circle or compass:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orbity(n)">Orbitie (<etym lang="la">orbitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the want
of children on the Parents
part, the want of parents on
the childrens part; any want
or privation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orchil(n)">Orchal (<etym lang="la">orca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stone
like Allum used sometimes
by Dyers to raise a red co&shy;
lour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ordeal(n)">Ordael orOrdeal (<etym lang="la">ordali&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies as much as judge&shy;
ment, and is compounded,
(as some say) of two Saxon
words, <etym lang="sx">Or</etym>, a privative, as
[ <term lang="gk">A</term>] in Greek, and<etym lang="sx">d&aelig;l</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> 
<term lang="la">pars, q. Expers</term>. But it is ar&shy;
tificially used for a kind of
purgation, practised in anti&shy;
ent times, whereby the party
purged was judged <term lang="la">Expers cri&shy;
minis</term>, called in the Common
Law, <term lang="la">Purgatio vulgaris</term>, and
utterly condemned by Pope
Steven the second. There were
of this, four sorts, one by
Kampfight (not unlike our
Duel.) The second called
Fire-Ordeal, which was for
the accused to pass, blind&shy;
fold with bare feet over hot
Plowshares, &amp;c. The third,
was hot water-Ordeal, by put&shy;
ting his arms up to the elbows
in seething water, &amp;c. The
fourth was cold water Ordeal,
like the late used trial of
Witches. Of these at large,
See Verstegan p.50,51. 


</page>

<page sig="ee3v">
And Mr. Lambert in his ex&shy;
plication of Saxon words,
<term lang="la">Verbo Ordalium</term>, where he ex&shy;
presses such superstitions as
were used in it. Of this you
may likewise read Holinshed
in his description of Brit.
fo.98. And Mr. Manwood
part. I. of his For. Laws,
pag.15. But, of all the rest,
Plotom. especially, <term lang="la">disput, de
feud</term> ca.41. &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ordalian law(n)">Ordalian Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">was
that Law which instituted
the Ordael aforesaid, and was
long before the Conquest,
but did continue of force in
England till the time of King
John, in whose days it was
abrogated; as Pol. Vir.
Holinshed &amp; supplimentum Chro&shy;
nicorum, witnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ordinary(n)">Ordinary (<etym lang="la">ordinarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
though in the Civil Law,
whence the word is taken,
it signifies any Judge that
has authority to take know&shy;
ledge of Causes in his own
right; as he is a Magistrate
and not by deputation, yet
in our Common Law it is
most commonly and usually
taken for him, that hath
ordinary Jurisdiction in cau&shy;
ses Ecclesiastical. See Brook
and Linwood hoc tit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oread(n)">Oreads (<etym lang="la">oreades</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Fairies of
the mountains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oredelf(n)">Oredelf,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a liberty where&shy;
by a man claims the Ore found
in his own <emend err="grouud">ground</emend>. Law
Terms. And Oredelf proper&shy;
ly signifies Ore lying under
ground; as aDelf of Coal, 
is Coal lying in veins under
ground, before it is digged up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orphrey(n)">Orfraies (<etym lang="la">aurifrisium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">friz&shy;
led cloth of gold, made and
used in England both before
and since the Conquest, worn
both by the Clergy and the
Kings themselves, as may ap&shy;
pear out of Math. Paris, where
he speaks of the Ornaments
sent by the Abbots of Eng&shy;
land to the Pope; and also by
a Record in the Tower,
where the King commands
the Templars to deliver such
Jewels, Garments, and Or&shy;
naments, as they had of his in
keeping; Among which he
names <term lang="la">Dalmaticum velatum de
Orefreis</term>, that is a damask gar&shy;
ment guarded with Orfraies.
Chauc. 

Of old the Jackets or Coat
Armors of the Kings Guard,
were also termed Orfrais, be&shy;
cause they were covered with
Goldsmiths work. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orgal(n)">Orgal,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Lees of wine
dried, used by Dyers, to make
their cloth drink in their co&shy;
lour throughly. Bul.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

which consisteth of divers

pertaining to Instruments or
Organs.</xpln></wordentry>

3 ca.2.</form> <xpln lang="en">is the greatest sort of

called Organ Ling.</xpln></wordentry>

remonies instituted by the
Poet Orpheus, to be kept eve&shy;
ry third year to the honor of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orifice(n)">Orifice (<etym lang="la">orificium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oriflamme(n)">Oriflambe (<etym lang="la">oriflammeus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the great and holy Standard
of France, having in the top
a purple Ensign or Flag, born
at first onely in Wars against
Infidels; But afterwards
used in all other Wars, and
at length utterly lost in a
Battle against the Flemmings.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="origin(n)" lexeme="original(n)">Origin 
 or Original 
 (<etym lang="la">origo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an off&shy;
spring, Pede&shy;
gree or birth; a Stock or
kindred; a beginning or
fountain, an Original, is also
the first authentick, or true
draught of a writing.</xpln></wordentry>

nial</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orison(n)">Orison (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Ora&shy;

communication.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ornomancy(n)">Ornomancy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">divi&shy;
nation by the moving of birds.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Orphean(a)">Orphean,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
Orpheus the Thracian Poet,
who is feigned to have plaid
so excellently upon the 
Harp, that he drew Stones,
Woods and Trees after him,
&amp;c. Hence we say, an Or&shy;
phtan Harp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orc(n)">Orque (<etym lang="la">orca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Hulk or
huge ship; Also a Sea-mon&shy;
ster so called, enemy to the
Whale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orpiment(n)" lexeme="orpment(n)">Orpiment 
Orpment  (<etym lang="la">auripigmen&shy;
tum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a soft
yellow kind of Arsenick,
like Brimstone, found very
deep in the earth; It is
commonly taken for Rats&shy;
bane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orthodoxal(a)" lexeme="orthodox(a)">Orthodoxal

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orthegonal(a)">Orthegonal (<etym lang="la">orthogonius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath right or even cor&shy;
ners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orthography(n)">Orthographie (<etym lang="la">orthogra&shy;
phia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the right form of wri&shy;
ting, or the art of writing
words truly; As to lose (<term lang="la">per&shy;
do</term>) to loose or untie (<term lang="la">solvo</term>.) 
Lest (as lest such a thing
should happen <term lang="la">ni</term>) and least,
as the least of all (<term lang="la">minimus</term>)
&amp;c. It is also a plat of buil&shy;
ding, drawn out with the
figure or order of the whole
work.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orthographize(v)">Orthographize (from <etym lang="la">or&shy;
thographia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to write or use
true Orthographie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ortive(a)">Ortive (<etym lang="la">ortivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">East,
easterly; as the Ortive Sun,

</page>

<page sig="ee4v">
the mouth, to bow down,
to sway or swing up and
down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oscian play(n)">Oscian Play,</form> <xpln lang="en">was a light
sport among the ancient Ro&shy;
mans, pleasing the peoples
humors. Tacit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oscine(n)">Oscines (<etym lang="la">oscines, ab os
&amp; cano</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are <emend err="these" source="errata">those</emend> kind of
birds, by whose chirping,
feeding, noise or voyces the
Augures foretold things to
come; As the Crow, Pie,
Chough, &amp;c. 

 <term lang="la">S&oelig;pe sinistra cava pr&aelig;dixit ab ilice Cornix</term> . Virg. 

To this kind of Divinati&shy;
on may be ascribed that old
womanish observation, that
when the Pie chatters, we
shall have strangers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oscitation(n)">Oscitation (<etym lang="la">oscitatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">yawn&shy;
ing or gaping; negligence or

strong a beak, that therewith
she breaks bones, and is there&shy;
fore called a bone-breaker or
Ossifrage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ostracism(n)">Ostracism (<etym lang="la">ostracismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of banishment among
the Athenians for ten years
space, which was done by
delivering shels with the con&shy;
demned persons names writ&shy;
ten in them; It was used
not so much to punish other
offences, as to abate the
immoderate power of Noble&shy;
men. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ostriferous(a)">Ostriferous (<etym lang="la">ostrifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oswold(pn)">Oswold ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">House&shy;
Ruler or Steward; forWold
in old English, and high
Dutch is a Ruler; But for 


</page>

<page sig="ee5r">
this the Normans brought
in Le Dispencer, now Spencer .
The holy life of St. Oswold
King of Northumberland, who
was incessantly in prayer, hath
given much honor to this
name. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="otraqua(n)">Otraqua,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of drink

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ovation(n)">Ovation (<etym lang="la">ovatio, ab ovo, as</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a smal triumph of a Prince
or Captain for a Victory ob&shy;
tained without slaughter of
men, in which he did either
go on foot or ride on horsback
with his Souldiers about him,
singing or shouting for joy,
and wearing on his head, a
Garland of Myrtle. Tho.<xref> See
Triumph</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ovation(n)">Ovation (<etym lang="la">ovatio, ab ovum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ouche(n)">Ouch ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of

Ornament, which women
did wear about their necks.
It is mentioned An. 24. H8.
cap.13. And is sometimes u&shy;
sed for a Boss or button of
gold. Chauc.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ounce(n)">Ounce (<etym lang="la">uncia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Twelve 
ounces make a pound weight
Troy (sixteen, a pound Aver&shy;
dupois) twenty penny weight
make an ounce; twenty four
grains make a penny weight;
twenty mites make a grain;
twenty four droits make a
mite; twenty Petits make a
droit; twenty four blanks
make a Petit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="overage(n)">Ourage (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Ouvrage</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outlawry(n)">Outlawrie (<etym lang="la">utlagaria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
the loss or deprivation of the
benefit belonging to a subject,
that is, of the Kings protecti&shy;
on and the Realm. Bract.
lib. 3. tract. 2. ca. II. num.
1 &amp; 3. <term lang="la">Forisfacit utlagatus
omnia qu&aelig; pacis sunt</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Owen(pn)">Owen (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class> <etym lang="la">Audoenus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">if
it be the same with St. Owen
of France. But the Britans
will have it from old King
Onous Father in Law to Her&shy;
cules; others from Eugenius,
that is, noble, or well-born;
Certain it is the Country in
Ireland called Tir-oen, is in La&shy;
tin Records <term lang="la">Terra Eugenii</term>, and
the Irish Priests know no
Latin for their Oen but <term lang="la">Euge&shy;
nius</term>, as <term lang="la">Rothericus</term> for Rocke .
And Sir Owen Ogle in Latin
Records (as I have been in&shy;
formed) was written Eugeni&shy;
us Ogle. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oxgang of land(n)">Oxgang of Land (<etym lang="la">Bovata
terr&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">six Ox-gangs of land
seem to be so much as six Ox&shy;
en will plough. Cromp. Jurisd.
fol.220. but an Ox-gang
seems properly to be spoken
of such as lyes in Gainour 


</page>

<page sig="ee5v">
Old nat. br. fol.117. Mr. Skene
<term lang="la">de verbor signif. verbo (bovata
terr&aelig;</term>) saith an Ox-gang of
land should alwaies contain
thirteen Acres, and that four
Oxen gates extended to a
pound land of old extent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oxymel(n)">Oxymel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Potion or
syrrup made of honey, vine&shy;
gar and water sod together,
good to cut and cleanse gross
flegmatick humors; some&shy;
times there are boiled certain
roots and seeds with it, and
then it is called Oximel com&shy;
positum ; sometimes it is made
with honey, vinegar, and the
Sea Onion, and then it is
named Oximel Scylliticum,
which also is of two sorts, to
wit, simple and compound.
See Dioscor. lib. I. ca.22. Gallen
lib.4. de sanit. tuend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oxyporopolist(n)">Oxyporopolist (<etym lang="la">oxyporopo&shy;
la</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that selleth meat in
sharp sawce and syrrups.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oyer and terminer(n)">Oyer and Terminer (<etym lang="la">au&shy;
diendo &amp; terminando</etym><emend err=")"></emend> <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">in true
French</class> <etym lang="fr"> Ovir</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Terminer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
in the intendment of our
Law, a Commission especial&shy;
ly granted to certain persons,
for hearing and determining
one or more causes. This was
wont to be in use upon some
suddain outrage or insurrecti&shy;
on in any place. Crompt. Ju&shy;
risd. fo. 131: and 132. See
the Stat. of Westminst. 2.
cap.29. An.13. Ed. I. who
might grant this Commissi&shy;
on. Fitzh. nat. br. fol.100. and
Brook. tit. Oyer and Terminer.
See <xref>Assize</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

king savour.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pace(n)">Pace (<etym lang="la">passus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pace in go&shy;
ing, a step or a stride; of
these there be two sorts, Pas&shy;
sus minor vel simplex, the
measure of two feet and an
half, which is usually the di&shy;
stance from the toes of the
fore-foot, to the heels of the
hinder foot. Passus major sive
Geometricus, a Pace or fa&shy;
thom of five foot, and by this
Pace, miles are measured.
In some places they reckon
three foot and an half to the
Pace. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

ter the obtaining some victo&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palatinate(n)">Palatinate,</form> <xpln lang="en">or County
Palatine, is a principal Coun&shy;
ty or County or Shire, hav&shy;
ing as it were the same autho&shy;
rity, as the Palace or Kings
Royal Court hath. Of these
County Palatines there are
four in England, viz. Lancaster,
Chester, Durham and Ely. An.
5. Eliz.1. cap.23. But An.33.
H 8 ca. 10. mention is made
of the County Palatine of
Hexam. <term lang="la">Unde qu&aelig;re</term> . See
Cassan. de consuetud. Burg.
pag. 14.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palatine(pn)">Palatine (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Palatin</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a 


</page>

<page sig="ee6v">
general and common appella&shy;
tion or title, for such as have
any special Office or Functi&shy;
on in a Sovereign Princes Pa&shy;
lace. This is the title of the
Prince Elector Palatine of
Trevers, and had its origen <term lang="la">&agrave;
magno Palatio Treverensi</term>. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palatine(a)">Palatine (from <etym lang="la">palatum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to the Pa&shy;
late . Hence, Palatine letters 
are such as are pronounced
by the help of the Palate, as
G. T. R. &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palatine(a)">Palatine (<etym lang="la">palatinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to a Palace or Prin&shy;
ces Court. It may also be
taken for the Hill Palatinus
in Rome, of which see Esqui&shy;
linus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pall-mall(n)">Pale Maille ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a game
wherein a round bowle is
with a mallet struck through
a high arch of iron (stand&shy;
ing at either end of an alley)
which he that can do at the
fewest blows, or at the num&shy;
ber agreed on, wins. This
Game was heretofore used
at the Alley near St. Jameses,
and vulgarly called Pel&shy;
Mel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palestrical(a)">Palestrical (<etym lang="la">pal&aelig;stricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or pertaining to wrestling,
that useth or teacheth wrest&shy;
ling, also that which is done
decently, with comely ge&shy;
sture of the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palindrome(n)">Palindromes ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are 
those sentences or verses,
where the syllables are the
same backward as forward.
As a noble Lady in Queen
Elizabeths time, being for a
time forbidden the Court, for
too much familiarity with a
great Lord in favour, gave
this Devise, the Moon cove&shy;
red with a cloud, and under&shy;
neath this Palindrome for
Motto . 

 <term lang="la">Ablata, at alba</term> . 

A great Lawyer this,

 <term lang="la">Si nummi, immunis</term>. 

Which may be Englished thus,

Give me my fee
I'le warrant you free. 

 <term lang="la">Roma tibi subito motibus ibit
amor</term>.

And this in English, which
is more hard, comes near a
true Palindrome.

Lewd did I live, and evil did I
dwel. 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palingenesy(n)">Palingenesie (<etym lang="la">palingenesia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
regeneration, new birth, or
second nativity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palinode(n)" lexeme="palinody(n)">Palinode 
Palinodie  (<etym lang="la">palinodia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
recantation, a
contrary song, an unsaying
that one hath spoken or writ&shy;
ten; the sound of the re&shy;
trait.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palisado(n)">Palizado (Span. <etym lang="sp">Palizada</etym>, 


</page>

<page sig="ee7r">
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Palissade</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a defence or
wall of Pales or Stakes, or
the pointed Stakes in a For&shy;
tification, which hinder the
enemy from scaling the work,
a term in War; it is also
taken for great posts set
up in the entry to a Camp,
for a defence against great
shot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pall(n)">Pall (<etym lang="la">pallium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mantle
such as the Knights of the
Garter wear; a long Gar&shy;
ment or Robe which philoso&shy;
phers wore. But it is now
most used for a vestment that
encompasses the neck and
shoulders, which the Pope
gives or sends to Arch Bi&shy;
shops, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palladion(n)">Palladion (Spa. <etym lang="la">Palladi&shy;
um</etym> Lat.)</form> <xpln lang="en">an image of Pallas,
which the Trojans fondly be&shy;
leeved was sent to preserve
their City and Estate, &amp;c.
which sottish beleef St. Au&shy;
gustin (lib.9. de Civit. Dei)
very well reproved, when he
said, The Trojans were keepers
of the Palladion, but not the Pal&shy;
ladion of the Trojans . However,
this word is still used for a
preservation or sure de&shy;
fence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pallas(pn)">Pallas,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Goddess of
wisdom, otherwise called Mi&shy;
nerva, &amp;c. In the Poetical
story of Perseus slaying Me&shy;
dusa, Pallas furnished him
with a shield for that purpose,
and with a Looking glass;
Mercury with wings for his
feet, Pluta with a Helmet, &amp;c.
See the Fable at large in Lo. 
Bacons Advancem. of learning,
fol.120. Hence tis we use
Palla' s shield, for a sheild of
wisdom and providence. For so
his Lordship means when he
says, In Wars the Shield of
Pallas prevails more then the
Sword of Mars ; that is wis&shy;
dom and stratagems prevail
more then down right
blows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palliardize(v)">Palliardize.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref lexeme="paillardize"> See Pailliar&shy;
dize</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palled(a)">Palled (Fr. <etym lang="fr">palle</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pale;
also dead, without spirit. Lo.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palliate(v)">Palliate (<etym lang="la">pallio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to hide
or cover, to conceal or
cloak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palliation(n)">Palliation (<etym lang="la">palliatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cloak&shy;
ing, covering or hiding:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palliatide(n)">Palliatide,</form> <xpln lang="en">that cloaketh,
covereth or concealeth; as
Chyrurgeons call that a Pal&shy;
liative cure, when a disease
or wound is cloaked for a sea&shy;
son, and not perfectly <emend err="cnred">cured</emend>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pallid(a)">Pallid (<etym lang="la">pallidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pale, bleak,
sometime yellowish, fearful,
whitish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pallification(n)">Pallification</form> <xpln lang="en">(a term in
Architecture) piling of the
ground plot. Sir H. W.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pallor(n)">Pallor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pale co&shy;
lour, paleness, wanness,</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palisado(n)">Pallizado</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Palizado</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmar(a)">Palmar (<etym lang="la">palmaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to victory or to a hand
breadth, or to the palm of the
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palm(n)">aPalme in measure (<etym lang="la">pal&shy;
mus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the breadth of a hand or
four fingers, and this is called
the minor Palm ; the Palm 


</page>

<page sig="ee7v">
major is a span, or according
to some, a shaftment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palm tree(n)">Palm Tree (<etym lang="la">Palma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is that
which bears Dates growing 
plentifully in the Holy Land;
Its branches were wont to
be carried as a token of victo&shy;
ry. 
 <term lang="la">------- Palmaque nobilis
Terrarum Dominos euehit ad Deos</term> . 
Because they are of that na&shy;
ture, as they will shoot up&shy;
wards, though oppressed
with never so great Weight,
and the leaves thereof never
fall; of this tree there is male
and female; the male bears
onely blossoms and no fruit,
but the female bears both;
but not unless it grow by the
male.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palm Sunday(pn)">Palm Sunday (<etym lang="la">Dominica
Palmarum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the sixth Sunday
in Lent, and the next before
Easter; so called, because, as
on that day the people went
to meet our Saviour with
boughs of Palm and Olive
branches in their hands, when
he entred solemnly into
Jerusalem, riding on an
Ass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmer(n)">Palmer (<etym lang="la">ferula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Feru&shy;
ler, so called, because in
Schools the palms of boyes
hands are struck therewith;
It is also called a Palmatory 
from the Span. <etym lang="sp"> Palmatoria</etym>,
which hath the same signifi&shy;
cation. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmer(n)">Palmer (from the Span. 
<etym lang="sp">Palm&eacute;ro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a poor Pilgrim,
that visits all holy places;
so called from a staff or
boughes of Palm, which
they were wont to carry 
with them. <xref>See Pilgrim</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmer(n)">Palmer (<etym lang="la">eruca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a worm
with many feet; so called
from the Palm Tree, which
it knaws and eats; a Cater&shy;
pillar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmiferous(a)">Palmiferous (<etym lang="la">palmifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
bearing or yeelding Palm or
Date Trees; Also victori&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmipedous(a)">Palmipedous (<etym lang="la">palmipes,
edis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath a plain and
flat foot; Palmipedous birds,
<expan type="">id est</expan> whole-footed, such are wa&shy;
ter-foul. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmester(n)">Palmester (<etym lang="la">chiromantes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Diviner by the palm of the
hand, one that tels the for&shy;
tune of another by looking in
his hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmestry(n)">Palmestrie</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref lexeme="chiromancy"> See Chiro&shy;
mantie</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmeto wine(n)">Palmeto Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a sweet
and pleasant juyce (like Mus&shy;
cadine or Allicant) coming
from the Palmeto Tree in
the Isle Mauritius. Herb. tr.
210.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palpation(n)">Palpation (<etym lang="la">palpatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">flat&shy;
tery, cogging, fair speoaking,
soothing</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palpitation(n)">Palpitation (<etym lang="la">palpitatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
panting, <emend err="beaten" source="errata">beating</emend> often;
quick moving up and down,
as the heart when it throbs.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ee8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palsgrave(pn)">Paltsgrave (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> and 
<etym lang="gr">Pfaltzgraff</etym> <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Teut.</class> from <etym lang="gr">Palts</etym>
or<etym lang="gr">pfaltz</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Palatium</term>, and

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paludament(n)">Paludament (<etym lang="la">paludamen&shy;
tum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coat-armor or Horse&shy;
mans coat, a Soldiers garment,
an Heralds coat of Arms. A&shy;
mong the ancient Romans, it
was a Military garment, which
none but the Lord General, or
the Chief-captains used to
wear. Alex. Gen. Dier. lib.5.
cap.18.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paludiferous(a)">Paludiferous (<etym lang="la">paludifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that causeth a Fen or Marsh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pamphili(n)">Pamphili,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of great

dred and forty, or a hundred
and sixty Oars of a side.
Heil.</xpln>

All.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panada(n)">Panado (Span. <etym lang="sp"> Panada</etym> or
 <etym lang="sp">Empanada</etym>; Fr. <etym lang="fr">Panade</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde
of meat made of crums of
Bread, and Currans boyled in
Water; or (as some will have 
it) of grated Bread, Milk,
Sugar, and grated Cheese.</xpln></wordentry>

contains all vertue. Silvester
makes it the title of one of
his Books, wherein he bewails
the loss of Prince Henry.</xpln>
<lemenote>

</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pancart(n)">Pancart ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a paper
containing the particular
rates of Tolls or Customs due
to the King, &amp;c. Thus termed
because commonly hung up in
some publick place, either
single, or with a frame. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Panchaia(pn)">Panchaia,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sandy Country
of Arabia, where is store of
Frankincense. Hence Dubar&shy;
tas and others, use Panchaian
Fumes, for incense or sweet
perfumes. So also Odor Pan&shy;
chaique for the smell of Ara&shy;
bian Frankincense.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pancratical(a)">Pancratical (<etym lang="la">pancraticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
expert at all feats of activity,
cunning at all kindes of games
and exercises, stout, like a
wrestler. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pandarism(n)">Pandarism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the function
or employment of a Pandor,
which is to make or set lecher&shy;
ous matches; Ruffianism,
baudery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pandect(n)">Pandects (<etym lang="la">pandecta</etym>, <term lang="la">a</term> <etym lang="gk"> &pi;&#x1f70;&nu;</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">omne</term>, &amp; <etym lang="gk">&#x1f10;&chi;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">babeo</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Books
which contain all matters, or
comprehend all parts of the
subject, whereof they intreat;
or Books of divers Argu&shy;
ments. The Volumn of the
Civil Law called Digestes, is
also called the Pandect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pandiculation(n)">Pandiculation (<etym lang="la">pandicula&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a gaping and stretching 


</page>

<page sig="ee8v">
ones self with all his body, as
they do that gape for sleep or

proach of an Ague.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pander(n)">Pandor (from the Belg.
<etym lang="br">Pander</etym>, that is, he that takes
a pawn or pledg: For the
souls of such, as make use of
him, are pawned into his
hands, as to Asmodeus his
Chamberlain)</form> <xpln lang="en">a he-Baud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pandora(pn)">Pandora</form> <xpln lang="en">fained (by Hesio&shy;
dus) to be the first woman, and
made by Vulcan; endued by
all the Gods with several ex&shy;
cellent gifts; but afterwards
by Jupiter, in displeasure sent
to her Spouse Epimetheus, with
a Box full of all manner of
miseries. Hence Pandora' s Box
is taken for misery, calamity,
and the like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pandurist(n)">Pandurist (<etym lang="la">panduristes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that plays on a musical instru&shy;
ment called a Rebech, or on a
Violin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panegyric(n)">Panegyrick (<etym lang="la">panegyricum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a licentious kinde of speaking
or oration, in the praise and
commendation of Kings, or
other great persons, wherein
some falsities are joyned with
many flatteries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panegyrist(n)">Panegyrist ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a praiser
or flatterer, one that writes in
commendation of, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panic fear(n)">Panick fear (<etym lang="la">panicum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sudden fear, wherewith one is
dis-straught, and put besides
his wit, coming without
known cause. So taken from
the God Pan, who had power
to strike men with terrors.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panicle(n)">Panicle (Dim. of <etym lang="la">panis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
little Loaf.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panifice(n)">Panifice (<etym lang="la">panificium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
craft of baking or making
Bread; also Bread it self, or
a Loaf of Bread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pannade(n)">Pannades ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the cur&shy;

boundings of lusty Horses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pannicle(n)">Pannicle (<etym lang="la">panniculus</etym>, Dim.
of <etym lang="la">Pannus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fine cloth, a little
peece or gobbet of cloth. The
fleshy Pannicle (<etym lang="la">panniculus
carnosus</etym>) the fleshy membrane
or skin, which lies next un&shy;
der the fat of the outward
parts, and in the fourth cover&shy;
ing that enwraps all the body
from the head to the sole of
the foot. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pannier(n)">Pannier (<etym lang="la">Panarium</etym>, Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Panier</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bin, hutch or place
to keep Bread in, a basket to
bear or keep bread in, a
Dosser.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="papacy(n)">Papacy (from <etym lang="la">Papa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="papal(a)">Papal (<etym lang="la">papalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to the Pope. 

Stephen Pasquier, in his <term lang="fr">Re&shy;
cherches de la France</term>, observes
that the word <term lang="la">Papa</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> the
Pope, comes from an old
mistake of <term lang="la">Pater Patri&aelig;</term>, writ&shy;
ten thus <term lang="la">Pa. Pa</term>. as we have it
in many Coyns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="papaverous(a)" lexeme="papavercan(a)">Papaverous 
or Papaderean 
 (<etym lang="la">papavereus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to
Poppy or Chestoul.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The term "papavercan" is not found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Papian law(n)">Papian Law (<etym lang="la">Lex Papia
Popp&oelig;a</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Law made among
the ancient Romans, against a
single life; that if any forbear
from the privileges of Parents,
ceast from marriage, and had
no children, then the people,
(who was the common Father
of all) should inherit their
Goods. Tacit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Paphian(a)">Paphian (<etym lang="la">paphius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to Paphos, a City of
Cyprus, dedicated to Venus,
and built by Paphus. Hence,
Paphos Archer is taken for Cu&shy;
pid; Paphian fire or shot, for
the fire or Arrows of Love.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="papulosity(n)">Papulosity (<etym lang="la">papulositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ful&shy;
ness of pimples or blisters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="papyriferous(a)">Papyriferous (<etym lang="la">papyrifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears or brings forth Pa&shy;
per, or the Rush Papyrus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paragraph(n)">Paragraph (<etym lang="la">paragraphus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Pilcrow; whatsoever is
comprehended in one sen&shy;
tence; where the line is bro&shy;
ken off (which Printers call a
Break) there ends the Para&shy;
graph. Books are most com&shy;
monly divided into Chapters,
those into Sections, and Secti&shy;
ons again into Paragraffs.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="ff2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parallels(n)">Paralels 
Parallels  (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&pi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1f79;&lambda;&shy;
&lambda;&eta;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, i. 
<term lang="la">equaliter di&shy;
stans</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lines running of
an equal distance from each
other, which can never meet,
though they be drawn infi&shy;
nitely in length thus &#x2550;&#x2550;&#x2550;&#x2550;&#x2550;&#x2550;

In Astronomy there are
five such imagined lines,
running circlewise about the
round compass of the Hea&shy;
vens. The first is the &AElig;qui&shy;
noctial Line, just in the mid&shy;
dle of the world, between the
two Poles. The second
northward from the &AElig;qui&shy;
noctial, is the Tropick of
Cancer, to which sign the Sun
comes about the eleventh day
of June . The third (yet
more northward) is the
northern Circle, within twen&shy;
ty three degrees and fifty
minutes of the North Pole.
The fourth Line is the
Tropick of Capricorn, de&shy;
clining southward from the E&shy;
quinoctial, as much as the
Tropick of Cancer doth
northward, and to this line
the Sun comes about the
twelfth of December . The
fifth and last Line, is the
Southern Circle, being as
near the South Pole, as the
Northern Circle (before
spoken of) is to the North
Pole.

These Parallels are also
called &AElig;quidistants . There
is another sort of Parallels,
(two of which goe to a
Clime) called Artificial Pa&shy; 
rallels, because they shew the
differences of artificial days,
&amp;c. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parallel(v)">To Parallel,</form> <xpln lang="en">to compare
or match.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parallelogram(n)">Parallelogram (<etym lang="la">parallelo&shy;
grammus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">having lines every
where a like distant, a long
square.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paralogism(n)">Paralogism (<etym lang="la">paralogis&shy;
mus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a deceitful conclusion,
or captious reasoning, a man&shy;
ner of arguing, which seems
true when it is not; As in
saying, he that affirms Pe&shy;
ter to be a living creature,
saith true; He that affirms
Peter to be a Bear, affirms
him to be a living creature.
Therefore he that affirms
Peter to be a Bear, sayes
true.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paralogize(v)">To Paralogize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to reason
captiously, argue deceitfully,
conclude falsely. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paralytic(a)">Paralytick (<etym lang="la">paralyticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sick of the Palsie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parament(n)">Paraments,</form> <xpln lang="en">Robes of state,
or the place where they are
kept. Chau.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paramount(n)">Paramount (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the
Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">par</etym>: <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">per</term> and <etym lang="fr">mounter</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan>
<term lang="la">ascendere</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies in our
Law, the highest Lord of

a Tenant to a Lord that
holds over of another Lord;
the first of these is called
Lord Mesn, the second Lord
Paramount, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

ver, he or shee, a Sweet&shy;

mark set unto, after, or in&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paraphernalia(n)">Paraphonalia,</form> <xpln lang="en">is used in
our Law, but in the Civil it is
Paraphernalia, which are those
Goods a Wife brings her
Husband, over and besides
her Dowry or Marriage mo&shy;
ney; as, Furniture for her
own Chamber, her own Ap&shy;
parel, and Jewels, if she be
of quality; all which she
must have, and not the Exe&shy;
cutors of the Husband, &amp;c.
Shep. Fa. Counc.122.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paraphrase(n)">Paraphrase (<etym lang="la">paraphrasis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
free manner of exposition or
interpretation, wherein a
man ties not himself to ex&shy;
press every word as it lies in 
the Copy, but to explicate
and adorn the matter more at
large, or to abridge it, yet still
keeping the Authors sence.
Any such Exposition is called
a Paraphrase or Paraphrastical
Exposition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paraphrast(n)">Paraphrast (<etym lang="la">paraphrastes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

words, then it is written in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parish(n)">Parish (<etym lang="la">parochia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a multi&shy;
tude of neighbors pertaining
to one Church. 

This Land was first divided
into Parishes by Honorius, Arch&shy;
bishop of Canterbury, in the
year of our Lord 636. Cam.
Brit. Of these Parish Church&shy;
es, there were in England in
the days of Henry the Eight
the number of 45000. Cow.
Now there is reckoned 8308,
and in Wales to 16; in all 9324.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parisyllable(n)">Parisyllable (<etym lang="la">parisyllabus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an equal syllable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parisyllabical(a)">Parisyllabical (<etym lang="la">parisyllabi&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath equal syllables;
those words are called Pari&shy;
syllabical, which have no
more syllables in one then an&shy;
other, as Fama, mensa, &amp;c.
So likewise we say in Gram&shy;
mar, the first declension of
Nouns is Parisyllabique, be&shy;
cause <emend err="sall">all</emend> the cases of such
Noun in the singular num&shy;
ber especially have even sylla&shy;
bles, as Gemma, gemm&aelig; gemm&aelig;,
geminam, gemma, gemma, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parity(n)">Parity (<etym lang="la">paritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">likeness,
equality, evenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paritude(n)" lexeme="pariture(n)" lexeme="parture(n)">Paritude,Pariture or
Parture<etym lang="la"> (from Pario</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a breed&shy; 
ing or ingendring, the time of
travail or deliverance of childe
or yong.</xpln>

</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parliament(n)">Parliament orParlement 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"><expan type="">que</expan> Parler le mens</etym><emend err=")"></emend> or <etym lang="it">Par&shy;
lament</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="it">from the Italian</class> and
<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Spanish</class> <etym lang="sp">Parlamento</etym>.</form> <xpln lang="en">With us
it was formerly the Assembly
of the King, and the three E&shy;
states of the Realm, viz. The
Lords Spiritual and Tempo&shy;
ral, and Commons, for debat&shy;
ing matters touching the
Commonwealth, and especial&shy;
ly the making and correcting
Laws; which assembly or
Court is of all others the
highest, and of greatest au&shy;
thority, as you may read in
Sir Thos. Smith, De Republ:
Angl' l2. c. I,2. and in Cowel.
In France, those high Courts of
Justice, (where mens causes
and differences are publickly
determined, without further
Appeal, whereof there be eight
in number in eight capital
Cities of France, viz. Paris,
Grenoble, Tholose, Dyon, Rouen,
Aix, Rhemes, and Bourdeaux)
are called Sedentary Parlements ;
and their Assembly of States
General is onely equivalent to
our Parliament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parmacety(n)">Parmacety,</form> <xpln lang="en">a corruption
of the words Sperma c&aelig;ti, the
Seed of the Whale, which is
an excellent oyntment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Parmesan(n)">Parmesan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of ex&shy;
cellent Cheese, made at Parma
in Italy, and therefore so cal&shy;
led: It is also sometime taken
for an inhabitant of the City
Parma.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parole(n)">Parole ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a word, a
term, also a speech, or saying.
Lease Parol, a Lease by word of
mouth. It is also a term of
War, when a prisoner is per&shy;
mitted to go at liberty for
procuring another Soldier, pri&shy;
soner with the enemy, to be
exchanged for him, or for rai&shy;
sing such a ransom by a day a&shy;
greed on, or upon any other
occasion or agreement; and
in default, the prisoner gives
his Parol, <expan type="">id est</expan> his word, to re&shy;
turn. During which time, we
say, the prisoner is upon his
Parol.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paroxysm(n)">Paroxysm (<etym lang="la">paroxysmus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
first coming, or the coming
again of an ague, the fit or
sharp assault of it. Malvez&shy;
zi.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pasche(pn)">Pasche (<etym lang="la">pascha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Passover,
the Feast of &AElig;ster, so named
ofEoster, a Goddess of the
old Saxons, whose Feast they
kept in April . Cam. <term lang="la">Ut inve&shy;
niatur Pascha. 

Post Martia nonas, ubi sit nova Luna requiras:
Et cum transierit bis septima Pascha patebit</term> .

Or thus:

 <term lang="la">Inde Dies Solis tertia Pascha venit</term> . 

Mynshew derives Easter 
from East; because at that
time, our Sun of Righteousness 
did rise, as the Sun in the
East. 

The Jewish Passover was a
holy Action ordained of God
in the killing and eating a
Lamb, partly to the end the
Jewish Church might keep in
memory the benefit which
God did for them, in passing
over the houses of the children
of Israel in Egypt, and smiting
them not. Exod.12.11. Also
to be a Type of Christ the
true Paschal Lamb. 

Verstegan says Easter, was by
the old Saxons, called<term lang="sx">Oster</term>
and at this present in Saxony
Ostern, which comes from
Ostermonat, their and our
old name of April.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Paschal(a)">Paschal (<etym lang="la">paschalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to the Passover or
Easter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pascuous(a)">Pascuous (<etym lang="la">pascuus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">serving
for pasture, or for feeding, or
grazing of Beasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pasquil(n)" lexeme="Pasquin(pn)">Pasquil orPasquin,
(from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pasquino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Libel clapt on a Post or I&shy;
mage; so called from Pasquil 
or Pasquin, an old Statue or
Image in Rome, whereon Li&shy;
bels, Detractions, and Satyri&shy;
cal invectives are fixed, and
on him fathered, as their
Author: There is also in
Rome, another old Statue
called Morforeo, whereon they
affix answers to those Pas&shy;
quins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passade(n)">Passade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an alms, be&shy;
nevolence or entertainment
given by, or to a Passenger:
The manage of a Horse, back&shy;
ward and forward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passant(a)">Passant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">passing, go&shy;

as when we say, a Lyon Pas&shy;
sant, that is a Lyon drawn, as
if he were going or passing
along.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="letters patents(n)">Letters Patents (<etym lang="la">Liter&aelig;
patentes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Writings sealed with
the Broad Seal of England,
whereby a man is authorised
to do or enjoy any thing,
that otherwise of himself he
could not. Anno 19 Hen.7.
cap.7. And they are so
termed of their form, be&shy;
cause they are Patentes, viz.
open, with the Seal hang&shy;
ing ready to be shewed for
confirmation of the Authori&shy;
ty given by them. 

The Kings letters Patents
are called Letters Patents
Royal, for difference, be&shy;
cause common persons may
grant Patents, or Letters Pa&shy;
tents, &amp;c. Fitzh. Nat. br.
fol.35. E. 2 Henry the sixth,
cap.10.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pavilion(n)">Pavillion (Lat. <etym lang="la">Papilio</etym>,

a Tabernacle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pavanne(n)">Pavin ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>  <etym lang="fr">Pav&aacute;ne</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of Dance; perhaps so called
&agrave; paienda terra, of paving the
ground. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Paul(pn)">Paul (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wonderful,
or rest; But the learned Ba&shy;
ronius, drawing it from the
Latin, makes it little or hum&shy;
ble. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pannage(n)">Pannage (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">pa&shy;
nage</etym> or <etym lang="fr">pasnage</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies, in
our Common Law, the mo&shy;
ney taken by the Agistors
for feeding Hogs with the
Mast of the Kings Forest.
Cromp. Jurisd. fol.165. Agist&shy;
ment (says Manwood) is pro&shy;
perly the common of her&shy;
bage of any kind of ground 
or Land or Woods, or the
money due for the same;
and Pawnage is most properly
the Mast of the Woods or
Hedgerowes, or the money
due to the owner of the same
for it. Mr. Skene calls it Pan&shy;
nagium, and defines it to be
the duty given to the King for
the pasturage of Swine in
the Forest. Leg. Forest. ca.
5,6,8.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pavoisade(n)">Pavoisade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any Tar&shy;
guet-fence, that of Galleys,
whereby the slaves are defen&shy;
ded from the smal shot of the
Enemy. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pavonine(a)">Pavonine (<etym lang="la">pavoninus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a Peacock or
a Peahen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pavor(n)">Pavor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">great fear and
dread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pausade(n)">Pausade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pausing,

resting seat or place.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perch(n)">Pearch orPerche (<etym lang="la">pertica</etym>
Fr. <etym lang="fr">perche</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Rod or Pole
wherewith land is measured,
the most usual contains six&shy;
teen feet, and an half in length;
whereof forty in length, and
four in <emend err="beadth">breadth</emend> make an Acre
of ground. Crom. Jurisd. fol.
222. But in several Coun&shy;
tries they are of several
lengths, as in Staffordshire
twenty four foot, in the For&shy;
est of Sherwood twenty five
foot. See more in Skene
de verb. sign. Verbo Particata
terr&aelig;.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peccadillo(n)">Peccadillo (Span. Fr.
 <etym lang="sp">peccadille</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little sin, a smal
fault, a venial sin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pectinal(n)">Pectinals (from <etym lang="la">pecten</etym>, a

such fish, whose ribs are
straight, as Soals, Thornback,
Flounders, &amp;c. because their
back-bone, and ribs do in some
sort resemble a comb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pectinate(v)">Pectinate (<etym lang="la">pectino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

it is in grass, to rake corn to&shy;
gether.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pectoral(n)">Pectoral (<etym lang="la">pectorale</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a brest&shy;

a Peitrel, Poitrel, or Stoma&shy;
cher. In Physick it signifies
a Lozenge or Medicine, good
for the stomack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pectoral(a)">Pectoral (<etym lang="la">pectoralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

mack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peculiate(v)">Peculiate (<etym lang="la">peculio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pu&shy;

way a mans goods; also to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pecuniary(a)">Pecuniary (<etym lang="la">pecuniarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to money. The
Heathens say, the Imprese of
a sheep was stamped upon
their first coyn, and from
thence their money was cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">pecunia</term>, from <term lang="la">pecus</term>. Gre&shy;
gory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pedage(n)">Pedage (<etym lang="la">pedagium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signi&shy;
fies money given for the pas&shy;
sing by foot or horse through
any Country. It is used
in the book called, <term lang="la">Pupilla
oculi.</term></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pier(n)">Peere (Fr. <etym lang="fr">pierre</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">seems
properly to be a Fortress made
against the force of the Sea,
for the better security of
ships, that lie at Harbor in
any Haven; So is the Peer
of Dover, described in Cam.
Brit. pag.259. You shall read
the word often in Sands Tra&shy;
vels, and comes from <term lang="la">Petra</term>;
because of the congestion of
great stones, to the rasing up
of such a Pile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peers(n)">Peers (<etym lang="la">pares</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">equals;
also the House of Lords in 
Parliament, was otherwise
called the House of Peers, and
their condition and dignity,
Peerage. Which word may
also signifie an Imposition
for maintenance of a Sea&shy;
Peer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pegasus(pn)">Pegasus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a winged

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pelagians(pn)">Pelagians,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient
sort of Hereticks, who (a&shy;
mong other damnable Te&shy;
nets) denied Original sin, &amp;c.
This Heresie took name from
Pelagius its first brocher, and
was condemned by a general
Council, held in the Island
of Malta, by Pope Innocent the
first, at which St. Austin was
present, and 214 Bishops.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pelagic(a)">Pelagick (<etym lang="la">pelagicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pelion(pn)" lexeme="Ossa(pn)">Pelion andOssa,</form> <xpln lang="en">two high
mountains in Thessaly; and we
say proverbially to mount Pe&shy;
lion upon Ossa, when we use
our utmost endeavors to
overcome any difficulty; or
when we attempt the doing
that which is not feaz&shy;
able.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pellecator(n)">Pellecator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a decei&shy;
ver with fair words.</xpln></wordentry>

ellers they are the lowest

staggering. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peneian Vale(pn)">Peneian Vale.</form> <xpln lang="en">Temp&eacute;, a
most pleasant valley in Thessaly,
on the Verge of the River Pe&shy;
neus, and therefore so called.
Dub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Penelope(pn)">Penelope ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the name 
of the most patient, true, con&shy;
stant and chaste wife of U&shy;
lisses, which was given to
her, for that she carefully lo&shy;
ved and fed those birds with
purpre necks called Penelopes .
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penetrability(n)">Penetrability (from <etym lang="la">pe&shy;

thing can resist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penetrable(a)">Penetrable (<etym lang="la">penetrabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peninsula(n)">Peninsula (Lat <term lang="la">quasi</term>, <etym lang="la">pene
insula</etym>, almost an Island)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
tract of land, which being al&shy;
most encompassed by water is
joyned to the firm land by
some little Ismus, narrow
place or entrance; As that
vast Continent of Peru and
Brasile in America were an
Island, but for that strait or
neck of land, between Pana&shy;
ma and Nombre de Dios.
Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penitencer(n)" lexeme="penitentiary(n)">Penitencer 
Penitenciary  (from <etym lang="la">p&aelig;ni&shy;
nitentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Priest, &amp;c. that enjoyns the
offendor his penance. Pe&shy;
nitentiary is sometimes also
taken for that place in Rome,
where a certain number of
Priests, indued with faculties
to absolve from reserved cases,
are appointed to sit, ready to
hear the confessions of those
that from sundry places re&shy;
pair for that purpose unto
them. Penitentiary Priests, or
Priests of the penitentiary,
are those that belong to the
aforesaid place, over whom 


</page>

<page sig="ff8r">
there is one stiled Chief Pe&shy;
nitentiary, who for the most,
if not always, is one of the
Cardinals, who admits and
gives faculties to the rest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penitential(a)">Penitential (<etym lang="la">p&aelig;nitentialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
very penitent, most sorrow&shy;
ful or repentant; the seven
Penitential Psalms of David,
are so called, because they are
held very efficacious in mo&shy;
ving sinful souls to repen&shy;
tance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pennigerous(a)">Pennigerous (<etym lang="la">penniger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
feathered, winged, bearing or
having wings and feathers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pennant(n)">Pennant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a rope to hoise

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pennipotent(a)">Pennipotent (<etym lang="la">pennipotens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

thered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pentameter(n)">Pentameter ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a verse
consisting of five feet; In
the first part it hath two feet
either Dactyles or Spondees,
with a long syllable; In the
later part also two feet, but
always Dactyles, and a long
syllable. As 

 <term lang="la">Res est solliciti plena timoris amor</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pentaptote(n)">Pentaptotes (<etym lang="la">pentaptota</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
nouns declined onely by five
Cases.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pentarch(n)">Pentarck (<etym lang="la">pentarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Captain of five men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pentastich(n)">Pentastick (<etym lang="la">pentastichus </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Porches having five rowes of
Pillars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pentateuch(pn)">Pentateuch (<etym lang="la">pentateuchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a volume of five Books; the
five books of Moses, (viz)
Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Nu&shy; 
meri, and Deuteronomie, so
called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pentecontarch(n)">Pentecontarck (<etym lang="la">pentecon&shy;
tarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Captain of fifty
men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pentecost(pn)">Pentecost (Gr. <etym lang="la">Pentecoste</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> the fiftieth)</form> <xpln lang="en">The Feast of
Pentecost or Whitsontide, so cal&shy;
led because it is the fiftieth
day from the Resurrection of
Jesus Christ.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pentereme(n)">Pentireme (<etym lang="la">pentiremes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Galley that has five Oares in
a seat or rank, or a Galley, 


</page>

<page sig="ff8v">
wherein every oar hath five
men to draw it. See <xref>Quinque&shy;
reme</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penulator(n)">Penulator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Furri&shy;
er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penurious(a)">Penurious (from <etym lang="la">penuria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
extream needy and necessi&shy;
tous, that wants all necessa&shy;
ties.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peplography(n)">Peplography (<etym lang="la">peplographia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the description of the vail,
called Peplum, which was an
embroidered vesture or hood
to cover the head, now used
for a kercher, worn especially,
by women, going to be
churched. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peptic(a)">Peptick (<etym lang="la">pepticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="tha"> that</emend>
comforts the stomack, and
helps it to digest the meat in
it, concoctive, digestive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="per(pp)">Per,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Preposition, being
compounded with another
word, renders it more power&shy;
ful and efficacious; as Amo,
to love; put per to it, and it is
to love throughly or perfect&shy;
ly well. Valid is valiant or
strong, pervalid, very valiant
or strong, &amp;c. and so of others.
Which being premonished,
the Reader, knowing the sim&shy;
ple words, will easily under&shy;
stand the compound, and so
save a labor of repeating many
of them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peraction(n)">Peraction (<etym lang="la">peractio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an ac&shy;
complishing, performing, end&shy;
ing or dispatching.</xpln></wordentry>

a going about, a travelling

cheval a place in Normandy.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peripatetical(a)">Peripatetical (<etym lang="la">peripateti&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Periscians(pn)">Periscians (<etym lang="la">periscii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

about them; as those that
dwell in the cold Zones; for

once risen, goes round about
their Horizon, and so casts
the shadows round, as it were

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perquisite(n)">Perquisite (<etym lang="la">perquisitum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in Bracton any thing
purchased, as Perquisitum fa&shy;
cere . lib.2. ca.30. numb.3. and
lib.4. ca.22. Perquisites of
Courts are those profits, that
accrew to the Lord of a Man&shy;
nor, by vertue of his Court Ba&shy;
ron, over and above the cer&shy;
tain and yearly profits of his
Land, as Escheats, Marriages,
Fines for Copy-Holds, and
such like. New Terms of
Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perquisitor(n)">Perquisitor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
enquirer, or diligent search&shy;
er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perreptation(n)">Perreptation (<etym lang="la">perreptatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a creeping into every corner,
a diligent searching.</xpln></wordentry>

victuals.</xpln></wordentry>

sound out, or perfectly, to
make a great noise; but Per&shy;

commonly taken to represent
the person of another.</xpln></wordentry>

 (<etym lang="la">perspicacia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

Perspiration is as it were
a breathing or vaporing of
the whole body through the
skin. Gorrh.</xpln></wordentry>

it is taken in the good part

near unto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parvis(n)">Pervise (<etym lang="la">pervism</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bar;
also a conference in former
time called the Pervis among
the yong Councellors, Plead&shy;
ers, Attorneys, or Students
of the Law, such as at this
day might resemble the course
in the Inns of Court, or
Chancery, called Moots and
Bolts, wherein the form of
pleading and arguing a case is
exercised; for so doth For&shy;
tescu (chap.51.) commending
those Laws, prove, when he
saith, That after the Judges
were risen at eleven of the
clock, from hearing Causes at
Westminster, <term lang="la">Placitantes tunc se
divertunt ad Pervisum, &amp; alibi
consulentes cum Servientibus ad
legem &amp; aliis Conciliariis suis</term> .
Chauc.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pervious(a)">Pervious (<etym lang="la">pervius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be gone in or thorow,
that is easie to be passed over
or thorow.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petalism(n)">Petalism (<etym lang="la">petalismus</etym> from
<etym lang="gk">&pi;&#x1f73;&tau;&alpha;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a leaf)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of
banishment for five years a&shy;
mong the Siracusians, practised
by writing the parties name,
whom they would be rid of,
in an Olive leaf, as at Athens
they wrote upon shells. Sir
W. Ral. l.5. f.277.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peter(n)">Peter (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>) (for which the
French use <term lang="fr">Pierre</term>, and our
Ancestors used Pierce)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
name of high esteem among
Christians, since our Saviour
named Simon, the Son of Jona,
<term lang="sy">Cephas</term> ; which is Syriack, and
by interpretation a Stone.
John I.42. But fool wisely
have some Peters called them&shy;
selves Pierius . Cam. 

St. Peter ad vincula .<xref lexeme="Gule of August"> See
Gule of August</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peter pence(n)">Peter pence (<etym lang="la">Denarii
Sancti Petri</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise called
in the Saxon tongueRome&shy;
fech <expan type="">id est</expan> the fee of Rome, or
due to Rome, and alsoRome&shy;
scot andRome-penning)
was a tribute given by Inas,
King of the West Saxons, be&shy;
ing in Pilgrimage at Rome, in
the year of our Lord seven
hundred and twenty, which
was a penny for every house.
Lamberds Explication of Sax&shy;
on words, Verbo, nunimus.
Whom see also fol.128. in St.
Edw. Laws, num.10. See also
King Edgars Laws, fol 78. cap.
4. Stow in his Annals, pag.76.
saith, He that had thirty
penny worth of Goods of one
kinde, in his house of his own
proper, was to give a penny at
Lammas yearly. <xref> See Rome&shy;
scot</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petrol(n)">Petrol (<etym lang="la">petroleum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde

rather a substance strained out
of the natural Bitumen ; It is
for the most part white, but
sometime black, and being
once set on fire, can hardly be
quenched.<xref> See Napthe</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petronel(n)">Petronel (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Petrinal</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
