the Pyrenean Mountains,
which were always hanged
at the Brest, ready to shoot,
as they do now at the Horses
Brest, called Petto, unde Petro&shy;
nel . Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petti-fogger(n)">Petti-fogger (from the Fr.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petty treason(n)">Petty Treason (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Petit
Trahison</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Treason in a lesser
or lower kinde. If a servant
kill his Master, a Wife her
Husband, a Secular or Religi&shy; 
ous man his Prelate, these are
Petit Treason, An.25 Edw.3.
cap.2. Whereof see more in
Stawnf. Pl. Cr. lib. I. cap.2.
Cromptons Justice of Peace, f.
2. For the punishment of
Petit treason, see An.22 H.8.
cap.14.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phalanx(n)">Phalanx ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a four&shy;
square Army consisting of
eight thousand footmen, set
in such array, that they might
encounter with their enemies,
foot to foot, man to man,
sheild to sheild. Polybius, l.5.
says the Phalanx contained
above twenty thousand; but
these numbers still altered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phanlangarian(n)">Phalangarians (<etym lang="la">phalanga&shy;

taining to a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Phalaris bull(pn)">Phalaris Bull.</form> <xpln lang="en">Phalaris
was a Tyrant of Sicily, who
tormented Perillus, the Arti&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="gg4r">
ficer first in the Brazen Bull,
he made for the destruction 
and torture of others, where&shy;
upon aptly Ovid. 

 <term lang="la">------- nec enim lex justior ulla,
Quam necis artifices arte perire sua</term> . 

So this bull is applied to
those that make a rod for
themselves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phantasm(n)">Phantasm (<etym lang="la">phantasma</etym>, the
French say <etym lang="fr"> phantosm</etym>, which I
have also read in English)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
vain Vision, or false Repre&shy;
sentation. Phantosm (saith
Suidas) is an imagination of
things, which are not indeed,
and doth proceed of the sen&shy;
ces being corrupted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phantic(n)">Phantick (from <etym lang="la">phantasia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
such as are haunted with
vain and illuding visions.
Dub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phare(n)">Phare (<etym lang="la">pharus</etym> or <etym lang="la">pharos</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Tower or high place by the
Sea coast, wherein were con&shy; 
tinually lights and fires,
which served Seamen to see
the Haven, and the safest en&shy;
trance; a Sea mark.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pharisaism(n)" lexeme="pharaisism(n)">Pharisaism or<emend err="Pharai"> Pharai&shy;</emend>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pharisee(pn)">Pharisee,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect of Jews,
professing more holiness then
the common sort, they held
contrary opinions to the Sad&shy;
duces, and wore Phylacteries 
or Scrols of parchment bound
about their heads, wherein
were written the Ten Com&shy;
mandments, vainly so inter&shy;
preting that of Deut.6.8. <term lang="la">mo&shy;
vebuntur super oculos tuos</term> ; they
owe their name to the Hebr.
 <etym lang="he">Phares</etym> or <etym lang="he">Pharesk</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">seperare,
interpretari</term>, as being both in&shy;
terpreters of the Law and
Separatists (by their feigned
devotion) from the rest of
the Jewish Church. Matth.
5.20. Luk.18.11.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pharmaceuty(n)" lexeme="pharmacy(n)">Pharmaceutie 
or Pharmacy 
 (<etym lang="la">pharma&shy;
ceutice</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">that part
of Physick which cureth with 


</page>

Medicines or Drugs.</xpln></wordentry>

lovers of Brothers or Sisters,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philauty(n)">Philautie (<etym lang="la">philautia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">love
of ones self, self-love, self&shy;
liking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Philibert(pn)">Philibert ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pro&shy;
per name for a man, signifying
much bright fame, or very
bright and famous, as Poly&shy;
phemus in Greek. Rhenanus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Philip(pn)">Philip ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lover

dy, or warlike person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Philippic(n)">Philippicks (<etym lang="la">philippica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
invectives, so called from De&shy;
mostene' s biting Orations a&shy;
gainst Philip.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Philippic fields(pn)">Philippick Fields (<etym lang="la">campi&shy;
Philippici</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are those that lye
near the City Philippolis in
Macedonia, built by Philip
Alexanders Father, famous
for the Roman Civil Wars,
there decided in two Bat&shy;
tles; the first between C&aelig;sar
and Pompey, the other between
Augustus and Mark Anthony,
against Brutus and Cassius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philippus(n)">Philippus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a coyn of gold,
worth about 3 s. sterl. Also
a coyn of silver worth 4 s.
sterl.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Philyrian scout(n)">Philyrian Scout,</form> <xpln lang="en">used
for the sign Sagittarius in Du&shy;
bartas; perhaps from the lea&shy;
thern Quiver or Case he car&shy;
ries on his back to hold his
Arrows; from Philyra, which
signifies a thin skin or parch&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry>

as <term lang="fr">Amie</term> in French.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philosophaster(n)">Philosophaster ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
smatterer in Philosophy; a
counterfeit philosopher.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philosophy(n)">Philosophy (<etym lang="la">philosophia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the love or study of wisdom;
a deep knowledge in the na&shy;
ture of things; There are
three different kinds thereof.
1. Rational Philosophie, inclu&shy;
ding Grammer, Logick, and
Rhetorick; and this dives
into the subtilty of disputa&shy;
tions and discourse. 2. Na&shy;
tural Philosophie, searching in&shy;
to the obscurity of natures se&shy;
crets, containing besides, A&shy;
rithmetick, Musick, Geome&shy;
try, and Astronomy. 3. Mo&shy;
ral Phylosophy, which con&shy;
sists in the knowledge and
practise of civility and good
behavior.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philosopher(n)">Philosopher (<etym lang="la">philosophus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
lover or studier of wisdom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philosophical(a)">Philosophical (<etym lang="la">philosophi&shy; 
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to philosophie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philostorgy(n)">Philostorgie (<etym lang="la">philostorgia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the love of parents towards
their children.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philotimy(n)">Philotimie (<etym lang="la">philotimia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
love of honor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="philtre(n)">Philtre (<etym lang="la">philtrum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an a&shy;
morous potion; a love-procu&shy;
ring drink or medicine; also
the hollowness or gutter in
the upper lip under the no&shy;
strils. 

Philtre-charmed . <expan type="">id est</expan> inchan&shy; 
ted with love potions. Dub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phisnomy(n)">Phisnomy (a corruption
of the word Physiogmony)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
art of knowing mens disposi&shy;
tions or natures, by view of
their face, eyes and features
of their bodies; and some&shy;
times that very feature is cal&shy;
led Physiognomy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phlebotomy(n)">Phlebotomie (<etym lang="la">phlebotomia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the cutting a vein to let
blood. Physitians (as tis
written) learned this practise
first of a beast called Hyppo&shy;
potamus, living in the River
Nylus, and being of a rave&shy;
nous nature, therefore of&shy;
ten over-charged with much
eating, is wont to seek in
the banks, for some sharp
stub of a Reed, upon which
pricking his leg, he thereby
easeth his full body; stop&shy;
ping the bleeding afterwards
with mud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Phlegeton(pn)">Phlegeton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Hell,
that always burns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phlegmatic(a)">Phlegmatick (<etym lang="la">phlegmati&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to an humor
in man, cold and moist; full
of, or subject to Fleam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phlegmon(n)">Phlegmon (<etym lang="la">phlegmone</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
inflammation of blood; a
swelling against nature being
hot and red.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Phoebus(pn)">Ph&oelig;bus,</form> <xpln lang="en"> Apollo, or the
Sun; Ph&oelig;be, Diana or the
Moon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phoenix(n)">Ph&oelig;nix ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the rarest
bird in the world, and is com&shy;
monly decribed thus; There
was never any but one of this
kind living at one time, and
that onely in Arabia, of the 


</page>

<page sig="gg5v">
bigness of an Eagle, of a purple
colour, having a bright col&shy;
ler of gold about his neck, a
goodly fair tail, and a tuft of
feathers upon his head; he
liveth above 600 years, and
being old builds him a nest of
Cinnamon, and the twigs of
Frankincense, which he fills
with Spices, and then with
the laboring of his wings in
the Sun, setting it on fire, is
there consumed; out of whose
ashes there grows a worm, and
of the worm another Ph&oelig;nix;
This, I say, is the common
received opinion as you may
see in Tacitus, and other Au&shy;
thors; But Dr. Br. in his Vul.
Er. makes question whether
there be any such Animal in 
nature, whom you may read at
large upon this subject. f.131.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phospher(n)">Phospher (<etym lang="la">phosphorus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
day-star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phrenetic(n)">Phrenetick (<etym lang="la">phreneticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath the frenzie (which
is the chiefest and greatest
mischeif that can come to the
brain) frantick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Phrygian(a)">Phrygian (<etym lang="la">phrygius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to Phrygia, a Country
in the lesser Asia, bounding
upon Caria, Lydia, Misia, and
Bithinia. 

A Phrygian Garment (<etym lang="la">phry&shy;
gia vestis</etym>) is a Garment
wrought with needlework, or
made of cloth of Baudkin.
So Phrygian wisdom is taken
for After-wit; according to. 
 <term lang="la">Ne sero sapias, sic sapuere Phryges</term> . 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phthisic(n)">Phthisick (<etym lang="la">phthisis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an (in&shy;
curable) ulceration of the
Lungs, accompanied with a
consumption of the whole bo&shy;
dy; the cough of the Lungs;
a consuming sickness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phylacist(n)">Phylacist (<etym lang="la">phylacista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
keeper of a Prison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phylactery(n)">Phylactery (<etym lang="la">phylacterium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
place where any thing is kept,
a preservative against poyson,
and fascination. 

Phylacteries were also Scrols
or Frontlets of parchment,
having the commandements
of God written in them, which
the Pharisees wore about their
heads and arms. Also threads
or bands of blew silk in the
fringes of a garment, by the 
beholding whereof, the memory
of Gods precepts was kept and
preserved. Deut.6.8. Matth.
23.5. <xref>See Pharisee</xref>, and see
Dr. Ham. Annotat. fo.121.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phylarch(n)">Phylark (<etym lang="la">phylarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
cheif over Tribe, a Ruler of
the people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physiarch(n)">Physiark (<etym lang="la">physiarcha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Governor of nature, God Al&shy;
mighty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physics(n)">Physicks (<etym lang="la">physica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">books
treating of Physick or natural
phylosophy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physician(n)">Physitian (<etym lang="la">Physicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
sence of this word in the
common acception is well
known, yet we vulgarly abuse
it, for a Leech or Medicus, but
not altogether intollerably, 


</page>

<page sig="gg6r">
because it is a trite and a true
saying, That <term lang="la">ubi definit Philo&shy;
sophus, incipit medicus</term>, where
the Naturalist (for there the
word Philosopher stands for a
Phisiologer) ends, there the
Medicus begins: So as, if an
expert Leech, must needs be
skild in the Physicks (that is
in those speculations, which
concern the works of nature)
the nearest word to fall with
our tongue, yet not far from
the thing, was Physitian, for
Medicus could not well brook
any flexion among us. El.
Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physiognomer(n)" lexeme="physiognomist(n)">Physiognomer 
Physiognomist (<etym lang="la">physiog&shy;
nomon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
one that professeth to know
the manners and natures of
some men, by the view of
their body, eyes, face, and
forehead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physiognomy(n)">Physiognomy (and by
contraction Physnomy, Physi&shy;
ognomia)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Art, which dis&shy;
covers the dispositions of the
minde by the Lineaments of
the body. Bac. <xref> See Physno&shy;
my</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physiology(n)">Physiology (<etym lang="la">physiologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
searching out of natural
things; a reasoning of the
nature of any thing; also A&shy;
natomizing Physick, or that
part of Physick, which treats
of the composition or stru&shy;
cture of mans body. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physiologer(n)">Physiologer (<etym lang="la">physiologus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
he that searcheth out, or dis&shy;
putes of Natural things, a
Natural Philosopher.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piacle(n)">Piacle (<etym lang="la">piaculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sacri&shy; 
fice, and all other things that
are done, and given for the
purging and satisfaction of
some grievous sin and offence;
also the offence it self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piacular(a)" lexeme="piaculous(a)">Piacular 
Piaculous  (<etym lang="la">piacularis</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">serving for the
purging of, or that hath power
to purge some faults or offen&shy;
ces; also that portends some
sorrowful thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pia mater(n)">Pia mater ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the in&shy;

brain round about, the Caul
or film of the Brain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pian piano(adv)">Pian piano ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in the
same sence the Spaniard says,
 <etym lang="it">Poco &agrave; poco</etym>, the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Pas &agrave; pas</etym>,
and we in English, By little
and little, soft and fair, by de&shy;
grees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piation(n)">Piation (<etym lang="la">piatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sacrifi&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piazza(n)">Piazza ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Market&shy;
place or chief street; such is
that in Covent-Garden,
which the vulgar corruptly
call the P-H, or I know
not what. Note, when two
z's happen together in Itali&shy;
an, the first is pronounced as
t ; so we pronounce it Piatza.
The close walks in Covent&shy;
Garden are not so properly
the Piazza, as the ground
which is inclosed within the
Rails.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Picards(pn)" lexeme="Picardites(pn)">Picards orPicardites
 (<etym lang="la">Picardi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">people of Picardy
in France, are said to have
first got that name of their
great and most accustomed
use of Pikes . Also a sort of
Hereticks (so called from one 


</page>

<page sig="gg6v">
Picardus) that held the same
opinions, or little differing
from the Adamites.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="picardize(v)">To Picardize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to speak or
do like a Picard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piccage(n)">Piccage</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Pickage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pickadill(n)">Pickadil (&agrave; <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class><etym lang="bl">Picke&shy;
diliekens</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Lacinia</term>. <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Teut.</class> 
<etym lang="gr">Pickedel</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the round hem, or
the several divisions set toge&shy;
ther about the skirt of a Gar&shy;
ment, or other thing; also a
kinde of stiff collar, made in
fashion of a Band. Hence per&shy;
haps that famous Ordinary
near St. James called Pickadil&shy;
ly, took denomination; be&shy;
cause it was then the out&shy;
most or skirt house of the
Suburbs that way. Others say
it took name from this, that
one Higgins a Tailor, who
built it, got most of his Estate
by Pickadilles, which in the
last age were much worn in
England.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pichigni(n)">Pichigni ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a word
among the French, by the
pronounciation whereof A&shy;
liens were discerned from the
native French. As Shibboleth 
among the Hebrews. Judges
12.6. 

So likewise (in Sands his
Travels, fol.239.) you may
read a story how the Genoa's 
were distinguished from the
Venetians, by naming a Sheep .
And in our own History, the
Flemings (in Wat Tylers Re&shy;
bellion) were distinguished
from English by pronouncing
Bread and Cheese, &amp;c. Stows
Survey, fol.51.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pickage(n)">Pickage (<etym lang="la">piccagium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
money paid in Fairs for break&shy;
ing the ground to set up
Booths or standings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pightle(n)">Picle aliasPitle (seems to
come from the Italian, <etym lang="it">Piccolo</etym>
or <etym lang="it">Picciolo</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Parvus, minutus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies with us a little small
Close or Inclosure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilaster(n)">Pilaster (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Pilastre</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

cap. I.) Also the inflamation or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilcrow(n)">Pilcrow.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Paragraph</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilgrim(n)">Pilgrim (<etym lang="la">Peregrinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that travels into strange
Countreys, commonly taken
for him that goes in devotion
to any holy place; a Pilgrim 
and a Palmer differed thus;
the Pilgrim had some dwel&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="gg7r">
ling place, the Palmer none :
The Pilgrim travelled to some
certain place, the Palmer to
all, and not to any one in
particular: The Pilgrim might
go at his own charge, the Pal&shy;
mer must profess wilful po&shy;
poverty: The Pilgrim might
give over his profession, the
Palmer must be constant, till
he had obtained the Palm ;
that is, victory over his ghost&shy;
ly enemies, and life, by death.
Chauc.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilaw(n)">Pillaw</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of ordi&shy;
nary meat among the Turks,
which is no other then Rice
sod with the fat of Mutton.
Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilosity(n)">Pilosity (<etym lang="la">pilositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hairi&shy;
ness, roughness. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilot(n)">Pilot (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class> <etym lang="it"> Pil&oacute;ta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Steers&shy;
man, he that directs the course
of a Ship: The Belgick call
him a <etym lang="bl">Lootsman</etym>. <xref lexeme="lodemanage">See Lode&shy;
menage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilotage(n)" lexeme="pilotism(n)">Pilotage orPilotism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the
office or art of a Pilot, the
skilful guiding or conduct of
a ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pimplean(a)">Pimplean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from Pimplea, a
Fount in Macedon, sacred to
the Muses, and is therefore
often used as an Ephithete for
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pinguefy(v)">Pinguefie (<etym lang="la">pinguefacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make fat or gross; some have

sense.</xpln></wordentry>

sus</etym><emend err="))">)</emend>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is fat, gross, rude or

a Tun, that is one hundred
twenty and six Gallons. An.
I R.3. cap.13.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piepowder, court of(n)">Piepowders Court or a
Court of Pypoudre (from
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">pied</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a foot and <etym lang="fr">poul&shy;
dreux</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> dusty)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Court held
in Fairs for the redress of all
disorders committed there;
which because they are most
frequented in Summer, the
word was given of the dusty
feet of the comers. Of this
see Crompt. Jurisdict. fol.
221.</xpln></wordentry>

ping. Master Montagu in his

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pissasphalt(n)">Pissasphalt (<etym lang="la">pissasphaltum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Pitch mingled with Bitumen,
either by accident or art;
The former is much the bet&shy;
ter, and comes from Apol&shy;
lonia in Epirus, where it first
received that mixture. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pissupprest(n)">Pissupprest,</form> <xpln lang="en">or the Stone,
is a disease in a Horse, when
he would fain stale but can&shy;
not at all; and therefore may
well be called the suppression
of the Urine. Markham.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Only noted in OED at 1610.
</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="placard(n)">Placard (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Plaquard</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
inscription set up; a Table
wherein Laws, Orders, &amp;c.
are written and hung up; al&shy;
so a Bill or Libel set upon a
post. In our Common Law
it is taken for a licence, where&shy;
by a man is permitted to
maintain unlawful Games.
2, &amp; 3. Ph. and Mar. ca.7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plagiary(n)">Plagiary (<etym lang="la">plagiarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that steals or takes free 


</page>

<page sig="gg8r">
people out of one Country
and sels them in another for
slaves; a stealer or suborner
of mens children or Servants,
for the same or like purpose,
(in which sense we term him
aSlockster) also a book stea&shy;
ler or book theef, one that
fathers other mens works up&shy;
on himself. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plagiarian law(n)">Plagiarian Law (<etym lang="la">plagi&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plaint(n)">Plaint ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a complaint, 
moan or lamentation; In our
Common Law it is used for
the propounding any action
personal or real in writing.
So it is used in Brook. tit. Plaint.
in Assize; And the party
making this Plaint is called
Plaintiff . Kitchin fol.231.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="planet(n)">Planet (<etym lang="la">planeta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">whereof
there are seven, bearing the
names of seven several Deities,
which you may remember
in their order by this verse. 

 <term lang="la">Post SIM, SUM sequitur, ultima Luna subest</term> . 

Would you count the planets soon,
Remember Sim, Sum, and the Moon. 

The first letter S. for Sa&shy;
turn, J. for Jupiter, M. for
Mars, M. Mercury, lastly, the
Moon ; They are also called
wandering Stars; because
they never keep one certain
place or station in the Firma&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="planetary(n)">Planetary (<etym lang="la">planetarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
caster of Nativities, because
the Planets are said to have
some power over earthly Bo&shy;
dies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="planetary(a)" lexeme="planetic(a)">Planetary

net.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plastic(n)">Plastique (<etym lang="la">plastice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

things in earth. 

Plastique is not onely un&shy;
der Sculpture, but indeed
very Sculpture it self; with
this difference, that the Plas&shy;
terer makes his figures by ad&shy;
dition, and the Carver by
substraction. Sir Hen. Wot.</xpln></wordentry>

ver-broad and full. Mr. Bir&shy;
kinhead in his <emend err="his"></emend>verses before

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Platonic love(n)">Platonick love,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a love
abstracted from all corporeal
gross impressions and sensual
appetite, and consists in con&shy;
templation, and Id&aelig;a' s of the
mind, not in any carnal frui&shy;
tion; Or it is a love of friend&shy;
ship, without any admixture
of sensuality. So called from
Plato that divine Philoso&shy;
pher.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Platonical year(n)">Platonical year (<etym lang="la">annus pla&shy;
tonicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is every 36000th.
year, when some Philoso&shy;
phers imagined, all persons
and things should return to
the same state as now they
are.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Platonist(n)">Platonist,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Philosopher
of the Sect of Plato.</xpln></wordentry>

clap ye hands for joy, is the
litteral signification; but it
is often used substantively for
a sign of rejoycing, or a clap&shy;
ing the hands for joy.</xpln></wordentry>

for which men receive praise,
received favorably, with joy
and clapping of hands, ac&shy;
ceptable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plebiscite(n)">Plebiscite (<etym lang="la">plebiscitum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pledge(n)">Pledge (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Pledge</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a surety or gage. To
pledge one drinking, had its
original thus; in the time
when the Danes bore sway in
this land, when a Native was
drinking, they would some&shy;
times stab him with a Dagger
or Knife; Hereupon people
would not drink in company
unless some one of the com&shy;
pany would be his pledge or
surety, that he should receive
no hurt, whilst he was in his
draught; Hence that usual
phrase, Ile pledge you, or be a 


</page>

<page sig="hh1r">
pledge for you. Others af&shy;
firm the true sence of the
word was, that if the party
drunk unto, was not dispo&shy;
sed to drink himself, he would
put another for a pledge to do
it for him, else the party who
began would take it ill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pledget(n)" lexeme="spledget(n)">Pleget orSpleget (<etym lang="la">sple&shy;
nium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a long plaister of cloth
or leather; a linnen cloath
dipped in any water, to wash
or lay to a sore place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pleiades(pn)">Pleiades ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the seven

about mid-heaven.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plenary(a)">Plenary (from <etym lang="la">plenus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full, ample, large; wealthy

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plenarty(n)">Plenarty,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an abstract of

used by our common Lawyers
in matters of Benefices;
wherein Plenaty and vacation

Pr&aelig;rog ca.8. fol.32. West.2.
ca.5. An.13. Ed.1.</xpln></wordentry>

dors or Commissioners that

ty from their King, or those

nemy or other person upon all

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plethorical(a)" lexeme="plethoric(a)">Plethorical 
 or Plethorick  (<etym lang="la">plethori&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fat,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pleurisy(n)">Pleurisie (<etym lang="la">Pleuritis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
ease when the inward skin
of the ribs in mans body, is
inflamed with too much
blood, flowing unnaturally
to it; In this disease there is
a hardness to fetch breath, a
cough, a continual ague, and
a pricking pain about the
Ribs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pleuritic(a)">Pleuritick (<etym lang="la">pleuriticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath, or is subject to the
Pleurisie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plicature(n)">Plicature (<etym lang="la">plicatura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fol&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plonket(n)">Plonkets</form> <xpln lang="en">( Anno I. <expan type="">read</expan>3.

cloth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="platoon(n)">Plottons</form> <xpln lang="en">(a term of war)
are small divisions; every
Plotton being eight in front;
led off by a Captain, and
every division after him led
up by a sufficient Officer.
Barif. p.172.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plumage(n)">Plumage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Feathers
or a bunch of feathers; also
pluming as <emend err="as"></emend> a Hawk does up&shy;
on a Pinion, where there is
more feathers then meat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plumassery(n)">Plumassery (from <etym lang="la">plu&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="hh1v">
ma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a plume or bunch of fea&shy;
thers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plumbagine(n)">Plumbagin (<etym lang="la">plumbago, inis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pure lead, turned almost in&shy;
to ashes, by the vehemency
of the fire; This is the ar&shy;
tificial Plumbagin, and comes
of lead put into a furnace
with Gold or Silver Oar, to
make them melt the sooner
(by which imployment it
gains some part in the worth
of those mettals;) There is
also a natural or mineral
Plumbagin, which (as Mathi&shy;
olus thinks)is no other then
Silver, mingled with Lead,
Stone or Oar. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plumbean(a)" lexeme="plumbrous(a)">Plumbean

</form> <xpln lang="en">of the co&shy;
lour and property of lead; lea&shy;
den; also dull, blunt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="podest&agrave;(n)">Podestat (Ital. <etym lang="it"> podesta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
man of power; a Judge in
Civil causes; a Governor or
Magistrate; In most of the
Cities under the State of Ve&shy;
nice there is a Podesta, who
represents the Senate, and
executes their power. Mer.
Ital.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="podemetry(n)">Podemetry ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">foot mea&shy;
sure, or a measuring by the
foot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poesy(n)">Poesy (<etym lang="la">poesis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Poets work,
Poetry; There are six sorts of
Poesie; The Heroick Poem
Narrative is called an Epique
Poem ; the Heroick Poem
Dramatique, is Tragedy ; The
Scommatick Narrative; is
Satyre ; Dramatick, is Come&shy;
dy ; The Pastoral Narrative,
is called simply pastoral (an&shy;
ciently Bucolique) the same
Dramatique, Pastoral Come&shy;
dy . The figure therefore of
an Epique Poem, and of a
Tragedy ought to be the 


</page>

<page sig="hh2r">
same; for they differ no
more, but that they are pro&shy;
nounced by one or many per&shy;
sons. Mr. Hobbs before Gon&shy;
dibert.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poetaster(n)">Poetaster (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Poetastre</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
counterfeit or ignorant Poet;
an unlearned fellow, that
pesters the world with idle
vanities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poitrel(n)">Poitrel.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Pectoral</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polar(a)" lexeme="polary(a)">Polar orPolary (<etym lang="la">polaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to the Pole . 

The Polar Circle, is that Cir&shy;
cle which is described by the
Pole of the Zodiack, being
carried about the Pole of the
world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polarity(n)">Polarity,</form> <xpln lang="en">the likeness, or
belongingness of a thing to
the Pole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pole(n)">Pole (<etym lang="la">polus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the end or
point of the Axletree, where&shy;
on Astronomers imagine Hea&shy;
ven to be moved, that part
of the Heaven which never
moves; There are two such
Poles, one in the North, no&shy;
ted by a Star called Polus Ar&shy;
ticus, visible to us far above the
earth, the other in the South
named Antarcticus, far out of
sight, being as much under
the earth in the South as the
North Pole is above it. It is
also taken for Heaven, and so
used by Poets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="point-blank(adv)">Point-Blank ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
fectly even, precisely to the
purpose, the nail on the head;
<term lang="fr">Poinct</term>, in French, signifies a
point, prick, or centre, period,
&amp;c. and <term lang="fr">Blank</term> the white or
mark of a pair of Buts, a white
paper, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polemarh(n)">Polemark (<etym lang="la">polemarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Lord Marshal of the field, a
chief Officer of War.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polemical(a)">Polemical (<etym lang="la">polemicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polemic(n)">Polemicks (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&lambda;&epsilon;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">verses treating of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="policy of assurance(n)">Policy of Assurance,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
course taken by those, who
adventure wares and merch&shy;
andize by Sea, whereby they
(loth to hazzard their whole
adventure) give to some o&shy;
ther a certain rate or propor&shy;
tion, as ten in the hundred,
or such like, to secure the
safe arrival of the ship, and so
much wares at the place a&shy;
greed on; So that, if the
ship and wares miscarry, the
Assurer makes good to the
venturer so much as he promi&shy;
sed to secure, as 50.100. more
or less, and if the ship arrive
safely he gains that clearly,
which the Venturer com&shy;
pounds to pay him; and for
the more even dealing be&shy;
tween them in this case, there
is a certain Clerk or Officer or&shy;
dain'd, to set down in writing
the sum of their agreement,
that they afterwards differ
not between themselves upon
the bargain. This term you
have An.43. Eliz caII. and in
course Latin called <term lang="la">Assecura&shy;
tio</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="politics(n)">Politicks (<etym lang="la"><emend err="p litica"> politica</emend></etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">books
treating of the Government
of a City or Commonwealth.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polypus(n)">Polypus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish called Pour&shy;
contrel, or many feet; it
changeth the colour often, and 


</page>

<page sig="hh3r">
is sometime metaphorically
applied to inconstant persons;
also a disease in the Nose cal&shy;
led Noli-me-tangere, breeding
a peece of flesh that often&shy;
times stifleth the Nose, and
stops the wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pontage(n)">Pontage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a contri&shy;
bution towards the mainte&shy;
nance or re-edifying of<emend err="Bridg"> Bridg&shy;</emend>
es Westm. 2. cap. 25: Anno

taken to this purpose, of those
that pass over Bridges. Anno
39 Eliz. cap 24. An I Hen 8.
cap.9. And see the Statute of
12 H.8. 5.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pontic(a)">Pontick (<etym lang="la">ponticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

that Sea which adjoyns to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pontificalibus(n)">Pontificalibus (<class type="pos">the Abla&shy;
tive case plural</class> of <etym lang="la">Pontificalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Bishop is said to be in his
Pontificalibus, when he is vest&shy;
ed in his Episcopal Orna&shy;
ments, to say or sing Divine
Service, upon some Festival&shy;
day. We commonly say such
a one is in his Pontificalibus,
when he is in rich attire, or
his best apparel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porcelain(n)" lexeme="China dishes(n)">Porcellane orChina Dishes,</form> <xpln lang="en">brought out of the
Kingdom of China, &amp;c. are
erroniously believed to be
made of Earth, which lies
one hundred years under
ground, &amp;c. But Gonzales de
Mendoza hath, upon ocular
experience, found them to be
made of a Chalky earth,
which (beaten and steeped in
water) affords a Cream or
Fatness on the top, and a
gross subsidence at the bot&shy;
tom; out of the Cream or
Superfluitance, the finest
Dishes (saith he) are made,
out of the residence thereof,
the courser; which being
formed, they gild or paint,
not after a hundred years, but
presently commit to the Fur&shy;
nace. To which Dishes (or
the finer sort of them, which
they say are forbidden to be
carried out of that Kingdom)
Scaliger and others ascribe
these properties, That they
admit no poyson; that they
strike fire; that they will
grow hot no higher then the
liquor in them ariseth. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porcine(a)">Porcine (<etym lang="la">porcinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or 
belonging to an Hog, hog&shy;
ish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porculation(n)">Porculation (<etym lang="la">porculatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
feeding or fatting of Swine,
bringing up of Hogs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pore(n)">Pores (<etym lang="la">pori</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">small and un&shy;
sensible holes, whereby the
sweat and vapors pass out of
the body, by the skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porous(a)">Porose orPorous (<etym lang="la">poro&shy;
sus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full of pores or little
holes. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porosity(n)">Porosity (<etym lang="la">porositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pori&shy;
ness or the being full of pores.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porphyry(n)">Porphyry (<etym lang="la">porphyrites</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
dark red Marble, spotted with
white.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porphyry chair(n)">Porphyry Chair,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chair
of Porphyry Marble in the
Cloister of St. John Lateran at
Rome, called <term lang="la">Sedes Stercoraria</term>;
because when the Pope takes
possession of his Episcopal See
in that Church, at the into&shy;
ning the Verse, <term lang="la">Suscitans de
terra inopem &amp; de stercore evi&shy;
gens pauperem</term>, Psal. 113. He
was carried from a side Chap&shy;
pel to the high Altar, in that
Chair; to signifie, that God
had raised him from a low con&shy;
dition, to that supreme Dig&shy;
nity. The usual tale of this
Chair is meer fiction.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porphyretic(a)">Porphyretick (<etym lang="la">porphyreti&shy; 
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to red Marble,
or purple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porrection(n)">Porrection (<etym lang="la">porrectio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
stretching or reaching out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porsyllogism(n)">Porsyllogism</form> <xpln lang="en">is, as it were,
an Auxiliary Syllogism, to
prove the main one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portable(a)">Portable (<etym lang="la">portabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portgreeve(n)">Portgreve (compounded
ofPort andgreve orgrave,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;fectus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">it signifies with
us the chief Magistrate in cer&shy;
tain Port-Towns. And (as
Camden saith in his Britan.
pag.325.) the chief Magistrate
of London was termed by this
name; in stead of whom,
Richard the First ordained two
Bailiffs: But presently after
him, King John granted them
a Major for their yearly Magi&shy;
strate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porteguidon(n)">Porteguidon ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an En&shy;
sign-bearer to a troop of men
at Arms.</xpln>

 <etym lang="sp">Manteo</etym>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cloakbag or Male.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portmote(n)">Portomote (compounded

 <etym lang="fr">Mot</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">dictio, verbum</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
Court kept in Haven-Towns;
as Swainmot in the Forest. It 
is sometimes called the Port&shy;
moot Court . An.43 Eliz.15.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="port-sale(n)">Portsale. Anno 35 H.8.
cap .7.I.</form> <xpln lang="en">sale of fish presently
upon return in the Haven.
Among the ancient Romans,
those things were rightly sold
in Portsale, which were pub&shy;
lickly sold <term lang="la"> Per Pr&aelig;onem sub
hasta</term>. <expan type="">id est</expan> by the Cryer, under a
Spear sticked up for that pur&shy;
pose, and some Magistrate
making good the sale by deli&shy;
very of the Goods, which
were sold to him, <term lang="la">Qui plurimum
rem augeret</term>. <expan type="">id est</expan> who would bid
most for them. Sigonius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="posade(n)">Posade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lighting

resting or resting place, from
the Spa. <etym lang="sp">Posada</etym>, an Inn.</xpln>

dering the voice.</xpln></wordentry>

perty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="posterganeous(a)">Posterganeous (<etym lang="la">postergane&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="posteriority(n)">Posteriority (<etym lang="la">posterioritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the being or coming, after or
behinde. It is a word of com&shy;
parison and relation in tenure,
the correlative whereof is pri&shy;
ority ; for a man holding Lands
or Tenements of two Lords,
holds of his ancienter Lord
by priority, and of his later
Lord by posteriority, Stawnf.
Prerog. fol 10, 11.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

Book published after the Au&shy;
thors death. It is sometimes
used for a mans Christen name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="postil(n)">Postil (<etym lang="la">postilum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a short ex&shy;

wherein more is observed,
then hath been by others; so
called from these words <etym lang="la">Post
illos dies</etym>, which are very fre&shy;
quent in Holy writ.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poldavis(n)">Pouldavis.</form> <xpln lang="en">Oulderness,

Dublets, or whereof Sails of
Ships are made. An. I Jac.24.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poundage(n)">Poundage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Subsidy
granted to the King of all
manner of Merchandises of
every Merchant, Denizen and
Alien, carried out or brought
into this Realm by way of
Merchandise, to the value of
twelve pence in every pound.
An.12 Ed 6 13 An.31 Eliz.
cap.5. and I Jac.33.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pourcontrel(n)">Pourcontrol.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Polypus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promenade(n)">Pourmenade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Walk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pursuivant(n)">Poursuivant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pur&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="hh5r">
suer, suitor or follower; but
more particularly it signifies a
Messenger, attending the
King in Wars or the Coun&shy;
cil Table, Exchequer, &amp;c. to
be sent upon any occasion or
message; as for the appre&shy;
hending a party accused, or
suspected of any offence com&shy;
mitted. Those that are used
in Marshal causes, are called
Pursuivants at Arms . Anno
24 H8. cap.13. whereof there
be four in number of special
names, which see in <xref>Herald</xref>. 

And Stow, speaking of Ri&shy;
chard the Thirds end (p.784.)
hath these words.  For his body
was naked to the skin, not so
much as one clout about him, and
was trussed behind a Pursuivant
at Arms, like an Hog or Calf,
&amp;c. The rest are used upon
other Messages in time of
Peace, especially in matters
touching jurisdiction. Also a
sort of persons, that pro&shy;
cure Commissions to pro&shy;
secute the Romanists on the
account of Religion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purpresture(n)">Pourpresture (from the
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pourpris</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a close or en&shy;
closure,)</form> <xpln lang="en">is thus defined in
Glanvile, lib.9. cap.11. <term lang="la">Pour&shy;
prestura est propri&egrave;, quando ali&shy;
quid super Dominum Regem in&shy;
just&egrave; occupatur, &amp;c.</term> Cromp. in
his Jurisd. fol.152 defines it
thus. Pourpresture is properly
when a man takes to himself,
or encroaches any thing that
he ought not, whether it be
in any Jurisdiction, Land, or
Franchise, and generally when 
any thing is done to the Nu&shy;
sance of the Kings Tenant, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portrait(n)">Pourtrait (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Pourtraict</etym>,
Lat. <etym lang="la">Protractus</etym>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Image
Picture, counterfeit or draught
of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portraiture(n)">Pourtraiture (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Pourtrai&shy;
cture</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a drawing or delinea&shy;
ting</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Powers(pn)">Powers,</form> <xpln lang="en">the third order
of the second Hierarchy of
Angels, so called by reason of
their peculiar Jurisdiction
over fiends, and all infernal
spirits. Tr. of Ma.<xref> See <emend err="Hie">Hie&shy;</emend>
rarchy</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Poynings' Law(n)">Poynings Law</form> <xpln lang="en">is an Act
of Parliament made in Ire&shy;
land, 10 Hen 7. and was so
called, because Sir Edw. Poyn&shy;
ings was Lieutenant of Ireland,
when that Law was made;
whereby all the Statutes of
England were made of force in
Ireland. For before they were
not, neither are any now in
force in Ireland, which were
made in England since that
time. L. Bac. Hen.7 and L.
Cokes 12 Rep. fol.109.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pragmatical(a)">Pragmatical (<etym lang="la">pragmaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is expert in doing things,
practised in the Law, and in
many matters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pragmatic(a)">Pragmatic (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class> <etym lang="sp">Prag&shy;
matica</etym>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Proclamation or
Edict; and is sometimes used
for a kinde of Agreement or
Paction between a secular
Prince, and the Pope, or some
other Bishop, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prandicle(n)">Prandicle (<etym lang="la">prandiculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
breakfast, a little dinner, a
small pittance or repast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pratic(n)">Pratique (from the Span.
<etym lang="sp">Pratica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">practise, or a thing
done by practise; but among
Merchants it is a Licence to
Traffick; as in the Ports of
Italy, and the Streights, if the
Mr. of the Ship brings a Bill
of Health, that is, a certificate
that the place from whence he
came is not infected with any
contagious disease, then the
Chief Magistrate or Signiors
of Health, (as they have in
some places) will grant him
Pratique, that is, leave to come
in and Traffick. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pratical(a)">Pratical (from the  <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
done by practise or experience.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pravity(n)">Pravity (<etym lang="la">pravitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">crook&shy;
edness, overthwartness, lewd&shy;
ness, naughtiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prebend(n)">Prebend (from <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;beo</etym>, to
give)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the portion, which e&shy;
very member or Canon of a
Cathedral Church, receives in
right of his place, for his
maintenance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prebendary(n)">Prebendary (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;bendarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
he that hath such a Prebend;
and is called so, a <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;bendo
auxilium, &amp; consilium Episcopo</etym> ;
for to that end were Prebends 
ordained in Cathedral Church&shy;
es, that the Prebendaries there&shy;
of should be assistants, and of
Council to the Bishop in his
Episcopal Function. Doddr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pre(px)" lexeme="pre(pp)">Pre (Lat. <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;</etym>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Preposi&shy;
tion signifying before, or in
comparison, often <emend err="compound">compound&shy;</emend>
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precaution(n)">Precaution (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cautio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
preventing a thing before it

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precention(n)">Precention (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;centio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

flourish of a Song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precarious(a)">Precarious (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;carius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
granted to one by prayer and
intreaty, to use so long as it
pleaseth the party, &amp; no longer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precellency(n)">Precellency (from <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cello</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

cellency. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preceptor(n)">Preceptor (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;ceptor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ma&shy;
ster, a Teacher, an Instructer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precidaneous(a)">Precidaneous (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cidaneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which goes before, or is
cut or killed before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precipice(n)">Precipice (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cipitium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
steep place, dangerous to go
upon, a downright pitch or fal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precipitate(v)">Precipitate (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cipito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
hurl or cast down headlong, to
do <emend err="undadvisedly">unadvisedly</emend> or rashly. It
is also the name of a Corrosive
powder, commonly called Red
Mercury, used by Chirurgions
to eat corrupted flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precocity(n)">Precocity<etym lang="la"> (from Pr&aelig;cox, ocis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
early ripeness, forwardliness
in ripening, over-hastiness in
ripening. Dod. Grove.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precognition(n)">Precognition (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cognitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
foreknowledge, prenotion, or
former notice of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preconious(a)">Preconious (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;conius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a Common&shy;
cryer; also to praise or com&shy;
mendation.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="hh6r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preconsultor(n)">Preconsultor (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Pre-adviser; there is a Col&shy;
ledge of these at Venice. See
Rel. Wotton. p.170.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="precursor(n)">Precursor (Lat. <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cursor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a fore-messenger, a fore-Ri&shy;
der, a fore-runner, or goer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predatory(a)">Predatory (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;datorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to robbing,
spoiling, and piracy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predestination(n)">Predestination (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;disti&shy;
natio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fore-appointment, an
ordaining before what shall
come after. It is most used
in divinity, and is thus defi&shy;
ned by Sir Wa. Ral. in his first
book fol.16. We can (saith
he) difference Predestination
no otherwise from Providence 
and Prescience, then in this,
That Prescience onely fore&shy;
sees, Providence foresees and
cares for, and hath respect to
all creatures, even from the
brightest Angels of Heaven to
the unworthiest worms of the
earth; And Predestination is
onely of men, and yet not
of all to men belonging, but
of their salvation properly
(in the common use of Di&shy;
vines) or perdition, as some
have used it, &amp;c. See more
 <term lang="la">loco citato</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predial(a)" lexeme="prediatory(a)">Predial 
or Prediatory (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;dialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging
to Lands or
Mannors. 

 Predial Tythes, are those we
call great Tythes, as of Corn
and Hay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prediator(n)">Prediator (Lat.<etym lang="la"> Pr&aelig;diator</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Lawyer that is expert in
Actions real, or cases concer&shy;
ning Lands.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predicable(a)">Predicable (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;dicabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be told or spoken of
abroad. In Logick there are
five Predicables, otherwise
called Porphyries five terms;
viz. Genus, Species, Differen&shy;
tia, Proprium, Accidens ; and
are called Predicables, <term lang="la">&agrave; pr&aelig;di&shy;
cando</term>, because they are Attri&shy;
butes of all things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predicament(n)">Predicament (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;dicamen&shy;
tum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Logick, where&shy;
of there are Ten, in which
every limited and bounded
nature is ranked and disposed;
The first called Substance, in&shy;
cludes all substances whatso&shy;
ever, as the four Elements,
and all other creatures. The
second, Quantity, contains all
quantities, as 10, 20; a yard,
a furlong, a mile. The third,
called Quality, has under it
all qualities, as Wisdom, Art,
Fortitude, Diligence, Sloth .
The fourth named Relation,
is properly of such words as
depend mutually one upon
another, as a Husband and
Wife, a Master and Servant.
The rest are, 5. Action or do&shy;
ing. 6. Passion or suffering
7. Where . 8. When . 9. Scitua&shy;
tion or place: 10. The habit
or outward covering of a
thing. See Peripatetical Insti&shy;
tutions. Les.3,4. 

Predicament is sometimes
used in ordinary discourse, for
state, condition, order, or the
like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predicate(v)">Predicate (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;dico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
publish, to say or tell openly,
to noise abroad. In Logick 


</page>

<page sig="hh6v">
it is used substantively, and
signifies the latter part of a
Proposition, as in saying,
John is a Schollar; the word
[ Schollar] is called the predi&shy;
cate, because it is spoken
or affirmed of the subject
John.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prefect(n)">Prefect (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;fectus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ru&shy;
ler, Governor, or President;
a Captain, a Provost, a Lord
Mayor. In old Rome, the
Prefect of the City had the
hearing of all matters be&shy;
tween Master and Servant,
Buyer and Seller, Orphans
and their Overseers, &amp;c. But
afterwards he did assume to
himself authority to hear all
causes whatsoever within a
hundred miles of Rome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prefecture(n)">Prefecture (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;fectura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Captainship, a Lieutenant&shy;
ship, an authority or Rule, an
Office, or little Jurisdicti&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preference(n)">Preference (from <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;fero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
preferment, advancement, ac&shy;
count before, place above, o&shy;
thers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pregnant(a)">Pregnant (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;gnans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">great
with child or young; full of
good sap and juyce; pithy,
ripe, lively, strong.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pregression(n)">Pregression (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;gressio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
going before, an out-going
or over-passing, a prevent&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pregustation(n)">Pregustation (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;gusta&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tasting or assaying be&shy;
fore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prejudicate(a)">Prejudicate  (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;judica&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fore-judged; determi&shy;
ned or condemned before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prelation(n)">Prelation (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;latio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a car&shy;
rying or setting before, prefer&shy;
ment, preference.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prelect(n)">Prelect,</form> <xpln lang="en">Either from <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;
lectus</etym>, read before; or from
 <term lang="la">pr&aelig;electus</term>, one chosen before
another.</xpln>

Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preludium(n)">Preludium (Lat. <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;ludi&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an entrance to a matter,
a proem; In musick, a vo&shy;
luntary before the Song, a flou&shy;
rish or preamble, and (as you
would say) signs and prof&shy;
fers :</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prelusion(n)">Prelusion (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;lusio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
playing before, a flourish, the
same with pr&aelig;ludium.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premature(a)">Premature (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;maturus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
ripe before other, or ripe be&shy;
fore due time and season; un&shy;
timely, comming too soon.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premeditate(v)">Premeditate (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;medi&shy; 
tor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to muse and think on a
thing before-hand, to advise
with himself beforehand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premious(a)">Premious (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;miosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rich

rewards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premission(n)">Premission (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;missio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sending before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premunire(n)">Premunire (from as some
think, more properly <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;mo&shy;
nere</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">when any man for an
offence committed, shall in&shy;
cur a Pr&aelig;munire, it is meant,
he shall incur the same pu&shy;
nishment, which is inflicted
on those that transgress the
Statute made Anno 16. Ric.2.
ca.5. (commonly called the
Statute of Pr&aelig;munire) and is
to be out of the Kings pro&shy;
tection, to forfeit Lands and 


</page>

<page sig="hh7r">
Goods, and to be attached
by their bodies, &amp;c. See more
in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premunition(n)">Premunition (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;munitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a fortifying or fencing before
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prenotion(n)">Prenotion (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;notio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fore-knowing of a thing;
fore-knowledge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prenuncious(a)">Prenuncious (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;nuncius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that first brings tidings, that
goes afore and tells news, that
signifies a thing to be at
hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preominate(v)">Preominate (from <etym lang="la">pr&aelig;</etym>

tell. Dr. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preoccupate(a)">Preoccupate (<etym lang="la">preoccupa&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">prevented, over-reached,
taken aforehand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prepensed(a)">Prepensed (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">pre-pense</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fore-thought; as
malice prepensed, in our Com&shy;
mon Law, is malice fore&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preposterous(a)">Preposterous (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;posterus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
overthwart, out of order,
contrary to all good fashi&shy;
on, and to the purpose; fro&shy;
ward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prepuce(n)">Prepuce (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;putium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
fore-skin that covers the head
or nut of a mans yard; which
the Hebrews used to cut off in
circumcision.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prerogative(n)">Prerogative (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;rogativa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an advantage, a prehemi&shy;
nency, authority, and rule a&shy;
bove others.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Presbyterians(pn)">Presbyterians,</form> <xpln lang="en">are those
that profess the doctrine of 
Calvin, condemn Episcopa&shy;
cy in the Church, and go&shy;
vern it partly by Lay-Elders;
and were not much known
among us by that name till
the long Parliament, that be&shy;
gan 3 Novemb. 1640. took the
Scottish Kirk for a pattern in
reforming.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prescience(n)">Prescience (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;scientia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
fore-knowledge, an under&shy;
standing before-hand of a
thing ere it come to pass. See
<xref> Predestination</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prescription(n)">Prescription (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;scriptio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a limiting or limitation; an
appointing or determining;
a Rule or Law; a long pos&shy;
session or continuance in pos&shy;
session; the course or use of
a thing for a long time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presentaneous(a)">Presentaneous (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;senta&shy;
neus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">present, ready, speedy,
forceable, effectual, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presentation(n)">Presentation (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;sentatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is used properly for the act
of a Patron, offering or pre&shy;
senting his Clark to the Bi&shy;
shop, to be instituted in a Be&shy;
nefice of his gift; The form
whereof see in the Register
original fol.322. a.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presentment(n)">Presentment,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a meer
denunciation of the Jurors
themselves, or some other
Officer, as Justice, Constable,
Searcher, Surveyor, &amp;c.
(without any information)
of an offence inquirable in
the Court, whereunto it is
presented. See Lamberds Ei&shy;
ren. lib 4,ca.5. pag.467.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preside(v)">Preside (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;sideo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to have
authority or rule, to have 


</page>

<page sig="hh7v">
the protection and tuition of
any thing, place, or people,
before others, to have the o&shy;
versight or charge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presidial(a)">Presidial (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;sidialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to a Lieutenant, Vice&shy;
Roy, cheif ruler or Presi&shy;
dent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presidy(n)">Presidie (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;sidium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Garrison, all manner of aid
and defence; help, com&shy;
fort.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presidiary(a)">Presidiary (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;sidiarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is ordained to be an aid
to another, pertaining to a
Garrison of Souldiers; also
as Presidial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prest money(n)" lexeme="imprest money(n)">Prest orImprest money 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr</class> <etym lang="fr">prest</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> ready)</form> 
<xpln lang="en">for that it binds those that
have received it to be ready
at all times appointed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prestige(n)">Prestiges (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;stigi&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">de&shy;
ceits, impostures, delusions,
cousening tricks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prestigiation(n)">Prestigiation (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;stigiatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a jugling, cousening or play&shy;
ing Legierdemain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prestigious(a)">Prestigious (<etym lang="la">prestigiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to a Jugler or Im&shy;
poster, that deceives with Le&shy;
gierdemain, or deludes the eie&shy;
sight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presto(adv)">Presto (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">quickly,
a word used by Juglers, in
their Hocus Pocus tricks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preterition(n)">Preterition (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;teritio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
going over, a passing by or
beyond, a surpassing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pretermission(n)">Pretermission (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;termissio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an omitting, a leaving out, a
letting a thing pass, a forget&shy;
ting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pretor(n)">Pretor (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;tor</etym>, so called 
 <etym lang="la">&agrave; pr&aelig;undo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Officer in old
time having the Rule of an
Army, the Generall; after&shy;
wards he had authority in
Judgement, and was a cheif
Justice, having other Judges
sitting under him, as Asconius
saith, to the number of seven&shy;
ty one, others write seventy
three; in process of time there
were so many Pretors chosen,
as there were Countries sub&shy;
ject to the empire. Thom.
At first the names of Consul,
Pr&aelig;tor and Judges were all
one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pretorian(a)">Pretorian (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;torius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to, or attend&shy;
ing on a Pretor ; The Preto&shy;
rian Guard of Souldiers in
old Rome were first establish&shy;
ed by Augustus, and consist&shy;
ed of ten thousand, every one
having double the wages of
a Legionary Souldier; and
were in the same nature to
the Emperors, as the Janiza&shy;
ries are to the Great Turk, or
as the Mamalukes were to the
Sultans of &AElig;gypt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prevaricate(v)">Prevaricate (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;varicor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to make a semblance or shew
to do a thing, and do quite
contrary, to betray a cause,
to swerve from truth, to go
out of the right way.<xref> See Ca&shy;
lumniate</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prevaricator(n)">Prevaricator (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;varica&shy;
tor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that leaves the right
way, or betrays a cause, a
false dealer, one that pleads
by covin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prevenient(a)">Prevenient (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;veniens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
coming or going before, pre&shy;
venting.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="hh8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="previdence(n)">Previdence (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;viden&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fore-seeing, or fore&shy;
casting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="previat(a)" lexeme="previous(a)">Previat
