<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="priapism(n)">Priapism (<etym lang="la">priapismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
disease when the Yard is
stretched out in length and
breadth, nothing provok&shy;
ing the patient to lust and
desire; if it come with a
beating or panting of the
Yard, then the evil is called
Satyriasis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pricker(n)">Pricker,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Huntsman on
horse-back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pricket(n)">Pricket,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fallow male
Deer, bearing that name from
a year old, to two years
old.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pridian(a)">Pridian (<etym lang="la">pridianus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of the
day before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primacy(n)">Primacy (from <etym lang="la">Primus</etym>, or
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Primace</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">excel&shy;
lency, cheif rule, highest e&shy;
state, and particularly an Ec&shy;
clesiastical dignity or com&shy;
mand over the Archbishops
and Bishops of a Kingdom or
Province; and he who hath
this dignity is called a Pri&shy;
mate or Metropolitan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primage(n)">Primage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a duty due to
the Marriners and Sailers for
loading any ship at the setting
forth from any Haven. An.32.
H.8. ca.14,</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prime(n)">Prime (<etym lang="la">primus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">first, prin&shy;
cipal, cheif. Also the first
hour of the day, in Sum&shy;
mer at four a clock, in winter
at eight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primer(n)">Primer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Prayer book of 
the Romanists so called; con&shy;
taining the Office of the Vir&shy;
gin Mary, which is divided
into seven several houres (as
a memorial of the seven prin&shy;
cipal parts and hours of our
Saviors Passion) viz. the Mat&shy;
tins and Laudes ; the Prime 
or first hour; the Third hour ;
the Sixth hour ; the Nineth
hour ; for morning. The E&shy;
vensong and Compline for the
<emend err="Eveniug">Evening</emend>; And these seven
houres are composed of
Psalms cheifly; Hymns, Can&shy;
ticles, Antiphones, Versicles,
Responsories and Prayers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primevous(a)">Primevous (<etym lang="la">prim&aelig;vus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the elder, or of the first age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primigenious(a)">Primigenious (<etym lang="la">primigeni&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that comes naturally of
it self, that hath not the be&shy;
ginning of another, the first
or original.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primipotent(a)">Primipotent (<etym lang="la">primipotens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of cheif power.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primitial(a)">Primitial (from <etym lang="la">primi&shy;
ti&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to first
fruits.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primitive(a)">Primitive (<etym lang="la">primitivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath no beginning of o&shy;
ther, the first.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primogeniture(n)">Primogeniture (from <etym lang="la">pri&shy;
mogenitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the first begetting
or bringing forth. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primordial(n)" lexeme="primordial(a)">Primordial (<etym lang="la">primordium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a first beginning, off-spring,
original. Bac. It is also used
adjectively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primum mobile(n)">Primum mobile ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">in
the Pagan Philosophy, is the
upper Heaven, supposed to
give motion to all the
rest.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="hh8v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="principality(n)">Principality (<etym lang="la">principali&shy; 
tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the estate or seat of a So&shy;
vereign Prince; Sovereignity,
Dominion, Seignory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Principalities(pn)">Principalities,</form> <xpln lang="en">are the se&shy;
cond Order of the second Hie&shy;
rarchy of Angels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="princock(n)">Princock (<etym lang="la">pr&aelig;cox</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a ripe&shy;
headed young Boy, or one
that is soon or over hasty
ripe; <etym lang="la">Non amo puerum Pr&aelig;cocis
ingenii</etym>, I love not a boy of
too early a wit; says the
Poet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prisage(n)">Prisage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">prizing,
praising, rating, valuing. It
seems also, to be that custom
or share, that belongs to the
King out of such Merchan&shy;
dize, as are taken at Sea, by
way of lawful prize. An.31.
Eliz. ca.5.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prisage of wine(n)">Prisage of wines, An.1.
H 8. ca.5.</form> <xpln lexeme="butlerage(n)">is a word almost out
of use, now called Butlerage,
it is a custom whereby the
Prince challenges, out of every
Bark loaden with wine, con&shy;
taining less then forty Tun,
two Tun of Wine at his
price. Cow.<xref> See Butlerage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Priscilla(pn)">Priscilla (a diminutive
of <etym lang="la">prisca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one of this name
was a great follower of Mon&shy;
tanus the arch Heretick, and
one of his Devillish Prophe&shy;
tesses, <term lang="la">circa ann. Christi</term> 181. 

Priscillianists a Sect of He&shy;
reticks that had their name
from Priscillianus about the
<emend err="the"></emend> year 388, who held two
Gods, one good, another bad,
the Creator of all things, and
denied the persons of the 
Blessed Trinity, with other
gross absurdities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prismatical glasses(n)">Prismatical Glasses (from
the Gr. <etym lang="gr">Prisma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are certain
triangular solid glasses, in
which you may see variety of
fine colours, &amp;c. Mr. White in
his Apol.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prism(n)">Prism (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&pi;&rho;&#x03af;&#x03c3;&mu;&alpha;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
powder or dust of those
things that are cut with a
Saw; Also a Geometrical fi&shy;
gure so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pristine(a)">Pristine (<etym lang="la">pristinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">old,
ancient, accustomed, won&shy;
ted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="privado(n)">Privado ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a <emend err="Favo">Favo&shy;</emend>
rite. Lo. Bac. in his Hen 7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="privation(n)">Privation (<etym lang="la">privatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
priving, bereaving, a with&shy;
drawing, a want or want&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="privative(a)">Privative (<etym lang="la">privativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that deprives, bereaves or
takes away; substantively, it
is a name for such monosylla&shy;
bical words, which being com&shy;
pounded with simple words
do deprive and take away the
proper sense or meaning of
them, as in Lat. de, dis, di, ex,
in, &amp;c. are called Privatives,
so are dis, un, in, &amp;c. in Eng&shy;
lish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="probate of testaments(n)">Probate of Testaments
 (<etym lang="la">probatio Testamentorum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
proving of wills, is the
producting and insinuating of
dead mens wills before the
Ecclesiastical Judge, Ordina&shy;
ry of the place, where the
party dyes, &amp;c. See more, if
you please, in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

lem, where those sheep were
washed, that were by the Law
to be sacrificed; it was other&shy;

thesda.</xpln></wordentry>

hath been tried.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prove(n)" lexeme="proof(n)">Prove orProof <class type="etymlang" lang="fr"> the Fr.</class>
call it <etym lang="fr">curette</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chyrurgeons
Instrument, wherewith he
tries the depth of wounds,
and sounds the bladder, and
gathers together such gravel,
congealed blood, or other
filth, as remains in it after
a stone taken out.</xpln>
<lemenote>
OED dates "prove" in this sense only in 1541.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="probity(n)">Probity (<etym lang="la">probitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">good&shy;

grity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="problem(n)">Probleme (<etym lang="la">Problema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
proposition or sentence pro&shy;
posed, with a question an&shy;
nexed. In Mathematicks it
is opposed to Theoreme, and
signifies such a proposition, as
is especially referred to
practise, or the doing of some&shy;
thing. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="problematical(a)">Problematical (<etym lang="la">problema&shy;

fing.</xpln></wordentry>

fore any thing is done, readi&shy;
ness. Sir H. Wot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proconsul(n)">Proconsul ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he who
having been Consul, went out
of his Magistracy at the years
end, with an extraordinary
consular power, into his
country to govern it; It is 


</page>

<page sig="ii1v">
sometimes taken for a Depu&shy;
ty, or one in stead or place of
a Consul ; under the Empe&shy;
rors those Governors of Pro&shy;
vinces, who were appointed
by the Senate, and people,
were called Proconsuls . Godw.</xpln></wordentry>

to drive off from day to day,

lay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="procurator(n)">Procurator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Procter,
Factor, or Solicitor, one
that looks to another mans
affairs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="procurator(n)">Procurator,</form> <xpln lang="en">is also used
for him that gathers the fruits
of a Benefice for another man.
An.3. Ric. I. Stat. I. ca.2. And
Procuracy is used for the spe&shy;
cialty, whereby he is autho&shy;
rized. <term lang="la">Ibid</term>. They are at this
day in the West parts cal&shy;
led Proctors . 

In the Republique of Ve&shy;
nice the Procurator is the se&shy;
cond man in dignity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prodigence(n)">Prodigence (<etym lang="la">prodigentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prodigy(n)">Prodigy (<etym lang="la">prodigium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
thing seldom seen, which sig&shy;
nifies some great good or
evil to follow; a wonder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prodigious(a)">Prodigious (<etym lang="la">prodigiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

vellous, contrary to the com&shy;
mon course of nature.</xpln></wordentry>

H. Wot.</xpln></wordentry>

titious</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proficient(a)">Proficient (<etym lang="la">proficiens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
helping, profiting, doing
much good; It is also used
substantively, as when we
say A. is a good proficient in
learning, that is, one that
profits or proceeds well in
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="profile(n)">Profile (Ital. <etym lang="it"> profilo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that design that shews the side
with the rising or falling
of any work; As a place
drawn sideways, that is so
as onely one side or moyety
of it may be seen, is called
the Profile; and is a term in
painting.</xpln></wordentry>

to put to flight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prohibition(n)">Prohibition (<etym lang="la">prohibitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
forbidding. It is also a Writ
framed for the forbidding
any Court, either spiritual
or secular, to proceed in any
cause there depending, upon
suggestion that the cognition
thereof belongs not to the
said Court. Fitz. nat. br. fol.
39. G.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prohibitory(a)">Prohibitory (<etym lang="la">prohibito&shy;
rius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that belongs to forbid&shy;
ding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="projectitious(a)">Proiectitious (<etym lang="la"><emend err="projecti"> projecti&shy;</emend>
tius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cast out, and nourished
of a stranger, flung away, as
of no account.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="projecture(n)">Proiecture (<etym lang="la">projectura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the jutting or leaning out in
Pillars, or other buildings, 
the coping of a wall.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolation(n)">Prolation (<etym lang="la">prolatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolegate(n)">AProlegate (<etym lang="la">Prolegatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolepsy(n)">Prolepsie (<etym lang="la">prolepsis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a na&shy;
tural <emend err="fore-knolwedge">fore-knowledge</emend> concei&shy;
ved in the mind; and hence
a figure in speaking whereby
we prevent and avoid what
another intended to alledge
against us.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proleptical(a)">Proleptical,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
the figure Prolepsis, or to
fore-knowledge. Proleptical
time, is that which is fixed in
the Chaos. Greg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proletarious(a)" lexeme="proletaneous(a)">Proletarious 
Proletaneous  (<etym lang="la">proletarius</etym>)
 <etym lang="la">proletaneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of a poor and base condition,
that has many children, and
little maintenance, or that
gives nothing to the Com&shy;
monwealth, but onely a sup&shy;
ply of children. 

A Proletarious Speech (<etym lang="la">prole&shy;
tarius sermo</etym>) the common and
vulgar speech, complement or
words of course; As when
one says to his friend; Pardon
my boldness, and the other
answers, You are not so bold as
welcome, or the like. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolifical(a)">Prolifical (<etym lang="la">prolisicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fruit&shy;
ful, that breeds or brings forth
issue apace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolification(n)">Prolification (<etym lang="la">prolificatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a making fruitful. Br.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ii2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolix(a)">Prolix (<etym lang="la">prolixus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">long,
large, high, liberal, sumptu&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolixity(n)">Prolixity (<etym lang="la">prolixitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
length, largeness, aboun&shy;
dance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prologue(n)">Prologue (<etym lang="la">prologus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pre&shy;
face, a fore-speech. The Pro&shy;
logue is such, as either opens
the state of the Comedy or
Fable; or such as commends
it, or the Poet to the people;
or such as refutes the Objecti&shy;
ons and Cavils of adversaries.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proloquutor(n)">Proloquutor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that speaks before or for o&shy;
thers, or that speaks at length;
The Speaker or Chair man
of each Convocation-house,
or of a Synod, is so ter&shy;
med. His Office is to com&shy;
mand the Clerk to call the
names of such as are of that
House, when he sees cause, to
cause all things propounded
to be read by him, to <emend err="ga">ga&shy;</emend>
ther the suffrages, and such
like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolusion(n)">Prolusion (<etym lang="la">prolusio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Es&shy;
say or flourish, that one makes
to prove what he can do be&shy;
fore he fight indeed; a
Proof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prolyte(n)">Prolyte (<etym lang="la">prolyta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Licen&shy;
ciate of the Laws, or one
that has studied the Law four
years.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promenade(n)">Promenade.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Pourme&shy;
nade</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Prometheus(pn)">Prometheus,</form> <xpln lang="en">Son to Ja&shy;
petus, who for stealing fire
out of Heaven, to make life
in his Images, was by Jupiter 
bound to Caucasus, where an
Eagle gnawed his heart, &amp;c.
Hence the fire of Prometheus,
Poetically used.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prominence(n)">Prominence (<etym lang="la">prominentia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the extending or jutting of a
thing out or over; a Pent&shy;
house. 

By this word the Anato&shy;
mists understand what por&shy;
tion soever notably surmounts
the parts circumjacent in
thickness, as a hill in the
plain. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prominent(a)">Prominent (<etym lang="la">prominens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
appearing or standing out
further then another, or a&shy;
bove and before other, ex&shy;
tending to, hanging over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promiscuous(a)">Promiscuous (<etym lang="la">promiscuus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
confused, mingled, common
to many; indifferent, mixed,
without order or considera&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promissary(n)">Promissary,</form> <xpln lang="en">he to whom
a promise is made. Mr.
White.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promontory(n)">Promontory (<etym lang="la">promentori&shy;
um, q mons in mari promi&shy;
nens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hill lying out, as an
elbow of land into the Sea;
A Mountain or head of land
butting out upon the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promoter(n)">Promoters (<etym lang="la">Promotores</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
are those who in popular
and penal actions defer the
names, or complain of Offen&shy;
ders, having part of the pro&shy;
fit for their reward. These
were called among the Ro&shy;
mans, Quadruplatores or De&shy;
latores . They belong espe&shy;
cially to the Exchequer
and the Upper Bench. Smith 


</page>

<page sig="ii3r">
de Repub. Angl. lib. 2. cap.
14.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promptitude(n)">Promptitude (<etym lang="la">promptitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
readiness, quickness, prone&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promptuary(n)">Promptuary (<etym lang="la">promptuari&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cellar, a Store-house, a
Spense, a Buttery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promulgation(n)">Promulgation (<etym lang="la">promulga&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a publishing, a proclai&shy;
ming, a noysing abroad. The
Law was hanged up pub&shy;
lickly in the Market Place,
for the space of three Market
days; which kind of publish&shy;
ing the Law was tearmed,
 <term lang="la">Legis Promulgatio</term>, <term lang="la">quasi</term>, <term lang="la">pro&shy;
vulgatio</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pro-nephew(n)">Pro-nephew (<etym lang="la">pronepos</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Nephewes Son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prone(a)">Prone (<etym lang="la">pronus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">having
the face down, inclined, stoop&shy;
ing downward, ready, easie,
quick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propagate(v)">Propagate (<etym lang="la">propago</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
cut down an old Vine, that
of it many young may be
planted, to make to spread;
to extend or dilate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propension(n)">Propension (<etym lang="la">propensio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
inclination of mind, readi&shy;
ness, proneness, propensi&shy;
ty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propense(a)">Propense (<etym lang="la">propensus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hea&shy;
vy, greatly inclined, very
ready and prone to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="properate(v)">Properate (<etym lang="la">propero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
go quickly or hastily, to say
or do quickly, to make haste
or speed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prophetize(v)">Prophetize (<etym lang="la">propheto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
prophecy or foretell things
to come, to sing praises to
God; To preach or inter&shy;
pret.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propination(n)">Propination (<etym lang="la">propinatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
drinking to one, a bidding
one drink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propinquity(n)">Propinquity (<etym lang="la">propinqui&shy;
tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">nearness, Neighbor&shy;
hood; also Affinity, Alliance,
Kindred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propitiate(v)">Propitiate (<etym lang="la">propitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
reconcile and appease God
with Sacrifices, to please, to
pacifie; also to asswage or mi&shy;
tigate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propitiatory(n)">Propitiatory (<etym lang="la">propitiato&shy; 
rium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the place where God
is pacified; Also a Table set
on the Arke of the Old Te&shy;
stament, on either side
whereof was a Cherubin of
Gold, with the wings spread
over the Propitiatory, and
their faces looking one to&shy;
wards another. It is also
used Adjectively, as belong&shy;
ing to such a Sacrifice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propitious(a)">Propitious (<etym lang="la">propitius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">not
displeased, merciful, favorable,
propice, gentle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proposition(n)">Proposition (<etym lang="la">propositio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that whereby we shew what
we will speak or prove, a
sentence or matter propoun&shy;
ded, a Question or Positi&shy;
on. 

In Logick the first part of
a Syllogism is called the Pro&shy;
position  or Major ; and this
hath three parts, Subjectum,
Pr&aelig;dicatum, and Copula ; as
Peter is a man; Peter is the
Subject, Man is the Predi&shy; 
cat or Attribute, and the verb
[ is ] is the Copula, or tying of
them together.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="113v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propr&aelig;tor(n)">Propr&aelig;tor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Lieu&shy;
tenant appointed by the Em&shy;
peror to Govern a Province,
with the authority of a Pretor,
a Lord Justice. The Trans&shy;
later of Livie saith, tis more
properly he, who having been
Pretor, went out of his Ma&shy;
gistracy at the years end,
and was sent into his Province
again, with ful authority of
Pretor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proprietary(n)">Proprietary (<etym lang="la">proprietari&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he to whom the proper&shy;
ty of a thing belongs; It is
most commonly used for him
that hath the fruits of a Be&shy;
nefice to him and his heirs or
successors; as in time past Ab&shy;
bots and Priors had to them
and their successors. See <xref>Ap&shy;
propriation</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propudious(a)">Propudious (<etym lang="la">propudiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is filthily abused in lea&shy;
chery, or full of shameful in&shy;
famy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propugnacle(n)">Propugnacle (<etym lang="la">propugnacu&shy; 
lum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fortress, a strong hold,
a Bulwark, a Defence, a Block&shy;
house. Mr. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propugnator(n)">Propugnator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
fender, a maintainer, one
that fights in defence of some
person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propulsation(n)">Propulsation (<etym lang="la">propulsatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a putting away, a driving back,
a chasing forward, a repel&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="propulsory(a)">Propulsory (<etym lang="la">propulsorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that serves to put away or
drive back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prorepsion(n)">Prorepsion (<etym lang="la">prorepsio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
creeping forward, a stealing
forward by little and little, a 
growing, spreading, or coming
forth. Icon Basil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pro-rex(n)">Prorex ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Viceroy,
he that in the Kings absence
supplies his place, and repre&shy;
sents his person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proritate(v)">Proritate (<etym lang="la">prorito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pro&shy;
voke, to allure, to stir up, to
exasperate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prorogue(v)">Prorogue (<etym lang="la">prorogo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to pro&shy;
long, defer, to put off till ano&shy;
ther day, to continue, as we
say the Parliament is Prorogued,
when it is adjourned or put
off for some time, but not
ended.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prosaic(a)">Prosaick (<etym lang="la">prosaicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is in Prose and not in Meeter,
pertaining to Prose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="procission(n)">Procission (<etym lang="la"><emend err="procissio" source="errata">proscissio</emend></etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
cutting up, a tilling, a
ploughing, a manuring of
land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proscription(n)">Proscription (<etym lang="la">proscriptio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the manner of condemnati&shy;
on, when it is proclaimed,
that who ever finds a man,
may lawfully kill him, and
have a reward; a designing
or exposing to slaughter; al&shy;
so publique sale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proscript(n)">Proscript (from <etym lang="la">proscribo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an Outlaw, a man designed
or exposed to slaughter, a
proscribed or attainted per&shy;
son. Those were termed Pro&shy;
scripti, who were not onely
exiled and banished their
Country, but had their goods
seized and confiscated. <term lang="la">Quo&shy;
niam eorum nomina in publico scri&shy;
bebantur, hinc proscribi dice&shy;
bantur</term> . Fr. Maturantius in
Phil.13.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proselyte(n)">Proselyte (<etym lang="la">proselytus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
stranger turned to our fashion
of living, or converted to our
Religion. It signified of old,
one converted from the Hea&shy;
thenish Religion to the Jew&shy;
ish. Acts 2.10 and 13.43.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prosimetrical(a)">Prosimetrical (<etym lang="la">prosimetri&shy;

long and short.</xpln></wordentry>

that art.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prosopopaeia(n)">Prosopop&aelig;ia, ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;

laying along. Apology for<emend err="learn"> learn&shy;</emend>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prostitute(n)">Prostitute (<etym lang="la">prostituta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">she

to be abused by all that come,
a common Harlot.</xpln></wordentry>

ing flat, over-thrown, de&shy;
stroyed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="protasis(n)">Protasis ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <emend err="">)</emend></form> <xpln lang="en">a<emend err="Propositi"> Propositi&shy;</emend>
on or Declaration; also the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="protatic(a)">Protatick,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
Protasis ; also he that layes
open the argument, or speaks 
the Prologue in a Comedy,
and appears no more, is cal&shy;
led Protatica persona.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Protestants(pn)">Protestants,</form> <xpln lang="en">were first so
called from their Protestation 
made at the Imperial City of
Spires in the Palatinate of
Rhene in Germany, in the year
1529. Heil. p.271.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="protend(v)">Protend (<etym lang="la">protendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to set,

spread abroad, to defer or pro&shy;
long.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Proteus(pn)">Proteus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the
Sea, who as Poets faign, was
able to turn himself into any
shape. Hence the Proverb,
 <term lang="la">Proteo mutabilior</term>, More change&shy;
able then Proteus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proto(px)">Protos ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Primus, the
first or chief, and is often used
in composition. As</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="protocol(n)">Protocol (<etym lang="la">protocolum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is first made and needs cor&shy;
rection; the upper part of
the Leaf of a Book, bearing
out above the rest, wherein
the name or title is written.</xpln></wordentry>

Baptist died before the con&shy;

first formed or made; an At&shy;
tribute or Epithete most pro&shy;
per for Adam. If from Proto&shy;
plastes, it may signifie Almigh&shy;

ty God, the first framer of all
things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="protype(n)">Protype (<etym lang="la">protypum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

py; an image or form where&shy;
of moulds are made, in which

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proveditor(n)">Proveditor (Ital. from <etym lang="it">pro&shy;
video</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a foreseer, one that
takes order for; It is an Of&shy;
ficer among the Venetians ;
In war their General (be&shy;
ing most commonly a stran&shy;
ger) is supervised by two
Proveditors, without whom
he may not attempt any
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

nation</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proverbial(a)">Proverbial (<etym lang="la">proverbia&shy;
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to a

ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proveditor(n)">Providore,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Governor 
of the Island Zant, so called;
See <xref>Proveditor</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="provincial(a)">Provincial (<etym lang="la">provincialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to a Pro&shy;
vince; which is with us most
usually taken for the circuit
of an Arch Bishops Jurisdicti&shy;
on. Among Friars, and o&shy;
ther Religious, he who is the
cheif of his Order in such a
Province, is their Provincial.
A 4. H 4. ca. 17.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proviso(n)">Proviso ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a con&shy;
dition inserted into any Deed
or other matter, upon the
observance whereof, the va&shy;
lidity of the whole con&shy;
sists.</xpln></wordentry>

and degrees of Provosts, of

tences, where many superflu&shy;
ous words are cut off; It

call it a Shalme, to play

ment three square, of seven&shy;
ty two strings, and of in&shy;
comparable sweetness, As

farmed (by great) the Empe&shy;
rors Tribute. 

It was an odious name a&shy;
mong the Jews, because they
were commonly men of ill
conscience, that exercised that
Office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="publication(n)">Publication (<etym lang="la">publicatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
publishing or making com&shy;
mon. In Chancery or other
Courts of Equity, we say a
cause is come to Publication,
when the Plaintiff hath ex&shy; 
hibited his Bill, the Defen&shy;
dant answered, and witnes&shy;
ses are examined, then the
Court, either by special or&shy;
der or of course, grants Pub&shy;
lication, or a publishing of the
proofs, that is, liberty for
both parties to take out the
Depositions of the witnesses
whereby to prepare for a hea&shy;
ring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purlieu(n)">Purlue (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">pur</etym>,

Manwood parte secunda of his
For. Laws, cap.20. In which
Purlue it was lawful for the
owner of the ground to
hunt, if he could dispend for&shy;
ty shillings per annum of
Free-hold, &amp;c. See Man&shy;
wood parte I. pag. 151, 157,
180.</xpln></wordentry>

Dwarfish people in the ut&shy;
termost Mountains of In&shy;
dia, in height not passing
one Cubit, their women
bring forth children at Five
yeers, and at Eight are ac&shy;
counted old. Fame goes,
that they have continual war
with Cranes, by whom they
are often worsted, &amp;c. 

But Dr. Brown in his Vul&shy;
gar Errors, chap. 21. with
good reason, makes doubt
whether there are, or ever
were any such creatures.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ii7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pyramid(n)">Pyramid (<etym lang="la">pyramis, idis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a great building of stone or
other matter, broad and four
square beneath, upwards, the
higher it goes, the smaller and
sharper.<xref> See Obelisk</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pyramidal(a)" lexeme="pyramidical(a)">Pyramidal 
 or Pyramidical (<etym lang="la">pyrami&shy;
dicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or pertaining to a Pyramid,
broad beneath and sharpning
upwards. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pyramidography(n)">Pyramidography (<etym lang="la">pyra&shy;
midographia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a writing, treat&shy;
ing, or describing of Pyramids ;
whereof one Mr. Greaves has
wrote a book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pyratical(a)">Pyratical</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Piratical</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pyrenaean mountains(pn)">Pyren&aelig;an Mountains<etym lang="la">
Pyren&aelig;i Montes (</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">are those
great Hils which divide France
from Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pyrrhonian(a)"><emend err="Pyrrhenian" source="errata">Pyrrhonian</emend>,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to
Pyrrho, a Sceptic Phylosopher
of Greece, who thought no&shy;
thing certain; Hence Phyrrho&shy;
nian incredulity . Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertaining to Pytha&shy;

opinion of the transmigration
of souls from one body to a&shy;
nother.</xpln></wordentry>

ras.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pythian games(pn)">Pythian Games (<etym lang="la">Py&shy;
thia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">certain Games institu&shy;
ted in Greece to the honor of
Apollo, in memory of his<emend err="van"> van&shy;</emend>
quishing the great Dragon Py&shy;
thon, sent by Juno to persecute
his mother Latona.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="python(n)">Python ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a man that
prophecieth, and tels things
to come, by a Devillish spi&shy;
rit which is in him; also a Ser&shy;

that is possessed with such a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Quakers(pn)">Quakers,</form> <xpln lang="en">a modern Sect,
not much differing from the
old Enthusiasts, and took
name from their trembling
and quaking, when, in their
Raptures and Enthusiasms,
they vainly pretend the Spi&shy;
rit of God comes upon them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quandary(n)">Quandary,</form> <xpln lang="en">a man is said
to be in a Quandary, when,
he is <emend err="a in">in a</emend> study, or doubt what
to do or whether to go;
and is conjectured to come 


</page>

<page sig="ii8r">
from <etym lang="la">quando ara</etym>, for that in
the time of Heathenism, peo&shy;
ple would ask, <term lang="la">quando ara?</term> 
when shall the sacrifice be
made? or when will the Al&shy;
tar be ready?</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quadruple(a)">Quadruple (<etym lang="la">quadruplus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
four times so much, four&shy;
fold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarantine(n)">Quarentaine ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Lent;

ring which, prayers are in som
places poured out for the

time it is taken for forty days
truce or cessation; sometime
for an indulgence or releasing
of forty days penance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarentine(n)">Quarentine (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Quarantaine</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a benefit al&shy;
lowed by the Law of Eng&shy;
land, to the widow of a lan&shy;
ded man deceased, whereby
she may challenge to continue
in his Capital Messuage or
cheif Mansion house by the
space of forty days after his
decease; Of this see Bract.
lib.2. ca.40. And if the Heir
or any other attempt to eject
her, she may have the Writ
 <term lang="la">de Quarantina habenda</term>. Fitz.
nat br. fol.161.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarry(n)">Quarry</form> <xpln lang="en">(besides that of
stones) signifies among Hun&shy;
ters a reward given to Hounds 
after they have hunted, or
the Venison which is taken
by hunting.</xpln></wordentry>

part of a Beam. Min. Of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quaternity(n)">Quaternity (<etym lang="la">quaternitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the number of four, which
(says Dr. Brown) stands much
admired, not onely in the 


</page>

<page sig="ii8v">
quaternity of the Elements,
which are the principles of
Bodies, but in the Letters of
the name of God, which in
the Latin, Greek, Arabian, Per&shy;
sian, Hebrew, and <emend err="Egptian">Egyptian</emend>, con&shy;
sists of that number, and was
so venerable among the Pytha&shy;
goreans, that they swore by the
number four . Vulgar Errors, p.
206.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quaver(n)" lexeme="semi-quaver(n)">Quaver in singing (from

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quid pro quo(n)">Quid pro quo,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an Arti&shy;
ficial Speech in our Common
Law, signifying as much as the
Greek <etym lang="gk">&omicron;&upsilon;&nu;&#x03ac;&lambda;&lambda;&alpha;&gamma;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, among
the Civilians, which is a mu&shy;
tual Protestation or perform&shy;
ance of both parties to a Con&shy;
tract; as a Horse and Ten
pound, between the buyer
and the seller. Kitch. fol. 184.
And used in our common
Speech, One for another; as to
render one Quid pro quo, <expan type="">id est</expan> to
give him as good, as he brings.
And is used by Apothecaries,
when, instead of one thing,
they use another of the same
nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quietus est(n)">Quietus est,</form> <xpln lang="en">he is quiet or
acquitted; it is commonly
used for an acquittance or dis&shy;
charge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quincupedal(n)">Quincupedal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
measure or rule of five foot
long.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quindecimvir(n)">Quindecimvir ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
of the fifteen Magistrates that
governed a Commonwealth,
and were joyntly in Office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quingenarious(a)">Quingenarious (<etym lang="la">quinge&shy;
narius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of five hundred, or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Quinquagesima Sunday(pn)">Quinquagesima Sun&shy;
day,</form> <xpln lang="en">is always that which

day ; so called either, because 


</page>

<page sig="kk1r">

fore Passion Sunday.<xref> See Sexa&shy;
gesima</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quinquereme(n)">Quinquereme (<etym lang="la">Quinque&shy;
remis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Galley, wherein
every Oar hath five men to
draw it; the Quadriremes had
four to an Oar; and the Tri&shy;
remes three. Some have
thought that the Quinquere&shy;
mes had five ranks of Oars,
one over another, and the
other Gallies ratably fewer;
but had this been so, they
must then have had five
Decks, each over other,
which hath seldom been seen
in Ships of a thousand Tuns;
nor could the third, fourth,
and fifth ranks have reached
the water with their Oars.
Sir Wal. Ral. History of the
World. lib.5. 
Quinquereme, may also be
taken for a little Ship or Gal&shy;
ley that hath five Oars on a
side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quinquevit(n)">Quinquevit ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one 
of the five that are in the like
Office and Authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quinquiplicate(v)">Quinquiplicate (<etym lang="la">quinqui&shy;
plico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to multiply by fives, to
double five times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintage(n)">Quintage (from <etym lang="la">quintus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
fifth part, or a laying out of
the fifth part of an Inheri&shy;
tance for yonger Brethren.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintain(n)">Quintain,Quinten or 
Quintin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a game or sport
still in request at Marriages,
in some parts of this Nation;
the manner now corruptly
thus, A Quintin, Butteress or
thick plank of Wood is set
fast in the ground in the High&shy;
way, where the Bride and
Bridegroom are to pass, and
Poles are provided, with
which the yong-men run a
Tilt on Hors-back; and he
that breaks most Poles, and
shews most activity, wins the
Garland. But Stowe in his
Survey of London, p.76. says,
That in the year of Christ
1253. the Youthful Citizens,
for an exercise of their Acti&shy;
vity, set forth a game to run
at the Quinten, and whosoever
did best, should have a Pea&shy;
cock for prize; and he that
hit not the broad end of the
Quintin with his Lance or
Pole, was laughed at; and he
that did, if he rid not the
faster, had a good blow on
his neck with a Bag full of
Sand, which hung on the o&shy;
ther end.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintal(n)">Quintal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
weight.<xref> See Kintal</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintessence(n)">Quintessence (<etym lang="la">quinta essen&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="kk1v">
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the vertue, force or spirit
of a thing; it is a certain,
subtile, and spiritual sub&shy;
stance, extracted out of a
thing, by separation from its
corruptible Elements, differ&shy;
ing really from its essence; as
Aqua vit&aelig;, of the spirit of
Wine, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintessential(a)">Quintessential (<etym lang="la">quintessen&shy; 
tialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to quintes&shy;
sence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintile(n)">Quintile (<etym lang="la">quintilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
moneth July, the fifth moneth
from March, reckoning it for
one.<xref> See July</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quintuple(a)">Quintuple (<etym lang="la">quintuplus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
five times so much, five fold.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quinzain(n)">Quinzain ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term or
delay of fifteen days; also a
staff of fifteen verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Quirinal(a)">Quirinal (<etym lang="la">quirinalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or pertaining to one of the
seven Hills of Rome called
Quirinalis, or to Rome itself.
See <xref>Esquilinus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quirister(n)">Quirister,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Singer in a
Quire, a Quire-man, a Cho&shy;
rister.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quiritation(n)">Quiritation (<etym lang="la">quiritatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
crying, bewailing, a calling
for succor, properly of the
Romans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quod libet(n)">Quod libet ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">what
pleaseth; a quirk or quiddity.
In some Schools there are
Quodlibets, or Quodlibetical 
Questions disputed pro and
con, wherein a man may hold
what part of the controversie
he pleaseth; in which dispu&shy;
tations, are many witty quips,
jeers, jests, &amp;c. for enter&shy; 
tainment and sport of the
Auditors. Thence some may
call a Quip that pleaseth some,
though it offend others, a
quodlibet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quodlibetary(n)">Quodlibitaries (from <etym lang="la">quod&shy;
libet</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">those that run after their
own fancy or imagination, and
do what they list.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quorum(n)">Quorum,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word much
used in Commissions under
the Great Seal, especially to
Justices of the Peace in the
several Counties. For exam&shy;
ple, if there be sixteen
Justices of the Peace in Com&shy;
mission for the County of
Kent, perhaps four of the
chief, and most substantial,
are of the Quorum, that is,
Quorum unus (for so the Com&shy;
mission runs,) one of which
four must always be present
at the execution of such
things as they are authorised
to do by their Commission.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quotidian(a)">Quotidian (<etym lang="la">quotidianus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
done daily, that happens every
day, ordinary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quotient(n)">Quotient (from <etym lang="la">quoties</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that part or portion, which
(in the division of a thing,
among many) falls to every
ones share; a term in Arith&shy;
matick. 
</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rabbi(n)" lexeme="rabbin(n)"><f type="l"/> RAbbi orRabbin (<class type="etymlang" lang="br">Br.</class>
<etym lang="br">Rabbi</etym>, from the Hebr.
 <etym lang="he">Rab</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">in Doctrina Magister</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Master or Doctor among the 


</page>

<page sig="kk2r">
Jews, a Teacher; one that is
in stead of many or equal to
many for his excellency.
Matth.23.7,8.</xpln></wordentry>

the Rabbies or Doctors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rabbinist(n)">Rabbinist,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that stu&shy;
dies, or is cunning in the
works of the Rabbies ; some&shy;
times used for a Dunce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rabdomancy(n)">Rabdomancy,</form> <xpln lang="en">Divination

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rabid(a)">Rabid (<etym lang="la">rabidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Wood, or
mad as a Dog; furious, ra&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="racemation(n)">Racemation (<etym lang="la">racematio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

great Clusters are gone; a
gleaning of Grapes. Hist. K.
Cha.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="racemiferous(a)">Racemiferous (<etym lang="la">racemifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears kernels, or clusters
of Grapes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raca(n)" lexeme="racha(n)">Raca orRacha (from the
Hebr. <etym lang="he">Rach</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to spit; or from
 <etym lang="he">Ric</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> lightheaded or empty)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an imperfect or broken speech,
proceeding from an angry
minde; a word of reproach,
signifying as much as a vain or
empty fellow. Matth.5.23.
Hence perhaps that opprobri&shy;
ous word of ours, a Rachil or
Rake-hel, <expan type="">id est</expan> such a one, as if
one should rake hell, his like
would not be found.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rachel(pn)">Rachel (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sheep or
Lamb; a Womans name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rack vintage(n)">Rack Vintage(31 H. 8.
cap.14.)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a second Vintage
or Voyage for Wines by our
Merchants into France, &amp;c.
for Rack'd Wines, that is,
Wines so cleansed and purged, 
that they may be, and are
drawn from the Lees ; from
this Voyage our Merchants
commonly return about the
end of December, or beginning
of January . Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ramage(n)">Ramage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Boughes,
Branches, or any thing that
belongs thereto. Hence a
Ramage Hawk or Faulcon, is
such a one, as hath been long
among the Boughs and
Branches, preying for himself,
a Hagard.</xpln></wordentry>

narrower then a Galley, but
swift and easie to be govern&shy;
ed. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rambooze(n)">Rambooz,</form> <xpln lang="en">a compound
drink, in most request at
Cambridge, and is commonly
made of Eggs, Ale, Wine,
and Sugar; but in Summer,
of Milk, Wine, Sugar, and
Rose water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rampant(a)">Rampant (Fr.<etym lang="fr"> Rempant</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
creeping, crawling, trailing 
along, or climbing; a term in
Heraldry, when a Lyon or
other Beast is painted rear&shy;
ing up with his right fore-foot
directly against the Dexter
point of the Escotcheon, as
it were ready to combat with
his enemy. Peacham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rape(n)">Rape (<etym lang="la">rapus vel rapa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
part of a County, signifying
as much as an Hundred; as
Southsex is divided into six
parts; which by a peculiar
name are called Rapes, viz.
The Rape of Chichester, of A&shy;
rundel, of Brember, of Lewis,
of Puensey, of Hastings. Cam.
Britan. pag. 225. These parts are
in other places called Tyth&shy;
ings, Lathes, or Wapentakes .
Smith de Repub. Angl. lib.2.
c.16.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rape(n)">Rape (<etym lang="la">raptus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Felony
committed by a man, in the 


</page>

<page sig="kk3r">
violent deflouring a woman,
be she old or yong. Briton.
cap. I. This offence is with
us Felony in the principal
and his aiders. Anno II H. 4.
cap.23. Anno I Edw.4. cap. I.
Westm.2. cap.13. See more in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rape wine(n)">Rape Wine (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Rap&eacute;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a very small Wine, coming
of Water cast upon the Mo&shy;
ther of Grapes, which have
been pressed; also the Wine
which comes from a Vessel
filled with whole and sound
Grapes (divided from the
cluster) and some Wine a&shy;
mong, which being drawn
out is supplied by the lea&shy;
vings of good wine, put
into the Vessel, and revived
and kept in hart a whole
year long by the said Grapes.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Raphael(pn)">Raphael (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Phy&shy;
sick of God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rapine(n)">Rapine (<etym lang="la">rapina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">robbery,

force. To take a thing se&shy;
cretly, is properly called
theft; but to take it open&shy;

pine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rapinous(a)">Rapinous (from <etym lang="la">rapina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
ravenous, greedy, violent, co&shy;
vetous, ravishing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhapsody(n)">Rapsody (<etym lang="la">rapsodia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an

tences.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rasp(n)" lexeme="raspatory(n)">Raspe

toire</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an In&shy;

from a File, being more
gross.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ratiocination(n)">Ratiocination (<etym lang="la">ratiocina&shy;

vus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to reasoning

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rational(n)">Rational (<etym lang="la">rationale</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Ornament, which the High
Priest of the Jewes wore
on his Brest, when he ex&shy;
ecuted his Function, be&shy;
ing four-square of the
length of a span, made cu&shy;
riously of Gold and twisted
Silk of divers colours,
wherein were set twelve
pretious Stones in four
ranks of Gold, and in every
Stone graven one of the
names of the twelve sons of
Jacob.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raucity(n)">Raucity (<etym lang="la">raucitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hoarse&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ravishment(n)">Ravishment (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Ravisse&shy;
ment</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">direptio, raptus</term>, &amp;c.)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in our Law an un&shy;
lawful taking away, either a
woman or an heir in Ward:
Sometime it is used also in
one signification with Rape,
( viz.) the violent deflouring
a Woman.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ranger(n)">Raunger (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Rang</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> a rank, row, lift,
order)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an Officer of the
Forest, but not within the
Forest, having no charge of
vert, but onely of Venison,
that comes out of the Forest
into his charge, or part of
the Pourallee, to safe conduct
them back again, &amp;c. See
Manwood, part I. of his Forest
Laws, p.50. And part 2. c.20.
num.15,16,17.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="re(px)">Re,</form> <xpln lang="en">of itself hath neither
signification, nor use (other
then as a Musical or singing
Note,) in composition it
commonly signifies, again,
mutually, or back again. As 
to Reassume (<etym lang="la">reassumo</etym>) to take
again; to Re-edifie (<etym lang="la">re&aelig;difico</etym>)
to rebuild or build again;
to Repel (<etym lang="la">repello</etym>) to thrust or
put back, &amp;c. Sometimes it
alters not the sence; as to
Remonstrate, to relinguish, &amp;c.
Sometimes it gives an energy
to the simple; as to Redargue,
to Reclaim, &amp;c. And some&shy;
times a contrary sence; as to
Reprove, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reach(n)">Reach,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the distance of
any two Points of Land,
which bear in a right Line to
one another; which term is
most commonly used in Ri&shy;
vers; as Lime-house Reach,
Greenwich Reach, &amp;c. The
Reach being counted so far, as
you can see the Reach to lie in
a straight line.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="real(n)">Real (<class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class> <term lang="la">Ab armis
Regis, monet&aelig; huic impressis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Spanish Coyn of equal value
with our sixpence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ream of paper(n)">Ream of Paper (from
the Teut.Riemen, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">cor&shy;
rigia, lorum</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">as much as con&shy;
veniently can be tyed with
one string, which is now
twenty Quires, and to every
quire twenty four or twenty
five sheets.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="realize(v)">Realize (Fr. <etym lang="fr">realizer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to make of a real con&shy;
dition, estate or property,
to make real or essen&shy;
tial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebate(v)">Rebate</form> <xpln lang="en">is a term most used
among Merchants and Trades&shy;
men; As when a Merchant
sells Wares to a Shop-keeper
for one hundred pounds, to 


</page>

<page sig="kk4r">
be paid at six moneths end;
if the Shop-keeper will at
any time before the end of
the six moneths, pay him
the one hundred pounds,
the Merchant commonly re&shy;
bates for the time, that is, al&shy;
lows him so much as the in&shy;
terest of the one hundred
pounds amounts to, for the
time of such anti-payment.
See <xref>Chamfering</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rebecca(pn)">Rebecca (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Fat and
full; a womans name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebeck(n)">Rebeck (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Reb&eacute;c</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Fiddle, or certain Musical In&shy;
strument of three strings.
Chaucer uses it for an old
trot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebesk work(n)">Rebesk work.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Ara&shy;
besque</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebus(n)">Rebus (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class> and is so
used <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">in Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Whereas (says 
Camden) Poesie is a speaking
Picture, and a Picture a
speechless Poesie, they who
wanted wit to express their
conceit in speech, did use to
depaint it out as it were in
Pictures, which they called
Rebus, by a Latin name, well
fitting their devise. These
our English in Edward the
Thirds time, learnt of the
pregnant Picardes, and were
so well liked and entertain&shy;
ed here by all degrees, that
he was no body that could
not hammer out of his name
an invention by this wit&shy;
craft. 

John Eagleshead (to notifie
his name about his Arms, as
I have seen (says Cam.) in
an old Seal with an Eagles&shy;
head) set down this Verse, 
<term lang="la">Hoc Aquil&aelig; caput est, signumque Figura Johannis</term> . 
Nor are these Inventions
altogether laid aside at pre&shy;
sent: For one Mr. Yates hath
three Yates or Gates in his
Seal, and the Motto, <term lang="la">Sit quar&shy;
ta C&aelig;li</term> . And I have seen
some Signs in London, that
neer amount to Rebusses, as
one, whose name is Chopping&shy;
ton, has for his Sign an Ax,
Chopping a Tun. But Re&shy;
busses may be of other matters
as well as names; and there&shy;
fore may be defined to be
Representations of ordinary
or odd things, accompanied
with equivocal Motto's or
words, which as they stand, 
seem to make a Sentence,
but pronounced without stop,
describe the things repre&shy;
sented. For example, a Fool
being painted kneeling, with
a Horn at his mouth, and
the words, <term lang="fr">Fol age nous trom&shy;
pe</term>, near him; pronounce them
another way, and you have
 <term lang="fr">Fol &agrave; genous trompe</term> . See Peach&shy;
am, l.3. p.155.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recalcitrate(v)">Recalcitrate (<etym lang="la">recalcitro</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to kick or strike with the
heel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recant(v)">Recant (<etym lang="la">recanto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to sing
after another, to uncharm,
to revoke or unsay a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recapitulate(v)">Recapitulate (<etym lang="la">recapitulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="kk4v">
to rehearse, relate, or make a
short repetition of a long dis&shy;
course.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recargaison(n)">Recargaison ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a back&shy;
fraught, or the lading of a
ship home again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recede(v)">Recede (<etym lang="la">recedo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to re&shy;
coil, retire, to go from,
to swarve from, to re&shy;
turn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recent(a)">Recent (<etym lang="la">recens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">new,
fresh, lusty, newly or lately
made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resensement(n)" lexeme="recension(n)">Resensement ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>) Recension (<etym lang="la">recensio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
reckoning, rehearsing, review&shy;
ing and numbring, an exami&shy;
nation or tryal of an account
or number.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The term "resensement" is not found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receptacle(n)">Receptacle (<etym lang="la">receptaculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Store-house or Ware-house,
any thing that is fit for the
receiving and safe keeping of
things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receptary(n)">Receptary (Fr.<etym lang="fr"> Recep&shy;
taire</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a note of Physical Re&shy;
ceipts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receptitious(a)">Receptitious (<etym lang="la">receptitius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is received, kept, or re&shy;
served to ones use from an&shy;
other.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receptivity(n)">Receptivity (from <etym lang="la">recipio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an aptness or capableness to
receive or take in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recess(n)">Recesse (<etym lang="la">recessus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a recoil&shy;

back, or further off, a re&shy;
treat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rechabites(pn)">Rechabites,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called from
Rechab their Father. Jerem.
35.2,3,4, &amp;c. These nei&shy;
ther drunk Wine, nor sowed
Seed, nor built Houses, nor
planted Vineyards; but like 
strangers lived all their days
in Tents. Rosse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recheat(n)">Recheat,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name of one
of those Lessons which
Hunters use in winding a
Horn; perhaps from the
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Rechercher</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to seek
diligently; because most com&shy;
monly, when they winde this
Lesion, the Hounds have lost
their game, or hunt a game un&shy;
known.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recidivation(n)">Recidivation (<etym lang="la">recidivatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a back-sliding, a falling back,
a relapse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reciprocal(a)">Reciprocal (<etym lang="la">reciprocus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath a recourse, respect
or return from whence it
comes, that ebbs and flows,
mutual, interchangable, one
for another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reciprocation(n)">Reciprocation (<etym lang="la">recipro&shy;
catio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a returning, mutual
yeelding, or interchang&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recision(n)">Recision (<etym lang="la">recisio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cut&shy;
ting off, away, or again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recitative(n)">Recitative (<etym lang="la">recitativus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is openly read, or re&shy;
hearsed aloud. Among the
Italians it is an artificial way
of singing.<xref> See Opera</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recluse(n)">Recluse (<etym lang="la">reclusus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">close&shy;
ly kept in, or shut up, as
a Monk or Nun, retired, soli&shy;
tary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recogitate(v)">Recogitate (<etym lang="la">recogito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
weigh and consider in minde
earnestly, to think and
think again upon some thing,
to revolve, to ponder in
minde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recognition(n)">Recognition (<etym lang="la">recognitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a knowledge, a consider&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="kk5r">
ing, a calling to remem&shy;
brance, a reviving, or over&shy;
looking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recognizance(n)">Recognizance (<etym lang="la">recognitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is defined in our Common
Law to be a Bond of Re&shy;
cord, testifying the Recogni&shy;
sor to ow to the Recognisee a
certain sum of money, and
is acknowledged in some
Court of Record, or be&shy;
fore some Judge, or other
Officer of such Court, ha&shy;
ving Authority to take the
same: As the Masters of the
Chancery, the Judges of either
Bench, Barons of the Ex&shy;
chequer, Justices of Peace,
&amp;c. And those that are
meer Recognisances are not
sealed but enrolled; and
Execution by force thereof,
is of all the Recognisors 
Goods and Chattels, except
his draught Beasts, and im&shy;
plements of Husbandry, and
of the moyety of his Lands.
Westm. part I. Symb. Lib.
2. Tit. Recognizances. Sect.
149. See more in Cow&shy;
el.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recognize(v)">Recognize (<etym lang="la">recognosco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to call or bring into remem&shy;
brance, to take notice or ac&shy;
quaintance of, to know a&shy;
gain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Recollects(pn)">Recollects,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
Branch of Franciscan Fri&shy;
ers.</xpln></wordentry>

the best of things. Selden.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recreant(n)">Recreant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
denies his own challenge, or
eats his word; wearied, faint&shy;
hearted, spent. I read it in
the Protestants Apology.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recrement(n)">Recrement (<etym lang="la">recrementum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
any superfluous thing, as
Dross, scum of metals, the
dregs, or dross of perfume,
that which is cut or pared
away.</xpln></wordentry>

to lay a fault to his charge,
that blames others.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rectangle(n)">Rectangle (<etym lang="la">rectangulus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
straight or even Angle, a
corner whose lines are joyn&shy;
ed so, as no part falls
longer or shorter then o&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

right Corners or Angles; a

&amp; facio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a rectifying or ma&shy;
king right or straight:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rector(n)">Rector ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Governor,
a Ruler, a Guider. In the
Common Law, Rector Ecclesi&aelig;
Parochialis, is he that has the
charge or cure of a Parish
Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rectorial(a)">Rectorial,</form> <xpln lang="en">Rector-like, be&shy;
longing to a Rector.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rectus in curia(n)">Rectus in Curia,</form> <xpln lang="en">is he
that stands at the Bar of a 
Court of Justice, and no
man has any offence to object
against him; an upright per&shy;
son. Smith de Repub. Angl.
lib 2. cap.3. See An.6 Rich.2.
Stat. I. cap. II</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reduplication(n)">Reduplication (<etym lang="la">reduplica&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a redoubling. It is a fi&shy;
gure in Rhetorick, when the
same word that ends one part
of a verse or sentence, is re&shy;
peated in that which follows;
As 


</page>

<page sig="kk6r">
 <term lang="la">-- Faciet is maxima Gallo;
Gallo cujus Amor</term> . Virg. 

And <term lang="la">magna Reipub. spe sita
est in juventute; In juventute in&shy;
quam illa</term>. Cic.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reeve(n)">Reeve orReve <term lang="la">alias</term>Greve
<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">from the Sax</class> <etym lang="sx">Gerefa</etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Go&shy;
vernor, and that, by reject&shy;
ing the first syllable, which a&shy;
mong the Saxons is usual.
Lamberts Explicat. of Saxon 
words, <term lang="la">verbo Pr&aelig;fectus</term>. It
signifies with us, the Bailiff
of a Franchize or Mannor,
especially in the West parts.
Kitch. fol.43.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="refectory(n)">Refectory (<etym lang="la">refectorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

ny Dine and Sup together;

past; a repairing or mending
a thing that is worn and de&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="referendary(n)">Referendaries (<etym lang="la">referen&shy;

Dispositionum ; who made re&shy;
lation of Petitions or Re&shy;
quests, exhibited to the Em&shy;
perors, and his answer or
pleasure touching the same. 
The like Officers are under
the Pope; As also under the
Masters of Requests in France;
and are there otherwise called
Rapporteurs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reformado(n)">Reformado ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">re&shy;
formed. <term lang="sp">Un Capitan reforma&shy;
do</term>, a reformed Captain, one
that having lost part of his
men has the rest taken from
him and put under an other,
himself being either casheired
or continued in pay, either as
an inferior Souldier, or for
what he hath done former&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

wilful in opinion, froward, re&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regal(a)">Regal (<etym lang="la">regalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Royal

</page>

<page sig="kk6v">
pertaining to a King; also a
certain Musical Instrument,
so called. 

Also a Jewel or Ring of
great value, which a King of
France offered at St. Thomas
shrine at Canterbury, called
the Regal of France, which
Henry the Eight, upon the dis&shy;
solution, took thence, and
wore on his own finger or
thumb.</xpln></wordentry>

make as much account, and

Feast or entertain with rari&shy;
ties. Sir Tob Matth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regalia(n)">Regalia,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Rights of a
King, which the Civilians say
are six, viz. 1. Power of Ju&shy;
dicature; 2. Power of Life
and Death; 3. All kinde of
Arming; 4. Masterless goods;
5. Sessments; 6. And the va&shy;
lue of money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regiment(n)">Regiment (<etym lang="la">regimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Government, Rule; a Regi&shy;
ment of Soldiers, is the pro&shy;
per command of a Colonel:
If it be of Horse, it common&shy;
ly consists of five, six, seven,
or eight Troops: If of Foot,
it usually hath eight, nine,
ten, eleven, or twelve Com&shy;
panies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regrater(n)">Regrater (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Regrateur</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan></form> <xpln lang="en">a Huckster, or one that
trims up old Wares for sale)
in our Common Law did
anciently signifie such as
bought by the great, and sold
by retail. Anno 27 Edw.3. 


</page>

<page sig="kk7r">
Stat. I. cap.3. But now it
signifies, him that buyes and
sells any wares or victuals in
the same Market or Fair, or
within five miles thereof.
Anno 5 Edw.6. cap. 14. Anno
5 Eliz. cap.12. and 13 Eliz.
cap.25.</xpln></wordentry>

turn thanks. Feltham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rejoinder(n)">Rejoynder (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Rejoindre</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to rejoyn, or
joyn again)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our
Common Law, as much as
Duplication with the Civilians,
that is, an Exception to a
Replication : For first, the
Plaintiff exhibites his Bill,
the Defendant answers, then
the Plaintiff replies to that
Answer, which is called a
Replication, to which the
Defandant rejoyns, which is 
called a Rejoynder, especially
in Chancery . Westm. part2.
Symb. Tit. Chancery. Sect.
56.</xpln></wordentry>

signifies in our Common
Law, a power, hope or pos&shy;
sibility to enjoy Lands, Te&shy;
nements or Rents, after the
estate of another expired.
For example, a man may let
Land to one for term of
his life, and the Remainder
to another for term of his 
life. Littleton, chap. Atturn&shy;
ment, fol. 113.</xpln></wordentry>
