ter grounds with often dig&shy;
ging and laboring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repatriate(v)">Repatriate (<etym lang="la">repatrio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
return again to ones Native
Country.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repensation(n)">Repensation (<etym lang="la">repensatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a making recompence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repentine(a)">Repentine (<etym lang="la">repentinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sudden, unlooked for, una&shy;
wares.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repercussive(a)">Repercussive (<etym lang="la">repercussus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
stricken or striking again, 


</page>

<page sig="kk8v">
beaten or cast back, that
which rebounds, reflects, or
resounds; or that hath power
to drive back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repercutive(n)">Repercutive (from <etym lang="la">re&shy;
percutio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Medicine that re&shy;
pels or drives pain from the
place whereto it is applied.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repertible(a)">Repertible (from <etym lang="la">reperio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
which may be found, gotten,
or recovered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repertitious(a)">Repertitious (<etym lang="la">repertiti&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is found by ad&shy;
venture, and sometimes by
advise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repertory(n)">Repertory (<etym lang="la">repertorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an Inventory of ones goods,
a Register, List, Roll, or In&shy;
dex.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repignerate(v)">Repignerate (<etym lang="la">repignero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
redeem a pledge or gage; al&shy;
so to replevy a distress.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="replete(a)">Replete (<etym lang="la">repletus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full, fat,
replenished, filled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="replevy(n)">Replevy (<etym lang="la">Plevina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
bringing of the Writ cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">Replegiari facias</term>, by him
that has his Cattle or other
goods distrained by another
for any cause, and putting
in surety to the Sheriff, that
upon the delivery of the
thing distreined, he will pur&shy;
sue the Action against him
that distreined. Terms of
Law. 

It is also used for the bail&shy;
ing a man. Pl. Coron. fol.72,
73,74. and West. I. Ca. II. and
15. An.3. Ed. I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="replication(n)">Replication (<etym lang="la">replicatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
unfolding, a replying, a
confirmation of ones saying 
with new allegations. See <xref>Re&shy;
joynder</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reportator(n)">Reportator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
carries back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reposition(n)">Reposition (<etym lang="la">repositio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a put&shy;
ting or setting again in his
place; a restitution. 

Reposition of the Forrest, was
an act whereby certain For&shy;
rest grounds being made
Purlieu upon view, were by
a second view laid to the For&shy;
rest again. Manwood part. I.
pag.178.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repository(n)">Repository (<etym lang="la">repositorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Store-House or Ware-house
to keep things in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reprisal(n)">Reprisal (Fr.<etym lang="fr"> Reprisaille</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
taking, a resting, or seizing on,
for a distress or pledge; also a
Prize.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reprisal(n)">Reprisals</form> <xpln lang="en">are all one in
the Common and Civil Law;
 <term lang="la">Est potestas pignorandi contra
quemlibet de terra debitoris
data creditori pro injuriis &amp;
damnis acceptis</term> . This among
the ancient Romans was
called Clarigation (from <etym lang="la">cla&shy;
rigo</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">res clare repeto</term>.) It
is called in the last Stat. of
27 Edw.3. Stat.2. cap.17.
Law of Marque . And the
reason may be, because one
destitute of Justice in ano&shy;
ther Territory, redresses him&shy;
self by the Goods belong&shy;
ing to persons of that Ter&shy;
ritory, taken within his
own bounds.<xref> See Law of
Marque</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reprise(n)">Reprise ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a taking
back or again; But, in our
Law, Reprises signifie deducti&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="ll1r">
ons, payments and duties,
that are yearly paid out of a
Mannor; as Rent-charges,
Pensions, Anuities, Fees of
Stewards or Bailiffs, &amp;c.
Hence we say, the Mannor of
A. yeelds so much clear year&shy;
ly rent Ultra Reprisas, besides
all Reprises.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reprieve(n)">Reprive (from the Lat:
<etym lang="la">reprendere</etym>, to take back)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
properly to take back or re&shy;
mand a Prisoner, and re&shy;
spite the execution and pro&shy;
ceeding of the Law against
him for that time. It is also
used substantively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repititious(a)">Repititious (<etym lang="la">repititius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that creeps, or by privy
means gets to high estate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repudiable(a)">Repudiable (from <etym lang="la">repu&shy;
dio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">refuseable, rejectable,
forsakeable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repudiate(v)">Repudiate (<etym lang="la">repudio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
forsake as one doth his wife,
to refuse, abandon or put a&shy;
way. 

The ancient Romans had
three kinds of separation in
Marriage; The first they
called Repudiation, which was
done by the man against the
will of the woman; And
the first man that thus repu&shy;
diated his wife was Spurius
Carvilius in the year after
the building of Rome, 523.
because shee was barren,
&amp;c. 

The second manner was 
called Divorce, and this was
done with the consent of
both, and to either of them, it
was permitted to require it,
the party suing for it, used
these words, <term lang="la">Res tuas tibi
babeto, vel, Res tuas tibi agito</term> . 

The third manner was ter&shy;
med Direption, for which
there was allowed separation
in marriage, and this was
done according to the Prin&shy;
ces will. I part. Tr. of
Times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repudious(a)">Repudious (<etym lang="la">repudiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
villanous, dishonest, reproach&shy;
ful, that one refuseth and ab&shy;
hors much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repugnancy(n)">Repugnancy (<etym lang="la">repugnancie</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
contrariety, disagreement of
things one with another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repullulate(v)">Repullulate (<etym lang="la">repullulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
bud out, to cast forth his
buds, to burgen and spring a&shy;
gain. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repumicate(v)">Repumicate (<etym lang="la">repumico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
raze with a Pumice, to make
slick or smooth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="requiem(n)">Requiem (the Accusative
Case of <etym lang="la">requies</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> rest, ease,
quietness)</form> <xpln lang="en">is often used in
English, especially in Poe&shy;
try; As to sing a Requiem
for the dead; whereby is un&shy;
derstood a Mass for the dead,
which begins with these
words. <term lang="la">Requiem &aelig;ternam dona
eis, Domine, &amp; lux perpetua lu&shy;
ceat eis</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rescind(v)">Rescind (<etym lang="la">rescindo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to cut,
or break down, or in sun&shy;
der; to take away, to de&shy;
stroy; to repeal an act or
Law. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resiance(n)">Resiance (from <etym lang="la">resideo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies a mans aboad, or con&shy;
tinuance in a place. Old. nat.
br. fol.85. Whence also comes
the Participle [ Resiant ] that
is continually dwelling or a&shy;
biding in a place. Kitchin
fol.33. It is all one with Re&shy;
sidence, but that custom of
speech ties Residence onely to
persons Ecclesiastical.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="residentiary(n)">Residentiary (from <etym lang="la">resideo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resignation(n)">Resignation (<etym lang="la">resignatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

up. 

It is used particularly for
the giving up a Benefice or 
Spiritual Living into the
hands of the Ordinary.</xpln></wordentry>

use <term lang="fr">Resiliment</term> in the same

tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">repentance, a return&shy;

cond thinking, wiser then the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="respiration(n)">Respiration (<etym lang="la">respiratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="respite of homage(n)">Respite orRespight of
Homage (<etym lang="la">respectus Homagii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
was the forbearing of Ho&shy;
mage, which ought first of all
to be performed by the Te&shy;
nant, that held by Homage;
which Respite was occasioned
upon divers good reasons, but
most frequently by such as
held by Knights service in
Capite ; who because the
Prince could not be at lei&shy;
sure to take their Homage,
did pay into the Exche&shy;
quer at certain times of the
year, or most commonly
every fifth Term, some small
sum of money for respite till
the Prince might be at lea&shy;
sure to take it in person.
This is now abrogated, with
the Court of Wards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="response(n)">Response (<etym lang="la">responsum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an 


</page>

<page sig="ll2r">
Answer, an Oracle, a Pro&shy;
phecy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retailler(n)">Retailler ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to shred,
pare, slip, or cut often; for
so do Retaillers, or those
that sell by Retaile, in sel&shy;
ling their Wares or Com&shy;
modities in peeces or parcels;
contrary to those that sell
in gross, by the great, or by
whole-sale, as they call it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retainer(n)">Retainer (from <etym lang="la">retineo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is taken for a Servant, not
menial, nor domestick, that
is, not continually dwel&shy;
ling in the house of his Lord
or Master; but onely using,
and bearing his name or Live&shy;
ry, and attending on Festi&shy;
val days, or at such times only,
when he is thereunto requi&shy;
red.</xpln></wordentry>

ish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retrieve(v)">Retrive (from the Fr.

is particularly used in Hawk&shy;
ing, when the Partridges
have been once sprung, then
to spring or finde them again,
is called to Retrive; but may 
be properly used in other
senses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retro(px)">Retro, (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">the Latin</class> <class type="pos">Ad&shy;

on.</xpln></wordentry>

ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retrocopulation(n)">Retrocopulation (<etym lang="la">retroco&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retromingent(n)">Retromingents (from <etym lang="la">Re&shy;

Brown, for such Animals, as
Urine or Piss backward;
such are all Femal quadru&shy;
pedes . 

The same Author uses Re&shy;
tromingency, for a staling or
pissing backward.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="ll3r">
revealing, a discovering, open&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revels(n)">Revels (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
veiller</etym>, ib. to awake from
sleep)</form> <xpln lang="en">are with us, sports of
Dancing, Masking, Come&shy;
dies, and such like, used for&shy;
merly in the Kings House, the
Inns of Court, or in the
Houses of other great person&shy;
ages; And are so called, be&shy;
cause they are most used by
night, when otherwise men
commonly sleep: There is also
an Officer, called, The Master of
the Revels, who has the or&shy;
dering and command of these
pastimes.</xpln></wordentry>

reflect</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rhenish wine(n)">Rhenish Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called
from the River Rheine in Ger&shy;
many, upon whose banks grow
those Grapes which make the
Rhenish Wine.<xref> See Baccha&shy;
rach</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhetoric(n)">Rhetorick (<etym lang="la">rhetorice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Art and Science of Elo&shy;
quence, or of speaking well
and wisely; first invented by
Empedocles. 

It is the force or faculty of
perceiving or finding out that,
in any matter, which is most
perswasive. Isocrates saith, the
Office of a Rhetorician is, <term lang="la">Ex
parvis magna, ex magnis parva
efficere</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhetorical(a)">Rhetorical (<etym lang="la">rhetoricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
skilful in Rhetorick, that
speaks eloquently.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhomb(n)">Rhomb (<etym lang="la">rhombus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Spin&shy;
ning wheele, Reel or Whirle;
also a figure that has equal
sides, and unequal Angles;
As a quarry of glass, &amp;c.
Rhombi are also the points
of the Marriners Compass.
<xref>See Rumbe</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhonchisonant(a)">Rhonchisonant (<etym lang="la">rhonchi&shy;

or sound of snorters, and per&shy;
tains to mocking.</xpln></wordentry>

ber, harmony or proporti&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ribadavia(pn)">Ribadavia,</form> <xpln lang="en">a gentle kind

Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Richard(pn)">Richard ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">power&shy;

and was but Herric rever&shy;

and Ceremonies of the Roman

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rival(n)">Rivals (<etym lang="la">rivales</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">they that

terest or fetch water from, the
same River or Brook. But
it is most commonly used Me&shy;
taphorically for those that
love and woo the same wo&shy;
man; Corrivals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Robert(pn)">Robert ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">famous

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Robigus(pn)">Robigus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God among

Feasts called Robigalia were
sacred.</xpln></wordentry>

from whence Malefactors
were thrown headlong. Fe&eacute;&shy;
stus.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rodage(n)">Rodage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
Toll exacted by some Coun&shy;
trey Lords in France, upon
every Wain that passes 
(though in the High-way)
near to their Seigniories,
whether it be laden or no:
for if it be, they will be paid
both for the Load, and for
the Cart. Cot.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rode(n)">Rode (from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Ree</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Reed</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">statio navi&shy;
um</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Station, Bay, or Harbor
for Ships. 

It may come (as the Fr.
<f type="f"/><term lang="fr">Rade</term>) from <etym lang="la">Radenda terra</etym>, in
which sence, is that of Virg. 7.
&AElig;neid. 

 <term lang="la">Proxima Circe&aelig; raduntur littora terr&aelig;</term> . 

</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rodomont(n)">Rodomond ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a brag&shy;

ous fellow, one that uses Ro&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rodomontade(n)">Rodomontade (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class> <etym lang="it">Ro&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rogalian(a)" lexeme="rogal(a)">Rogalian 
Rogal 
 (<etym lang="la">rogalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to a great
fire; Ignis rogalis, a Bon&shy;
fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rogation(n)">Rogation (<etym lang="la">rogatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Que&shy;
stion or Demand; a Desire or
Request, a Praying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rogation week(pn)">Rogation week,</form> <xpln lang="en">is always
the next but one before
Whitsonday ; and is so called,
because of the especial devo&shy;
tion of Prayer and Fasting,
then enjoyned by the Church
to all persons, not onely for
a preparative to the joyful
remembrance of Christs glo&shy; 
rious Ascension, and the De&shy;
scension of the Holy Ghost in
form of Cloven Tongues
shortly after; but also to re&shy;
quest and supplicate the bless&shy;
ing of God upon the Fruits
of the Earth. And in this re&shy;
spect the solemnization of
Carnal Matrimony is forbid&shy;
den from the first day of the
said week, till Trinity Sunday .
The Belgians call itCruys&shy;
week, <expan type="">id est</expan> Cross-week, and
so is it called in some parts of
England, because of old (as
still among Roman Catho&shy; 
licks) when the Priests went
on Procession this week in
the Fields, the Cross was car&shy;
ried before them. The first
institution of this weeks so&shy;
lemnities, is by Historians re&shy;
ferred to Claudius Mamertus,
Bishop of Vienne in France.
Dr. Ham. 


</page>

<page sig="ll5r">
In the North of England it
is called Gang week, from the
Ganging, or going on processi&shy;
on, &amp;c. For toGang in the
North, is to go. 

In the Inns of Court it is
called Grass-week, because the
Commons of that week con&shy;
sist much of Sallads and hard
Eggs upon some of the days. 

The Feasts of the old Ro&shy;
mans called Robigalia and Am&shy;
barvalia (<term lang="la">quod victima arva am&shy;
biret</term>) did in their Heathenish
way somewhat resemble these
institutions, and were kept
in May in honor of Robi&shy;
gus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rogatists(pn)">Rogatists.</form> <xpln lang="en"> See <xref>Circumce&shy;
lians</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rogitate(v)">Rogitate (<etym lang="la">rogito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to bid,
to intreat, to require often, to
beg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roger(pn)">Roger (Germ. <etym lang="gr">Ruger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
quiet, the same with <term lang="la">tranquil&shy;
lus</term> in Latin. Frodoard writes
it always Rotgarius or Rod&shy;
garus, so it seems to signifie,
all Council, or strong Coun&shy;
cil. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rolls(n)">Rolls,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among
Book-binders; as Books in
Rolls are those which are
bound with a Roll of Gold on
the edges of the Cover; and
in Fillets, when they have
Lines or Fillets of Gold on
the out-side of the Cover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="romanize(v)">Romanize (<etym lang="la">romanizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
imitate the speech or fashion
of Rome, or the Romans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="romance(n)">Romance ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a feign&shy;
ed History, either in Verse or
Prose in the Vulgar Lan&shy; 
guage; the first news we
heard of this word, was from
a Poem writ in French by
John Clopinel alias Meung, in&shy; 
tituled Le Romant de la  Rose,
and afterward translated into
English by Geffrey Chaucer;
but we now give the name
Romance most commonly to
a feigned History writ in
Prose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="romancist(n)">Romancist (from the Spa.
<etym lang="sp">Romancista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that com&shy;
poses such Romances.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="romant(n)">Romant,</form> <xpln lang="en">the most elo&shy;
quent French, or any thing
written eloquently, was in
old time termed Roman, of
the Roman, or most eloquent
Language. Hence Le Roman
de la Rose, the Romant of the
Rose : (In the confines of
Germany and Loraign, the Lan&shy;
guage that is not German is at
this day called Romant) Cot.
Chaucer useth it for a brief
History.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rondache(n)">Rondach ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a round
Target or great Buckler. Lu&shy;
stra Lud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rondacher(n)">Rondacher ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Tar&shy;
gettier, or one that serves with
a Rondache.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rondelier(n)">Rondelier ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a maker
of Bucklers, or of round
Targets; also a Souldier
that serves with one of
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rood(n)">Rood (<etym lang="la">roda terr&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
fourth part of an Acre of
Land. Anno 5 Eliz. cap.5.<xref> See
Pearch</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rood(n)">Rood ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Saxon</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cross.
Hence the Invention of the 


</page>

<page sig="ll5v">
Holy Cross by St. Helen, is cal&shy;
led Holy Rood day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rood-loft(n)">Roodloft ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Shrine
whereon in old time, and
yet some place the Cross of
Christ, and the Images and
Reliques of Saints.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roral(a)">Roral (<etym lang="la">roralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to dew, dewy, that
may be sprinkled like dew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rorid(a)">Rorid (<etym lang="la">roridus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dewy,
moist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roriferous(a)">Roriferous (<etym lang="la">rorifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
makes or brings dew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rorulent(a)">Rorulent (<etym lang="la">rorulentus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">co&shy;
vered with, or full of dew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rose(n)">Rose:</form> <xpln lang="en">when we desire to
confine our words, we com&shy;
monly say, they are spoken
under the Rose, and the Ger&shy;
man custom describes a Rose
in the seeling over the Table;
the original whereof Lemnius
and others have thus recor&shy;
ded; The Rose was the flow&shy;
er of Venus, which Cupid con&shy; 
secrated to Harpocrates, the
god of Silence, and was there&shy;
fore an Emblem thereof, to
conceal the pranks of Vene&shy;
ry, as is declared in this Te&shy;
trastick. 

 <term lang="la">Est Rosa flos Veneris, cujus quo facta laterent,
Harpocrati Matris, dona dicavit Amor;
Inde Rosam Mensis hospes suspendit Amicis,
Conviv&aelig; ut sub ea dicta tacenda sciant</term> .
 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rosary(n)">Rosary (<etym lang="la">rosarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gar&shy;
den or bed of Roses, a place
where Roses grow, an ordi&shy;
nary Limbeck for distilling
Rose-water; Also a pair of
Beads, called Fifteens, con&shy;
taining Fifteen Pater Nosters,
and 150 Aves ; Also an an&shy;
cient Coyn so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roscid(a)">Roscid (<etym lang="la">roscidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wet or
moistened with dew, dewy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rosion(n)">Rosion (<etym lang="la">roscio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a gnaw&shy;
ing, a griping, a biting, a nib&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rot(n)">Rot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term of war, six
men (be they Pikes or Mus&shy;
keteers) make a Rot or file.
See <xref>Brigade</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rotal(a)">Rotal (<etym lang="la">rotalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to a wheel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rote(n)">ByRote (<etym lang="la">rotatim</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">row&shy;
lingly, roundly; when one 
has a lesson by heart, and says
it as roundly and perfectly
as a wheel runs in his rote or
track.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rotundity(n)">Rotundity (<etym lang="la">rotunditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
roundness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rouge Cross(pn)" lexeme="Rouge Dragon(pn)">Rouge Cross andRouge
Dragon,</form> <xpln lang="en">the names of two
Offices of Pursuivants at
Arms.<xref> See Harold</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roundel(n)">Roundel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Ball
or such like round substance
in Blazon, of which Heralds,
reckon nine sorts. See Guil&shy;
lim. p.356.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roundelay(n)">Roundelay,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Shepheards
dance; Sometimes used for a
Song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roundlet(n)">Roundlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain mea&shy;
sure of Wine, Oyle, &amp;c. con&shy;
taining eighteen Gallons and
an half.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="round(n)">Rounds,</form> <xpln lang="en">Statues and their
fragments are so called by
Painters.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rowland(pn)" lexeme="Rolland(pn)">Rowland orRolland
 <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class></form> <xpln lang="en">whereas it was an&shy;
ciently writtenRodland, it
may seem to signifie Councel
for the Land; And the first
I find so named was Land&shy;
warden in France, under Ca&shy;
rolus Magnus against the Pi&shy;
racies of the Normans. The
Italians use Orland for Row&shy;
land by Methathesis . Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="royalist(n)">Royalist ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
takes the Kings part, or sides
with the King.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubefy(v)">Rubefy (<etym lang="la">rubefacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rubicon(pn)">Rubicon,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name of a
River in Italy over which Ju&shy;
lius C&aelig;sar passed in the begin&shy;
ning of his Expedition against
Pompey; whence, to pass the
Rubicon, is to undertake and
enter into a great and dange&shy;
rous exploit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubicundous(a)">Rubicundous (<etym lang="la">rubicundus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
very red or ruddy, blood
red.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubid(a)">Rubid (<etym lang="la">rubidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">reddish,
somewhat red or ruddy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubiginous(a)">Rubiginous (<etym lang="la">rubiginosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
foule, musty, blasted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubor(n)">Rubor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">shamefac'd&shy;
ness, rednes, blushing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubric(n)">Rubrick (<etym lang="la">rubrica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a special
title or sentence of the Law,
or of any book written or
printed in red; The Calen&shy;
der of Saints and Festivals
is commonly so called, be&shy;
cause the chief of them are 
printed in red letters; In
the Cannon Law the Ar&shy;
guments of every Chapter,
were written with red Let&shy;
ters, which was called the
Rubrick, and the Text with
black.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubricate(v)">Rubricate (<etym lang="la">rubrico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make, or colour red with
Oaker.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rubrificative(a)">Rubrificative,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Plaister
of so strong, or strongly draw&shy;
ing Simples, that it ulcerates
or at least makes red the place
it is applied unto. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ructation(n)">Ructation (<etym lang="la">ructatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
belching or breaking wind
upward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rudiment(n)">Rudiment (<etym lang="la">rudimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the first teaching or instructi&shy;
on; a beginning, a principle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rugosous(a)">Rugosous (<etym lang="la">rugosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full of
wrinkles, crumples, or plaits,
rough, riveled, withered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhumb(n)">Rumbe (<etym lang="la">rhombus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
in Geometry, and signifies a
whole line in the Compass
consisting of two winds,
as the Line of North and
South, or that of East and
West. The Spaniards first
gave that name, as Peter of
Medina takes it upon them,
yet not out of their own Lan&shy;
guage, but fancying to them&shy;
selves that the Lines of the
Compass (as indeed they do)
much resembled the spars of a
Spinning Wheel, which in
Lat. is called <term lang="la">Rhombus</term>, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from
the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x1fe5;&epsilon;&mu;&beta;&omega;</etym>, to turn about,
they call those Lines Rumbos,
and the word hath taken.
Greg. 284.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ll6v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rumia(pn)">Rumia,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Goddess that
ruled over sucking Children,
and Womans Paps.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rummage(v)">Rumidge,</form> <xpln lang="en">to remove any
Goods or Luggage out of a
place. Seamen use it for re&shy;
moving and clearing things in
the Ships Hould, that Goods
and Victuals may be wel-stow&shy;
ed and placed. Seamens Dict.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rumiferate(v)" lexeme="rumigerate(v)">Rumiferate (<etym lang="la">rumifero</etym>)

</form> <xpln lang="en">
to disperse a rumor, to carry

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ruttier(n)">Ruttier (Fr.<etym lang="fr"> Routier</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Directory for the knowledge
or finding out of courses,
whether by Sea or Land; al&shy;
so an old Traveller, one that
by much trotting up and
down, is grown acquainted
with most ways; and hence
an old beaten Soldier, or an
old crafty Fox, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="s"><alpha>S.</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sabbath(pn)"><f type="l"/>SAbaoth,Sabbath,Sab&shy;
baoth, orSabboth (<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class> 
<etym lang="la">Sabbathum</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="he">from the Hebr.</class> 
<etym lang="he">&#x05e9;&#x05d1;&#x05ea; Scabath</etym>, (<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">quievit</term>) a
day of rest, or a time set a&shy;
part for holy rest,</form> <xpln lang="en">which is
Friday among the Turks, Sa&shy;
turday among the Jews, and
Sunday, or our Lords-day a&shy;
mong us Christians; which,
in stead of the Saturday or
Jewish Sabbath, was instituted
by the Apostles to be kept Fe&shy;
stival, in honor and memory
of Christs Resurrection on
that day; and so hath been
kept by the Church ever
since.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saboath(pn)">Sabaoth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in all the
Tongues, is also an Attribute 


</page>

<page sig="ll7r">
the Hebrews gave to God,
Lord of Hosts, of Armies and
Powers, and comes of the
Hebr. <etym lang="he">Tsabaoth</etym>, signifying Ar&shy;
mies or Powers, and that
comes of Tsaba, he hath fought
with Armies or Powers.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sabbatical(a)">Sabbatical (<etym lang="la">Sabbaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to the Sabbath or
Seventh day, that keeps the
Sabaoth . A Sabaoth days
journey, is taken for two
miles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sabbatical year(n)">Sabbatical year,</form> <xpln lang="en">was the
Seventh year, in which the
Jews rested from Tillage. Le&shy;
vit.25.2.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sabbatism(n)">Sabbatism (<etym lang="la">Sabbathismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the celebration of the Sa&shy;
baoth, Holy Rest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sabbatarians(pn)">Sabbatarians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of
Hereticks, who celebrate the
Jewish sabaoth, and not our
Lords day.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sabellians(pn)">Sabellians</form> <xpln lang="en">(a Sect of He&shy;
reticks<emend err="">)</emend> from Sabelli&shy;
us their first Founder, who
held, the Father, Son, and
Holy Ghost, were onely one
Substance, and one Person,
having three Names, &amp;c. <xref lexeme="anti-Trinitarians">See
Antitrinitarians</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sable(n)">Sable ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">black colour
in Blazon. It is also a rich
Fur of a Beast, so called, like
and neer as big as a Polecat,
of colour between black and
brown, and breeds in Russia,
but most in Tartaria.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sacerdotal(a)">Sacerdotal (<etym lang="la">sacerdotalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to Priests or
Church-men, Priestly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saccus cum brochia(n)">Saccus cum brochia,</form> <xpln lang="en">seems 
to be a service of finding a
Sack, and a Broach to the
King, by vertue of a Tenure,
for the use of his Army.
Bract. lib.2. cap.16. numb.
6.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sack of wool(n)">Sack of Wool (<etym lang="la">saccus
Lan&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a quantity of Wool,
containing six and twenty
stone, and fourteen pound.
Anno14 Ed.3. Stat. I. cap.21.
See <xref>Sarplar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sacramental(a)">Sacramental (<etym lang="la">Sacramen&shy;
talis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to a Sacra&shy;
ment or Oath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sacramentaries(pn)">Sacramentaries (<etym lang="la">Sacra&shy;

nots, or Calvinists, in the
Doctrine of the Sacrament.
Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sacrificial(a)">Sacrificial (<etym lang="la">sacrificialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to a Sa&shy;
crifice, Offering or Oblati&shy;
on</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sacrilege(n)">Sacrilege (<etym lang="la">sacrilegium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
robbing of a Church, or other
holy consecrated place, the
stealing holy things, or abu&shy;
sing Sacraments or holy My&shy;

that robs the Church; wick&shy;
ed, extreamly bad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sacristy(n)">Sacristy (<etym lang="la">sacristia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ve&shy;
stry in a Church.<xref> See Sacrary</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="ll7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sacristian(n)">Sacristian (<etym lang="la">Sacrista</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Sexten or Vestry-keeper in a
Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sadduces(pn)">Sadduces,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect among
the Jewes, who beleeved not
the being of Angels or Spi&shy;
rits, the Resurrection of the
body, nor that there was a
Holy Ghost; they received
onely the Pentateuch, and in
many other things agreed
with the Samaritans, &amp;c. The
derivation of their name is va&shy;
riously delivered by Authors;
some say, they take it from
Sadoc, who is said to have
lived about the time of A&shy;
lexander the Great, and to be
the Author of this Sect; O&shy;
thers, from Tsedech or Zaddi&shy;
chim, both which signifie Ju&shy;
stice; others deduce the name
from Sedah a Chaldean word,
signifying to part or di&shy;
vide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="safe conduct(n)">Safe Conduct (<etym lang="la">salvus
Conductus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Security or
Protection given by the
Prince under the Broad Seal,
or by any other person in au&shy;
thority, most commonly for
a strangers quiet coming in,
and passing out of the Realm.
Touching which you may see
the Statues, An.15. H.6. ca.3.
and An.18. ejus. cap.18. and
An.28. H.8. ca. I. The form of
this, see in the Regist. Original
fol.25.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sagacious(a)">Sagacious (<etym lang="la">sagax, acis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
witty, that perceives and
fore-sees quickly, wise, skil&shy;
ful, quick of scent, taste or
sight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sagacity(n)">Sagacity (<etym lang="la">sagacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sharp&shy;
ness of wit, quickness, or
liveliness of spirit or under&shy;
standing, wittiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saginate(v)">Saginate (<etym lang="la">sagino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
frank, to make fat, to cram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sagittal(n)">Sagittal (<etym lang="la">sagittalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
suture or seam that runs
straight on the top of the
head, distinguishing the right
from the left side of the head;
Also belonging to an Ar&shy;
row.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sagittarius(pn)">Sagittarius,</form> <xpln lang="en">or the Ar&shy;
cher; one of the twelve signs
of the Zodiack, in form of a
Centaure or Archer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sagittiferous(a)">Sagittiferous (<etym lang="la">sagittifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears or weares Ar&shy;
rowes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sagittipotent(a)">Sagittipotent (<etym lang="la">sagittipo&shy;
tens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that can do much by
shooting with Arrows, a cun&shy;
ning Archer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saguntine(a)">Saguntine (<etym lang="la">Saguntinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to the City
Saguntus, scituate beyond I&shy;
berus in Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saint Anthony's fire(n)">Saint Anthonies fire (<etym lang="la">E&shy;
rysipelas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease rising of
hot cholerick blood, which
beginning first with a blister
growes after to a soar or scab
like a Tetter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saker(n)">Saker (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Sacre</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Hawk
so called; Also a peece of
Ordnance of that name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Salacia(pn)">Salacia,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Goddess of
water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salacious(a)">Salacious (<etym lang="la">salax, acis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that 
is very much enclined and
bent to lechery, hot in lust;
lecherous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salacity(n)">Salacity  (<etym lang="la">salacitas </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lechery, 


</page>

<page sig="ll8r">
or rather an instinction,
tickling or provocation to
lechery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salade(n)">Salade ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Helmet or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salamander(n)">Salamander (<etym lang="la">salamandra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a quadruped beast, in shape
like a Lizard, full of spots,
it will for a time resist a flame
until its moisture be consum&shy;
ed, but not live in, or quench
the fire, as some authors have
affirmed. See Dr. Brown in
his Vulgar Errors, fol.138.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salarian(a)">Salarian (<etym lang="la">salarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to salt. 

Salarian Verse, a kind of
Song, which Mars his Priests,
among the old Romans, were
wont to sing. Tac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salary(n)">Salary (<etym lang="la">salarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a re&shy;
compence or consideration
made to any man for his pains
or industry bestowed on ano&shy;
ther mans business; wages
given to servants, a sti&shy;
pend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salebrity(n)">Salebrity (<etym lang="la">salebritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
ruggedness, or unevenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salebrous(a)">Salebrous (<etym lang="la">salebrosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
uneven, unplain, rough; also
harsh, unpleasant, hard to un&shy;
derstand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salet(n)">Salet,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Head-peece,
An.4, and 5, Phil. &amp; Mar. it
seems to come from the Fr.
 <etym lang="fr">Salut</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> health; because it
keeps the head whole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saliant(a)">Saliant (<etym lang="la">saliens</etym>, a term
in Heraldry)</form> <xpln lang="en">is when the Li&shy;
on is leaping and sporting
himself, and differs little from
Rampant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saligot(n)">Saligot ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a water 
Caltrop, or water Nut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salinous(a)">Salinous (from <etym lang="la">salina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to salt or a
Salt-pit. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Salic law(n)">Salique Law (<etym lang="la">Lex Salica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a Law whereby the Crown
of France cannot be inheri&shy;
ted by a woman, cannot fall
from the Lance to the Distaff,
as their saying is; Which
Law one (undertaking to
prove out of Holy Writ) ur&shy;
ged that place of Mathew,
where it is said; Mark the
Lillies (which are the Arms
of France) and see how they nei&shy;
ther labour nor spin . This Law
they pretend was made by
Pharamond their first King,
and that the words, Si aliqua,
so often mentioned, gave it
the name of Salique Law;
Others say it took denomi&shy;
nation from the name of the
place Salethani, where it was
made, or from the name of
Salgast, who was Chancellor
to Pharamond, and one of the
chief in making this Law.
Hailan saith, it was never
heard of in France till the
dayes of Phillip the fair, 1321.
Others say it was framed by
Charls the Great, after his
Conquests in Germany, where
the incontinency of the wo&shy;
men, living about the River
Sala (in the Country now
called Misnia) gave both the
occasion and name to this
Law; the words are these,
 <term lang="la">De terra vero Salica nulla portio
h&aelig;reditatis mulieri veniat,
sed ad virilem sexum tota ter&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="ll8v">
r&aelig; h&aelig;reditas perveniat</term>. Sel&shy;
den.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salivarious(a)">Salivarious (<etym lang="la">salivari&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">clammy and thick like
spettle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salivation(n)">Salivation (<etym lang="la">salivatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
continual having of much
spettle in the mouth, or a
drawing of humors to the
mouth, and a delivery of them
from thence in manner of
spettle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sally(v)">Sally (from the Span.
<etym lang="sp">Salir</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to go or issue out,
most commonly applied to
those that are besieged in a
Town or Castle, when they
sally or issue out upon the be&shy;
siegers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Salmacian spoils(n)" lexeme="Salmacidan spoils(n)">Salmacian 
Salmacidan Spoiles 
(<etym lang="la">Salmacida Spolia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Spoils or
Conquests got without blood
or labour; from Salmacis a
fountain of Caria, which is
said to enfeeble all such as
either drank of it, or bathed
in it, Hence that of Tully in
his book de Officiis, <term lang="la">Salmacida
spolia sine sanguine &amp; sudore</term>,
and there used for effeminate
or venerial Conquests. 

This Salmacida Spolia was
the Motto of the Scene or
Frontispiece of a Mask at
Whitehal at Christmas 1636,
or 1637.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Salomon(pn)">Salomon (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">peace&shy;
able</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salus(n)">Salus (Fr. <etym lang="fr">salut</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was
a coyn of Gold stamped by
King Henry the Sixth in
France, and worth some five
shillings sterling, which one&shy;
ly coyn, with another of
Blancks of eight pence a
peece was current in those
places of France where King
Henry was obeyed. Stowes
Annals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Samaritans(pn)">Samaritans,</form> <xpln lang="en">people of Sa&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="mm1r">
maria, a Country and City
of Syria; The Jews at this
day are divided into three
Sects, the first and greatest,
are called the Talmudists in
that (besides the holy Scrip&shy;
tures) they imbrace the Tal&shy;
mud, which is stuffed with
the Traditions of their Rabins 
and Cacams ; the second re&shy;
ceive the Scripture alone;
the third the Pentateuch one&shy;
ly, which are called Samari&shy;
tans. Mr. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanbenito(n)">Sambenito ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">or
San-benito, properly Santo Be&shy;
nito, St. Benet, but it is usu&shy;
ally taken for a coat of course
Sackcloth, in which Penitents
in Spain are reconciled to the
Church. And in that respect
may be called Sanbenito, <term lang="la">quasi</term>
<term lang="la">Saco benedicto</term>, a blessed Sack&shy;
cloth. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sambuca(n)">Sambuke (<etym lang="la">sambuca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
instrument of Musick, which
we commonly take for a Dul&shy;
cimer ; Also an Engin of war,
set by a rowling Tower, which
by Ropes and Pullies clapt the
Bridge suddenly from the
Tower to the besieged walls.
Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Samian(a)">Samian (<etym lang="la">samius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
pertaining to the Isle Samos,
or to an earthen pot or a
Whetstone; because there
were good ones in that Isle.
Dub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sampler(n)">Samplar (a corruption
from <etym lang="la">Examplar</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pattern or
copy to imitate, an extract
or draught; It is most used
by young Maids, for a patterne 
of several sorts of needle&shy;
work wrought in a peece of
Canvas.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sampson(pn)">Sampson (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">there
the second time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sance bell(n)" lexeme="sancting bell(n)">ASance or<emend err="Sacting">Sancting</emend>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanctiloquent(a)">Sanctiloquent (<etym lang="la">sanctilo&shy;
quus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that speaks holily.</xpln></wordentry>

ousness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanction(n)">Sanction (<etym lang="la">sanctio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Law,
a Decree established; Also a
penal Statute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanctuary(n)">Sanctuary (<etym lang="la">sanctuarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a holy or sanctified place, as
Temple, Church or Chappel.
In the old Law it was the
most holy place of the Taber&shy;
nacle wherein God gave visi&shy;
ble tokens of his presence
Psal.20.2. And more parti&shy;
cularly it is a place privileged
by the Prince, for the safe&shy;
guard of mens lives, that are
offenders, being founded on
the Law of mercy, and upon
the great reverence, honor &amp;
devotion, which the Prince 


</page>

<page sig="mm1v">
bears to the place, where
unto he grants such a Privi&shy;
ledge. Of this you may read
Stawnf. pl. Cor. lib.2. ca.38.
This seems to have taken be&shy;
ginning from the Cities of
Refuge which Moses appoin&shy;
ted them to flye unto for
safeguard of their lives, that
had by casualty slain a man,
Exod. ca.21. In bastardly
imitation whereof, first the
Athenians, then Romulus e&shy;
rected such a place of im&shy;
munity, which they, and
he after them called Asylum .
Pol. Virg. de inventione re&shy;
rum, lib.3. cap.12. The Em&shy;
perors of Rome made the pla&shy;
ces of their own Statues or
Images, a place of Refuge,
as appears, Cod. lib. I. titulo,15.
 <term lang="la">De iis qui ad Statuas confu&shy;
giunt</term> . As also the Churches:
Eodem, titulo 12. <term lang="la">De iis
qui ad Ecclesias confugiunt
&amp;c.</term> . 

But among all other Nati&shy;
ons, the ancient Kings of
England seem to have attri&shy;
buted most to those Sanctu&shy;
aries, permitting them to
shelter such, as had com&shy;
mitted both Felonies and
Treasons, so that within
Forty dayes they acknow&shy;
ledged their fault, and sub&shy;
mitted themselves to banish&shy;
ment; During which time,
if any man expelled them,
if he were Lay, he was Ex&shy;
communicated, if a Clark, he
was made irregular; But af&shy;
ter Forty days no man might 
releeve them. See the New
Book of Entries verbo, Sanctu&shy;
ary, and Fleta lib. I. cap 29.
And how by degrees they
have been taken away, you
may read partly in him, and
partly in the Statutes. An.
26. Hen.8. ca.13. and 28 ejus&shy;
dem cap7. Anno 32. ejusdem,
cap.12. &amp; 33. ejusdem cap 15.
An. I. Ed.6 ca12 &amp; 2. eius&shy;
dem, cap.2 &amp; 33. &amp; An 5. ejus&shy;
dem cap.10.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanctum sanctorum(n)">Sanctum Sanctorum</form> <xpln lang="en">( <expan type="">id est</expan>
the Holy of Holyes) was
the holiest place of the
Jewes Temple, where the
Ark was kept, and wherein&shy;
to none entred, but the High
Priest, and he but once a
year.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sandal(n)">Sandal (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class> <etym lang="he"> Sandal</etym>,
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sandalium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a slipper or
Pantofle; Also a kind of old
fashioned shoo, open and fast&shy;
ned with Latchets on the In&shy;
step, such as religious persons
wear. Also</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sandal(n)" lexeme="sanders(n)">Sandal orSaunders
 (<etym lang="la">santalum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a precious wood
brought out of India, where&shy;
of there are three kinds, to
wit, red, yellow, and white
Saunders. They are all of a
cooling nature, especially the
red, which is often used in
Physick against hot dis&shy;
eases.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sandarac(n)">Sandarack (<etym lang="la">Sandaracha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the best red Arsenick or Or&shy;
pine; a bright Painters red,
whereof there are two kinds;
one (the right &amp; better) found
in Mines of Gold and Silver; 


</page>

<page sig="mm2r">
the other made of burned
Ceruse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanglant(a)">Sanglant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bloody,
bleeding, embrued or full of
blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanglier(n)">Sanglier ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wilde
bore, five years old.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanguinary(a)">Sanguinary (<etym lang="la">sanguinarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
cruel, thirsty, bloody, desi&shy;
rous of, or delighted in shed&shy;
ding blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanguine(a)" lexeme="sanguineous(a)">Sanguin 
Sanguineous (<etym lang="la">sanguine&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bloody,
full of blood, cruel, red. San&shy;
guin colour, is a blood red co&shy;
lour, or my Ladies Blush.
Sanguin in Heraldry signifies a
Murrey colour; but is com&shy;
monly taken for a complexi&shy;
on, most inclinable to blood. 

 Sanguin flesh (<etym lang="la">caro sanguinea</etym>)
is that which is engendred
of blood; of which sort is
the flesh compounded in the
Muscles, the Heart, and the
rest of Sanguin Substance;
the Anatomists call it the
proper flesh; as also Exanguis 
the improper flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanguinolent(a)">Sanguinolent (<etym lang="la">sanguinolen&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bloody, full of blood,
merciless.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanhedrim(n)" lexeme="sanhedrin(n)" lexeme="synedrion(n)" lexeme="synedrium(n)">Sanhedrim orSanhe&shy;
drin, (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr</class>)Synedrion or
Synedrium ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
generally the place where
Counsellors meet to consult
of, and determine matters;
also the Assembly it self: But,
by an appropriation of the
word, it is commonly taken
onely for the highest Court of
Judicature, or supreme Coun&shy;
cil of the Jews, which con&shy; 
sisted of one High Priest and se&shy;
venty Seniors or Elders; from
which number, it was called
by them in Hebrew words,
signifying <term lang="la">Domus judicit sep&shy;
tuaginta unius</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Court of
seventy and one Judges; and
it was (as it were) their Par&shy;
liament, to consult about, to
judge and decide the greatest
matters that could arise in
their Ecclesiastical or Civil
Commonwealth; as, to de&shy;
termine the Controversies
that might happen concern&shy;
ing their High Priest, true
and false Prophets, differen&shy;
ces betwixt Nation and Na&shy;
tion, Tribe and Tribe, &amp;c.
This High Court was first in&shy;
stituted (God commanding
it) in the Wilderness by
Moses, whilst under his con&shy;
duct, the Children of Israel
were on their journey out of
Egypt, towards the Land of
Promise; and afterwards it
continued still in vigor among
them, till our Saviours Passi&shy;
on. 

Besides this great Sanhedrim
or Synedrion, the Jews had
two lesser or inferior to it;
the one consisting of three
Judges; to the Examination
and Decision of which Court,
the most petty Actions were
subject, As private quarrels,
thefts, and the like; this they
called by words of their
Language, signifying, <term lang="la">Domus
judicit trium virum</term>, The Court
of three Judges. The other
consisted of twenty and three, 


</page>

<page sig="mm2v">
and so was termed by words,
signifying <term lang="la">Domus judicii viginti
trium</term>, to whose Court be&shy;
longed the Decision of weigh&shy;
tier Sutes and capital Causes. 

these Courts were erected
in several places, according
to the exigence and commodi&shy;
ty of their Country, whereas
their other supreme Court,
after their possession of the
Land of Promise, and the set&shy;
tlement of their Common&shy;
wealth, was onely held in
Jerusalem, Jews might appeal
from those inferior Courts, to
this; but from this there lay
no appeal. Four kindes of
death were in their power,
Stoning, Burning, Sword,
Strangling; and they fasted
all that day when they con&shy;
demned any to death. 

The Thalmudists use the
word Sinbedriin for the afore&shy;
said great Council. 

Synedrians (<etym lang="la">synedri</etym>) are the
Counsellors, Judges or Mem&shy;
bers of that Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanity(n)">Sanity (<etym lang="la">sanitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">health,
soundness, good estate of wit
and memory, right wits.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saniak(n)">Saniacks orSansiakes,</form> <xpln lang="en">
are Governors of Cities a&shy;
mong the Turks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="santo(n)" lexeme="santon(n)">Santo,Santon, orSan&shy;
cton ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a holy man, a
great Saint. Dodona.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saphire(n)">Saphire (<etym lang="la">sapphirus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pre&shy;
tious stone so called, brought
out of East India, of a clear
skie colour, the best have, as
it were Clouds in them, in&shy;
clining to a certain redness:
This stone is said to be of a
cold nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sapid(a)">Sapid (<etym lang="la">sapidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">well sea&shy;
soned, savory, that hath a
smack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sapidity(n)">Sapidity (<etym lang="la">sapiditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">plea&shy;
santness of taste or savor;
also pleasantness of talk.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sapientipotent(a)">Sapientipotent (<etym lang="la">sapienti&shy;
potens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mighty in wisdom, or
that by his wisdom and pru&shy;
dence, is able to do much,
and to bring great things to
pass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sapor(n)">Sapor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> see Sapi&shy;
dity</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sapphic verse(n)">Sapphique Verse</form> <xpln lang="en">(so cal&shy;
led from Sappho, a famous
Poetess, who is held to be the
first inventer of them) con&shy;
sists of eleven syllables, and
hath a Trochee, a Spondee, a
Dactyle, and two Trochees im&shy;
mutably, as 

 <term lang="la">Nuncius celso veniens Olympo</term> . 

After three verses is inserted an Adonique, of a Dactyle, and
a Spondee;
 <term lang="la">Rara juventus</term>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="mm3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saraband(n)">Saraband (Ital. <etym lang="it"> Zaraban&shy;
da</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of lesson in Mu&shy;
sick, and a Dance so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sarah(pn)">Sarah (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Lady, Mi&shy;
stress or Dame.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcling time(n)">Sarcling time,</form> <xpln lang="en">or time of
Sarkling, is the time when
the Country man weeds his
Corn, and comes <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the
Lat.</class> (<etym lang="la">Sarculare</etym>) or <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the
Fr.</class> (<etym lang="fr">Sarcler</etym>), both which sig&shy;
nifie to rake or weed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcasm(n)">Sarcasm (<etym lang="la">sarcasmus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
biting taunt, bitter jest, a
manner of scoffing nipping&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcinarious(a)">Sarcinarious (<etym lang="la">sarcinarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to Packs,
Fardels, &amp;c. serving to carry
burthens or loads.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcinate(v)">Sarcinate (<etym lang="la">sarcino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to load
with Fardels or Packs; also
to patch or sew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcophage(n)">Sarcophage (<etym lang="la">sarcophagus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Grave, a Sepulchre, a Tomb;
also a Stone called Eat-flesh,
because it consumes, in forty
days, the dead Carkasses in&shy;
closed within it, the Teeth ex&shy;
cepted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcotic(a)">Sarcotique (from <etym lang="la">sarcoma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
breeding or belonging to new
or superfluous flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarculate(v)">Sarculate (<etym lang="la">sarculo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to rake,
to weed up with a Hook or
other Instrument.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sardonian gem(n)">Sardonian Gem (<etym lang="la"><emend err="sardoni">sardoni&shy;</emend>
us lapis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a pretious stone of a
black colour, being a kinde
of Onyx, and called a Corneol,
the best whereof are found in
Sardinia, and therefore so cal&shy;
led.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sardonian laughter(n)">Sardonian Laughter (<etym lang="la">ri&shy; 
sus Sardonius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a long and
causeless laughter, whereof
the end is sorrowful; so used
from the Herb Sardoa, which
being of a poysonous nature,
causes men to die with such a
convulsion or contraction of
their sinews, that they seem
to grin or laugh. This Herb is
like Smalage, and is found in
Sardinia. 
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarmentitious(a)">Sarmentitious (<etym lang="la">sarmenti&shy;
tius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to twigs
or branches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarplier(n)">Sarplar (<etym lang="la">sarplera lan&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
a quantity of Wool. This in
Scotland is called Serplathe, and
contains fourscore stone; for
the Lords of the Council in
Anno 1527. decreed four Ser&shy;
pliathes of packed Wool, to
contain sixteenscore stone of
Wool, by the Traffick of
Merchants now used. The
Merchants use to pay fraught
for their goods to Flanders,
by the Sack; to France, Spain,
and England, by the tun; and
to Dansken, and the Eastern
Seas, by the Serpliath . Skene
de verborum significatione, verbo
Serpliathe. With us in Eng&shy;
land, a load of Wool (as I
have been informed) consists
of eighty Tod, each Tod con&shy;
sisting of fourteen pound. And
that a Sack of Wool is in
common account equal with
a load; and a Sarplar (other&shy;
wise called a Pocket) is half a
Sack: Further, that a Pack
of Wool is a Hors-load, which
consists of seventeen stone, 


</page>

<page sig="mm3v">
and two pounds. See Fleta,
lib 2 cap 12.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sartor(n)">Sartor (Lat. <etym lang="la">&agrave; Sartio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Tailor, a Botcher, a Mender
of old Garments.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sassafras(n)">Sassafras,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Tree of great
vertue, which grows in the
Florida of the West Indies,
the Rinde whereof hath a
sweet smell like Cinnamon ; it
comforts the Liver and Sto&shy;
mack, and opens Obstructi&shy;
ons of the inward parts, be&shy;
ing hot and dry in the second
degree. The best of the Tree
is the Root, next the Boughs,
then the body, but the prin&shy;
ciple goodness of all rests in
the Rinde. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sassinate(v)">Sassinate</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Assassinate</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Satan(pn)">Satan (Heb.) (Gr <etym lang="gr">Sa&shy;
tanas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">An adversary, the divel,
enemy to God, and all good&shy;
ness. The Divel took this
name from the Hebr. <etym lang="he"> Sitnah</etym>,
which signifies hatred or
spightfulness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Satanical(a)">Satanical (from Satan)</form> <xpln lang="en">di&shy;
velish, pertaining to the <emend err="Di">Di&shy;</emend>
vel. Feltham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satellite(n)">Satellite (<etym lang="la">satelles, itis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
retained to guard a mans per&shy;
son; a Yeoman of the Guard;
a Serjeant, Catch-pole, one
that attacheth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satiate(v)">Satiate (<etym lang="la">satio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to fill, to
satisfy, to cloy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satiety(n)">Satiety (<etym lang="la">satietas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">plenty,
fulness, glutting, so much as
one desireth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satisdation(n)">Satisdation (<etym lang="la">satisdatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

sufficient for performance of
Covenants, or for payment of
moneys.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satorious(a)">Satorious (<etym lang="la">satorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to a Sator, or to
him that sows, sets, or
plants.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satrap(n)">Satrap (<etym lang="la">satrapa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a great
Ruler, a Peer of a Realm, a
Lieutenant, Governor or
President of a Country.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saturate(v)">Saturate (<etym lang="la">saturo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to fill
or satisfie with any thing
superfluously, to cloy, clam,
or glut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saturity(n)">Saturity (<etym lang="la">saturitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">ful&shy;
ness, plenty excess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saturnals(n)">Saturnals (<etym lang="la">saturnalia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Feasts dedicated to Saturn, in
December, when Servants had
freedom. 

Macrobius his Saturnals, are
Books intreating of the Col&shy;
loquies and Passages at some
of those Feasts.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saturn(pn)">Saturn (<etym lang="la">Saturnus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hath
the first place among the seven
Planets, but is slowest in
motion, not finishing its
course under thirty and eight
years space: The antient
Mathematicians attributed
Sterility and Mortality, to
this Planet; to Jupiter, happy
times, and the beginning of
life. To Mars, the cause of
all Debates, Garboils, and
War: To Sol, Riches and
Treasure: To Venus, Loves
and Marriages: To Mercury,
Eloquence and Knowledge:
To Luna, the Empire and
command over Humid mat&shy;
ters. 

Saturn with Alchymists, is
used for Lead ; with Heralds,
for Sable.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="mm4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saturnian(a)" lexeme="Saturnine(a)">Saturnian
or Saturnine (from <etym lang="la">Sa&shy;
turnus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bar&shy;
ren, dull,
heavy, melancholly; also un&shy;
lucky or unfortunate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satire(n)">Satyre (<etym lang="la">satyra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of
Poetry, whereof there seems
to have been two kindes;
the one more ancient, which
consisted onely in variety
of Verses; the other more
modern, containing an open
reprehension of mens vices,
without respect of per&shy;
sons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satirical(a)">Satyrical  (<etym lang="la">satyricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to Satyres;
biting, ripping, repro&shy;
ving</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satirist(n)">Satyrist,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that writes
Satyres or invectives.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satyr(n)">Satyre (<etym lang="la">satyrus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a strange
Monster, having the body
of a man all hairy, with legs
and feet like a Goat, full of
motion, which the Poets
were wont to call Gods of
the Woods; these (as Pliny
testifies, Lib.7. cap.2.) were
found in times past in the
Eastern Mountains of India.
And St. Hierome in the life of
St. Anthony, reports, he saw
one of these in his time:
 <term lang="la">Vidi homunculum (inquit) 
aduncis naribus, &amp; fronte cor&shy;
nibus aspera, cui extrema cor&shy;
poris in caprarum pelles define
bant, &amp;c.</term> But the truth here&shy;
of, I will not rashly impugn, 
nor over boldly affirm. And
Satyres shall dance there . Isai.
13.21.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sauciate(v)">Sauciate (<etym lang="la">saucio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to hurt,
to wound, to cut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saul(pn)">Saul (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lent of the
Lord, or (as some will) Fox.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sausage(n)">Saucidge (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Saucisse</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of pudding,
well known. The Bolonia
Saucidge is made of Beef and
lean Bacon in equal quantity,
flayed and chopped small
with half as much lard, and
some Pepper, Ginger and
Salt; then put into a clean
Ox-gut, half a foot long, and
laid in Salt for two days to&shy;
gether, and after hung up in
the Smoak. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saltire(n)">Saultoir orSautoir ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
St. Andrews Cross, termed so
by Heralds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saxons(pn)">Saxons</form> <xpln lang="en">the ancient
name of our Ancestors in
England) were so called from
their use, and wearing a
certain Sword or Weapon,
made after the fashion of a
Sithe, which in the Nether&shy;
lands is called a Saisen 
These kinde of Swords were
anciently writtenSeaxen or
Seaxes, and the Welshmen
wrote them Saisons, as they
yet write us. The learned
Engelhusus, of this Weapon
Seaxe, and name Saxon, hath
this Latin Rime. 

 <term lang="la">Quippe brevis gladius apud illos  Saxa vocatur,
Unde sibi Saxo nomen traxisse putatur</term>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

ting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scalado(n)">Scalado (from the Span.
<etym lang="sp">Escalada</etym>, and that from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Scala</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Ladder)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

der; it is a term of War, and
most commonly applied to
the gaining a Castle or
Town, by scaling it with
Ladders.,</xpln></wordentry>

ing one way,
ladderwise, not bolt up

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scale(pn)">Scale,</form> <xpln lang="en">an eminent place

and publickly cites offenders.
Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scalper(n)" lexeme="scalping iron(n)">Scalper
or

(<etym lang="la">scal&shy;
prum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

ons Instrument, to scrape or
