<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scandalize(v)">Scandalize (<etym lang="la">scandalizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
offend by giving ill example,
to give one occasion to sin or
be offended; also to slander
or defame.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scandaltim magnatum(n)">Scandalum magnatum 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the especial name of
a wrong done to any high
personage of the Land, as
Prelates, Dukes, Earls, Ba&shy;
rons, and other Nobles; as
also of the great Officers of
the Realm, by false news, or
horrible and false Messages,
whereby debates and discords
betwixt them and the Com&shy;
mons, or any scandal to their
persons might arise. Anno
2<expan type="">read</expan>2. cap.5.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scanderbeg(pn)">Scanderbeg, i. e. Great
Alexander;</form> <xpln lang="en">the nick-name of
that valiant Captain George
Castriot, the late terror of
the Turks, who is said in his
whole life time to have slain
three thousand of them with
his own hands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scandular(a)">Scandular (<etym lang="la">scandularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is of wooden Tiles, or
Shingles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scapular(a)">Scapular (<etym lang="la">scapularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to the shoulder. It
is also used substantively for
a narrow and square peece
of cloth, &amp;c. Worn by
Monks over the rest of their
Habit, and falling over the
shoulders on both sides from
the neck (which goes
through it, by a slit or
hole made for that pu&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="mm5r">
pose) down almost to the
foot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarabee(n)">Scarabee (<etym lang="la">scarabeus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
black flie, bred commonly
in Dung, called a Beetle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarify(v)">Scarifie (<etym lang="la">scarifico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
launce or open a soar; to
make little incisions and
holes or openings either that
the blood and humor may
the easier come out, or to
prepare a place for the bet&shy;
ter extraction of Cupping&shy;
Glasses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarification(n)">Scarification (<etym lang="la">scarificatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a cutting or lancing; a scra&shy;
ping the skin with a fleam,
that one may bleed the bet&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scatinian law(pn)">Scatinian Law (<etym lang="la">Lex Sca&shy;
tinia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was a Law made by
Scatinius, wherein the use of
preposterous venery was cha&shy;
stised.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarp(n)">Scarpe (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Escarpe</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Scarf, worn by Commanders
in the Field; and so named
in Heraldry. Leigh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scaturiginous(a)">Scaturiginous (<etym lang="la">scaturigi&shy;
nosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that bursts out, or runs
over, out of which water
riseth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scavage(n)">Scavage,</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise called
Shewage, is a kinde of toll
or Custom exacted, by Majors,
Sheriffs, and Bailiffs of Cities
and Burrough Towns, of
Merchants for Wares shewed
to be sold within their pre&shy;
cinct, which is forbidden by
the Statute of 19 H 7.8. It
comes of the Saxon word
(Sceaw) to behold or view,
or to shew; and hence the 
wordSceaw-stow, a Thea&shy;
tre or Shew-place, a behold&shy;
ing place. Verstegan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scavenger(n)">Scavenger (from the
Teut. <etym lang="gr">Schaben</etym>, or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Schaven</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to scrape or
shave away)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Officer well
known in London, that makes
clean the streets, by scraping
up and carrying away the
dust and durt. The Germans 
call him a <etym lang="gr">Drecksimon</etym>, from
one Simon, who was appoint&shy;
ed Scavenger of Marpurg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scelestic(a)">Scelestique (<etym lang="la">scelestus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
wicked, ungracious, mis&shy;
chievous, full of naughtiness.
Feltham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skeleton(n)">Sceleton ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is that
which the vulgar call an Ana&shy;
tomy; it is the whole Fa&shy;
brick or dry frame of humane
Bones; The dry carkass of a
man or woman, without Ar&shy;
teries, Muscles, or other natu&shy;
ral Appurtenances: For
 <etym lang="gr">Sceletos</etym> in Greek signifies
Bony, or dry as a bone. El.
Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skelm(n)">Scellum orSchellum 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">from the Belg.</class> <etym lang="bl">Schelm</etym>,)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
rogue, a villain, or a wicked
person. But Sir Rich. Green&shy;
vile was about the year 1644.
termed Schellum Greenvile,
for leaving the Parliaments
party, and adhering to the
King, which is a Renegado ra&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scene(n)">Scene (<etym lang="la">scena</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the front
or forepart of a Theatre or
Stage, or the partition be&shy;
tween the Players Vestry, and
the Stage; a Comedy or Tragedy, 


</page>

<page sig="mm5v">
or the division of a Play into
certain parts, viz. first into
Acts, those again into Scenes,
which sometimes fall out
more, sometimes fewer in
every Act, The definition
of a Scene being <term lang="la">mutatio perso&shy;
narum</term>. Godw. In old time it
signified a place covered with
boughes, or the room where
the Players made them ready.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scenical(a)">Scenical (<etym lang="la">scenicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to a Scene, Stage,
or Comedy, or to Players on
Stages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scenography(n)">Scenography (<etym lang="la">scenogra&shy;
phia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the model or draught
of any work presented with
its shadowes, according as the
work it self shews, with its
dimensions, according to the
Rules of prospective. Enchir.
of Fort.<xref> See Sciagraph</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sceptical(a)">Sceptical (<etym lang="la">scepticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
contemplates, or always seeks
and never finds. The Phi&shy;
losophers, called Scepticks,
were such as used to search
into, and consider much of
things, but leave them in sus&shy;
pence, without any determina&shy;
tion; affirming they knew no&shy;
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sceptriferous(a)">Sceptriferous (<etym lang="la">sceptrifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears a Scepter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scevity(n)">Scevity (<etym lang="la">sc&aelig;vitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">un&shy;
luckiness, lefthandedness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scevola(pn)">Scevola (<etym lang="la">sc&aelig;vola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Sur&shy;
name of Q. Mutius, a noble
Roman, who voluntarily
burnt off his own right hand,
&amp;c. hence the word is used
for a left handed man, or one
that hath but one hand. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schediasm(n)">Schediasm (<etym lang="la">schediasma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sudden invention, or a work
extempore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schedical(a)">Schedical (<etym lang="la">schedicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
hasty, sudden, extemporary,
not labored.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scheme(n)">Scheme (<etym lang="la">schema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the out&shy;
ward habit or fashion of any
thing, the adorning a speech
with Rhetorical figures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schism(n)">Schism (<etym lang="la">schisma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pro&shy;
perly a cutting in two, a dis&shy;
agreeing of minds, a division
in the Church of Christ con&shy;
sisting with an unity in mat&shy;
ters of Faith. 

Schism (says an Author) is
an uncharitable division or
recession of any member from
the unity of the whole
Church. As Heresie is a de&shy;
parting from the Communion
of the Church in respect of
doctrine; So Schism is a di&shy;
viding or cutting off ones self
for external things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schismatic(a)">Schismatick (<etym lang="la">schismati&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that is divided from
the external Communion of
the Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schismatical(a)">Schismatical (<etym lang="la">schismati&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of, or pertaining to Schism
or such division in the
Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scholastica(pn)">Scholastica ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a wo&shy;
mans name, and signifies,
leasure from business.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scholastic(a)">Scholastic (<etym lang="la">scholasticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to a Schol&shy;
lar or School, Schollarly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scholy(n)">Scholy (<etym lang="la">scholium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
close, a short, or compendious
exposition. 

And Scholiast, one that 


</page>

<page sig="mm6r">
writes such Expositions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciagraph(n)">Sciagraph (<etym lang="la">sciagrapha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a description of the whole
frame and contrivance of
every room; As the Carpen&shy;
ter shews with a Lath how
the work will fall out; a
Platform.<xref> See Scenography</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciamachy(n)">Sciamachy (<etym lang="la">scimachia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
counterfeit fighting, a privy
exercise; a shadow or i&shy;
mage of contention or fight&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciater(n)">Sciater ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;
strument used in chusing the
scituation of Cities.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciatherical(a)">Sciatherical (from <etym lang="la">Scia&shy;
thericon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertaining to
a Sun-Dial.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciatica(n)">Sciatica ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gout
in the hip caused by gross
and flegmatick humors, ga&shy;
thered in the hollowness of
its joynt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciatic vein(n)">Sciatique Vein (<etym lang="la">Vena sci&shy;
atica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is seated above the out&shy;
ward ankle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="science(n)">Science (<etym lang="la">scientia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cun&shy;
ning, skill, learning, know&shy;
ledge. The seven liberal Sci&shy;
ences are these, Grammer,
Logick, Rhetorick, Astrology,
Geometry, Arithmetick and Mu&shy;
sick</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scientifical(a)">Scientifical (<etym lang="la">scientificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of exceeding skil, or won&shy;
derful knowledge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scintillation(n)">Scintillation (<etym lang="la">scintillatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a sparkling up of fire, or
new wine leaping in the
glass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciolist(n)">Sciolist (<etym lang="la">sciolus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a smat&shy;
terer in any knowledge, one
that fancies himself to be a 
wit, and to know more, then
indeed he doth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciolous(a)">Sciolous,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
such a Sciolist, or smatterer in
learning. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sciomanty(n)">Sciomantie (<etym lang="la">sciomantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the part of Necromancy,
practised by shadows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scion(n)">Scion (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Scio</etym>, <term lang="la">&agrave; scin&shy;

a Graf, a young Plant, a Shoot
or sprig.</xpln></wordentry>

rical</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skiff(n)">Schiph (<etym lang="la">Scapha</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a ship&shy;
boat, commonly all of one
peece:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scipper(n)">Scipper orSchipper,</form> <xpln lang="en">is
<class type="etymlang" lang="du">a Dutch word</class> signifying the
Master of a ship, An. I. Jac.
Sess. I. ca.34. But we usually
take Skippers for common Sea&shy;
men or Marriners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scirpean(a)">Scirpean (<etym lang="la">scirpeus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scirrhous(a)">Scirrhous (from <etym lang="la">schir&shy;
rhus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to a hard
swelling without pain, grown
in the flesh within the skin,
caused through choller, or
through thick, cold or clam&shy;
my fleam: Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scissile(a)" lexeme="scissible(a)">Scissile

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scitament(n)">Scitament (<etym lang="la">scitamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kind of meat having a very
pleasant taste; Also pleasant&shy;
ness, or a fine or witty thing
set to adorn ones talk.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="mm6v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scite(n)">Scite (<etym lang="la">scitum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Ordi&shy;
nance, Decree or Statute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scomm(n)">Scom (<etym lang="la">scomma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a scoff, a
mock, a sentence spoken in
mirth that sounds otherwise
then it is meant, by him that
speaks it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sconce(n)">Sconce (from the Teut.
<etym lang="gr">Schants</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Block-house or
Fortification in War; also
taken for the Head, because
a Sconce or Block-house is
made, for the most part round
in fashion of a Head, whence
comes the term in Oxford,
to Sconce one (Lat. <etym lang="la">Malctare
pecunia</etym>) <expan type="">id est</expan> to set up so much
in the Buttery Book upon
his head, to pay, as a punish&shy;
ment for his offence commit&shy;
ted. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scopelism(n)">Scopelism (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&kappa;&#x03cc;&pi;&epsilon;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rockiness, or the
being full of Rocks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scoptic(n)">Scopticks (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> 
<etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&kappa;&omega;&pi;&tau;&omega;, cavillor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Jests, Jeers,
Flouts, Cavils; sentences or
words spoken in mirth, that
sound otherwise then they
were meant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scopulous(a)">Scopulous (<etym lang="la">scopulosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of rocks, very rocky.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scorbute(n)">Scorbute (<etym lang="la">scorbutus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
disease called the Scurvy . Herb.
Trav.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scorbutical(a)">Scorbutical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining or
subject to that disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scorpion(n)">Scorpion (<etym lang="la">scorpio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a vene&shy;
mous Worm with <emend err="seveen">seven</emend> feet,
bearing his sting in his Tail,
with which he strikes mis&shy;
chievously; they may be kill&shy;
ed with fasting spettle of a
found man. Also one of the 12 
Signs, which Vide in Zodi&shy;
ack. Also a kinde of warlike
Engine, wherewith to shoot
small Arrows or Darts, cal&shy;
led also an Onager, which you
shall finde described by Mar&shy;
cellinus, lib.23. cap.3.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scortator(n)">Scortator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a whore&shy;
monger, a hunter of Harlots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scot and lot(n)">Scot and Lot</form> <xpln lang="en">( An.33 H 8.
cap.19.) signifies a customary
contribution laid upon all
Subjects after their ability.
Scot comes from the Fr.
 <etym lang="fr">Escot</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">symbolum</term>, a shot.
Rastal saith, it is a certain
custom or common Tallage
made to the use of the Sheriff
or his Bailiff. Scot (says
Camden) <term lang="la">illud dicitur quod ex
diversis rebus in unum acervum
aggregatur</term> . And in this sence
it is still used; for when good&shy;
follows meet at the Tavern
or Alehouse, they at parting,
call for a Shot, Scot, or reckon&shy;
ing: And he is said to go
Scot-free, that pays not his
part or share towards the
reckoning:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scotomy(n)">Scotomy (<etym lang="la">scotoma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
ease in the Head; with a dim&shy;
ness in the eyes, which makes
all things seem to go round.
This word comes from the
Greek, and is the same with
Vertigo in Latin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scotomatical(a)">Scotomatical (<etym lang="la">scotomati&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is troubled with
such a whimsey in the head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scottering(n)">Scottering (<etym lang="la">unde, nescio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
in Herefordshire, Boyes at the
latter end of Harvest will
burn a wad of Pease in the 


</page>

<page sig="mm7r">
Straw, which they call a Scot&shy;
tering, and eat the Pease, being
so parched.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scovel(n)">Scovel (from the Italian
<etym lang="it">Scovola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Malkin to make
clean an Oven; hence per&shy;
haps our word Shovel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scout(n)">Scout (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">the Belg.</class> <etym lang="bl">Schonuvet</etym>,
or <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Escoute</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a discover&shy;
er or fore-runner of an Ar&shy;
my, or one sent out to espy,
and bring tidings of the ene&shy;
mies purpose. 

In Holland they have an
Officer in their Towns called
aScout, who is chosen by
the States, and with the Ba&shy;
lues, have the judging of all
criminal matters in last re&shy;
sort, without Appeal, and
have also the determining ci&shy;
vil causes, appealable to the
Hague. How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="screable(a)">Screable (<etym lang="la">screabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be spitted out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scribe(n)">Scribes (<etym lang="la">scrib&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">menti&shy;
oned in Scripture, their of&shy;
fice was twofold. I. To read
and expound the Law in the
Temple and Synagogues. 2. To
execute the office of a Judge,
in ending and composing
Actions. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scriptorian(a)">Scriptorian (<etym lang="la">scriptorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of, belonging or serving to
writing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scruff(n)">Scruff,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a kinde of fuel,
which poor people (when
firing is dear) gather up at
ebbing water, in the bottom
of the Thames about London,
and consists of Coal, little
sticks of Wood, Cockle-shells,
and the like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scruple(n)">Scruple (<etym lang="la">scriptulum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is of
Troy weight seven grains and
an half; the third part of a
dram, and a dram the third
part of an ounce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrupular(a)">Scrupular (<etym lang="la">scrupularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to a scruple,
small.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrupulosity(n)">Scrupulosity (<etym lang="la">scrupulosi&shy; 
tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">curiousness of Conscience,
anxiety, doubtfulness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrutable(a)">Scrutable (<etym lang="la">scrutabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be searched or traced
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrutiny(n)">Scrutiny (<etym lang="la">scrutinium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
search or diligent inquiry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sculptor(n)">Sculptor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a graver
or carver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sculpture(n)">Sculpture (<etym lang="la">sculptura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
graving or carving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scurrile(a)">Scurrile (<etym lang="la">scurrilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to scoffing or saucy
jesting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scurrility(n)">Scurrility (<etym lang="la">scurrilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">im&shy;
moderate jesting, saucy scof&shy;
fing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scutage(n)">Scutage.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Escuage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scutcheon(n)">Scutchin.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Thole</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scutcheon(n)">Scutchion (from <etym lang="la">Scutum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Coat of Arms, or Shield.
See <xref lexeme="escutcheon">Escotcheon</xref>. It is sometimes
also taken for the bud of a
Tree, cut off with a part of the
bark, for inoculation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scutiferous(a)">Scutiferous (<etym lang="la">scutifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
bears a Buckler or Shield.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scutiform(a)">Scutiform (<etym lang="la">in forma scuti</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
fashioned like a Scutcheon or
Shield.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scylia(pn)">Scylia,</form> <xpln lang="en">a gulf or danger&shy;
ous place in the Sicilian Sea.
See <xref lexeme="Charybdis">Charibdis</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scimitar(n)">Scymitar orSemitar 
(<class type="etymlang" lang="it">Italian</class> <etym lang="it">Scimitara</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a crooked 


</page>

<page sig="mm7v">
flat back'd sword used by the
Turks and Persians. See <xref target="Cimeterre">Ci&shy;
miterre</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scytale(n)">Scytale (<etym lang="la">scytala</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a field
Mouse, &amp;c. Also a little round
staff, which the Lacedemonians 
used to write secret letters
on. And in this last sence
my Lo. Bacon uses it, in his
 Advancement of Learning, fol.
268.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seater(n)">Seater,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old Idol of
the Saxons, which was honor&shy;
ed on the day called Satur&shy;
day, which thence took its
denomination. This Idol
was also called Crodo, and
by some mistaken for Sa&shy;
turn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scythian(a)" lexeme="Scythic(a)">Scythian 
Scythick <etym lang="la"> 
(scythicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to Scy&shy;
thia, a large Country in the
north part of the World.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sea-lungs(n)">Sea-longs,</form> <xpln lang="en">the fervent
froth of the Sea. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sax(n)">Seax,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of sword
made like a Sithe, and worn
by the old Saxons, of which
there were two sorts, a longer
and a shorter, which last were
calledHandseaxes ; Of this
kind ofHandseaxes, Erken&shy;
wine, King of the East Sax&shy;
ons did bear for his Arms
three Argent, in a field Gules .
Verstegan . See <xref>Saxon</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sebacean(a)">Sebacean (<etym lang="la">sebaceus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">made
of tallow or sewet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sebastian(pn)">Sebastian ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hono&shy;
rable, or majestical.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sebastocrator(n)">Sebastocrator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was
a great Officer of the Em&shy;
pire, who (about Constantine
the Greats time) was third in 
dignity from the Emperor,
and the second was called
Despot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secament(n)">Secament (<etym lang="la">secamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is cut or shread
from a Log or Block, as chips,
and such like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secation(n)">Secation (<etym lang="la">secatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cut&shy;
ting, sawing, parting or di&shy;
viding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secern(v)">Secerne (<etym lang="la">secerno</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to di&shy;
vide, to lay or separate one
from another, to sever, to
chuse from among others.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secession(n)">Secession (<etym lang="la">secessio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
parting from other, a forsak&shy;
ing or going a side; a sepa&shy;
rating of ones self from ano&shy;
ther. In ancient Rome it was
a general Insurrection and re&shy;
volt of the Commons, wherein
they left the City, until such
time as they had the Au&shy;
thority of their Tribunes
strengthned; yea, and cer&shy;
tain Laws enacted and esta&shy;
blished by a solemn oath, with
a curse denounced against
all of them that went about to
abrogate or abolish the same,
which thereupon were called
 <term lang="la">Sacrat&aelig; Leges</term>. Livy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seclude(v)">Seclude (<etym lang="la">secludo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to shut
a part from other, to shut out,
to put away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seclusory(n)">Seclusory (<etym lang="la">seclusorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
place where any thing is
shut up a part from other; a
Coop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secundine(n)">Secondine (<etym lang="la">secund&aelig;</etym>; <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
<etym lang="la">secunda nativitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the three
skins, wherein an infant lies
while it is in the womb, or 


</page>

<page sig="mm8r">
when it comes into the
world; the second or after
birth</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sectary(n)">Sectary (<etym lang="la">sectarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that follows private opinions
in Religion, a Ring-leader of
a Sect, a seditious, factious
person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="section(n)">Section (<etym lang="la">sectio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cut&shy;
ting, dividing or parting. 

Books are commonly divi&shy; 
ded into Chapters, Chapters,
into Sections, and Sections in&shy;
to Paragraffs or Breaks, as the
Printers call them; which is
the breaking off at such a
word and beginning a new
line.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sective(a)">Sective (<etym lang="la">sectivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is
often, or that may be cut or
divided:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secular(a)">Secular (<etym lang="la">secularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to the space of one
hundred years, that is done
or renewed every hundreth
year, or once in an age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secular plays(n)">Secular Plays (<etym lang="la">ludi se&shy;
culares</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">were solemn Games
or Plaies among the ancient
Romans, performed once in
a hundred and ten years, and
sometime every hundreth
year, in honor of Apollo or
Diana.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secular priests(n)">Secular Priests,</form> <xpln lang="en">among
the Romanists, are those whose
Ordinary conversation is a&shy;
mong men of the world, and
profess the undertaking the
charge of Souls, as condistinct
from those that profess a
monastical or conventual life,
under the rule of some holy
Predecessor, and thence are
called Regulars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secundary(n)">Secundary (<etym lang="la">secundarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of the second sort, the second,
the next to the first. At the
Secundary of the Fine Office,
is an Officer next to the
chief Officer; Secundary of
the Counter, who is (as I
take it) next to the Sheriff
in London, in each of the two
Counters, and so of o&shy;
thers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secundate(v)">Secundate (<etym lang="la">secundo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make lucky or prosperous,
to make better or amend a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="secundine(n)">Secundine.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Secon&shy;
dine</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="securiferous(a)">Securiferous (<etym lang="la">securifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that beareth an Axe or
Hatchet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sedateness(n)">Sedatenes,</form> <xpln lang="en">quietness, mi&shy;
tigation; the same with <xref>Seda&shy;
tion</xref>. <expan type="">Lord</expan> Prot. Speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sedation(n)">Sedation (<etym lang="la">sedatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an ap&shy;
peasing, mitigating or asswa&shy;
ging, qualifying or quiet&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sedentary(a)">Sedentary (<etym lang="la">sedentarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that sits much, that is done
sitting. In France they have
eight Sedentary Parliaments
or High Courts of Justice,
which are so called, because
they are always sitting.<xref> See
Parliament</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sediment(n)">Sediment (<etym lang="la">sedimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a sinking down to the bot&shy;
tom, or that sinks to the
bottom; grounds, the dregs
or dross of perfume. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seditious(a)">Seditious (<etym lang="la">seditiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
contentions, mutinous, facti&shy;
ous, loving discord. Mr.
Feltham in his Resolves uses 


</page>

<page sig="mm8v">
Seditiary, for a seditious per&shy;
son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seduction(n)">Seduction (<etym lang="la">seductio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
seducing, a leading away, aside,
or apart, a misleading, a deceiv&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sedulity(n)">Sedulity (<etym lang="la">sedulitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">care
and great diligence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="segador(n)">Segador ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sp">Span.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a reaper,
a Mower, a Harvest-man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="segment(n)">Segment (<etym lang="la">segmentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

gobbet cut off from any thing,
a partition. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="segmentation(n)">Segmentation (<etym lang="la">segmenta&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a cutting into smal peeces,
an embroidering.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="segnity(n)">Segnity (<etym lang="la">segnitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">neg&shy;
ligence, slowness, slothfulness;
also barrenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="segregate(v)">Segregate (<etym lang="la">segrego</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
take out of the stock, to lay
apart, to sever or separate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sejan horse(n)">Seian horse (so called
from <etym lang="la">Cneus Sejanus</etym>, who first
backed him)</form> <xpln lang="en">was of extraor&shy;
dinary bigness and wonder&shy;
ful composure, but had this
fatal property, to bring
whomsoever was his Master
to some miserable or untime&shy;
ly end. Whence grew the
proverb, <term lang="la">Equum habet Sejanum</term>,
a man has that which will be
his own ruin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seiant(a)">Seiant orSeisant (from
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Seant</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tearm in He&shy;
raldry, when a beast is pain&shy;
ted sitting upright.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seignior(n)">Seignior (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Seigneur</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Lord, a Master; a Land&shy;
lord, or a Lord of Jurisdiction,
a proprietary or owner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seigniory(n)" lexeme="seigniorage(n)">Seigniory 
Seigniorage (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Seigneu&shy;
ry, Seigneu&shy;
riage</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Seignory, Soveraign&shy;
ty, mastery, dominion o&shy;
ver. 

<term lang="en"> Seigniorage</term>. An.9. H.5.
Stat.2. cap. I. seems to be a
Regality or Prerogative of
the King, whereby he chal&shy;
lenges allowance of gold and
silver, brought in the mass to
his Exchange, for coyn.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seisin(n)">Seisin (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Sai&shy;
sine</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our Common
Law, possession, and to seize,
is to take possession; Primier
seisin, is the first possession,
&amp;c. See more of this in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sejugate(v)">Sejugate (<etym lang="la">sejugo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to sever
or <emend err="separte">separate</emend> from other, to put
a part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sejunction(n)">Sejunction (<etym lang="la">sejunctio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
separating or putting a sun&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Selenites(pn)">Selenites ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stone
wherein is a white which in&shy;
creases and decreases as the
Moon doth; Also, lunary
men, or people that are held
by some to inhabit the Moon.
How.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="selion(n)">Selion (Fr. <etym lang="fr">seillon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
ridge of land lying between
two furrows; Sometimes it
contains an Acre, sometimes
half an Acre, sometimes more
or less. Therefore Crompton
in his Jurisdictions fol. 221.
saith, a Selion of land cannot
be in demand, because it is a
thing incertain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sellander(n)">Sellander,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a certain kind 


</page>

<page sig="nn1r">
of dry scab, growing in the
very bent of the Ham of a
horses hinder leg. Mark&shy;
ham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sellary(n)">Sellary (<etym lang="la">sellaria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a place
wherein were formes and
stools for men to sit on. It is
used by Tacitus in his Annals
for that place where Tiberius
exercised his horrid and un&shy;
natural lusts.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Sense not found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semblable(a)">Semblable ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">like, a&shy;
like, even such, resem&shy;
bling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semblance(n)">Semblance ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">shew,
seeming appearance: Also re&shy;
semblance, likeness, like form
or feature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sementation(n)">Sementation (<etym lang="la">sementatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a bringing forth seed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sementine(a)">Sementine (<etym lang="la">sementinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to sowing, conti&shy;
nuing to seed time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semi(px)">Semi orSemis (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the

in composition, for half.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semicastration(n)">Semicastration (<etym lang="la">semi</etym>
and <etym lang="la">castratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">half gelding,
the taking away one Testicle.
Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semicircular(a)">Semicircular (<etym lang="la">semicircu&shy;
laris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath the form of
half a Circle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semicolon(n)">Semicolon,</form> <xpln lang="en">half a Colon,
or a point in writing or print&shy;
ing made thus [;] in the
middle of a sentence; the
Colon thus [:] the Period 
thus [.] the Comma thus
[,] the Admiration point thus
[!] as when we say, <term lang="la">O tem&shy;
pora! O mores!</term> The Interro&shy;
gation point thus [?] when
we ask any question. A Cir&shy; 
cumflex is over the second [ a]
when we say <term lang="la">am&acirc;sti</term>, for <term lang="la">ama&shy;
visti</term>; An Apostroph is when
some vowel is cut off; 'twas,
for it was, and the like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semidole(n)">Semidole (<etym lang="la">semidolium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
vessell containing half a Tun,
a Pipe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semiferous(a)">Semiferous (<etym lang="la">semifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
half wilde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semihore(n)">Semihore (<etym lang="la">semihora</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">half
an hour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semimarine(a)">Semimarine (<etym lang="la">semimari&shy;
nus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging partly to
the Sea, and partly to the
Land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seminality(n)">Seminality (from <etym lang="la">semi&shy;
na</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a belongingness to seed;
an aptness to have or bear
seed. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seminary(n)">Seminary (<etym lang="la">seminarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
seed plot, a place where
plants are set to be removed;
a Nurcery, a tree whereof
Plants and Graffs be taken;
Also the first beginning or
chief cause of any good or
evil; And by metaphor, a
Colledge, or Nursery of young
Students.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seminate(v)">Seminate (<etym lang="la">semino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
sow, breed or ingender.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seminifical(a)">Seminifical (<etym lang="la">seminificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that causeth or brings forth
seed for generation. For
Males are said to be seminifi&shy;
cal and pubescent at, or soon
after fourteen years of age, as
Aristotle says, <term lang="la">bis septem annis
exactis</term>, &amp;c. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semipedal(a)">Semipedal (<etym lang="la">semipedalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
half a foot in quantity or
height.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simitar(n)">Semitar.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Scymitar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="nn1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semitate(v)">Semitate (<etym lang="la">semito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
pathes, to divide into pathes
or ways.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semivowel(n)">Semivowels (<etym lang="la">semivocales</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
certain Consonants so called,
because they have half the
sound of Vowels, As f, l, m,
n, s, therefore of old s, and
still m in the end of words
before vowels are cut off like
vowels. See Nat. Hist. fol.
46.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semiustulated(a)">Semiustulated (<etym lang="la">semiustu&shy;
latus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">half burned, half roast&shy;
ed or broiled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sempiternal(a)">Sempiternal (<etym lang="la">sempiternus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
perpetual, endless, lasting al&shy;
wayes, continual, immortal,
eternal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semuncial(a)">Semuncial (<etym lang="la">semuncialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to half an
ounce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seneschal(n)">Senescal (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Seneschal</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Steward. As the high Se&shy;
neschal or Steward of Eng&shy;
land. P l. Cor. fol 152. It is also
used for the Steward of
Courts. Kitch. fol 83.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="senescent(a)">Senescent (<etym lang="la">senescens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
waxing old, growing in age,
wearing away, drawing to
the wain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="senesce(v)">Senesce (<etym lang="la">senesco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to wax

decay or wear away.</xpln></wordentry>

of apprehending, thinking or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sensuality(n)">Sensuality (<etym lang="la">sensualitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

pleasing of sence, contentment
given to the appetite, satis&shy;
faction to the flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sententiosity(n)">Sententiosity (<etym lang="la">sentensio&shy;

which are concise and pithy
peeces of wit, containing
much matter in few words.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sententious(a)">Sententious (<etym lang="la">sententiosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of sentences, pitthy, full
of matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sentinel(n)">Sentinel ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">or Sentry.

ted to stand and watch in a
certain place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="separatory(n)">Separatory (Fr. <etym lang="fr">separa&shy;
toire</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Chizel or Instru&shy;
ment, wherewith Chyrurge&shy;
ons cut out the peeces of
bones, left between the
holes, which they bore with
a Trepan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="separatist(n)">Separatist (<etym lang="la">separans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one

munion of the Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sepiment(n)">Sepiment (<etym lang="la">sepimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sept(n)">Septs,</form> <xpln lang="en">are multitudes

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="septuagenary(a)">Septuagenary (<etym lang="la">septuage&shy;
nus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to seventy or
threescore and ten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Septuagesima(pn)">Septuagesima,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Sun&shy;
day certain, being always the
next but one before Shrove&shy;
Sunday, from which, till the
Octaves of Easter, the solem&shy;
nizing of marriage is by the
Cannon Lawes forbidden;
that being a time of mourn&shy;
ing, for the fall of Adam, and
misery of man thereon ensu&shy;
ing; And Easter with its
Octaves is a time of Christs
glorification, and so of ours al&shy;
so in him, for his, and by him,
our conquest over death and
sin; And that therefore all
carnal affection ought during
that space to be wholly mor&shy;
tified in us. Cow.<xref> See Quin&shy;
quagesima</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Septuagesimal(a)">Septuagesimal (<etym lang="la">septuage&shy;
simus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to the num&shy;
ber seventy, or Septuagesima
Sunday.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="septuagints(n)">Septuagints (<etym lang="la">septuaginta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
properly signifie the seventy
Translators of the holy Bible
out off Hebrew into Greek,
who were in truth Seventy
two (viz.) six chosen out of
every one of the Twelve
Tribes of Israel, by Eleazer
the High Priest, at the request
of Ptolm&aelig;us Philadelphus
King of &AElig;gypt, for the rich&shy;
est ornament of his memora&shy;
ble Library. These by com&shy;
pendious speech are called
the seventy Interpreters, as
the <term lang="la">Centum viri</term>, among the
Romans, who were indeed 


</page>

<page sig="nn2v">
One hundred and five, three
out of a Tribe, and thirty
five Tribes. Bud&aelig;us.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="septuary(a)">Septuary (from <etym lang="la">Septem</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
may be applied to any thing
composed of the number se&shy;
ven. Dr. Br. uses it for a
week, consisting of seven
days.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="septuncial(a)">Septuncial (<etym lang="la">septuncialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of seven ounces, or seven parts
of the whole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sequel(n)">Sequele (<etym lang="la">sequela</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the fol&shy;
lowing, consequence, issue,
or success of a thing; also a
train or retinue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sequence(n)">Sequences (<etym lang="la">sequencia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an&shy;
swering Verses, or Verses that
answer one another sequenti&shy;
ally. 

A Sequence at Cards, is three
of a sort that answer or fol&shy;
low one another, in number
or degree, as King, Queen,
and Knave, Eight, nine, and
ten, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sequester(v)" lexeme="sequestrate(v)">Sequester 
Sequestrate  (<etym lang="la">sequestro</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">to separate
a thing in controversie, from
the possession of both those
that contend for it. And this
is double, Voluntary Sequestra&shy; 
tion or Judiciary . Voluntary is
that which is used by the
consent of both parties: Ju&shy;
diciary is that which the
Judge of his Authority doth,
whether the parties will or
not. Cow. 

In what sence it hath been
of late years used, very many
know by sad experience.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sequestrator(n)">Sequestrator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is he
that puts a thing in contro&shy;
versie into another mans
hand; or rather the third per&shy;
son, who takes a thing in
controversie between two
But it is now usually taken
for an Officer, that receives
the Rents of Recusants or
Delinquents Estates, for the
use of the Commonwealth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seraglio(n)">Seraglio (<class type="etymlang" lang="tu">the Turkish
word</class>  is <etym lang="tu">Serai</etym>, borrowed <class type="etymlang" lang="pe">from
the Persian</class> <etym lang="pe">Seraw</etym>, which sig&shy;
nigies a house)</form> <xpln lang="en">is that place
in Constantinople, where the
Grand Signor resides with
his Court; the description
whereof, you may see at large
in Mr. Rob. Withers Book,
set out by Mr. Jo. Greaves.
1650.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serene(n)">Serain ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a foggy
mist or dampish vapor, falling
in Italy about Sun-set, at which
time it is unwholsom to be a&shy;
broad there, especially bare&shy;
headed, mildew; also the
fresh and cool air of the even&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seraph(n)">Seraph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Turkish coyn
of fine gold, worth about a
French crown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seraphim(pn)">Seraphim (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class> <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">fulgen&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="nn3r">
tes aut comburentes</term>;</form> <xpln lang="en">so called

chy</xref></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sergeant at law(n)">Sergeant at Law</form> <xpln lang="en">(or of
the Coyf) is the highest de&shy;
gree, taken in that professi&shy;
on, as a Doctor of the Civil
Law, &amp;c. See more of this in
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sergeanty(n)">Sergeanty (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> 
<etym lang="fr">Sergeant</etym>, or <etym lang="fr"> Sergent</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> one re&shy;
tained to guard ones person)
</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our Common
Law, a service due to the
King, from his Tenant hold&shy;
ing by such service; For this
service cannot be due to any
Lord from his Tenant, but
to the King onely. And this
is either grand or petit, as you
shall find in Littletons Tenures,
and Bra. l.2. ca.26.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="segreant(a)">Sergreant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a tearm in He&shy;
raldry, applied onely to the
Griffin, which is so cal&shy;
led.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serosity(n)">Serosity (<etym lang="la">serocitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
waterishness or thinner parts
of the mass of blood (an&shy;
swering to whay in milk)
which floats upon it after it
has been let out of a vein; al&shy;
so the whayish or waterish
moisture drawn by the Kid&shy;
neys from all parts of the bo&shy;
dy, and after some concoction
termed, urine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serous(a)">Serous,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to such
waterishness, or moysture, &amp;c.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serotine(a)" lexeme="serotinous(a)">Serotine

that is in the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serpentine(a)">Serpentine (<etym lang="la">serpentinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to Serpents;
under which general name all
vermine that creep on the
belly, and not on their feet,
as Snakes, Adders, &amp;c. are
contained. Also winding,
wrigling or crooking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serpentine verse(n)">Serpentine verses,</form> <xpln lang="en">are
those which do, as it were,
run into themselves, as we see
Serpents pictured with tail in
mouth, <emend err="to" source="errata">so</emend> these verses begin,
and end with same word.
As that of Juvenal. 


</page>

<page sig="nn3v">
 <term lang="la">Crescit amor nummi, quantum ipsa pecunia crescit</term> . 

Also a kind of warlike En&shy;
gine called a Serpentine or Ba&shy;
silisco:</xpln></wordentry>

Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serviter(n)">Serviteur ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a servi&shy;
tor; servant, Serving-man,
attendant or waiter. Wee
use the word Servitor in our
Universities, where the poor
or meaner sort of Schollars
(that have not wherewith
sufficiently to maintain them&shy;
selves) execute the office of
a Servitor or attendant to
those of greater wealth and
quality.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sesquipedal(a)">Sesquipedal (<etym lang="la">sesquipedalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of a foot and a half in measure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sesquipedalian(n)">ASesquipedalian,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
is a foot and half high. 

Sesquipedalian words (<etym lang="la">verba
sesquipedalia</etym>) used by Horace
for great, stout, and lofty
words; words that are very
long, consisting of many Syl&shy;
lables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sesquitertian(a)">Sesquitertian (<etym lang="la">sesquiter 
tius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which contains as much
as another, and a third part
more.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="session(n)">Session (<etym lang="la">sessio, &agrave; sedeo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sitting: Sessions are usually
taken for the quarterly sit&shy;
ting of Justices in court, o&shy;
therwise called General Sessi&shy;
ons . An.5. Eliz. ca.4 or Open
Sessions, ib. There are also o&shy;
ther kinds of Sessions, of which
see Cromp. Justice of P. fol.
109 &amp; 110.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sesterce(n)">Sesterce 
Sestercie  (<etym lang="la">sertertius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
coyn among the
Romans, whereof Denarius 
contained four, and is so cal&shy;
led <term lang="la">quasi</term> <term lang="la">Semitertius</term>, for it con&shy;
tained two and a half of the
brazen coyn called As, and
it is marked with this figure,
H S. which signifies 2 lib. &amp;
demi. Thom. Of our money it
valued about three half pence
farthing; Or (as the Transla&shy;
tor of Tacitus computes it)
three half pence farthing, and
half farthing. This Character
compounded of H-S. two ca&shy;
pital I I. and the letter S
thus coupled together stood
for Sestertius, others say the
true character was LL-S.
Godwin 137.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sestine(n)">Sestine ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Stanza of
six verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shittim(n)">Sethim orSetim,</form> <xpln lang="en">a tree
like a white Thorn, the tim&shy;
ber whereof never rots. Of
this tree was made the holy
Ark of the Old Testament.
See <xref>Ark</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="nn4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="setigerous(a)">Setigerous (<etym lang="la">setiger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
bears or hath bristles on his
back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Severians(pn)">Severians</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called from
Severus their first founder) a
sort of Hereticks that con&shy;
demned marriage, abstained
from eating flesh and drinking
wine, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sevidical(a)">Sevidical (<etym lang="la">s&aelig;vidicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
speaks cruel and rigorous
words, that threatneth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seville(a)">Sevil.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Sivil</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sevocation(n)">Sevocation (<etym lang="la">sevocatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
calling apart or aside, a with&shy;
drawing from.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shewel(n)">Sewel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a paper, clout or
any thing hanged up to keep
a Deer from entring into a
place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sewer(n)">Sewer orSewar,</form> <xpln lang="en">has
two significations with us,
one applied to him that issues
or comes in before the meat
of the King or other great
Personage, and placeth it up&shy;
on the Table, &amp;c. The other,
to such passages or gutters, as
carry water into the Sea or
River, in Lawyers Latine
called Sewera, An.6. H.6. ca.
5. And there are Commissi&shy;
ons of Sewers usually granted
under the Great Seal, autho&shy;
rising certain person, to see
Dreins and Ditches well kept
and maintained in the Marish
and Fen Countries, for bet&shy;
ter conveyance of the water
into the Sea, and preserving
the grass for food of Cattle.
This word is probably de&shy;
rived from the Fr. (<etym lang="fr">issue</etym>) an
issue or going forth, as if we 
should call them Issuers, be&shy;
cause they give issue or pas&shy;
sage to the water, &amp;c. And
the Lat. word (<term lang="la">suera</term>) some&shy;
times used in these Commis&shy;
sions, is a competent reason
for this conjecture. See Fitz.
nat. br. in Oyer and Terminer.
I have heard of an old
French book containing the
Officers of the King of Eng&shy;
lands Court, as it was ancient&shy;
ly governed, wherein he,
whom we now call Sewer,
was called Asseour, which
comes from the Fr. (<etym lang="fr">Asseoir</etym>)
to set, settle or place, wherein
his Office in setting down the
meat is well expressed. And
Sewer, as it signifies an Of&shy;
ficer, is by Fleta Latined
Assessor, a setter down, lib.2.
ca.15.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sexagesima Sunday(pn)">Sexagesima Sunday,</form> <xpln lang="en">is
always the Sunday next be&shy;
fore Shrove Sunday, and is so
called either for being the
sixth before Passion Sunday,
or the second before Quadra&shy;
gesima Sunday, reckoning
backward from Quadragesima 
to Quinquagesima, and thence to
Sexagesima, and so to Septua&shy;
gesima.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sexennial(a)">Sexennial (<etym lang="la">sexennis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is six years old, or of six years
standing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextant(n)">Sextant (<etym lang="la">sextans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a coin
less then that called Quadrant,
by the third part; a certain
poise or weight being two
ounces, by some called Obolus,
by others the sixth part of any
measure, sum or quantity that 


</page>

<page sig="nn4v">
is divided into twelve parts;
also two inches. Jun. The 
sixth part of Iugerum. Varr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextantary(a)"><emend err="Sextanrary">Sextantary</emend> (<etym lang="la">sextantarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to the meas&shy;
sure, quantity or weight of
Sextant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextary(n)">Sextary (<etym lang="la">sextarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a mea&shy;
sure, whereby all other may
be made, after Bud&aelig;us, and
certain tryal by weight and
measure. The Roman Sextary 
contains of Wine or Wheat,
two pound Roman, that is
four and twenty ounces, a
pound and an half haverdu&shy;
poise weight, less then the Pa&shy;
ris pint by eight ounces. You
may try it, following Glare&shy;
ans rule, by making a measure
four inches long, by square
three inches deep, and as
many broad, which is the true
Sextary; according to this
account, it is just our pint and
a half; for in our Wine pint
are but sixteen ounces. Phy&shy;
sitians assign but eighteen
ounces, or at the most twenty
to Sextarius, and then it is
but two or four ounces more
then our pint. 

Sextarius, after Geo. Agrico&shy;
la, contains two Hemin&aelig;, one
pound measure and eight
ounces, that is twenty ounces
or inch measures.

Sextarius is in weight of
Oyl sixteen ounces, five
drams, and one scruple; of
Wine eighteen ounces and an
half, two Siliquies, two grains
and two third parts of a grain.
Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sext(n)">Sexte,</form> <xpln lang="en">a part of the Ca&shy;
non Law, added to the de&shy;
cretals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sexton(n)">Sexten,</form> <xpln lang="en">seems to be cor&shy;
rupt from Sacristian, which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextry(n)">Sextery.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Sacristy</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextile month(n)" lexeme="sextilian month(n)">Sextile orSextilian
moneth (<etym lang="la">Sextilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the moneth
of August, so called because it
is the sixth from March,
which was the first moneth
of the year with the Romans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shackbolt(n)" lexeme="shackle(n)">Shackbolt orShackle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
prisoners Bolt, a Fetter or
Give.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextula(n)">Sextule (<etym lang="la">sextula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the sixth
part of an ounce, that is a
dram and scruple; also a mea&shy;
sure of Land.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sextuple(n)">Sextuple (<etym lang="la">sextuplus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">six&shy;
fold, or that contains, or is
made of the number six. A
time in Musick, containing
six Crothets to a Bar, appro&shy;
priated chiefly to Sarabands.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shallop(n)">Shallop (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Schalupe</etym>, or Lat. <etym lang="la">Scapha</etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Boat, or perhaps from Shal&shy;
low-up, because being a small
Vessel, it goes up into shallow
places) a kinde of small Boat
so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chamois(n)">Shamois orChamois,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kinde of wilde Goat, whose
skin, being rightly dressed,
makes our true Shamois Lea&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shaftment(n)">Shafment,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a kinde of
measure used in some parts of
England, and is the breadth
of a mans hand, and the
length of the thumb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shamsheer(n)">Shamsheer,</form> <xpln lang="en">the usual
Sword among the Persians, 


</page>

<page sig="nn5r">
it is not unlike the Turkish
Scymitar ; For (Mr. Herb. in
his Travels saith) it is crook&shy;
ed like a Crescent, and sharp
as a Razor. Fol.147.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sash(n)">Shash</form> <xpln lang="en">is the whole peece
(be it long or short) of fine
linnen, of which the Tur&shy;
bant is made, but the name of
the Linnen is Telbent ; whence
we falsly call that which a
Turk wears about his head a
Turbant, whereas the true
name is Saruck, and the
Turks themselves so call it;
it comes from Sarnack, which
signifies to joyn about, or to
swathe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shaw(n)">Shaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Persian 
Tongue, is a King; and Pot&shy;
shaw an Emperor. Herb Tr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shekel(n)">Shekle.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Sicle</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sherbet(n)">Sherbet orServet (in the
Persian tongue, it signifies
pleasant liquor)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a kinde of
drink in great request, both
in Turky and Persia, and is
compounded of joyce of Le&shy;
mons, Sugar, Amber, and
other ingredients; another
sort of it is made of Violets,
Honey, juyce of Raisons, and
the like. 

Others say Sherbet is an A&shy;
rabian word, and signifies
drink in general.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sherry sack(n)">Sherry-Sack,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called
from Zeres, a Sea Town of
Corduba in Spain, where that
kinde of Sack is made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skene(n)">Skeyn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of long
knife, or short sword, anci&shy;
ently, and still used by the
Irish-Kernes . Antiq. Hibernic&aelig;,
p.57.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shibboleth(n)">Shibboleth orSchibbo&shy;
leth (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">by the pronoun&shy;
ciation of this word, the Ga&shy;
laadites (who fought for, and
under Jepthe, the Judge of
Israel) discovered the Ephra&shy;
mites to be their enemies, and
not Galaadites, as they pre&shy;
tended to be for their safety;
for when they were taken by
the true Galaadites at the pas&shy;
sages over Jordan, (through
which they endeavored to
escape) they could not pro&shy;
nounce Shibboleth or Schibbo&shy;
leth, but Sibboleth, which
cost two and forty thou&shy;
sand of them their lives at
that time. Judges, cap.12.
Hence the word is usually
<emend err="taxen">taken</emend> for a word of tryal, to
discern Citizens from Aliens,
Friends from Foes: It signi&shy;
fies Spica, or an Ear of Corn.
See <xref>Pichigni</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shilo(pn)" lexeme="shiloh(pn)">Shilo orShiloh (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class> 
<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">missus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is mentioned in the
Prophecy of Jacob, where it
is said, The Scepter shall not de&shy;
part from Judah, till Shiloh
come ; that is, till our Saviour
come. (Gen.49. 10.) The
word signifies a Prosperer or
Safe-maker.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waters of Shiloah(n)">Waters of Shiloah.</form> <xpln lang="en">Seein <xref>
Waters</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shingle(n)">Shingle (from the Teut.
<etym lang="gr">Schindel</etym>, and that from
 <etym lang="la">Scindo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Slate or Lath of
Wood to cover houses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shingles(n)">Shingles (<etym lang="la">&agrave; cingendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
disease about the Brest, Belly,
or Back, the place affected,
looking red and increasing 


</page>

<page sig="nn5v">
circlewise more and more; It
is chiefly cured with Cats
blood; if it go round the bo&shy;
dy, it kils.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shoud(n)">Shoud,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Ju&shy;
stice of Peace among the
Turks.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrew(n)">Shrew,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Field&shy;
Mouse, which if he go over a
beasts back, will make him
lame in the Chine; and if he
bite, the beast swels to the
heart, and dyes. Gesn. From
hence came our English
phrase, I beshrew thee, when
we wish ill; and we call a
curst woman, a Shrew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrift(n)" lexeme="shriving(n)">Shrift orShriving (Sax.)
perhaps from <etym lang="la">Scrinium</etym>, <term lang="la">quasi</term>
<term lang="la">revelare peccata, ab intimo scri&shy;
nio</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was anciently taken for
auricular Confession.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shrovetide(pn)">Shrove tide, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">from the Sax.</class>
<etym lang="sx">Shrive</etym> or<etym lang="sx">Shrift</etym>, and the
<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class><etym lang="bl">Tyde</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">tempus</etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a time of
shriving or confessing sins;
For about that time the Ro&shy;
man Catholicks use to confess
their sins and receive the Bles&shy;
sed Sacrament, to the end they
may the more religiously ob&shy;
serve the holy time of Lent,
then immediately ensuing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrine(n)">Shrine (<etym lang="la">scrinium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
which contained the body of
a Saint, or the place where
such a body was buried or in&shy;
tombed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sialoquent(a)">Sialoquent(<etym lang="la">sialoquus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that spits much in his
speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sibilate(v)">Sibilate (<etym lang="la">sibilo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to whistle
or hiss. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sybil(pn)">Sibils.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref target="Sybil"> See Sybils</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siccaneous(a)">Siccaneous (<etym lang="la">siccaneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
dry of nature, that has no
Rivers or Springs to water
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siccifical(a)">Siccifical (<etym lang="la">siccificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath power to make
dry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siccity(n)">Siccity (<etym lang="la">siccitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">dryness,
drouth, lack of sap or moi&shy;
sture, barrenness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sicilian vespers(n)">Sicilian vesperas.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See
Vesperas</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shekel(n)">Sicle orShekel (<etym lang="la">siclus</etym>, 
from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">Shakal</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">li&shy;
bravit</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">as well a kind of coin
both of Silver and Gold, as
a weight among the Jews;
on the one side of the silver
Shekel was carved a pot with
Manna, and this Inscription
in Hebrew, The Shekel of Is&shy;
rael, on the other Aarons
Rod, with this, Holy Jerusa&shy;
lem ; this (which was called
the Holy Shekel was worth
of our money about two
shillings four pence; the com&shy;
mon Shekel half so much,
in weight half an ounce.
Exod.30.13. Gen.23.15,16.
And from thence comes our
word Skele or Skale (scale)
to weigh with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sidelayes(n)">Sidelayes,</form> <xpln lang="en">A term of
Hunters, and is when Dogs
are laid in the way to be
let slip at a Deer, as he passes
by.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "side," n.1.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sideman(n)">Side-men</form> <xpln lang="en"> alias Quest&shy;
men, those that are yearly
chosen according to the
Custome of every Parish, to
assist the Churchwardens in
the inquiry and presenting 


</page>

<page sig="nn6r">
such offenders to the Ordina&shy;
ry, as are punishable in the
Court Christian. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

Br.</xpln></wordentry>

</form> <xpln lang="en">of or like stars, shining, bright;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siderite(n)">Siderite (<etym lang="la">siderites</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an iron&shy;

magine) has power to set men
at variance; Also the Load&shy;
stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigalion(pn)">Sigalion,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Image in
&AElig;gypt, that by pressing his
fingers on his lips, seem&shy;
ed to command silence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sigiliar(a)">Sigiliar (<etym lang="la">sigillaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a Seal or
Mark.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sigillative(a)">Sigillative (<etym lang="la">sigillatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sealable, that is apt, or hath
strength to seal, or mark;
made of wax: Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigismund(pn)">Sigismund ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">victorious, peace, or victory
with peace; That Sig sig&shy; 
nifies victory, Alfric, Dasi&shy;
podius and Luther all agree.
yet Hadr. Junius turns it victo&shy;
rious or prevailing speech.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sigle(n)">Sigles (<etym lang="la">sigl&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">notes,
breviatures, Letters set for
words. As S. P. D. for <term lang="la">Salu&shy;
tem plurimam dicit</term>, &amp;c. Mr.
Selden.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signacle(n)">Signacle (<etym lang="la">signaculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a sign, seal, mark or charact&shy;
er.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signatory(n)">Signatory (<etym lang="la">signatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is used or serves to
seal withall; As <term lang="la">Annulus
signatorius</term>, a Seal-Ring, a Sig&shy;
ner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signature(n)">Signature (<etym lang="la">signatura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a signing, subscribing, a sign
manual, ones hand or mark
set to a writing, a signing
of a Notary. Among Prin&shy;
ters  the mark or letter they
set at the bottom of every
sheet printed, as A, B, C,
&amp;c. to tell their Quires by,
and distinguish one sheet
from another, is called the
Signature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signaturist(n)">Signaturist,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
sealeth, marketh, brandeth,
&amp;c. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signiferous(a)">Signiferous (<etym lang="la">signifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears a sign, Standard or
Image.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="silentiary(n)">Silentiary (<etym lang="la">silentiari&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gentleman Usher, who
sees good rule and quietness
kept.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cilery(n)">Silery orCilery,</form> <xpln lang="en">Dra&shy;
pery wrought on the heads
of Pillars and Posts, and
made as cloth or leaves turn&shy;
ing divers wayes; it comes
from Siler. <expan type="">id est</expan> an Osier or
smal withe, because the
work of Silery is made on
the tops of Pillars, as Osiers
or smal withes. Min. <xref> See
Drapery</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siliceous(a)">Siliceous (<etym lang="la">siliceus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
pertaining to flint, flinty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllogism(n)">Sillogism</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Syllo&shy;
gism</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="nn6v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sillographer(n)">Sillographer (<etym lang="la">sillogra&shy;
phus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a writer of scoffs, taunts
and revilings; Such was
Timon.</xpln></wordentry>

strous</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Silurist(pn)">Silurist (from <etym lang="la">Silures</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
