South wales.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cymbal(n)">Simbal.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Cimbal</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="similar part(n)" lexeme="similary part(n)">Similar
or Similary 
parts (<etym lang="la">partes
similares</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">parts (of the body)
of one substance, and which
(though divided) retain the
name of the whole. And Dis&shy;
similary parts differ from the
whole, as Nerves, Bones,
and the like. See <xref>Dissimi&shy;
lary</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symmetry(n)">Simmetry.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Symme&shy;
try</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Simon(pn)">Simon (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">obedient,
listning. Philo.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simony(n)">Simony (<etym lang="la">simonia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
buying or selling of Church
Livings, or other Spiritual
things for money. It first
took denomination from Si&shy;
mon Magus, a Sorcerer of Sa&shy;
maria, who offered money to
the Apostles, that he might
have power to give the Holy
Ghost, to any he should lay
lay his hands on, for which at&shy;
tempt he was sharply reproved
by St. Peter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simoniac(n)">Simoniakes (from Simon
Magus)</form> <xpln lang="en">those that buy or sell
Church Livings or other Spi&shy;
ritual things. It is also a
general name for all Here&shy;
ticks, because (as Saint 
Iren&aelig;us saith) Simon was the
Father of them all.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simoniacal(a)">Simoniacal (from <etym lang="la">Simo&shy;
nia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or pertaining to Si&shy;
mony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simous(a)">Simous <etym lang="la">(simus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">flat nosed.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simplist(n)">Simplist (<etym lang="la">simplisia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Herbalist; one that under&shy;
stands or professes to under&shy;
stand the nature of Simples,
Plants, and Drugs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simulacre(n)">Simulacre (<etym lang="la">simulacrum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an Image of a man or woman,
the proportion of any thing,
the shadow, figure, sem&shy;
blance or pattern of a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simulation(n)">Simulation (<etym lang="la">simulatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
faigning, a counterfeiting, a
making of resemblance, a
dissembling, a colour or pre&shy;
tence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="simultaneous(a)">Simultaneous (from <etym lang="la">si&shy;
multas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is privily displea&shy;
sed, or hates with dissem&shy;
bling of countenance. Le Str.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sina(pn)">Sina,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mountain in A&shy;
rabia, where the Law of
God was given to Moses;
called also Horeb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sinapism(n)">Sinapism (<etym lang="la"> sinapismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Medicine, Oyntment, or Salve,
made of Mustard, serving to
raise blisters or wheals upon
the skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syndic(a)">Sindic.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Syndic</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

Linnen; as Cambrick, Lawn,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<page sig="nn7r">
hand, unlucky, unfortunate,
contrary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sinisterity(n)">Sinisterity (<etym lang="la">sinisteritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
unhandsomness, froward&shy; 
ness, lack of grace in doing a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sinon(pn)">Sinon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a perfidious Gre&shy;
cian that betrayed Troy, &amp;c.
from whence all perfidious
men may be called Si&shy;
nons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sinoper(n)">Sinoper (<etym lang="la">sinopis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a red

dle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sinopical(a)">Sinopical <etym lang="la"> sinopicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scion(n)">Sion.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Scion</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siphac(n)">Siphack,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an Arabick
word used by Anatomists,
and signifies the inner rim
of the belly, which is joyn&shy;
ed to the Cawl, where
the Intrailes are covered.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="si quis(n)">Siquis,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a little Bill
set up in some open place up&shy;
on a Post or Wall; and is so
called, because it usually be&shy;
gins with <term lang="la">Si quis</term>. <expan type="">id est</expan> If any
one (viz.) hath found, that
which is mentioned herein
to be lost, let him bring it to
such a place, and he shall
be thus rewarded for his
pains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sir(n)">Sir,</form> <xpln lang="en">a title of dignity
given to Baronets and
Knights; and not onely at&shy;
tributed to Kings, but to all
Gentlemen in discourse;
some derive it <class type="etymlang" lang="he">from the Hebr.</class> 
 <etym lang="he">Sar. princeps</etym>, others <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&kappa;&#x03cd;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Dominus</term>, o&shy;
thers <class type="etymlang" lang="br">from the Brit</class>.<etym lang="br">Syr</etym> or 
<etym lang="br">Syre</etym>, <term lang="la">Domine</term>; others <class type="etymlang" lang="it">from
the Ital.</class> <etym lang="it">Sere</etym>, or <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Sire</etym>.
And Stephanus deduces it
from Cyrus the Persian word,
for a Lord, Ruler, or great
Prince.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siren(n)">Sirens (Sirenes <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the
Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&#x03cd;&rho;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">attrahere</term>.) See 
<xref lexeme="mermaid">Mermaides</xref>. 

</form> <xpln lang="en">Alluring and tempting wo&shy;
men, are called Sirens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sirenical(a)">Sirenical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to Sirens, attractive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sirenize(v)">Sirenize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to play the
Siren, to attract or allure,
as Sirens  doe with sing&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sirius(pn)">Sirius,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Dog-Star,
or Star called Canicula, at
whose rising the Dog-days
always begin, and from
which the Canicular or Dog&shy;
dayes tooke denominati&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sirocco(n)">Sirocco ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a South&shy;
East wind, thought to be
hurtful and infectious in
Italy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sisyphus(pn)">Sisyphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a great Rob&shy;
ber of Attica, slain by The&shy;
seus. Poets say, he rouls a
stone to the top of a Hill,
which still tumbles back
again, and so makes his
labor endless, &amp;c. Hence
to roul the stone of Sisy&shy;
phus, is taken for any
hard or insuperable la&shy;
bor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sitarch(n)">Sitark <etym lang="la">(sitarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that hath the office to pro&shy;
vide Corn, and Victuals suf&shy;
ficient.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seville(pn)">Sivil orSevil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the

from whence we have our
Sevil Oranges, and therefore
so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sixain(n)">Sixain ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a sixth,
sixth part, the proportion of
six; Hence a Poem or Stanza
of six verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="size(n)">Size,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a portion of
bread or drink, <expan type="">id est</expan> a farth&shy;
thing, which Schollars in Cam&shy;
bridge have at the Buttery,
it is noted with the letter S.
As in Oxford with the letter Q
for half a farthing, and Qa.
for a farthing; And where&shy;
as they say in Oxford, to Bat&shy;
tle in the Buttery book. <expan type="">id est</expan> to
<emend err="to"></emend> set down on their names,
what they take in Bread,
Drink, Butter, Cheese, &amp;c.
So in Cambridge they say to
size, <expan type="">id est</expan> to set down their
quantum, how much they
take on their names in the
Buttery book. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skink(n)">Skink,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland a kind

and Sinews of Beef long
boiled. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skinker(n)">Skinker (from the Dutch

ler or Cup-bearer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slay(n)">Slay (from the Teut.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slockster(n)">Slockster ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class> <etym lang="bl">Slocker</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

way mens servants. <xref> See Pla&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slot(n)">Slot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term of hunting,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slough(n)">Slough,</form> <xpln lang="en">a damp, such
as usually happens in Cole&shy;
pits; also a deep sinking mud&shy;
dy place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smaragdine(n)">Smaragdine (<etym lang="la">smaragdi&shy;
nus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to the
precious stone called a Sma&shy;
ragd or Emerald ; green, as an
Emerald.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Smectymnuans(pn)">Smectymnuans,</form> <xpln lang="en">about
the beginning of the long
Parliament in the year 1641,
five Ministers wrote a book
against Episcopacy and the
Common Prayer, in behalf
of the Presbyterian Govern&shy;
ment, to which they all sub&shy;
scribed their names, being
Steven Marshal, Edm. Calamy,
Tho. Young, Mathew Newco&shy;
men, and Will. Spurstow;
the first letters whereof
make this word, Smectym&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="nn8r">
nuus; And from thence
they were called Smectym&shy;
nuans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smegmatic(a)">Smegmatick (<etym lang="la">smegmati&shy;
cus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath the power or
strength to scoure or cleanse,
as soap.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smeth(n)" lexeme="smoothery(n)">Smeth orSmoothery;</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snaphaunce(n)">Snaphaunse,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fire-lock,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="socage(n)">Soccage (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Soc</etym>.
<expan type="">id est</expan> a Coulter or plough-share)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a tenure of lands by or
for certain inferior or hus&shy;
bandly services to be per&shy;
formed to the Lord of the
Fee. See Institutes of <emend err="Com">Com&shy;</emend>
mon Law, 31.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Socinians(pn)">Socinians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a late Sect, be&shy;
gun by L&aelig;hus Socinus the
Uncle, and made up by Fau&shy;
stus Socinus of Sienna, his
Nephew, who first dispersed
his Errors in Polonia, Tran&shy;
sylvania, and Sarmatia, about
the year 1555. They deny the
eternal Divinity of the second
Person of the Blessed Trinity,
with other gross Errors. See
Mr. Chewneys Anti-Socinia&shy;
nism.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="socome(n)">Socome,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old Law
word, signifying the custom
of grinding at the Lords
Mill; and there is <emend err="Bond-So">Bond-So&shy;
come</emend>, where the Tennants
are bound to it; and Love&shy;
Socome, where they doe it 
freely out of love to their
Land-lord.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="socord(n)">Socord (<etym lang="la">socordia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Lus&shy;
kishness, sloathfulness, neg&shy;
ligence, idleness, sottish&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Socratic(a)">Socratick (<etym lang="la">socraticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to that excellent
and wise Philosopher Socra&shy;
tes; Hence, wise, prudent,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sodality(n)">Sodality (<etym lang="la">sodalitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sodomy(n)">Sodomy (<etym lang="la">sodomia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bug&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solary(n)">Solary (<etym lang="la">solarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sun&shy;
Dyal; Also a yearly Pension
paid to the Prince, to live
out of common business; or
the rent that one pays yearly
for an house that is built up&shy;
on the soil or land of the
Commonwealth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soldado(n)">Soldado (Span. <etym lang="fr">Soldat</etym>. Fr.)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Souldier, one that follows
the wars. <etym lang="sp">Soldado bor&aacute;do</etym>, a
cashiered Souldier; a Soul&shy;
dier blotted out of the Muster
Roll; derived from the Brit.
wordSawdiwr, <expan type="">id est</expan> miles, and
that fromSawd, which sig&shy;
nifies <term lang="la">pr&aelig;lium</term> or <term lang="la">bellum</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soldan(n)">Soldan,</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Sultan</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soldier(n)">Soldures (<etym lang="la">soldurii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">were
(as C&aelig;sar saith) in the Gaulish
language, such kind of men,
as destined and vowed them&shy;
selves to the amity of any, to
take part in all their good and
bad fortunes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soleated(a)">Soleated (<etym lang="la">soleatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">shod,
as horses are, or that wears
pattens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solecism(n)">Solecism (<etym lang="la">sol&oelig;cismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
false manner of speaking, con&shy;
trary to the rules of Gram&shy;
mer, incongruity; Any thing
done out of order, or con&shy;
trary to rule, may be tear&shy;
med a Solecism. The people
of Pamphilia were called Soli,
from whose barbarous kind
of speaking, came this word
Sol&aelig;cism.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solecismical(a)">Solecismical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining
to a Solecism, incongru&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solid(n)">Solides,</form> <xpln lang="en">Five regular bo&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Solent(pn)">Solent,</form> <xpln lang="en">the ancient name
of that part of the Sea, which
divides the Isle of Wight
from our main Land in
Hamshire. Bedes Hist. pag.
366.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solifidian(a)">Solifidian<etym lang="la"> (from sola fi&shy;
des</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that holds faith onely
(without works) necessary
to salvation, or one that de&shy;
pends upon faith alone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soliloquy(n)">Soliloquy (<etym lang="la">soliloquium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
talk alone as of one with one,
or one with himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soliped(n)">Soliped (from <etym lang="la">solidus</etym> and
<etym lang="la">pes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath a whole or
sound foot, not cloven nor
broken, such is that of a
Horse. If from <term lang="la">solus</term> and
<term lang="la">pes</term>, then it signifies, one
footed, or that hath but one
foot: Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solistim(n)">Solistim (<etym lang="la">solistimum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
kind of dancing among the
Augures, or a Divination
taken by falling of the bread
on the ground, which was
given to Chickens.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solitaneous(a)">Solitaneous (<etym lang="la">solitaneus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
solitary, single, alone, without
company.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solivagant(a)">Solivagant (<etym lang="la">solivagus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that goes here and there a&shy;
lone, and flies company, wan&shy;
dring all alone, solitary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solievation(n)"><emend err="Sollevation" source="errata">Solievation</emend> (from the
Span. <etym lang="sp"><emend err="Solvare" source="errata">Solvar</emend></etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">sublevare</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

or assisting. Lustr. Ludov.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Solon(pn)">Solon,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the seven
wisemen of Greece. The other
six were Chilo, Cleobulus, Tha&shy;
les, Bius, Pittacus, and Pe&shy;
riander.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solstice(n)">Solstice (<etym lang="la">solstitium</etym>, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
<etym lang="la">Solis statio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Sun-stead or
stay, when it can neither go
higher nor lower, which is
in Summer about mid Iune,
when the days are at the<emend err="long"> long&shy;</emend>
est, and in Winter about mid
December, when they are at
the shortest; at which time
the Sun comes to the Tropick
of Capricorn, and in Iune to
that of Cancer . It is most
commonly taken for Midsum&shy;
mer ; and Mid-winter is term&shy;
ed Bruma.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solstitial(a)">Solstitial (<etym lang="la">solstitialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to the Solstice, 
or stay of the Sun. Also
that continues but a little
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soluble(a)">Soluble (<etym lang="la">solubilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">which
may be unloosed or un&shy;
bound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sontage(n)">Sontage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a tax of forty
shillings, laid upon every
Knights Fee. Stowe, pag.
284.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sontic(a)">Sontick (<etym lang="la">sonticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">noy&shy;
some, hurtful. The Sontick
disease (<term lang="la">Morbus Sonticus</term>) a
continual and extream sick&shy;
ness, that hangs long upon a
man, and is ended within no
certain time; and whereby
we are disabled to perform
our necessary business. The
Falling Evil is such a disease. 
Sigonius infers, That every
disease which hinders us in
the performance of our busi&shy;
nesses, is termed Sonticus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sophia(pn)">Sophia ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Wisdom;
a name peculiarly applied by
the Primitive Christians to
our most Blessed Saviour,
who is the Wisdom of his Fa&shy;
ther, by whom all things
were made; and therefore
some godly persons do more
then dislike the communica&shy;
ting it to any other. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sophy(pn)">Sophy,</form> <xpln lang="en">the great Lord
or King of Persia, so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sophism(n)">Sophism (<etym lang="la">Sophisma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a 


</page>

<page sig="oo1v">
crafty or deceitful sentence;
an Oration or Sentence,
seeming to be true, but false
indeed; a cavil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sophist(n)" lexeme="sophister(n)">Sophist 
or Sophister 
 (<etym lang="la">Sophista</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">
He that professeth Philosophy
for lucre or vain-glory; a
deceiver, under an eloquent
or crafty speaking; a cunning
or cavilling disputer, who
will make a false matter seem
true.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sophisticate(v)">Sophisticate (<etym lang="la">sophistico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
adulterate or falsifie, to
make counterfeit or deceit&shy;
ful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sophistry(n)">Sophistry (<etym lang="la">sophistria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the art of quaint beguiling
or circumvention, by words
or false Arguments, called al&shy;
so Lulliin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sorbonists(pn)">Sorbonists,</form> <xpln lang="en">are those

Divinity of the Colledge of
Sorbon in Paris; which took
Denomination from one Ro&shy;
bert de Sorbonne, who was
one of the Almoners and
Preachers of St. Lewis the 
Ninth, King of France, and
the Donor and Instituter of
this Colledge, about the
year One thousand two hun&shy;
dred sixty and four. 2 Part
Tr.&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sorites(n)">Sorites ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of
Argument consisting of di&shy;
vers propositions, in which
the Predicate of the former,
is still made the subject of
the later, till in conclusion
the last Predicate be attri&shy;
buted to the first subject:
As Thomas is a man; a man
is an Animal; an Animal is a
Body; a Body is a Substance;
therefore Thomas is a Sub&shy;
stance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soritical(a)">Soritical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to
such an Argument:</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sororiant virgin(n)">Sororiant Virgin (<etym lang="la">Virgo

<page sig="oo2r">
Sororians</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a yong maid,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spahi(n)">Spahies orSpachies,</form> <xpln lang="en">

at once, with Bowe, Mace,

tar. Sands.</xpln></wordentry>

which is a Convulsion, shrink&shy;
ing or plucking up of the Si&shy;
news, arising either of too
much fulness, or over-much
emptiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spat(n)" lexeme="spatule(n)">Spat,Spathule orSpa&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spatiate(v)">Spatiate (<etym lang="la">spatior</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to walk 


</page>

<page sig="oo2v">
abroad, to travel, to wander,
to go jetting up and down.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="species(n)">Species ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure,
image, form, or shape, like&shy;
ness, semblance, outward face
or shew, &amp;c. the different
kinde of any thing. With
Grammarians, Species is the
accident of a word, as Pri&shy;
mitive or Derivative . With
Logitians it is the second of
the five Predicables . See <xref>Ge&shy;
nus</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="specifical(a)">Specifical (<etym lang="la">specificus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">spe&shy;

pearance, honorable in

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spectre(n)">Spectre (<etym lang="la">spectrum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an
apparition or imagination of
a substance without a body,
which presents it self sensibly
to men against the order and
course of nature; a Ghost,
a Spirit, a fantasie, a vision.
If you would know the seve&shy;
ral kinds and more particulars
of these Specters, read a Trea&shy;
tise of them, printed Anno
1605.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="specular(n)">Specular (<etym lang="la">specularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any

the better, belonging to see&shy;
ing or spying, to Spectacles or
glass windows.</xpln></wordentry>

diligently; to behold and

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sphacelism(n)">Sphacelism (<etym lang="la">sphacelis&shy;
mus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an ulcer eating in the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sphere(n)">Sphere (<etym lang="la">sph&aelig;ra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fi&shy;
gure in all parts equally
round, a Circle, a Globe, a
Bowle or any thing that is
round. 

The Sphere of the World
consists of Ten Circles, the
&AElig;quinoctial, the Zodiake, the
Two Colures, the Horizon,
the Meridian, the Two Tro&shy;
picks, and the two Polar Cir&shy;
cles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spherable(a)">Spherable (<etym lang="la">sph&aelig;rabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be made round like
a Sphere.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spherical(a)">Spherical (<etym lang="la">sph&aelig;ricus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
round like a Sphere, Orbicu&shy;
lar, Globe-like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spheromachy(n)">Spheromachy (<etym lang="la">sph&aelig;roma&shy;
chia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">playing at Tennis, or
Bowling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sphinx(n)">Sphinx ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Indi&shy;
an, and &AElig;thiopian Beast,
rough bodied like an Ape
(of the kind whereof he is)
yet hairless between his
Neck and Breast, round, but
out-faced, and Breasted like
a Woman, his unarticulate
voyce like that of a hasty
speaker, more gentle and
tameable then an ordinary
Ape, yet fierce by nature,
and revengeful, when he is
hurt; having eaten meat e&shy;
nough, hee reserves his
Chaps full to feed on when
he feels himself hungry a&shy;
gain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiciferous(a)">Spiciferous (<etym lang="la">spicifer</etym>) </form> 
<xpln lang="en">that beareth ears of Corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spicilegy(n)">Spicilegy (<etym lang="la">spicilegium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
gathering ears of corn, glean&shy;
ing or leising corn. <expan type="">Lord</expan> Bac.
Advan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiculator(n)">Spiculator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Archer, or Spear-man of
a Guard; Some take it
for a Tormenter or Hang&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spine(n)">Spine (<etym lang="la">spina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a thorn, the
sting of a Bee, a prickle; Al&shy;
so the back-bone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spinal(a)">Spinal (<etym lang="la">spinalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
pertaining to the Chine, or
Back-bone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiniferous(a)">Spiniferous (<etym lang="la">spinifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
beareth prickles, or thornes,
thorny.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spinosity(n)">Spinosity (<etym lang="la">spinositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">thor&shy;
niness, fulness of prickles, dif&shy;
ficulty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spinster(n)">Spinster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term or ad&shy;
dition in our Law-Dialect,
added in Obligations, Evi&shy;
dences and Writings, to un&shy;
married Women, as it were,
calling them Spinners ; And
this onely addition is given
to all unmarried women, from
the Viscounts Daughter
downward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spintrian(a)">Spintrian (from <etym lang="la">Spin&shy;
tri&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to those
that seek out, or invent
new and monstrous actions
of lust. Tacitus annal lib.6 &amp;
Rel. Med.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiracle(n)">Spiracle (<etym lang="la">spiraculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
breathing hole, a hole out of
which breath, air, smoak, or
wind issues, a damp hole.
Lo Bac.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="oo3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiral(a)">Spiral<etym lang="la"> (from spira</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cir&shy;
cular, turning round, wind&shy;
ing about. Sir H. Wotton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiration(n)">Spiration (<etym lang="la">spiratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
breath or breathing. In Di&shy;
vinity it is a breathing or im&shy;
pulse of the Will, by which it
expresseth its affection. The
Holy Ghost proceeds from
the Father, and the Son, as
from one onely source, and
not as made or created, nor
as begotten, but produced
through the will, by an ineffa&shy;
ble way, and this Divines
tearm Spiration. Tour. Cat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spirarch(n)">Spirarck (<etym lang="la">spirarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Captain in a foreward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiritualty of a bishop(n)">Spiritualties of a Bi&shy;
shop (<etym lang="la">Spiritualia Episcopi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">were
those profits which he recei&shy;
ved, as a Bishop, and not as
a Baron of the Parliament.
Stawnf. pl. Cor. fol.132. Such
were the duties of his Visita&shy;
tion, his Benefit growing from
ordering and instituting
Priests, Prestation money,
that <term lang="la"> Subsidium charitativum</term>,
which upon reasonable cause
he might require of his Cler&shy;
gy. Joannes Gregorius de Bene&shy;
ficiis, cap.6. num.9. And the
benefit of his Jurisdiction.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spiss(a)">Spiss (<etym lang="la">spissus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">thick, slow,
and long, gross, massive,
firm, hard, and sound, stand&shy;
ing thick and close together,
full of. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spissity(n)" lexeme="spissitude(n)">Spissity <etym lang="la">spissitas</etym>
Spissitude <etym lang="la">spissitudo</etym> 
</form> <xpln lang="en">thickness, grossness. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spitter(n)">Spitter,</form> <xpln lang="en">a red Male Deer 
of one year old, whose Horns
begin to grow up sharp Spit&shy;
wise, called also a Brocket
from broach, the same with a
Spit. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spittle(n)" lexeme="spittle-house(n)">Spittle orSpittle-house 
<class type="etymlang" lang="it">from the Ital.</class> <etym lang="it"> Sped&aacute;le</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Teut.</class>
<etym lang="gr">Spital</etym>, or it may be con&shy;
tracted from Hospital;</form> <xpln lang="en">for it
hath one and the same signifi&shy;
cation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splendent(a)" lexeme="splendid(a)">Splendent <etym lang="la">splendens</etym>
Splendid <etym lang="la">splendidus</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">
bright, clear, shining, fa&shy;
mous, notable, excellent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spleen(n)">Splene</form> <xpln lang="en">(splen) the Milt
of Man or Beast, which is
like a long narrow Tongue,
lying under the short ribs on
the left-side, and hath this
office of nature, to purge the
Liver of superfluous Melan&shy;
cholick blood; sometime it
signifies anger or choler.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splendor(n)">Splendor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">clear&shy;
ness, brightness, light, beau&shy;
ty, elegancy, glory.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splenetic(a)">Splenetick (<etym lang="la">spleneticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
sick in the Splene, or trou&shy;
bled with the Splene, that 
hath a great Splene; also cho&shy;
lerick or angry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spoliation(n)">Spoliation (<etym lang="la">spoliatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
robbing, spoiling or taking
away. If any difference had
been between two Parsons, or
two Incumbents, claiming
under one Patron, and the
right of Patronage not in
question; this was to be de&shy;
cided in the Spiritual Court,
and was called Spoliation.
Nat. Br.36,37.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="oo4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spondelion(n)">Spondalion ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Himn

sung to procure and settle the
favor of the Gods, whilst the
Incense was a burning</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sponge(n)">Sponge (<etym lang="la">spongia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is well
known, and is between the
nature of an Animal, and a
Plant; it grows under the
Sea-rocks of the Isle Sa&shy;
mos, and not elswhere in the
world. Sir H B.</xpln></wordentry>

small holes, or eyes like a
Spunge, light or pure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spontal(a)" lexeme="spontance(a)" lexeme="spontaneous(a)"><emend err="Spontal" source="errata">Spontane</emend> <etym lang="la">spontalis</etym>

us</etym>

</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spontaneity(n)">Spontaneity,</form> <xpln lang="en">the freeness
or natural unconstrainedness
of an action, done without
<emend err=" itherconstraint">either constraint</emend> or choice; as 
an Herb grows, or an Animal
eats when he is hungry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spouse(n)">Spouse (<etym lang="la">sponsa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a woman

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spright(n)">Sprights,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of short
Arrows, (formerly used for
Sea-fight) without any other
heads, save wood sharpned,
which were discharged out of
Muskets, and would pierce
through the sides of Ships,
where a bullet would not.
Nat. Hist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spring tide(n)">Spring-tides.</form> <xpln lang="en">As there are
every day two tides; so every
moneth two courses of great
tides and small tides; For seven
days about the change of the
Moon, are the great or Spring&shy;
tides, and the next ensuing
seven days are the small or
Neap-tides ; then at Full Moon
are the Spring-tides again, and
all the last quarter Neap-tides ;
which course of the Sea is
thus monethly renewed for
ever; save that, some extra&shy;
ordinary Spring-tides some
times happen in the Spring 
and Autumn, and sometimes
after plenty of Rain, or rage
of Weather, &amp;c. And in
Neap-tides the water is never 


</page>

<page sig="oo4v">
so high, nor so low, as in
Spring-tides.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="springal(n)">Springal (from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Springael</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a yong-man, or
a stripling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spume(n)">Spume (<etym lang="la">spuma</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">foam,
froth, scum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spumid(a)">Spumid (<etym lang="la">spumidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">frothy

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spumiferous(a)">Spumiferous (<etym lang="la">spumifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears foam, froth or scum.</xpln></wordentry>

that spits often or much. Sir
H. W.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squadron(n)">Squadron (from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Squadra</etym>, or Fr. <etym lang="fr">Esquadron</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
certain number of Soldiers
ranged into a square Body or
Battaillon . This word is most
commonly appropriated to
Horsmen, (Battaillon to Foot&shy;
men) and sometime both to
Horse and Foot.<xref> See Brigade</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squalid(a)">Squalid (<etym lang="la">squalidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">filthy,
sluttish, foul, il-favored, cau&shy;
sing one to abhor the sight
of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squalor(n)">Squalor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">filthiness,
sluttishness, uncleanness, de&shy;
formity of any thing for want
of trimming, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squamigerous(a)">Squamigerous (<etym lang="la">squami&shy;
ger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath or beareth
scales, scaly.</xpln></wordentry>

drate</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squinant(n)">Squinant (<etym lang="la">squinanthum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the sweet rush, which is very
medicinable: Camels meat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squinancy(n)">Squinancy (<etym lang="la">squinantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a swelling disease in the

ficulty in breathing; the
Squinty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stabulate(v)">Stabulate (<etym lang="la">stabulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
stand or be as Cattle in a Sta&shy;
ble or Stall, to be housed as
Beasts are, to keep or stall up
ones self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stadie(n)">Stade (<etym lang="la">stadium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a race for
men or horses to run in; also
a proportion or measure of
ground, whereof there are
three sorts, (viz) The Itali&shy;
an, <emend err="containinig">containing</emend> one hundred
twenty and five paces; the O&shy;
lympick of one hundred and
twenty paces; and the Pyr&shy;
hick of two hundred paces;
all after five feet to the pace.
Of these Stades, eight make
an Italian mile, containing
one thousand paces, we may
call it eight furlongs. See
Tho.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Only OED citation dates ca. 1374.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="staggard(n)">Staggard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a red Male
Deer four years old.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stagirite(pn)">Stagirite.</form> <xpln lang="en"> Aristotle so cal&shy;
led, from Stagira a Town in
Macedonia, where he was born.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stallage(n)">Stallage (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Estallage</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in our Common Law,
money paid for pitching stals 


</page>

<page sig="oo5r">
in Fair or Market. See <xref>Sca&shy;
vage</xref>. This in Scotland is cal&shy;
led Stallange . Skene <term lang="la">verbo Stal&shy;
langiatores</term>. And among the
Romans it was termed (<etym lang="la">Sili&shy;
quaticum</etym>) from <etym lang="la">siliqua</etym>, their
first and least of all weights.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stallion(n)">Stallion (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Estalon</etym>, or Ital. <etym lang="it">Stall&oacute;ne</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Horse kept for covering
Mares.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="standard(n)">Standard orEstandard,
( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Estandart</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Ensign for Horsmen in War,
and is commonly taken for
that of the King, or chief Ge&shy;
neral. It is also used for the
principal or standing measure
of the King, to the scantling
whereof, all the measures
throughout the Land are, or
ought to be framed, &amp;c. Mag&shy;
na Charta, and confirmed
Anno 14 Edw.3. cap.12. Of
these Standards and measures,
read Britton. cap.30.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stannary(n)">Stannaries (<etym lang="la">Stannaria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the Mines and Works, touch&shy;
ing the getting and purifying
of Tin in Cornwal, and other
places; of which works,
there are two sorts, (viz.)
Lode-work and Stream-work .
See Cam. Britan. pag. 119.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stanza(n)">Stanza ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Staff of
Verses. As Spencers Books
are divided into Canto' s,
and those again into Stan&shy;
za' s.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="staple(n)">Staple (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Estape</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mart
or general Market, a Publick
Store-house in a Sea Town,
or Town of Traffick, whi&shy;
ther the Merchants of Eng&shy; 
land, by Common Order or
Commandment, did carry
Wools, Wool-sels, Cloaths,
Lead, Tin, &amp;c. (which are
the Staple Commodities of
this Land) for the utterance
of them by the great. See
Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Staple Inn(pn)">Staple Inn,</form> <xpln lang="en">neer Holborn
Bars, now one of the Inns
of Chancery, was formerly
an Inn or Hostel of the
Merchants of the Staple,
and from thence so called.
Stow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="starrulet(n)">Starrulet</form> <xpln lang="en">(a Dim. of Star)
a little Star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stasiarch(n)">Stasiarch ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch&shy;
rebel, the head of a Sedition.
Le Str.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stater(n)">Stater ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient
Coyn of several sorts. 

The Corinthian Stater was
worth one and twenty pence
wanting a Farthing. 

The Macedonian Stater was
worth about two shillings
nine pence half-peny. 

The Golden Attick Stater 
weighed two drams, and
therefore worth seventeen
shillings six pence. Peach&shy;
um.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="statics(n)">Staticks ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Sci&shy;
ence of weights, a species of
Mechanicks. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="station(n)">Station (<etym lang="la">statio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a stand&shy;
ing place, a Bay or Rode for
Ships to rest in; also a place
of resort, abode or stay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stationary(n)">Stationary (<etym lang="la">stationarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
appointed to keep ward in
any place, that is in Garison,
setled, standing.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="oo5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stationer(n)">Stationer</form> <xpln lang="en">(so called of
his station or standing Shop
to sell in) is often confounded
with Book-seller, and some&shy;
times with Book-binder ; where&shy;
as they are three several
Trades; The Stationer sells 
Paper, and Paper-Books, Ink,
Wax, &amp;c. The Book-seller 
deals onely in printed Books,
ready bound, and trimmed
up; and the Book-binder binds
them, but sells not. Yet all
three are of the Company of
Stationers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="statuary(n)">Statuary (<etym lang="la">statuarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Stone-cutter, a maker of
Statues or Images.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="statuminate(v)">Statuminate (<etym lang="la">statumino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to prop up, to under-set, to
make sure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="statute(n)">Statute (<etym lang="la">Statutum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">hath
divers significations in our
Common Law; first it signi&shy;
fies a Decree or Act of Parlia&shy;
ment, &amp;c. Statute, in another
signification, is a kind of
Bond; as Statute Merchant,
and Statute Staple . An.5. H 4
cap.12. The reason of which
name is, because those Bonds
are made according to the
form of Statutes, properly
provided for the same, which
direct both before what per&shy;
sons, and in what manner
they ought to be made West.
part. I. Symb. lib.2. sect.151.
27. Edw.3. ca.9. and 23.
Hen. 8.6. See more in
Cowel. 

Statutes is also used in
our vulgar talk, for the petit
Sessions which are yearly 
kept for the disposing of
Servants in Service, by the
Statutes of 1, and 5. Eliz.
cap.4.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steccado(n)">Steccado (Span. <etym lang="sp"> Estaca&shy;
da</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a place railed in for a
Combate or Lists.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Steelyard(pn)">Steel-yard.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref target="Stil-yard"> See Stil&shy;
Yard</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steeple(n)">Steeple (from the Sax.
<etym lang="sx">Stipel</etym>, which signifies a high
Tower)</form> <xpln lang="en">the tower or Steeple
of a Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steganography(n)">Steganography ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a description of the way or
manner of covering Edifi&shy;
ces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stellar(a)">Stellar (<etym lang="la">stellaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">starry,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stellation(n)">Stellation (<etym lang="la">stellatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
blasting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stelled(a)">Stelled (<etym lang="la">stellatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full
of, or garnished with stars.
Feltham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stiletto(n)">Steletto orStiletto ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a little Ponyard, or the smal
and sharp pointed Dagger,
forbidden in many Towns of
Italy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stelliferous(a)">Stelliferous (<etym lang="la">stellifer</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
bears or has Stars in it, star&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stellion(n)">Stellion (<etym lang="la">stellio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the spot&shy;
ted or starry Lizard, so cal&shy;
led; Also an envious fel&shy;
low, or one that cannot en&shy;
dure another should be the
better by him; from the Stel&shy;
lion, which, having (as he
doth half yearly) cast his skin
(a Soveriegn remedy for the
Falling Sickness) presently
devours it, to deprive man&shy;
kind of it. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="oo6r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stellionate(v)">Stellionate (<etym lang="la">stellionatus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a deceit, in dissembling a
thing, to take profit by ano&shy;
ther unjustly, a counterfeit&shy;
ing of merchandize, a cousen&shy;
ing or selling the same thing
to several persons. Lo. Bac.
Hen.7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stenography(n)">Stenography (<etym lang="la">stenogra&shy;
phia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the art of Short-writ&shy;

cing any thing into a narrow&shy;
er compass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stentor(pn)">Stentor;</form> <xpln lang="en">a Grecian that
had a voyce lowder then fif&shy;
ty men together. Hence
we use Stentorian voyce, for
a great, loud, roaring voyce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stephen(pn)">Stephen ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Crown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stepmother(n)">Step mother,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called,
because she steps in, instead of
a Mother, by marrying the
Sons or Daughters Father; a
Mother in Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stercorean(a)" lexeme="stercorarious(a)">Stercorean

 (<etym lang="la">sterco&shy;
rarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sterile(a)">Sterile (<etym lang="la">sterilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">barren,

without generation, yeelding
nothing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sterility(n)">Sterility (<etym lang="la">sterilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">bar&shy;
renness, unfruitfulness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sterling(n)">Sterling,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the common
term or Epitheton for money 
currant in this Nation; which
thus took denomination;
In the time of Richard the
First, money coined in the
East part of Germany, be&shy;
gan to be of special request
in England for its purity, and
was called Easterling money,
as all the Inhabitants of those
parts were called Easterlings,
and shortly after some of
that Country, skilful in Mint
matters and Allayes, were
sent for hither to bring the
coyn to perfection, which
since that time was called
from them Sterling, for Easter&shy;
ling ; Not from Sterling or Stri&shy;
veling in Scotland, not from a
Star, or the bird Starling, which
some dreampt to be stam&shy;
ped on it; For in old Deeds,
they are always called Num&shy;
mi Esterlingi ; which implied
as much as good and lawful
money of England, or Proba
Moneta, among the Civili&shy;
ans, and Monois de Roy in
France. Cam. Rem. fol.184. 

A Pound Sterling is Twen&shy;
ty shillings in our English
money, and an English penny
was of old called a Sterling;
and in the composition of
Measures made in Edward the
Firsts time, we find, that <term lang="la">De&shy;
narius Angli&aelig;, qui nominatur
Sterlingus, rotundus, siue ton&shy;
sura, ponderabit 32 grana in
medio spic&aelig;</term>. Antiq. Hibern. p.
133.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sternomancy(n)">Sternomancy (<etym lang="la">sternoman&shy;
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">divination by a mans
breast.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="oo6v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sternutation(n)">Sternutation (<etym lang="la">sternutatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a sneezing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sternutatory(n)">Sternutatory (<etym lang="la">sternutato&shy; 
rium medioamentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a medi&shy;
cine or powder that will
cause sneezing, sneezing pow&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sterquilinious(a)">Sterquilinious (from
 <etym lang="la">sterquilinium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stews(n)">Stewes,</form> <xpln lang="en">are those pla&shy;
ces, which are permitted to
women of professed incon&shy;
tinency, for the profer of
their bodies to all commers;
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Estuve</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Bath
or Hot-house; because wan&shy;
tons are wont to prepare,
or rather to purge them&shy;
selves for those venereous
Acts by often bathing and
Hot-houses. 

And that this is not new,
Homer shews in the eighth
Book of his Odiss. where he
reckons hot Bathes among
the Effeminate sort of plea&shy;
sures. Of these Stewes see
the Statute, Anno II. H.6.
ca. I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sticonomanty(n)">Sticonomanty ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Divination by words writ&shy;
ten on the barks of trees.</xpln></wordentry>

ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is marked with an hot
iron, notably defamed for
a naughty fellow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stigmatize(v)">Stigmatize (<etym lang="la">stigmatizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to mark with an hot iron,
as we use to do Rogues,
and notorious offenders at
Goal-deliveries.</xpln></wordentry>

stantively for a Still or Lim&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Steelyard(pn)">Stil-yard, orSteel-&shy;
yard (<term lang="la">Guilda Teutonicorum</term>,</form> <xpln lang="en">
Anno 32. Hen.8. cap.8.
and Anno 32. ejusdem ca.14.) 
is a place near the Thames
in London, where the Fra&shy;
ternity of the Easterling
Merchants, or the Merch&shy;
ants of Hawnse and Almain
( Anno I. Edw.6. cap.13.)
were wont to have their
abode. It is so called of
a broad Yard or Court,
wherein Steele was much
sold, upon which that house
is founded. Nathan Chitr&aelig;us.
See <xref>Hanse</xref>. 

The place is now one&shy;
ly famous for Rhenish wine,
Neats Tongues, &amp;c. The
Lord Herbert in his Henry 8.
calls it the Stilly art, but
gives no reason for that deno&shy;
mination.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stimulate(v)">Stimulate (<etym lang="la">stimulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to prick, to move, to in&shy;
cense, to stir forward, to pro&shy;
voke.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

ry words of the Law, to

ally what he is required to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stirps(n)">Stirps ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the root,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stoccado(n)">Stocada (Spa. <etym lang="sp">estocada</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stoics(pn)">Stoicks (<etym lang="la">Stocici</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sect
of Philosophers at Athens,
whereof Zeno was the chief,
they held a wise man ought
to be free from all passi&shy;
ons, never to be moved ei&shy;
ther with Joy or Grief, and
esteeming all things to be or&shy;
dered by an inevitable ne&shy;
cessity of Fate. 

They were called Stoicks,
of the Gr. (<etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&upsilon;&#x03ac;</etym>) <expan type="">id est</expan> a Porch;
because Zeno taught his fol&shy;
lowers in a common Porch of
the City.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stoical(a)">Stoical,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining to such
Philosophers; severe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stoicism(n)">Stoicism,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Doctrine
or Discipline of the Sto&shy;
icks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stole(n)">Stole (<etym lang="la">stola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any Gar&shy;
ment wherewith the body
is covered, a Robe of ho&shy;
nour. Among the ancient
Romans, it was had in great
reverence, and held as a
Vest or Badge of chastity,
hence that of Martial, lib. I.
 <term lang="la">Quis ftoralia vestit &amp; Stola&shy;
tum permittit meretricibus pu&shy;
dorem? </term> 

And with the modern
Romanists it is that part of
the Priestly Ornaments,
which, being put over 


</page>

<page sig="oo7v">
the neck, is afterwards set
crosswise over the breast with
the ends hanging down on
each side, and used in memo&shy;
ry of the cord, by which our
Blessed Saviour was tyed to
the Pillar, when he was
whipt and scourged; and sig&shy;
nifies the light and sweet
yoak of Christ, whereunto
we are patiently and obedi&shy;
ently to submit our necks. 

The ancient Spartan Soul&shy;
diers did also wear a crimson
Stole or Tippet about their
necks, and a shield of brass.
I. part. Tr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stolid(a)">Stollid (<etym lang="la">stolidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fooling,
fond, lewd of condition, un&shy;
advised, dull, doltish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stolidity(n)">Stolidity (<etym lang="la">stoliditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fol&shy;
ly, unadvisedness, fondness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stomachic(n)">Stomachick (<etym lang="la">stomachicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is sick in the stomack,
that cannot keep the meat it
has taken.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stomachosity(n)">Stomachosity (<etym lang="la">stomacho&shy;
sitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">anger, indignation, dis&shy;
dain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stomatic(n)">Stomatick (<etym lang="la">stomaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath a sore or swelling in
the mouth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stone of wool(n)">Stone of Wool,</form> <xpln lang="en">ought to
weigh fourteen pounds, yet
in some places by custom it
is more or less, and two Stone
make a Tod of Wooll. See
Crompt. Just. of P. fo.83. b. See
Sarplar. A Stone of Beef is
but eight pound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stone falcon(n)">Stonefaulcon (<etym lang="la">Lithofal&shy;
cus</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&lambda;&#x03af;&delta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <etym lang="la">Lapis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">so called from the
stones and rocks where she 
eyries or builds her nest.
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stumming of wine(n)">Stooming of Wine.</form> <xpln lang="en"> There
is (says Mr. How. in his Let&shy;
ters) a hard green wine that
grows about Rochel, and the
Islands thereabouts, which the
cunning Holander sometime
useth to fetch, and he hath a trick
to put a bag of hearbs or some o&shy;
ther infusions into it (as he doth
Brimstone in Rhenish) to give
it a whiter tincture and more
sweetness; then they reimbark it
for England, where it passeth
for good Bachrag, and this (says
he) is called Stooming of Wine .</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stork(n)">Storck ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bird fa&shy;
mous for natural love to&shy;
wards his Parents, whom he
feeds being old and impotent,
as they fed him, being young.
The Egyptians so esteemed this
Bird, that there was a great
penalty laid upon him that
should kill him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stowing(n)">Stowing,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the laying
any goods or victuals in order
in the Hold of a Ship; and
at Land it is the laying coals
or other goods in a Ware&shy;
house, Cellar, or other place;
and Stowage is the place it self
or the money that is paid for
such place to lay goods in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strabism(n)">Strabism (<etym lang="la">strabismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
squintness in the eyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strage(n)">Strage (<etym lang="la">strages</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a slaughter,
a discomfiture, a multitude of
men slain; also a beating, fel&shy;
ling or cutting down to the
ground, properly of trees; a
great ruin and fall.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strait(n)">Straight.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Streight</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strake(n)">Strake</form> <xpln lang="en">of a wheel, is the 


</page>

<page sig="oo8r">
iron wherewith the wheel is
bound, or the wood or hoop
wherein the Spoaks are set;
because it makes a strake in the
ground, as it goes, Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strand(n)">Strand.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Strond</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strangury(n)">Strangury 
or

ria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
ease, which
is when one makes water by
drop-meal, very hardly, and
with great pain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strappado(n)">Strappado ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a punish&shy;
ment most commonly of Soul&shy;
diers for some offence; which
is hanging them by the arms
drawn backward, and being
so bound they are drawn up
on high, and let down again
with a violent swing, which (if
used with rigor) unjoynts
their back and arms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stratagem(n)">Stratagem (<etym lang="la">stratagema</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stratagemical(a)">Stratagemical,</form> <xpln lang="en">done by

Streight of Magellan, Gebral&shy;
tar, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stream-work(n)">Stremeworks,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a kind
of work in the Stanneries, for
(says Mr. Cam. Tit. Cor.) <term lang="la"> Ho&shy;
rum stannariorum sive <emend err="metalli">metalli&shy;</emend> 
<emend err="cornum" source="errata">corum</emend> operum duo sunt genera;
alteram Lodeworks, alterum
Stremeworks vocant; Hoc in
locis inferioribus est cum fossis
agendis stanni venas sectantur &amp;
fluviorum alveos subinde de&shy;
fluctunt; illud in locis &aelig;ditiori&shy; 
bus, cum in montibus puteos,
quos Shafts vocant, in magnam
altitudinem defodiunt, &amp; cuni&shy;
culos agunt</term> these you may
read mentioned An.27. H.8.
cap.23.</xpln></wordentry>

ground, or under a thing Ben.
Johnson.

Alexandrinus were a Miscella&shy;
nie, or Books of several scat&shy;
tered subjects.</xpln></wordentry>

urbs of London, so called, be&shy;
cause it lies by the River side.
Chau.</xpln></wordentry>

ma, which is a Wen or swel&shy;
ling in the Neck and Arm&shy;
holes, wherein are as it were
hard kernels closed in the
skin, some take it to be the
Kings evil.</xpln></wordentry>

ver of Hell; The Gods were
wont to swear by it, and what
god soever swore by Styx false&shy;
ly, was banished from Heaven,
and prohibited Nectar for
1000 years. 

Done by the water of Styx <expan type="">id est</expan>
by necessity. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="subjugum(adv)">Subjugum, <expan type="">id est</expan> under the
yoke.</form> <xpln lang="en">The Armenians and other
Nations in ancient time, were
wont to force such enemies,
as they had vanquished, to
go in despight, under certain
Spears pitched a cross, like a
Gallows; and this they term&shy;
ed Sub jugum, and was held a
great disgrace. Tacitus An&shy;
nales, lib.15. And Liv.
lib.3</xpln>

Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="subpaena(n)">Subp&aelig;na,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Writ that
lies to call a man into the
Chancery, upon such case
onely as the Common Law
fails in, and hath not provi&shy;
ded for; so as the party, who
in equity hath wrong, can
have no remedy by the ordi&shy;
nary rules and course of the
Common Law. West. par.2.
Symb tit. Proceedings in Chance&shy;
ry. Sect.18. There is also a Sub
p&aelig;na ad testificandum, which
lies for the calling in of wit&shy;
nesses to testifie in a cause, as
well in Chancery, as in other
Courts; And the name of
both these proceed from
words in the Writ, which
charge the party called to ap&shy;
pear at the day and place as&shy;
signed, <term lang="la">sub p&aelig;na centum libra&shy;
rum</term>, &amp;c. But in case the party,
to appear, be a Lord of Parli&shy;
ment, or the Widow of such
Lord, then is he or she called
by the Lo Keeper or Lo. Chan&shy;
celors Letter, giving them no&shy;
tice of the suit intended a&shy;
gainst them, and desiring them
to appear. Cromp. Juris. fol.33.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="subriguous(a)">Subriguous (<etym lang="la">subriguus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
moist, wet, and waterish un&shy;
derneath.</xpln></wordentry>

ted from other affairs, done at
times.</xpln></wordentry>

 (<etym lang="la">subsidiarius</etym>)</form>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="subsidy(n)">Subsidy
 (<etym lang="la">subsidium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">aid
or assistance; a tax or tribute
assessed by Parliament, and
granted by the Commons to
be levied of every subject, ac&shy;
cording to the value of his
Land or Goods, most com&shy;
monly after the rate of 4s. in
the pound for land; and 2s.8d
for goods, &amp;c. See more in
Cowel and in Rastals Abridgm.
tit. Taxes, Tenths, Fifteens,
Subsidies. &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="subsortition(n)">Subsortition (<etym lang="la">subsortitio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a chusing by lots, after others
have chosen, to fill up the
number of those that before
were refused. Suet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="substitute(n)">Substitute (<etym lang="la">substituo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
ordain in place of another, to
appoint in the room of, to de&shy;
pute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="substitutive(n)">Substitutive (<etym lang="la">substitutivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is appointed or ordain&shy;
ed in place of another. It is
also a term in Logick, as <term lang="la">Pro&shy;
pesitio <emend err="substtitutiva">substitutiva</emend></term>, a conditio&shy;
nal Proposition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="substruction(n)">Substruction (<etym lang="la">substructio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an underpinning or grounsel&shy;
ling of a house; a building or
ground-work, a making a
foundation; an under-filling,
A term in Architecture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="succentor(n)">Succentor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that

from this word, or if it be
written with a C, then tis
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Cinquante</etym>, which
signifies fifty, and so may be
taken for one that is fifty
years of age or above.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<page sig="pp3r">
tur, quia eorum suffragiis
caus&aelig; Ecclesiastic&aelig; judican&shy;

risdict. lib.4. cap.16. numb.14.

cap.14. which inables every

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suffrage(n)">Suffrage (<etym lang="la">suffragium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
good word, or favorable
voyce in ones behalf, as at
the time of chusing Mayors,
Burgesses or the like; a
speaking in ones favor. 

Suffrages, in ancient Rome
were the voyces of the peo&shy;
ple given by Centuries, Gu&shy;
ri&aelig; or Tribes, which went
affirmatively under this form
 <term lang="la">Uti rogas</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> be it according
to your Bill: And negatively
thus, <term lang="la">Antiquo</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> I deny or re&shy;
ject it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sultan(n)">Sultan,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Persian
language, properly signifies
an Earl. But Sultan or Sol&shy;
dan among the Turks, Per&shy;
sians, and Arabians is com&shy;
monly taken for a King,
Prince or Soveraign. Also a
Turkish Coyn of Gold worth
about Six shillings, Six pence
sterling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sultanin(n)">Sultanin 
or Sultana </form> <xpln lang="en">a Turkish
coin of gold
worth a&shy; 
bout Seven shilling six pence
or Seven shillings ten pence
sterling; It is so called be&shy;
cause coyned at Constantinople
where the Sultan lives.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sumac(n)">Sumack,Sumake, or
Sumaque,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of hearb
or shrub of a stinking 


</page>

<page sig="pp3v">
smell, <emend err="of" source="errata">with</emend> black Berries, that
Curriers dress their leather
with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="summage(n)">Sumage,</form> <xpln lang="en">seems to be Toll
for carriage on horse-back.
Crompt. Jurisdict. fol.191. for
where the Charter of the
Forest, cap.14. hath these
words, for a horse that beareth
loads, every half year a half
penny, the book called <term lang="la">Pupil&shy;
la oculi</term>, useth these words,
 <term lang="la">pro uno equo portante Summagi&shy;
um per dimidium anni obulum</term> .
It is otherwise called a Seam ;
and a Seam, in the Western
parts is a horse load, which
word Seam and Sumage may
well come of the Fr. <etym lang="fr"> Somme</etym>,
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Sarcina</term>, and <term lang="fr">Sommi&egrave;r</term>, <term lang="la">equus
sarcinarius</term>, a Sumpter horse.
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sunamite(pn)">Sunamite (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> <etym lang="la">dor&shy;
miens</etym>, one sleeping. A worthy
good woman of Suna that
often entertained Eliseus the
Prophet, by whose prayers
she had a Son, when by course
of nature she was past hopes
of any, and afterwards had
the same son raised from death
to life by the same Eliseus
4 Kings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sunday(pn)">Sunday</form> <xpln lang="en">was dedicated
to the Idol of the Sun, by the
old Pagan Saxons, and there&shy;
fore called the Sun' s day, or
day of the Sun ; now <term lang="la">dies
Dominicus</term>, or our Lords day.</xpln></wordentry>

the doing more then a man
is of necessity bound to do,
a giving over-plus. In Di&shy;
vinity, works of Supereroga&shy;
tion are taken to be such, as
are done upon a pious ac&shy;
count; to which works a
man is not bound in particu&shy;
lar by any positive precept of
Gods Law.</xpln></wordentry>

thers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="superlative(a)">Superlative (<etym lang="la">superlati&shy;
vus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">highest in degree, pre&shy;
ferred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supermeate(v)">Supermeate (<etym lang="la">supermeo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to go or slip over, to run, or
flow over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supernal(a)">Supernal (<etym lang="la">supernus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
which comes from above,
high.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supernation(n)">Supernation (<etym lang="la">supernatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a swimming upon, over, or a&shy;
loft. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supersaliency(n)">Supersaliency (from <etym lang="la">su&shy;
per</etym> and <etym lang="la">salio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a leaping or <emend err="jump"> jump&shy;</emend>
ing upon. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supersedeas(n)">Supersedeas (from <etym lang="la">super&shy;
sedeo</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to omit, to leave off
or cease)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Writ which
lies in divers cases, as appears
by the Table of the Register
Original, and the Judicial also
and by Fitz. nat. br. fol.236
and many other places noted
in the Index of his book, ver&shy;
bo Supersedeas. But it signi&shy;
fies in them all a command or
request to stay or forbear the
doing of that, which in ap&shy;
pearance of Law, were to be
done, were it not for the
cause whereupon this Writ is
granted; for example, a man
regularly is to have Surety of
Peace against him, of whom
he will swear he is afraid, and
the Justice required hereun&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="pp4v">
to cannot deny him; yet if
the party be formerly bound
to the Peace, either in Chan&shy;
cery, or elswhere, this Writ
lieth to stay the Justice from
doing that, which otherwise
he might not deny. Cow. 

This word is also used in
our common discourse to like
purpose, as when one is com&shy;
manded or requested by wri&shy;
ting or word of mouth, to
surcease the doing that which
he had former order, or ought
to have done; we say the
former order or command is
superseded.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supersession(n)">Supersession (<etym lang="la">supersessio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
surceasing, a leaving off, or gi&shy;
ving over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="superstition(n)">Superstition (<etym lang="la">superstitio</etym>,
from <etym lang="la">super</etym> and <etym lang="la">sto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an excess
of Ceremonious worship,
vain Religion or Devotion;
the worship of D&aelig;mons; an
honoring of that which
should not be honored, a vain
reverence or fear towards that
thing wherein is no efficacy
or force, but onely by illusi&shy;
on, spiced conscience in vain
things. Tho. 

St. Thomas Aquinas menti&shy;
ons four kindes of Supersti&shy;
tion. 2 da. 2 d&aelig;. qu 92. Art. I.
and Art 2. in Corp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supervacaneous(a)" lexeme="suvervavuous(a)">Supervacaneous orSu&shy;
pervavuous (<etym lang="la">supervacaneus vel
supervacuus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">needless, vain,
superfluous, not necessary, un&shy;
profitable; also that which
is set aside above ordinary use,
against some occasion to be
used.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supervene(v)">Supervene (<etym lang="la">supervenio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
come unlooked for, to come
upon or after another thing;
to leap upon, as the Male
doth the Female.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supervive(v)">Supervive (<etym lang="la">supervivo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
recover from peril of death,
or when a man seems to be
dead; to out-live, or live
longer then an other thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supine(a)">Supine (<etym lang="la">supinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">upright,
upward, the belly upward;
also negligent and careless.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supinity(n)">Supinity (<etym lang="la">supinitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

with the belly upward, neg&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppedaneous(a)">Suppedaneous (<etym lang="la">suppedane&shy;
us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to a foot-stool,

the feet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppeditate(v)">Suppeditate (<etym lang="la">suppedito</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies properly to relieve
the skirmishers with footmen,
to supply or second with foot
forces. Metaphorically, to
give or minister sufficiently,
to supply or furnish what is
wanting; also to subdue or
overcome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppellecticarious(a)">Suppellecticarious (<etym lang="la">sup&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppository(n)">Suppository (<etym lang="la">suppositori&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any thing put up into the
Fundament, to make the body
soluble; it is commonly made
of Honey boiled, till it grow
thick, and so made into an apt
form for that purpose, where&shy;
to sometime is added the Yolk
of an Egg, or Salt, when we
would have it work the effect
more speedily. It may also be
used adjectively, for put, or
set under.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppuration(n)">Suppuration (<etym lang="la">suppuratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a mattering, a gathering of a

Mattary-head, a resolving
into Mattar. <term lang="la">Suppurare</term> (says
Min.) is <term lang="la">sub pelle pus agere: 
Quia tunc efficiendum est, ut
materies apostematis in pus con&shy;
vertatur</term></xpln></wordentry>
