<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surplusage(n)">Surplusage (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Surplus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies in our Common Law
superfluity or addition more
then needs, which sometimes is
a cause that the Writ abateth.
Brook tit. Nugation and Super&shy;
fluity fol. 100. Plowden, casu
Dive and Maningham. f.93. b.
It is also sometimes applied to
matter of account, and sig&shy;
nifies a greater disbursment
then the charge of the Ac&shy;
comptant amounts to. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surprisal(n)">Surprizal (Fr. <etym lang="fr">surprinse</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a sudden taking, an assaulting
or coming upon a man before
he is aware; a taking tar&shy;
dy, or finding in the man&shy;
ner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surrejoinder(n)">Surreioynder,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a second
defence of the Plaintiffs acti&shy; 
on, opposite to the Defen&shy;
dants Rejoynder ; And there&shy;
fore Hotoman calls it <term lang="la">Triplica&shy;
tionem, qu&aelig; est secunda actoris
defensio, contra rei duplicationem
opposita</term> ; Nor doth Hotoman
onely call this <term lang="la">Triplicationem</term>,
but the Emperor himself, <term lang="la">de
Replicationibus lib.4. Institut.
Titulo</term> 14.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surrender(n)">Surrender (<etym lang="la">sursum reddi&shy;
to</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an instrument, testify&shy; 
ing with apt words, that the
particular Tennant of Lands
or Tenements for life or
years, doth sufficiently con&shy;
sent and agree, that he who
hath the next or immediate
Remainder or Reversion there&shy;
of shall also have the particu&shy;
lar estate of the same in pos&shy;
session, and that he yeelds
and gives up the same unto
him; For every Surrender
ought forthwith to give a
possession of the things sur&shy;
rendred, West part. I. lib.2.
sect.503. where you may read
divers presidents. But there
may be a Surrender without
writing; And therefore
there is said to be a Surrender
in Deed and a Surrender
in Law; Surrender in Deed 
is that, which is really and
sensibly performed; Surren&shy;
der in Law is in intendment
of Law, by way of consequent
and not actual. Perkins, Sur&shy;
render fol.606. and Seq. As if
a man have a Lease of a Farm,
and during the term he ac&shy; 
cept of a new Lease, this Act
is in Law a Surrender of the
former. Coke vol.6. fol.11. b.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surreptitious(a)">Surreptitious (<etym lang="la">surrepti&shy;
tius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">stoln, or done by stealth,
falsely come by, that no man
knows of.</xpln></wordentry>

or put in ones room, to sub&shy;
stitute or subrogate.</xpln></wordentry>

stituted to supply the room 


</page>

<page sig="pp6r">
of another, most commonly,
of a Bishop.</xpln></wordentry>

vives, over-lives or out-lives
another. In our Common
Law it is taken for the long&shy;
er liver of Two Joyntenants,
or of any Two joyned in the
right of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suspension(n)">Suspension (<etym lang="la">suspensio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
hanging up; also doubt, in&shy;
certainty of mind. It is used
for a temporal stop of a mans
right, and differs from Ex&shy;
tinguishment in this, that a
right of estate suspended, re&shy;
viveth again, but extin&shy;
guished, dyes for ever.
Brooke tit. extinguishment,
and Suspension. fol.314. Sus&shy;
pension is also sometimes used
in our Common, as it is
in the Cannon Law, <term lang="la">pro
minori Excommunicatione</term>. As 
Anno 24. Hen.8. Cap.12.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suspensory(n)">Suspensories (from <etym lang="la">sus&shy;

pensoires</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">certain cords or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suspiral(n)">Suspiral (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Souspiral</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a passage for air or breath to
come in and go out at; a
bent or breathing hole; hence
the Tunnel of a Chimney,
the Window of a Sellar, the
Mouth of a Cave or Den.
In the Statute of 35 Hen.8.
Cap.10. it seems to be taken
for a Spring of water, pas&shy;
sing under the ground, to&shy;
wards a Conduit or Cest&shy;
ern.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swainmote(n)">Swainmot orSwain&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swallow's tail(n)">Swallows Tail</form> <xpln lang="en">In build&shy;
ing, or Carpenters work,
it signifies a fastning two
peeces of Timber so strongly
together, that they cannot
fall asunder, and is so called
from the resemblance it hath
with a Swallows Tail, being
forked.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sweep(n)">Swepe orSweep (<etym lang="la">telo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
was an instrument of war;
like that which Brewers use
with cross beams to draw wa&shy;
ter. Tho. <term lang="la">Est genus machin&aelig;
( ut ait Festus) quo hauritur a&shy;
qua, in alteram partem pr&aelig;gra&shy;
vante pondere</term> . 

Swepe, in some parts of
England, is taken for the crop
of hay that is got in a meadow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Swithin(pn)">Swithin ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
old English<etym lang="oe">Switheahn</etym>,
that is, very high, as <term lang="la">Celsus</term> or
 <term lang="la">Exuperius</term> with the Romans .
This name hath been taken up
in honor of St. Swithin, the
holy Bishop of Winchester, a&shy;
bout the year 860, and called
the weeping St. Swithin, for
that about his Feast Pr&aelig;sepe 
and Aselli, rainy Constel&shy;
lations, arise cosmically, and
commonly cause rain. Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sybarite(n)">Sybarites (<etym lang="la">Sybarit&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">peo&shy;
ple of Sybaris, in sensual
delights passing all other;
hence</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sybaritical(a)">Sybaritical (<etym lang="la">sybariticus</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">dainty, wanton, costly, sump&shy;
tuous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sybil(pn)">Sybil (<etym lang="la">sybilla</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a name of
all women that had the Spi&shy;
rit of Prophecy; there were
ten famous, the first was cal&shy;
led Persica, 2 Lybica, 3 Del&shy;
phica, 4 Cum&aelig;a, 5 Erythr&aelig;a,
6 Samia, 7 Cumana, 8 Hel&shy;
lespontiaca, 9 Phrygia, 10 Ti&shy;
burtina. They all Prophe&shy;
cied of the Incarnation of
Christ. But the certain num&shy;
ber of them is not agreed on
among Authors, some making
more, others fewer; where&shy;
of read Vulgar Errors, pag.
150.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sybillianists(pn)">Sybillianists,</form> <xpln lang="en">Christians
so called by the Pagans in the
Primitive times, because they
believed and esteemed the
Prophecies of the Sybils,
touching Christ.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="pp7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sybilline(a)">Sybilline (<etym lang="la">Sybillinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to a Sybil or Prophe&shy;
tess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sycomanty(n)">Sycomanty,</form> <xpln lang="en">Divination
by Fig, or Sycomore Leaves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sycomore(n)">Sycomore (<etym lang="la">Sycomorus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Tree like a Fig-tree, having
great branches, and large
leaves like a Mulberry; it
bears fruit three or four times
in a year, much like a wilde
Fig, but without any Seeds
within. The fruit grows up
on the very body of the Tree
and the great main boughs,
and will never be ripe, except
it be scraped with an iron
tool. It is found plentifully
in Caria, Egypt, and the Isle
of Rhodes, especially in such
places where Wheat will not
grow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sycophant(n)">Sycophant (<etym lang="la">sycophanta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
tale-bearer, a false accuser, a
Deceiver, Parasite, Smell&shy;
feast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sycophantize(v)">Sycophantize (<etym lang="la">sycophan&shy;
tisso</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to play the Sycophant,
to slander or accuse falsly, to
deal deceitfully.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syderation(n)">Syderation (<etym lang="la">syderatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
blasting of Trees with great
heat and drouth, tree-plague;
also a sudden taking or be&shy;
numming of a Limb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syderosous(a)">Syderosous (<etym lang="la">syderosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
Planet strucken; also full of
Stars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllabical(a)">Syllabical (<etym lang="la">syllabicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to or consisting of
syllables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllabize(v)"><emend err="Syllavize">Syllabize</emend>,</form> <xpln lang="en">to divide by
syllables, or to make a Table
or Index to a Book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllabary(n)">Syllabary (from <etym lang="la">syllaba</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Book treating of syllables, or
teaching the use or knowledg
of syllables; also as Sylla&shy;
bus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllabus(n)">Syllabus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Table
or Index in a Book, to shew
places or matter by Letters or
Figures; also an Argument
subtilly reproving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllogism(n)">Syllogism (<etym lang="la">syllogismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
most perfect kinde of Argu&shy;
ment, which gathers a neces&shy;
sary conclusion out of two
premisses; as thus, 

1. Every vice is odious. 

2. Drunkenness is a vice. 

3. <term lang="la">Ergo</term>, Drunkenness is 
odious. 

The first part of a Syllogism
is called the Proposition or Ma&shy;
jor ; the second, the Assumpti&shy;
on or Minor ; and the third,
the Conclusion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllogistical(a)">Syllogistical (<etym lang="la">syllogisticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to a Syllo&shy;
gism.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syllogize(v)">Syllogize (<etym lang="la">syllogizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
reason or argue by Syllo&shy;
gisms.</xpln></wordentry>

of or belonging to the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sylvestric(a)" lexeme="sylvestrious(a)">Sylvestrick

 (<etym lang="la">sylvestris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of Wood or Forest, full of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sylvigerous(a)">Sylvigerous (<etym lang="la">sylviger</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symbol(n)">Symbole (<etym lang="la">symbola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a to&shy;
ken, badge, or sign to know
one by, a secret and mystical 


</page>

<page sig="pp7v">
note; a short and intricate
riddle or sentence; also an
uniform consent or concur&shy;
rence of divers opinions; al&shy;
so the sum of our belief, the
Creed. 

Many frauds you shall read
in Plautus, plotted and acted
by counterfeiting, and slie
conveyance of those Symbols
or tokens, wherein there was
ever some image or other. So
the Symbol or Amphytrion in
that Tragicomedy was <term lang="la">Sol
cum quadrigis</term>, the Sun in his
Chariot drawn with four
horses. Pyrogopolinices the
bragging Soldier, had his own
lovely self with great decorum 
drawn in his Signet for a Sym&shy;
bol. El. Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symbolize(v)">To Symbolize (from <etym lang="la">Sym&shy;
bola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to Sympathize, to con&shy;
cur in opinion, jump in
Councils, agree in humors
or manners with; also to
joyn purses, or pay rateably
towards any charge, to club. 

Fire and air are called
Symbolizing Elements, so are
Earth and Water, because they
share and participate of each
others quality.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symbolical(a)">Symbolical<etym lang="la"> symbolicus(</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to a Symbol,
or token. 

Symbolical Philosophy, is that
kinde of Learning and Wis&shy;
dom, which, knowing the
causes and proprieties of
things natural and supernatu&shy;
ral, teach us how to make or
expound those mystical and
artificial bodies called Sym&shy; 
boles, of what kinde so&shy;
ever.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symbolography(n)">Symbolography ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
description of Symboles, a
writing or expression of
things by signs and tokens;
also the art or description of
Instruments or Presidents.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symmachy(n)">Symmachy (<etym lang="la">symmachia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
aid in war, league among
men of divers Countries to
joyn in war against one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symmetry(n)">Symmetry (<etym lang="la">symmetria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
due proportion of each thing
to other, in respect of the
whole. The convenience
that runs between the parts,
and the whole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="symmetrist(n)" lexeme="symmetrian(n)">Symmetrist 
or

<etym lang="la">Symmetri&shy;
a</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one

well the parts agree with the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sympathetical(a)">Sympathetical (<etym lang="la">sympathe&shy;
ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">agreeing well together,
in nature, disposition, or pas&shy;
sions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sympathy(n)">Sympathy (<etym lang="la">sympathia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
natural consent or combina&shy;
tion, mutual passion, affecti&shy;
on or disposition; fellow&shy;
feeling, symbolizing; as wa&shy;
ter, in coldness, participates or
sympathizes with the Earth;
in moistness with the Air.
Resemblance of quality, con&shy;
cordance of natures &amp; things.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

pricking in the side with a
Plurisie ; generally whatever
happens in a living Creature
against or besides nature, as
sickness and the inward causes
and accidents thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

fies that differently from

trary Categorematical imports
what has a predicamental or
self-signification.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syndic(n)">Syndic (<etym lang="la">syndicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a censor
or controller of manners;
an Advocate, Agent, or At&shy;
torney for a Commonwealth,
or for the Commonalty of a
City or Country, one that
hath the charge or Commissi&shy;
on to deal in affairs of the
Commonwealth with a For&shy;
rein Prince. The Government
of Geneva is by a Common
Council, consisting of two
hundred, the four chief where&shy;
of are called Syndiques . Heil. 


</page>

<page sig="pp8v">
There are also Syndicks at Na&shy;
poles, Dantzick, &amp; other places.</xpln></wordentry>

els into a dipthong. 4 Ages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="synod(n)">Synod (<etym lang="la">synodus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a meeting
or assembly of Ecclesiastical
persons, for the cause of Re&shy;
ligion. Of this there are four
kindes: As first, a General
Oecunenocial or Universal Sy&shy;
nod or Council, and that is,
where Bishops, &amp;c. of all Na&shy;
tions meet. Secondly, National
Synod, wher those of one only
Nation meet. Thirdly, Pro&shy;
vincial Synod, where Ecclesia&shy;
stical persons of one onely
Province meet. Fourthly,
Diocesan Synod, where those
of but one Diocess meet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="synodal(a)" lexeme="synodical(a)">Synodal

 (<etym lang="la">Synodicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="synonym(n)">Synonima's (<etym lang="la">synonima</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
words of one and the same
signification, which is to be
understood both of Appella&shy;
tives and proper names; as
 <term lang="la">Ensis, mucro, gladius</term>, all Latin
for a Sword; and <term lang="la">Publius,
Cornelius, Scipio, Africanus</term>, all
one mans name. So, stout,
hardly, valiant, doubty, couragi&shy; 
ous, adventurous, all compre&shy;
hended under the Latin word
( <term lang="la">fortis</term>).</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="synonimize(v)">Synonimize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to vary the

nification, to use <term lang="la">Synonima' s</term>,

sence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Syrtes(pn)">Syrtes (<term lang="la">omnibus linguis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sandy place in the outmost
parts of Affrica, where the
sands so move with the waves,
that that which was now deep
sea is streight-way full of
quick sands; And is usually
taken for any quick-sand or
shelf in the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="systatic(a)">Systatique [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&#x03c3;&upsilon;&#x03c2;&alpha;&tau;&iota;&kappa;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath the force or <emend err="pow">pow&shy;</emend>
er of compacting, building, or
putting together. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syzygy(n)">Sysigie [ <etym lang="la">sysigia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a con&shy;
junction, a coupling. The
conjunction of the Moone
with the Sunne; the new
moone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="system(n)">Systeme [ <etym lang="la">systema</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the
compasse of a song, or (by
a metaphor) of any other
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="systole(n)">Systole [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the motion
or lifting up of the heart or
Arteries; Also the shortning
of a long vowel. 
</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="t"><alpha>T</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tobacco(n)"><f type="l"/> Tabaco.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See tobacco</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabefy(v)">Tabefy [ <etym lang="la">tabefacio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
corrupt, consume or melt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabellary(n)">Tabellary [ <etym lang="la">tabellarius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
carrier of letters; an auditor,
a scrivener.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabellarious(a)">Tabellarious [ <etym lang="la">tabellarius,
a, um</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to carriers
or auditors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabellion(n)">Tabellion [ <etym lang="la">tabellio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a No&shy;
tary publick, or Scrivener, al&shy;
lowed by authority to ingrosse
and register private contracts
and obligations. His office
in some countrys did former&shy;
ly differ from that of a Nota&shy;
rie, but now they are grown
or made one.<xref> See Notarie</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabard(n)">Taberd orTabard [<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a jacket, jerkin, mandilion,
or sleevelesse coat; a chymere .
Verstegan says it was ancient&shy;
ly a short gown that reached
no further then the midleg;
Stow in his Surveigh p. 456.
sayes, 'twas a jacket or sleev&shy;
less coat, whole before, open
on both sides, with a square
collar winged at the shoul&shy;
ders. It is now the name one&shy;
ly of an Haralds coat, and is
called their coat of armes in
service. It is also the signe of
an ancient Inne in Southwark.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabernacle(n)">Tabernacle [ <etym lang="la">tabernaculis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Pavillion or tent for war; a
little shop, shed, or booth,
made of bords or boughs. The
Tabernacle of God you may
read described, Exod.26. It
was made like a tent to re&shy;
move too and fro as occasion
required, it had in it one room 


</page>

<page sig="qq1v">
called Sanctum Sanctorum,
wherein the high Priest enter&shy;
ed but once a year, and ano&shy;
ther room caled the holy place,
&amp;c. Heb.9.2,3,4. There was
of old among the Israelites, a
feast commanded by God, cal&shy;
led the feast of Tabernacles,
which began on the 15. day
of the 7. moneth, and continu&shy;
ed 7 dayes, during which time
the Israelites lived abroad in
Tabernacles, in remembrance
that their Fathers a long time
so lived, after God had deli&shy;
vered them out of the land of
Egypt. Now the feast of Ta&shy;
bernacles drew neer, Lev.23.34.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabernarious(a)">Tabernarious [ <etym lang="la">tabernarius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to Shops or Ta&shy;
verns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabid(a)">Tabid [ <etym lang="la">tabidus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">corrupted,
consuming, pining awy, wast&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabifical(a)">Tabifical [ <etym lang="la">tabificus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that
brings into consumption, py&shy;
ing or rotting away; conta&shy;
gious, corrupt, poysonous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tabitha(pn)">Tabitha [<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>] Roe buck;
a womans name. 
Laws of the 12. Tables (<etym lang="la">leges
12. tabularum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">were certain
Grecian Laws brought from
Athens by the decemviri unto
Rome, and there written in 12.
Tables of brasse; By which
Laws Justice was ever after
<emend err="admistred">administred</emend> to the Romane peo&shy;
ple. Godwin 122.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="table(n)">Table</form> <xpln lang="en">of Apelles was a
picture drawn by Apelles, that
famous painter, the moral
whereof was on the one side to
represent the excellency of 
abstinence, and sobriety in the
life of man, and <emend err="one">on</emend> the other,
the deformity of <emend err="drukennesse">drunkennesse</emend>
and gluttony, &amp;c. you may
read the story at length in the
first part of the treasury of
times. fol.609.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabouret(n)">Tabouret [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a pincase;
also a little low stool for a
childe to sit on. In France the
priviledge of the Tabouret is
of a stool for some particular
Ladies to sit in the Queens
presence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabular(a)">Tabular [ <etym lang="la">tabularis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">wher&shy;
of boards, plancks, or tables
may be made long and large.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabulary(n)">Tabulary [ <etym lang="la">tabularium</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
chest or place wherein Regi&shy;
sters, or Evidences are kept in
a City, the Chancery or Ex&shy;
chequer office.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabularious(a)">Tabularious (<etym lang="la">tabularius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
<emend err="pertaing">pertaining</emend> to writings or ac&shy;
counts; also belonging to
tables, or good for them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabulate(v)">Tabulate (<etym lang="la">tabulo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to board
a floore or other place, to
make a thing of boards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tasse(n)">Taces,</form> <xpln lang="en">armour for the
thighs, so called, because they
are tached or tacked on with
straps of leather to the corslet .
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tagliacotian nose(n)">Tagliacotian nose</form> <xpln lang="en">(an in&shy;
habitant of Bruxils had his
nose cut off in a cumbate,
and a new one of another
mans flesh set on in its sted,
by Taliacotius, a famous
Chirurgeon of Bononia.) a
nose of wax. Dr. Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tagus(pn)">Tagus</form> <xpln lang="en">a river in Spain,
parting Castile from Portugal,
where hath been found gra&shy;
vel like gold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tail(n)">Taile (from the French
<etym lang="fr"> Taille</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a cut or cut&shy;
ting)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifieth in our com&shy;
mon Law a kinde of inheri&shy;
tance in Fee, opposite to Fee&shy;
simple, when a man holds
certain lands in taile, that
is, to him, and to the heires
of his body lawfully begot&shy;
ten. This taile is as it were
cut from Fee-simple or free
inheritance, because it is
not in the tenants free power
to dispose of those lands, be&shy;
ing as it were taille cut from
him or divided by the first
giver, and entailed or tyed
on his issue, &amp;c. Taile is ei&shy;
ther general or special,
whereof you may read at
large in Littleton, termes of
the Law, and other Law
books.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tail(n)">Tailes.</form> <xpln lang="en">Kentish men are
said to have tailes, which thus
took its origen; St. Thomas of 
Canterbury being in disfavor
with Hen. the second, rode from
the Court towards Canterbury
upon a poor jade, and some
common people, the more to
vilifie him, cut off his horse
tail, for which crime the suc&shy;
cessors of those people are said
to have had tails, as a judge&shy;
ment from heaven for some
generations, now long since
ceased; And from hence the
French do in derision call us
in general <etym lang="fr"> Coudar&eacute;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tallage(n)">Tailage, orTallage (from
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">taille</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a tax, task, tri&shy;
bute or imposition. Hence
also <emend err="Taulagiers" source="errata">Tailagiers</emend> in Chaucer
for tax or toll-gathers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taint(n)">Tainct,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of red-co&shy;
loured spider so called, and
found in the Summer-time;
It is so little of body that ten
of the largest will hardly out&shy;
weigh a graine; this by
Country people is accounted
a deadly poison to cowes
and horses: but Doctor
Brown is not satisfied there&shy;
in. See his vulgar errours.
p.177.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talaria(n)">Talaries (<etym lang="la">talaria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">shooes
with wings, which Mercury
wore, as Poets feigne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talassion(n)">Talassion (<etym lang="la">talassio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a song
used to be sung at marriages.
See <xref>Thalassio</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talent(n)">Talent (<etym lang="la">talentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a va&shy;
lue of money, whereof there
were divers sorts; Among
the Greeks there were two
talents, the greater and the
lesse; the greater valued a&shy;
bout 233. l. sterl. the lesse a&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="qq2v">
bout 175 l. Among the He&shy;
brews the greater Talent of
the Sanctuary contained 400.
l. the lesser half so much,
Exod.25.39. It also signifies
a faculty or ability; as we
say, a man of good talents,
<expan type="">id est</expan> of good parts or abili&shy;
ties.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tally(n)">Taley orTally,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
 <etym lang="fr">taille</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> cut or slit; because a ta&shy;
ley is a score made of a stick
of wood slit in two pieces, to
keep account between two
parties; one part of it re&shy;
maining in the custody of
the one, and the other of the
other, so that the one cannot
score up any thing without
the other.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tallion(n)" lexeme="lex talionis(n)">Tallion, or <etym lang="la"> lex talienis</etym>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Law where each suffered what
they had done to others, eye
for eye, one bad turn for ano&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talisman(n)">Talismans (<class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab</class>.)</form> <xpln lang="en">ima&shy;
ges, or figures made under
certain constellations. See
Gaffarels curiosities. p.147
for their antiquity and use, see
See <xref lexeme="gamahe">Gamahes</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talismanical(a)">Talismanical</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging
to such Images.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tallage(n)">Tallage.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Tailage</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Talmud(pn)">Talmud or Thalmud (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">from
the Hebr.</class> <etym lang="he">&#x05d7;&#x05dc;&#x05de;&#x05d9;&#x05d3; talmid</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">disciplina</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a superstitious and
blasphemous book of the Je&shy;
wish Law, divised by their
Rabbins, and of great autho&shy;
rity among them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talwood(n)">Talwood</form> <xpln lang="en"> Anno 34, and
35. H.8. ca.3. &amp; A.7. Ed.
6. Ca.7. &amp; 42. Eliz. Ca.14.
Talshide, ibid m. It is a long
kinde of shide of wood, riven
out of the tree, which shortned
is made into billets. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tamarind(n)">Tamarinds (<etym lang="la">tamarindi</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a fruit brought hither out of
India like green damascens,
the tree whereof is like a date
tree, they are cold of opera&shy;
tion, and therefore good a&shy;
gainst burning feavers, and
all inward diseases proceed&shy;
ing of heat and choler.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tamarisk(n)">Tamarisk (<etym lang="la">tamarice</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
shrub, whereof there are
two kindes, the greater,
which beareth fruit like the
lesser oak apples or gals, the
lesse bearing gayish leaves
without fruit; The decocti&shy;
on of which lesser Tamarisk,
in wine and a litle vinegar
being drunk, is of great ver&shy;
tue against the hardnesse and
stopping of the spleen or milt.
Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tampoy(n)">Tampoy</form> <xpln lang="en">a curious sort of
drink in the Moluccaes and
Philippines made of a kind of
Gilliflowers . Mr. How. 2. vol.
of flowers.138.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tampion(n)">Tampeon or tampkin (Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Tampon</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a bung or stopple.
It is a small peece of wood,
turned fit for the mouth of a&shy;
ny peece of Ordnance, to 


</page>

<page sig="qq3r">
keep out raine or sea-wa&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tanacles(n)">Tanacles (from the Ital.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tangible(a)">Tangible (<etym lang="la">tangibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tanistry(n)">Tanistry (<etym lang="la">a thanis, viris a&shy;
pud Saxones honoratis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
Law or custom in Ireland,
which did not observe the
hereditary right of succession
among Princes and great per&shy;
sons, but he that had most
power, was eldest of the house,
and was most worthy of blood
and name, did inherit. Antiq.
Hib. p.38.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tantalize(v)">Tantalize.</form> <xpln lang="en">Poets feigne
Tantalus King of Phrygia to
have been the son of Jupiter
and the nymph Plota, and for
that he received the gods to
a banquet, and sod his own
son Pelops, and gave them
him to eat, Ceres only did
eat of the shoulder, the rest
forbearing that meat, yet
Pelops was restored to life
and received an ivory shoul&shy;
der for his own; and also
for that Tantalus discovered
the secrets of the gods to
men; therefore is he said to
be tormented in hell thus;
He stands up to the chin in
a pleasant river, and a tree
of faire fruit hanging over
him, and yet is he alwayes
plagu'd with hunger and
thirst, for when he either
stoops down to drink, or rea&shy;
ches out his hand to take an 
apple, they both so retire
that he cannot touch the one
or taste the other, therefore
he may be called Tantalus,
 <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1f71;&nu;&tau;&alpha;&tau;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">infelicis&shy;
simus</term>. Hence to be tantali&shy;
zed, is to be in the condition
of Tantalus, to be neer un&shy;
to, or in <emend err="some" source="errata"></emend> sight of some
happinesse or wished thing,
and yet not to be permitted
to enjoy it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tapinage(n)">Tapinage ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">secrecy,
a lurking, or lying close.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tapissant(a)">Tapissant ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">lurking,
lying, squatting, a terme of
hunting, with us called short&shy;
ly Tapis .</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED nut see "tapis" v.1.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taratantara(n)">Tara-tantara, or tarantara
(<class type="etymlang" lang="br">from the British</class><etym lang="br">Taran</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan>
thunder, or from<etym lang="br">taro</etym> and
<etym lang="br">taraw</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to strike, and so
may signifie as much as <term lang="la">per&shy;
cutiens, percute</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en"> it is a word
of encouragement to battel
which the trumpets do
(as neere as they can) i&shy;
mitate.</xpln></wordentry>

tara.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tarantula(n)">Tarantula ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a most
venemous spider, so called
of tarentum, a neapolitan
City, where they most a&shy;
bound; Some take it to be
a flie, whose sting is deadly;
yet curable by divers sounds
of musick. See more of this
in Sands Travels. fol.249.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tardigrade(a)">Tardigrade (<etym lang="la">tardigradus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that goeth slow, or hath a
slow pace.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="qq3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tardiloquent(a)">Tardiloquent (<etym lang="la">tardiloquus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that speaks slowly or draws
his speech out at length.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tardity(n)">Tardity (<etym lang="la">tarditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">slow&shy;
nesse, slacknesse, hindering
or delaying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tarpaulin(n)">Tar-pawling</form> <xpln lang="en">is a peece
of canvasse tar'd all over to
lay upon the deck of a
ship to keep the raine from
soaking through.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tarshish(pn)">Tarshish</form> <xpln lang="en">the Ocean or
main Sea, Psal.48.9. Break the
ships of Tarshish . Tarshish
was the name of the sonne
of Javan, the sonne of
Japheth, the sonne of Noah,
Gen.10.4. of whom Tarsus a
City of Cicilia in Syria, had
the name, Acts 21.34. from
thence they went by shipping
into far countreys, Africa,
Judea, Ophir, &amp;c. 1 Kings
27.48. and 10.22. Hereupon
that sea was called Tarshish,
and generally the name is ap&shy;
plied to every Ocean. Wil&shy;
son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terrace(n)">Tarrasse (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Terrasse</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
bank or heap of earth, but
most usually an open galle&shy;
ry or place to walk in, com&shy;
monly above ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tartar(n)">Tarter (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Tartre</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Lees or dregs that stick to
the sides of wine vessels: hard
and dry like a crest; sound
and so close compacted that
you may beat it into pou&shy;
der; called also Argal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tartarine(a)" lexeme="Tartarean(a)">Tartarine

<etym lang="la"> 
(tartarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of hell, hellish, terrible.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tiercel(n)">Tassel</form> <xpln lang="en">or Tiercel (Fr. <etym lang="fr">tier&shy;
celet</etym>) the male of any kinde
of hawk; so termed, because
in bignes or strength of body,
he is commonly a third part
lesse then the female.</xpln></wordentry>

taining to a web. Dr Brown
speaks of Telary spiders, that
is, such as weave cobwebs.

more hardy then needs, and
wisdom requires, foolhardy,
rash, indiscreet unadvised.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temerity(n)">Temerity (<etym lang="la">temeritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">rash&shy;
nesse, fool-hardinesse, <emend err="unad">unad&shy;</emend>
visednesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tempe(pn)">Tempe,</form> <xpln lang="en">a pleasant and
most delightful place in Thes&shy;
saly, held to be the muses gar&shy;
den, whence all pleasant
woods and fields are given
that name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temperament(n)">Temparament (<etym lang="la"><emend err="tempara" source="errata">temperam</emend>&shy;
mentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a moderation, mean
or measure: a proportion of
the four chief qualities of the
body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temperamental(a)">Temparamental,</form> <xpln lang="en">pertain&shy;
ing to temperament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temperance(n)">Temperance (<etym lang="la">temperantia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
moderation, refraining of
sensuality and unruly affecti&shy;
ons, sobernesse. 

Temperance is a vertue, which
rules the appetite, and bridles
our sensual delights, and
makes a man content to mo&shy;
derate himself in them ac&shy;
cording to reason. Tour.
Cat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temperature(n)">Temperature (<etym lang="la">temperatu&shy;
ra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">moderation in mingling
things together; good disposi&shy; 
tion, temperatenesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tempestivity(n)">Tempestivity (<etym lang="la">tempestivi&shy; 
tas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">season or time conveni&shy;
ent opportunity, fitnesse of
time, seasonableness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Templary(pn)" lexeme="Temple, Knight of the(pn)">Templaries, or Knights
of the Temple (<etym lang="la">Templarii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
certaine religious Christian&shy;
souldiers dwelling about the
Temple at Hierusalem, and
therefore so called, whose of&shy;
fice and vow was to defend
the Temple of Hierusalem and
holy Sepulchre, and to en&shy;
tertain Christian stranges
that came thither for devoti&shy;
on, to guard them in safe&shy;
ty, when they went to visit
the places of the holy land:
Their habit was a white cloak
or upper garment with a red
crosse and a sword girt about
them, as you may see in
Mr. Dugdales Antiquities of
Warwickshire. This order was
instituted by Pope Gelatius
about the yeer of our Lord
1117. or 1120. After it had
flourished about two hundred
yeers, it was suppressed by
Clement the fifth. 

These Templars first founded
and built the Temples or Tem&shy;
plars Inne in Fleetstreet, which
without controversie is the
most ancient of all the Innes
of Court, and though they
were divided into three seve&shy;
ral Houses, that is the Inner
Temple, the Middle Temple, and
the Outward Temple (which
last is now converted into
Essex house) yet were they
at first all but one house; 


</page>

<page sig="qq4v">
in which these Knights lived
in great honour and opulency
about one hundred yeares;
For they had many Castles,
Lordships and Seignories
belonging to them and their
order in many parts of Eng&shy;
land; and the Master of this
Order was a Baron of this
Nation; their Church, yet
standing, was dedicated to the
service of God by Heraclius,
Patriarch of Hierusalem, Anno
Dom.1185. After the suppres&shy;
sion of these Templars, their
lands were (by a general
Council held at Vienna) con&shy;
ferred on the other more <emend err="an"> an&shy;</emend>
cient religious Knights of
the Order of Saint John of
Hierusalem, called also Joan&shy;
nites, and after Knights of
Rhodes, and lastly of Malta,
where they live at this day. 
And this cannon of the Coun&shy;
cel was confirmed to the
Knights of Saint John resi&shy;
ding here in England by Act
of Parliament made 17. Edw.2.
In the reigne of Edw. the
third (after several noble
persons had in this interval
been tenants and occupants
of the Temple-Innes) certain
of the Reverend ancient Pro&shy;
fessours of the Laws obtain&shy;
ed a very large, or perpetual
Lease of this Temple, or of
two parts thereof, distin&shy;
guished by the names of the
Middle and Inner Temple, from
the said Joannites (then re&shy;
siding in their goodly house
called the Priory of Saint 
Johns of Hierusalem, neere
Smithfield) to pay yearly ten
pounds. 

These Knights Templars
bore for their Armes, A
Shield Argent, charged with a
crosse gules, and upon the
nombreil of it, a holy Lamb.
And Matth. Paris saith, on
their common seal was engra&shy;
ven a horse with two men
riding on him. But the so&shy;
ciety of the Inner Temple
have taken for their en&shy;
signe or devise, A Pegasus or
flying horse, sable or gules,
upon a Shield Or. Stow. O&shy;
ver the door of the Temple&shy;
Church was this inscription
in ancient characters, remain&shy;
ing legible till April 1656.
when the cloister was new
whited and this defaced.
<term lang="la">Anno ab incarnatione domini
MCLXXXV. dedicata hec
Ecclesia in honorem beal&aelig;
Mari&aelig;, &agrave; Domino Eraclio Dei
gratia Sanct&aelig; resurrectionis
Ecclesie Patriarcha, quarto I&shy;
dus Februarii, qui eam an&shy;
natim petentibus, de injuncta
sibi penitentia, LX. dies in&shy;
dulsit</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temporaneous(a)">Temporaneous (<etym lang="la">tempora&shy;
neus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">done suddenly, at a
certaine time, pertaining to
time; variable for the
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temporary(a)">Temporary (<etym lang="la">temporarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
in time, at the houre ap&shy;
pointed, temporal, tempo&shy;
reous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temporality(n)">Temporalities</form> <xpln lang="en">of Bishops,
were such revenues as Bi&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="qq5r">
shops had laid to their Sees
by the Kings and other great
personages, as they were
Lords of the Parliament.
See <xref lexeme="spiritualty of a bishop">spiritualities of Bi&shy;
shops</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temporize(v)">Temporize (from <etym lang="la">tempus,
oris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to observe, agree with,
or apply himself to the time;
to seek to please the times,
to live as the times go; Also
to linger or protract the
time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temporizer(n)">A Temporizer.</form> <xpln lang="en">He that
doth so, a time-server.</xpln></wordentry>

drunkennesse.</xpln></wordentry>

 (<etym lang="la">temulen&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">drunken, cupshot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenacious(a)">Tenacious (<etym lang="la">tenax, acis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that holds fast, long and sted&shy;
fast, good and sure, clammy,
glewish; also hard to be mo&shy;
ved, stiff necked.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenacity(n)">Tenacity (<etym lang="la">tenacitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">fast&shy;
keeping, sure holding, nig&shy;
gardlinesse, misery; also con&shy;
stancy, stedfastnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tend(v)">Tend (<etym lang="la">tendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to extend, to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tendon(n)">TendonsorTendines
 (Lat. <etym lang="la">tendones</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">certain instru&shy;
ments of moving in the top of
muscles, made of sinews and
ligatures, and knitting them
to the bones, they are har&shy;
der then sinews, and not so
hard as ligatures. Thom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenderling(n)">Tenderlings.</form> <xpln lang="en">The soft tops
of a Deers hornes when they
are in blood, any living things
that are nesh and tender.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tendrel(n)">Tendrels (from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">tendron</etym>, or <etym lang="fr"> tendrillo</etym>, or Lat.
 <etym lang="la">tenendo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">little sprigs of vines
or other plants, wherewith
they take hold to grow or
stay themselves up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenebrio(n)">Tenebrion (<etym lang="la">tenebrio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one
that will not be seen by day,
a lurker, a night-thief; also a
night-spirit, a hobgoblin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenebres(n)">Tenebres. (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">&agrave; tenebr&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
darknesse, obscurity; Also the
service or mattins used in the
Roman Church on Wednesday,
Thursday and Fryday before
Easter, <emend err="and" source="errata"></emend> are cal'd tenebr&aelig;,
(and thence tenebr&aelig;, wednes&shy;
day, thursday, &amp;c.) as be&shy;
ing begun with many lights,
and ending in darknesse, re&shy;
presenting the nightly time
of our blessed Saviours ap&shy;
prehension in the garden
Gethsemani; in which office
are lighted at the first on
a triangular candlestick
fifteen candles, vid. as
many as there are Psalmes and
Canticles in the office, and
at the end of every Psalme 
one of the fifteen lights is ex&shy;
tinguished till they be all put
out; so to shew the forsaken
desolate state of our blessed
Saviour in his passion, all the
light or comfort of his
friends leaving him, or being
forced from him for a time,
and he left alone <term lang="la">sub potestate
tenebrarum</term>, under the pow&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="qq5v">
er of darknesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenebrosity(n)">Tenebrosity (<etym lang="la">tenebrositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
great darknesse or obscurity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenebrous(a)">Tenebrous  (<etym lang="la">tenebrosus</etym>)</form> 
<xpln lang="en">very close, dark or obscure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenerity(n)">Tenerity (<etym lang="la">teneritas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">softness,
tendernesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenn&eacute;(n)">Tenne,</form> <xpln lang="en">a terme used by He&shy;
rals, signifying an orange or
tawny colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenon(n)">Tenon,</form> <xpln lang="en">that part of a Post
or rafter which is put into a
mortise hole, to make it stand
upright, or to bear it up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenor(n)">Tenor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a continual
order, form, fashion, trade,
state or race; Also the con&shy;
tent or substance of a mat&shy;
ter. 

The tenor part in musick
is that which is next above
the base. 

The order in consort-vo&shy;
cal musick is thus: 1. Base ;
2. Tenor; 3. Counter-tenor ;
4. Mean or Contra-alto. 5.
Trebble or Alto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tensile(a)">Tensile (<etym lang="la">tensus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">stretched
out, bent, strouting out.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tent(n)">Tent</form> <xpln lang="en">hath divers significa&shy;
tions. 

As first (from <etym lang="la">tentorium</etym>) it
signifies a Pavillion or tent
for War, commonly made of
sackcloth or such like. 

Secondly, Tent which Chi&shy;
rurgions put into a wound,
which comes from (<etym lang="la">tento</etym>, to
try) because it tries how wide
or deep the wound is. 

Thirdly, Jewellers call that
Tent which they put under
Table Diamonds when they 
set them in work, and is made
of mastick and turpentine. 

Fourthly, Tent or tinet 
wine, which is kinde of Ali&shy;
gant, though not so good as
pure Alignant, and is a gener&shy;
al name for all wines in Spain,
except white from the Span. 
( <term lang="la">vino tinto</term>) <expan type="">id est</expan> a deep red&shy;
wine. 

Fifthly, Tent (from <etym lang="la">tentum</etym>)
a mans privy member.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tentative(n)">Tentative (from <etym lang="la">tento</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
posing (for the passing) of
graduates; a probation or ex&shy;
mination of such as are to
take degree, or that tries or
examines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenths(n)">Tenths (<etym lang="la">decim&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is that
yearly portion of tribute,
which all Ecclesiastical li&shy;
vings yeeld to the King, A.
26. H.8. ca.3. The Levites 
paid them to their high
Priests, Numb. ca.8. Milron.
in Ezekiel. It signifies also a tax
levied of the temporalty. Ho&shy;
lingshed. H.2. fol. III.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tentorian(a)">Tentorian (<etym lang="la">tentorianus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">be&shy;
longing to a tent or pavilli&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenuate(v)">Tenuate (<etym lang="la">tenuo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
small, thin or slender; to make
leane or feeble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenuious(a)" lexeme="tenuous(a)">Tenuious 
Tenuous 
 (<etym lang="la">tenuis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">slen&shy;
der, thin, low, lean, poore,
sparing, smal, of no estimati&shy;
on. <expan type="">Lord</expan> Bac. and Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenuity(n)">Tenuity (<etym lang="la">tenuitus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">smal&shy;
nesse, poverty, leannesse, thin&shy;
nesse, finenesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenure(n)">Tenure (from <etym lang="la">tenere</etym>, to 


</page>

<page sig="qq6r">
hold)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the manner where&shy;
by tenements are holden of
their Lords. What may make
a tenure, and what not, See
Perkins reservations 70. and
in that Chapter you shall
finde the most of those tenures
recited, that are now usual in
England. And for the tenures
of Scotland, See Cow. in
Tenure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tepefy(v)">Tepefie (<etym lang="la">tepesacio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make warme.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tepid(a)">Tepid (<etym lang="la">tepidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">mean be&shy;
tween cold and hot, luke&shy;
warm; also cold and nothing
earnest in a matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tepidity(n)">Tepidity (<etym lang="la">tepeditas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">luke&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terebinthine(a)">Terebinthine (<etym lang="la">terebinthi&shy;

or awger, to pierce to thirle,
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terebration(n)">Terebration (<etym lang="la">terebratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tergeminous(a)">Tergeminous (<etym lang="la">teregeminus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

the three borne at the same
time. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tergiductor(n)">Tergiductor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tergiment(n)">Tergiment (<etym lang="la">tergimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that which is put into the
scales to make weight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tergiversation(n)">Tergiversation (<etym lang="la">tergiversa&shy; 
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a flinching, withdrawing,
shifting, slinking, shrinking
back or dodging, a non-suite
in Law, a hasting, a running<emend err="a"> a&shy;</emend> 
way, yet fighting still.<xref> See Ca&shy;
lumniate</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terminals(n)">Terminals (<etym lang="la">terminalia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
feasts instituted to the honour
of the God <etym lang="la">terminus</etym>, and kept
in February at the eighth ca&shy;
lends of March, because be&shy;
tween <term lang="la">terminalia</term> and <term lang="la">refugi&shy;
um</term>, the <emend err="old" source="errata">odde</emend> dayes of the leap
year were put in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terminate(v)">Terminate (<etym lang="la">termino</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to end,
to finish, to bound, to appoint
or assigne bounds or matches,
to limit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Terminus(pn)">Terminus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the God of
hounds who was wont to end
the strifes and controversies
of countrey people in divi&shy;
ding their lands. See Lactanti&shy;
us l. I. c.20.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ternary(a)" lexeme="ternarious(a)">Ternary

 (<etym lang="la">ternarius</etym>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to three.</xpln></wordentry>

ber of three.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terra sigillata(n)">Terra-sigillata ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
earth brought from the Isle
Lemnos, it was used to be sent
from thence sealed, therefore
called sigillata, and said to be
good for curing wounds,
stopping fluxes, expelling poi&shy;
sons, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terr&aelig;-filius(n)">Terre-filius (<expan type="">id est</expan> son of the

that lives on the earth, or is

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terrar(n)" lexeme="terrer(n)">TerrarorTerrer (from 


</page>

<page sig="qq6v">
 <etym lang="la">terra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a particular or survey
of a Mannor, or of ones whole
estate of lands, containing the
quantity of acres and boun&shy;
daries thereof; sometimes u&shy;
sed for a suit-roll, or cata&shy;
logue of all the tenants and
residents names within a
Mannor, and what lands they
hold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terre-tenant(n)">Terre-tenant (<etym lang="la"><expan type="">id est</expan> tenens ter&shy;
ram</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is he, who hath the natu&shy;
ral actual possession of the
land, which we otherwise call
the occupation. Anno 39. Eliz.
cap.7. For example, A Lord
of a Mannor hath a Freeholder
who lets out his free land to
another to be occupied, this
occupier is called the Terre
tenant. West. part 2. Simb. tit.
Fines Sect.137. Cromp. Jurisd
fol.197. Perkins Feofments.
231.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terricrepant(a)">Terricrepant (<etym lang="la">terricrepus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

terly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="testaceous(a)"><emend err="Testareous" source="errata">Testaceous</emend> (<etym lang="la"><emend err="testareus" source="errata">testaceus</emend></etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">made
of tile, brick, or baked earth;
that hath a shell. Testaceous
animals, are such as have
shells, As all shel-fish, snailes,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="testament(n)">Testament (<etym lang="la">testamentum</etym> 
<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">testatio mentis</term>, the witnesse
of the minde, as the last Will
and Testament is, of which
there are two sorts, viz.
nuncupatory, and in writing <emend err=";">); </emend></form> <xpln lang="en">
The first is when a man being
sick, and for fear lest death,
want of memory or speech
should come so suddenly up&shy;
on him, that he should be
prevented, if he staid the wri&shy;
ting his Will, desireth his
neighbours and friends to
beare witnesse of his last Will,
and then declares the same by
words before them; which af&shy;
ter his decease being proved
by the witnesses, and put
in writing by the Ordinary.
stands in as good force (ex&shy;
cept for lands) as if it had in
his life time been put in wri&shy;
ting &amp;c. Of this reade a
Treatise of Wills, and the duty
of Executors, compiled by
Master Wentworth of Linc.
Inne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="testamentarious(a)">Testamentarious (<etym lang="la">testa&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="qq7r">
mentarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of, or belong&shy;
ing to a Testament or last
Will.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thalassion(n)">Thalassion [ <etym lang="la">thalassio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a

Bridals or weddings in Rome,
as an auspicate or lucky word;
like this among the Greeks,
 <term lang="la">Hymen O Hymen&aelig;e, Hymen,
&amp;c.</term> Catul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thavies Inn(pn)">Thavies Inne in Holborn,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">is one of the eight Innes of
Chancery, it was anciently the
house of one John Thavie, an
Armourer, of whom it was
rented in Edward the third's
time, by some professours of
the Law, but about Henry
the seventh's time, it was pur&shy;
chased by the Benchers of
Lincolnes Inne, for the Stu&shy;
dents and other professours
of the Law of Chancery, and
still retaines the name of
the old owner Master Tha&shy;
vie. The Armes of this
house are Azure, two garbs
in saltoror, with a T. argent,
in a chief Sables Stow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theater(n)">Theater [ <etym lang="la">theatrum</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
place made halfe round, where
people assembled to behold
playes and solemne games;
a stage or scaffold. See <xref>Amphi&shy;
theater</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theatral(a)" lexeme="theatrical(a)">Theatral

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theatins(pn)">Theatins,</form> <xpln lang="en">an order of
religious persons, which be&shy;
gan about the time of Pope 
Clement the seventh. So cal&shy;
led, because they were first
instituted by John Peter&shy;
Caraff, who was first Bishop
of Theace in the Kingdome
of Naples, and afterwards
Pope Paul the fourth. Spir.
Conflict.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theft-boot(n)">Theft-bote (fromtheft
andboote, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">compensatio</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">sig&shy;
nifieth the receiving of
goods from a theef, to the
end to favour and maintaine
him; the punishment wher&shy;
of is ransome and imprison&shy;
ment, and not losse of life
and member. Stawnf. pl.
Cor. lib. prin. Ca.43. And
the mirror of Justices. lib.
2. Cap. des peches criminels
al suite le roy. And yet he
there makes mention of a re&shy;
cord aledged which testified a
judgment of life and member
given this in case.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thelemite(n)">Thelemite [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a liber&shy;
tine, one that does what he
list</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Themis(pn)">Themis,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Godesse of

in B&oelig;otia. 

Note that Theos in Greek
is Deus, God; with which
we have many words com&shy;
pounded. As,</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theoderic(pn)">Theoderic [<class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Germ.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">con&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodore(pn)">Theodore [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">Gods gift,
a mans name, now corruptly
by Welsh Britans called
Tydder, Caw. I think this
but a weak conceit of Cam&shy;
den, the Britans sayTudur,
which may come fromTaw&shy;
dwr, signifying grossenesse or
fat, and so signifies a fat or
grosse man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theogony(n)">Theogonie  [ <etym lang="la">theogonia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theologaster(n)">Theologaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theology(n)">Theology [ <etym lang="la">theologia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">di&shy;
vinity, reasoning, or science

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theologue(n)" lexeme="theologer(n)">Theologue 
or, 
Theologer [ <etym lang="la">theologus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Divine, a Professor of Divi&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theological(a)">Theological (<etym lang="la">theologicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
pertaining to Divinity. 

Faith, Hope and Charity are
called the Theological vertues,
because they have their ob&shy;
ject and end in God: For
the object of faith is Gods
veracity or infallibility in
speaking truth; the object of
hope is Gods infinite inclina&shy;
tion to do good to all; the
object of charity is Gods infi&shy;
nite perfection, whereby he is
worthy of al love. Tourney Cat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theologize(v)">Theologize,</form> <xpln lang="en">to preach or
play the Divine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theomachy(n)">Theomachy [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a war&shy;
ring or fighting against the 
gods, as the old Giants are
feigned to have done.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theomagical(a)">Theomagical [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the wisdome of
God, or that works wonders
by his help. Enth. Trium.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theomancy(n)">Theomancy, [ <etym lang="la">theomancia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a kinde of divination or in&shy;
chanting by abusive calling
upon the secret, farfetched
mysterious and wrested names
of God. Florio.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theominy(n)">Theominy [ <etym lang="la">theominia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
the anger or wrath of God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theophilus(pn)">Theophilus [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">loving

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theorbo(n)">Theorba [from the Ital.

instrument different from the
Lute, in that the head, or
part of the head of this bends
back, and the head of that is
commonly strait.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theorem(n)">Theoreme [ <etym lang="la">theorema</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
speculation; any actione or
undoubted truth of an art;
but particularly as it is op&shy;
posed to problema that which
respects contemplation more
then practice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theorematic(a)" lexeme="theoretic(a)">Theorematick 
 or 
Theoretick 
 [ <etym lang="la"><emend err="theore">theore&shy;</emend>
maticus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to a theo&shy;
reme, or to contemplation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theoremist(n)">Theoremist,</form> <xpln lang="en">a professor
of Theoremes or axioms of
undoubted truth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theory(n)">Theory [ <etym lang="la">theoria</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">specu&shy;
lation, contemplation and
knowledge of an art without
practice, deep study, a sight
or beholding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theosophical(a)">Theosophical [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">from the Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="qq8v">
wise in things belonging to
God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="therapeutic(a)">Therapeutick (<etym lang="la">therapen&shy;
ticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">curing, healing. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="teraphim(n)">Therephim,</form> <xpln lang="en">an image

Judg.17.5. made an Ephod
and Theraphim.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theriacal(a)">Theriacal [ <etym lang="la">theriacus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">of a

or belonging to triacle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thermefy(v)">Thermefy [ <etym lang="la">thermefacio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
to chase or make one hot
with outragious eating and
drinking hot things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thermopolist(n)">Thermopolist [ <etym lang="la">thermopila</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thesaurize(v)">Thesaurize (<etym lang="la">thesaurizo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thesiphone(pn)">Thesiphone,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thesis(n)">Thesis [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a general and
indefinite question, argument
or position.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="theta(n)">Theta [<etym lang="gk">&Theta;</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a greek letter,
answering to [th] with us,
used as a mark for persons
condemned to death, (being
the first letter of the Greek
word <etym lang="gk">&delta;&#x03ac;&nu;&alpha;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">mors</term>) or for
faults in Writings or Books, as
the letter L. for lands or lau&shy;
dabilia ; select words and sen&shy;
tences. Sidon. 
 <term lang="la">Et potis es nigrum sititio pr&aelig;&shy;
figere, Theta Persi&aelig;</term> . 
</xpln>
<lemenote>
The errata indicate that one should read "vitio" somewhere in this word-entry.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thetis(pn)">Thetis,</form> <xpln lang="en">sometimes used for
the Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

der the Thills of the Cart to
beare them up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thole(n)">Thole [ <etym lang="la">tholus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a knot in
the midst of a timber vault,
where the ends of the posts
meet, called a Scutchin: a
Pinacle, a Tabernacle; Also
that place in Temples, where
donaries &amp; such gifts as were
presented there, are hung up,
El. Ar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thomas(pn)">Thomas [<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies
twin, or as some will have it
bottomlesse deep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thoracic(a)">Thorachique [from <etym lang="la">thorax,

or stomack. Thorachique vein

tery</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thor(pn)">Thor</form> <xpln lang="en">was an idol of great
esteem among the old Saxons 
and Teutonicks, and the day
now called Thursday was de&shy;
dicated to his peculiar service,
and thence took denominati&shy;
on, which the Danes and
Swedes yet callThursday;
He was also called the God of
thunder, whence in the Ne&shy;
ther-lands the day is called
Dundersdagh, orThunders&shy;
day. Verstegan.60,61.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thorp(n)">Thorp [<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a vilage or
country town; we have ma&shy;
my villages especially in Lei&shy;
cester and Nottingham-shires,
that still retain this ancient
name; And in Holland they cal
itDorp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thrasonical(a)">Thrasonical [ <etym lang="la">thrasonicus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
vain-glorious, boasting,
cracking, Thraso-like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thrave(n)">Thrave of corn,</form> <xpln lang="en">was too
Shocks of six sheaves apeece, 


</page>

<page sig="rr1r">
Stat.2. H.6. ch 2. The word
comes from the British Dre&shy;
va, <expan type="">id est</expan> twenty foure. In most
Counties of England 24.
sheaves do now go to a
Thrave. Twelve sheaves make
aStook, and twoStooks a
Thrave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threne(n)">Threne<etym lang="la"> threnum</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">lamen&shy;
tation; also a lamentable
verse or song; a funeral song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threnody(n)">Threnody [ <etym lang="la">threnodia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
mourning song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threnetic(a)">Threnetick [ <etym lang="la">threneticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
mournful, lamentable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threap(v)">Threpe [<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to affirme
positively, or to face one
down with confidence; still
used in the North.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="third-borough(n)">Third-borow</form> <xpln lang="en">is used for a
Constable, A 28. H.8. Ca.10
which also is noted by Master
Lambert in his Duty of Con&shy;
stables, pag 6. and seemes to
be corruptly used for the Saxon 
(<etym lang="sx">Free-borh</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">ingenuus fide
jussor</term>,) <xref> See Headborow</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

rise often, as the heart doth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thrones(pn)">Thrones [ <etym lang="la">throni</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">have the
<emend err="the"></emend> third ranck in the cele&shy;
stial Hierarchy, whom toge&shy;
ther with Dominations, Prin&shy;
cipalities and Powers, Saint
Paul mentions; They signi&shy;
fie Majesty, on whom God
is said to sit. Thou sittest, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

incense.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thymous(a)">Thymous [ <etym lang="la">thymosus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">full

led.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thyrse(n)">Thyrse [ <etym lang="la">thyrsus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">though
it may beare divers signifi&shy;
cations, yet Mr. Herrick in
his Poems uses it for a Jave&shy;
lin wrapped with Ivy, which
the flock of drunken Harlots
bare in Bacchus his Sacrifice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tiara(n)">Tiara [<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a round Or&shy;
nament for the head, which
Princes, Priests, and women
of old time ware. Hence we
still call it a tire for a womans
head, and a tiring-woman . It
is sometimes used for the
Popes triple Crown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tibial(a)">Tibial [ <etym lang="la">tibialis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">of, or
belonging to pipes; meet to
make pipes of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tibicinate(v)">Tibicinate [ <etym lang="la">tibicino</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
sing or pipe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tick-tack(n)">Ticktack [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> trictrac</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a game at Tables so called,
not from the sudden remo&shy;
ving the men and the snap&shy;
ping noise they make, as Min.
would have it; but ticktock 
 <term lang="la">quasi</term>, touch and take, that
being the law of the game,
if you touch a man, you must
play him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tide(n)">Tide [<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">time. See <xref lexeme="spring tide">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tierce(n)">Tierce [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> tiers</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a cer&shy;
tain measure of liquid things, 


</page>

<page sig="rr1v">
as wine oyle, &amp;c. containing
the sixth part of a Tun. Anno
32. H.8. Ca.14. or the third
part of a Pipe, and from this
last it takes denomination,
because tiers in French signi&shy;
fies a third, or third part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tigrine(a)">Tigrine [ <etym lang="la">tigrinus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">of, or
like the swift beast called a
Tigre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="timariot(n)">Timariots,</form> <xpln lang="en">wheresoever
any land is conquered by the
Great Turk, it is divided in&shy;
to divers parts, and given
to those whom they call
Timariots for terme of life,
with obligation to serve on
horse-back wheresoever they
shall be summoned; This is
not much unlike our old te&shy;
nures of Knights service or
Escuage, but not hereditary;
according to the value of the
timar or feud, the Timariot is
to come in with one, two,
three, or more horses, &amp;c.
See Sir Hen. Blounts voiage
fol.65.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="timbrel(n)">Timbrel [<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">from the Belg.</class>

merousnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="timocracy(n)">Timocracy [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en"> <term lang="la">domina&shy;
tus, in quo &agrave; censu magistratus
creantur. Scap.</term> a government
wherein the Magistrates were
created by their riches.</xpln></wordentry>

re</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a clashing or crashing, a
rustling or gingling noise,
made in the fall of wooden
stuff, or vessels of mettal. Mr.
How.</xpln></wordentry>
