cheese. Flo.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tissue(n)">Tissu ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> woven or plait&shy;
ed)</form> <xpln lang="en">with us cloth of tissu is
cloth of silk and silver, or of
silk and gold woven toge&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Titan(pn)">Titan,</form> <xpln lang="en">used of Poets for
the Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Titanic(a)">Titanick [ <etym lang="la">titaniacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of, 


</page>

<page sig="rr2r">
or belonging to the Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tithe(n)">Tithe (<etym lang="la">decim&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">seemes to
be an abreviate of tithing, be&shy;
ing the Saxon [Teothung]
a little altered, which signi&shy;
fies decuriam, a tithing. Lam.
Expl. of Sax. words, verbo de&shy;
curia. It signifies the tenth
part of all fruits predial or
personal, &amp;c. See Cowel upon
this word, and Sir Henry spel&shy;
man de non temerandis Eccle&shy;
siis, and Mr. Seldens History
of Tithes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tithing(n)">Tithing [<class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class><etym lang="sx">Teothung</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifies (sayes Lambert) the
number or company of ten
men, with their families cast
and knit together in a soci&shy;
ety, all of them being bound
to the King, for the peaceable
and good behaviour of each
of their society; of these com&shy;
panies there was one chiefe
or principal person, who of
his office was called (Teo&shy;
thung-man) at this day in the
West parts (tithing-man,) but
now he is nothing but a Con&shy;
stable; for that old discipline
of tithings is left long since.
It also signifies a Court. Anno
23. Ed.3. Ca.4.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="titillation(n)">Titillation [ <etym lang="la">titillatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
tickling, a stirring, a pleasant
moving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="titubate(v)">Titubate (<etym lang="la">titubo</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to stag&shy;
ger in going, to stumble; and
by metaphor to stutter or
stammer in speaking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="titular(a)">Titular (from <etym lang="la">titulus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that beareth a title one&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tobacco(n)">Tobaco or Tobacco (<term lang="la">sic 
vocatur in omnibus linguis</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
drug too well known in Eng&shy;
land since the yeare 1585.
when the Mariners of Sir
Francis Drake first brought it
hither from the Indies, where
some affirm there is an Island
called Tobacco, and abound&shy;
ing with it, whence the
drug took denomination, if
not, the Island so called from
the drug.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tobias(pn)">Tobias [<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Hebr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the Lord
is good.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tod(n)">Tod</form> <xpln lang="en">of wool is a quanti&shy;
ty containing twenty eight
pounds in weight, or two
stone.<xref> See Stone</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tolzey(pn)">Tolseyor Toldsey</form> <xpln lang="en">is a place
in the City of Bristow, an&shy;
swerable to the old Exchange 
in London, where the Mer&shy;
chants meet; And may per&shy;
haps be so called, because
oft-times there is money told 
upon the heads of round posts
or pillars made for that pur&shy;
pose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tolutation(n)">Tolutation [ <etym lang="la">tolutatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">an
ambling pace, a going easie.
Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tolutiloquence(n)">Tolutiloquence [ <etym lang="la">tolutilo&shy;
quentia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a smooth or nimble
kinde of speaking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toman(n)">Toman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of coine
among the Persians valuing
3. l. 6. sh. sterl. Herb. tra.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tome(n)">Tome [ <etym lang="la">tomus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">properly a
severing or dividing. When
an Authour has wrote a book,
which being altogether, would
be too great and unweildy,
he commonly divides it into
several Tomes or Parts.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="rr2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tomboy(n)">Tomboy</form> <xpln lang="en">(a girle or wench
that leaps up and down like
a boy) comes from the Saxon 
tumbe, to dance, andtumbod,
danced; hence also comes the
word tumbling, still in use.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tomentitious(a)">Tomentitious [ <etym lang="la">tomentitius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
made of flocks or wool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tomin(n)">Tomin ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">six penny
weight, or the weight of a Spa&shy;
nish real. Among Jewellers it
is taken for three Carrats.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tonical(a)">Tonical (from <etym lang="la">tonus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to tone, note, tune or
accent. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tonitruate(v)">Tonitruate (<etym lang="la">tonitruo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
thunder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tonnage(n)">Tonnage</form> <xpln lang="en">is a custome or
impost due for Merchandize
brought or carried in Tuns
and such like vessels, from
or to other Nations, after
a certain rate in every Tun.
Anno 12. Edw.4. cap.3.
Anno 6. Hen.8. cap.14. Anno
I. Ed.6. cap.13. primo fac.
cap.33. I have heard it also
called a duty, due to the Ma&shy;
riners for the unloading
their ship arrived in any
Haven after a rate for every
Tun. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

kernels at the root of the

ons and swellings, occasioned

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="topaz(n)">Topaze (<etym lang="la">topazius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a<emend err="pre"> pre&shy;</emend>
tious stone, whereof there are
two kinds; one of the colour
of gold and the other of Saf&shy;
fron colour, not so good as
the first. It is written that
this stone being put into
seething water, so cooles it,
that one may presently put
his hand into it. Bul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tophet(pn)">Tophet (Heb. <etym lang="he">Toph</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a large
and wide place neer Hie&shy;
rusalem where Jewish Idola&shy;
ters (after the manner of
the Ammonites) burnt their
children and offered them up
to the idol Moloch, set up in
this Tophet, being in the val&shy;
ley of Hinnom, as we may read,
2 King.23.10. Jer.7.31, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="rr3r">
 <etym lang="sp">Tornada</etym>. <expan type="">id est</expan> a returne, or turn&shy;
ing about)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a sudden, vio&shy;
lent and forcible storme of

so termed by the Mariners;
and does most usually happen

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="torrent(n)">Torrent (<etym lang="la">torrens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">substan&shy;
tively, signifies a violent
stream coming down a hill,
caused by rain or snow; a
land or rain flood in summer
time; any strong ran&shy;
ning streame. Adjective&shy;
ly, burning or rosting; as in
Solinus it is used for the scort&shy;
ching time of Summer, <term lang="la">&AElig;stivo
torrente</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tournament(n)">Tournement ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a<emend err="turn"> turn&shy;</emend>
ing, rounding, revolution 


</page>

<page sig="rr3v">
a converting, changing, ex&shy;
changing, translating, a ben&shy;
ding or inclining towards.
It was in Queen Elizabeths
dayes an exercise in great
request among our Nobility,
called also justing or tilting,
&amp;c. but now is out of request.
See <xref>Turneament</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tournois(n)">Tournois [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a French
penny, the tenth part of a pen&shy;
ny sterling, which rate it
holds in all other words (as
the Sol or Livre) whereunto
it is joyned. In France they
say so much money Tournois,
as we say sterling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tract(n)">Tract [ <etym lang="la">tracta</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a line, or
thred, a discourse drawn out
in length. In the Masse it
is two or three versicles be&shy;
twixt the Epistle and Gospel;
and so called, because it is
sung with a slow, long, pro&shy;
tracted tone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tractate(n)">Tractate [ <etym lang="la">tractatus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">an

words; also a part of a book,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tradition(n)">Tradition [ <etym lang="la">traditio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
teaching, a doctrine which
is delivered to us from o&shy;
thers. In Divinity that is
called Tradition which is
delivered by hand to hand
from Christ or his Apostles to
the present age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traditive(a)">Traditive [ <etym lang="la">traditus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to tradition; as a tra&shy;
ditive Science, is a Science
delivered by word of mouth
from Father to sonne, or con&shy;
tinued, or left to posterity by
tradition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traduction(n)">Traduction (<etym lang="la">traductio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
conveying, from one place to
another, a translating; a
slandering, defaming or tradu&shy;
cing, a withdrawing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tragelaph(n)">Tragelaph (<etym lang="la">tragclaphus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the great and blackish deere
called a stone-buck, deer&shy;
goat, or goat-hart; because
conceived between a buck,
goat and the hind. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tragematopolist(n)">Tragematopolist (<etym lang="la">trage&shy;

</page>

<page sig="rr4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tragicomedy(n)">Tragecomedy (<etym lang="la">tragecom&aelig;&shy;
dia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a play that is half Tra&shy;
gedy and half Comedy ; such is
Amphitruo in Plautus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tragedy(n)">Tragedie [ <etym lang="la">trag&oelig;dia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
lofty kinde of poetry, so cal&shy;
led from<etym lang="gk">&tau;&rho;&#x1f79;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a goat, and
<etym lang="gk">&omega;&delta;&#x1f74;</etym>, an ode or song; because
the actors thereof had a goat
given them as a reward. The
differences between a Tragedy
and a Comedy are these;
First, in respect of the matter,
because a Tragedy treats of
exilements, murders, matters
of grief, &amp;c. a Comedy of love&shy;
toyes, merry fictions and pet&shy;
ty matters; In a Tragedy the
greatest part of the actors are
Kings and Noble persons;
In a <emend err="Comdy"> Comedy</emend>, private persons
of meaner state and con&shy;
dition. The subject of a Co&shy;
medy is often feigned, but of
a Tragedy it is commonly
true and once really perform&shy;
ed; The beginning of a
 Tragedy is calme and quiet,
the end fearful and turbu&shy;
lent; but in a Comedy con&shy;
trarily, the beginning is tur&shy;
bulent, and the end calm. 
Antesignanus. 

Both Comedies and Tra&shy;
gedies ought to have five Acts
and no more, according to
that of Horace. 

 <term lang="la">Nev&egrave; minor quinto, ne &ugrave;sit pro&shy;
ductior actu fabula---</term> 

These acts are divided into
several Scenes, which some&shy;
time fall out more, sometimes
fewer in every act; The de&shy;
finition of a Scene being
<term lang="la">Mutatio Personarum</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tragedian(n)">Tragedian (<etym lang="la">tragicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
maker or writer of Tragedies,
a Tragediographer ; Also the
actor of them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tragical(a)">Tragical (<etym lang="la">tragicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to Tragedies, cruel,
outragious. See <xref>Comical</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trajection(n)">Trajection (<etym lang="la">trajectio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
passing over, a conveying or
carrying over; also an in&shy;
terlacing or setting things
out of order.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trajectitious(a)">Trajectitious (<etym lang="la">trajectitius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to passage; As tra&shy;
jectitious mony, is that which
is carried over the sea at the
peril of the Creditor, whether
it were money indeed, or mo&shy;
ney turned into wares.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tralatitious(a)">Tralatitious [ <etym lang="la">tralatitius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
transferred or transposed: of
the common sort, ordinary,
vulgar. Apol. for learning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tralucency(n)">Tralucency,</form> <xpln lang="en">a shining tho&shy;
row, translucency. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tramontane(a)">Tramontane [ <etym lang="la">transmonta&shy;
nus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that dwels beyond the
mountaines or in the north,

fies, over, from one place to an&shy;

ration of our Saviour Christ,
doth not signifie the turning
or change of one figure or
shape into another, but as it
were a putting on an exceed&shy;
ing splendor and brightness
that made his blessed face
shine as the Sunne, and his
cloaths white as snow.</xpln></wordentry>

to another, a transmit&shy;
ting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transmute(v)">Transmute [ <etym lang="la">transmuto</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
to change from one place to
another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transnomination(n)">Transnomination [ <etym lang="la">trans&shy;
nominatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a changing of
name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transom(n)">Transome,</form> <xpln lang="en">a brow-post or
beame in building, that goes
overthwart. And in a ship it is
that timber which lies athwart
the stern.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transpeciate(v)">Transpeciate [from <etym lang="la">trans</etym>
and <etym lang="la">species</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to change forme
or shape.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="rr5r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transpiration(n)">Transpiration [ <etym lang="la">transpira&shy;
tio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">an evaporation or breath&shy;
ing forth. <term lang="la">Est totius corporis
veluti respiratio qu&aelig;dam per

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transpose(v)">Transpose [ <etym lang="la">transpono</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
remove from one place to a&shy;
nother, to alter the order
of a thing; a word much
used by Printers, when their
pages, lines or words are
misplac'd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tranvasation(n)">Tranvasation [ <etym lang="la">transvasa&shy;
tio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a turning, pouring or re&shy;

another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transubstantiation(n)">Transubstantiation [ <etym lang="la">tran&shy;
substantiatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a passage or con&shy;

another; as of bread into the
body of Christ, by the words
of consecration, according to
the doctrine of the Roma&shy;
nists.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="transvection(n)">Transvection [ <etym lang="la">transve&shy;

thwart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trepan(n)">Trappan.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Trepan</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Traskites(pn)">Traskites,</form> <xpln lang="en">certain late
hereticks so called from John
Trask, their first Master; 
He held it was not lawful to
do any thing forbidden in the
old Law, nor to keep the Chri&shy;
stian Sabboth; and to this
purpose one Theophilus Bra&shy;
born his fellow Sectary,
wrote a book in the yeare,
1632.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trave(n)">Trave (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Tra&shy;
v&eacute;e</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a bay of buildings)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
trevise or little roome made
purposely to shoo unbroken
horses in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traverse(v)">Traverse (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Traverser</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
to thwart or go overthwart,
to crosse or passe over, to go
to and again. In our com&shy;
mon Law it signifies some&shy;
times to make contradiction
or deny any point of the
matter wherewith one is
charged; sometime to over&shy;
throw or undo a thing done.
The formal words of this
Traverse in the first <emend err="sign fica-">significa&shy;</emend>
tion are, (<term lang="la">absque hoc</term>) without
that that any other matter or
thing, &amp;c. As is commonly
used in the later end of an&shy;
swers in Chancery, &amp;c.
See more of this in Cow&shy;
el, and in Kitchin, fol.
240.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traverse-board(n)">Travers-board,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a board
which they keep in the stee&shy;
ridge of a Ship, having the
thirty two points of the com&shy;
pass marked in it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="travested(a)">Travested (from the
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Travestir</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">disguised
or shifted in apparel; And
Metaphorically it may be
applyed to any thing 


</page>

<page sig="rr5v">
that is translated out of one
language into another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traumatic(a)">Traumatick (<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class> <etym lang="gk">&tau;&rho;&alpha;&upsilon;&shy;
&mu;&alpha;&tau;&iota;&kappa;&#x1f78;&#x03c2;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to wounds
or to the cure of wounds, vul&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treated(a)">Treated, (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">traict&eacute;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
handled or intreated of, con&shy;
tracted or agreed on; enter&shy;
tained, in which last sense it is
now much used, as to say, I was
nobly or kindly treated at such
a mans house, or had good
entertainment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trental(n)">Trental (from the lat.
 <etym lang="la">triginta</etym> or the Fr. <etym lang="fr">trente</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trepan(n)" lexeme="trepanned iron(n)">Trepan orTrepandiron
( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">trepan</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an instrument,
hauing a round and indented
edge, wherewith Chirurgions
open a fractured scull, and by
the help of a Lavatory (with
in it) raise up the crushed
and depressed parts thereof,
and take out peeces of bones
and clotted blood. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trepan(v)">To Trepan, or rather trap&shy; 
pan (<class type="etymlang" lang="it">from the Ital.</class> <etym lang="it">Trappare</etym> 
or <etym lang="it">trappolare</etym> <expan type="">id est</expan> to entrap, en&shy;
snare, or catch in a gin)</form> <xpln lang="en">in
the modern acception of
the word, it signifies to cheat,
or entrap in this manner; a
whore admits a man to be
naught with her, and in the
very instant, rings a Bell or
gives a watch word, and in
comes a Pander who pretends
to be her husband, and with
vapouring and threats, upon
the act of adultery, forces
money or bond from the de&shy;
luded third person. Some
take this word to be derived
from a Pander that does en&shy;
trap, or a trapping Pan&shy; 
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trepidate(v)">Trepidate (<etym lang="la">trepido</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
fear, to tremble, or quake for
fear, to be astonied.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trepidation(n)">Trepidation (<etym lang="la">trepidatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
fear, trembling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tressis-agaso(n)">Tressis-agaso ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

horse-keeper; a fellow of no
worth. Mr. How.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trestle(n)">Trestle (<etym lang="la">tripus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a three

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triacle(n)">Triacle (<etym lang="la">theriaca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a reme&shy;
dy against poison.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triangle(n)">Triangle (<etym lang="la">triangulum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a figure that hath three an&shy;
gles or corners, of which
there are six sorts. 

1. Equilateral, which is
when the three sides thereof
are of an equal length, and
the Angles all equal among
themselves. 

2. An Isoceles triangle, is 


</page>

<page sig="rr6r">
that which hath two equal
sides and two equal Angles
opposite to those sides. 

3. All irregular triangles, ha&shy;
ving three unequal sides and
angles, are known in Geome&shy;
try under the terme of Scale&shy;
num . 

4. An Oxugoneum, is a tri&shy;
angle having three acute an&shy;
gles. 

5. An Amblogoneum, is a tri&shy;
angle, having two acute an&shy;
gles and one obtuse. 

6. And lastly, an Orthogo&shy;
noum, is a triangle, which hath
one right angle. Enchir. of
Fortif.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triangular(a)">Triangular (<etym lang="la">triangularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath three corners, or is
three cornered.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triarchy(n)">Triarchie (<etym lang="la">triarchia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
government, where three are
in like authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triarch(n)">Triarck (<etym lang="la">triarchus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Master of a Ship with three
tops, or of a Galley that hath
three orders of oares.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Triarians(pn)">Triarians (<etym lang="la">triarii</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">Soul&shy;
diers that were alwaies set in
the Rereward, and were the
strongest men; they ever
fought standing, and bowing
somewhat their knees, as
if they would rather die,
then remove their places.
Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tribe(n)">Tribe (<etym lang="la">tribus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kindred
or company, that dwel toge&shy;
ther in one Ward or Liberty;
as the people of Rome were di&shy;
vided into 35. Tribes, Bands,
Wards, or Hundreds; It
seemeth in old time the same 
people were divided into
three parts onely, and that
this name Tribus did thence
first arise. Tho. Tribes in
Scripture signifie the posteri&shy;
ty of the twelve Sonnes of
Israel Psal.78.55. Numb.13.
3,5,16.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tribunal(n)">Tribunal ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a judge&shy;
ment-seat; it was a place e&shy;
rected on high in form of our
Pulpits, but many degrees
larger, and in the midst stood
the Sella Curulis <expan type="">id est</expan> the Ivory
chair, from whence the chief
Magistrate administred Ju&shy;
stice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tribune(n)">Tribune (<etym lang="la">tribunus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
name of two chief officers in
Rome; the first was Tribune of
the people, who was to defend
their liberties against the
power of the Nobles, and for
that cause had the gates of his
house alwayes open both day
and night, and was called
tribunus alebis ; the other was
called tribune of the Souldi&shy;
ers, who had charge to see
them well armed and ordered,
&amp;c. And of these there was
tribunus major &amp; minor, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tribunitial(a)">Tribunitial (<etym lang="la">tribunitius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to the Tribune.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tributary(n)">Tributary<etym lang="la"> 
(tributarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that payeth tribute, which is
money arising out of the
goods of the people, after their
ability.</xpln></wordentry>

cture.</xpln></wordentry>

ners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trillo(n)">Trillo ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an excel&shy;

an uniform trembling or sha&shy;
king of the same Note, either

ficially from the stomack, as
the Italians.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="rr7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trimodial(a)">Trimodial [from <etym lang="la">trimodia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">

Sicily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trine(a)">Trine [ <etym lang="la">trinus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">of three
yeers old, or pertaining to the
number three. 

Trine Aspect .<xref> See Aspect</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trinitarians(pn)">Trinitarians,</form> <xpln lang="en">a religious
order.<xref> See Mathurins</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trinitarian(pn)">Trinitarian</form> <xpln lang="en">hereticks, o&shy;
therwise new Arians are those
that deny the blessed Trinity,
and all distinction of the Di&shy;
vine persons, inveighing a&shy;
gainst the word Trinity, and
blasphemously tearming the
most sacred Mystery of the
Trinity, <term lang="la">Infernalem cerberum</term> 
as Lindanus testifies <term lang="la">in dubi&shy;
tantis sui Dialogo secundo</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ttrinity(pn)">Trinity (<etym lang="la">trinitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
number of three, or three in
one. The distinction of the
persons in the unity of the
God-head; one and the selfe
same God in Essence, being
for subsistence three, to wit,
the Father, the Sonne and ho&shy;
ly Ghost, I John 5.7. And
these three are one . How three
remaining three, may yet be
one; and one, abiding one
be three, and all this at once,
is a Mystery rather to be re&shy;
ligiously adored, then curi&shy;
ously sought into, requiring
rather faith to beleeve, then
reason to comprehend and
judge it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trinity House(pn)">Trinity-house,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a certain
house at Deptford neer Lon&shy; 
don, which belongs to a com&shy;
pany or Corporation of Sea&shy;
faring men, that have power
by the Kings Charter, to
take knowledge of those that
destroy Sea-marks <emend err="aud">and</emend> to re&shy;
dresse their doings, as also to
correct the faults of Sailers,
&amp;c. And to take care of di&shy;
vers other things belonging
to Navigation and the seas.
Anno 8. Eliz. Cap.13. and
Anno 35. ejusdem ca.6.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trinobants(pn)">Trinobants (<etym lang="la">trinoban&shy;
tes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a people in the East
part of England, by the
Thames.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trinoctial(a)">Trinoctial (<etym lang="la">trinoctialis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to three nights
space.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trinodal(a)">Trinodal [<etym lang="la">trinodis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath three knots, three knot&shy;
ted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trinket(n)">Trinquet [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">is proper&shy;
ly the top or top-gallant on
any mast, the highest saile of
a ship; also taken for a small
pretty, gay thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tribolar(a)">Tribolar [ <etym lang="la">tribolaris</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
vile, of small estimation, little
worth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trionimal(a)">Trionimal [ <etym lang="la">trionimus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath three names.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripartite(a)">Tripartite [ <etym lang="la">tripartitus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is divided into three
parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripedanious(a)" lexeme="tripedal(a)">Tripe&shy;
danious

dal <etym lang="la">Tripeda&shy;
lis 
Tripeda&shy;
neus</etym> 
</form> <xpln lang="en">that is

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripery(n)">Triperie ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a marker,
shop or street, wherein tripes
are usually sold.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="rr7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triplicate(v)">Triplicate [ <etym lang="la">triplico</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
triple, to do or fold a thing
three times.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triplicity(n)">Triplicity [ <etym lang="la">triplicitas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
threefold being, threefoldness. 

Astrologians divide the
twelve signes into foure Tri&shy;
gons or Triplicities, so called,
because they are distant the
third part of a circle one from
the other.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripod(n)">Tripode [ <etym lang="la">tripodium</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
three footed stool, any thing
that hath three feet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripodical(a)">Tripodical,</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath
three feet, three footed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripoli(n)">Tripoly [ <etym lang="la">tripolium</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a stone,
with the pouder whereof La&shy;
pidaries and Stonecutters
smooth or polish their Jewels,
also a kinde of herb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triptote(n)">Triptote [ <etym lang="la">triptoton</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Noun having but three cases.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripudiate(v)">Tripudiate [ <etym lang="la">tripudio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
dance, to go tripping on the
toe, dancer-like. 

Tripudiary divination was
by bread rebounding on the
ground, when it was cast un&shy;
to birds, or chickens. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triquet(a)">Triquet (<etym lang="la">triquetius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">having
three corners, triangular.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trireme(n)">Trireme [ <etym lang="la">triremis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Galley wherein every oare
had three men to it, or a Gal&shy;
ley that hath three oares on
every side.<xref> See Quinquereme</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trisagion(n)">Trisagion [<class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">thrice
holy, the Sanctus, Sanctus,
Sanctus, mentioned in the
Church-service.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trismegistus(pn)">Trismegistus (<expan type="">id est</expan> <etym lang="la">ter max&shy;
imus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, because he
was the greatest Phylosopher, 
Priest and King, he is called
also Hermes Trismegistus, and
Mercurius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tristisical(a)">Tristisical [ <etym lang="la">tristisicus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that makes sad or heavy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tristitiate(v)">Tristitiate (from <etym lang="la">tristi&shy; 
tia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make sad or pensive;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trisulk(a)">Trisulk [ <etym lang="la">trisulcus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">having
three edges, or three furrows.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trisyllabical(a)">Trisyllabical [ <etym lang="la">trisyllabicus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that hath three syllables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trite(a)">Trite [ <etym lang="la">tritus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">worne,
over-worne, old, threed&shy;
bare, much used, com&shy;
mon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tritheites(pn)">Tritheites (<etym lang="la">tritheit&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sort of hereticks, that held
there were three distinct
God-heads in the Trinity of
the persons.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triticean(a)">Triticean (<etym lang="la">triticeus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">whea&shy;
ten, of wheat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Triton(pn)">Triton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a god of the sea,
also a weathercock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triturable(a)">Triturable [from <etym lang="la">trituro</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be threshed, thresha&shy;
ble. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trituration(n)">Trituration [ <etym lang="la">trituratio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
threshing, as they do corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trivial(a)">Trivial [ <etym lang="la">trivialis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">common,
used or taught in high-ways,
of small estimation, homely.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triumph(n)">Triumph [ <etym lang="la">triumphus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
solemn pomp or shew at the
return of a captaine from a
victory. Among the Romans 
there was <term lang="la">triumphus Major &amp;
minor</term>, the lesser kinde of
triumph was called Ova&shy;
tion, <etym lang="la">ab ove</etym>, from a sheep
which was in this kinde of tri&shy;
umph led before him, and 


</page>

<page sig="rr8r">
afterwards sacrificed by him;
In the greater triumph (pro&shy;
perly so called) the Lord
General sacrificed a Bull, &amp;c.
Of the magnificence of this
triumph, see Plutarch in the
triumph of Paulus &AElig;milius;
And of the Ceremonies of
both, See Dr. Heilin in his
description of Italy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triumphant arches(n)">Triumphant arches,</form> <xpln lang="en">were
among the Romans erected for
them onely, who, having
subdued whole provinces, or
conquered forreigne Nations,
and obtained brave and for&shy;
tunate victories, seemed
worthy of triumph; and
thereupon they were called
Triumphant Arches. Upon
these arches for the perpetual
and everlasting memorial of
acts atchieved, were cut and
engraven the portraitures of
the very places, where the
war was performed, the re&shy;
semblances of fabricks and
ranged battels, if the service
was on land; and of ships, if it
were at sea; In Pliny' s dayes
they began first to be built,
before, onely Statues and
Trophees were set up, &amp;c.
Livie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="triumvirate(n)">Triumvirat [ <etym lang="la">trumviratus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
the office of the triumvir, or
of three in the like authority;
of which there were several
sorts in ancient Rome, as you
may read in Livie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trochisk(n)">Trochisk [ <etym lang="la">trochiscus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
little wheel; also a little round
ball flat in the end, made of
sundry powders; any kinde 
of medicine made round like
a little wheel, ring or loaf of
bread, the Apothecaries
call a trosque, or trochisk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="troglodite(n)">Troglodites [ <etym lang="la">troglodit&aelig;</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
people in the furthest part
of Africk beyond &AElig;thiope,
that dwell under ground, go
naked and eat Serpents, of
whom you may read in Her&shy;
berts Travails.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tronage(n)">Tronage</form> <xpln lang="en">is a kind of Toll,
Westm.2. Cap.25. Anno.13.
Ed. I. taken (as it seemes)
for weighing; For I find in
fleta, lib.2. cap.12. Sect. Item.
Ulnas, that Trona is a beam
to weigh with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trompery(n)">Tromperie [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">fraud,
cozenage, deceit, circumven&shy;
tion, legerdemain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trope(n)">Trope (<etym lang="la">tropus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure, or
figurative manner of speak&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tropical(a)" lexeme="tropological(a)">Tropical 
or, 
Tropological 
[<etym lang="la">tropicus</etym>] 
</form> <xpln lang="en">that speaks figuratively, or by
tropes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trophy(n)">Trophie [ <etym lang="la">troph&oelig;um</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a to&shy;
en or mark set up in a
place where enemies are
vanquished with their ensigns
or other spoyles hanged on it;
a signe or token of victory,
a brave, a victory of joy;
Also a frame of wood made
to hang somewhat upon in
manner of a funeral hearse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tropics(pn)">Tropicks [<etym lang="la">tropici</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">two
imagined circles in the Hea&shy;
vens of equal distance on
either side from the &AElig;quator;
The one is called the Tropick 


</page>

<page sig="rr8v">
of Cancer, the other of Capri&shy;
corne, to the first the Sunne
cometh about 12. June,
to the other about 12.
December . They are called
Tropicks of the Greek word
<etym lang="gk">&tau;&rho;&epsilon;&pi;&omega;</etym>, which signifies to
turne; because when the
Sunne comes to either of
them, he turns his course,
either higher, having been at
the lowest, or lower, having
been at the highest. Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tropology(n)">Tropology (<etym lang="la">tropologia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a figurative kinde of spea&shy;
king, or a speaking by
Tropes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trochisk(n)">Trosque.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Trochisk</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trover(n)">Trover (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">trou&shy;
ver</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> to find)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies in our
Common Law, an Action
which lies against a man,
that having found anothers
goods, refuseth to deliver
them upon demand, &amp;c.
See the New Book of Entries,
verbo, Trover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="troy(n)">Troy</form> <xpln lang="en">weight containes
twelve ownces in the pound
and no more; by which Gold,
Silver, Precious stones and
bread are weighed.<xref lexeme="weight"> See 
Weights</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

 <etym lang="fr">truelle</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an instrument that

with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truant(n)">Truand ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a common

bond; a knave, a scown&shy;
drel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truchman(n)" lexeme="terjuman(n)">Truch man orTeriuman

dy of a tree without the
boughs; a body without a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tuberous(a)">Tuberous [ <etym lang="la">tuberus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">full

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tuel(n)">Tuel,</form> <xpln lang="en">the fundament a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turban(n)">Tulipant</form> <xpln lang="en">a roll or wreath

</page>

heads in stead of hats, a shash.
Herb. tr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tullianum(pn)">Tullianum  <class type="etymlang" lang="la">[Lat.]</class></form> <xpln lang="en">a dark
and stinking dungeon or
common prison in old Rome,
built or enlarged by King
Tullius, from whom it took
name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumbrel(n)">Tumbrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an Engine
of punishment, which ought
to be in every Liberty,
that hath view of Frank
Pledge, for the brideling of
Scoulds and unquiet women.
Kitchin. fol.13. a. called also a
Cucking-stool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumefy(v)">Tumefie [ <etym lang="la">Tumefacio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
to make to swell, or puff
up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumid(a)">Tumid [ <etym lang="la">tumidus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">risen,
swollen, puffed up; also proud,
haughty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumor(n)">Tumor [<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a swel&shy;
ling, rising, or puffing
up of the flesh, by reason
of some malicious matter
or ill humour; loftinesse,
pride.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumulate(v)">Tumulate [ <etym lang="la">tumulo</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make the ground hollow,
to bury, to entomb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumultuary(a)">Tumultuary
 [ <etym lang="la">tumultua&shy;
rius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that is done in haste 
without advisement, suddenly 
and without fear, hasty, disor&shy;
derly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumultuous(a)">Tumultuous  [ <etym lang="la">tumultuo&shy;
sus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">full of businesse and trou&shy;
ble, seditious, mutinous, full
of broile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tun(n)">Tun,</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure of oyle,
wine, &amp;c containing two
hundred fifty two Gallons,
I Rich.3.12. In weight it 
is commonly twenty hun&shy;
dred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tunicat(a)">Tunicat (<etym lang="la">tunica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Jer&shy;
kin, jacket or sleevelesse
coat; also a skin or coat that
covers the eye, whereof there
are four sorts. i. Cornea, which
is white and resembles an
horn. 2. Uvea, which is like a
grape kernel. 3. Vitrea, which
resembles glasse. 4. Christalli&shy;
na, which resembles christal
in clearnesse. Tho.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tunicle(n)">Tunicle (<etym lang="la">tunicula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
jacket or coat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turban(n)">Turbant</form> <xpln lang="en">a Turkish hat
or ornament for the head, of
white and fine linnen, wreath&shy;
ed into a rundle, broad at the
bottome to enclose the head,
and lessening for ornament to&shy;
wards the top; The custome
of wearing these Turbants
had this origen; The <emend err="barba">barba&shy;</emend>
rous people having the Gre&shy;
cian Army once at a great
advantage at or near the
Hill Thermopyl&aelig;, there was
no other remedy, but that
some few should make good
a narrow passage, while
the maine of the Army might
escape away; there were
brave spirits who under&shy;
took it, and knowing they
went to an unevitable death,
they had care of nothing
but sepulture, which of old
was much regarded, where&shy;
fore each of them carried
his winding sheet wrapt a&shy;
bout his head, and then with
losse of their own lives, saved 


</page>

<page sig="ss1v">
their fellows; whereupon for
an honourable memorial of
that exploit, the Levantines 
used to wrap white linnen a&shy;
bout their heads, and the
fashion so derived upon the
Turk . Sir Henry Blounts
voyage. fol.18.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turbary(n)">Turbarie,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an inte&shy;
rest to dig turves upon a
Common. Kitchin fol.94.
old Natura brevium. fol.
70.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turbination(n)">Turbination (<etym lang="la">turbinatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the fashioning a thing like a
top, broad above, and small
beneath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turbineous(a)">Turbineous (<etym lang="la">turbineus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to a storm and
blustering winde, whirling
round.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turbith mineral(n)">Turbith mineral,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
red powder (made according
to the Paracelsian practice)
which is used against the
French disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turbulent(a)">Turbulent [ <etym lang="la">turbulentus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
troublous, angry, full of
contention, busie, sediti&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turgent(a)">Turgent [ <etym lang="la">turgens</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
swelling, rising, strouting
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turgescence(n)">Turgescence (from <etym lang="la">tur&shy;
gesco</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a swelling up, or grow&shy;
ing or waxing big; a swel&shy;
ling for anger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turgid(a)">Turgid (<etym lang="la">turgidus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
swollen, a puffed up, risen
in state, big, strouting
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turgie(n)">Turgie [ <etym lang="la">theurgia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">white
magick; a pretended con&shy;
ference with good spirits or
Angels. Sir Wal. Ral. lib. I. fol.
178.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED but cf. "theurgy" (1569-)..
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turn(n)">Turn,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the Sheriffs Court
kept twice a year, viz. with&shy;
in a moneth after Easter, and
againe after Michaelmas .
Magna Charta, cap.35. And
3. Ed.3. cap.15. See more
of this in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tournament(n)">Turneament or Turney,</form> <xpln lang="en">is
a martial exercise of Knights
or souldiers combating one
with another in disport on
horseback, and is thus defined.
<term lang="la">Cap. Felicis Extra de Tornea&shy;
mentis. Torneamenta dicuntur
Nundin&aelig; vel feri&aelig;, in quibus
milites ex condicto convenire
&amp; ad ostentationem virium
suarum &amp; audaci&aelig;, temer&egrave;
congredi solent</term> . The word is
used in the Stat. of 24.
Hen.8. cap.13. And the rea&shy;
son of the name may pro&shy;
ceed from the French (<etym lang="fr">Tour&shy;
ner</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">vertere</term>) because it
consisteth much in agility,
both in horse and man. See
<xref>Tournement</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turpentine(n)">Turpentine (<class type="etymlang" lang="br">Br.</class> <etym lang="br">Twr&shy;
penti</etym>, <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class> <etym lang="la">Terebynthina</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a faire clear and moist kind
of rosin, which issues out
of the Larx and Turpen&shy;
tine tree; It is good to
be put into ointments, and
emplaisters, for it glewes,
cleanses and heals wounds;
It may be also licked in with
honey, and then it cleanses
the breast, and gently looseth
the belly, provoking urine 


</page>

<page sig="ss2r">
and driving out the stone and
gravel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turpify(v)">Turpify (<etym lang="la">turpifico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make uncleane or disho&shy;
nest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turpitude(n)">Turpitude (<etym lang="la">turpitudo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
dishonesty, villany, defor&shy;
mity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turriferous(a)">Turriferous [ <etym lang="la">turri&shy;
fer</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that beares a Tow&shy;
er</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tuscan work(pn)">Tuscan-work;</form> <xpln lang="en">In Ar&shy;
chitecture there are five or&shy;
ders of pillars, The Tus&shy;
can, Dorique, Jonique Corin&shy;
thian, Composite or Italian .
See Sir Hen. Wottons Ele&shy;
ments of Architecture. p.
206. and 209. The Tuscan 
is a plaine, massy, rural pil&shy;
lar, resembling some sturdy,
wel-limb labourer, homely
clad; The length of it ought
to be six diameters of the
grossest of the Pillar be&shy;
low.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tutelary(a)">Tutelarie (<etym lang="la">tutelaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of,
or belonging to a Guardian,
or to the custody of a Ward,
or to protection and de&shy;
fence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tutele(n)">Tutele [ <etym lang="la">tutela</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">wardship,
guardianship, custody of
a childe in nonage; also
safe keeping, defending, pro&shy;
tection.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tutelina(pn)">Tutelina,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Goddesse
having the protection of
corne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tutty(n)">Tutie (<etym lang="la">tutia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a medicin&shy;
able stone or dust, said to
be the heavier foile of brasse,
cleaving to the upper sides
and tops of brasse-melting 
houses, and such ordinary A&shy;
pothecaries passe away for
Tutie; whereas the true Tu&shy;
tie is not heavy, but, light
and white like flocks of wool,
falling into dust so soone as
it is touched; this is bred of
the sparkles of brazen fur&shy;
naces, whereinto store of the
mineral Calamine hath been
cast. Cot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tut-mouthed(a)">Tutmouthed,</form> <xpln lang="en">he that hath
the chin and nether jaw
sticking out further then the
upper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tuysco(pn)">Tuysco</form> <xpln lang="en">was the most an&shy;
cient and peculiar idol-god
of all the old Germans, from
whence they called them&shy;
selvesTuytshen, that is,
Duytshes or Duytsh-people;
and the day which yet a&shy;
mong us retaines the name
of Tuisday) was especial&shy; 
ly dedicated to the adoration
and service of this Idol. See
its posture in Verstegan. pag.
57.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Twelfth Day(pn)">Twelf-day (<term lang="la">dies duo de&shy;
cimus</term>or <term lang="la">Epiphanea</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the feast
of the Epiphany of our
blessed Saviour so called,
because it is the twelfth
day after the Nativity exclu&shy;
sively. See <xref>Epiphany</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twibill(n)">Twibil <etym lang="la"> (Tweebill</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an instrument used by Car&shy;
penters to make mortise-&shy;
holes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twilight(n)">Twilight (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class><etym lang="bl">Twee&shy;
light</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cockshoot time, ei&shy;
ther in the morning or e&shy;
vening, when tis betwixt 


</page>

<page sig="ss2v">
day and night, or betwixt two
lights, that is of the Sun and
the moon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tyberiade(pn)">Tyberiade,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Topograph,
the model or draught of a
place, called so of a book
of that name, composed by
Bartholus the Lawyer, who
was the first that graced
his works with such fi&shy;
gures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tydder(pn)">Tydder.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Theodore</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tympany(n)">Tympany [ <etym lang="la">tympanites</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a disease, wherein the body
waxing leane, the belly
swels up, having great store
of winde and windy humours
gathered together, between
its inner skin and the guts,
which being smitten with the
hand, makes a noise like a
Tabor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tympan(n)">Tympane [ <etym lang="la">tympanum</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Tymbrel, Taber, Drum
or Drumstale; Also an in&shy;
strument of a Printers press
whereon he layes the sheet
that is to be printed; so called,
because it is made of parch&shy;
ment, and being struck&shy;
en on, will sound like a Ta&shy;
ber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tympanist(n)">Tympanist [ <etym lang="la">tympanista</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Drumster or Taberer;
also one sick of a Tympa&shy;
nie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tympanitical(a)">Tympanitical [ <etym lang="la">tympaniti&shy;
cus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that hath a Tympany or
dropsy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tympanize(v)">Tympanize [ <etym lang="la">tympanizo</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
to play on a Drum, Taber or
Tymbrel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="typographer(n)">Typographer (<etym lang="la">typogra&shy;
phus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Printer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="typography(n)">Typography (<etym lang="la">typographia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="type(n)">Type [ <etym lang="la">typus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a figure,

thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="typical(a)">Typical [ <etym lang="la">typicus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">my&shy;

other thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vacant(a)"><f type="l"/> Vacant (<etym lang="la">vacans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">empty,
void, having nothing to
do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vacancy(n)" lexeme="vacation(n)">Vacancy 
Vacation 
 [<etym lang="la">vacatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a
time of ceasing from labour
or common businesse, leasure, 


</page>

<page sig="ss3r">
exemption; Vacation hath
a special signification in this
Nation, being used for all
that time respectively,
which passeth betweene
Tearm and Tearm at Lon&shy;
don, which every Almanack 
will tell you. And when
such times begun and end&shy;
ed in our Ancestors dayes,
See Roger Hovedens annals,
parte posteriori. fol.343. a.
where you shall finde this
intermission was called Pax
Dei &amp; Ecclesi&aelig;.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaccary(n)">Vaccary aliasvacharie
 [ <etym lang="la">vacaria</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">seemes to be a
house to keep kine or cowes
in. Fleta lib.2. Cap.41.
Sect. Item inquiratur,12.
And Cromptons Jurisd. fol.
194. In these words. With&shy;
out warrant no subject may
have a vaccary within the
Forest . But in the Stat. of
37. H.8. Cap.16. I finde
vachary to be, as it were
a special proper name of a
certain quantity and compass
of ground within the Forest of
Ashdown. Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vacillation(n)">Vacillation [ <etym lang="la">vacillatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a wagging or wavering;
loosenesse, inconstancy. Mr.
Mont.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vacive(a)">Vacive (<etym lang="la">vacivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">em&shy;
pty, void; as &aelig;des vaciv&aelig;,
houses that stand voide
without a Tennant, or ha&shy;
ving all voided out of
them.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vacuity(n)">Vacuity [ <etym lang="la">vacuitas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">empti&shy;
nesse, voidness, cleernesse, free&shy;
dom from.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vacuum(n)">Vacuum [<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">an
empty or void place. Lo.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

 <etym lang="la">vaginnipennes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">pertaining

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vail bonnet(v)">Vaile-bonnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">to put

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vaid' ombre(pn)">Vaid'ombre,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of
Religious, begun by John
Gualbert, a Florentine, a&shy;
bout the yeare, 1040. who
betaking himself to the study
of Religion, retired to a
place in the Appennine, cal&shy;
led Val ombreux or the shady
vale ; his followers weare a
smoaky coloured habit, and
follow the rule of Saint Ben&shy;
net. Heyl.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ss3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vale(v)">Vale [from <etym lang="la">valeo</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">fare&shy;
well, God be with you, God
keep you in health.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valentine(n)">Valentines,</form> <xpln lang="en">are either
Saints chosen for special Pa&shy;
trons for a year; or men or
women chosen for special lo&shy;
ving friends by an ancient
custome upon Saint Va&shy;
lentines day, the four&shy;
teenth of February ; about
which day birds choose their
mates.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Valentinians(pn)">Valentinians,</form> <xpln lang="en">certaine
Heretiques so called from
Valentinianus their first
Master, who held our Sa&shy;
viour received not flesh of
the blessed Vergin Mary;
And therefore was wont to
say, Jesus, borne by the
Virgin, but not of the Virgin, 
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valet(n)">Valet ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Groom,
Yeoman or Household-ser&shy;
vant of the meaner sort.
In old time it was a
Title for all young Gen&shy;
tlemen, till they came
to eighteen yeares of age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valetudinary(n)">Valetudinary (<etym lang="la">valetudi&shy;
narium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a place where sick
men lie, a sick mans lodg&shy;
ing, an Hospital for sick
persons; or the place where
they get health.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valetudinary(a)">Valetudinary (<etym lang="la">valetu&shy;

nesse, sickly, often sick,
crasie; also one recovering
out of sickness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vapor(n)">Vapor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a hot breath,
reaking or moisture issuing
out of a thing. 

A Vapour is defined to be a
certain watery thing, and yet
is not water; it is as it were
a fume or smoak, which
will easily be resolved into
water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaporation(n)">Vaporation (<etym lang="la">vaporatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

reaking.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vairy(n)" lexeme="berry(n)">Varry orBerry [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr"> Vaire</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="ss4r">
a tearm in Heraldry and
signifies that which is diversi&shy;
fi'd with argent and azure;
as the fur of Ermines pou&shy;
dered thick with blew
haires.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The term "berry" in this sense is not found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="varvel(n)">Varvels [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">Vervelles</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
are like little rings of Silver
about Hawks legs, whereon
are commonly inscribed the
arms or name of him that ows
the hawke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vasiferous(a)">Vasiferous [<etym lang="la">vasifer</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that
carries a vessel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vasselage(n)">Vasselage [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">subje&shy;
ction, the duty or estate of a
vassal or slave. Among the
ancient Romans 'twas used for
valour and a valiant or worthy
deed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vastation(n)">Vastation [<etym lang="la">vastatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a wa&shy;
sting, spoiling or destroy&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vastity(n)">Vastity [ <etym lang="la">vastitas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">exces&shy;
sive greatness, destruction, de&shy;
stroying.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vatican(pn)">Vatican [<etym lang="la">vaticanus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the
chief Library in Rome, called
also the Palatine, founded by
Pope Sixtus the fourth, who
not only stored it with the
choisest books he could pick
out of Europe, but allowed
also a large revenue for its
perpetuall augmentation.
It is so called from the Hill
Vatican, where the Library
stands; And that Hill was so
called from <term lang="la">Vaticiaium</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
a foretelling, because it was
famous for manny divinations
and prophesies uttered upon
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaticinate(v)">Vaticinate [ <etym lang="la">vaticinor</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
to Prophecy or Divine;
to conjecture or fore&shy;
tel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaticiny(n)">Vaticiny [ <etym lang="la">Vaticini&shy;
um</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="aprophecy">a prophecy</emend>; a foretel&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaticinian(n)">Vaticinian [ <etym lang="la">vaticinius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to prophecy&shy;
ing or divining, or to them
that practise it, propheti&shy;
cal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vavasour(n)">Vavasour orValvasour,</form> <xpln lang="en">
is one that in dignity is next
a Baron. Cam. Brit. page 109.
It is also the name of
an ancient family in the
North of England. Some&shy;
times it is abusively taken
in ill part, for a Jolly
fellow, or a great man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaudeville(n)">Vaudevil [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coun&shy;
trey ballad or song, a
Roundelay or Virelay, so
tearmed of Vandevire, a
Norman Towne wherein
Oliver Bassel, the first in&shy;
venter of them, lived;
also a vulgar Proverb,
a Country or common say&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaunt-courier(n)">Vauntcourers.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See vancur&shy;
riers</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vauntlay(n)">Vauntlay [<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">from the Fr.</class> 
 <etym lang="fr">Avaunt</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> before, and lay]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a tearm of hunting, when
they set hounds in readinesse
where they think a chase will
passe, and cast them off be&shy;
fore the rest of the kennel
come in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaward(n)">Vaward</form> <xpln lang="en">the foremost part
of an army in battle.<xref> See Van&shy;
guard</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ss4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vayvode(pn)">Vayvode,</form> <xpln lang="en">a title of digni&shy;
ty in Transilvania, Walachia,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uberate(v)">Uberate [ <etym lang="la">ubero</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make plenteous and fruitful;
to fatten or give suck with the
breast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uberous(a)">Uberous [ <etym lang="la">uber</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">fertile,
