dant, copious, ample,
great.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uberty(n)">Uberty [ <etym lang="la">ubertas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">plen&shy;
tifulnesse, fertility, store, a&shy;
bundance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ubication(n)">Ubication [from <etym lang="la">ubi</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
the being in a place, the lo&shy;
cality of a thing. Tr. of
Schisme.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ubiquitary(a)">Ubiquitary [from <etym lang="la">ubique</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is every where, or in all
places.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ubiquitarians(pn)" lexeme="Ubiquetii(pn)">Ubiquitarians orUbi&shy;
quetii,</form> <xpln lang="en">a late Sect, [ran&shy;
ked by some among those
that are called Semiluthe&shy;
rans ] holding that Christs
body is every where as well
as his Divinity; in which
kinde of Doctrine one Jo&shy;
annes B&aelig;dcker was emi&shy;
nent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ubiquity(n)">Ubiquity [ <etym lang="la">ubiquitas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a be&shy;
ing every where, and in all
places.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vecordy(n)">Vecordy (<etym lang="la">vecordis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><emend err="mad"> mad&shy;</emend>
nesse, trouble of minde, folly,
doting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vectarious(a)">Vectarious [ <etym lang="la">vectarius</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
of, or belonging to a
coach, waggon or any car&shy;
riage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vectible(a)">Vectible [ <etym lang="la">vectibilis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is or may be carri&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vectigal(n)">Vectigal (<etym lang="la">vectigalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
pays or pertaines to pay&shy;
ing tribute, subsidy, pen&shy;
tion or rent. It is also u&shy;
sed substantively for toll,
impost-money or tribute it
self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vection(n)">Vection (<etym lang="la">vectio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a carrying
or portage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vectitation(n)">Vectitation (<etym lang="la">vectitatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
often carriage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vectorian(a)">Vectorian (<etym lang="la">vectorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">apt
to carry, serving for carri&shy;
age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vegetal(n)" lexeme="vegetable(n)">Vegetals 
Vegetables  
 [<etym lang="la">vegetabilia</etym>] 
</form> <xpln lang="en">is a general name for all
things that live and grow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vegetable(n)">Vegetable (<etym lang="la">vegetabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
able to live and increase in
growth, as plants or other
living things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vegetation(n)">Vegetation (<etym lang="la">vegetatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
making strong, lively and
quick, a refreshing or com&shy;
forting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vegetive(a)">Vegetive (<etym lang="la">vegetus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
liveth and groweth; whole,
strong, quick, lively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vehicle(n)">Vehicle [ <etym lang="la">vehiculum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Cart, Wain, Wagon or
Chariot; a general name
for all things serving to car&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vehicular(a)">Vehicular (<etym lang="la">vehicularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of, or pertaining to any in&shy;
strument or engine of car&shy;
riage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein(n)" lexeme="vein, adipal(n)" lexeme="vein, adiposous(n)" lexeme="vein, arterial(n)">Vein  (<etym lang="la">vena</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a veine
in the body, an Arte&shy; 


</page>

<page sig="ss5r">
ry, a pulse; yet every vein
is not a pulse, though e&shy;
very pulse be a veine;
the several kindes whereof
follow. 

<subform>Adipal or Adiposous veins 
[ <etym lang="la">ven&aelig; adipos&aelig;</etym>]</subform> <subxpln>are two
veines, a right (sometimes
a branch of the right kid&shy;
ney-vein) and a left one
(ever a branch of the de&shy;
scendant trunk of the hol&shy;
low veine) which parti&shy;
cularly nourish the fat and
skin that's about the kid&shy;
ney, and generally breed fat
in those parts by which they
run. </subxpln>

<subform>Arterial veins [ <etym lang="la">vena ar&shy;
terialis</etym>]</subform> <subxpln>is one of the foure
principal veines of mans
body, issuing from the right
ventricle of the heart, the
blood whereof it carries to
the lungs for their nourish&shy;
ment.</subxpln>
</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme=" vein, auricular(n)">Auricular vein (<etym lang="la">vena au&shy;
ricularis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the eare veine,
which runnes up along by
the kernels which are un&shy;
der the eare, and is there
divided into two branches,
the one whereof mounts up
before the eare, and the o&shy;
ther behinde it; Chirur&shy;
gions open it against deaf&shy;
nesse, paine, and ulcerations
of the eares.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, axillary(n)">Axilary vein (<etym lang="la">vena ax&shy;
illaris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a great and large vein,
which, being a branch of
vena cava, is conveyed under 
the canel bone, and through
the Arm-hole into the inner
seat of the arme, where 'tis
dispersed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, basilic(n)">Basilick vein (<etym lang="la">vena ba&shy;
silica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the liver vein, which
issues from the second main
ascendant branche of vena
cava, and is divided into
two branches, a deep and
a superficial one; the later
whereof being neere the in&shy;
ward processe of the Arme
and very neer the skin, is
divided into other two;
{ viz.) a lesse which runs
into the head vein, and to&shy;
gether with it makes the
Median or middle veine,
whilest the greater passes
along the elbow, to the
hand, and there makes the
Salvatella.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vena cava(n)">Vena cava ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
hollow vein which is a great
one, issuing from the thick&shy;
est part of the liver and then
divided into two main bran&shy;
ches; and they into many o&shy;
thers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, cephalic(n)">Cephalick vein [ <etym lang="la">vena
cephalica</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the head veine
which springs out of the
Axillar veine, and passeth
<emend err="betweeen">between</emend> the first and se&shy;
cond muscle of the shoul&shy;
der, stretcheth to the out&shy;
most parts, and there lies e&shy;
vident a loft. Thum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, cervical(n)">Cervical veine [ <etym lang="la">vena
cervicalis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the veine of the 


</page>

<page sig="ss5v">
braines which passes by the
crosse processes of the neck&shy;
joynt, up to the filme or
thin skin, which is next the
braine, and there ends.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein. celiacal(n)">Celiacal vein (<etym lang="la">vena c&oelig;lia&shy;
ca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the blind vein, a second
branch of the Mesenterique
vein, runs unto the blinde
gut, and there ends in many
branches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, common(n)">Common vein.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Median
vein</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, coronal(n)">Coronal veine (<etym lang="la">vena coro&shy;
nalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Crown-vein; a
branch of the spleen-veine,
so termed, because it environs
the heart in manner of a
Crown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, crural(n)">Crural vein (<etym lang="la">vena crura&shy; 
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the thigh veine, a great
vein which issues from the 
trunk descendant of the
hollow vein.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, cistic(n)">Cystique vien (<etym lang="la">vena cysti&shy; 
ca</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a small, and sometimes
double, sometimes single
branch of the Port vein,
whence it mounts to the neck
of the gall, and there di&shy;
vides it selfe into two bran&shy;
ches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, diaphragmatic(n)">Diaphragmatick veins
<etym lang="la">(ven&aelig; diaphragmatic&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
midriff veins; two several
branches of the hollow vein,
from which they runne in&shy;
to the midriff, and there
end.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, emulgent(n)">Emulgent vein.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref lexeme="emulgent"> See <emend err="Emul">Emul&shy;</emend>
gent</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, epigastric(n)">Epigastrick veins (<etym lang="la">ven&aelig;
Epigastric&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an outward and
an inward branch of the 
flanck-veins, both which, af&shy;
ter divers passages, at length
joyne themselves unto those
that belong to the dugs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, dexter epiploic(n)">Dexter Epiploick veine
<etym lang="la">(vena Epiploica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the second
branch of the spleen veine,
goes to the Epiploon and the
gut colon ; Also a fourth
branch of the spleen veine,
which, ending towards the
upper part of the Epi&shy;
ploon, is called Epiploick, but
with the addition of Poste&shy;
rior.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, frontal(n)">Frontal vein (<etym lang="la">vena fronta&shy;
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the forehead veine, a
third branch of the outward
throat vein, whence mount&shy;
ing by the bottom of the ne&shy;
ther jaw, it comes into the
lips and nose, and thence
ascends by the inside of
the eye to the middle of the
forehead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garter(n)">Garter or gartering vein,
</form> <xpln lang="en">is a fourth branch of the
thigh vein, from which it
descends, among the back
muscles of the thigh, un&shy;
to the bought of the ham,
where it gets this name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, gastrepiploic(n)">Gastrepiploick vein (<etym lang="la">vena
gastrepiploica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the third
branch of the trunk of the
Port vein, issuing side&shy; 

wayes out of the right side
thereof, and spreading a&shy;
broad in the bottome of the
ventricle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, gastric(n)">Gastrick vein (<etym lang="la">vena ga&shy;
strica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the belly veine; a
branch of the Port veine,
from which it descends to 


</page>

<page sig="ss6r">
the hallow part and back&shy;
side of the ventricle; There
is also another called the
Petty-gastrick, which is
the first branch of the
Spleen veine, and goes to
the right side of the ven&shy;
tricle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, hederiform(n)">Hederiform vein [ <etym lang="la">vena he&shy;
deriformis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain veine
which passes down along by
the sides of the womb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, h&aelig;rmorrhoidal(n)">Hermorrhoidal vein (<etym lang="la">ve&shy;
na hemorrhois</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the first
branch of the Mesenterick,
which runnes to and ends at
the Colon and strait gut, some&shy;
times it issues from the spleen
vein.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, hepatic(n)" lexeme="vein, liver(n)">Hepatick or liver vein
<etym lang="la">(vena hepatica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the great car&shy;
rying vein, which proceeds
out of the hollow part of the
liver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, humeral(n)">Humeral veine [ <etym lang="la">vena
humeralis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the shoulder
vein.<xref> See Cephalick vein</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, hipogastric(n)">Hipogastrick vein (<etym lang="la">vena
hypogastrica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the third
branch of the flanck veines,
and is it selfe divided into
divers branches, the first
whereof runne to the yard,
bladder and strait gut, and
thence to the bottome of
the fundament, others to
the Matrix, and others
after a long course go down
almost to the ham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, iliac(n)">Iliack veines [ <etym lang="la">ven&aelig; Ilia&shy;
c&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the flanck veines; two
maine descendant branches
of the hollow veine, a right 
and a left one, from either
of which, five others issue,
the right one is opened a&shy;
gainst the dropsie and o&shy;
ther diseases of the liver;
the left for the passion of the
spleen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, intercostal(n)">Intercostal vein [ <etym lang="la">vena
intercostalis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the fourth
branch of the trunk as&shy;
cendant of the hollow
veine; It feeds three di&shy;
stances between the upper
ribs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, intestinal(n)">Intestinal veine [ <etym lang="la">vena
intestinalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a fourth branch
of the Port veine, from the
posteriour and right part
whereof it issues and commu&shy;
nicates it self sometime to the
hungry gut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, jugular(n)">Jugular <emend err="veinss">veins</emend> [ <etym lang="la">ven&aelig;
jugulares</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the two throat
or neck veines, [ viz.]
an outward one, which is
sometimes double, and mounts
along the sides of the neck
to the bottome of the head,
where it is divided into five
branches; And an inward
one, which ascends along
by the windpipe to the
bottome of the braine, and
is there divided into two
branches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, labial(n)">Labial veins [ <etym lang="la">ven&aelig; labio&shy;
s&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the lip veines, whereof
there are two on each inner
side, both of the upper and
under lip.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, lumber(n)">Lumber veine (<etym lang="la">vena lum&shy;
bosa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the veine of the loynes,
the fourth branch of the 


</page>

<page sig="ss6v">
descendant trunk of Vena
cava, divided, neere its
source, into divers parts,
all which bestow them&shy;
selves among the joynts of
the loines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, mammal(n)">Mammal veine [ <etym lang="la">vena
mammalis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">is double, an
inward and an outward one,
distributed among the parts of
the breast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, matricious(n)">Matricious vein (<etym lang="la">vena
matricis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the matrix vein,
or a veine that runnes a&shy;
long the flank neere the
Reines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, median(n)">Median veine (<etym lang="la">vena me&shy;
diana</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the middle, com&shy;
mon or black veine; com&shy;
pounded of the two lesse bran&shy;
ches of the liver and head&shy;
veines, and running along
the middle of the arme, al&shy;
most to the wrist, where it
passes in the form of a Y into
the hand; There is likewise
another of this name under
the instup.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, meseraic(n)">Meseraik veins</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Me&shy;
senterique</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, mesenteric(n)">Mesenterique veins (<etym lang="la">ven&aelig;
mesenteric&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">two veins, one
a branch of the Port veine,
ends at the Mesentery, but
is formerly divided into three
branches, whereof the other
is the third, and called
so, because it likewise ends
at the Mysentery in some
fourteen or fifteen bran&shy;
ches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, musculous(n)">Musculous veine [ <etym lang="la">vena
musculosa</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the first branch 
of the flank veins, tearmed
thus, because it communi&shy;
cates it selfe with divers
muscles above the belly and
loynes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, nasal(n)">Nasal veine (<etym lang="la">vena nasalis </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the nose vein, seated between
the nostrils.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, ocular(n)">Ocular vein [ <etym lang="la">vena ocu&shy;
laria</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the eye vein, that
part of the frontal vein, which
runs along by the inside of
the eye.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, organic(n)">Organick veins,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Iliack
veins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, pericardic(n)">Pericardick vein (<etym lang="la">vena
pericardica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the second branch
of one of the two main as&shy;
cendant branches of the hol&shy;
low vein; whence it runnes
to the Pericardium, and there
ends.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, popletic(n)">Popletick vein [ <etym lang="la">vena poplitis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
the ham-veine.<xref lexeme="garter"> See Garter&shy;
veine</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, port(n)">Port veine [ <etym lang="la">vena porta</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
the carrying veine, seat&shy;
ed in the liver by divers
roots, which at length joyn
in one stock or trunk, and
so passe forth into the Ven&shy;
tricle, Spleene, Gall, Me&shy;
sentery, and other parts of the
body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, ranular(n)">Ranular vein [ <etym lang="la">vena ranu&shy;
laris</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the first branch of the
outward throat veine, as&shy;
cends to the tongue, and
parts in two, under each side
thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, renal(n)">Renal veins (<etym lang="la">vena renum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the kidney veines; two
thick and short branches of 


</page>

<page sig="ss7r">
the descendant trunk of the
hollow veine, a right and a
left one, divided into seven
or eight others (when they
come neer the kidney, into
the substance whereof they
enter) there is likewise ano&shy;
ther of this name seated under
the instup.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, sacred(n)">Sacred vein (<etym lang="la">vena sacra</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the second branch of the
flank veine running to the Os
sacrum, and thence getting
this name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, salvatel(n)">Salvatel vien [ <etym lang="la">salvatella</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
is made of the two bigger
branches of the liver and
head veines, from which it
runs through the wrist into
the hand, and unto the root
or division of the third and
little fingers.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The term "salvatel" was not found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, saphena(n)">Saphen vein (<etym lang="la">saphena</etym>)</form> 
<xpln lang="en"> the mother veine; the first
branch of the thigh veine,
consisting of two divisions,
the one inward, which ends
among the inner kernels of
the thigh, the other more
outward, hath three branches,
the first ends in the skin of
the thigh, the second goes
but to the knees, the third
to the muscles of the leg,
whence running along, a&shy;
bove the inner ankle (where
it is most opened and known
by this name) it comes to
the sole of the foot and there
ends.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, sciatic(n)">Sciatique vein (<etym lang="la">vena sci&shy;
atica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a branch of the
thigh vein, which descends 
down the legge to the out&shy;
ward ankle, where it is
commonly opened for the
Sciatica, and thereupon gets
this name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, spermatic(n)">Spermatick veine [ <etym lang="la">vena
spermatica</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the third branch
of the trunk descendant of
the hollow vein.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, splenitic(n)">Splenitick vein [ <etym lang="la">vena
splenitica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Spleen veine,
one of the two main bran&shy;
ches of the Port vein, from
which it runnes to the spleen,
and there ends, divided into
four parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, stomachic(n)">Stomachick vein (<etym lang="la">ve&shy;
na stomachica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the stomack
veine runnes to the hol&shy;
low part of the ventricle,
and there ends in two bran&shy;
ches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, subclavicular(n)">Subclavicular vein [ <etym lang="la">ve&shy;
na Subclavicularis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">one
of the two maine ascendant
branches of the hollow
veine, divided into six
parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, sural(n)">Sural veine [ <etym lang="la">vena sura&shy;
lis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the two maine
branches of the thigh veine,
most eminent in the bought
of the knee, from whence
it bestows and loses it selfe
among the muscles of the calf
of the leg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, temporal(n)">Temporal vein [ <etym lang="la">vena
temporalis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the veine of
the Temples, opened for the
Megrum, pain of the ears, and
extraordinary watering of the
eyes.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ss7v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, thorachic(n)">Thorachique vein [ <etym lang="la">vena
thoracis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the breast veine,
which is divided into two
branches, both which be&shy;
stow themselves among the
muscles of the Thorax or
breast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, thymic(n)">Thymick veine (<etym lang="la">vena thy&shy;
mica</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the first branch of the
subclavicular) goes to the
fag peece or kernel, which
is under the kannel bone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, torcular(n)">Torcular vein [ <etym lang="la">vena
torcularia</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the second branch
of the outward throat vein,
from which it ascends by
the inside of the scull to the
braine, which it moystens and
seeds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein, umbilical(n)">Umbilical vein [ <etym lang="la">vena um&shy;
bilica</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">is that whereby an
infant in the womb receives
nourishment, and which
(it being born) closes it self,
and serves as a ligament
to settle the liver to the
navel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veliferous(a)">Veliferous [ <etym lang="la">velifer</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
that bears saile, or is under
sail, as a ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velification(n)">Velification [ <etym lang="la">velificatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a sailing forwards, or hoy&shy;
sing saile; a course or voy&shy;
age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velifical(a)">Velifical [ <etym lang="la">velificus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is done with sailes displayed
or full spread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velitation(n)">Velitation (<etym lang="la">velitatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
skermishing by leaping from
place to place, brawling,
bickering in words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velivolant(a)">Velivolant (<etym lang="la">velivolans</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
running and (as it were) flying
with full sail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velleity(n)">Velleity (from <etym lang="la">velle</etym> the
infinitive mood of <etym lang="la">volo</etym>, to
will)</form> <xpln lang="en">an inclination of
the will; a kinde of wil&shy;
ling or desiring, or (as the
vulgar say) a wishing and
woulding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vellication(n)">Vellication [ <etym lang="la">vellicatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
a plucking, pulling, lug&shy;
ging; also a carping at,
depraving or detracting
from.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velocity(n)">Velocity (<etym lang="la">velocitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
swiftnesse, quicknesse, nimble&shy;
nesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venal(a)">Venal (<etym lang="la">venalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is set
to sale, that doth or speaketh
what one will for money,
that will be bribed and sell
his faith and troth for money.
Lo. Herbert.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venality(n)">Venality [ <etym lang="la">venalitas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">ven&shy;
diblenesse, a being sale&shy;
able; a letting or setting
to sale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vena porta(n)">Vena porta.</form> <xpln lang="en"> See port vein
in <xref>Vein</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venalitious(a)">Venalitious [ <etym lang="la">venaliti&shy;
us</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to the sale of
men or children, or of
slaves; that is to be bought
or sold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venatic(a)">Venatick [ <etym lang="la">venaticus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
of, or belonging to hunting or
chasing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venation(n)">Venation [ <etym lang="la">venatio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a hunt&shy;
ing or chasing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venator(n)">Venator [<class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a hunter or
huntsman.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venatorious(a)">Venatorious (<etym lang="la">venatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of, or belonging to hunt&shy;
ing and chasing, serving for
that game.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="ss8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vendible(a)">Vendible [ <etym lang="la">vendibilis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">sale&shy;
able, easie and ready to be
sold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vendicate(v)">Vendicate (<etym lang="la">vendico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to claim
or challenge to himself.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venditation(n)">Venditation (<etym lang="la">venditatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

bragging, shew or setting
forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vendition(n)">Vendition [ <etym lang="la">venditio</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a sale

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venefice(n)">Venefice [ <etym lang="la">venefcium</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">the
art or craft of poysoning; poy&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venefic(a)" lexeme="veneficial(a)" lexeme="veneficious(a)">Venfick 
Veneficial

 [ <etym lang="la">venesicus</etym>]
</form> <xpln lang="en">that poysoneth; venemous,

that beareth poyson, vene&shy;
mous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venemous(a)">Venemous  [ <etym lang="la">venenosus </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of poyson or venom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venerate(v)">Venerate [ <etym lang="la">veneror</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to re&shy;
verence, worship or ho&shy;
nour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venereal(a)" lexeme="venereous(a)">Venere&shy; 
al 
Venere&shy;
ous  
 [ <etym lang="la">venereus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
disposed to lechery; leche&shy;
rous, lustful, fleshly, las&shy;
civious.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venery(n)">Venerie [ <etym lang="la">venus, eris</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">car&shy;
nal lust, lechery, fleshly wan&shy;
tonnesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veniable(a)">Veniable (from <etym lang="la">venia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">par&shy;
donable. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venial(a)">Venial [ <etym lang="la">venialis</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">that may
be forgiven without much
difficulty, pardonable. 

Sinne is either original or
actual ; the first is a priva&shy;
tion of original justice, which
we inherit from our first 
parent Adam, being all
by course of nature con&shy;
ceived and borne in that
privation or original sinne;
The latter is a thought,
word or deed contrary to
the Law of God; And
this Actual sinne is, by ma&shy;
ny Divines, divided into
mortal and venial; Mortal
sinne they account to be a&shy;
great offence against the
charity of God or our
neighbour, and to be so cal&shy;
led, because it kills the soul;
and robs it of the spiritual
life of grace; Venial sinne,
they reckon to be any small
and pardonable offence a&shy;
gainst God or our neigh&shy;
bour, as the stealing an ap&shy;
ple or a pin; an idle word
or such like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vent(n)">Vent (<etym lang="la">ventus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">winde, a
blast, aire, breath, also a
brute or report.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventelet(n)">Ventelet</form> <xpln lang="en">(a dimin. of vent)
a little winde, a small puff,
gentle gale, coole blast of
winde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventiduct(n)">Ventiduct [from <etym lang="la">ventus</etym>
and <etym lang="la">duco</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a conduit or
conveyance of winde, as an
 Aqueduct is of water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventilate(v)">Ventilate [ <etym lang="la">ventilo</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">to ga&shy;
ther winde, to give a vent,
to fan or winnow corn; Also
to turn out of one hand into
another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventoy(n)">Ventoy [from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">ven&shy;
tau</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">a fan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventosity(n)">Ventosity [ <etym lang="la">ventositas</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">
windinesse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventricle(n)">Ventricle [ <etym lang="la">ventriculus</etym>]</form> <xpln lang="en">


</page>

<page sig="ss8v">
the place wherein the meat
sent from the stomack is di&shy;
gested; some use it for Epi&shy;
gastrium, others take it for
the stomack it self; a little
belly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventricle(n)">Ventricles</form> <xpln lang="en">of the heart,
are two large holes, one on
the right, the other on the left
side thereof, that, the greater
and closed within a slender
flesh, contains the naturall
blood; this, of a harder sub&shy;
stance, contains the blood
wherewith our arteries are
nourished; and thereupon
that is called the bloody, this,
the spiritual ventricle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventriloquist(n)">Ventriloquist (<etym lang="la">ventrilo&shy;
quus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that has an evil spi&shy;
rit speaking in his belly, or
one that by use and practise
can speake as it were out of
his belly, not moving his
lips.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ventripotent(a)">Ventripotent (<etym lang="la">ventripotens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
big paunch'd, belly-able,
huge gutted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venundate(v)">Venundate (<etym lang="la">venundo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
buy and sell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Venus(pn)">Venus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the goddess of lust;
also lust it self, venerie, un&shy;
chastnesse, lechery; also (a&shy;
mong Alchimists) the mettal
copper; also one of the seven
Planets.<xref lexeme="Saturn"> See Saturne</xref>. The 
day or morning Star.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Venus-escuage(n)">Venus Escuage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is used
for Knights (or nights) ser&shy;
vice to Ladies. 

 <term lang="la"> Quod facus, facies Veneris
cum veneris <emend err="a te">ante</emend>
Ne sedea, sedeas, ne pereas
pereas</term> . 

</xpln>

See OED "Venus," 11b.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venustate(v)">Venustate (<etym lang="la">venusto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
make beautiful, faire or sight&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vepricosous(a)">Vepricosous (<etym lang="la">vepricosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veracity(n)">Veracity (<etym lang="la">veracitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
speaking truth, or the quali&shy;
ty or vertue of saying truth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verbal(a)">Verbal (<etym lang="la">verbalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is
of a word, or that descends of
<emend err="of"></emend> a word; In Grammer those
words are called verbals 
which come from some verb,
as <term lang="la">amabilis</term> from <term lang="la">amo</term>. <term lang="la">Lector</term>,
from <term lang="la">Lego</term>, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verbality(n)">Verbality (<etym lang="la">verbalitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

verb; a fulness of words. Dr.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verbatim(adv)">Verbatim ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">word by
word, that which is precisely
spoken, according as it was de&shy;
livered before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verberable(a)">Verberable (<etym lang="la">verberabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that may be beaten, or is wor&shy;
thy to be beaten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verberate(v)">Verberate (<etym lang="la">verbero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verbigerate(v)">Verbigerate (<etym lang="la">verbigero</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to

broad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verbosity(n)">Verbosity (<etym lang="la">verbositas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
much talking or speaking,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verecund(a)" lexeme="verecundous(a)">Verecund

dus</etym>.</form> <xpln lang="en">
modest, shamefac'd, demure,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdant(a)">Verdant (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">verd</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
green, fresh, lively, new, in
prime.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdigis(n)">Verd grease orvert-greece
</form> <xpln lang="en">a green substance made of 


</page>

<page sig="tt1r">
the rust of Brass or Copper,
which hath been hanged cer&shy;
tain days over strong vinegar;
It is of a fretting nature, and
therefore to be used with
great discretion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verderer(n)" lexeme="verdour(n)">Verderer orVerdor (Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Verdier</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Judical Officer of
the Kings Forrest, &amp;c. of
whom read Cowel at large.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verd&eacute;(n)" lexeme="verdea(n)">Verdi orVerdea,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of
white Muscadine wine, made
in Toscany, which is sometimes
brought into England in bot&shy;
tles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdict(n)">Verdict (<etym lang="la">verdictum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
the answer of a Jury or In&shy;
quest, made upon any cause
civil or criminal, committed
by the Court to their conside&shy;
ration or tryal: And this
Verdict is two-fold, either
general or special, Stawnf. pl.
Cor. lib.3. cap.9. See more in
Cow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdure(n)">Verdure (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Verdeur</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
greenness or green things, as
hearbs, &amp;c. a raw or natural
sowreness in Wine, Fruits.
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verditure(n)">Verditure,</form> <xpln lang="en">is one of the
names of green Colour among
Painters, whereof they have
four most usual; Green Rice,
Verditure, Vert Greece, Sap&shy; 
green.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verge(n)">Verge ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a rod, stick,
yard or wand; also a Serge&shy;
ants Verge or Mace: It is al&shy;
so used for the compass about
the Kings Court that bounds
the jurisdiction of the Lord
Steward of the Kings Hous&shy;
hold, and of the Coroner of 
the Kings House, and seems
to have been twelve miles
compass. Anno 13.R.2. Stat.
I. ca.3. Fitzh. nat. br. fol.241. 
B. Britton. fol.68. b 69. a. and
Fleta lib.2. ca.2. and Sir Edw.
Cokes Reports lib.4. fol.47. a.
For this see the Statute of 33
Hen.8. cap.12. towards the
end. But Fleta saith, this
compass about the Court is
called <term lang="la">Virgata</term>, <term lang="la">&agrave; quam
Marishallus portat ut signum su&aelig;
potestatis</term> . lib.2. ca.4. Sect. I.
Verge hath also another signi&shy;
fication, being used for a stick
or rod, whereby one is admit&shy;
ted Tenant, who, holding it
in his hand, swears fealty to
the Lord of a Mannor, and
for that cause is called Te&shy;
nant by the Verge. Old. nat. br.
fol.77.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verger(n)">Verger (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class><emend err=")"></emend> or Virger from
 <etym lang="la">Virga</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that bears a Verge
or white wand before a Magi&shy;
strate, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vergobret(n)">Vergobert ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mayor
or Burgomaster; Among the
ancient Heduanes it was a year&shy;
ly elected chief Officer or
Magistrate that had power of
life and death, a part of
Tr of Times</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veridical(a)">Veridical (<etym lang="la">veridicus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that says or speaks truth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veriloquy(n)">Veriloquy (<etym lang="la">veriloquium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the true exposition of a word,
the Etymology or right
meaning of a word; Also
a Tale, Speech, or Re&shy;
port.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veriloquent(a)">Veriloquent,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Veridi&shy;
cal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermiculated(a)">Vermiculated (<etym lang="la">vermicu&shy;

with Chequer work, or with
smal peeces of divers colours,

Gules in Armory.<xref> See Cin&shy;
naber</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermination(n)">Vermination (<etym lang="la">vermina&shy;
tio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease with worms,
properly in Cattle, a vehe&shy;
ment ache by the wringing of
the Guts, as if they were
gnawn with worms. Fel&shy;
tham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermiparous(a)">Vermiparous (<etym lang="la">vermipa&shy;
rus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that brings forth, or
breeds worms. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vernaccia(n)">Vernaccia ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind
of wine like Malmsey, drunk
much in Rome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vernaculous(a)">Vernaculous (<etym lang="la">vernaculus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
that is born and brought up
in our own house, that takes
beginning in our own Coun&shy;
try; Proper, natural.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vernal(a)">Vernal (<etym lang="la">vernalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or

springing or waxing green,
as hearbs do burgeoning.</xpln></wordentry>

tering, servile or slavish beha&shy;
vior.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vert(n)">Vert (<class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class> <etym lang="fr">verd</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> green)
</form> <xpln lang="en">green colour in Heraldry. In
the Forrest Laws it signifies
every thing that grows and
bears a green leaf within the
Forrest that may cover and
hide a Deer. See Manwoods,
2. part. Forest Lawes, fol.6. a. and
fol.33. b.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdigris(n)">Vert Greece.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref lexeme="verdigis"> See Verdi&shy;
greece</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertible(a)">Vertible (<etym lang="la">vertibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may be turned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertical(a)">Vertical (from <etym lang="la">vertex, icis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
wavering, inconstant, apt
to change or turn; also stand&shy;
ing right over the head.
Vertical Circle . See <xref>Azi&shy;
muth</xref>. 

Vertical point, is the Zenith,
or point of the Firmament,
which is directly over ones
head.</xpln></wordentry>

in the head; a disease in the
head, caused by wind, wherein
the Patient thinks all things
turn round; a whirling or
turning about.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertumnal(n)">Vertumnals,</form> <xpln lang="en">Feasts dedi&shy;
cated to, or Books treating of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vertumnus(pn)">Vertumnus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a god among
the Romans, that would turn
himself into all shapes, and
was supposed to have the go&shy;
vernment of mens minds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesicatory(n)">Vesicatory (<etym lang="la">vesicatorium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a cupping glass, or any sharp 
Ointment, Cataplasm, or Plai&shy;
ster, which has power to draw
humors outward, exulcerat&shy;
ing the skin, and raising little
blisters on it. It is also used
adjectively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesicle(n)">Vesicle (<etym lang="la">vesicula</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
bladder. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesperal(a)">Vesperal (<etym lang="la">vesperalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to the evening, or
to the West part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vespers(n)">Vesperas,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Evening-&shy;
song, or evening prayers; so
called among Roman Catho&shy;
licks. 

Sicilian vesperas is taken
proverbially for mischiefs
done, or death inflicted in
a place and time of imagi&shy;
ned security; from a gene&shy;
ral massacre of the French
made on a sudden through&shy;
out Sicily (whereof they
were over insolent masters)
by the incensed Islanders
( Anno 1582.) and about
five of the clock in the after&shy;
noon at the toll of a Bell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vespery(n)">Vesperies ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">even&shy;
ing Exercises or Disputati&shy;
ons (among the Sorbo&shy;
nists .)</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vespertine(a)">Vespertine (<etym lang="la">vespertinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of the evening, done in the
evening.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vespillon(n)">Vespilone (<etym lang="la">vespilo, onis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he
that carries forth dead bo&shy;
dies in the night time to
bee buried, as they use in
time of plague and great sick&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vest(n)">To Vest (<etym lang="la">vestio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to cloth,
array, attire, adorn, &amp;c. See
 <xref>Vestment</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="tt2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vestal(n)">Vestals (<etym lang="la">Vestales Virgines</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
were certain Virgins among
the ancient Romans, consecra&shy;
ted to the Goddess Vesta, and
therefore so named; they
were always chosen between
six and seven years of age, and
continued thirty years in
their Office; whereof the
first ten years they bestowed
in learning the Ceremonies
of their Order; the second,
in execution thereof, and the 
last ten in teaching others;
After it was lawful for them
to marry, if they would:
Their chief Office was to
keep fire continually burn&shy;
ing in a round Temple at
Rome, in honor of Vesta; and
if it chanced to go out, they
were to renew it again with
no usual fire, but such as they
could get by art from the
Sun beams. 

<term lang="la">Nec tu aliud vestam, quam puram intellige flammam</term> .Ovid. 

They were greatly honored
in the City, and had divers
priviledges; for they were
carried in Chariots, and the
chiefest Magistrates would do
reverence to them; they had
Officers going before them,
as the Consuls had, and if
they met any one, who was
led to be put to death, they
had authority to deliver him,
taking an oath that they came
not that way of purpose, but
by chance; they might also
make a Will, and dispose of
their Goods as they pleased;
but if any of them were
found to live unchaste, she was
openly carried with sad silence
to the Gate called Collina,
where, being put into a deep
pit, she was presently buried
alive. These Vestals were first
instituted by Numa Pompilius,
or (as some write) by Ro&shy;
mulus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestiary(n)">Vestiary (<etym lang="la">Vestiarium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Wardrobe, Press or Chest, 
where Apparel is laid; also a
Vestry in a Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestible(a)">Vestible (<etym lang="la">vestibilum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
void place without the door,
a Porch, an Entry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestigate(v)">Vestigate (<etym lang="la">vestigo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to seek
out, to seek by the print of
the foot, to trace, to search
diligently, to hunt after.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestige(n)">Vestige (<etym lang="la">vestigium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
print of a mans foot, a foot&shy;
step, a trace, or track, a mark
of any thing; the sole of the
foot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestment(n)">Vestment (<etym lang="la">Vestimentum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Garment, Vesture, Apparel,
Cloathing, Attire. It is par&shy;
ticularly used by the Roman&shy;
ists for the upmost Garment,
which the Priest hath on,
when he says Mass; and they
say he is vested, when he is
so attired. This Vestment the
French call Chasuble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestitor(n)">Vestitor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
cloatheth, a Tailor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vetation(n)">Vetation (<etym lang="la">vetatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a for&shy;
bidding to do something.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="tt3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veteran(n)">Veteran (<etym lang="la">veteranus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">anci&shy;
ent, old, one that hath served
long in a place or office; it
is used both substantively and
adjectively.</xpln></wordentry>

us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">crafty, subtil, gotten by
long use.</xpln></wordentry>

us</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that lets Horses or
Mules to hire, a Muletor, a
Horse-courser, a Hackney&shy;
man; also an Horse-Leach or
Farrier; it is also used ad&shy;
jectively. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veterine(a)">Veterine (<etym lang="la">veterinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vetust(a)">Vetust (<etym lang="la">vetustus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">old, an&shy;
cient.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vexillation(n)">Vexillation (<etym lang="la">vexillatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
company of men of arms un&shy;
der one Standard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vexillary(n)">Vexillary (<etym lang="la">vexillarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Standard-bearer; also per&shy;
taining to a Standard or En&shy;
sign.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vial(n)">Vial (<etym lang="la">phiala</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a plain pot,
with a wide mouth; also the
general name to all plate,
serving for Wine or Water;
a Glass or Glass Bottle. Vials
of wrath, mentioned in the
Apocalipse, signifie Gods readi&shy;
ness to be fully revenged on
sinners.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viand(n)">Viande ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">meat, food,
sustenance, victuals, especial&shy;
ly of flesh. Often used in the
Holy Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viary(a)">Viary (<etym lang="la">viarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to the way. Fel&shy;
tham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viatic(a)">Viatick (<etym lang="la">viaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy; 
taining to a journey, or travel&shy;
ling by the way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viaticum(n)">Viaticum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">all
things necessary for a Tra&shy;
veller, be it in victual or o&shy;
ther things: The Blessed
Sacrament, as given to dying
people, is also so called by
the Fathers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viator(n)">Viator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a travelling
by the way, a way-faring&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viatorian(a)">Viatorian (<etym lang="la">viatorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
or belonging to the way,
travelling or journeying,
or serving to way-faring&shy;
men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vibration(n)">Vibration (<etym lang="la">vibratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
brandishing, shaking, or
wagging, as men do drawn
swords, when they threaten
others.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vibrissation(n)">Vibrissation (<etym lang="la">vibrissatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a quavering or warbling
in singing, a shaking a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicarious(a)">Vicarious (<etym lang="la">vicarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
is in stead or place of
another, that supplies an&shy;
other mans room, and
takes pains for him; as
an under-servant or Vi&shy;
car.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vice versa(n)">Vice versa ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">con&shy;
trary to what was before,
the former course being
changed into the opposit or
contrary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicenarious(a)">Vicenarious (<etym lang="la">vicenarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or belonging to the twen&shy;
tieth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicennals(n)">Vicennals (<etym lang="la">vicennalia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
solemn games and vows for
twenty and thirty years.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="tt3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicesimal(a)" lexeme="vicenarious(a)">Vicesimal 
Vicesim  </form> <xpln lang="en">the same with
 <xref>Vicenarious</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicinal(a)">Vicinal (<etym lang="la">vicinalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to Neighbors or
Neighborhood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicinity(n)">Vicinity (<etym lang="la">vicinitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
company of Neighbors, dwel&shy;
ling nigh one; Neighborhood,
highness, likeness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vicissity(n)" lexeme="vicissitude(n)">Vicissity 
 <etym lang="la">vicissitas</etym> 
or 
Vicissitude 
<etym lang="la">vicissitudo</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">changing or succeeding by
cours, the turn or course in al&shy;
tering, now one, now another,
an interchangeable course.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viscount(n)">Vicount <term lang="la">alias</term> Viscount
 (<etym lang="la">Vicecomes</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">signifies with us
as much as Sheriff . Between
which two words, I finde no
other difference; but that the
one comes from our Conque&shy;
rors, the Normans, and the
other from our Ancestors,
the Saxons . Viscount also sig&shy;
nifies a degree of Nobility
next to an Earl, which (as
Cam. Britan. pag.170. saith)
is an old name of Office, but
a new one of Dignity, never
heard of among us till Henry
the Sixth his days. But this
degree of honor is far more
ancient in other Countries.
See Cassan. de gloria Mundi.
parte 5. Consid.55.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="victim(n)">Victime (<etym lang="la">victima</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
Beast killed in Sacrifice for
Victory, an Oblation, a Sacri&shy;
fice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="victimate(v)">Victimate (<etym lang="la">victimo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to Sa&shy;
crifice, to make an Oblation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="victor(n)">Victor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Conque&shy;
ror, he that overcomes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vidame(n)">Vidame (<etym lang="la">Vicedominus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
honor in France, of which
there are but four, viz. That
of Chartres. 2. Amiens.
3. Chalons. And 4. of Gerbery.
in Beauvois. 

A Vidame was originally
the Judge of a Bishops Tem&shy;
poral Jurisdiction, or such an
Officer to him, as the Vicount
was to the Count or Earl, but
in process of time, of an
Officer, he became a Lord, by
altering his Office into a Fief,
held of the Bishoprick he
belonged to; so that even
to this day the Estate of all
Vidames depends of some Bi&shy;
shoprick, or is annexed to
the Temporalities thereof,
and therefore they are no
better then Seigneurs Medio&shy;
cres (as the French say)
though the first of that rank;
and in all other Priviledges
and Rights equal to Vicounts,
with some advantage of Cre&shy;
dit, in respect of high Juris&shy;
diction, which those have
usurped by degrees upon
their Earls; and these had at
the first, by the gift of their
Bishops.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="videlicet(adv)">Videlicet ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is to
say, to wit: It is usually
written thus (viz.) And in
the same sence we use (i. e.)
for id est, and sometime <expan type="">id est</expan>) a&shy;
lone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viduation(n)">Viduation  (<etym lang="la">Viduatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a di&shy;
viding, a leaving alone, a de&shy;
priving, a making widow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viduity(n)">Viduity (<etym lang="la">viduitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">wid&shy;
owhood, or the estate of a 


</page>

<page sig="tt4r">
widow; also lack of things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vietor(n)">Vietor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cooper,
that with hoops binds Ves&shy;
sels, or he that makes baskets,
or vessels of Osier, to be co&shy;
vered with Leather.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="view(n)">View,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a term of Hunt&shy;
ing, and signifies the print of
the foot of a Fallow-Deer in
the ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vigesimal(a)">Vigesimal (<etym lang="la">vigesimus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
taining to the twentieth in
number.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vigil(n)">Vigil (<etym lang="la">vigilia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a watch&shy;
ing, abstaining from sleep; a
watch by night, which they
used to divide into four parts.
The first Vigil began at six of
the clock in the Evening, and
continued till nine. The se&shy;
cond began at nine, and con&shy;
tinued till twelve: The
third was from twelve till
three: And the fourth was
from three till six of the
clock in the morning. This
word is often mentioned in
Scripture. Also the eve or
day next before any solemn
Feast, because then Christians
were wont to watch, fast and
pray in Churches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vigintivirate(v)">Vigintivirate (<etym lang="la">vigintivira&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Office of the Viginti&shy;
viri, or of twenty men in like
authority. Tacit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vigone(n)">Vigone ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a kinde of
Demicaster, or Hat of late so
called, from the fine Wool,
which for the most part they
are made of, borne by a kinde
of Sheep of Spain of that
name. And Codebeck (which
are a courser sort of Hats, 
and made for the most part
of Hair) took name from a
Town in Normandy, where
the best of that sort are
made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vigor(n)">Vigor ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">strength,
force, lustiness, courage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vigorous(a)">Vigorous (<etym lang="la">vigorosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
strong, firm, lusty, couragi&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vilify(v)">Vilifie (<etym lang="la">vilifico</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to make

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viper(n)">Viper (<etym lang="la">Vipera</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a vene&shy;
mous Serpent in some hot
Countreys, lying much in
the Earth, having a short tail,
which grates and makes a
noise as he goes; they are of
a yellow colour, and some&shy;
times red. The Male has but
one Tooth in every side, but
the Female more, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Virgo(pn)">Virgo ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one of
the Twelve Signs of the
Zodiack ; so called, because
as a Virgin is barren and un&shy;
fruitful, whilst she lives with&shy;
out the help of man; so
whilst the Sun continues in
this Sign, it brings forth no&shy;
thing, but onely ripens such
Fruit as the preceding part of
the year has brought forth.
Mi.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vitrean(a)" lexeme="vitrine(a)">Vitrean

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vitrification(n)">Vitrification (<etym lang="la">vitrificatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
glassiness, or the making of
Glass. 

Vitrification (says Dr.
Brown) is the last work of
fire, and when that arrives, 


</page>

<page sig="tt5v">
humidity is exhaled; for
powdered glass emits no fume
or exhalation, although it be
laid upon a red hot iron.
Vul. Er. fol.53.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vitus dance, St.(n)">St.Vitus his Dance,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a

tain malignant humor gender&shy;
ed in the body, of near kin
with the poison of the Taran&shy;
tula.</xpln></wordentry>

gor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vivency(n)">Vivency (from <etym lang="la">vivo</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a li&shy;
ving, or injoying life.</xpln></wordentry>

mans name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ulophone(n)">Ulophone (<etym lang="la">ulophonum</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a

substance, made of Misseltoe
Berries; also the black Ca&shy;
meleon Thistle, whose Root
is also venemous.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yule games(pn)">Vle,Yule, orVle-games,
</form> <xpln lang="en">in our Northern parts, are
taken for Christmas games, or
sports; from the French
<etym lang="fr">Nou&euml;l</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> Christmas, which
the Normans corrupt to <term lang="fr">Nuel</term> 
or <term lang="fr">Vle</term> . But Dr. Hammond 
thinks it more probable, that
Yule should be taken immedi&shy;
ately <class type="etymlang" lang="la">from the Latin</class> <term lang="la">Jubilum</term>,
as that signifies a time of re&shy;
joycing or festivity, &amp;c. See
his Answer to six Qu&aelig;ries, p.
464.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ultime(a)" lexeme="ultimate(a)">Vltime 
Vltimate 
 (<etym lang="la">ultimus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
last, final, extream, the fur&shy;
thest, or utmost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ultimity(n)">Vltimity (<etym lang="la">ultimitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the
lastness or end of a thing.
Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

a taking vengeance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umber(n)">Vmber,</form> <xpln lang="en">somewhat a sad

ers; also a Beast ingendred

Sheep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbilical(a)">Vmbilical (<etym lang="la">umbilicalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or pertaining to the Na&shy;
vil. Vmbilical Vein. See in <xref>Vein</xref>. 

Vmbilical Arteries, are two
Arteries marching from the
Navil, through Periton&aelig;um 
to the sides of the Bladder;
they are the first Arteries
that in the Infant are begot&shy;
ten. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbilicality(n)">Vmbilicality,</form> <xpln lang="en">the being
of a thing, at or in the midst;
as the Navil in the midst of
the Belly. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbrage(n)">Vmbrage (Fr. or <etym lang="fr">Om&shy;

also jealousie or suspition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbragious(a)">Vmbragious (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Vm&shy;

or casting a shadow; that is
done in the shade, or very pri&shy;
vately.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbratilous(a)">Vmbratilous,</form> <xpln lang="en">idem. Bac.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbrella(n)">Vmbrello (Ital. <etym lang="it"> Ombrella</etym>)
a</form> <xpln lang="en"> fashion of round and broad
Fans, wherewith the Indians 
(and, from them our great
ones) preserve themselves
from the heat of the Sun or
Fire; and hence any lit&shy;
tle shadow, Fan, or other
thing, wherewith women
defend their faces from the
Sun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="un(px)">Vn,</form> <xpln lang="en">is an English Priva&shy;
tive, which may be added at
pleasure to simple words, and
deprives them of their natu&shy;
ral sence; as un-accessible,
which cannot be come to; to
un-bewitch, un-deceive, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="union(n)">Vnion (<etym lang="la">unio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">peace, con&shy;
cord, agreement, the number
one. 

Vnion, is a combining
or consolidation of two
Churches in one, which
is done by the consent of the 
Bishop, Patron, and Incum&shy;
bent, &amp;c. See more of this in
Cowel. 

Vnion Pearls (so called
by Antiphrasis, because they
always grow in couples;
<term lang="la">Nulli duo reperiuntur indiscre&shy;
ti</term>, says Pliny; <term lang="la">Vnde nomen
unionum, scilicet, Roman&aelig; im&shy;
posuere delici&aelig;</term>) are the best sort
of Pearl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uniparous(a)">Vniparous (from <etym lang="la">unus</etym>
and <etym lang="la">pario</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that brings forth
but one at a birth. Dr.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="unison(n)">Vnison (Fr. <etym lang="fr">unisson</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
one; an oneliness; or lone&shy;
liness, a single or singleness,
A term in Musick, when two
Strings or Notes have one
and the same tone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="unity(n)">Vnity (<etym lang="la">unitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an uniting
or joyning two things or more
together; also concord, a&shy;
greement. 

Vnity of Possession in our
Common Law, is a joynt
possession of two Rights
by several Titles. For ex&shy;
ample, I take a Lease of
Land from one upon a cer&shy;
tain Rent; Afterwards I
buy the Fee simple; this
is an Vnity of Possession,
whereby the Lease is ex&shy;
tinguished, by reason, I,
who had before the occu&shy;
pation onely for my rent,
am become Lord of the
same, and am to pay my
rent to none but my self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="universality(n)">Vniversality (<etym lang="la">vniversa&shy;
litas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">generality, the whole 


</page>

<page sig="tt7r">
State, all in general.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="univocal(a)">Vnivocal (<etym lang="la">univocus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
signifying but one thing.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="univocally(adv)">Vnivocally (<etym lang="la">univoc&egrave;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
the same signification; A
term in Logick; wherein as
oft as the same word in the
same signification, that is,
meaning the same notion, is
applied to more, tis said to sig&shy;
nifie or be spoken univocally.
Per. Instit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vocabulary(n)">Vocabulary (<etym lang="la">vocabula&shy;
rium</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dictionary, a world
of words; it is also used
adjectively (from <etym lang="la">vocabula&shy;
ris</etym>) with relation to words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vocal(a)">Vocal (<etym lang="la">vocalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
hath a voyce, loud, making
a noyse, belonging to the
voyce. 

Vocal Nerves (<etym lang="la">vocales
nervi</etym>) are those noble sinews,
which have the vertue of
forming the speech. 

Vocal Prayer, is that which
is uttered by words, as men&shy;
tal is within the mind,
without pronunciation of
words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vocality(n)">Vocality (<etym lang="la">vocalitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
tune or sound of a voyce.</xpln></wordentry>

Calling or course of life.</xpln></wordentry>

ing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="volubility(n)">Volubility (<etym lang="la">volubilitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

lity to turn round, aptness to
roll, roundness, inconstancy,
mutability. Also sound or
quick speaking without im&shy;
pediment or staggering,
the falling or round going
of words by measure. Tho.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voluble(a)">Voluble (<etym lang="la">volubilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that

turning; having a round pro&shy;
nunciation or good delivery
of speech.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voluntary(n)">Voluntary (<etym lang="la">voluntarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
one that serves or does any

pulsion, of his own accord or
will.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voluntative(a)">Voluntative (from <etym lang="la">volun&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voluptable(a)">Voluptable (<etym lang="la">voluptabilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voracity(n)">Voracity (<etym lang="la">voracitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">glut&shy;

cessive eating.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vorago(n)">Vorago ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gulf, a
<emend err="Whirlpoool">Whirlpool</emend>, a Quagmire, or
marvellous deep place, that
sucks or swallows up even Ri&shy;
vers, and whereout nothing
can come; Also a Gluttonous
waste-gut, and spend all.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voraginous(a)">Voraginous (<etym lang="la">voraginosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
full of Gulfs, and Whirle&shy;
pits.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voration(n)">Voration (<etym lang="la">voratio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
vouring or eating up greedi&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vortumnus(pn)">Vortumnus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the god of
changing things, that is of
merchandize.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="votary(n)">Votary (from <etym lang="la">voto</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">he that
makes a vow, or binds himself
by vow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="votive(a)">Votive (<etym lang="la">votivus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that is
vowed or promised by vow;
Also that is or hath been
greatly wished or desired.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vouch(v)">Vouch (Fr. <etym lang="fr">Voucher</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
cite, pray in aid, or call to
aid in suit. It is a word much
used in our Common Law;
of which see Cowel; Also 


</page>

<page sig="tt8r">
to avow, or affirm boldly, to
avouch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vowel(n)">Vowel (<etym lang="la">vocalis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a letter
which makes a perfect sound
of it self, of which there are
five, a, e, i, o, u.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Urania(pn)">Vrania,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Muses,
to whom the invention of
Astrology is attributed; cal&shy;
led also the heavenly Muse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uranoscopy(n)">Vranoscopy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a spe&shy;
culation or view of the Hea&shy;
vens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urbane(a)" lexeme="urbanical(a)">Vrbane 
 or 
Vrbanical <etym lang="la"> vrbanus 
vrbanicus</etym>
</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to a City, ci&shy;
vil in curtesie, gentle in
speech and gesture, pleasant in
behaviour and talk, comely,
seemly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urbanity(n)">Vrbanity (<etym lang="la">urbanitas</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">cur&shy;
tesie, civility, civil life, good
manners, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urbicarian(a)">Vrbicarian (<etym lang="la">vrbicarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of
belonging to a City. And
Suburbicarian, under or with&shy;
in the jurisdiction of a City,
properly and specially attri&shy;
buted, by ancient Writers, to
a certain part of Italy near
adjacent to Rome; But ex&shy;
tended by Ruffinus, a barba&shy;
rous Author, to all those
Countries or Regions of
which Rome was then the Po&shy;
litical Head; viz. all the
West.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urent(a)">Vrent (<etym lang="la">urens</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">burning,
parching.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ureter(n)">Vreter ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Pipe
or Conduit by which the U&shy;
rine passeth from the Reins to
the Bladder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Urim and Thummim(pn)">Vrim and Thummim,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
light of the knowledge of
Christ, by the Word, toge&shy;
ther with perfection of ver&shy;
tue, and holy manners, Exod.
28.30. Thou shalt put in the
Brest-plate of Judgement, the
Vrim and Thummin . Who
made this Vrim and Thummim,
what it was, and of what
made, is very hard, if not un&shy;
possible to find out: Certain&shy;
ly, it was not reckoned a&shy;
mong the things wrought by
Art, but was given by God to
Moses alone, to put in the
holy Pectoral, as Levit.8.8.
and written of Christ, Colos.
2.3. Dan.8.13. Wilson. And
see Sir Walt. Ral. lib.2. fol.
395.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urinary(n)">Vrinary (<etym lang="la">urinarius mea&shy;
tus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the Pipe by which the
Piss runs out from the Blad&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urinator(n)">Vrinator ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">one that
dives or swims under water,
and fetches up Merchan&shy;
dize from the bottom. Dr.
Charl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urn(n)">Vrn (<etym lang="la">urna</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure of
liquid things, containing of
old two Gallons and a Pottle;
also the general name for a
Pitcher or Pot; but most
commonly taken for a Vessel
or Coffin, wherein the ashes of
the dead were kept, for the
old Romans were wont to
burn their dead bodies; Now
it is often taken for a Grave
or Sepulchre, also a vessel
wherein the Roman Pretor did
put the names of such as were
to be elected or tried by lot.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="tt8v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uroscopy(n)">Vroscopy ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an in&shy;
spection of Urines, or cast&shy;
ing of water, as Phisitians
do. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ursine(a)">Vrsine (<etym lang="la">ursinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or be&shy;
longing to a Bear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ursula(pn)">Vrsula ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
she Bear; a womans name,
heretofore of great reputati&shy;
on in honor of Vrsula the
Britan Virgin Saint, marty&shy;
red under Gods scourge,
Attila, King of the Hunnes.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urus(n)" lexeme="ure-ox(n)">Vrus orVre Ox,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
huge-bodied, hulk-backed,
short-horned, and red-eyed
wilde Ox. Pliny.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usquebaugh(n)">Vsquebagh orVskabagh</form> <xpln lang="en">
Irish Aqua vit&aelig;, the word in
that language importing as
much.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ustion(n)">Vstion (<etym lang="la">ustio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a burning
or searing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usucaption(n)">Vsucaption (<etym lang="la">uscaptio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">

on, or the attaining a thing
