ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usury(n)">Vsury (<etym lang="la">usura</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">usage;
the occupation of a thing;
Also money or moneys worth
given above the principal sum
for the lone of it; Interest,
use.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usurpation(n)">Vsurpation (<etym lang="la">usurpatio</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
an usurping, an unjust or
often using, a taking against
Right and Reason, an in&shy;
croaching on another mans
Right.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="utas(n)">Vtas (<etym lang="la">Octava</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
Eighth day following any
Term or Feast; As the
Vtas of Saint Michael, the
Vtas of Saint Hillary, the
Vtas of Saint Martin, the
Vtas of Saint John Baptist,
and the Vtas of the Blessed
Trinity, &amp;c. as you may read,
Anno 51. Hen. 3. Stat. con&shy;
cerning general days in the
Bench. 

And any day between the
Feast and the Eighth day, is
said to be within the Vtas;
The use of this is in the
Return of Writs, as ap&shy;
pears by the same Sta&shy;
tute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="utensil(n)">Vtensil (<etym lang="la">utensile</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">any
thing necessary for our use
and occupation; Houshold&shy;
stuff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uterine(a)">Vterine (<etym lang="la">uterinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
pertaining to the womb. 

Fratres Vterini, brothers
of the same Mother, that
came both of one Womb, or
Belly. Mr. Mont.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="utible(a)">Vtible (<etym lang="la">utibilis</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
may bee used, profita&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="utinam(n)">Vtinam ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class> <class type="pos">Adverb</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
God grant, Would to God;
it is sometimes used substan&shy;
tively in English, for a wish.
Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vultan(pn)">Vultan (<etym lang="la">Vulcanus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the

sometimes used for fire it
self; Or for any Work&shy;

tinually about the fire; Or

burns and casts out flame and
smoak.</xpln></wordentry>

sed, set out to the use of all

wounded. Feltham. A term in
Heraldry.</xpln></wordentry>

or wound.</xpln></wordentry>

he that healeth wounds, a
Chyrurgeon; Also used ad&shy;
jectively, which relates to
wounds or sores.</xpln></wordentry>

with crafty wiles or de&shy;
ceits.</xpln></wordentry>

pinor</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">craftiness, deceipt,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vultuosous(a)">Vultuosous (<etym lang="la">vultuosus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of

nance, or of a heavy and sad
look.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vulturine(a)">Vulturine (<etym lang="la">Vulturinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
of or <emend err="pertainining">pertaining</emend> to the ra&shy;
venous Bird called a Vulture,
or Cormorant; also grey co&shy;
loured.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uvula(n)">Vvula ( <class type="etymlang" lang="la">Lat.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little
peece of flesh in the inmost
roof of the mouth, which
sometimes hungs loose down&shy;
ward, and hinders from
speaking, and swallowing
meat; the Palate of the
mouth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uxorious(a)">Vxorious (<etym lang="la">uxorius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to a Wife; also
that is very indulgent, or fond
of a Wife. 
</xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="w"><alpha><f type="l"/>W</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wage(n)"><f type="l"/> WAge (from the
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Gager</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en"><expan type="">id est</expan> to
put in security for the perfor&shy;
ming of any thing; As
to Wage Law, and Wage de&shy;
liverance . 


</page>

<page sig="uu1v">
When an Action of Debt
or Detinue is brought against
one (upon some secret agree&shy;
ment, or contract had between
the parties, without Special&shy;
ty shewed, or other matter
of Record) for goods lent or
left with the Defendant, then
the Defendant may Wage his
Law, if he will, that is,
Swear upon a book, and cer&shy;
tain persons with him, that
he detains not the Goods,
nor ows any thing to the
Plaintiff in manner and form
as he hath declared. Terms of
Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wage law(n)">To Wage Law</form> <xpln lang="en">(in the
Common Acception) seems
to be, to follow, urge, drive
on or prosecute the Law, or
Law Sutes; as to Wage War is
 <term lang="la">pr&aelig;liari</term>, <term lang="la">bellare</term>, to drive on the
War, to fight in battails as
Warriors do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wain of the moon(n)">The Wain of the Moon
(from the ancient Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wan</etym>,
 <term lang="la">Quod significat defectum, indigen&shy;
tiam, inopiam, &agrave; lat. vanus,
quia evanescit</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the decrease
or declination of the Moon.
Hence also To look Wan, that is
pale, as being in a decaying
or defective health.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waive(v)">To Waive orWeive,</form> <xpln lang="en">is to
forsake. As to Waive the com&shy;
pany of Thieves. Stawnf. pl.
Cor fol.26.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waif(n)">Waif orWeif.</form> <xpln lang="en">The nine&shy;
teenth Chapter of the Grand
Customary of Normandy, is
entituled (De choses gaites)
and Latined by the Interpre&shy;
ter, <term lang="la">De rebus vaivis</term>, <expan type="">id est</expan> Of 
things waived, which are
there thus defined. <term lang="la">Vaiva
sunt res, vel alia, qu&aelig; nullius
proprietati attributa, sine posses&shy;
sionis reclamatione sunt inventa,
qu&aelig; usque ad Diem &amp; annum
servanda sunt</term> . This Weif or
things weived, are nothing
but things forsaken. The
Civilians call it <term lang="la">Derelictum</term> .
Bract. (lib. I. cap. 12 num.10)
reckons them <term lang="la">inter res, qu&aelig;
sunt nullius, ea qu&aelig; pro waivio
habentur; sicut de averiis, ubi
non apparet dominus</term>; where he
also saith, <term lang="la">Quod olim fuerunt
inventoris de jure naturali, &amp;
jam efficiuntur principis de jure
gentium</term> . This is a Regality
and belongs to the King, ex&shy;
cept it be challenged by the
owner within a year and a
day, as appears by Britton,
cap 17. Now the Kings in
their times have granted this,
and such like Prerogatives,
to Subjects within their Li&shy;
berties and Fees; so that
Waifs, Estrays, Things Lost, are
the Lords of the Franchise,
where they are found, but
must first be cried and pub&shy;
lished in Markets and Church&shy;
es near about, or else the year
and day runs not to the pre&shy;
judice of him that lost
them. 

Mr. Skene, <term lang="la">De verborum
signif. verbo</term>, Waif, saith Waif
is <term lang="la">pecus vel animal abberrans</term>,
which wanders and strays out
of the way from the known
Master, and being found by
any person within his bounds, 


</page>

<page sig="uu2r">
must be by him proclaimed
sundry Market days, and in
the Parish Church, and with&shy;
in the Sheriffdom; otherwise
the Detainer may be accused
of Theft, and it is lawful for
the owner to challenge the
Beast with in a year and a
day. 

The Expositor of Law Terms
also saith, Waif is when a
Thief has felloniously stoln
Goods, and being closely
pursued with Hue and Cry, or
else overcharged with the
burden or trouble of them,
for his ease or more speed,
flies away, and leaves the
Goods, or any part of them
behinde him; then the Kings
Officer, or the Reeve, or Bailiff
of the Lord of the Manor,
who has such Franchise of
Waif, may seize the Goods,
so waived, to the Lords use,
who may keep them, as his
own proper, except the
owner come with fresh Sute
after the Felon, and sue an
Appeal, or give in Evidence
against him at his Arraign&shy;
ment upon the Indictment,
and he be attainted thereof,
&amp;c. In which cases the first
owner shall have restitution
of his Goods, so stoln and
waived. Also if a man be pur&shy;
sued with Hue and Cry, as a
Felon, and leave his own
Goods, &amp;c. these shall be
taken as Goods waived and
forfeited, as if they had been
stoln. 

Waived also belongs to a 
Woman, that being sued in
Law, contemptuously refuseth
to appear, as the word Out&shy;
lawed doth to a man: For
Women cannot be out-lawed,
because they are not sworn in
Leets to the King, nor to the
Law, as Men are: so that a
Man is said Out-lawed, or
without the Law, to which
he was sworn, and a Woman
waived. Terms of Law.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Waldenses(pn)">Waldenses,</form> <xpln lang="en">took name
from one Waldo of Lions in
France, about the twelfth
Century, and held, They
were not bound to make pro&shy;
fession of their Faith, deni&shy;
ed the real Presence, Purga&shy;
tory, &amp;c. And condemned
the eating of Flesh, Eggs,
and Milk, &amp;c. See Rosses 
View, pag 223.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wake(n)" lexeme="country feast(n)">Wakes orCountrey
Feasts,</form> <xpln lang="en">were most usually
kept on the Sunday next after
that Saints day, to whom the
Parish Church was dedicated.
And these Feasts took Ori&shy;
gin from a Letter written by
Gregory the Great to Mellitus
Abbot, sent into England, in
these words. It may therefore
be permitted them (the Eng&shy;
lish) that in the Dedication days,
or other Solemn days of Martyrs,
they make them Bowers about the
Churches, and Feasting together,
after a good Religious sort, kill
their Oxen now to the refresh&shy;
ing of themselves, to the praise
of God, and increase of Charity,
which before they were wont to
offer up in Sacrifice to the Divel, 


</page>

<page sig="uu2v">
&amp;c. Bede Eccles. Hist. cap.30.
And they may be called
Wakes, because on the Vigil
of those Feasts, people were
wont to watch and pray, or
to awake from sleep at the se&shy;
veral Vigils of the night;
but now that Religious Cu&shy;
stom is prophanely converted
into rude Sports, and Glut&shy;
tonous Feasting for the most
part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walter(pn)">Walter (Germ. a mans
name, from<etym lang="gr">Waldher</etym>, for so
it is most anciently written)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Pilgrime, according to Re&shy;
neccius; others make it a
Wood-Lord or Wood-Man.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wapentake(n)">Wapentake,</form> <xpln lang="en">is all one with
that which we call a Hundred,
as appears by Bract. lib.3
Tract.2. cap. I. num. I. In
some Counties they are called
Hundreds, in others Wapen&shy;
takes, &amp;c. See more of this
in Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wardmote(n)">Wardmote,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Court
kept in every Ward in Lon&shy;
don. An. 32 Hen.8. cap.17.
ordinarily called among them,
the Wardmote Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wardwite(n)">Wardwit aliasWard&shy;
wyte,</form> <xpln lang="en">is to be quit of giving
money for keeping Watch
and Ward. Stows Survey, fol.
919.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warp(v)">Warp (from the old Sax&shy;
on, <etym lang="sx">awarp</etym> or <etym lang="sx">awurp</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to
throw or cast; hence we still
say a board warps or casts;
and in some parts of England
we call a Moul, a Mould&shy;
warp, which is as much as 
to say, a Cast-earth. Ver&shy;
stegan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wassail(n)">Wassail orWassale</form> <xpln lang="en">on
Twelf-day at night, or on
New-years Eve. The Origin
in the words of Verstegan,
thus. 'Lady Rowena, Neece
'to Hingistus, King of the Sax&shy;
'ons, as she was very beauti&shy;
ful, so was she of a very
'comely deportment, and
' Hingistus, having invited
'King Vertiger to a supper, at
'his new built Castle, cal&shy;
'led Thong-Castle, caused her
'after supper to come forth of
'her Chamber, into the Kings
'presence, with a Cup of
'Gold filled with Wine in
'her hand, and making, in
'very seemly manner, a low
'reverence to the King, said
'with a pleasing grace, and
'countenance in our ancient
'Saxon Language, Waes
'heal hlaford Eyning, which
'is, according to our present
'Speech, Be of health Lord
' King; for as (was) is our
'Verb of the preter-imperfect
'tence, signifying have been,
'so (Waes) being the same
'Verb in the Imperative
'Wood, and now pronoun&shy;
'ced (was) is as much to
'say, as, Grow, be or become,
'andWaesheal, by corrupti&shy;
'on of pronounciation after&shy;
'wards became Wassaile. The
'King, not understanding
'what she said, demanded it
'of his Chamberlain, who was
'his Interpreter, and when
'he knew what it was, he 


</page>

<page sig="uu3r">
'asked him, how he might
'answer her in her own Lan&shy;
'guage; whereof being in&shy;
formed, he said unto her
'Drinc heal, <expan type="">id est</expan> Drink health,
' &amp;c. Verst. p.101. 

I have also heard another
(but less handsom) etymolo&shy;
gy of this word Wassale, <term lang="la">quasi</term>,
Wash-ale ; because common
people do often, on those
nights, wash their throats
with Ale, the old Saxon 
liquor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waters of Shiloah(pn)">Waters of Shiloah,</form> <xpln lang="en">pro&shy;
perly waters, which came
from a Fountain at the Root
of Mount Sion, and ran
through Jerusalem with a still
and quiet course. Therefore
in Nehemiah 2. it is called the
Dragon or Serpents Well, be&shy;
cause the Waters of it crept
gently as a Serpent; but Fi&shy;
guratively it denoted the
Promise of help to the men of
Jersalem, against the Kings of
Syria and Israel, from Gods
power alone (without hiring
Forein forces) to repel their
enemies. Isai 8.6. The wa&shy;
ters of Shiloah, which run so
softly. See Psal.46. 4. Wil&shy;
son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Watling Street(pn)">Watling street,</form> <xpln lang="en">is one of
the four ways, which the Ro&shy;
mans are said to have made
here in England, and called
them, Consulares, Pr&aelig;torias,
Militares, Publicas . This
Street is otherwise called
Werlam-street, and leads from
Dover, to London, Dunstable,
and so to Westchester. An. 
39 Eliz. cap.2. The second
Street is called Ikenild-street,
beginning Ab Iconis, who were
the people inhabiting Norfolk,
Suffolk, and Cambridge-shire,
as Mr. Camden declares in his
Britan. pag 345. The third is
called Fosse, the reason of the
name he giveth, because he
thinketh it was ditched of
each side. The fourth is cal&shy;
led Ermyn-street, &amp;c. Of these
read more in the said Author.
pag.43,44. And in the first
Volume of Holinsheds Chro&shy;
nicle, cap.19.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Weald of Kent(pn)">Weald of Kent,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
woody part of the Country.
Cam. Britan pag 247. Verste&shy;
gan saith, ThatWald,Weald
andWold, differing in Vowel,
signifie one thing, to wit, a
Forest or Wood; for so the
(Teut.)Wald also signifies.
Yet I have observed that in
Leicester and York-shires those
places are now called Wolds,
which have little or no Wood
on them, but are rather a
Heathy, open, and campian
part of the Countrey; but
it is very probable those pla&shy;
ces were formerly Woods
or Woody. In a very an&shy;
cient Charter of the Ab&shy;
bey of Garradon in Leicester&shy;
shire, I finde Walda, as Latin
for Weald or Wold . From this
word Wald, came Waltham
Forest, anciently calledWald
ham forest. And VValde&shy;
grave, (an ancient name in
Norfolk) took denomination 


</page>

<page sig="uu3v">
from the disposing and over&shy;
seeing the Forrest, for so much
the name imports.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="way-bit(n)">Wea-bit orWay-bit,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a
word used in the North of
England, where if you ask how
far tis to such a place, they
answer, a mile and a Way-bit,
by which is understood a
mile and vantage, or a mile
and better. I find it <emend err="witten">written</emend>
Wea-bit in Mr Cleavelands Po&shy;
ems, but I should rather think
it Way-bit; <term lang="la">quasi</term>, a bit or part of
a way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weapon salve(n)">Weapon Salve,</form> <xpln lang="en">is that
by which a wounded person
is said to be cured, by apply&shy;
ing it to the sword or weapon
that made the wound; and
was first found out by Para&shy;
celsus. Of this see Dr. Charl&shy;
tons Paradoxes, p. 1.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wedding(n)">Wedding (<etym lang="la">nupti&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">comes
from the Germ. [<etym lang="gr">wed</etym>] <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">pig&shy;
nus</term>, a pledge; and wedde in
Scotland signifies so much at
this day. Skene.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weigh(n)">Weigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a certain weight
of Cheese or Wool, containing
256 pounds of Avoyr de pois .
And in some parts of this
land it signifies a certain
<emend err="quainty">quantity</emend> of corn (most com&shy;
monly of Barly or Malt) con&shy;
taining six Quarters, or forty
eight Strikes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weight(n)">Weights (<etym lang="la">pondera</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">there
are two sorts of them in use
with us; the one called Troy
weight, which has Twelve
ounces in the pound, and by
this, Pearl, precious Stones,
Electuaries, or Medicinal 
things, gold, silver and bread
are weighed; the other Avoir
du pois, which contains sixteen
ounces in the pound; by
this all other things are
weighed that pass between
man and man by weight, sav&shy;
ing onely those above named.
Why the one should be called
Troy weight, I have not lear&shy;
ned, though I read it <term lang="la">libram &amp;
unciam Trojanam</term>, as if it came
from Troy: The other seems
to be so termed by reason of
the more full weight; for <term lang="fr">A&shy;
voir du pois</term> in French is as
much as to say, to have good
weight; but by these words
<term lang="fr">Avoir du pois</term> are sometimes
signified such merchandize as
are bought and sold by this
kind of weight. Fleta lib.
2. cap.12. saith, Fifteen ounces
make the merchants pound;
which 'tis like, though an
ounce less, should be all one
in signification with the
pound <term lang="fr">Avoir du pois</term>, and the
other pound, called by Fleta,
Trone weight, plainly appears
to be all one with that, which
we call Troy weight . And I
find not Troy weight mention&shy;
ed by any other that ever I
read upon this subject, but
onely our own Countrimen.
See <xref>Tronage</xref>. One Phidon an
Argive is said to have been
the first finder out of Weights
and Measures. See <xref>Ounce</xref> and
 <xref>Sarplar</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="welkin(n)">Welken orWelkin ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a cloud, but now commonly
taken for the Sky, Element, or
Air.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="uu4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Welsh(pn)">Welch,</form> <xpln lang="en">the people of Wales,
which were the old Britains,
and those a people of the
Gauls ; from whence the Sax&shy;
ons (according to their man&shy;
ner of speech) instead of Gal&shy;
lish, called them Wallish, and
by abbreviation Walch  or
Welch. Verst. p.120.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="werewolf(n)">Were-wulf or Were-wolf 
(<etym lang="sx">were</etym> <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">in the old Sax.</class> was
sometimes used for man)</form> <xpln lang="en">this
name remains still known in
the Teutonick, and is as much
as to say Man-wolf ; which is
a certain Sorcerer, who having
annointed his body with an
Ointment, made by instinct
of the Devil, and putting on
a certain inchanted Girdle,
does not onely to the view of
others, seem as a Wolf, but to
his own thinking, hath both
the shape and nature of a Wolf,
so long as he wears the said
Girdle, and accordingly wor&shy;
ries and kills humane crea&shy;
tures. Of these sundry have
been taken in Germany, and
the Neatherlands. One Peter
Stump, for being a Were-wolf
and having killed Thirteen
Children, Two Women, and
One man, was at Bedhur, not
far from Cullen, in the year
1859, put to a very terrible
death. Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Westphalia bacon(n)">Westphalia Bacon,</form> <xpln lang="en">so cal&shy;
led from the Country Westpha&shy;
lia, a Province in Germany,
from whence it comes; which
Province is wonderfully sto&shy;
red with Acorns, that feed
Swine of an exceeding plea&shy; 
sant taste and nourishment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wharf(n)">Wharf (from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Werf</etym>, idem)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a broad plain
place near a Creek or Hithe
of the water, to lay Wares
upon, that are brought to
or from the water. New Book
of Entries. fol.3. col.3. Or it is a
working place for Ship&shy;
wrights.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wharfage(n)">Wharfage,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Fee due for
any thing that is landed at
the Wharf, or brought upon
the Wharf to be carried by
water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wharfinger(n)">Wharfinger</form> <xpln lang="en">is the Keeper
of a Wharf . An 7. Ed.6. ca 7.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whirlbat(n)">Whirlebat.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Whorle&shy;
bat</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whitehall(pn)">White hall</form> <xpln lang="en">in Henry the
eighths time was called York&shy;
house, as being the Arch Bishop
of Yorks house, otherwise
called Cardinal Wolsey; upon
whose conviction in a premu&shy;
nire it fell to that King, who
beautified and enlarged it, and
called it Whitehall.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whitsunday(pn)" lexeme="Pentecost(pn)" lexeme="Whitsontide(pn)">Whitsunday,Pentecost,
Whitsontide (<expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">albi solis tem&shy;
pus</term>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is a solemn Feast in memo&shy;
ry and honor of the coming
of the Holy Ghost upon the
heads of the Apostles, in
tongues, as it were, of fire.
( Act.2.3) Pentecost in Greek
signifies the fiftieth, it being
the fiftieth day after the Re&shy;
surrection. It is also called
Whitesunday, from the Catechu&shy;
mens, who were clothed in
white, and admitted on the
Eve of this Feast to the Sa&shy;
crament of Baptism. 


</page>

<page sig="uu4v">
Verstegan says it was anci&shy;
ently called Wied Sunday,
<expan type="">id est</expan> sacred Sunday; for wied or
wihed signifies sacred in the
old Saxon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whorlbat(n)">Whorlebat (<etym lang="la">c&aelig;stus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is
a Weapon with Plummets
of lead, used in Games for
exercise by the ancient Ro&shy;
mans.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whole-chase boot(n)">Whole-chase Boots,</form> <xpln lang="en">are
whole hunting, or large ri&shy;
ding Boots; and Demichase,
are, with the French, half hun&shy;
ting, or (as we call them)
Summer riding Boots; though
some of our Shoomakers do
ignorantly apply the word De&shy;
mi-chase to a certain colour of
the leather.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wicket(n)">Wicket (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Hu&shy;
isset</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a little door (com&shy;
monly where great Gates
are.)</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wildfire(n)">Wildfire</form> <xpln lang="en">(what it is, is well
enough known) was in&shy;
vented by the Grecians a&shy;
bout the year of our Lord
717, when Caliph Zulciman
besiedged Constantinople, and
therefore the Latines call it
 <term lang="la">Gr&aelig;cus ignis</term>. Heil.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="William(pn)">William ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gr">Teut.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">for
sweeter sound, drawn from
Wilhelm, which is inter&shy;
preted by Luther, much de&shy;
fence to many; as Wilwald,
Ruling many; Wildred,
much reverend fear, or aw&shy;
ful; Wilfred, much peace;
Willibert much increase.
Cam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wimple(n)">Wimple (Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wimpel</etym>) 
</form> <xpln lang="en">a Streamer or Flag; But
it is most commonly taken
for the linnen plaited cloth,
which Nuns and Religious
women wear about their
necks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winefrid(pn)">Winefrid, <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">if Saxon</class>, sig&shy;
nifies win or get peace; but
some conceive it to be <class type="etymlang" lang="br">a Brit&shy;
tish word</class>, corrupted from
<etym lang="br">Gwen Brewa</etym>.</form> <xpln lang="en">Brewa
was the Saints name at first,
but had the additionGwen
(which signifies white in the
Feminine Gender) from the
white circle that remained in
her neck, after she was revi&shy;
ved by Benno, the Priest, (as
the story goes) by joyning
her cut off head, to her dead
body. For it is a Tradition
among the Britans, that in the
very place where her head
was cut off by wicked Cra&shy;
dacus, there sprung the Well
that has to this day conti&shy;
nued under the name of St.
Winefrids Well in Flintshire;
by some esteemed to be the
most plentiful and miraculous
Spring in the<emend err="word"> world</emend>. Cam. in
part.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winfrid(pn)">Winfrid,</form> <xpln lang="en"> i. e. An Ob&shy;
tainer of Concord, or a
Win-peace; for so it signi&shy;
fies in the old Saxon. An
English man of that name,
was by means of Charls the
Great, made Arch-Bishop
of Magunce, by Pope Gre&shy;
gory the Second, and was
afterwards called Boniface;
he is accounted an Apostle of 


</page>

<page sig="uu5r">
Germany, for his preaching
and converting much people
to the Christian Faith in
Saxony, and thereabouts. At
Doccum in Friezland, hath
been reserved unto our time,
a Book of the four Gospels,
all written with his own
hand. Verst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wizard(n)">Wisard (perhaps from the
Sax.<etym lang="sx">Witega</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> a Prophet
or Foreteller of things to
come)</form> <xpln lang="en">or cunning man, the
Hebrews describe him thus;
he put in his mouth the bone
of a Bird and burned Incense,
and did other things, till he
fell down with shame, and
spake with his mouth, things
that were to come to pass.
We commonly take him for a
kinde of Witch, or one that
can tell where things are, that
were lost, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wiseacre(n)">Wiseacre (<class type="etymlang" lang="bl">from the Belg.</class> 
<etym lang="bl">Waerseggher</etym>, <term lang="la">ex</term><etym lang="bl">Waer</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan>
 <term lang="la">Versus</term> &amp;<etym lang="bl">Sagen</etym>, <expan type="">id est</expan> <term lang="la">Dicere</term>)
</form> <xpln lang="en">one that knows or tells
truth, but we commonly
use it <term lang="la">in malam partem</term>, for a
Fool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wisemen of Greece(n)">Wisemen of Greece</form> <xpln lang="en">were
seven.<xref> See Solon</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="witch(n)">Witch,</form> <xpln lang="en">is derived from the
Dutch <etym lang="du">Witchelen</etym> or <etym lang="du">Wiiche&shy;
len</etym>, which properly signifies
whinnying or neighing like a
Horse; also to foretel or pro&shy;
phecy; and <etym lang="du">Wiicheler</etym> signi&shy;
fies a Southsayer; for that
the Germans (from whom our
Ancestors the Saxons usually
descended) did principally
(as Tacitus tells us) divine 
and foretel things to come by
the whinnying and neighing
of their Horses; <term lang="la">hinitu &amp;
fremitu</term>, are his words. For
the definition, Mr. Perkins
( cap. I.) saith, Witchcraft is
an art serving for the working of
wonders, by the assistance of the
Divels, so far as God will per&shy;
mit . Delrio defines it to be,
An art, which by the power of a
contract, entred into with the
Divel, some wonders are
wrought, which pass the com&shy;
mon understanding of men . Lib. 
I. cap. 2. de Mag. Disq.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wittol(n)">Wittal,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Cuckold that
wits all, or knows all; that
is, knows himself to be a
Cuckold, which commonly
is the last man in the Parish,
that wits or knows the same.
Min.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Woden(pn)">Woden,</form> <xpln lang="en">among the old
Saxons was honored for their
God of Battel; the word
signifies Fire or Furious.
Hence we say, when one is in
great rage, that he is Wood ;
and hence we call Wednesday 
instead of Wodnesday, on which
day he was chiefly honored.
See Verst.59.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wonders of the world, seven(n)">Seven wonders of the
World,</form> <xpln lang="en">are these. 1. The
Pyramides . 2. Mausol&aelig;um .
3. The Temple of Ephesus.
4. The Walls of Babylon.
5. The Colossus of Rhodes.
6. The Statue of Jupiter O&shy;
lympicus. And 7. The Pha&shy;
rus or Watch Tower built by
Ptolom&aelig;us Philadelphus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wold(n)">Wold.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Weald</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>


</page>

<page sig="uu5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wool-driver(n)">Wooldrivers</form> <xpln lang="en">( A.2,3 Ph.
&amp; Ma. cap.13.) are those that
buy Wool abroad in the
Country of the Sheepmasters,
and carry it on horse-back to
the Clothiers, or Market
Towns to sell again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wool-staple(n)">Woolstaple.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Staple</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wool-winder(n)">Woolwinders,</form> <xpln lang="en">are such as
winde up Fleeces of Wool,
to be pack'd and sold by
weight, into a kinde of bun&shy;
dle, after it is cleansed, in
such manner as it ought to be
by Statute. And to avoid
such deceipt, as the owners
were wont to use, by thrust&shy;
ing in Locks of refuse Wool,
and such other dross to gain
weight, they are sworn to
perform that Office truly be&shy;
tween the owner and the
Merchant. See the Statute of
8 Hen.6. cap.22. and 23 H.8.
cap.17. And 18 Eliz. cap.25.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrangland(n)">Wranglands,</form> <xpln lang="en">seem to be
misgrown Trees, that will ne&shy;
ver prove Timber. Kitchin,
fol.169. 6.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED except in quotations (e.g., "wrong," a, 1).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wreath(n)">Wreath,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Boars-tail so cal&shy;
led by Huntsmen; also in
Heraldry, it is that which is
placed between the Mantle 
and the Crest, being most com&shy;
monly made of two coloured
silks, wreathed together; cal&shy;
led also a Torce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wreck(n)">Wreck (from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Va&shy;
rech</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is where a Ship perishes
at Sea, and no man escapes a&shy;
live out of it; the Civilians
call it Naufragium . This
Wreck being made, the goods 
that were in any part of the
Ship (being brought to Land
by the waves) belong to the
King by his Prerogative, or
to him to whom the King
has granted this priviledge.
An. 17 Edw.2. cap. II. But if
any person in the Ship come
to Land, it is no Wreck, no, if
either Dog or Cat escape a&shy;
live, the goods are the own&shy;
ners still, so he come within a
year and a day to claim them.
And for this the Statute is
plain, Westm. I. cap.4. An.
3 Edw. I. The Emperors of
Rome made no advantage of
this sad event, as appears Ti&shy;
tulo de Naufragiis, II. Cod.
And Richard the First had
some remorse of poor Sea&shy;
means miseries in this case;
for he <term lang="la">quietum clamavit Wreck
suis subditis</term>. Rog. Hoveden.
Parte post. Annal. fol.386.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wroth(a)">Wroth (from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Wreedt</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">angry, cruel, fierce,
inhumane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wreak(v)">Wreke (from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Wreken</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">to avenge or re&shy;
venge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wort(n)" lexeme="relewurt(n)">Wurt orWort ( <class type="etymlang" lang="sx">Sax.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Herb, andRelewurt (now
called Colewurt) an Herb,
much used for pottage in
times of old. The City
Wirtsberg in Germany (in
Latin <term lang="la">Herbipolis</term>) had that
name from the abundance of
Worts or Herbs, which grew
about the Hill sides by that
Town. Verst. 
</xpln>
<lemenote>
The term "relewurt" has not been found in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>
</wordgroup1>


</page>

<page sig="uu6r">
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="x"><alpha><f type="l"/>X.</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="xenodochy(n)"><f type="l"/> XEndochy (<etym lang="la">Xenodochi&shy;
um</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hospital.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Xeriff(pn)">Xeriff,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name by which
some Princes of Barbary are
instiled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="xerophagy(n)">Xerophagy (<etym lang="la">xerophagia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the eating dry meats.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="xerophthalmy(n)">Xerophthalmy (<etym lang="la">xeroph&shy;
thalmia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">soarness or bleared&shy;
ness of the eyes, when they
neither swell, nor run, but
onely look somewhat red, ha&shy;
ving little or no pain, but a
kinde of itching.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="xilinous(a)">Xilinous (<etym lang="la">xilinus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to Cotten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="xylobalsamum(n)">Xylobalsamum ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
sweet and odoriferous wood,
whereof Baulm naturally
comes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="xylopolist(n)">Xylopolist (<etym lang="la">Xylopola</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a
Woodmonger, or one that
sells Wood or Timber. </xpln></wordentry>

</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="y"><alpha><f type="l"/>Y.</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yardland(n)"><f type="l"/> YArdland (<etym lang="la">virgata terr&aelig;</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
is a quantity of Land so
called from the Sax. (Gyrd&shy;
lander) but not so certain a
quantity, as that it is the same
in all places; for in some
Countries it contains twenty
acres, in some twenty four,
in some thirty, according to
Mr. Lambert, in his Explica&shy;
tion of Saxon words, Verbo, 
Virgata terr&aelig;: This Yardland
Bracton calls Virgatam Terr&aelig;
( Lib 2. cap.10. &amp; 27.) but
he expresseth no certainty
what it contains. 

Mr. Noy in his Compleat
Lawyer, pag.57. saith, That
two Fardels of Land make
a Nook of Land, and four
Nooks make a Yardland, and
four Yardlands make a Hyde 
of Land; and four (but some
say eight) Hides make a
Knights Fee, the relief wherof
is five pound, and so ratably.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="year(n)">Year (<etym lang="la">annus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">was divided
by Julius C&aelig;sar into twelve
moneths, fifty two weeks,
three hundred sixty and
five days, and six hours,
wanting eleven minutes,
which odde six hours, every
Leap or Fourth year, make
the odde day in February .
The moneth is the twelfth
part of the Solary year, the
week is near the fourth part
of the moneth; the natural
week day, a seventh part of
the week, the Quadrant the
fourth part of the day, the
hour the sixth part of the
Quadrant, the Point the
fourth part of the hour; the
Moment or Minute about the
fifteenth part of the Point,
&amp;c. 

The Greeks observed the
Lunary year, that is twelve re&shy;
volutions of the Moon, three
hundred fifty and four days.
Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yeoman(n)">Yeomen orYemen,</form> <xpln lang="en">
seems to be one word 


</page>

<page sig="uu6v">
made by contraction of two
Danish words (Young Men)
which I gather out of Canu&shy;
tus Charter of the Forest,
Part I. fol. I. num 2. in these
words, <term lang="la">Sunt sub quolibet horum
quatuor ex mediocribus homini&shy;
bus, quos Angli (Leges&shy;
pend ) nuncupant, Dani vero
(</term>Young Men) <term lang="la">vocant, locati,
qui curam &amp; onus, tum viridis
tum veneris suscipiant</term> . These
Mr. Cam. in his Britan. pag.
105. placeth next in order
to Gentlemen, calling them
( <term lang="la">ingenuos</term>) whose opinion the
Statute affirms. Anno 16 R.2.
cap.4. Whereunto adde the
Statute An.20. ejusdem Regis,
cap.2. 

Sir Thomas Smith in his Re&shy;
pub. Angl. lib. I. cap.23. calls
him a Yoman, whom our Laws
call <term lang="la">Legalem hominem</term>, which
(says he) is in English a Free&shy;
man born, that may dispend of
his own Free-land, in yearly
revenue, to the value of forty
shillings sterling; and writes
a discourse touching their
estate and use in this Com&shy;
monwealth: The former E&shy;
tymology of the name he
likes not, making question,
whether it comes of the
Dutch (<etym lang="du">Yoncker</etym>) or not,
which in the Low-Countries
signifies a mean Gentleman,
or a Gay-fellow; but he
that hath added the Margi&shy;
nal Notes to that Book,
seems to draw it from the
Saxon (Geman) which sig&shy;
nifies a married man. 

Verstegan (cap.10.) saith,(Gemen) among the ancient
Teutonicks, and (Germein)
among the modern, signifies
as much as Common, and
that the first letter G. is in
this word, as in many others,
turned into Y, and so written
Yemen, and that therefore
Yemen or Yeomen signifies
Commoner . 

Yoman signifies an Officer
in the Kings House, who is in
the middle place, between
the Serjeant and the Groom;
As, Yoman of the Chaundry, 
and Yoman of the Scullery, An.
33 Hen.8. cap.12. Yoman of
the Crown. Anno 3 Edw.4.
cap.5. And 22 ejusdem, cap. I.
And 4 Hen.7. c.7. This word
( Yongmen) is used for Yomen
in the Statute of 33 Hen.8.
cap.10.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yex(v)">To Yex,</form> <xpln lang="en">is that we do,
when we have the Hicket or
Hick up; some take it, to sob
or sigh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="youncker(n)">Yoncker ( <class type="etymlang" lang="bl">Belg.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a lusty
Lad, a gay-fellow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yule(pn)">Yule.</form> <xpln lang="en"><xref> See Vle</xref>. 
</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="z"><alpha><f type="l"/>Z.</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zachary(pn)"><f type="l"/> ZAchary (<class type="etymlang" lang="he">Heb.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the me&shy;
mory of the Lord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zane(pn)">Zane ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the name of
John in some parts of Lom&shy;
bardy, but commonly used
for a Silly John, a simple 


</page>

<page sig="uu7r">
fellow, a servile drudge, or
foolish Clown, in any Co&shy;
medy or Interlude. Flo.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zany(n)">Zanni ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">men, that
with foul mouths, unseemly
speeches, disfigured faces,
mimique gestures and strange
actions, profess to procure
laughter; used also for cross
biting, or cunning-catching
knaves. Charact. of a L. Diur&shy;
nal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zecchin(n)">Zecchine ( <class type="etymlang" lang="it">Ital.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a coyn of
Gold currant in Venice worth
about seven shillings and six
pence sterling. But the Turk&shy;
ish Zecchine Sir Hen. Blount
 values at nine shillings ster&shy;
ling. Voyage Levant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zealot(n)">Zelots (Zelotes)</form> <xpln lang="en">they that
fear lest the thing they love
should be common to another,
they that envy at one, or as&shy;
say to follow another in living;
but most commonly used, for
those that are zealous, fervent
or hot in matters of Religi&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zelotypy(n)">Zelotypie (<etym lang="la">zelotypia</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">jea&shy;
lousie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zenith(n)">Zenith ( <class type="etymlang" lang="ar">Arab.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the point
of the Firmament directly o&shy;
ver ones head, wheresover he
be; called the vertical point.
See <xref>Nadir</xref>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zephirus(pn)">Zephirus ( <class type="etymlang" lang="gk">Gr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">the West
wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zereth(n)">Zereth,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hebrew mea&shy;
sure of nine inches.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zero(n)">Zero ( <class type="etymlang" lang="fr">Fr.</class>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cyphre in A&shy;
rythmatick, a thing that
stands for nothing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zodiac(n)">Zodiack (<etym lang="la">zodiacus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">is an
oblique imaginary circle in 
the Firmament, dividing the
Sphear athwart the &AElig;qui&shy;
noctial into two points, viz.
the beginning of Aries and
Libra ; in the midst whereof
is the Eccliptick line; Its ut&shy;
most limits are the two Tro&shy;
picks, Cancer and Capricorn ;
its length Three hundred and
sixty degrees, and breadth
Sixteen. It is divided into
Twelve Signs, Six Northern&shy;
ly and Six Southerly; the
Northern are Aries, Taurus,
Cancer, Gemini, Leo, Virgo ; the
Southern, Libra, Scorpio, Sagit&shy;
tarius, Capricornus, Aquarius,
Pisces ; he turns upon his own
Poles from West to East.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zoilus(pn)">Zoilus,</form> <xpln lang="en">was a back-biting
Poet, who wrot against Ho&shy;
mers Works, from whence he
was called Homeromastix, <expan type="">id est</expan>
Homers scourge . Hence all en&shy;
vious persons, or such as back&shy;
bite or carp at other mens
works are called Zoilists.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zone(n)">Zone (<etym lang="la">zona</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">a Girdle; In
Cosmography it signifies a di&shy;
vision made of the Heavens
into five parts, whereof one is
extream hot, two extream
cold, and two temperate.
The hot or torrid Zone, is all
that part of the Heavens,
which is contained between
the two Tropicks of Cancer 
and Capricorn, in which Zone
the Sun continually keeps his
course. The two cold or fri&shy;
ged Zones are situate between
the two Polar Circles, and the
very Poles, continually want&shy;
ing the neighborhood of the 


</page>

<page sig="uu7v">
Sun; The two temperate Zones
are betwixt the Tropicks of
Cancer and the Artick, and be&shy;
twixt the Tropick of Capricorn,
and the Antartick Circles, en&shy;
joyning an indifferency be&shy;
tween heat and cold; So 
that the parts next the torrid 
Zone are the hotter, and the
parts next the frigid Zone are
the colder. These five Zones
are disposed according to the
order of the five Zones in
Heaven. 

Ovid. 

 <term lang="la">Utque du&aelig; dextra C&oelig;lum, totidemque sinistra
Parte secant zon&aelig;, quinta est ardentior illis:
Sic onus inclusum numero distinxit eodem
Cura Dei, totidemque plag&aelig; tellure premuntur.
Quarum qu&aelig; media est, non est habitabilis &aelig;stu;
Nix tegit alta duas; totidem inter utramque locavit
Temperiemque dedit mist&aacute; cum rigore flamma</term> . 

Zone also signifies a Soul&shy;
diers Belt or Marriage Girdle;
the Souldiers Belt was lined
in the inside, where, when
they went to war, they put
their money; Whence Horace
saith, of a man that has lost
his money; <term lang="la">Zonam perdidit</term> . 

Young Maids when they
were married, were wont to
have a marriage Girdle, tied
about their middle, which
their Husband, the first night
of their Marriage, did untie;
whence <term lang="la">Zonam solvere</term> has
been translated, to deflowr a
Virgin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zonarious(a)">Zonarious (<etym lang="la">zonarius</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">of or
belonging to a Girdle, Purse,
or Zone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zonigrism(n)">Zonigrism (<etym lang="la">zonigrismus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Instrument with a long and
narrow neck, to convey po&shy;
tions into the <emend err="stromack">stomack</emend>, with
little taste of bitterness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zoography(n)">Zoography (<etym lang="la">zoographia </etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
the painting or picturing of 
beasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zoographer(n)">Zoographer (<etym lang="la">zoographus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Painter or one that draws
the pictures of beasts. Dr. Br.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zoophyte(n)">Zoophytes (<etym lang="la">zoophyta</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">that
are in part living creatures, in
part plants, as Oysters, Spun&shy;
ges, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zygostatical(a)">Zygostatical (<etym lang="la">Zygostaticus</etym>)</form> <xpln lang="en">
belonging to the pound
weight of Sixteen ounces, or
to a Clark of a Market that
looks to weights. 
</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>
</section>
